author: {'steamid': '76561197980381118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 11240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11238, 'last_played': 1712016023}
review:
To steal a quote from Henry Miller, Divinity: Original Sin 2 is like a wh*re. From a distance she seems ravishing, you can't wait until you have her in your arms. And five minutes later you feel empty, disgusted with yourself. You feel tricked.

At the start, it seems like the game ought to be a huge improvement over its predecessor. There are more options for character creation. There is a greater focus on your party members. The combat promises a wide variety of approaches to encounters, limited only by your imagination. But after a while, you'll start to realize that the freedom the game offers is an illusion.

Perhaps the biggest bone of contention is the armour system. Instead of reducing damage or making your enemies harder to hit, it instead acts an additional set of hitpoints, divided into magic armour and physical armour. This armour must be depleted before you can start doing damage to an enemy or start applying status effects against your enemy, and since the armour is divided into two categories the game strongly encourages the player to go with all-physical or all-magical parties. On my first play-through I foolishly went with one spellcasting character in my party, which meant that were basically doing bugger all to the enemy while the rest of the team were the ones doing damage.

Surfaces make a return from the first game, and while they aren't a bad idea in practice they become so obstrusive as the game goes on that at times it feels you're spending more time putting out fires than fighting the enemy. And this game even introduces "cursed" surfaces that are even harder to get rid of!

The game's encounter design is awful, packed to the gunwales with "Gotcha!" encounters that start out with the player suddenly being thrown into combat where the enemy will invariably go first (regardless of how many points you put into Wits) and then proceed to insta-gib one of your party members. So you reload and try a different strategy, many of which are completely absurd. For example, in one encounter, my party faced off against a witch, who opened combat by INSTANTLY nuking my party. The solution? Have one character engage her in dialogue, and have another teleport her over to another powerful NPC, who can deal with her handily. When you "break" an encounter like this, you'll probably feel clever the first time you do it, like you've outsmarted the developers. But then you realize that those developers deliberately designed the game like this, and suddenly it feels cheap.

And then there's the writing...oh dear. I'm convinced that whoever wrote Divinity: Original Sin 2 was either a sociopath or someone whose entire socialization occured on an unmoderated internet forum.

The first Original Sin was quite silly, and at times it felt like it was trying to summon the spirit of Terry Pratchett. The humour didn't always work, and the jokes didn't always land, but I found it to be a welcome change from the obscenely po-faced and self-serious Pillars of Eternity. But with Original Sin 2, the writer seems to have caught the disease that a lot of writers succumb to, which is the feeling that they aren't being taken seriously. So they decided to fill the story with the same tired grimdark cliches that have been plaguing fantasy settings for over a decade now. Fantasy racism! Religious fanaticism! Oppressed mages! At the same time, however, they also retained some of the absurd humour of the first Original Sin, resulting a game that's just...tonally confused. One moment you'll be treated to the horrific sight of people being magically lobotomized, and the next you're speaking with a talking squirrel reading on an undead cat. Just what the hell am I supposed to FEEL when presented when presented with this sort of thing?

Well, one thing's for certain, which is that the writing in Original Sin 2 makes me feel bored, irritated, and bewildered.

Nearly every NPC is some variation of vile, loathsome, irritating, contemptible, or monstrous. Every faction is corrupt and debased. Talking to people more often than not results in a barrage of insults, condescension, and mockery, for no other than reason than you dared to engage them in conversation. I could count maybe two or three individuals who weren't irredeemable knobheads, and those that weren't usually had nothing to offer except some sob story. Did you think that talking to animals might provide some much-needed levity? Well, you'd be wrong, because they're all sob stories, too! And your party members? Well, with the possible exception of the dwarf and the bard, they're also a bunch jerks and edgelords.

By the end of game, I wanted to side with the bad guys, just so I could finally destroy this miserable, hateful world.

I know I'm harping on the game's joyless tone a lot, and that's because it's so INESCAPABLE. You can't play Original Sin 2 without it burrowing into your brain like some kind of malignant tumour. Really, I fail to see the appeal in playing a game that feels like being confronted by a bully in a high school locker room, or working at a customer service job in a world populated exclusively by the worst sort of Karens. It's a tabletop game run by a DM with nothing but utter hatred and scorn for the players. What's fun about that?

Nothing, that's what.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997050459', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2811, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2811, 'last_played': 1710877515}
review:
I'm in the final act of the game, and I'm done. I've had to force myself to play this far and I just can't do it anymore. I have absolutely no idea why this game is so highly rated. The combat CAN be good, but most of the time it's an absolute slog. The game loves to throw an insane amount of enemies at you to really slow things down. I'll give you an example: 

There's a fight in the second act of the game at an oil drill where you have to fight a handful of magisters. The fight triggers once you get to the top of the oil platform, and if you hit the dialog checks, you can have one extra guy in the fight. So you're fighting the magisters, no biggie. Then halfway through the fight, an absolute TON of oil blob monsters spawn all over the ground, completely surrounding the platform. But that's fine, you have the high ground right? Wrong. These things can jump clear across the map and land on the platform right next to you. Okay, so deal with the ones on the platform, then launch fireballs at the ones on the ground. They're made of oil, they should explode. And they do. Problem is, that sets the ENTIRE ground on fire because everything is covered in oil. And the blobs that don't die from the initial explosion...well, they turn into fire blobs, so you've just created the most deadly situation possible. So you reload and go back to the platform, start the fight over again. This time you make sure not to use any fire attacks (making your fire mage absolutely useless) so the oil blobs won't turn into fire blobs. Well guess what? There are oil barrels on the ground and at some point during the fight, they will just explode. You didn't shoot them. If a blob attacked one of the barrels, it still shouldn't have exploded, because the blobs don't deal fire damage. The barrels just randomly explode. So now you have to deal with fire blobs whether you like it or not, and 90% of the battlefield is covered in fire. But that's okay, your other mage has a rain spell that should put out the fire, right? Nope. This is CURSED fire, so water doesn't put it out. The only way to deal with cursed surfaces is to cast Bless on them, which uses Source...a very limited resource you need for your strongest combat abilities. It's a very long, tedious battle that drags on forever. Most fights play out like this, with an overwhelming number of enemies and deadly surfaces. 

So what about the story, is it any better? No. Every faction in this world is some form of bad guy and the world is being invaded by monsters. Your only goal is to ascend to godhood and deal with the problem yourself. Oh but guess what, all your companions want to ascend to godhood too. And at a certain part in the story, if you don't have a high enough persuasion skill or a good relationship with them, they'll just straight up leave your party. They're all incredibly one-dimensional and boring, so losing them wouldn't be that big of a deal...except you've invested 30+ hours into them and they're an integral part of your team. I had to reload a save and respec my main character into higher persuasion, just so I could convince the lizard prince to stay with me. Even though I'd done his main sidequest, he didn't like me enough to stay on his own, and I wasn't about to lose my tank. Of course, ultimately it didn't matter, because I just can't take any more of this game. The story is boring, the characters are boring, the world is boring, and the fights are incredibly tedious. 

If you want to play a game where every faction is villainous but done well, go play Tyranny. If you want to play a game where the world is being invaded and you have to stop it, go play Pathfinder: Wrath of the Righteous. This game just feels awful to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135522537', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 15436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15005, 'last_played': 1712542744}
review:
In my eyes this game is overrated and extremely flawed in execution and it serves as a great tutorial on how NOT to design a gameplay loop. This game makes about all of the errors of a game like Underrail, but made by a much larger and more equipped studio. It's fairly easy to find many good write ups of the games strong points, so here I will note some of its weaknesses. 

1) By far, the games biggest shortcoming is the way it handles level-gating of it's content combined with the drought of XP. Basically, you have to explore the wide open game areas in a very strict order or you will run into enemies that are virtually impossible at your current level. This frequently turns into save-scumming for hours, trying to find the next level-appropriate encounter. Exploration is PUNISHED with death. While games based on D&D generally scale linearly, this game scales exponentially, making a difference of 1 level almost impossible to overcome. This wouldn't be THAT big of a deal if it weren't for the fact that a good portion of the XP is easily miss-able, making it way too easy to become under-leveled. You can't skip ANYTHING or you will fall behind on XP. It seems they made this problem worse in the definitive edition, nerfing some of the games most generous XP rewards and making it even harder to stay on track. It cannot be overstated how much this brings the game down. 

2) The gear grind is another thing, related to the issue above. In addition to character power levels scaling wildly, their equipment does as well. What this means is that every time you level up, you need to take a break from exploring to update the weakest gear of your party. Cool, you gotta take a mandatory shopping trip every level, that sucks a lot but OK. What is worse is how this system completely devalues unique equipment. That cool unique level 12 sword you had to complete a quest for is just about always worse than a boring common level 14 sword. In addition, if you defy all odds and somehow manage to get access to a weapon above your level, seemingly miles ahead of your current gear, it is useless; your character receives a massive accuracy penalty for even holding it. This also comes with the opposite problem; if you go back to finish a quest you are well past the level of (which you pretty much have to for XP), you will be rewarded with useless gear. Further, if you level up mid-dungeon, and the game expects you to be, say, level 13 at the beginning, and level 14 by the end, prepare for that level 14 fight to suck. You're level 14, you're armor and weapons should be level 14, right? Nope, not unless you haul it back to town for your mandatory shopping trip. 

3) My third gripe with the game is it's crafting system. I think crafting systems don't belong in most games they get put into, this game included, though I think this is a weaker criticism than those above. My issue with these systems comes from the observation that they all seem to turn into boring busywork to pad out the game time. For example, why does every craft need a progress bar? To waste your time. I have no idea what items I should be grabbing because some recipes require jars, teddy bears, sticks, paper, and all of the other random junk you come across. Do I just pick up everything? If I do, the game turns into an inventory management nightmare. Does anyone actually find this fun? I would rather be exploring, solving puzzles, or fighting void-woken than this. For god's sake, just let my character pay someone to do this crap for me!!

4) Perhaps the most frustrating issue is the botched mouse control. What you mouse over is not what you click on. You will frequently unintentionally walk over and loot stuff during combat because the game decided that you clicked on a corpse rather than the enemy. Sometimes, you have to mouse into the middle of the air in order to select something. This is the biggest BS sometimes and makes me want to swear and uninstall. So many unnecessary reloads from this crap.

5) My final criticism is that the character building and combat system, and how they intertwine, is utter trash. The gist is that, due to the new armor system, you MUST maximize damage over everything. The character building system seems robust until you realize that almost all options simply don't maximize damage and thus are non-viable. All good builds are essentially the exact same thing; maximize your damage attribute/ability and splash poly, scoundrel, etc for OP abilities, simple as that. The game is also quite difficult and really expects up-to-par characters, so good luck making it work without hours of research. 

Final Thoughts
The more time I spend playing this game, the less I like it. If you can get past all of the sloppy mechanics, build a team of bad MFs to take on this games challenges, it can be pretty good fun, for a bit. However, most of the time spent playing this game seems to be A) grabbing heaps of "crap you might need later", B) reloading because you got OHKOd by an enemy 1 level above you, C) reloading again because you mis-clicked and wasted your turn in combat, or D) slowly prodding the game world for the next level appropriate chunk of content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075234627', 'num_games_owned': 1071, 'num_reviews': 364, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1711708555}
review:
I've played my fair share of RPGs, including the first Divinity: Original Sin. However this one did not sit well with me. The armor system and combat in general did not feel good. There's no indication of what level a quest is geared towards, meaning you need to massively save-scum even in the first area. Walk 10 steps too far and you get into an unwinnable fight, perhaps with teleporting crocodiles or something else that will AoE-slaughter your party in the first turn.

Maybe I've gotten old and impatient or simply outgrown the genre, but this is not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198800872623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8730, 'last_played': 1707702873}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198317988078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1790, 'last_played': 1678929440}
review:
I tried very hard to like this game and got all the way through Act 1, but it never really clicked for me. The way the dialogue is written for your character is unlike many other RPGs I've played, written in 2nd person in such a way that you only get the broad strokes of what your character is saying.

Playing an Origin character, the Red Prince, had mixed results for me. I picked him because the general consensus is custom characters feel a bit lacking in comparison. But it was plainly obvious I was playing him far nicer than the writers intended him to be, because every one of his unique dialogue options ran contrary to how I intended to play him. I think this level of choice could actually be a detriment, i'd rather Larian have done something closer to Deus Ex where the Origin characters at least had more spoken dialogue and didn't give you 4 dialogue options every time for a response, where most of those result in the sameish reply from the NPCs. It's just fluff at that point. BG3 has this issue too but to a lesser extent.

The gameplay was... too messy. Larian struggles to make a UI that doesn't feel user-hostile and messy as hell to use. BG3 after this managed to get to what I consider passable - DOS2's is just not enjoyable to interact with and requires constant micromanaging to keep usable, and that's time spent away from interacting with the core gameplay and the story. DOS2's turn-based combat feels slow and clunky compared to similar games, and the surface system would have benefitted immensely from using a grid. Animations are slow and lack weight, prepare to hear "I'll yield to none!" quite a bit, and be forced to often choose between moving and attacking since they draw from the same resource of action points. 

The leveling system is a bit too freeform for my tastes. There's no classes per se, simply tons of skills you can choose form an level up in, but to me it is nice to have the structure of a class but the option to branch into others via multiclassing or the like. This felt like utter choice paralysis for me as the game doesn't do a particularly great job easing you into its mechanics either. At some point it started feeling like I needed to pull up the wiki and build guides just to operate at a base level.

Gear progression is tied to the merchant's randomized inventories and did NOT feel like it kept up with enemy levels unless you were grinding out every single quest in an area, which didn't feel good. By the time I reached the end of Act 1, the challenge felt reasonable for the Act boss, but as soon as Act 2 began I felt miles behind the level curve once again and put down the game because I wasn't down to spend more than 28 hours in Act 1 again. 

It's a shame though because I was enjoying the story, as grim and dark as it was from the outset. The art style is nice, though the presentation is extremely basic when it comes to dialogue unfortunately. I was interested in the world Larian had crafted and the Lizards, as lazily named as they are, were my favorite race playing as the Red Prince. 

I gave it a good shot but this game isn't for me, it just never clicked, but there's something good here that you might be able to enjoy better than me depending on your tastes. The game also is free of nickle-and-dimeing predatory microtransactions, so I'd sooner recommend it than a lot of triple-A titles right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088598864', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1991, 'last_played': 1726663745}
review:
Overrated. Game is terribile at explaining what to actually do. 
Main Story is dry, did not catch me after 32h. Same goes for companions.
I got like 15 sidequests, but i dont know what to do in one of them. 
The fights in this game are not really "hard", they are just unfair most of the time, what makes them "hard". The pure amount of items and crafting materials they throw on you is just insane. Funny that most of that stuff is just useless. Inventory managment is a pain. 

This game is just not motivating at all. I really ttried to like this game, but after 32h i gave up, its impossible. Maybe if i turn down difficulty and read every single text in this game, every book/note, talk to every NPC and spend hours tto study all this i can get further... but honestly for doing this the game should be fun at least a bit.

If you are really a die hard fan of cryptic games this might be it for you. For me def not.
I can see some qualities in this game, but more than a 5/10 i can not rate it so far,

author: {'steamid': '76561198287437725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2082, 'playtime_at_review': 3850, 'last_played': 1736714402}
review: Over hyped. Game is obsessed with stun locks and negative status effects. Every item you get that helps raise your armor takes away from every other stat you are building towards from the beginning. You want to run a certain build? GL since most items are random and so are the stat bonuses that attached to it. So if you want to sit there and watch your entire screen be nothing but fire every single fight and 1-2 enemies focusing on stun locking your character for the entire fight until you're dead then this is the game for you. Very dated game, using AP system if you dont perfectly click on the box of the character you will waste 1 of the 4 AP you get because your character moved when you actually wanted to attack. I tried so hard to get past all the BS of this game but honestly I just don't enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198418752573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 7389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2499, 'last_played': 1734495375}
review: This game was great for the first three acts but as soon as i hit the fourth it has been one of the worst things ive ever played, every fight has some gimmick, either its them respawning over and over again or every fight has at least two people that WILL charm you or madden you, or freeze, or stun, or knock down loop. It quickly became impossible to even get a single turn for myself. Theres also no fights in act 4 that are not level 20 based so if you arent 20 by the time you reach it it quickly becomes miserable. I can barely progress anymore because its never ending nonsense in the last act and at this point im ready to just drop the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198317866221', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 8167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8167, 'last_played': 1724867658}
review:
[h3]From Hero to Hoarder: My Descent into Inventory Madness[/h3]
[i]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/i] isn’t just a game—it’s an elaborate psychological experiment to see how much loot one person can carry before their soul leaves their body. I knew I had a problem when I spent 20 minutes comparing two identical belts. IDENTICAL. Except one had +1 Constitution, and the other made my rogue look like they shopped at Fantasy Hot Topic. Guess which one I picked? Trick question: I didn’t. I stared at both, paralyzed by indecision, until I remembered I was supposed to be saving Rivellon.

The story? Oh, it’s phenomenal, assuming you can tear yourself away from sorting your gear like a D&D Marie Kondo. Combat? It slaps, if you enjoy screaming internally when an enemy sets the floor on fire and all your well-laid plans go up in flames. Literally. It’s the kind of game that rewards creativity, punishes stupidity, and forces you to use your last resurrection scroll on the sh*ttiest character in the party—usually because you set them on fire.

But let’s be real: I didn’t save the world. I spent hours reorganizing barrels and gold stacks, only to be ambushed by a group of skeletons wearing better armor than me. Guess who spent 30 minutes after that comparing stats again? That’s right. Me. The real boss of this game isn’t [spoiler]Braccus Rex[/spoiler]; it’s my inability to let go of +1 Wits.

author: {'steamid': '76561198271683008', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1723403032}
review:
Gameplay itself feels solid albeit repetitive, puzzles feel genuinely clever and finding solutions feels rewarding, but the world feels flat and lacks reactivity.  You can go on murder sprees without even superficial consequences, and from this there is a lack of permanence or a sense of a real world to care about, even when writing itself is serviceable enough. You can murder magisters in Fort Joy and the other ones are just manning their posts thoughtlessly waiting for you to show up, never replacing those posts, never trying to address mass murder of other magisters, not caring about you until you are immediately visible AND trespassing. 
Fort Joy tries to have this sense of scarcity and urgency but instead gives incentives for the exact opposite.  Instead of urgency, it is best to meander.  Instead of real scarcity, you are forced into tedious rituals like bedroll spamming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111038144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 21719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21719, 'last_played': 1696286358}
review:
I would recommend this game only to people that are either into getting ambushed all the time or have a group of friends to laugh with in this game. Luckily I had the latter. It is astonishing to me that this game is so loved even though the playthrough is rather linear and mechanics of combat is split into 3 scenarios.

Scenario 1: you get ambushed and you die
Scenario 2: you have a mage with teleport and bunch of oneshotting aoe spells and you one shot the enemy
Scenario 3: you have a warrior with full stats into strength, 2 handed and warfare and you one shot the enemy

I finished this game only in tactician mode once where the devs decide to handle the difficulty in the most boring way possible; by increasing the mobs stats into ridiculous amounts. The combats in this game are in 90% of instances an ambush which makes for a boring experience.

Additionally, the story did not connect with me in any way and it was in places very dull. (which was a weird 
 gaming experience for me because I am usually the nerd in the group getting all the lore info possible)

I'd recommend anyone to do their research before buying this game. This game has 98% positive reviews, but when I looked at achievements only about 12% of the players finished the game on the easiest difficulty which makes me question the relevance of the steam review system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198324307501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2592, 'last_played': 1735447152}

author: {'steamid': '76561198054964503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 7136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1597, 'playtime_at_review': 6870, 'last_played': 1736380982}

author: {'steamid': '76561198347597322', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1722352105}
review: I loved Baldurs Gate 3 and I really wanted to play this, but the game is unplayable with constant crashes. From Google searches it looks like there have been crashing issues for years with few fixes, really disappointing

author: {'steamid': '76561198038032329', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 14368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 58, 'playtime_at_review': 13120, 'last_played': 1735762380}
review:
Negative since it can be a very frustrating game. The way some things are structured you quite easily lose a few hours.

Random dialogue options/ characters = INSTA-DEATH (like i have to explore everything to gain enough XP. to add random insta death characters all over the place to make me lose a few hours is annoying.

Sometimes the dialogue options are all kinda bad or at least bland in the choices. Hard to choose anything if you have nothing you actually can agree with.

The accents really don't fit the game. Personally really disliked them. 

You can randomly lose companions. sometimes permanently. Worst part is they will keep all the gear they had in the inventory. (SPOILER. when you enter the well of ascension. if you just walk through the door instead of talking to all your characters first you lose them?? sure they got the icon that there is dialogue but all game that hasnt meant anything important. you also lose companions through other fairly random events if your not hardcore trying to follow the story but even then you cant know the first time..)

One of the most frustrating things about this game. Some checkpoints overwrite your own saves.. Like im not joking. itll start a boss fight and overwrite your last quicksave. If its your first time playing it will very likely end your game right there.. or make you go back several hours (SPOILER you wake up some ancient witch.. and at the start of the fight it overwrites the save. fight starts with a big aoe and your surrounded by wolves so unless you played it before you will likely lose)

The whole concept of only being able to do certain quests in a certain order. it is annoying. i have to spend ages looking for a quest my level when ive already explored the map 3 times. not to mention there are several maps. it can take the fun out

Overall you almost have to read guides in order to not meet any nasty surprises thanks to the bad design. It is fun and there is a lot of ways you can fight and all.. but a good game shouldn't be plagued by so many little problems. And looking at the company. and the game that came out afterwards (baldurs gate) and it being practically the same system.. so i really dont feel bad giving them a bad review. 

It is a fun game (for the most part)  but maybe worthwhile to wait for a solid discount

author: {'steamid': '76561197998348859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 708, 'playtime_at_review': 5567, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 1564, 'last_played': 1736666583}
review:
Loved the first game, but I'm not enjoying the second one. Story is fine, pulling off combos feels good - but the game feels unfair in ways the first game didn't.

Look online for help and lots of responses talk about sneaking around and utilizing teleport to gain unfair advantages during fights. Bosses never play by the same rules you do - able to jump right into back line while starting with maximum AP and having it restored every round. 

Lots of fights seem far too prolonged - such as the Aeterea fight who gets unlimited summons of her dogs. Additionally, there are many ambush fights that kick off with little warning. [spoiler]For example, Red prince sleeping with his love interest results in an ambush[/spoiler]. Having played other CRPGs like BG2, Pillars of Eternity, and DoS1, I never felt the game was as unfair as DoS2. [spoiler]Except for encountering lich the first time in BG2[/spoiler]

Edit: I learned to accept that many encounters are meant to be quickloaded away from and I'm enjoying the game. My previous negatives still stand, however, just accepting the game needs to be played a little differently means I can recommend it.

Edit: Last act is no good. Unbelievably boring fights - reverent for example - plus ridiculous ambushes and instants deaths [spoiler]Sibele fight is unbelievable. Had to go back to the ship to get tornado to clear deathfog after the fight was finished as I couldn't access key areas.[/spoiler]. There is a difficulty spike but mostly the fights, which are by far the best part of this game, really drop off and become just annoying. DOS2 is a wobbler for me, but given the renowned praise I'm going to go with a do not recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991699085', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 1649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1649, 'last_played': 1712892075}
review:
A fun and deep RPG experience, big fan of the turn based combat system and some of the amazing depth in story.

Unfortunately I keep sliding off it due to a surprisingly buggy interface. I'll be assigning skill points in the window pane and suddenly my character will run to where the mouse is. It sometimes is non-obvious if an action will change me to a different character perspective. I found the journal sometimes frustrating in the things it did or did not remember and would occasionally add stuff that I didn't know because I'd completed a later prerequisite of a quest I didn't previously pick up.

On top of this, some of the characters and quests felt more grating than engaging and it'd flip between me feeling like I was flooded with things to do and then suddenly unsure of what I was meant to be doing. Some of the mechanics regarding cooking and crafting also felt a bit tacked on.

There's something bloated, unfair and, to be frank, broken with the system, and I feel you can somewhat work around it, play with the rules, but it isn't fun for me

author: {'steamid': '76561198058005334', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 1179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 772, 'last_played': 1710379572}
review:
This has an entirely *mediocre* story with good backing music.
Pretty early on, it's not super clear where to go, but at the same time it feels like there is a very set order in which to do things, because you need experience and gear to beat enemies, aka level gating.
 I don't really enjoy that. I guess it's to make murrderrerring your captors more appealing. 
At least the combat system is kind of fun.

But yeah, that and the difficulty spikes I found going into the next act and meeting weird undead scarecrows made me give up on this campaign.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028215265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 221, 'playtime_forever': 10738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10738, 'last_played': 1639607859}
review:
I played with friends and it was still a struggle to play through due to fights taking forever, floor effect spam, getting stunned by tiniest amount of electrified water, being teleported to an instakill... list goes on.

We also found that there was a rather strict way it was intended for the players to engage enemies, so if you took a left instead of intended right, you found out very quickly that was a mistake, given that you wouldn't stand much of a chance without some serious cheese tactics.

Fights also tended to last a very long time, taking us several hours just to get through one of them.


Mayhaps these are less of an issue on lower difficulties, but our experience was soured overtime.


If you actually want to play something like this that does the job properly, go play Baldur's Gate 3. The developers thankfully learned a lot from this one to make BG3 miles better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994718625', 'num_games_owned': 499, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 5791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1507, 'last_played': 1724458583}
review:
I really wanted to like this, but it's impossible. I do not like the combat, you are on fire 90% of the time, I don't care for most of the skills, can't get into the story, it looks horribly, there aren't that many RP opportunities either, I had a few moments where I was basically railroaded by the devs to do something, most replies are either giga good person or an asshole.

I'll probably try again, after all, I'm almost at act 2 or whatever, but i'd be lying if I wasn't forcing myself to play.
Trust me, I see the appeal and I understand why people love this game but it's not for me. I'll take my action, bonus action and movement any day over this idiotic system

[EDIT]
Finished the game. Absolutely horrible. I retract my statement about understanding why people love this. God awful game

author: {'steamid': '76561198001685126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3266, 'last_played': 1733683162}
review: This game is really a tactical battle game rather than an RPG. Even on storymode, it's basically unplayable without having the perfect spec, the perfect gear, and several mods. Every fight is an hour long. Every quest needs to be Googled. It's a huge slog. Clearly, people like this game, but if you're more of a casual gamer who is considering buying it because you liked Baldur's Gate, stay away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078127192', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1732830104}
review: Definitely not the game for me. There's virtually no tutorializing of the combat system and literally everyone you fight has a random assortment of magical abilities that ensure you're covered in fire and poison and unable to move or fight back by the time your turn comes around. If this is just how it's going to be for the rest of the game then I don't want to see it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198261054877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 12519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8725, 'last_played': 1730185356}
review:
Somehow this game feels more like a prequel than a sequel to the original Divinity game. Combat is severely dumb downed to the point where you wonder whether the developers took the time to evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of the the combat in the previous title rather than saying screw it and strip the game of what it great in the first place and then slap a few bandaids on - 

Eg. in the first game, the player tended to simplify fights by locking down enemies with CC and whittling their HP down which led to a stale combat loops of applying CCs every turn while the enemies just stands there and stares at you. The only downside to such a strategy is that the CC abilities have a chance to miss and thus cannot be entirely relied upon. However, the developers apparently looked at that and thought to themselves- why not just implement a armor system where players would have to inflict enough damage to break that armor before they were able to apply the CCs onto the enemies? As it turns out, having armor on 99% of the enemies is a bad design choice(yes even puny little imps with no clothes on) have armor because why not) because it waters down the uniqueness and flavor of each ability in the game. You could have an potentially creative combo to approach a fight but NOPE, the spells just do the same thing as long as the enemy has their shields intact. Launching a boulder at the enemy's face has the EXACT same effect as firing an electric bolt from your fingertips thanks to this asinine armor system. Why even implement interesting synergistic spells when you handicap the player and prevent them from engaging with them? 

One might defend the new armor system by saying: just break the armor first then like the developers intended then do whatever you want to the enemies. But here lies the biggest problem- the process of stripping enemies' armor tends tear into the the actual HP bar and makes it so by the time the enemy is exposed; they are already at the brink of death so why not just invest everything purely into damage and kill the enemy before they can even react instead of figuring out synergies between different status effects. 

This leads to another glaring issue that I personally am surprised the developers have not discovered during playtest which is that the game is basically heavily incentivises the player to go all in on damage to kill off enemies before they can touch you and ignore defense because CC and status effects are impractical in this game because the enemies are able to chain CC you much more effectively that you can do the same to them due to them either overpowering you in terms of sheer numbers or simply having more action points in most fights. In fact, during my first playthrough, I had to respec my party to focus solely on damage rather than survivability for the unfair final boss battle and I ended up one shotting the boss on my first turn and skipping the second phase, which really goes to show the extent to which the game favors nuking the enemy and not playing the game any other way. Unfortunately for players who enjoy a bit of variety in their playstyles(tanks, healers, etc), this game does not seem to cater well to them at all. 

TLDR: do not be deceived by the fans who claim the second game is far superior than the first, they are likely the ones who started with the second game and could not adjust to different mechanics in the first and gave up straight away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020662109', 'num_games_owned': 491, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7776, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1720347378}
review: Really promising game to start but just took way too long to complete, and the final act was too time consuming and punishing.  Liked the instant rest and teleporting systems.  But yeah it just became a chore to finish.  Also it'd be great to know what some skills did at a glance- for instance you get a shield with some fancy sounding skill, but you have to google it to find what it does. Definitely liked first D:OS game better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004433391', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2781, 'last_played': 1732418008}
review: The game is meh.  Some points are good, some rather obvious flaws exist.  Chief complaints would be that the user interface *desperately* needs an undo since sometimes you click to attack but it instead moves you to that point wasting your action and probably getting you out of position.  An undo would fix this but they couldn't be bothered.  Some of the quests are deeply unbalanced, for example whoever came up with the demon possessing one party member after another should be keel hauled.  The devs spent (wasted?) gobs of time on a system of combining things which is kinda cool if you're into that (I'm not).  Coop is decent (mostly), though there is a highlander air of there can be only one that is against the coop grain.  Overall this game shows that even on a good day computer gaming is a distant second to table top.  The game is like table top with a very poor DM plus poor mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039879684', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 1741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1741, 'last_played': 1719373503}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035598984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 17072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17072, 'last_played': 1627798513}
review:
The core system of character classes and abilities in Divinity 2 is almost excellent. The array of spells and abilities is interesting, every point invested matters, and you've got a variety of interesting synergies to explore. Multiclassing happens totally organically for many characters and just makes sense. 

So, it hurts a bit that I can't actually recommend the game. We've got about two-and-a-half big problems here that suck the fun out of the game. Unfortunately, they're all things you have to invest a lot of time to find. 

== SPOILER ALERT ==
(Although, you do not want to spend 100 hours in the game spoiler free. You will not enjoy the ending.) 

== SPOILER ALERT ==

1. The ending might be the absolute worst ending I've ever seen in a video game. You get all kinds of foreshadowing about this epic battle coming at the end between the main characters, competing for divinity. You're told that there's no way around it, one and only one person must become Divine. 

You get to the final Big Bad. It's a good fight. There's a lot going on. You bring him down. Dialogue happens. Lots of normal RPG stuff so far. 

You go through the dialogue. Still normal stuff. Then you get one line of dialogue worth of advance notice. 

BLIP. 

You're in the supposedly epic final battle. No lead in. No prep time. No transition of any kind. You have not been here before, and the arena is not meaningful. It's just rocks and cliffs. 

That's it. 

THAT'S FUCKING ALL. 

Nothing else to the epic battle for divinity. No prep. No interesting conversations about the importance of it all with your companions. No chance to discuss and look for a peaceful solution. No 3rd option. Just one line of dialogue, a BLIP, and a generic arena. 

I'm not sure anything has shaken me out of enjoying a game as badly as this absolutely ruined ending. 


2. This is the game where I finally connected the dots and learned that I absolutely hate exponential item power scaling. 
You've all seen this before. Witcher 3 had it, WOW had it, Borderlands had it (much more evident at higher levels, usually in DLCs). You should watch out for this any time you have level requirements for items. 
In Divinity 2, you'll find that level 11 items feel about twice as powerful as level 10 items. It just gets worse from there. In order to keep your build feeling anywhere close to powerful enough for your level, you'll need to constantly hunt for equipment upgrades. Some items will look excellent for their level on paper, then be obsolete a half hour later on your next level up. 
This wrecks roleplaying systems. Witcher 3 was excellent, but when I started noticing that I had to replace my swords every level, I just lost interest. Geralt is not that kind of loot hound. It just does not fit. 
WOW always had odd problems around the edges with this. Remember level 19 arena twinks? Remember how they had some level 60 player running them through dungeons to try to find specific super-rare level 19 items? Yeah, we all knew that was bullshit. At its core, that was exponential item power scaling. 


2.5. I got kinda numb to it after probably spending 12+ hours of each playthrough simply organizing items, but therein lies the problem. The UI is clunky trash and inventory management is terrible. You should not spend this much time organizing items in any game, RPG, Factorio, or otherwise (and you don't have to in Factorio, at least not without interesting complex-automated-factory reasons). But, since your gear will go obsolete every single level, you have to. You have to find every scrap of gold you possibly can so that you can afford constant upgrades. So, you have to wade through the terrible inventory management. Good luck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006719006', 'num_games_owned': 853, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 3544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2665, 'last_played': 1706136323}
review:
I start a game on the easiest, most condescendingly-titled difficulty level. The prison cook attacks me; I swing my sword at him, and suddenly everything is on fire and half my party is asleep. The other half does no damage to the enemy, because armor mechanics are completely nonsensical.

I spend 4 hours researching how to do anything meaningful in the game. Reddit says that using a sword was my first mistake, and that the best warrior is actually a mage/archer combo, and that I was OBVIOUSLY supposed to stack Fire Flame 3 times, augmented by an Eternity Rune with a carbonized Greater Rift Dust glaze, then cast it on the nearest enemy's wool socks using a wand I should've already collected from a hidden spot where you need to click on exactly the right pixel to glitch up a cliff, and talk to British-voice NPC # 814.

You'll win every fight in like 2 turns, they say. But that build is only viable for the first 120 hours, then you have to switch to a rogue/summoner/butter knife combo to beat the last 41 bosses.

I awaken the next morning with a renewed sense of purpose & clarity. I create a new min-maxed character based on the internet's suggestions. I am attacked by the prison cook; I achieve one stack of Fire Flame and suddenly everything is on fire, which immediately turns to poison for some reason, then electrified blood, then back to fire. Half my party is frozen, and the other half only have enough action points to move three inches before their turns end. I cast a healing spell; it heals 4 damage. I am attacked for 26 damage. My party is dead in 2 turns. The game asks if I would like to re-load a previous save. I decline; I would rather be doing ANYTHING other than playing this game.

Moreover, probably an amazing game if you're good at guessing what the devs were thinking when they built that part of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198256463867', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4033, 'last_played': 1734303460}

review:
After 6 hours i found exploding fire crabs, crocodiles with ranged attack (they hurl oil balls at you, one was able to teleport, using an artifact), poison-spitting giant frogs (another ranged attack), and giant turtles who also spit from distance. Meanwhile every wonderfully escaped characters scorn you that you was not so fool to go back for them  when the kraken climbed up with its tentacles and destroyed the already flaming ship with those knocked out npcs.

So what can i say? This fantasy world is simply stupid. Story is nonsensical. Graphics is good, but hey, cannibal elves? Really? Choose only if no other game on the market or if you get a high discount, 10/3

author: {'steamid': '76561198058595438', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 7004, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6967, 'last_played': 1709606304}
review:
Do you enjoy games where your party is kitted out in paper mache and eggshells for armor, with boffers and pool noodles for weapons?  How 'bout where every hit is a foregone conclusion--for the enemy? 
 Do you like never being able to take anyone by surprise because Larian had never heard of the concept of a surprise round before making Baldur's Gate 3?  How 'bout a magic system where it's all friendly fire all the time, counterspells aren't a thing, and you can be cursed into doing damage with healing spells?  What about perpetually losing initiative on every character that's not your stabby-stabby sneakthief?  Environmental effects that can't be dispelled/mitigated except by long cooldown, high-use cost abilities?  Then boy howdy, do I have a game for you!

Your gear buys you one solid hit from the enemy, or perhaps two, before they're through either your magic armor or your physical armor.  Once your armor is gone, you're subject to status effects that range from annoying (bleeding, burning, cold, shocked) to TPK-inducing (stunned, knocked down, petrified, frozen, turned into a chicken--all the stuff that makes you lose at least one turn).  Your attacks, meanwhile, are shrugged off with relative ease bar the stabby stabby Rogue whenever they backstab a caster (casters have crappy physical armor and sky-high magic armor, Fighter types are the inverse, and Finesse guys get a balance of the two types).  The imbalance is such that one NPC can, with their full allotment of attacks, drop the armor of a given party member and leave them half dead in a single round.  Meanwhile, you have to focus fire with at least two characters (sometimes three) to be able to start CCing that enemy and pounding them into the ground.  Since you're virtually guaranteed to lose initiative unless you're rolling a full party of Rogues and it rains +Init gear and you're constantly buffing them with Clear Minded (and even then you'll probably lose more than win), congrats, you're fighting an encounter with 3 characters because whoever gets burned down in the opening round is fucked unless you can kill whoever's doing the damage fast enough (fat chance of that!).  Sure, maybe they won't be dead before it's their turn in the combat and they can down a potion and then not die, but if their status effect forces them to lose their turn or is accompanied by a DoT, they'll probably be dead before they get to act.

I've already restarted once when I realized my party as it stood was broken and completely incapable of winning fights.  I'm going to give the current crop of bullshit encounters another attempt and exploit Lone Wolf, and if that doesn't do it, then Larian can get bent and I'm uninstalling.  I want to like this game, I really do.  The world is intriguing, the writing is solid, I like the characters (well, except the elf bitch trying to murk Red Prince's first Dreamer buddy), and I am invested in the story.  However, the combat is unfair to a frustrating degree and I am growing very, very, very tired of reloading saves only to wipe over and over again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033932698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1715659002}
review: There are other neg reviews that cover the game play issues I didn't care for. Mainly, it feels like you have to play the game in a specific way to succeed. Also the combats drag on forever and felt pretty repetitive. Lost interest in the first Act.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071359259', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 5524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2008, 'last_played': 1717784117}
review:
As always with Larian games - it's a very good "game", but a disappointing "role-playing game".
It has a nice combat system, interesting skills (much better than in the previous game). Some boss fights are cool too. The characters are... well... not fascinating, but, again, better, than in Original Sin 1.
The main minus is the game world. It just doesn't feel like it lives. It's more like an amusement park, where everything was made to entertain the player. Cities, for example, serve only 2 purposes: quest hub and shop. You want to buy a high-level spell? Go to a local market and buy it from a common merchant. Why this merchant in the center of the village of Driftwood has the spell that requires a source point to be casted? Why local magisters don't do anything with that?
Even Skyrim - absolutely soulless game - feels more "lively", than the Original Sin 2. At least there you couldn't buy high level spells from a market merchant - it was necessary to go to the college.
The game doesn't want you to explore the game world. Even more, it punishes you for that! Thinking about investigating of an interesting location? Forget about it - you'll be slaughtered by monsters in no time, if their level is at least 1 level higher, than yours. Players that like this game usually respond that you may use ton of exploits to win even in the most difficult battles. But the problem is, in order to use these exploits, you must use some very specific skills and very specific equipment, which seriously limits the enjoyment.
And another bad thing about the exploration. I remember how I, being level 18, found an amazing two-handed scythe in the Arx Cathedral. Excited, I equipped it at tried in combat. Well, it didn't go well - I was missing my targets constantly, because... the level of my weapon is too high. Damn, that's just illogical. I'm a level 18 warrior with 15 points in two-handed weapons. Why can't I use lvl 20 scythe? I could understand something like that in Diablo, where everything is about loot, but in an RPG it just looks not very good. The game should reward you for explorations, not punish you!
Divinity: Original Sin 2 is an interesting game, but only in terms of combat. The gameplay loop is extremely simple: go to a city, get as many quests as you can, follow the quest markers on your map to solve them, return back for your reward.
That's all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059136167', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1711735471}
review:
i just cant recommend when it feels like such a chore even on easy difficulty. the beginning area has very hard fights. the only indication of what im supposed to do for a quest is things such as "find this person" no clue where to "find this person" at all, that in turn makes everything a guide video if i don't want to spend the next year running around at a snails pace. 7 hours in and i feel like ive accomplished nothing. I have escaped fort joy to the hideout by just getting lucky. 

I also feel like im being punished for my preferred class choice as there is clearly a better choice for damage and such but I don't want to restart because of that. im sure I would have enjoyed this game if the starting area was actually more designed as a starting area.. explanations kinda non existent, why should I have to rely on reddit and youtube to beat a quest.. (unless your life revolves around games and you have all day to wander)

author: {'steamid': '76561198210842129', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9369, 'last_played': 1719435192}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025014447', 'num_games_owned': 17, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2173, 'playtime_at_review': 1906, 'last_played': 1736842714}
review:
I tried to like this game, but I'd barely gotten to Fort Joy (the first area of the game) before it became tedious.

I'll start by saying the game has some strengths. The entire game is voice acted, which is nice. There're lots of NPCs to interact with, lots of quests to do, a class system complex enough for builders to work through. There is quite a bit of scope to plan your characters, and the option to play multiplayer is also nice (it is unique as well in all the RPGs I've played). It is highly nonlinear, and there are many ways to meet a quest objective. You can also kill (almost) any NPC, which completionists might find fun just to see how the plot reacts.

However, the game is also plagued with problems:

- The plot is very dry. I more or less lost track of it completely soon after arriving at Fort Joy. The game doesn't introduce what Source is, why Sourcerers are considered dangerous, what Fort Joy is, and so on (I actually learned this stuff from Wikipedia).
- The characters are very dry. I came to know my party members OK, but almost everyone else just fades out of memory. For example in the first zone there's a blue dragon, but what their name is I don't remember, or why they were shackled when I first met them. They're completely colorless and leave no impression, and I barely interacted with them.
- You do a lot of running around, but there's no fast travel beyond waypoints. After you've waypointed you still have to s-l-o-w-l-y walk to wherever you wanted to go (even worse if you split your party).
- Inventory management is tedious. It's not immediately obvious which items are junk, which are equipment, or even which are armor pieces and which are weapons. There's no way to search for which items add to a particular stat. Furthermore the items have weight, so you can't lug everything around, and there's no way to search for the heaviest items so you can drop them.
- Combat is also tedious. Even if you're level 8 and your opponents are level 2 - which means you kill them in 1 hit - you still have to go through the same turn-based combat, watching their animations.
- You also repeat the same tactics against most opponents, adding to the tedium.
- Even worse, combat is needlessly complex. I've lost count of the number of times I've friendly fired. Friendly fire in this game is not like casting a Fireball and having the edges of it hit my teammates, it's things like aiming the Fireball at an enemy and then having it hit my teammate because they were in the line of sight - there is no warning that this will happen. Similarly, I've stunned myself by casting lightning spells on something who's standing in a pool of water. I still haven't figured out if this always happens or if it's a percentage-based chance. Not having "combat preview" is an incredible drawback.
- There's no difficulty scaling. This means the game is less nonlinear than one might think, because you might not have the levels to do stuff in a different order.
- There's also a limited amount of enemies, which I suppose means there's no grind, but also means that, combined with the above, you should kill all the nonessential NPCs you can for loot and gold.

The upshot is this game has no plot, so there's no reason to play it for the story, and also tedious combat, so there's no reason to play it as an action game. Why play it then?

You're better off playing Dragon Age: Origin, Cyberpunk 2077, or The Witcher 3, to name a few other RPGs off the top of my head.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030123832', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 372, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1710639902}
review:
Divinity: Original Sin was a very bad game, and Baldur’s Gate 3 was a very good game. I expected DOS:2 to be somewhere in the middle, and that’s exactly what I got. If I had to describe this game in one word, it’d be ‘mid’.

If you want to read a lot of compliments, you’re probably better off reading a thumbs up review - but I’ll cover the positives in brief. DOS:2 is quite pretty, very long, and beautifully detailed. It has a ‘classless’ system that some people will find very refreshing, and the emphasis on surfaces in combat is a clever and unique approach to cRPG combat. It also does a really good job of making DOS:1 optional - you’ll understand everything you need to understand without playing the first one.

Much has been made of Larian’s character writing elsewhere, but unfortunately there aren’t many positives on display here. Your companions in particular are underwhelming - they’re uniformly edgy and shallow, with zero banter between party members. The Origin system lends them a bit more dimension, but I’d rather not have to make a character the protagonist before they’re interesting. The other characters are quite generic and forgettable. 

Combat is a strange beast - I thought BG3 had a problem with alpha strike gameplay, but in DOS:2 it’s the only approach possible. You [i]will[/i] run 3-4 pure dps characters, and you [i]will[/i] kill or be killed. You can make it easier on yourself pre-combat by laboriously moving all of your characters into ambush positions, prepping surfaces with poison or fire to make hazards, and other incredibly tedious micromanagement chores. Often, twenty minutes into a fight, you’ll figure out that you just don’t have the juice to win, and you’ll have to load a save to try your luck elsewhere. This feels as bad as it sounds.

Speaking of feeling bad, the dual armor system on enemies is incredibly restrictive and can render whole archetypes unexpectedly useless. Enemies have both physical and magical armour, and until you bust through at least one type, you don’t do damage to their health. This means you want a full party of physical damage dealers, or a full party of magical damage dealers, or you’ll run into problems. It limits your approach severely, and your approach was already limited by the encounter design!

Perhaps you’ll think to look at consumables in order to give you some extra tools to handle the tedious, demanding combat. Well, there’s a lot of stuff in the game - too much, often with underwhelming or duplicate effects. Very little of it has a significant impact in combat. As for gear, there’s a ton of that too, but it’s mostly of the ‘randomly generated stats’ variety. Gold is a huge issue at the start unless you steal, and then so abundant that stealing becomes pointless. The whole gearing and consumables system feels bloated and shallow, not helped by the terrible inventory management interface that I’ve come to expect from Larian games at this point. 

But the worst of DOS:2, the cardinal sin (if you’ll pardon the pun) is the pacing. The open-ended, meandering design is a massive weakness. You’ll be spending the vast majority of your time wandering across the map, avoiding overleveled encounters and trying to find something that you can actually handle at your level and gear. Nothing is signposted, and your quest log is insufferably vague. The designers have a very specific order that they expect you to do things in, and they expect you not to skip anything, but they’ll be damned if they indicate those expectations to you through any method other than death. Without a guide, progress is impossibly slow.

Whilst the creativity and dedication shown is admirable, DOS:2 is crippled by poor choices. Its glaring shortcomings ruin what could have been a quality experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990222067', 'num_games_owned': 48, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2093, 'last_played': 1732929115}
review: Lots of "Google It Stupid" quest design. Gameplay mechanics are good but the quests and puzzles let it down. Basically it depends on vague objectives and hidden mechanics that you would have NO IDEA what to do unless you google it. You can blunder through, but you'll miss out on half the game and frequently get stuck on "Oh sorry you weren't supposed to be here yet" battles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068015911', 'num_games_owned': 1037, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 5164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5164, 'last_played': 1717283373}
review:
The game is atrociously boring. The combat is repetitive, unbalanced, you're under powered in the beginning and nothing is a threat to you later on, bloated inventory with hundreds of useless items, the range in tone from childish humor to gore and despair is jarring, the dialogue and story is just a badly written info dump with a million random fantasy words, it feels like it was generated by ChatGPT. 

The amount of exaltation of this game on YouTube and in the reviews is honestly bizarre. 3/10 at best, I wouldn't even buy it on discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198296846751', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 13607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12124, 'last_played': 1721162236}
review:
So close to be a good game. Really. It is just too annoying too many times. Enemies pop out from nowhere without any sign of ambush (no there is no perception check here, this is NOT D&D). To many times, somebody from the party is useless against the enemy, because they are resistent against their skills (nope, not only one element, for example earth). Sometimes you run into annoying bugs.
I am just sad. Recently happened that 4 hours gameplay was mainly just doing literally nothing for me: because I am not the sneaky character, then my wits is low, than enemy is immune to all my spells. Real fun, yeah -_-

OK. This is simply a really bad game. Lazy and bad design. I started calling enemies popping out from nowhere without any sign 'larian effect'. Especially when you unable to do anything for rounds against them.
Just don't buy this for full price :/

Or rather don't give any money for this. Get it for free if you insist to play this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198871848781', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 5367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5367, 'last_played': 1726110608}
review:
I have a HATE HATE - LOVE relationship with this game. I played Baldurs Gate 3 before, and world wise it really holds its own. Although it feels lower budget (lacking animations and VA.) I feel the love and passion in this game that went into building the masterpiece a few years down the line. The first 20 hours(fort joy) are absolutely amazing, making you think its a masterpiece. 

However, this game is not a masterpiece. After act 1 I seriously struggled getting through it. This game does not hold your hand. It does not even teach you the ropes, in fact it throws you in the pool as an infant and expects you to swim, it also never lets up. The combat for one(classic), was always a struggle. Never through out the story are you at parity with the enemies. They are always a few levels ahead oneshotting you. With that youd expect encouragement with smart creative gameplay? No, the pathfinding is absolutely atrocious, in ways that make you wanna pull your hair out. Wanna shoot an arrow or spell at an enemy ever? A 5 inch fence will block you when, a puddle of piss is apparently an obstacle when you are shooting STRAIGHT. With that, the level design is horrid, often boxing you in and not letting you use your abilities in any meaningful way while the AI gets advantage on almost every incline and gap through a wall. Oh and how dare I forget about the elements, there are barrels everywhere, and EVERY encounter turns into a California forest fire. You could be in the ocean and still catch on fire! Really, the game practically begs you to cheat every fight with how tedious they are. The funny thing is your supposed to be Godwoken!

Its not only the combat that is unforgiving and tedious. Much of the games stories and content devolves into a "how the hell would I know that?" while playing. I've never had to use a guide until this game, where there are multiple missions which require a hyper specific thing to advance. One requiring a painting across the map to be placed on a pedestal and there was 0 guidance by the story. I like choices, but when most of the quests turn into an OJ simpson investigation as the player searches every random text, it gets tedious.

I can tell this was made with love and passion and thats what counts... but I suppose playing BGS3 beforehand left a harsh taste in my mouth which is not fair to the game completely. Thats the thing, BGS3 fixed every problem I mentioned above, so ive played and seen better. Seriously if not for the aggravating combat, its up there for the first act. I encourage you to play Baldurs Gate over this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066630070', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 11066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11066, 'last_played': 1727329124}
review:
I spent more than 100 hours playing this game and adoring it, but never venturing more than a bit past Fort Joy.  After enjoying Baldur's Gate 3 so much, I thought I would come back and finally venture forth into Rivellon and see how it was.

I wish I hadn't.

Acts 1 and 2 are phenomenal.  They aren't free of flaws or bugs, but they are few and far enough between that none stick out more than the others.  Act 3 is when things start to turn.  The Godwoken are powerful.  It seems they were more powerful than Larian knew what to do with.  Enemies begin breaking established rules in combat, doing things the player is incapable of, and using far more action points than the player will ever have access to in a single turn.  Act 4, combat wise, is an absolute joke.  Act 3's poor combat choices just compound on themselves to the point that combat became something I would dread and get through as quickly as possible.  Not because it was difficult, but because it fucking sucked.  The only good part of Act 4 was Lohse's personal quest, which I won't be spoiling here.  Act 4 did however ensure that I will NEVER play this game again.  It quite honestly ruined the entire game for me.

Story 8/10
Gameplay without combat: 5/10
Gameplay with combat: 2/10

If you're looking for a fun CRPG, I cannot recommend this one.  Larian does, however, seem to to learn a hell of a lot from every game they make.  Baldur's Gate 3 is a massive improvement on DOS2.  Despite me now somewhat hating DOS2, this does give me considerable hope for the next Larian game, and make me more than a little excited for it.  Maybe they'll even manage to make the last act in their next game not the worst portion of it like it was in their last two games.  Here's hoping.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112208199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5144, 'last_played': 1714242755}
review:
TLDR: DOS2 is an impressive combination of detailed, open-ended gameplay with robust tactical combat that nails the feel of a TTRPG rule-set. However, it gets bogged down by being too open and too detailed, with unfun combat and a focus on TTRPG flavored rules over the full TTRPG experience. Its not a bad game, but there are other games that do it better. If you like a lot of crunch in your rpg, this might be great for you. Just wasn't for me.   

I want to start by saying I don't think DOS2 is a bad game. Larian put a ton of work into this game and it shows. The attention to detail is mind blowing, and the open-ended/non-linear structure of the game play is impressive. The tactical combat is very robust and well rounded, with some unique ideas that make DOS2 stand out from other top-down rpg's. And if you're looking for a game that makes you feel like you're playing Dungeons & Dragons or a similar TTRPG, DOS2 nails it. 

That said, I think the game's strength's also act as it's weaknesses as well:

1. There is a little too much detail.
There is so much going on in this game. From deep world building to a huge cast of background characters to numerous ways to approach any given situation. But across my 85-hours of play, I found myself saying "wait who were you again?" or "what was I supposed to do here?" over and over. I'm used to juggling multiple quest-lines and characters but DOS2 has so much going on that it feels awkward. When it all lines up, its cool, but it just as often feels bloated. And with so much going on, its difficult to care. 

2. Free-range doesn't always equal fun.
It would have been fun to be in the room when someone said, "you can't do that in a video game" only for Larian to say "challenge accepted!" The fact that they managed to give you so many ways to approach travel, combat, and quest lines is a masterclass in innovation. That said, the openness never really feels like its serving the narrative, but just exists for its own sake. Now sandboxes can be incredibly fun, but the narrative of DOS2 doesn't really line up with that experience. I had multiple experiences where I would take time exploring and stumbling into quests, only to return to the main quest line only to discover that those "side-quests" were actually a part of the main quest, and that I had unknowingly closed off some narrative options. Now I like games that enforce consequences for your actions, but if those consequences aren't communicated, it just starts to feel like the story is punishing your for embracing the gameplay.

3. The combat is relentless and unforgiving.
DOS2 embraces tactical/turn-based combat, and you really have to think about what you are doing. Now there's nothing wrong with that per-say, but the game understands the system better than most players (myself included) and one mistake even on normal difficulty can lead to brutal consequences. And there's just so many dumb ways to die. Even outside of combat you have to keep your guard up. Its like playing Dungeons & Dragons with a mean DM. Someone who's idea of fun is to make a every encounter a lethal encounter. There's never a challenge or combat that exists to make you feel cool or just have fun. Its always a pop-quiz with some new and exciting way to screw you over. Combined with the bloated number of mechanics you have to hold in your brain at every moment, DOS2's combat is exhausting.

4. DOS2 captures the essence of TTRPG rules, but not the essence of the TTRPG fun.
 As I said, the game does a great job of adapting TTRPG's to the video game format, but it constantly feels like a game being DM'd by a rules-lawyer who really needs you to understand the details of their home-brewed D&D setting before you can play (and seeing as I have been that DM in the past, I should know!). I never got the feel of 'fun' that I've had with TTRPG's. The main story is vague and never really gives you reason to care beyond ,"you just should because you're the chosen one". The companions only come in three flavors of morally grey edge-lord stereotype, and I never felt like I would be missing anything without them in the game.

All in all, I think this is an ambitious game that accomplishes some impressive technical feats, at the cost of the overall experience. If you're the sort of player that enjoys crunchy rules and combat over narrative and user experience, than this game is for you. Otherwise I would suggest Pillars of Eternity I & II.

Again kudos to Larian for what they accomplished. I don't regret playing or buying the game, and I think there's some good ideas here that will be a ton of fun once perfected.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037515091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 17434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17434, 'last_played': 1702501926}
