author: {'steamid': '76561197989215277', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 4249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4249, 'last_played': 1725116335}
review:
This must be one of the most overhyped games in exsitence. Its not an awful game but its nowhere good enough that it is getting this kind of praise. 

Combat:
The combat is a let down. 90% of the fights its always the same formular, stack physical damage or magical damage. Kill everything as fast as possible. 
Savescumming is recommended, you will never know what will spawn halfway into the fight. Dont bother with Magical armor and fortify buffs. Almost every encounter ends with everybody on fire. Necrofire is even worse. Fights drag on forever.

World and Story:
World looks nice and has some nice details for you to explore. Story is bland, most of the NPC's are douchbags. With sometimes wierd though processes on your behaviour.
Quest are a mess. "Side Quests" are pretty much mandatory because you need the exp to progress. Everything is laid out in a specific pattern for you to progress. But you don't know what the developers had in mind. Its trial and error. 

RPG elements are flat, 60% of dialog ist just flavor. Only a handful of skills per class. 

This is a 6/10 at best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014544594', 'num_games_owned': 315, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 574, 'last_played': 1711897751}
review:
So. The start is great. Because the initial heroes are in constrained location and there is limited things to do.

Then you find yourself on the island and it goes downhill. I hate "especialy" fatnasy rpg for this. Ona minute you are stranded and are learning how to do a knife-n-a-string recipe so that you can add up one extra damadge point to your weapon and in a minute the "world" opens to you, and random NPC are either bothering you (hey you, you look like a lad that can take this quest) or are clearly just sitting there for you to "solve" their problems (a woman weeping, muttering something about husband that is too long away). Sorry but this is shitty writting. 
Then you have a journal full of anmes and places and alternative options how to solve something but everything is basically a fetchquest. 

in one instance I palyed coop and we got an item that cen teleport us. there was a beach underneath the cliff and the guy told e to teleport him to another side. well we teleported him to the beach below, he went angry , run away and our quest was unsucesfull. ...ah, the guy meant that we should teleport him even further away to a shipping mole? well you got one shot and if you didnt understood the assignement you can savescum. 

I think the mechanics = to paly coop and that you dont ahve to be in the battle when your co-player is further away, is a good start, but the rest of the RPG fantasy bs is still there and its unimaginative and broken.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146300490', 'num_games_owned': 1557, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 6272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6272, 'last_played': 1708872064}
review:
"Probably the best and most complete CRPG ever made!" Yeah, heard that line way to much and got fooled by this statement, to me it's easily the weakest one I played as well as the first one I never do a second run for and I even had to make a break because it drags on forever, heck! I was even about to make a second break a few hours before the ending because it's no fun at all! But why is such a priced game so crappy you may ask? Well here goes, and since it's rated up so heavily, I focus on the issues rather than the good, there are enough of those after all:

Annoying bugs: With a game that scale, it's only logical, but how come my character freezes randomly and never ever moves again until saving and reloading the game? This was so often it's just ridiculous! Some quests were broken or never triggered as well, so that's just great..

Clutter clutter clutter: Oh god! The sheer amount of s**t in this game you can pick up and carry around is overwhelming! But in a negative way.. Other games toss garbage into said category and you can one-click sell the junk, not here! As a matter of fact you don't even know if that "junk" might not be a quest item or otherwise essential. Better yet, you can sell quest items! Got me puzzled for an hour, why I couldn't finish a quest and later to which freaking merchant I sold this junk item to. On the other hand, misc items with minor use for a short while will be marked unsellable forever for some reason and clutter up your overflowing inventory further! WTF??

Thievery: It's impossible to not steal something in this game, but not because it's so incredible, but because the infinite junk laying around on the floor makes it difficult to never steal something. Stealing a freaking bucket may even lead to you fighting the entire town and slaughtering them all, dooming it to become a ghost town over a goddamn bucket or spoon you never wanted! On the bright side, pickpocket is actually worthwhile! NPCs have some neat stuff in their inventory, that seem to break upon death, so forget about the dozens of items and thousands of gold, when they die, it's almost all gone! What's with this? Also pickpocketing leaves NPCs searching for the thief, which can be hilarious at first, like when you are in a vault, that would bring a prepper to proudful tears and for some reason you can easily convince them you haven't stolen them and they keep on searching, despite there being no one else! But forced conversations (multiple sometimes) over some junk gets dull really fast.

Insta-Death & infinite waves of enemies: Yeah, you got that one covered as well! The most fun thing in a strategy game! Insta-death surfaces leave your character dead on the ground and reviving them will immediately kill them again, so your only option to solve this BS is to load a previous game, super fun! in act 4 the game keeps hurling infinite encounters at you for some reason, that leave you with so much frustration, that you keep wondering why you still bother with this sh**show anymore! Even better, the encounter before the final boss is infinite and you can only get past by quickly solving the puzzle (or install an essential mod) and quickly rush past those possessed muppets (yes, they are puppets) and to top it off: the goddamn puppets are harder to battle than the final boss, which I brought down so quickly, that I thought, there would come much more, nope..

Multiplayer: Yes, the game has it! But why is it a reason to be so frustrated? Well firstly, when launching the game (without skip launcher option) you are greeted with a crappy launcher, that demands you create an account. You can only press skip once you click create account - every single time! Once this nonsense has been dealt with, it's clear this game was hardly meant for SP, since every character has their very own reputation and conversation with NPCs, which makes you scratch your head, why your main char is so precious, to get that source collar removed, but those who helped in the arena are practically worthless scum! In addition to that, you may end up your party not following you for some reason, so you always have to watch out for them to actually follow along and they even end up with forced conversations with no hope of passing any checks, because your persuasive char has once again been ignored.. Had this with act 1, where one char was force greeted without me noticing until I was in a battle and him missing, only to end up in a fight after the conversation was finished, so 2 battles simultaneously! What's wrong with this bulls***???

Seriously, how can something like this be so highly rated when there are games like Wasteland, Pillars of Eternity or Shadowrun around? And to think they made BG3, another overrated game, ugh.. I won't get this thing unless entirely for free, with how poorly this game is made. Also a must avoid for vision impaired gamers, wished I never found a mod to increase the text scale and refunded the game to spend the money on poorly received dlc for another, actually great CRPG..

My final Rating: 4/10. It has it's moments and can be fun no doubt, but it's so laughably frustrating for way too often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198811389430', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 3443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3443, 'last_played': 1711022213}

author: {'steamid': '76561198200715328', 'num_games_owned': 61, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1487, 'last_played': 1728941061}
review: I tried to give this game a chance, but not only is the most monotonous of all Larian's already very monotonous roster, the "armor" just being more health makes this game tedious too. If you name any RPG or CRPG 99 out of 100 times armor will be a percentage based damage reduction, with this game, and the original, being the only two games to ever implement this mechanic in a CRPG. On top of this, despite the fact that this game uses AP (action points) it still fells skilless to play. Kiting is impossible because you're either thrown into tiny areas, or the enemy has 8 dashes and infinite range on any non-melee attacks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052794154', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 15722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15509, 'last_played': 1720480964}
review:
New to DND style games and decided to play this with a few friends. And as a new player to this genre of game, for new players, I say this is a skip. The game has a lot of fumbles with it. You would think that when playing a DND type game that you are going to create your own character, class, etc and you can do that. But you are only going to get away with that if you play on the most basic difficulty because the enemies are weak and as a first time player you are not going to know where to allocate your points into what stats.

So me and my friends played on the standard normal difficulty and things led to many things that break the so called immersion of this game. Save scumming because we did not like certain quests ending the way they did, dying because the enemies take away your armor in one hit, not positioning properly for a fight you didn't even know was about to break out and get AOE to death, and persuasion checks that are pointless if you succeed them, you're still going to fight. So that adventure got canned and never finished.

So then I did a solo run, still can't play the way I want to, so I default to what everyone does, look up builds. Now I am not playing a game the way I want to play, I am playing just to beat it and the builds work. Now we go even deeper issues with this game. Enemies, your class skills need to be properly tuned and fixed with a patch. I don't care how old this game is, enemies being blocked by a house door or being behind furniture or something in the house and they have line of sight to attack me, but then I try to shoot them with my ranger no line of sight. Enemies clipping terrain, now you can't crowd control and knock them down to negate some damage. For the people that like to be immersed in these type of games, how can you be when 90% of the NPC's are rude as **** forcing you to become not the hero but just someone that gets things done with so much blood on your hands. NPC's you helped in the past act like they've never seen you or saw you help them in the past and sometimes see you have something of their's "Give it to me! Or your life." You want another example. "You helped me and I've given you my thanks, now p*** off." That doesn't seem like immersion to me, that just makes everything in the game look like XP numbers to me now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116177285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 123, 'playtime_at_review': 2667, 'last_played': 1735645559}
review:
Pros: 
- The soundtrack is nice, not annoying and doesent really gets repetitive
- The dialogue writing is generally good, you can talk to almost any animal as well.
- The game is dirt cheap, is dirt though.
- The starting location and the end location are actually having interesting quests.
- World design has a lot of potential, devs left it to your imagination, though. 

Mixed:
- Puzzles. Some are overly complex, others bugged, third are too simple. I liked some, was very annoyed by others. 

Cons:
- Combat. It is heavily dependent on your characters level. Oh, you're one level off? A shame, grind in a single player game. Its also very weirdly balanced, where some enemies are just made to be ridiculously difficult, while others are pushover. Oh and thanks for the enemies who can only die after using a certain spell with 2 round cooldown, can run away from you across the whole map, immune to most magic and so on. 
The whole game is just artificial difficulty, with no elaborate combat. That is explorer mode; the only difference with harder difficulty is that boring combat lasts 10 minutes instead of 3 hours. 
- Characters' art looks different than their game model. They never tried to even make them look alike. [b] One of many overlooks by the devs [/b]
- A couple of locations are abysmally bad. Oversized, empty, and you just have to fight through a lot of copy pasted enemies to find... nothing (Wrecker's Cave as a very good example of this). 
- Romance is very plain, and when it comes to intercourse — devs didn't even care to make your character remove the armor. (you can do that manually, though, do what you paid developers to do) 
-  Endings are very underwhelming. Your romance is not reflected, its very rigorous and mostly depends on just one choice. Surprisingly, side characters seem to have more variety than main characters... yeah. Oh and the ending cutscene is just awful, especially when it touches upon the same subject thrice in a row. 
- Interface is awful, one of the worst I ever faced in a game. Its not complex, but very inconvenient and poorly designed. Comes with unusual key mapping so that you press L to look up the quests.
- Bugs like Han disappearing. 
- Why would you make a purging wand give you a skill that purges instead of just purging? 
- Why some weapons have hp (amount of uses), and others dont? Its not even connected to balance, its just there. It doesent add any difficulty as well since you can just buy a ton of repair kits. 
- Only a handful of choices in the game matter. There are certain enemies that you can do 3 good skill checks in a row... to only find that the outcome is the same no matter what you pick.
- Quests go like this - Do X, get ambushed. Or you find out that this character had some bad motives and you can either kill them or leave them be. 

5.5/10: Just buy BG3 as it is better in every way. People also say that DOS1 is better than 2. DOS2 was just for Larian to make mistakes and never repeat them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035342552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 4691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4691, 'last_played': 1725910755}
review: I can't recommend it. The combat is fun for a while, but spells are not interesting long term and I'm so done with the story. Itemization is boring and the loot system sucks. I slogged my way through DOS 1 but couldn't be bothered finishing DOS 2. Maybe later I'll try again but I'm OK for now. I bought on sale price so I got my value from it but it's overall not a very satisfying experience to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066156186', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 2972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2972, 'last_played': 1718843723}
review: The beginning is pure suffering. After that it starts to feel good. Then you want to kill yourself in the mid. I just can't. I need to enjoy myself. Not torture myself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040259135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 6777, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6777, 'last_played': 1706240634}
review:
Ehh... I can't say this game is more than "serviceable" for an RPG. 

My biggest complaint is that I felt very constrained for an RPG; it seemed like the game wanted to me take quests/encounters in a very specific order, and "side" quests often felt mandatory to get strong enough to defeat the main quest's next encounter. Experience and good items were very scarce, while difficulty spikes were prevalent from start to finish; many encounters quickly overwhelmed me with raw stats and required hours of trial and error (And worse, backtracking) to defeat.

On top of that, the turn-based combat felt painfully slow; even against unimportant lackeys, a single fight usually took 5+ minutes to clear at least. Long, unskippable animations play out for almost everything, no matter how unimportant. And considering that fights often have 8+ characters taking turns one at a time, it adds up fast.

The combat does have a lot of potential for complex interactions between abilities; you can spill oil on an enemy and then light them on fire, soak them in water and then shock them with lightning, and sometimes instantly kill enemies with certain environmental hazards; this can make a lot of encounters much easier if you're willing to spend long enough strategizing and prepping.

But it just wasn't enough to really grab me, especially because I often couldn't just come back later if there was an encounter I was struggling with; I'd simply run out of other ways to get experience and items. I finished the game once, can't remember most of the plot, and I mostly remember the campaign for being a frustrating chore.

TL;DR, get it on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561199384197901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2073, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2073, 'last_played': 1716110217}

author: {'steamid': '76561198421642992', 'num_games_owned': 116, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1968, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 684, 'last_played': 1733170752}
review: How anyone can play this after BG3 and say its better is beyond me. Its objectively worse in every way. Writing is ok. Your companions have little personality - they rarely have any opinion on what's happening. There's a million side missions with no clear resolution. There's little opportunity to talk your way out of a fight - every conversation ends in battle. There are much more combat encounters than in BG3 - and they're unfortunately not fun at all. Yay I have to fight a bunch of magisters for the millionth time, and I only have like three abilities and 3 AP per turn. What fun! I wanted so badly to like this game but it was such a let down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032428617', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1715113999}
review:
Went into this blind and felt like combat was impossible. The reason for this? Because it was! Each combat I was finding whilst exploring were too high level. I would end up dying, reload, try the combat again and just die again. It was only after googling that I found out I shouldn't be attempting this combat just yet, and instead I should be following some specific order of combats.

Really felt like this game is supposed to be played with a walkthrough/guide. I'd recommend doing research into the game (specifically combat) if interested in buying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032528962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4176, 'last_played': 1721955488}
review: By no means a terrible game. It's passable. I just didn't care for the writing. Neither story nor characters grabbed me. Mechanics were interesting, but encouraged combat optimization over role play. Not my cup of tea.

author: {'steamid': '76561198833949818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 3621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3274, 'last_played': 1711118947}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001656726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1723110322}
review:
I'm happy to play BG3 in Honor mode, but I really don't enjoy the combat of D:OS 2. I tried lowering it down from Classic to Explorer mode, which made the combat easier but not enjoyable. I looked up multiple youtube videos for pointers, but I just can't enjoy this game's combat; the whole thing about stripping an opponent's armor or magic armor and then using chain crowd control is lame as hell, and having enemies destroy you with AoE at the start of every combat if you don't manually unlink your party and reposition them is... also lame as hell. I just could not enjoy this game's combat.

What about exploration? You go to a door, try to open it. It's locked. You try to pick the lock; your rogue's skill is too low, and your precious lockpick is gone forever. So you try to break it; now your weapon's durability is shot and it's unusable in combat. You unequip your weapon, and punch and kick the door. A hundred kicks later, it's open, and you can go into a room and pick up like 2 gold, which is a tiny fraction of what it costs to buy another lockpick. Who the hell thought this was a good idea?

What about the characters, setting and story? Setting and story look interesting, but I didn't get very far, so I can't tell for sure. Some characters were alright, others I just wanted to murder for being total pieces of shit, like the Red Prince. I didn't actually like any of the origin companions though, like I did instantly like Lae'zel in BG3. D:OS 2 companions were just... okay, at best. Which is not too bad, and I'm sure they have interesting storylines down the road, but it's not good enough to keep me engaged and playing a game whose gameplay I've flatly disliked.

Clearly, many players enjoy this game, if you look at its excellent review scores... but just as many players are like me, who did not enjoy it. D:OS 2 has 97 achievements, and only 8 of them have been completed by over 50% of players. I quit halfway through exploring Fort Joy, the first town you get to right after the prologue, and got multiple achievements that only 30 or 40% of players have gotten. More than half of all players quit this game very, very early- they just don't bother to be like me, and leave a negative review on the way out. I love Larian and BG3, but I can't love D:OS 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025308341', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1718483947}
review:
I used to LOVE Neverwinter Nights 1 & 2. I figured I would love this game too, but I was very wrong.

Combat - slow, boring, and unclear. I have to pick builds for my NPCs, but I have absolutely no idea what I'm picking.
Writing - I do not care at all about any of the characters I have met, which makes picking their classes that more obnoxious.
Exploration - I found some shells. Maybe if I skip enough of this dialogue, I can also find a more interesting map.

I had some pretty high hopes for this game back when I bought it, but I have been consistently disappointed with my purchase. Oh well, YMMV.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036290092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 601, 'playtime_at_review': 4778, 'last_played': 1735763620}

author: {'steamid': '76561198057617231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3401, 'last_played': 1725830037}
review:
We gave this game hours of our life. We really tried, but it just wasn't worth it. Got right to the end city, and we said "screw it." The gameplay is for players who are interested in tweaking the perfect build, and even low difficulties are not for folks who want to play an RPG and have fun at the same time. 

Got steadily worse as it went along. Play BG3 instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056789888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4730, 'last_played': 1720756140}

author: {'steamid': '76561198050668079', 'num_games_owned': 733, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 10059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10059, 'last_played': 1692314609}
review: I like most CRPGs but Larian's just never grab me. This was at the time one of the most hyped CRPG releases ever. I played it over 100 hours before realizing that I was in denial. I started it and gave up after 10 hours multiple times. I tried to get my friends to play. Again and again. I can't get past the first chapter because the fact is I just don't like the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199163479543', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 305, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1736523811}
review: Came here after spending nearly 200 hours on Baldur's Gate 3 and just finished a run on tactician mode, loved BG3 but this is just painful. Combat is ludicrously difficult even on classic mode. All mine and my companions attacks are like throwing pennies at them but im getting destroyed in one turn by the enemies.... tried to find quests that were my appropriate for my level so i could gain xp and come back to the challenging combat at a higher level but found only more fights against higher level enemies! What am i supposed to do when i cant even get to level 3, this is a joke. Would love to refund the game but spent 3 hours on character creation and just the starting bit of the tutorial so now i cant refund... Larian please make more like BG3 and not this as it just isnt fun when its this difficult.

author: {'steamid': '76561199272275335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 899, 'last_played': 1724537083}
review: some of the worst tabletop i have seen by far. this is one of those lame games that require meta knowledge otherwise your forced to scum save every single fucking encounter because the game sets you up in ways that outright punishes you for doing anything else but what it wants or just breaking the game with op builds. honestly i figured id go back and try it again since i took a break but holy fuck its so bad. BG3 really did what these games cant. hell the devs actully went in and nerfed the first levels big boss fights because it was too hard for players to get off the island which is hilariously bad game design to make it so punishing that your more luck prone in darkest dungeon than this game

author: {'steamid': '76561198037213705', 'num_games_owned': 929, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 6998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6998, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1726868236}
review:
Very buggy and just tedious at times, disappointing, dont think Im going to bother finishing act 4.
Would benefit a lot from areas being more linear rather than being "open" yet usually if you go any path but one youre going to be underleveled - does not care at all about springing something on you that will wipe your party straight away. Between that and the bugs there was an awful lot of time looking at loading screens from loading a save.

author: {'steamid': '76561198275758922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2473, 'last_played': 1727037444}
review:
Divinity: Original Sin 2 had the potential to be an RPG masterpiece, but it falters by constantly pushing players toward CHEESY TACTICS and game-breaking exploits. 

While the world is engaging, the story and the dialogues are boring at times. The biggest problems is how easily the game enables cheesy strategies, instead of rewarding clever planning or tactical prowess. Want to escape a tough battle? Simply flee combat at any moment, leaving the rest of your party behind, and then rejoin the fight later, fully healed, as if nothing happened. The flee-and-return loop feels cheap and destroys the immersion of tough, high-stakes encounters. 

PICKPOCKETING TRADERS becomes an essential tactic, especially if you want to afford better items or simply stockpile gold. The game’s economy feels broken, to the point where exploiting traders by stealing from them is practically required. It's hard to feel like a noble hero when you're constantly robbing everyone you meet just to stay equipped and keep up with the rising difficulty curve. It feels more like a forced exploit rather than a clever alternative.

If you’re looking for an RPG that rewards thoughtful play rather than exploitation, this may not be the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561199209900842', 'num_games_owned': 65, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2291, 'last_played': 1732998542}
review: I would love to recommend this phenomenal game to anyone, but it simply does not work on modern hardware. I've tried mod fixes, I've tried changing steam launch settings, I've done everything under the sun, but ever since getting a new computer running Windows 11 it has not even gotten past the launcher. I know this will never be fixed by the developers, so I cannot in good faith recommend this game in the state it's in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198884997016', 'num_games_owned': 79, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1710888394}
review: The base game is completely unplayable on its own for me as it will not stop crashing after nearly every action. After you correctly install vortex or mo2, a 4GB memory patch, New Vegas script extender, and an unofficial patch you can then play the game with no problems and it should be fairly easy to mod anything else you don't like in the future. I cannot recommend this game to anyone who expects the game to function on its own which it rightfully should.

author: {'steamid': '76561198345710431', 'num_games_owned': 562, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1731813353}
review:
Played this game many times before on various other platforms. 
Not entirely sure why this is happening but essentially it appears that 'game crashing' is a known issue.
I am not going to recommend, because honestly I am not one to 'back' a game that is playable only through modding.
Though New Vegas is a wonderful Fallout game and I looked forward to playing it through again...
the game crashed 4 maybe 5 times within the last 6 hours of game play.
I refreshed / reinstalled the files and still got crashed loading between zones.
With a game of this size, I do not have the time to be researching how to fix game crashes and honestly don't feel like 'editing / modding' just to enjoy a game that should be playable 'out of the box'.

I do not support 'fixing to play games' I paid for the game and it should be playable.

review:
When it works this is easily the most fun I've had in a first-person Fallout game. The issue is that getting it to work is a massive hassle. It's like every time I successfully fix an issue a new one pops up the next day. It sucks that such a great game is ruined by piss poor optimization but that's life. 

If you don't mind having to troubleshoot the game for a few hours every other day or so it's worth it. If you just want to be able to just play a game without downloading a variety of mods (and still having issues) you are better off saving your money.

review:
I cannot recommend this game in windows 11 because:

> It crashes sometimes when you change area, cross a door or move the cam quickly (in a fight, e.g.)
> Sometimes it does not load a saved game. It gets stuck in an endless loading screen. It does not allow you to alt+tab to the task manager to kill the process. So, you need to reboot the computer and try another saved game. If you find one saved game that loads, usually you can then load from that point other saved games that were not loading. Nevertheless, I have got Quicksaves and Autosaves not being able to be loaded whatever, they seem “coprrupted”.

Of the 9 h played, I think I may have been able to actually play only 4h.

I have tried windows compatibility mode with windows 7 and 8, and also modding/ patching the game. Above issues still happen

Sad.-

author: {'steamid': '76561197997817622', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 5381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5381, 'last_played': 1713195730}
review:
I am a long-time Fallout fan.  Fallout is my favorite video game franchise and I've played it since the original Fallout.

However, this game in it's current state has not been kept up by Bethesda to be a usable product any more. 
 It's not patched to run on Windows 10 (or above? I'm on 10), there seems to be such a common trend with many users experiencing crashes.. it's a shame.  I really wanted to play this again.  I just purchased the Ultimate package (even tho I already owned New Vegas without the DLC and wasn't getting an extra discount for owning the main game already) so I could play it through again, check out the new content, and generally take more time at it than my first run-through.  BUT, THIS GAME IS UNPLAYABLE.  This game crashes several times an hour.  After following Bethesda's advice from their website (the usual, update drivers, go into compatibility mode, etc.) that didn't work.  I did find some guides on installing a bunch of mods and such, but WOW.  I thought I was into the game, but I'm not about to spend HOURS installing utilities and mods to get this thing working.  For some it may be worth it, those that have given feedback seem to say installing all that stuff does get rid of the crashes.

TLDR; If you do not want to spend hours patching/installing mods (that are not done by Bethesda btw) then it may be worth it to purchase this in it's current state.  For me, a huge fallout fan, it's ABSOLUTLY NOT WORTH IT.  R.I.P. New Vegas.  I'm bummed about that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198889363554', 'num_games_owned': 40, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1254, 'last_played': 1719452823}

author: {'steamid': '76561198060193952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4572, 'last_played': 1716481872}
review:
I absolutely love, and adore this game. I have mostly fond memories of Fallout: New Vegas, back when I last played this game in 2019... which might be very confusing, given that I'm not recommending it in this review...

I don't know if it's a recent update that caused this, or if the game doesn't like Windows 10, but Fallout: New Vegas is the most user-hostile game I've played. Booting it up again, 5 years later, now with all of its DLCs, that I regret purchasing, the game would crash literally every single hour. With no mods installed. I had to download a certain patch, just to stop it from crashing, and it did... HOWEVER... then it refused to save my game, because Windows thought the game was a virus, so I had to deal with that... AND THEN... because that wasn't enough, naturally the game decides to randomly corrupt all of your save games. All of them. Game just gets stuck on the loading screen forever.

I love Fallout: New Vegas, and I recognize it as the best in the Fallout series, but I cannot recommend a game, that resists me THIS MUCH just trying to fucking play it. And don't list me any "workarounds", they don't work. I shouldn't have to go through that bullshit, just to play a game. Now if you have actual "FIXES", that are guaranteed to work, WITHOUT being forced to start a new game, and abandon my 10 hour save, THEN we can talk.

But until then, I'm not playing this game, and I can't recommend it, until Bethesda/Obsidian pull their heads out of their asses, and actually fix the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054600469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1707007242}

This game is amazing BUT be warned...

However from there on it kept crashing sooner and sooner and I couldn't get 5 minutes of playtime before it crashed.

As my refund request was turned down, I figured I might as well bother trying to mod the game to get to work and after hours of trying out different mods I eventually found one that fixed the problem.

I now have  80+ hours in the game. I loved it and would recommend it if it worked as bought off steam...

review: While I genuinely enjoy and really like this game, it's just almost impossible to play this game without modding. I'm not too good with technology so I struggled with installing mods and honestly if you're like me (only a casual gamer that doesn't know anything about modding) I can guarantee you, the game will crash OFTEN. You'll have to play parts over and over again because the game just crashes every 10 minutes. I like the game a lot so I just suffer through it, I tried to download mods but I just couldn't figure it out. Either way, just keep that in mind if you're planning on playing this game.

review: Mixed feelings, the game is as fun as i remember. But on steam it crashes over and over. Sometimes i can play for an hour no crashes. The only way i've found to make it more stable was lowering the graphics and trying a mod. Why is steam selling buggy games on this platform? The we can't fix everything someone else does in their game does't really work, but they're choosing to sell products that do not function correctly. I love the game, but i'm not sure i can even say i'll be able to complete the game. The crashes are non stop, even with extra work on my part. Not worth the hassle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049066509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5241, 'last_played': 1713274147}
review: I absolutely love New Vegas since it was released and I played it on the 360. I reinstall it on steam every so often wondering why I don't play it more. Then I get 15 minutes in, have it crash only to remember that this version is unstable and glitchy as can be, which I didn't experience on the 360. This is being said after having sunk 87 hours into it on steam and finding the recurring problem ultimately too frustrating to continue, though I would love to keep playing this game. "Controller supported" is also a bit generous as this barely counts. Sad to say as much as I love this title I can't recommend purchasing this version even on sale, as I doubt they'll ever do anything to fix it, unless it's re-releasing a remastered version and charging for the privilege of having a working game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986087857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1713161168}
review: So I've been trying to get FO3 and FONV to work, but neither seem to want to create a New Game. The game just crashes after I make an attempt at creating a New Game. For FO3, I've tried all the fix-it guides, and none of them worked. I gave up. I didn't even try to do any fixes for FONV, so I'm just going to leave a negative review until it's fixed. There's really no excuse for these games to not work, even years after their releases. As I stated in my FO3 review, I can still play the original Assassin's Creed game which is older than FO3 and made by Ubisoft, and have zero issues with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198219228563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1080, 'last_played': 1718413574}
review:
This game would receive a positive rating from me, if it worked with modern hardware. Just a heads up: if you want to play this you'll have to download a plethora of third party patches/mods that fix unavoidable, game breaking glitches and bugs. And even then, after hours and hours of trouble shooting, you may still have issues. 

Some of the glitches/bugs I have encountered include:
-Stuttering
-Interiors not loading (invisible walls or floors)
-Random fps drops
-Everything (player and npcs) rubber-banding in place (still have no clue how to describe this)
-And the classic CTD

If you don't mind spending a few hours out of your day modding/troubleshooting the game to make it functional on your setup, then I would recommend it. However, it's complete BS that you have to do that in the first place. It's like buying a Ford F150, but instead of an actual engine the dealership just gave you a tiny one from a STIHL grass trimmer. I hope that this game will get a remaster or something to make it work on modern systems, but with Bethesda it'll probably be another 10 years before that ever happens.

Out of the 18 hours of gameplay (I have at the time of writing this), only 6 or 8 of those hours were actually me playing the game. The other 10 was troubleshooting or me having to restart because the mods I downloaded were insufficient in fixing my game and I have to start another save to try another set of mods. And I'm STILL troubleshooting as I'm writing this. I've nearly exhausted my will to continue trying to make this game playable, but when you go through the first 1 or 2 hours of the game for it to only start showing issues that the mods you downloaded should have fixed, it's tiresome. 

Please, if you plan on buying this game, just know what's in store for you...

author: {'steamid': '76561199017846509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1717178189}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971163638', 'num_games_owned': 652, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1136, 'last_played': 1715019434}
review:

I suppose that's apt for a game that features the gambling capital of the world.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987519830', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3567, 'last_played': 1726683978}
review:
The amount of time I have spent modding this bucket of shit into something remotely presentable has been double the time I've spent actually playing it and even then this piece of shit keeps crashing. The number of hoops I have had to jump through to mod this game has broken my brain and I can barely string together a coherent rant about this crappy experience so much like the process of modding this game itself, I give up. No more. I refuse. I need to get on with my life.

THAT BEING SAID, if you somehow manage to put enough hours into duct taping this game together with various mods, you may end up with an enjoyable experience at the end of the day. But I do not recommend this game because those hours are much better spent making your own game from scratch. If you have a friend who's a programmer and he's willing to patch this thing up for you on a budget of a Coke and some Slim Jims, then by all means buy this game when it's on sale. But remember that this game is not your job, your time on this Earth is limited. Learn from my mistakes, my son. Amen.

author: {'steamid': '76561199031882266', 'num_games_owned': 41, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 6247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 5612, 'last_played': 1735956955}
review: I wish this game wasn't from 2010 and had the gameplay stiffness from 2005. Mods will obviously patch and improve this otherwise fantastic game, but out of the box is a game that is one-part oversold and one-part a masterpiece. Oversold due to the buggy nature of the game, even at launch, especially if you wanna due true vanilla which I can only say is baffling. Masterpiece due to sharing a fantastic showcase of roleplaying, writing and ambition that is held back by its time and the fact people demonizing Bethesda like they're the Devil for having Oblivion make the game. Even so, this is a more than solid 8-9 out of 10 held back by it's age and buggy unless modded. Otherwise, great if not fantastic 20$ dollar game for people okay with getting their hands a little dirty for making this piece of history shine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198869302365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1731123383}
review:
Probably a nice game, but i did not receive the game displayed here.  

Due to my IP being German i receive the German version of the game, which has a few issues:
* even though my entire system is set to English everything is in extremely bad German (even the German people i asked have no idea what kind of game-setting "Bildschirmeffekte Hochdynamikbereich" is supposed to be) and well a rpg kind of relies on text. it would also be nice to know how to save the game (maybe its "datadata").
* modding does not work at all. NVSE tells me to find a patch, which converts it to the normal version, but the download links no longer work (and also are random exe files from entrusted sources).
* the graphic is dated without mods and the German version has always had worse graphics anyway. so its not a "the game-play is bad, but its nice to look at" either.

its nice for a laugh about the extremely bad language, but i can get that for free from other games.  
why do i have 5 hours of playtime? first i tried to play it like a justcause game and then i tried to either mod or patch it for probably 8 IRL hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983562541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 7527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7102, 'last_played': 1720533249}
review:
Granted, this is an older game, operating on a newer Windows OS, and granted, I bought it when it was heavily discounted, and granted, I've played it for close to 120 hours by now, BUT: 

- By today's standards, the developers cut corners with the visuals of the game: all the house interiors look more or less the same, as do the vaults, as do the watch towers, etc...c'mon guys, you can do better than this
 - The game is quite buggy; some NPCs don't do what they're supposed to in quests, and/or you don't get credit for completing the quests even after you've done everything you're supposed to
- The quests themselves can get quite confusing, as there are quests-within-quests, etc., and sometimes it's hard to keep track of what you're supposed to be doing
- The direction arrows for (supposedly) guiding you to people and/or places that you're supposed to go to or interact with to complete quests are maddeningly vague and hard to interpret
- The game keeps crashing my Win11 system, by locking-up so that I have to re-boot my machine each time it does. I'll grant that this probably isn't the developers' fault, but it's a heads-up to anyone thinking of playing this game on a Win11 OS

In summary, it's not a bad game; as I said, I've spent may hours playing it, and had some fun doing so. But, the problems therein make it a game that I won't tell people NOT to play it, but go in with eyes open that there are some bugs that can make it pretty frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004825044', 'num_games_owned': 928, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 2043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2043, 'last_played': 1716248853}
review: This game just isn't for me.  I've tried getting into these games several times before over the years, and this is the first time I've beaten one, but I really didn't feel like I was having fun.  The controls are so stiff and awkward, the game crashes often, the game doesn't look great, and overall, I didn't have a good time with it.  I can see why some people can like it, and can find enjoyment in it.  But for me?  I don't think I'll ever like a Fallout game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007341704', 'num_games_owned': 421, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2103, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 2100, 'last_played': 1719080257}
review:
I gave Fallout: New Vegas another try after not finishing it when it first came out. With the recent resurgence of interest in the Fallout series, I thought it was worth revisiting. While I found the base game okay this time around, the DLCs really ruined the experience for me. They weren’t entertaining and seemed to offer very little reward for the effort.

For example, in the Utah DLC, all I got was a good handgun. In the DLC with the robots, I received some body enhancements, but that was about it. The heist DLC was the worst; it was terrible, and all I managed to walk away with was a single gold bar because I couldn’t carry more. These DLCs made me overpowered for the base game, but sadly, they also sapped my interest. I didn’t even bother playing the last DLC and just finished the main game to close the chapter. If you want to play it maybe stick to the base game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117240399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1713803624}
review: Let me start by saying; If this is your first time playing New Vegas, it is a perfect gem. However, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME IF YOU HAVE A MODERATE TO HIGH END PC BUILD (AMD 7000  series card or better). The game itself is unplayable due to some setups not properly running the game. You can expect constant crashes, crashes at startup, frame rate stuttering so bad it appears to be less than 25fps. There are some fixes that have been discovered through Nexus mods, but in my opinion, a game should not need the support of a mod or modifications to files etc, in order to simply run. Would recommend purchasing on console instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993673688', 'num_games_owned': 552, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 15588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13286, 'last_played': 1735356577}
review:
As there are plenty of reviews out there already singing the praises of this game independently, I'd figure I'd add the perspective of someone with many, many hours of [i]Baldur's Gate[/i] and especially [i]Baldur's Gate 2[/i] under my belt -- and I mean the original releases that came on multiple CDs, not the remasters. 

For an old fogey like me, the biggest thing to get used to is the combat. While BG and BG2 were turn-based with pause, BG3 is fully turn-based; where BG2 was based on D&D 2e and 3e, BG3 is based on 5e. Since I had no tabletop experience with it before this game, it also served as an introduction to 5e for me (or at least Larian's house-ruled version, as changes are inevitable when you're translating a game from pen and paper to computer). So a lot of this review is actually going to be about that, too.

I was skeptical when I heard that despite its length, the game topped out at 12th level (BG1's low level combat was extremely one-sided, and BG2 [i]starts[/i] at 8-10, depending on class) and that your party had no more than 4 people (down from 6), but as it turns out this is mostly compensated for by the deepened combat system. Mobility and positioning are far more important now, since movement is restricted each turn and enemies make far better use of theirs. Spell-like abilities are far more abundant, meaning pure spellcasters are not as impressive/overpowered as they used to be. Battles are now much more an exercise into correctly applying the limited use of every character's vast pool of options, rather than the classic "mage and fighter meat shields" setup of most BG2 battles. Both systems have their pros and cons, but the 5e system is a lot more balanced between classes if nothing else. Though, if you like your fights absolutely unbalanced and unfair, BG3 has plenty of options for that as well, mostly by abusing the physics system in ways I'm sure a tabletop DM would never allow.

Speaking of classes, that's been completely overhauled too, with the ability to pick a class on every level, rather than the mechanically more complicated and restricted multiclassing and dualclassing from 2e/3e. This is a fun and versatile system that allows you to mix and match proficiencies and abilities to build a character you like without being dependent on having a specific kit designed for them. One thing that holds back the fun somewhat is that the game's length means you will be at the lower levels for a [i]long[/i] time, so if you have a build planned that only really comes into its own at the later levels you'll be waiting on that quite a bit. You do get access to a cheap and easy way to respec your character early in the game, so switching builds depending on their viability at each stage is an option.

In terms of the actual combat in the game, the biggest hurdle is understanding the system and the action economy (there are "actions" and "bonus actions" and they are mostly not interchangeable), but once you do most fights pose little problem. There are only a handful of fights I would call challenging, and even on the highest difficulty levels you will find yourself with an inventory full of weapons, items and consumables that you don't need to win. The main thing making the game's hardest difficulty setting "honour mode" a true challenge is that you have to do it all on a single save, which enforces extreme caution. I personally prefer just having tougher but replayable battles over an ironman mode, but fortunately the game is very moddable, so there's options if you want the game harder, or trivialize combat entirely so you can focus on the story.

Combat mechanics aside, the role-playing part is where it gets really fun. Whereas the standard approach in most RPGs is fighting, or getting a quest item, or getting a quest item by fighting, BG3 leans a lot more into your character's background and proficiencies, and relies on abundant dice rolls for everything. Skipping things or doing them out of order is practically the norm, and the game is built to handle it. When it's firing on all cylinders, the game feels like an actual tabletop session of D&D, where your party pulls outrageous stunts (and/or spectacular failures) based on how the dice favored their crazy ideas, while the DM wearily looks on and rewrites campaign notes in the background. There is still plenty of combat and a few major places where fighting your way out is unavoidable, but these stand out when contrasted with how often you can talk or physically manipulate your way out of things. As with any CRPG there are still always places where you wished you had more options, but the game does a good job of accommodating you.

So is the game perfect then? Well, no, nothing is. It's very, very good, but there are blemishes. Small physics, camera and UI glitches that are fortunately mostly resolved by saving and loading the game. A classic if by now a bit antiquated approach to loot where the game showers you with magical items, but most of them are not very interesting or impressive and get chucked on the pile. Some mechanics, while adding flavor, feel tacked-on and inconsequential -- camp supplies, alchemy, dyes. There are cameos from companions in earlier games, but the story doesn't gel very well with how things were left at the end of the Bhaalspawn saga. There are weaknesses around the storyline if you want to play an "evil" character, with "good" characters definitely getting to see and do more. And while the game's immense size is surely hard to fault in terms of value for money, it does mean that by Act Three, when your course is pretty well set and it seems like things are ramping up to a confrontation, the game still throws new side quests at you like you're just starting out, which can lead to fatigue if you're not able to simply plow ahead and ignore them. 

So with all that, do I recommend BG3? ...are you kidding? If the many other reviews didn't already give you an indication, BG3 is an RPG with phenomenal and probably unparalleled scope, size, depth and quality, and more importantly, the ability to pull you in and keep you hooked. I've spent many a day going to bed far later than I should have just because there was "one more quest" to finish up, "one more area" to explore, and before I knew it I was neck deep into new shenanigans. It brought me all the way back to a time where BG2 was, for a long time, the only game I played, to the point where I learned all the ins and outs of the engine and even made a few mods for it myself. I'm (probably!) not going to go that far for BG3, but it definitely gave me the same feeling of wanting to go for another playthrough almost immediately after I'd finished the first one, even knowing how many hours that was going to take, just to do things differently this time. That time commitment is definitely not for everyone, as shown by the fact that no less than [i]half[/i] of all players don't even make it through Act One, but this game is so large that even just Act One would qualify as a full price release on its own for most studios. Not so Larian, and while they've broken many hearts by saying there won't be an expansion or sequel to BG3, by the end of this game you definitely feel the weight of all that effort and time the developers sank into it, and you can't really blame them for going "enough".

[i]Baldur's Gate 3[/i] is a game I think everyone should play, even if you don't complete it. Those who like CRPGs will almost certainly love it, those who have never played CRPGs may come to like the genre, and all in all this game is probably the best advertisement for [i]Dungeons & Dragons[/i] outside of the source material. It's a ray of sunshine in a gaming industry where insidious mediocrity and shameful cash grabs have become the norm for AAA releases, and we should thank our lucky stars for the fact that it's very replayable, because unfortunately we're not likely to see its match any time soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111039865', 'num_games_owned': 182, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 10079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9250, 'last_played': 1732400631}
review:
I bought Baldur's Gate 3, like many others, caught up in the wave of hype surrounding its release. At first, it didn't grab me. 
With no prior experience playing Dungeons & Dragons and not being a fan of turn-based combat, I struggled to connect with the game. The mechanics felt foreign, and I found myself drifting away to play other titles.

But something about Baldur's Gate 3 kept pulling me back. I gave it another shot, and then, it clicked. 
I started to enjoy the combat, figuring out how to use the environment to my advantage, and I realized just how much influence you can wield outside of battle. Conversations, choices, and strategies became just as important as swinging a sword or casting a spell.

I became invested in the characters, more than I have in any other game. Well, most of them — I don't like Wyll. His story just felt underwhelming compared to the others. Each companion had depth and complexity that kept me hooked. The freedom the game offers is truly unparalleled. I could shape my own story in ways that felt meaningful. I found myself losing track of time, wanting to know what would happen next.

Fast forward 150 hours(!), and I’ve just finished my first playthrough. Without a doubt, this is the best game I’ve ever played, and I’ve played a LOT of games. The sense of emptiness it leaves behind is almost painful. All I want to do is dive back in and start a new run. (Taking suggestions on what character or class to try next)

In summary, yes, I wholeheartedly recommend Baldur's Gate 3. It’s an unforgettable experience that sets a new standard for storytelling and player agency in games.

PS: Be warned, though; after playing Baldur's Gate 3, other games may feel linear and their characters shallow in comparison.

author: {'steamid': '76561199165161200', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 18105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1122, 'playtime_at_review': 16445, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1736800380}
review:
As someone who has never played a game like this before, I debated a long time before forking over the cash for it. I know zero about D&D, have never played any kind of strategy game before.

I haven't finished the game yet, but can tell you without a doubt it's one of my favorite games I've ever played. It's story-rich, the gameplay is incredibly fun, the characters are very well written. It's a 10/10 for me! Best game ever!

author: {'steamid': '76561198167916465', 'num_games_owned': 9, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 16171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6064, 'last_played': 1732947980}
review: A true masterpiece, a work of art, the highest form of technical brilliance! When I play, I feel like I’m age 7 again (I’m 46 at time of writing this). I’m actually ‘playing’ and using my dormant imagination as a middle aged man! This is not a typical game, this is something completely transformative. When I am deep in the underdark, below the adamantine forge, under the arcane tower in the shadowlands searching for the moonrise tower as deities vie for influence over my party members…I am literally teleported inside a novel where I am the main character! This is true role playing! Thank you Larian, this game single handedly elevated the entire industry, I am humbled by it’s brilliance, thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561199092716175', 'num_games_owned': 96, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 14326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13605, 'last_played': 1733658515}
review:
I was in a very dark place in life when I decided to play this game to distract myself from the hell I was going through. For some reason, every aspect of this game—the music, story, characters, and the feeling of being alone against the world—resonated with me deeply. This game reignited the magic of excitement I used to feel while playing video games. It inspired me to move forward and regain faith in life during my lowest moments.
"You are not alone in this. None of us are." 
Thank you Larian for creating this masterpiece of a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996873645', 'num_games_owned': 335, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 11614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7247, 'last_played': 1732099527}
review:
Awesome game, but I held off playing it because of the top-down/isometric camera - didn't like the camera in DOS2 either.  Then I found the "Native Camera Tweaks" mod on Nexus Mods.

This totally changes the game, allowing you to use standard 3rd person camera controls, and actually see what's ahead when moving up-hill.

It turns out all outdoor areas have sky boxes (including sun and moon), and almost all interior areas have ceilings.  Trust me, you'll hardly notice the few times a ceiling is missing or "pops in", unless you're looking for it.  And there's no performance hit that I've noticed.

Makes me wander why Larian didn't give an unlocked camera by default...

Also you have full control over zoom/pitch/FoV/invert axis/dead zones etc through the mod's configuration file.

[b][i]EDIT:  The mod has been updated (8 SEP 24) to work with patch 7.  Many thanks to Ersh for updating it so promptly!

author: {'steamid': '76561198130044198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 33056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31154, 'last_played': 1732785411}

author: {'steamid': '76561198032540115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 29175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27203, 'last_played': 1730064036}
review:
T.L. D.R. this is one of the best games ever created and deserve every single award it won.

My first playthrough of Baldur's Gate III took over 250 hours to complete, just by walking around, interacting with party members, NPCs, trying to complete every quest, testing different builds. Yet the game never felt like it was padding.

It's no wonder a lot of AAA devs complained that this game overdelivers, because it does in all aspects. You can truly see the passion and dedication of Swen and his team with this title because it's just so freaking massive; yet by the end of final Act you're still left craving for more, wanting to explore more of this beautifully crafted world and characters.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]Strengths[/h1]

✅ This game provides a fantastic, almost accurate experience of 5th Edition Dungeons & Dragons. The devs had to adapt a lot of the rules to fit the game format but if you've played DnD before then this will be easy to grasp.

✅ I think the best part of this game is how much freedom you have to tackle on challenges and fights. For example, I play a lot of Stealth Strategy games (like Commandos, Desperados and Shadow Tactics), so I really enjoy setting up my party members to dispatch bosses with few actions as possible while striking with one character after the other while hiding. There is a lot of player expression you don't see in any other game.

✅ The character writing of this game reminds me a lot of BioWare's, which is poetic considering that Baldur's Gate I & II were made by them. Nearly all character arcs feel satisfying. I've been craving for a game like this since the Mass Effect Trilogy. Also, if you've played the original Baldur's Gate games, prepare for some nice surprises.

✅ The replay value of this game is absolutely gargantuan, because there are different routes, quest outcomes and small details that carry changes through the rest of the game. Not to mention different classes to experience. You'll often find yourself tempted to start fresh new save files to restart your journey with different classes, and I don't blame you.

✅ The fact this game has, on top of all that, FULLY FUNCTIONAL ONLINE MULTIPLAYER WITH UP TO FOUR PEOPLE, is the cherry on top. Being able to play this game with friends (and struggling to align the schedules) is ridiculously fun and further adds replay value.

✅ The modding community is very active and Patch 7 (September 3rd, 2024) even added an official mod  manager and support in-game.

[h1]Weaknesses[/h1]

❌ Even on the lowest settings performance can sometimes tank a bit in large populated areas. You may see a significant drop in FPS. But overall this game is very well optimized.

❌ I feel this game could've done a better job with some of the tutorials. For instance, you can fail or even downright miss quests if you long rest too much depending on which part of the game you are.

❌ The game rewards "murder hobo'ing" a bit too much. You still get experience for milestones (discovering new locations, completing quests without killing, etc.), but if you want to maximize experience gained it's easier to just slaughter everything.

❌ The final Act feels a bit lackluster in some aspects, not to mention the gauntlet of fights leading to the final battle being a bit disappointing. No spoilers but I was expecting something more way more flashy and bombastic.

[hr][/hr]

Baldur's Gate III winning Game of the Year in 2023 is a testament that gamers just want fun, complete experiences that respect their time and don't try to exploit their wallets with lootboxes, season passes and cashgrab microtransactions. Crazy, huh?

It's a shame we won't get an expansion or DLC for this game, but I frankly can't wait to see what Larian is cooking; whether it's Divinity: Original Sin 3 or a brand new IP. I'm sure they'll apply everything they learned with Baldur's Gate III and blow our minds once again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062461653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 7325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5865, 'last_played': 1735171102}
review:
Buying this game is the worst mistake of my life.

97 hours of doing blind honour runs and I still couldn't even reached Act II...

It was super worth it though. I've been doing almost 10 new runs everytime I got wiped and still manage to find new stuff and learn new things in every run.

author: {'steamid': '76561198297718034', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 5197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5197, 'last_played': 1719670012}
review:
Baldur's Gate 3 is the most intimidating game I’ve ever played. It felt like walking into the gym, where every day is leg day and the only exercise allowed is split squats. The mountain of decisions led to serious decision paralysis, keeping me up until 2 AM, hooked on the game's twists.

The final battles demonstrated how much my party and I had improved. The ending was satisfying, with all companion storylines completed and everyone getting a happy ending.

As someone who doesn’t usually enjoy turn-based games, Baldur's Gate 3 challenged me in ways no other game has. It rightfully earned the Game of the Year award last year for its deep story, complex characters, and thrilling battles that kept me playing late into the night. Plus, this game has no micro-transactions, which are rare these days.

author: {'steamid': '76561198295517407', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 91556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91213, 'last_played': 1732971411}
review: This game returned a piece of me that I hadn't felt in a long time. It gave me so much comfort. When I'm sad I'll load this game up and lose myself in it. I could sit there for days, play it, and not leave my room. It's given me a beautiful story full of characters written with so much care and detail, characters who have felt the same things I have, love, joy, abandonment, betrayal, hope, and so on. The endless possibilities, finding new things every run, seeing how beautiful this game really is. I've never felt so connected to any game before, and I don't think I ever will.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095434209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 15629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3229, 'playtime_at_review': 12211, 'last_played': 1736847689}
review:
Cheaper than a crack addiction but somehow even more all-consuming than one! 
Act 3 burnout is too real otherwise 10/10. 
Will waste another 200 hrs of my life on it again soon!
