Best 'Lore' game I have purchased in a long time. My first was Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura, way back in 2001! (CRPG) tbf. But that was my first but Baldur's Gate has really caught my eye and enjoying every second of it.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198054108303', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 17596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 172, 'playtime_at_review': 13990, 'last_played': 1735774755}
review:
Baldur's Gate 3 is a magnificent journey that immerses players in a world of magic, mystery, and mayhem. From the very beginning, the game captures your attention with its stunning visuals, engaging storytelling, and intricate character development. Larian Studios has truly outdone themselves in creating an experience that pays homage to the beloved Baldur's Gate series while introducing fresh and innovative gameplay mechanics.

The first two acts of the game are nothing short of brilliant. The attention to detail in the environments, the diverse array of characters, and the complex narrative choices make for a truly unforgettable experience. The combat system is both strategic and dynamic, offering a perfect blend of classic RPG elements and modern gameplay.

The character creation and progression system in Baldur's Gate 3 are exceptional, allowing players to mold their characters into unique personalities with their own strengths, weaknesses, and backstories. The companions you encounter throughout your journey are well-written and add depth to the overall narrative, with each having their own quirks and motivations.

However, where Baldur's Gate 3 falters is in its final act. The journey to the climax is nothing short of spectacular, but as the story reaches its pinnacle, the experience becomes marred by a noticeable lack of polish. Quests become less refined, and the overall level of detail in both the narrative and the environment seems to take a hit.

While the final act still manages to deliver a satisfying conclusion to the overarching story, the lack of polish is undeniable. Some plotlines feel rushed, and there are instances where the game's performance dips, breaking the otherwise immersive experience. It's disappointing to see such a fantastic journey conclude with a slightly tarnished finale.

Despite these shortcomings, Baldur's Gate 3 remains a must-play for any RPG enthusiast. The majority of the game is a testament to Larian Studios' dedication to quality, and the final act, although unpolished, doesn't diminish the overall enjoyment of the game. With the promise of updates and improvements, there's hope that the developers will address these issues, ensuring that Baldur's Gate 3 stands as a shining example of modern RPG excellence.

author: {'steamid': '76561198863931938', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 12289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 15, 'playtime_at_review': 10319, 'last_played': 1736535635}
review:
[h1]A Flawed Masterpiece[/h1]

This was an experience. I don't usually write reviews for games, even my favorite ones, but I write reviews for books, and this game felt like a book to me.

[h3]The Good[/h3]

First, I want to say how incredibly developed most of the story is, particularly the lifelike portrayal of the characters. The voice acting sets a new standard, arguably the best across all games, given the extensive voice work throughout. Even minor characters are voiced with excellence. The gameplay was something completely new to me, as I've never played DnD nor any game of this playstyle before. I was weirded out by the combat at the start, but as time passed and I managed to kill a formidable boss by distracting it with a cat. Needless to say, I fell in love with the combat. This game offers unparalleled freedom, allowing players to explore various paths, each with its own beauty. Also, story-wise, so many characters say some genuinely profound quotes that left me pondering for hours. LOTR is probably my favorite movie series, and fantasy books are my favorite genre to read; this game provided me with that immersion while giving me the choice to shape the story in almost any direction I wanted. Playing through the Creche during Act 1, accompanied by the music of Mountain Pass, felt like experiencing Fellowship of The Ring in game form.

The music, in particular, deserves commendation—it stands among the best I've encountered across all forms of media, not just in video games. I was flabbergasted to learn that most of the ambient tracks haven't even been officially released. Kudos to Borislav Slavov for the incredible soundtrack; I'll always remember him and what he made me feel with his music.

Acts 1 & 2 are nearly flawless. Act 1 was polished to impossible magnitudes; every side quest was lovable, every location was there for a solid reason, every enemy, every character, especially the Creche and Underdark parts. I haven't felt so excited for a game as I was during playing Act 1 since forever. Then, Act 2 surpassed it for me and became my favorite. I was drawn to its eerie, mysterious, and dark ambiance, which constantly reminded me that I didn't belong there. Amidst the darkness, stumbling upon a brightly lit inn, where goodness prevailed against all odds, the last frontier of humanity, it left a lasting, hopeful impact. Lastly, The villain of Act 2 was built up for 60 hours and delivered every single ounce of it.

[b][i]"I have a price to pay for my power; it will cost me your life…for my own, I have already paid."[/i][/b]

[h3]The Bad[/h3]

Throughout the first half of the game, I was astonished and was sure this is the most perfect game ever made, but it really does have its issues. The issues showed in Act 3. It felt like an entirely different game, marred by performance issues and a rushed, unpolished plot. Certain plotlines, including that of the guardian, felt forced, inserted merely for the sake of a twist. The pacing felt off, and the quests lacked coherence. The world is in imminent danger of being completely destroyed, but meanwhile, you can halt all of that and go exorcise a possessed individual, searching for clues around the city. Why not, I guess?

[h3]The Ugly[/h3]

Bugs became noticeable towards the end of Act 2, and by Act 3, they rendered the game almost unplayable at times. I found myself restarting frequently during Act 3. Not only were there strange battles where waiting for turns dragged on for 5 minutes, but they were also plagued with bugs. I refrained from using many spells, including summons, due to their buggy and game-breaking nature. Even pets were affected. The ultimate disappointment came during the final fight, which I had hoped would be more polished. Instead, it was riddled with switcheroo bugs that made watching the fights impossible. It was an absolutely dreadful experience.

Another frustrating issue was the romance aspect. Like, I want to hug Gale, as a friend, or Wyll, I do not want to have sex with them. Not everyone I hug is someone I want to be intimate with, nor does showing kindness to someone necessarily indicate romantic feelings. The whole dynamic felt forced, leading me to make decisions I otherwise wouldn't have made just to avoid unintentionally initiating a romance.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3] 

This game is truly remarkable, perhaps one of the best ever created. It had the potential to be even greater, I believe, if the final act received the same level of care, attention to detail, and polish as Acts 1 and 2. Nevertheless, despite its flaws, it remains an incredible experience. It's certain to hold a place in my top 5 games of all time. I'd rate it a solid 9/10. As for its shortcomings, maybe they get tackled with a definitive edition in the future, and it will become a 10/10? Well, hopefully. 

[b][i]"Am I happy? I don't know. But I am Hope, and I persist because of you."[/i][/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198134688032', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 13492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11179, 'last_played': 1723852354}
review:
I have finally finished the game with my party and I don't think there ever was a game I have played in my life that made me go and say, "I really want a DLC or expansion for this." The game is amazing and has set a new standard for AAA games, the world is carefully crafted, Its feels lived in, its relaxing and soothing in a weird way. The only other game that made me feel this way when walking around it was probably Kingdom come: Deliverance just because of how realistic it feels, Realistic in a sense that it feels like you could very well see something similar in real life, people going about their day, working their jobs, doing their routines, I feel like that's that something that is rarely captured and done well in RPG's or is something that is simply overlooked and barely given any attention to by the developers.

The voice actors and actresses also did an amazing job as well as the writing team, each character was incredibly interesting thanks to them. None of the main characters are boring carbon copies of each other, they all have their own personalities, mannerisms, they all have deep stories that you end up uncovering more and more as you progress through the game making them feel even more fleshed with each part of the game, and the voice actors and actresses did an amazing job translating all of that into their voices. 

The writing is outstanding for both the NPC's and the Playable characters, The writing got me immersed in my characters to the point when I was picking dialogue I wasn't looking for the option with the best outcome but what MY character would say, whereas in other games like Skyrim, Kingdom come or fallout I would often do the opposite. The character creator is also really good, every time I created a new character for a different play through I would always end up building lore of that character in my head, I never wanted to just make a character that just looks cool, I also wanted them to have a story prior to the events of the game.

If you don't know whether you should buy the game or not because you might not end up liking, trust me, give it a go. You have two hours of playtime to refund the game if you don't end up liking it, or you can get the game through other means although I urge you to buy it if you're interested in it and have the money to do so. I have never played a game in this genre prior to Baldurs gate 3, My main interest in games were competitive multiplayer games such as counter strike, rainbow six siege, call of duty and I have the hours to back it up on my profile, *2800 hours on counter strike, 1800 hours on R6 siege.* I ended up loving it and it caused me and my friends to gain massive interest in DnD to the point where we're planning on setting up a campaign at some point. 

Baldurs gate 3 has set a new standard for games, I think it's unfair to expect indie games to be held to the same standard as Baldurs gate 3. But AAA games SHOULD be and NEED to be held to the standard of Baldurs gate 3, it's ridiculous that these massive studios are releasing broken half completed games for full price, some of them having gold or special editions which cost even more and rarely add anything of value to the game, not to mention how many times the studios attack or ridicule people when they go to point the obvious flaws a game has or even when providing constructive criticism.

I very rarely write reviews for games, And the ones that I did end up writing were mostly Meme/Joke reviews not to be taken seriously. This is probably the first Proper review that I have written about a game because of how much I enjoyed my time with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026004314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 24496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23498, 'last_played': 1733207898}
review:
I've never played D&D, and I'm not a huge fan of turn-based RPG's which is why I steered away from this game for as long as I did.
Then I randomly started seeing BG3 shorts pop up on my youtube and I started checking them out, which finally lead me to get the game.
This is one of the few RPG's that I've played where you can make the story yours with the vast amount of choices and decisions you could make. I love Mass Effect series for same reason, BG3 absolutely goes above and beyond anything I've ever played before.

Story wise, character wise, companion wise, this game excels in so much and has proven that games from AAA devs could be so much better.
This game can always be a brand new adventure every time you play depending on your choices and which characters you play.
So many possibilities, so many choices, this game is worth full price, I have no regrets.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990176020', 'num_games_owned': 766, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 7887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7887, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1701547019}
review:
Quite possibly the greatest game I have or ever will play. You know you've played a fantastic game when you get that empty feeling when it finally ends. 

Larian knocked it out of the park with BG3 and it's a game that every person should at least try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079882415', 'num_games_owned': 453, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 22483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 23, 'playtime_at_review': 14298, 'last_played': 1735852086}
review:
It's honestly easier for me to talk about what I didn't like about this game, as the list of things I liked would go on too long.
Mostly polish was a bit of a problem with minor annoying bugs randomly popping up; often dialogue with a certain NPC would not progress the quest properly if a battle ends without my character being close enough to them. Another was that an NPC merchant would no longer sell some useful equipment because I progressed a quest that took place in the building.
Rarely, a quest kinda fails if you long rest after starting it... but it doesn't mark the quest in your journal. This happened in Act 1 and 2, and I had to reload after I realised that some NPCs died when they could have been saved.
There were also a few dialogue bugs where some dialogue skips or doesn't progress without pressing the skip button.
Everything else, I loved. The gameplay was as good as it could have been, though I think Divinity OS 2's gameplay was slightly better suited for a video game than the 5e D&D rules. The dialogue and voice acting were superb, and the facial animations were excellent. Virtually every NPC get a little personality, even if they only have a single line. And there are a lot of NPCs.
The characters were incredible and when I finished the game, I felt genuinely sad that my journey was over. It reminds of the ending I got for BG2, in which I had similarly bittersweet feelings after finishing it.
Larian cares about the games their making, so I would give them my full support, so long as they keep producing games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029222516', 'num_games_owned': 140, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 30796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1887, 'last_played': 1732439854}

author: {'steamid': '76561198210022420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 295, 'playtime_forever': 27058, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27041, 'last_played': 1721973196}
review:
[h1][b][u]OVERALL[/u]: 10/10[/b][/h1]

You know when you see a wall of 10/10 from every press outlet there is, you always cringe a bit, saying to yourself : " there we go another hypetrain going nowhere I bet !". 

[b]But for BG3 it couldnt be any further from the truth[/b], a breath of fresh air in the gaming industry, a love letter to the genre, a masterpiece for the ages ! A game so deep I made like 7 characters even before reaching anywhere close to the end game, testing out builds, player choices so on so forth... 

So much depth, passion, attention to everything, it's borderline unbelievable with the current gaming industry climate, but they done did it !!! Mission accomplished on all fronts, 5 stars, 10 out of 10, 100%. [u]Props & respect to anybody involved in this project[/u], [b]Baldur's Gate III is just a cut above in every way[/b].

I thought i'd list many postitive aspects, but forget about that, the game is just that good it will speak by itself. The NPC's, builds, mechanics, approaches, choices, the vibe, the lore, the art style, [b]JESUS CHRIST[/b] need I say more ? 

[b]MASTERPIECE[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198064232590', 'num_games_owned': 207, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8957, 'last_played': 1733020678}
review: Don't know who Baldur is and haven't reached his gate yet, but I've been loving the journey so far. Only downside is the main story characters make it really difficult for you to pick just one of them to romance. 11/10, this game definitely deserves all the praise it has received and then some. Thank you Larian <3

author: {'steamid': '76561199470655713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 28714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3866, 'last_played': 1735074978}
review:
I have a hate/love story with this game.

I played it the first time on a console and after first 1o hours I rage-quit because it was so hyped at the time, I was overly judgemental about everything and I was MAD. Expectations management failed.
I have a tendency to rush through the story in games which you don't want to do here AT ALL otherwise it's a really disappointing experience. 

I came back a week later to give it another go because I'm greedy, deluxe edition for ps5 costed quite a lot. And also curious to know what the hype was actually about.
I did my first playthrough and still was not really impressed, especially by the ending.

What I did like though was music (huge kudos to Borislav Slavov, the music is just magical) and the visuals. The game is such an eye candy! This aspect is important because it pushed me to try the game again but on PC so I can use custom camera tool to take nice pictures.

And here's where the love story begins.

I'm enjoying the game now because I know how I should play it and I'm more or less used to turned-based combat by now. Must admit, not a huge fan of turned-based combat, but it's DnD, it's only right. 

Larian Studios did a great job and they continue to provide us with improvements. New kisses animations are amazing, this is something I didn't have the first time and was a bit disappointed by how bland the romances were with just one animation. And it's just one example. There are many more.

I think everyone should at least try it. And if you're somewhat like me, just be patient. I thought the game was not for me, but it has made its way on my favourites shelf after all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081811009', 'num_games_owned': 1438, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 31918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5306, 'last_played': 1732410000}
review:
One of the most defining masterfully crafted RPG in this modern gaming era. Complex tactical turn based RPG combined with fantasy storytelling in vast world full of choice matters and consequences.

Trully deserved as RPG of a generation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125856246', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 13708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6077, 'last_played': 1733022538}
review: As a massive fan of Skyrim and The Witcher 3 and not previously a fan of turn based combat, Baldur's Gate 3 has still been a fantastic experience for me. I really wanted Starfield to be my game of 2023 but it has been outmatched, by a large margin, by Baldur's Gate 3. The writing, worldbuilding, UI design and art direction are much, much better in my humble opinion. Having spent around 80 hours on my first playthrough I will certainly be replaying Baldur's Gate 3 in the not-too-distant future so I can make some different choices, which unlike in most RPGs these days, are actually meaningful.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983250061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 146101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5113, 'playtime_at_review': 60309, 'last_played': 1736847411}
review:
Baldur's Gate 3 is the most incredible game of my life!

Back in the year 2000, I decided to try and play a long video game. I was a master of arcade games, so wanted to try, one of the new long playing games. I bought Baldur's Gate 2 Shadow's of Anm. That game was incredible! My younger brother was a Dungeon Master playing D&D at the time, I told him about this game, he was impressed. Now after 1000 hours playing Baldur's Gate 3 with 4 times I have played, this time as a Fighter/ Monk with Tavern Brawler, it really is incredible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198333999501', 'num_games_owned': 50, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 8535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5778, 'last_played': 1729332307}
review:
Easily one of the best videogames I have ever played and a great introduction to the cRPG genre. With the rise of Ubisoft "open world" slop and microtransactions, actually good AAA games are few and far between nowadays and I'm so glad BG3 turned out the way it did.

The main quirk of BG3's gameplay is that it's based on the Dungeons & Dragons tabletop game, meaning the combat system is turn based and heavily reliant on dice rolls. To increase your chances of winning encounters, you actually have to think, maybe even read some tutorial messages and tooltips, not just hold W and left-click. 90% of the negative reviews on games with turn based combat systems are always a bit sad to read because they always boil down to: "Game is bad cuz I can't read." and it is a shame because they massively overshadow the constructive criticism of the remaining 10%.

What I'm trying to say is that unless your attention span has been cooked by TikTok, you're going to be absolutely fine as Larian did a fantastic job with the "Examine" and "Inspect" features and if they aren't digestible enough for you, there are thousands of guides and introduction videos to the complex world of Baldur's Gate and DnD.

It's hard to praise raw graphical prowess of a modern videogame as the gaming industry has already met something of a barrier in this department. However I can absolutely give praise to the amazing art direction. From the fire and brimstone of Bhaal's Temple to the peaceful wildlife of the Druid Grove, every single environment and location feels unique, believable and looks absolutely stunning.

It's an unfortunate fact that there are no perfect games and Baldur's Gate 3 is no exception. While the main story is pretty engaging at first, it becomes painfully obvious how shallow the main three villains are by the time you get to the last act. Don't get me wrong, they're not terrible per se but they fail to be anything asides from being the obvious bad guy that needs to be defeated in order to move the story forward. Ketheric Thorm especially had a ton of potential. Judging from his character design and backstory, I suspect there were plans for him to be more nuanced than his final version.

This is especially puzzling to me because the optional side storylines are absolutely amazing with their deep and impactful choices you can make in them.

Less significant issues include:

- Sub-optimal inventory system
- The camera sometimes getting stuck in environment where a lot of verticality is involved
- Minor texture pop-in in areas with a lot of NPCs
- Critical failures in dialogue skill checks invalidating any buffs you have
- The need to savescum an encounter in Act 2 involving Isobel because failure causes you to get locked out of 75% of the content in said Act
- The absence of an option to pause cutscenes
- Alert being too necessary of a feat, limiting creativity with your builds
- Certain characters being way too horny after being exposed to basic human decency, I guess it's realistic if nothing else
- The Long/Short rest system sometimes grinding gameplay to a hault because you ran out of spell slots just before a boss fight
- Some rare and miscellaneous bugs

Overall, it's an exceptional game despite its minor shortcomings and I would recommend it to anyone looking for something different than the typical modern AAA stuff.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198029701130', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 7462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7462, 'last_played': 1714165792}
review:
Fantastic game. Fun with four friends, if they don't take 3 minutes to take action EVERY SINGLE TIME. It's a bummer that you can't progress companion NPC questlines if you have all the 4 spots reserved for players, as you can't bring them with you to the quest objectives.
All in all fun, immersive, great music and really long game (about 110 hours to complete with 4-player coop).

author: {'steamid': '76561198034499014', 'num_games_owned': 817, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 12636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1072, 'playtime_at_review': 11251, 'last_played': 1736824973}
review:
One of the best games I've ever played. Perfectly portrays D&D and in itself, with scenario, feeling, musics, graphics, characters. Its a captivating masterpiece. Proud to be a supporter on Early-Access.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198054203384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 34671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26098, 'last_played': 1718219619}
review:
Well, after 435 hours -- two and a half full playthroughs, three romances, all Dark Urge endings, and just starting my third playthrough now -- I figure I might as well finally write a review.

I didn't really see the point as this game completely deserves its Overwhelmingly Positive status, but I'll just speak from the heart, here. I played Baldur's Gate 1 and 2 back in the day, as a young person diving into the classics and wanting to see where Dragon Age: Origins got its soul from. So the idea of Baldur's Gate 3 ever even being made -- let alone in next-gen graphics, with full voice acting, endless reactivity, and from a passionate studio of developers who put their blood, sweat, and tears into bringing the D&D 5e universe alive into a video game -- seemed absurd. Surely that would be too much of an undertaking? Would it even profit?

But here we are. And the game is real. And it's a beautiful outlier, an impossible passion project - from the fans, to the actors, to the developers - that will stay us with for a long, long time - just like its predecessors.

If you're new to Baldur's Gate: play the game. Go in blind. Fall under its spell.
If you're a veteran of the series: The third act is when this game reminds you that it is [b]Baldur's Gate.[/b] Don't be surprised if you want to go right back to BG2 after this out of nostalgia.

I envy anyone who gets to experience Baldur's Gate 3 for the very first time. Gather your party and venture forth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034263830', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 37160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 502, 'playtime_at_review': 21078, 'last_played': 1736748667}
review:
I had naively thought I knew what "RPG" meant before playing this game, having played many traditional JRPG's like Final Fantasy, tactical RPG's like Fire Emblem, adventure RPG's like Zelda, and even western action adventure RPG's like The Witcher and Cyberpunk 2077.  Turns out, I never truly understood and appreciated the "role playing" part of "role playing game" prior to playing BG3.  Any future RPG I ever play going forward will be held against BG3 as a standard.

The sheer amount of customization and open world exploration available int his game has completely redefined the genre.  There are no less than 10 full playthroughs possible with this game with countless choices and consequences in a decision tree that is pretty incalculable for most mere mortals.  You may have seen memes of this game, but you can choose your entire experience.  You can be a degenerate, or you can be wholesome; you can choose predefined characters with predefined story archs, or you can invent your own.  You can play with friends and create your own adventure and leave the NPC's out of it entirely, or you can go at it alone.  You can be any of chaotic/lawful/neutral good/evil/neutral.  I'm only on my second playthrough as of writing this and I have ideas for many more playthroughs and character designs and builds afterwards.

This game is the first game I've bought close to full price in a very long time, and it was totally worth it.  It's a complete game, aside from free patches and updates.  There will not be an expansion like Phantom Liberty for Cyberpunk 2077 or Blood and Wine for The Witcher 3, and these devs will not be involved with any sequels to this series.  And you know what?  I am completely fine with that, because this game is just that complete on its own.

I had never played Dungeon's and Dragons, or any TTRPG for that matter, at the time that I first tried BG3.  In fact, I never played BG1 or 2 either.  And none were necessary to enjoy this game.  But now, I hope to try the older games in the series, and have since picked up TTRPG's as a new hobby in part because of how much I enjoyed BG3.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047499018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 13059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11325, 'last_played': 1723586988}

author: {'steamid': '76561198034775049', 'num_games_owned': 552, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 15142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8637, 'last_played': 1733008112}
review:
This is definitely my GOTY. One of the best CRPGs of all time. (TIP - Rest a lot or you'll miss a lot of additional dialogue with your companions)

If you like RPGs, tactics, huge adventures and bears, the game is a must-buy. It's not a question. The only real question is: Are you into turn-based combat, tough choices, intrigues, ready to spend at least 100 hours+ into the game?

GAMEPLAY

It's an isometric RPG, very well executed. Combat is turn based, very similiar to Divinity Original Sin. You can exploit almost any fight as much as you want, throw hundreds of barrels upon your enemies just before setting them on fire. It's as bad as great in my opinion. I've talked to multiple bosses just to reload my save, setup a perfect ambush and just obliterate them without any dialogue. Seems weird. Boss too tough? Surround him with explosive barrels before a fight and blow his ass off,

Larian did something great combining classical RPGs and their own style. You have your ordinary RPG: classes, abilities, XP, lockpicking, multiclasses. Then you have a simulated world that you can interact with in creative way. Can't pick a chest? Just take it away to open in camp or just smash the lock instead of lockpicking it. 

EXPLORATION

I got bored of generic RPG games, which didn't reward a player for being curious. Be curious here. Go here, there and there and you'll be rewarded. Either be it with an item or even a quest. It definitely delivers the exploration aspect. It is dense and even emptier areas are packed with surprises. Characters, chests, secrets, stories, scrolls, books (READ THEM, they give lots of information and lore).

STORY

It's mostly great, but it kinda doesn't deliver at the end aswell. You've got a lot of choices to make, paths to decide, yet they get narrower the more the story progresses. It's hit and miss. Don't get me wrong, the acting, characters and story is still phenomenal, just uneven in my opinion.
Some core characters miss a lot of opportunity to be even deeper, it just ends so quick with either black or white. The deeper we go, the shallower waters we encounter.

Companions are on a completely different level. You've got so many unique, talented, charismatic characters in this game, it blows my mind. To be fair their stories got me more engaged than the main story. Even though some of them left me immediately after some of my choices, I'm still eager to let another playthrough a go, just to see their stories and reactions.

SOUNDTRACK

Cannot to mention the phenomenal OST. It's great at least said. Some songs are just... another level. You don't or won't forget them, flashbacks from the fights and exploration will comeback. Borislav Slavov did climb up to his top! Even after beating the game, I still keep coming back to those great memories.

Game's totally worth full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048265175', 'num_games_owned': 44, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 21712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 22, 'playtime_at_review': 21690, 'last_played': 1736562965}
review:
Before diving into my review, I want to say that I absolutely loved Path of Exile 1 and have spent countless hours enjoying it. Naturally, I was excited to dive into Path of Exile 2, and after investing over 300 hours, I initially enjoyed the game as well. Unfortunately, my perspective shifted drastically after just one day.

Here’s what happened:

When I logged into my main character (Infernalist), which I had painstakingly leveled to 94 and invested most of my playtime in, I discovered my account had been hacked. Nearly all of my valuable gear and items were stolen. I immediately reported the issue to support via email and forums, hoping for swift action.

While investigating, I managed to track down the hacker myself by searching for my missing items in the trade market. They were openly selling my entire setup. I provided this information to support and even posted about it on the forums, asking the moderators to block the hacker from selling the stolen items.

To my shock, my forum posts were removed, and I was put on probation for requesting action against the hacker. Not only was I robbed of the time and effort I’d invested in the game, but I also felt silenced by the very team I turned to for help.

The email response from support was even more frustrating. After receiving a generic, copy-paste reply, my account was locked—effectively punishing me for being the victim of a hack. As I browsed the forums, I found that many other players had experienced similar situations: accounts compromised, reports filed, and then locked out by support.

This entire experience has been deeply disappointing. It feels like being kicked while already down. Instead of offering meaningful support, GGG’s response added insult to injury.

Until there’s a significant change in how these situations are handled, I cannot recommend Path of Exile 2 in its current state.

Edit:
I am still locked out of my account, with no response from support despite multiple follow-ups. To make matters worse, players on the forums are reporting being locked out for weeks without any resolution or updates. This lack of communication only adds to the frustration and leaves me questioning GGG’s commitment to resolving such critical issues.

Edit2:
It’s the start of a new year, and I’m still locked out of my account with no response from support. The wait continues.

Edit3:
For those seeking more details about similar account-related issues, I recommend checking the "Help and Information" section on GGG's Path of Exile forum. Many players are sharing their experiences there, which might provide additional context regarding the current situation.

Edit4:
My account has been locked since December 27, 2024, and I have not received any response from support. The situation surrounding account breaches remains as unclear as ever. Numerous players, including myself, have reported taking extensive security precautions, yet accounts are still being compromised without any evident cause or pattern.

Efforts to get information about the account recovery process, including inquiries made by locked-out players on the forum, have provided no clear details or timelines. Meanwhile, the number of compromised accounts seems to be increasing daily, a situation that can be followed on the forums, further adding to the growing frustration and concern among the community.

It’s particularly disheartening to note that the hacker I identified—who had taken my gear and items—still has access to the game and appears to be actively trading an even wider range of gear and items.

Until these issues are resolved, it might be safer to avoid engaging with the game to protect your account. I do not place blame on GGG, but the growing reports of account compromises and the lack of understanding about how they occur are deeply unsettling.

Edit5:
10.01.2025 - Still no response from support and still locked out of my account. Reports of compromised accounts continue to increase.

Edit6:
11.01.2025 - Support responded. The recovery process was completed within 3 hours and I got access to my account again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016581033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1733607848}
review:
The game hard crashes taking the OS with it, requiring manual shutdown by using the power button.

GGG has been silent about this issue except a single post in known issues which misdiagnoses the problem as a "Win 11 24H2 issue". GGG requested DxDiags and did not access them.  GGG does not mention this issue in the patch notes.

Currently on the Path of Exile 2 Early Access Bug Reports Forum has two main threads:
1) Hard crashing PC locks up: 248 Pages, 2471 Replies, 146069 Views. Created at 7th of December, 2024.

2) POE 2 Complete PC Freeze while loading screen: 216 Pages, 2159 Replies, 204635 Views. Created at 7th of December, 2024.

In comparison the entire "[POE 2] Bugs" thread has 138 Pages, 1370 Replies, 29196 Views.

In terms of ratio, more than half of the replies and views to the forum belong to these two threads.

There are no bugs that are more important than this. This is not "I cannot use X skill bug". This is "improper usage of system APIs by the application" causing "100% CPU utilization" leading to a crash, resulting in "shortened component lifespan and possibly bricking PC".

There are people who have lost their PSUs, SSDs, GPUs, CPUs, Bluetooths, USBs... Any part you can put in a PC, there is someone on the forum that have lost it due to this "bug".

This happens on every kind of OS and hardware.

OS: Happens on Linux, Win10, Win11.
Hardware: AMD and Intel CPUs, AMD and Nvidia GPUs in all types of combination. If a hardware can run it, there is a person with that hardware on those 400 page threads with this crashing bug.

author: {'steamid': '76561198299474170', 'num_games_owned': 43, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 12654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 12155, 'last_played': 1735837309}
review:
Updated review after spending 200+ hours. I've forced myself to go through most of the endgame, pushed to t15 maps, got lvl 90, 8 ascendacy points etc.

While there are moments of greatness, significant flaws hold the game back from being truly enjoyable in the long run. 

Pros:

Animations are fluid and visually impressive, adding a sense of polish to combat and abilities. Same with effects and graphics in general—the world of the game is visually appealing, with a great atmosphere that does it job to immerse players into the dark fantasy world of POE.

The 3-Act campaign is well-crafted, enjoyable, and easily the most rewarding part of the game.

Cons:

Endgame Balance: The endgame feels tedious, plagued by poor drop rates, frustrating atlas mechanics, and build limitations. Progression feels more like a chore than a reward. Tldr: You might end up crippling your experience and getting frustrated faster than you may get your 5 socket gem or find your first divine orb :)

On-Death Effects: These mechanics are far too punishing and unfun, making the game feel unfair rather than challenging.

RNG Dependency (in a bad way): The trials (Sekhemas and Chaos) are overly punishing. The mechanics lack inspiration and offer little room for meaningful counterplay. The RNG itself is too punishing—if you get unlucky with debuffs, you can outright lose the trial through no fault of your own. For example, getting a movement speed debuff often leaves you as good as screwed, no matter how well you’ve prepared. I think it can be easily improved by adding more links between room choices in Sekhemas and more debuff choices in Chaos and making debuffs less punishing at least in early stages.

Similarly, the Atlas system feels like a battle against RNG rather than a test of skill or preparation, punishing players regardless of their gear or build. The endgame allows little to no creativity in build crafting. The game is so punishing that players are forced to build around strict defensive caps just to survive. For example, you have to push resistances, but even then, you can still be one-shot by an absurd "on death" mechanic from a random white mob. Survivability becomes mandatory, leaving players no choice but to roll defenses on every single piece of gear. The game is just unplayable otherwise.

*Kripparian’s video "Path of Exile 2 is Ruthless" captures these issues perfectly. The endgame systems feel needlessly harsh and punishing.

Final Thoughts (updated):

I can recommend Path of Exile 2 in its current state solely for its excellent 3-act campaign, which is a fantastic experience.

However, I suggest avoiding the game’s endgame content for now, as it is plagued by poor balance, frustrating RNG mechanics, and punishing systems that stifle build creativity.
If you’re interested in the good endgame experience, I recommend waiting until GGG hopefully addresses at leat some of the abovementioned issues, fixes the endgame, adds more classes, updates the skill tree, fixes armor/resistance balance and so on. But as it stands, I can’t recommend playing endgame in its current state, nor am I willing to overlook the game's flaws simply because it is "better than Diablo 4." Being better than a bad game is hardly an achievement, and Path of Exile 2 should aim much higher.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119633949', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 805, 'last_played': 1733928729}
review:
Path of Exile has been my favorite game for over ten years now, saying that I was hyped for Path of Exile 2 would've been an enormous understatement.

The game is graphically stunning, the sound design and music are top notch and the performance is great.

However, I am happy this is an Early Access, as the game has some issues that need to be addressed:

1. The concept of using your currency during the campaign to make your items better is perfect, but to do so you need the aformentioned currency, which barely drops. There is no deterministic crafting during the campaign, so you pick up an item, make it magic, if it's a good mod you upgrade it, and you continue this cycle for a few times until you have the item you want. There is no guaranteed way of getting upgrades, Path of Exile had this and it made the campaign quite a lot better.

2. The reason why the currency drop rate is lowered is because of the new loot system, supposedly dropping more useful items at the cost of not having entire screens of loot. Again, this is perfect in a vacuum, but the items you can use are rare, I've gotten halfway through Act 2 and I am still using mostly Act 1 items.

3. The new gem system is intuitive and takes away a lot of the frustration that was present in the old system. What is not fine is dropping 25 Uncut Skill Gems every 1 Uncut Support Gem. Every choice you make regarding your build feels almost permanent; people always hated this, and for a good reason, Path of Exile is a franchise built on experimenting, you simply don't have enough freedom to do so right now.

4. Gold is now an integral part of the game, being the main currency to buy items and refund passive points. This system had already been tested in Path of Exile and received a lot of praise... with one complaint. The amount of gold that drops is too scarce, if I want to buy a random ring (that isn't even guaranteed to be rare) I have to spend THOUSANDS of gold, which (at the start of the game) equals to hours of playing. The same applies to refunding skill points, we have an entirely new passive skill tree, new weapons, new skills, etc. and we are still half-locked into tentative choices.

5. This is probably only an issue because of the previous complaints but, the balance feels quite off. It takes really long to kill any enemy, especially some bosses that take 15 minutes of perfect dodging and continuous damage uptime. I think the balancing is based on having decent rare items that are appropriate to your level, but since this is not the case currently (see points 1 and 4), every fight is an unfun struggle.

I won't complain about server issues and the likes because this is the exact reason why we have an Early Access, to iron out things before the full release. This review is to be taken as just feedback from a quite experience player, both in Path of Exile and ARPGs in general. I believe the game has the potential to become the best ARPG ever made, it's just not there yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561199124624947', 'num_games_owned': 61, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6417, 'last_played': 1735132311}
review: At the current state there has been a known issue for weeks affecting users that have the Windows 24H2 update. The game will at random moments freeze and it will not only affect the game itself but will result in the entire PC freezing up, the only fix being a forced shutdown. No solution was proposed by the devs. Neither has there been one for the constant losing of endgame maps where they kick you out as you try to load into one, resulting in you losing crucial waypoint items, effectively hard-locking you out of playing the endgame. Supposedly the issues are high priority and have been addressed but as the threads with hundreds of replies will tell you, they have not. The devs priorities are to nerf builds before going on holiday and not on fixing their game so it would actually be playable. Until this changes I cannot recommend this game to anyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066224354', 'num_games_owned': 825, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1734735338}
review:
This should be taken with a grain of salt as I played Path of Exile 1 for 6500 hours, and my first impressions are biased by the differences in comparison with a game I love so much as PoE 1. I'll obviously disregard all the disconnections and the "login screen simulator" because, well, we already kinda accept that.

In Path of Exile 2, the entire campaign feels like playing The Mud Flats on Path of Exile 1. The gameplay feels very sluggish, and killing every mob pack is a task by itself. It's not hard at all... it's just tiresome. The boss fights felt the same to me.

I tested 3 different classes, and movement always felt incredibly slow, even with boots with movement speed or playing as Monk with skills that favour movement. The game feels clunky... nothing is snappy. It feels like everything has too much weight and inertia, and you're always struggling to move or do anything (cast a spell, dodge, walk, hit something, open a portal). It feels like slow motion.

Having collisions between players in the same party was a terrible idea, and it feels awful, especially in narrow corridors and passages, even with the rolling dodge. You and your teammates block each other all the time and even walking too close to another player in your party in open areas will be annoying.

Your power scaling as you progress through the game feels as slow as the player's movement. In PoE1 you feel more and more powerful as you progress through the campaign, and you keep feeling challenged by facing larger packs of more powerful monsters. In PoE2, you feel you keep fighting the same quantity, level, and types of monsters you started fighting against, but you feel weaker against them.

In regards to graphics, I understand they wanted to improve the visuals for items and gems, given how beautiful the new graphics of the game are right now, but while chasing for visual consistency, they made it so everything looks the same, and you can't distinguish between things or easily spot what you're looking at. In PoE1, if you fill a tab with different types of boots, you can clearly distinguish them. The same goes for Gems. In PoE2, everything looks the same. All the gear looks like indistinguishable beige scraps, and looking at gems on a stash tab tells you nothing about them.

I could keep writing here about many other aspects I disliked, but I don't want to trash the game, that's not my intention here. Also, after only about 13 hours of playing the game, this should obviously be considered with a grain of salt as it's more of a "first impressions" community feedback rather than a full review.

Like me, everyone who has played PoE1 since its beta knows how long it took to become the game it is today (my favourite game). Maybe GGG still has a lot to improve on it, and maybe it will become a better game than it is on early access, but for now, sadly, it feels like PoE2 is for PoE1 exactly what Diablo 3 was for Diablo 2: not the same game with improvements, but a worst and different type of game.

Many of its positive reviews on Steam just say a brief "D4 bad", and I don't disagree with the sentiment about Diablo 4. What I'll say is that this game is too much like D4 and too far from PoE1 for me to like it as it is right now.

I love Path of Exile, and I sincerely hope this game gets better in time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068979242', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 6880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6880, 'last_played': 1735316400}

author: {'steamid': '76561198083195892', 'num_games_owned': 377, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 6905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2470, 'playtime_at_review': 4435, 'last_played': 1736846628}
review:
I'm having difficulty with the game in its current state. It's unbalanced, and it's causing my computer to freeze every time I try to play. This issue occurs on Windows 11, and I'm wondering if it's happening on other operating systems as well.

Skins are not the main focus right now, but it's important to understand why new cosmetics are being introduced if past skins won't transfer. It would be great if past cosmetics could be transferred before considering future purchases.

The primary motivation for purchasing the game at this time is the 300 game currency, which will be necessary for vault improvements upon release.
Is it better than the first version? Absolutely! It's definitely worth waiting for updates. 
For now, I'm giving it a thumbs down. I'll wait for an update and a more playable version of the game, and then I'll change or add something to the review.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970750819', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1038, 'last_played': 1734162908}
review: I really want to like the game, but after 12-15 hours I'm just not having fun.  It's slow, there's no loot, bosses are painful slogs.  I don't feel like I'm getting more powerful or progressing, I just feel like I'm on a treadmill sweating to just not fall off.  I have to use multiple skills to kill trash mobs, everything respawns if you die, and it all feels unrewarding.  There's just no joy in the game right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018805282', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3512, 'last_played': 1735298271}
review: Being new to the PoE series, I really have no idea what I'm doing. The game doesn't help new players understand the different currencies, crafting system, etc... I'm just about done with cruel and the major issue for me is loot. finding level 8 uniques in act 3? If I'm supposed to utilize the website to trade for better items thats terrible game design. I'd rather farm gear and play the game than to use a website to sell/buy things. After reading how terrible the loot/drops remain in endgame, I think I'll check back with some later updates.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048476033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 7576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1460, 'playtime_at_review': 7576, 'last_played': 1735970591}
review:
A Game That Respects Your Intelligence; Not Your Time.

I can't remember the last time I gave a game a negative review. Honestly, I don't want to give this game a bad review either. I want to like POE2. In fact, I am happy to recommend it later if enough things change. My problem is that, at the moment, the game has too many mechanics that are intentionally designed to prevent you from succeeding unless you get lucky.

There are typical video game barriers that are meant to be overcome where the solution is fun and learning. POE2 requires that from you, but asks for so much more; giving you opportunity, then taking it away without offering you the chance to try again. Did an Atlas Map boss defeat you? Congrats, you can never fight that boss again, forfeiting their loot (which includes more Atlas Maps). Did you get one shot, with 4000 shields, from the perfect combo of Rare Modifiers on a monster right out of the gate? Congrats, you didn't just lose the XP in that Atlas Map, but you lost XP from the last 2 Atlas Maps you completed as well. Did really rare currency drop for you, but you immediately died from invisible ground damage? Too bad. It's gone and there are no "escape death" skills available in the game.

It is understandable that people would make the "Git Gud" argument. I don't necessarily disagree, but what concerns me is that getting "gud" in POE2 isn't fun and involves a lot of RNG. Around level 90 the game just doesn't feel fun anymore and most, if not all, of the endgame activities do not have sustainable mechanisms to help players recover from unfortunate experiences without demanding more time, more risk, and other sacrifices...

I don't have a lot of time to play video games. The holiday season is an exception. The last thing I want is to put an hour into a game only to be worse off than when I started. It's okay to slow progression upon failure, but to take it away feels cheap and un-fun. Video games should be an escape and feel rewarding. Even if I did plow through all of the challenges to hit max level, I don't believe I would feel like the time was worth it. And, I would certainly not want to go through that pain again with multiple characters; potentially one I might like more.

I told myself I would review the game after hitting level 90 to give it as fair of an assessment as possible. There are things I love about POE2, but the endgame, as is, does not want me as a player. It isn't my style. Honestly, I feel as though the design choices I outline in this review (and many more) are antithetical to what gaming is all about. I cannot recommend POE2 until GGG values my time as much as I do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060305581', 'num_games_owned': 449, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 843, 'last_played': 1734122513}
review:
So this might be a controversial opinion, but one I've seen repeated quite a number of times in the community. So I'm not the only one who feels this way. That being said, this review is mostly based on the perspective of someone who played PoE1 before this game. Not for thousands of hours, but enough to compare the game. So keep that in mind while reading this.

I'm not sure if this is the right direction for PoE to go in (at least for me personally).
The game feels very slow compared to PoE1. Combat is slow and a lot more single enemy based. And as many have said, it's more in the style of a souls-like game, than a typical ARPG game.

I think the new boss fights are fun and challenging, but also very slow. Feels like you do basicly no damage, and that causes it to take quite long. Combining that with the fact that you only have 2 flasks now, it's easy to run out of healing if you don't dodge every attack perfectly. Again, more like a souls title. If that's what you're looking for, you'll love it. But personally, that's not what I'm looking for in an ARPG.

The skill tree is there, it's just as big as PoE1, so no complaints there. And I'm sure the end game will be just as expansive as well. But haven't gotten to it yet. And I'm not sure I want to as of now.

New skill gem system is alright. It's nice you don't have to individually level all the gems over and over. But I feel like the skill gem menu could use some work. It's a little cluttered and confusing, and could use some more sorting / filter options.

I haven't experienced a lot of bugs, but I do kept getting caught and stuck on random things while trying to do leaping attacks. So that made it feel a little clunky at times. So in that regard the movement could use some work. But the new WASD movement actually feels quite nice and is a welcome change. I'm sure this will also translate very well to controller gameplay. Which is a big plus for future console players.

If you enjoyed PoE 1 but always wanted it to be a bit more tactical or 'souls-like', this might just be exactly what you're looking for. And you'll probably love it. But if you enjoyed PoE 1 for its fast paced gameplay, zooming through maps destroying everything in your path, you might not like this sequel so much. If you're a new player, or perhaps a diablo 4 player, you'll probably enjoy PoE 2. It's slightly more beginner friendly than PoE 1, and the combat feels a lot like diablo 4. Which is kind of a big negative for me, but might be positive for others.

Overall, the game just feels unfinished to me. Which is totally fair, as it's early access, and not finished. But in its current state I feel like PoE 1 is the better game. If I could give this game a mixed rating I would. But sadly I have to choose between positive or negative, so in this state that would have to be a negative for me. I'll play it some more, to give it a fair chance, but these are my first impressions as of this moment.

I will alter this review if my opinion changes in the future.

Edit:
Played some more, and created a ranger class. Improved the gameplay by a lot compared to the warrior. Clearing speed is so much faster. So it seems like the balance with certain classes and skills is quite off between classes. Mercenary seems especially broken right now with the explosive grenade skill. So certain builds are heavily favored at the moment compared to others. Something to keep in mind if you decide to buy and play.

Edit 2:
Enjoying the game a lot more with my ranger build, but it brings up a core issue. There is a big unbalance right now. Some characters have like 1 or 2 viable builds, while everything else is just kind of bad. While other characters are very easy and have great clear. Currently it seems especially the warrior is very bad, which I had happened to pick as my first character. So that is in part the reason why I had this experience which reflects in my review. For me PoE is all about unleashing creativity and making fun builds, and just copying a meta build is not fun for me at all. So when there is only a view viable ways to play the game, that severely limits creativity, and thus fun.

I'm enjoying the game now, as opposed to before when I wrote this review. But it still leaves much to be desired, and there's definitely issues. I'm confident this will change over time, and it will only get better from here. So as mentioned before, I'm sure I'll give this game a positive review in the future. But right now it's not quite there yet!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026951607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 27730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 11626, 'playtime_at_review': 19290, 'last_played': 1736845981}
review:
I dont mind pointing out all the "good" things about this game and would gladly praise where it's good and give it a positive review. But honestly, the bad things causes incredible frustrations that overshadows the good I'm just going to say it - dont buy this game. I'd refund if they'd let me. 

Mobs On-Death Player Kill ; decades later this is still a thing. It serves no purpose other than to slow you down and take the fun away. It's not even a "let me damage you a small amount of damage and it takes multiple to kill you"- it's literally a 1-shot death, big boss, rare mobs, magic mobs, WHITE mobs can all do it. There are so many poorly visual overlap that you wont even be able to recognize it. So you'll get a lot of "how did i just die question mark". 

It's not a die and let's redo it again - because when you die, you lose 10% exp, it's a couple hours of your life when youre 90s+ level. You also lose the map, modifiers, items and all the buffs you put onto that map. It's a 1x try and if you fail you have to reinvest again in order to retry. The thing is, it's not a once in a while thing, it is a CONSTANT thing, every single map and every single mob as the potential to just auto kill you after you kill it. You can spend 300 hours to find an end game boss and dies and have to repeat that RNG again.

At this point - it feels like i'm playing a game where theres' 10 monsters that im using AOE on, and if i accidentally hit that 1/10 mob that's inserted in there, i'll die and lose all my progress. That's literally how it feels. Did I just give GGG a new idea to implement just now? A hidden monster in the mobs that if we kill we auto lose similarly to killing FPS hostages in rescue missions?

The punishment is just absurd - it's always more steps back than forward. You could be grinding 10 hours a day and make zero progress in the game for some very specific reasons. 

- exp lost, you can farm for hours and it just takes 1 death to take it all away
- items balancing - you can farm days for an "upgrade" and not be able to use it because you'd have to rebalance your entire 75 minimum resist to even be able to play the game. So no, your "upgrade" isnt an upgrade, it's sitting in your stash for days/weeks until you can find the other 5-7 pieces to make it usable. Keep in mind in end game it could cost a fortune per items.
- the balancing ~ literally the game makes it where if you do not have the mandatory resist? you simply dont play the game. Not all stats are created equal but some are just mandatory absurdly implemented. 

GGG can claim to be a game for hardcore all day - but let me tell you something - from a business standpoint? your real $ and revenues inst from the HC players and the dedicated grinders - it's your casuals that works a full time job and can play a few hrs a day. 

Once the hype goes down - expect this game to drop like any other if they keep up with this ridiculous punishment that has no place in today's ARPG. 

Advice for GGG - hire a few psychiatrist and ask them to explain why people play video games and whats actually keeping them playing. Run a few studies and data mining - you'll be surprised that if you'd fix those things? you'd be far more successful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015557224', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1733680276}

SSDs and a sound card have been reported damaged by the result of the game freezing up the computer and forcing users to power cycle. Another failed early access, that shouldn't be legal to do if you ask me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961107802', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1389, 'last_played': 1734787445}
review:
Will update review once things improve during EA or on release.

Currently, crafting is a joke, you don't get enough currency to "gamble" your items, the vendor pricing is way over tuned so leaning on them instead is too difficult.

Whilst I like some rarity of loot and the slower pace, this is too much. Need to increase currency drops to let people craft at the very least.. End of act bosses should feel rewarding too.

After the initial honeymoon for what is a fantastic game, you will realise the replayability, power progression and dopamine reward just isn't there. Sincerely hope the Devs listen to feedback from the players.

I love POE too, but don't blindly white knight the game when it really needs you to give constructive criticism to get better and grow.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060544753', 'num_games_owned': 231, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 17609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 6310, 'playtime_at_review': 16190, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1736799092}
review:
Killing Monsters has become very slow and drawn out, killing 5+ packs will maybe give you 1 normal item. There is absolutely no reward for killing monsters and clearing packs, After about 20 hours of gameplay I have maybe dropped a handfull rares, which most I can't even use for my class and you end up either disenchanting them for 1 regal shard or some gold.
Damage is very slow and character power feels underwhelming, Hit a boss for 7 minutes straight just to get 1 tapped for 5 times in a row, flask charges don't recharge so when you're out of charges during a boss fight.. (even if you roll the mod of 0.15 charges per sec)


The game pace has become extremely slow, tedious and unrewarding. A white mob takes many hits without giving any loot at all 99% of the time, but rares can be even worse. A rare can take long to kill making the game pacing and progression through the acts feel very off and uncomfortable. You'll be lucky if a rare will drop 1 or 2 blue (magic) items. Also very often you'll get surrounded and locked in by a pack of monsters, not being able to roll out or move anymore. So you just stand there taking hits waiting for you character to die while trying to get out. Very amusing.


You get forced to repeatedly grind out areas for XP and hopefully a single 'usefull' drop or orb just so you are able face the next area boss. You'll often find yourself getting completely stuck in a zone, not being able to progress and not having any gold anymore to gamble some items. You'll just have to repeat the zones multiple times praying you can get a single rare drop. Which most of the times does not happen and it's extremely time consuming. IF an item drops make sure to loot it as as fast as you can because if you get 1 shot before being able to loot an item (which happens more than you'd think) all the loot in the map will despawn! So be ready to get stuck in the same map for an hour without seeing any rares. It feels very discouraging and unrewarding.

Every fight feels intentionally drawn out, Every Act area has some sort of boss that deals unfair amounts of damage at a time, when you die to a boss, you will have to start over and the boss' health, and all the monsters in the area will reset.
You get 'forced' to play WASD movement because it's important for survivability to be able to stay moving while casting or attacking.

There is also very little defence on the Passive tree, There are no, or barely any '% Life nodes' On the tree, and there is very little of actual defensive passive you can get. The only 'worthy' defence is Evasion rating currently which many builds dont use at all. Armour barely defends you against hits, especially on higher tiers/bosses. There are very few ways to build life/spell suppression/block/Global Defence/leech/phys conversion/Max Resistance, etc, etc on your tree. These shortcomings become very apparent in late-game maps and in citadels when constantly dying to 1 shots from juiced bosses and after death effects from rares.

If you die in a endgame map, All of your portals will get deleted and you fail the map, so don't even think of trying to juice a corrupted rare map on high tiers. If you die it's all gone. I have dropped a Divine orb in a T14 map, and got 1-shot to After-death effects, losing my valuable divine. When valuable loot drops, I don't get excited but instead very anxious. You have to pick up your loot before getting randomly 1 shot to a field of overlapping after death effects (which has happened multiple times). This is especially bad on tier 15 'citadel' maps. These are rare boss encounters that usually give you expensive fragments, IF you don't get 1 tapped to some random attack/effect, the boss itself can and will just 1 tap you if you are caught off guard. losing and failling your entire Citadel Map and chance at valuable loot! it is just extremely frustrating. Making you scavenge the end game map for your next attempt at a citadel. Just to randomly lose it again. 

Most of the currency orbs have been removed from PoE 1, Like alteration orbs for example, but also the crafting bench is gone. Making it very hard to roll yourself a decent flask, jewel, item, or craft some easy resistance on a open modifier slot for your gear.

The entire soul, essence and feel of PoE is gone, the game is a very unfinished, slow paced, frustrating, drawn out mess.
This game is absolute garbage, unsatisfying, poorly designed. 

There are no redeeming qualities at all. (yet?) 
All around I'd give it a 4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198062441981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 44, 'playtime_at_review': 2785, 'last_played': 1735831023}
review:
After about 45 hours, as a PoE 1 veteran with over 5k hours, I can say this is not PoE... 
First let's start with the pros: 
- Amazing visuals. Everything looks nice, sharp, with a lot of details. 
- Good performance. The game can run on older devices pretty fine (RTX 2080 no issue). 
- Bosses are cool. They remind me a lot of Elden Ring (which I also love) but only in the early game (campaign)
- Skills are fun (and the variety is good enough) 

And that's it folks... Now for the bad, and there is a lot of it:
- The game is grindy... Yes, yes I know. The company is called Grinding Gear Games. But God damn... I've grinded thousands of hours in PoE 1 but the rewards are so bad and boring that I don't feel the desire to do it anymore
- Skills are cool, but extremely limited. It might sound strange, but the fact you can only have 1 support of each is bad design imo. 
- Ascendancy is garbage. Sure, it should be difficult. But not to the point where newer players give up entirely after failing 10 times in a row
- Crafting is dead... As a big crafting enjoyer in PoE 1, I hate this to no end. Now you just have to pick garbage of the ground hopping to get something decent through the method of Jesus Take The Wheel. 
- End game is a piece of ****. I can't enjoy a game that has such a boring, annoying end game loop... I haven't even got deep into it and I'm already done with it. 
- Skill piano is a thing... People have complained for years about flask piano and considered it to be the worst thing in PoE 1 ever. Now we have skill piano, with obligatory flask ussage (although only 2) and it feels even worse. 
- Visual Clarity is a bad joke. There is so much garbage (beautiful garbage but still garbage) on the screen that I can't see what the hell is happening most of the time
- One shots.... I thought this wouldn't be a problem anymore, but now it's way worse... Monsters can one shot you. Bosses will one shot you. And if you die, the punishment drains all your desire to play anymore.
- Areas are massive and mostly empty. They feel frustrating, boring and more than anything grindy

All in all, I would recommend players to play PoE 2, but only for like 50 hours, the campaign and the early maps. For 30$ I believe that is more than good enough. 
But, for me at the very least, this is not the kind of game I would return every 3-4 months to play again. 

I will most likely sink another 50 or so hours in it and be done. I doubt I'll touch it again untill the full release, and even then I'm not sure if I'll bother with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059779819', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 918, 'playtime_forever': 4692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 18, 'playtime_at_review': 4692, 'last_played': 1736015840}
review:
Unfortunately, the game has deviated a lot from the first part and wants to look like Dark Souls, which is a shame because I just want to relax and have fun and not have a heart attack after not dodging for once.

The progress is very slow and the loot isn't good either. It all feels like a lot of work, and the difficulty level is too high. The game really has a lot of potential, but more needs to be done. I don't recommend it at the moment, but it's still early access, so a lot can still happen.
______________________________________________________________

[b]Update from 01/2025:[/b]

Unfortunately, a lot of things that I don't like about the first part and that were promised for the second part haven't been implemented, for example the death penalty, I mean, what's the point? If I want frustration, I play LoL or Dota Ranked. Unfortunately, things don't progress very well from level 75 onwards, it feels like a lot of hard work to level up here.

The skill tree is very big, yes, but the limited skill points mean you can't get very far out of the starting position.

The Trial of Chaos is just annoying, it's just luck which stupid debuff you get. That then decides whether you get through it properly or whether you get to the boss just before you have a heart attack.

The other Trial of Sekhema is also a joke, why do I lose honor for every fart and then lose even though I'm superior to the opponents and just didn't avoid every micropixel? At level 3 I have to run the instance 3 complete rounds in a row, yeah right.

OK, the Labyrinth Trial in PoE 1 was also annoying, but I much prefer this in comparison!

The endgame only consists of boring map point grinding, I immediately had a flashback to Mario Party 1 or 2 haha. Well, that was done better in PoE 1, especially with the Kalandra League, where you put the maps together yourself and don't have such a boring run through the maps with no goal.

Another hook is that all my skins from PoE 1 are not compatible, but similar skins are offered in the shop, exactly my kind of humor.

Then there are some quests that can't be completed because they're bugged, and leveling up and having to go through the same campaign twice with exactly the same content is too boring for me, I don't feel like leveling up another character.

I'll take another look at the game when it's released as a F2P, but before that it'll be put away in the Steam library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046308190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1733881491}
review:
I love GGG.  I think they're an amazing company and I've thoroughly enjoyed PoE1.  I absolutely realize this is an early access but, I'm terrified of the direction PoE is going.  So far, PoE2 feels like playing PoE1 on ruthless, but worse.  The movement is insanely slow and sluggish and everything feels extremely punishing without giving much reward.  

I simply can't imagine trudging through the campaign as it stands every league.  The game feels far too much like Dark Souls and not enough like PoE.  

If you're on the fence about wanting to participate in early access, I'd wait and give them some time.  I'm sure GGG will figure out the balancing and it will eventually be an amazing game.  But, as it stands right now, it's just not that much fun.  It's exhausting and tedious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084358928', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2, 'playtime_at_review': 2015, 'last_played': 1735754420}
