author: {'steamid': '76561197997898951', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 8445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5940, 'playtime_at_review': 8445, 'last_played': 1736321058}
review:
Good game, however:

1. Fix your auction house system! 

Having to use a clunky external website, search for an item, then try and find a player GENUINELY selling it who's online, message them, hoping they actually reply, then try and group up with them in game, then manually trade said item is laughable in 2025.

2. Remove lame one shot mechanics!

Even with defensive talents and gear, energy shields, screen wide curses that reduce enemies damage, as well as capped resistances, you still get one shot by random mobs. This brings nothing to the game except a form of frustration for the player, and greatly limits your build choices and playstyle! 

Hell, the game doesn't even do the decency of telling you what led to your demise! One second you're alive and kicking, the next your presented with a respawn button and massive chunk of xp removed (at endgame).

3. Make uniques great again!

What's with the same useless, low level uniques dropping at level 90 in stacked t16 content, as at level 10! And why are they so...bad! It's like diablo 4 all over again! No rare colors and awesome, class changing gear to chase and get all excited about,  just more minor boosts and stat spreadsheet comparisons on rare/yellow gear. Yawn! 

4. Game needs some serious optimisation!

Getting 40 fps on a 4080 at 4k with settings on medium and dlss on Max performance is pretty horrible. Id hate to see what other people are getting but it can't be good, especially when a big part of the game is overrunning you with a zerg of enemies which has the greatest impact on your FPS.

5. Improve endgame variety!

One of your big selling points was hundreds of bosses, but with the current state of endgame 99% of your time will just be spent killing trash. At least give us some more variety and the ability to just fight bosses should players choose! 

Oh, and please add an inventory auto sort button! Again, there's no excuse not to have these basic quality of life features in this day and age.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980383033', 'num_games_owned': 1351, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 185, 'playtime_at_review': 1684, 'last_played': 1736096260}
review:
I would love to recommend this game, but I currently cannot in its current state.

The Good: The new gameplay mechanics feel good, the WASD movement feels great, the new skill gem system stop making gearing as much of chore of needing both good stats AND good sockets.

The Bad: I don't think GGG played melee or minions AT ALL when testing. On-Death effects don't affect ranged builds, ranged enemies do more dmg than melee enemies, enemies dashing into you can move you upwards of a full screen away (massive CC), and using a move that moves you causes you to get body blocked on enemies (also CC). This makes melee just statistically worse than ranged. The fact that the first ascendancy also uses Forbidden Sanctum is just another slap in the face to melee, as it is quite easy to do on ranged, since you can just kite.

Minions run the problem that they body block themselves and you and have worse AI than PoE1, so this causes them to get stuck in doorways a LOT especially when you amass an army of them, and them body blocking you is once again more CC on you. The minions are also extremely squishy, making the permanent ranged ones the only viable endgame option, as the Reapers and Brutes have the problem of being melee and zombies and Unearthed minions are temporary, which die if you get too far away, instead of teleporting to you, like they do in PoE1.

I can see what they're going for with PoE2, but they need to make melee actually playable, and melee minions actually tanky while also not body blocking. They also NEED to remove the fact that enemies walking into you is CC, ESPECIALLY for melee since if you go to swing at an enemy, but get dashed into right as you do, your attack is now out of range. Not to mention, PLEASE REMOVE THE ON-DEATH EFFECTS almost 80% of the enemies have them, they do a lot of dmg, armor cannot reduce the physical ones, they often come out faster than you can react and move away. The bosses are monumentally easier than literally any of the mobs as a melee, while the bosses are harder on ranged because of squish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019518025', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 9392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 4067, 'playtime_at_review': 8984, 'last_played': 1736820554}
review:
System freezing crash, also killing peoples PCs. This is not a Windows issue, it is a POE2 issue. Issue persisting since product was installed [b]on a brand new build with entirely new parts[/b]. Running:

Mobo: X670E GAMING PLUS WIFI
Processor: 9800X3D
RAM: 32GB DDR5 @ 6000MHz
GFX: 4070 SUPER

Running on Win 23H2. The claim that rolling back Win to a previous version as a surefire fix is inaccurate. This works for some but not for others. 

In game settings don't matter, as it persists through all variety of configurations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045404219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 14315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 7355, 'playtime_at_review': 9160, 'last_played': 1736816357}
review:
Pros:
- Bosses
- Sound design
- Visual style

Cons:
- Rarity modifier on gear
- After dying in the endgame on maps, all map modifiers disappear (map boss, corruption, delirium, etc.)
- In general, too many punishments for death
- I closed 200+ maps and still did not see a single citadel
- Only one attempt for pinnacle bosses, failed - farm keys or resources for the pinnacle boss again
- High density of visual effects, sometimes you just can't see the boss mechanics, the developers need to add the ability to make it transparent or turn it off
- Minions are always stuck in narrow corridors and passages
- If there are a lot of minions, because of their number you can't see any mechanics or what can kill you, the developers need to add the ability to make it transparent

Controversial points:
- Loot and "crafting" mechanics
- Ascendancy, not everyone may like this kind of trials difficulty
- Mechanics like rituals and strongboxes

At the moment, I can only recommend the game to go through three acts of the campaign, the endgame requires improvements

author: {'steamid': '76561197962990907', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 22859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 8474, 'playtime_at_review': 3655, 'last_played': 1736829687}
review:
Are you into masochism? Then this game is exactly for you.

Everything they did feels and is catered to make the life of the player miserable, zone reset on death, single portals for maps where if you dodge roll even slightly late you lose everything, huge maps where you have to backtrack because you went the wrong way, abysmally low gear drops, extremely high respec costs while on the other side nerfing builds people use without warning whatsoever.

Its like they took out all of the good things that made Path of Exile 1 to what it is today, slapped on a new skin, added some interesting bosses and neglected everything else. Not saying Path of Exile 1 doesn't have its flaws either but it's a breath of fresh air compared to this and they went way too far in the wrong direction with this.

I'm fairly certain that if there isn't a significant change in the vision and direction of this game where player time is respected and valued people will play trough this once, and/or get stuck somewhere in the acts and never touch this again. Path of Exile 1 used to thrive every time a new league would be released but in the way this is setup i just don't see this happening currently.

Would give it a neutral but it doesn't allow that, so currently its negative.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961114976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1628, 'last_played': 1734721021}
review:
I had been waiting for this game and was excited to dive in, playing as a sorceress for almost 30 hours.

Overall, the game is quite good, a fresh and engaging iteration of the well-known Path of Exile formula. However, there are a few rough edges worth mentioning:

- Respawning areas upon death: This feels needlessly punishing and disrupts the flow of gameplay.
- Oversized areas: Some zones feel unnecessarily large, as though compensating for a lack of content. While this is understandable for an Early Access title, the later areas in Act 3, in particular, are uninteresting. There’s little to explore—just long, tedious slogs to get through.
- Clunky skill gem system: Why are skill gems drops rather than being tied to levels or a more manageable system that offers flexibility? It feels like this system exists mainly to encourage purchasing skill gem tabs.
- Low drop rates: Loot feels sparse, which can make progression slower and less satisfying.
- Crafting feels like gambling: The crafting system leans heavily on RNG, removing many of the deterministic mechanics from Path of Exile 1. The removal of alterations and scours in favor of exalt slamming makes crafting feel more like praying to the RNG gods than a thoughtful system.
- High respec costs: Respecs are far too expensive, which is limiting experimentation.

Despite these issues, I genuinely enjoyed the game once my build gained traction. Once the speed and efficiency increased a bit, it made the gameplay more fun and rewarding for me.

Unfortunately, that experience was short-lived. When GGG released a new patch, it effectively bricked many builds, including mine. While I understand that this is Early Access and balance changes are expected, the high cost of respeccing (which exceeded my current gold) leaves me at a dead end. 
I’m not upset about needing new gear for a different build but without enough gold to respec and no viable way to earn it without a functioning build, I’m stuck. Sure, I could grind low level areas to slowly accumulate gold, but there really are better ways to spend my time.

If you're going to drastically nerf builds during Early Access, at least make respeccing free or significantly cheaper. Early Access players are your playtesters and are essentially paying to help you refine the game. Let them experiment freely.

I’m reluctant to start a new character, knowing there’s a risk the same thing could happen again. It’s a shame because I genuinely enjoy playing the game, but these choices are holding it back from being better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137242720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 8303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8121, 'last_played': 1735030509}
review:
Your account does not have access to Path of Exile 2 Early Access. Redeem an Early Access key on our website or purchase access now.

Witches Demon Form constantly causing the game to crash. Also causes a crash when trying to transform back.

Constantly crashing when changing Support Gems and Equipment.

Constantly crashing before entering the map when trying to do Endgame/Waystones with friends. Unless it's meant to be done by yourself...Which I hope is not the case.

Unpleasant microtransaction practices so they can squeeze a few more dollars off of you. The official website also needs to be more transparent on what cosmetics work for which Path of Exile game. At the moment they are just thrown in together with no indicator.

- Thoughts -

• Tiny Inventory
The inventory space is really small. So if you're picking up equipment you will constantly be warping back to camp. This wouldn't be that big of a problem if gems, skills, and equipment had their own unique tab.

• Gold
Not enough gold. Quantity piles of gold instead of quality. Unless you're constantly warping back to camp to sell all your items. Skill points are also really expensive to reallocate. Especially with all the current and future nerfs happening.

• Loot
Feels lackluster, even more so from bosses.

• Body Blocking
New players starting out will find this very frustrating. It wouldn't be an issue if there was a way to get of of it without having to simply just kill the mobs.

• Walking Simulator
Allow us to teleport to checkpoints around the map we're in.

• Melee
Doesn't feel bulky enough. You melt like butter, and taste like a rare steak. It also feels like Path of Exile 2 punishes you for playing Melee characters. (Example: Honor System)

• Endgame
Very punishing and frustrating. I hate the fact that you only get one life each map, and the fact that you can lose hours of experience gained over a single death.

I would also appreciate it if there were percent values for all the other bars in settings. Specially the tabs for Interface and Sound.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126791935', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 561, 'playtime_at_review': 2397, 'last_played': 1736098224}
review:
I had an incredible experience with [i]Path of Exile[/i] last year, so much so that I decided to pause playing and wait for the sequel, which I was incredibly excited about. I spread the word, convinced friends to try it, and eagerly purchased early access on day one. Unfortunately, I now find myself writing this review with deep disappointment.

One month after launch, the game remains unplayable for me due to persistent technical issues. Running on an AMD Ryzen 7 9800X3D with Windows 11, the game frequently freezes my entire PC during teleports, forcing a full system restart. While there's a workaround - disabling a few CPU cores - it impacts performance and doesn't completely fix the crashes. Instead, it reduces them to game-only crashes, which are still frustrating. Another approach is to disable Engine Multithreading before every teleport and re-enable it afterwards. While this method works, it completely breaks immersion, and forgetting to toggle it even once results in the same freezing issue. Worse, the game can freeze during startup, leaving no opportunity to make adjustments.

The game itself also falls short of expectations. Only three of the six planned acts are available, and yet players are required to go through them twice to reach the endgame, which quickly becomes repetitive and boring. The maps are unnecessarily large but offer little reward for exploration, and most classes and builds lack meaningful movement options for much of the game, making traversal feel like a tedious grind. On top of that, the game punishes players excessively for dying. Losing everything because of one mistake, or worse, dying to on-death effects, makes the experience more frustrating than challenging.

The new ascendancy system is another disappointment. It's hard to believe it made it into the live version of the game, as even the original Labyrinth feels like a better alternative in comparison. To make matters worse, [i]Path of Exile 2[/i] seems to have taken a step backward in QoL features. Fixes to issues players raised in the original game are mysteriously absent here, and it feels like GGG is stubbornly pushing unpopular mechanics simply because they believe they're good ideas. Even simple features like an auto-sort button or the option to skip the campaign after finishing it once are still missing.

Despite all these issues, I have to acknowledge that the game's atmosphere, graphics, visual effects, music, voice acting, monster variety, boss designs, and core combat are all exceptional. These elements showcase the potential [i]Path of Exile 2[/i] could achieve if the developers addressed the glaring flaws. However, in its current state, the game is a massive letdown. I can't recommend it to anyone, especially since the full version will eventually be free.

I sincerely hope the developers listen to feedback and make the necessary improvements, as I believe this game has the potential to be the best ARPG of all time. But for now, it's simply not worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202497669', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 7597, 'playtime_at_review': 7202, 'last_played': 1736751087}
review:
Path of Exile 2 is and exhilarating rush with tight and fluid combat, difficult but fair boss fights, outstanding visuals and a compelling narrative. Yet despite all that i can not recommend this game to any in its current state. 

The reason for this is at the moment the game is prone to cause complete computer freeze and crashing upon loading into new zones. the game is utilizing 100% of the CPU and not leaving allowing background programs to before normal operations. Until Grinding Gear Games address' this issue, do not purchase this incredible ARPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048344915', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4730, 'last_played': 1734719506}
review:
Path of Exile 2 Review:

While visually polished, PoE 2 delivers fantastic and exhilarating boss fights, showcasing Grinding Gear Games' mastery in creating thrilling encounters. However, the levels are far too large for the painfully slow movement speed, and the lack of build creativity—mirroring Diablo 3's skills both in design and appearance—leaves much to be desired. Loot drops are conspicuously absent on maps, and restrictive stat requirements stifle cross-classing potential, further limiting player freedom.

If you loved PoE 1 for picking up loot, trading, crafting, and making the screen explode with action, do not play PoE 2. But if you prefer slower, MOBA-style gameplay, PoE 2 might be worth a try.

Grinding Gear Games could have a world-class, perfect game if they removed weapon restrictions on skills, adopted the same freedom as PoE 1, sped up the action by 100%, and brought back the old currency system while keeping gold—revolutionizing vendors and making them both valuable and fun to engage with. Also, why isn’t there a vending machine-style interaction for player trading? It’s 2025—why do I still have to PM for a physical transaction?

For D&D fans, it’s like going from 3.5 to 5.0—streamlined but at the cost of depth and complexity. PoE 2 struggles to recapture what made its predecessor iconic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040871613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 6266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3985, 'playtime_at_review': 1707, 'last_played': 1736841015}
review: Hating the Elden Ring "time your dodge perfectly" gimmick BS.  They killed mouse and keyboard controls too.  Had to settle on the WASD control theme for now just to tolerate it. I like not needing color matched linked gear sockets any more though.  Does not have the PoE feel.  Combat feels off, mouse control is spongy, boss fights are more about memorizing when to dodge now.  Regret not waiting for free release.  I would ask for a refund on my supporter pack if I could.

author: {'steamid': '76561198978618446', 'num_games_owned': 65, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 63, 'playtime_at_review': 724, 'last_played': 1736802042}
review:
[h1]Lost Access After 12 Hours, No Response from Support[/h1]

I really enjoyed the first 12 hours of Path of Exile 2, but suddenly I lost access to the product entirely. It’s been over a week since I contacted support, and I still haven’t received any reply. When I log in on the developer’s website—where I originally activated my early access—it now claims that I’ve never played the game and don’t have early access at all.

This is incredibly frustrating, especially since the gameplay was promising up until I got locked out. I really hope this issue gets fixed, but for now, I can’t recommend a game that I can’t even play and that offers zero support response. Consider waiting until they sort out these access and support issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088542809', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 8820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5202, 'playtime_at_review': 6335, 'last_played': 1736847208}

author: {'steamid': '76561198016445163', 'num_games_owned': 651, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 990, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1734298740}
review:
I cannot recommend PoE2 as it is right now. Best word to describe this game is "tedious". Loot barely exists, "more accessible crafting" is a lie, there is barely any crafting at all, it could be just identifying items on the ground and there could be 0 differences. Enemies are overtuned. I am absolutely fine with slower gameplay, i adore bosses in this game, but if you want to decrease player speed then DO SAME ABOUT ENEMIES. You are slow but enemies are zooming toward you without much time to do anything. Often game turns into Serious Sam where you just run backwards every pack. 
Skill restrictions and enormous, usually empty maps do not help. Game is exhausing and tedious to play atm. I hope some things will be resolved, but recent NERFS to already hard, slow paced and unbalanced game without any buffs makes me nervous bout future. 
Right now its just PoE1 Ruthless that is extremally polished from technical standpoint but, as far as ruthless go, it hates players having fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140350388', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1389, 'last_played': 1735169428}
review: The existence of endgame-affecting Permanent choices like venom drought in act 3 making me feel like I have to start all over again on my melee character (melee early game is torture compared to ranged builds) because I chose the wrong one not knowing, is bad design for any mmo/rpg.  I'm personally fine with the choosing the class/ascendancy being permanent, i'm fine with melee being harder, but the idea of making people feel like they need to know their endgame builds with knowledge of the whole game's permanent choices ahead of time makes it feel really discouraging for newcomers of the series to even start.

author: {'steamid': '76561198415690964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2855, 'last_played': 1734456206}
review:
It's a bit of a grind, same as PoE 1.

I do like the new slower, more punchy and deliberate mechanics/combos, and I really liked the campaign, but in the end, you need to spend hundreds of hours on it to keep making meaningful progress, and to feel like you're becoming more powerful.

I don't have hundreds of hours to sink into one new game.

I wish there was some kind of dad league with increased loot drops, the ability to properly craft and try things on, fiddle with builds, see damage numbers, etc, but there isn't, so you need to be childless and unemployed with lots of free time to properly enojoy the endgame, and I'm neither, so it's not for me.

I didn't mind spending some money on early access to find that out though, and I do like GGG's output, it's just a mismatch with my current life situation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026815343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1205, 'last_played': 1733965222}
review: Constant nerfs without passive points refund to make up for it. Im fine with nerfing a build but if youre going to do so then at least allow me to swap into another build. Instead you have to make a new character because of how expensive they gate the passive point refund system

author: {'steamid': '76561198009980939', 'num_games_owned': 417, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 4333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3425, 'last_played': 1735343026}
review:
It's like Ruthless mode in PoE1 to some extent. If you like that you'll love this. Also some souls-like design philosophy. Lotsa rolling. Bosses have more distinct, dangerous attack patterns and later on have bullet hell mechanics. Running past trash mobs is more efficient than killing them unless you need to level up cuz they're all damage sponges. Skill tree is like a stripped down version of the PoE 1 tree. Archnemesis mods are back, not a fan.

Sanctum is awful as an ascension trial, and the Ultimatum trial makes me wish every ascension trial was Sanctum.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052294905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3, 'playtime_at_review': 1301, 'last_played': 1736701181}
review: Worst drop rates i have ever seen in a game. Every Map feels like mobs got twice as strong while you didnt because lack of good EQ. Magic attacks from enemies are unreasonable powerful.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971156489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 797, 'playtime_at_review': 4226, 'last_played': 1736828011}
review: For the time being I cannot recommend this game as it freezes my system constantly. There are no "fixes". There are workarounds that might buy you a few additional loading screens without freezing, but eventually every "fix" still has the freezing issue. It is not Windows or the 24H2 security update. It is the POE2 software itself. And GGG has been incredibly silent on this issue and any timeline for a fix. If and when they fix this I'll come back and leave a review that talks about the gameplay, but there's no point in doing that now since I can no longer risk my hardware attempting to play the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072044943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 2143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2143, 'last_played': 1733954458}
review:
PoE2 is a decent campaign to be played once, but it fails spectacularly at being a hack'n'slash that makes you want to grind for hours and come back for a reset every 3 months.

Of course, technically it's much better than its predecessor - graphics are great, most skills look and feel good, and the optimization is fine considering I haven't noticed any crazy slowdown on my old RX 5700 XT. The bosses are also the highlight of the game (with a few exceptions) and they're quite fun to fight for the first time.

But the game is just a slog to play through. Every area is a gigantic maze filled with dead-ends. Act 3 is particularly bad with this, I've spent 30 minutes in a single zone without even trying to clear it fully but just trying to find the exit and the objectives (mini-bosses, etc.) This is by far one of the biggest issues - sure it can be fun to fully explore the first time, but you're supposed to want to play 2-3 characters every 3 months. And the thought of playing through Act 3 again any time soon is already exhausting.

ARPGs are supposed to be all about loot, but loot is pathetic in PoE2. And what little drops is completely worthless - like a normal rarity item with a base 30 levels below the current area (best I've seen: white lvl 16 gloves in a lvl 56 area). You're supposed to "craft" but there's no crafting in this game. You can only use various orbs to add completely random mods to items which will be worthless 99% of the time. Found a cool armor that just needs life to be an improvement over your current piece? Enjoy using a rare exalted orb to add +4 to maximum life. The end result is that you can often feel weaker as the game goes on and your few "good" pieces of armor from 15h ago start showing their age.

If you enjoy the melee playstyle in these games, know that the PoE2 designers actively despise you. Everything is made to make melee feel terrible - many enemies have on-death effects or stand in degen pools, and half your stronger passive points come with a nice -10% attack speed just in case you ever felt too fast with your 2 seconds swings. And it's not like you're tanky either - if your power fantasy is to be a big immovable wall, this won't happen here. You'll have to kite even basic monsters like everyone else because otherwise you'll just die in a couple of seconds.

PoE2 wanted to be the "Dark Souls of ARPGs" and succeeded at being neither. There is no reason to play this over Path of Exile or Elden Ring. And if you just want to play the campaign once to check it out - might as well wait until the full release when it'll be F2P.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980039448', 'num_games_owned': 469, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 9992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 4138, 'playtime_at_review': 3762, 'last_played': 1736831257}
review:
I can't in good faith recommend POE2 in its current state. (in T7 maps for context)

CONs
-Slow campaign
-Painful gearing process - from early campaign to maps, the solution to getting gear is simply go to the trade website
-Insanely huge maps - why does it take 25 minutes to clear a T3 magic map?
-One shot mechanics are alive and well, despite SIGNIFICANT investment in survivability in the tree and items
-Painful on-death mechanics, especially in maps. Nothing hurts quite as bad as seeing an expensive item on the ground after dead

PROs
-Great boss fights (minus one-shots with minimal telegraphing)
-Great art/design/UI
-Combat generally feels great, despite being SLOW

Understand the game is in Early Access, if you're liking it, that's awesome. I certainly enjoyed the game for most of the hours I put into it, but the CONs listed above have killed my enjoyment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010207209', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1733696221}
review:
Very Promising Game. Wolf Boss is Tuned to Hell. So far bosses in Act 1 are more mechanically complex than the entire campaign of PoE 1. New players should expect to hit a wall quickly.
My sentiments agree the with the present dissenting reviews of the game:
1) The developers intended to produce a game which had more in common with the Souls-like genre than the original Diablo (2) clone of the original Path of Exile. This is a betrayal of the players whom are passionate and addicted to the former game. A departure in genre is not inherently evil, however, to modernize the previous engine, make minimal effort to visually differentiate between the two, and simply increment the version number is a fundamental failure of branding.
The second preview video speaks to how poorly they differentiated the two- I encourage the reader to watch the trailer and attempt to spot the differences- the UI is an intermediate state between the two games- 5 flasks are featured instead of 2, and the spirit meter over the mana bar and presence of the portal button are unique to the 2nd game. Without simply asserting that change is bad, this marginal change in visual style fails to prepare the veteran player for the jarring differences in mechanics.
Notably, PoE 1 is a game where the player is expected to obtain a power level which almost trivializes most combat encounters. And from an early level. Boss fights have the potential to be challenging, and may require the player to focus on survival and endurance. This is heavily contrasted with this games desolate, and oppressive attitude towards encounters. The lowest ranks of enemies and consistently threatening and attack in large mobs. Higher tiers of enemies have the damage and persistence to be greater threats than the named boss fights. Items are scarcely dropped and the player is constantly experiencing a position of oppression where the environment is a substantial challenge to be overcame.
2) Alluded to in the comparison between titles, PoE 2 is not a particularly rewarding Souls-like. Encounters routinely (read nearly always) have two or thee phases with individual health bars rivaling entire fights in the former game. Spaces are tight and maneuverability is limited thought the first act. The inclusion of checkpoints is a welcomed change, though the union of a checkpoint and a disproportionately wide semi-open box is a tired cliché indicating a protracted fight to follow. The experience is unvaried and loses its luster after the first or second repetition. A single enemy will manifest with high mobility and health. Their attacks will feature stuns which chain into massive damage area of effect (AoE). Attacks routinely deplete half or all one’s health in a single blow and affect a portion of them map exceeding (70 or 80)% of the playable surface. Fights are inter spaced with phases where the primary antagonist becomes immortal and the player is forced to defeat a sizable pack of base enemies within the greatly reduced area of the boss arena. This process repeats for multiple minutes before a health bar is depleted, the primary antagonist transforms and the process must be repeated for the next phase. Routinely these fights have 3 phases spanning in encounter duration of multiple minutes to fractions of an hour. Dying at any point, most often to a single hit, forces the player to restart from the beginning of the entire encounter.
These fights are long and arduous. A test of skill and ability, but they fail the reward the player. No dispensation of items or currency arises which uniquely rewards the players persistence. Plainly, the player will earn more, for less work, in a fraction of the time be remaining among the common enemies. Here, PoE 2 fails to achieve its ambition of being a souls-like. Fights become repetitious, tedious, and unrewarding. Fatigue sets in and the player is left questioning if the outcome merits the abuse. Some may revel in the suffering, but I find no joy in being broken and battered by a loved one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971899978', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1932, 'last_played': 1734710990}
review:
The game is not in a good place currently. 
Slower gameplay is a welcome idea, but when it only affects the player and the monsters remain unchanged for PoE then it simply doesn't work. The game is also presently lacking any real crafting system as the current implementation is functionally identical to identifying an item found on the ground. 

These are my main complaints, but honestly apart from removing the need to press 5 potions every 5 seconds I struggle to find an area where PoE2 improve on its predecessor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047791722', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 10250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10244, 'last_played': 1735334917}
review:
Fantastic piece of an ARPG until you reach maps. After that you just randomly die on every second or third map, until you can afford broken defences (it's called energy shield). Then you randomly die on every 5th to 10th map. 
For now, it's better to try out different classes and skills before reaching endgame and don't interact with it in any way, unless you are top 0.1% experienced players or RMT to get decent imbalance items, which will result in you completing maps much faster, lessening frustration caused by random deaths.
Wish I could play more of that, but not in the current state of endgame mapping.

Will be updating this review after trying out new patches, but for now I cannot recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114221912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 263, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1734257205}
review:
So, my mate Johan - bless his gaming incompetence - hands me Path of Exile 2 like it's some divine gift, right? Imagine getting excited to play together, and then BAM! The character customization screen is smoother than a dolphin's backside, but when the gaming starts, the network decides to have a seizure with 2000ms ping. It's like trying to play chess during an earthquake - completely mental!

Path of Exile 2 is basically the Diablo 4's clever cousin who became a philosophy major, can quote Nietzsche at dinner, but can't figure out how to use a washing machine. Intelligent? Absolutely. Attractive? About as appealing as a wet sock left in a gym locker for a month!

Let's talk microtransactions, shall we? Oh, they're generous - they give you 300 points to start. Generous like a car salesman offering you free floor mats when you're buying a Ferrari! Ten dollars gets you a whopping 10 points, and a single tab costs 30 points. Want a skin? That'll be 400 points, mate. It's like paying rent for a virtual wardrobe!

The gold economy? More restricted than a nun's dating profile. You want a random ring? That'll be THOUSANDS of gold - which translates to hours of gameplay. Hours! I could learn a new language in the time it takes to afford one bloody ring! And skill points? Oh, they've created this massive, complex skill tree that makes quantum physics look like a children's connect-the-dots.

The screen zoom is so hilariously designed, it's clear they're more interested in showing off your expensive skin than actual gameplay. You'll be admiring your pixel-perfect outfit while getting murdered by mobs you can't even see. It's like being mugged while taking a selfie - absolutely brilliant!

Crafting? More painful than watching my nan try to use Snapchat. Every single crafting attempt is like playing Russian roulette with your virtual items. Can't even reset an item properly? It's madness!

They should rename this "Path of Lags 2" or "Path of Microtransactions 2".

author: {'steamid': '76561198035626005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3234, 'last_played': 1732498754}
review:
TLDR: After over 50 hours of this this game I can confidently say, unfortunately, that the people who are going to enjoy this game the most are brand new fans, or casual Dragon Age enjoyers. But I do recommend it, I enjoyed this game.

To be clear. I am a massive BioWare fan. I’ve played all their games (even Shattered Steel on my dad’s old PC from the 90s). I’m going to go down the different aspects of the game below.

Technical level/business decisions: in my entire 54 hour playthrough I had absolutely 0 crashes. 0 frame drops and only 1 bug, that I easily fixed with a quick fast travel. The game runs flawlessly which is a great thing. Also, EA for some reason let BioWare cook this thing with no other BS like Denuvo, MtX, requiring EA app, etc.

Visuals/art style/envirments: it’s no secret that the discourse for this game on its art style is tumultuous. But when I actually sat down to experience it, I grew to like the art style quickly. The envirments are absolutely stunning, and there are a LOT of different environments. Animations are also surprisingly stellar for a Frostbite engine game. There are moments where the animations are janky and not immersive, but overall I was incredibly impressed with the visuals. 

Gameplay/combat: surprisingly one of my favorite parts of the game. Progression and skill tree is really expansive, and has an absolute massive build craft options (respeccing for free too!) the combat is an amalgamation of God of War 2018 combined with Mass Effect 3, and came together really well. Builds can become so OP I had to increase the difficulty.

Accessibility: every aspect of the games interface and accessibility can be changed. You don’t like the HUD? Turn it off, you don’t like damage numbers? Turn it off. You love difficult games but hate “bullet spongy” enemies? Do the custom difficulty and turn enemy health down and everything else up. A truly customizable experience for everyone. And it works really well.

Writing/Dialogue: this is where things start to decline for me a bit. BioWare has always impressed me with its writing. Specifically its companions, and this game for me, it large succeeds only in specific companions. The overall writing of this game all over the place. The tone changes regularly, the dialogue is off in many ways. It has such a safe, “neutered” writing in its dialogue. The majority of conversations you have are met with brevity and optimism. I did not like this. So many companions didn’t have nuanced arcs, as much as I was interested in their characters, save for a few. So many safe options taken, no states within your group really happen, and no matter what choice you make the group never really experiences tension with each other save for maybe 2 conversations.
In contrast though, there are moments and characters that showcase the power of terrific BioWare character writing. Every conversation with Solas was gripping and incredible, no small thanks to his VA, who did an amazing job. Also, characters I originally hated when I met I grew to like and even adore as their story progressed (shout out to Bellara). And of course, the ending sequence of this game, which can take upwards of 3 hours to complete, is the absolute best part of the entire game, filled with twists and turns and tough choices. It sucks that it had to be the ending to get all those big moments. 

In conclusion: I was initially disappointed as it seemed BioWares writing was at its weakest with this game. As I played though. The writing and even dialogue got a little better, and a little better. And by the end I was fully immersed. 
This game is very clearly biowares “clean slate” moment. A bridge to open a new era of BioWare to us after years of nothing save for 2 disappointing games. I genuinely believe if you are a new fan to this series, you will enjoy this game a lot. If you are a casual DA fan, you will enjoy this game as well. And if you’re a hardcore DA nerd you may struggle with the tonal shift and deflated companions in comparison to others. But overall the main story is great, and I absolutely recommend this game to anyone

author: {'steamid': '76561198084443159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3883, 'last_played': 1732172844}
review:
Ok, I'll try my best to help people who, like me were torn between bad and good reviews. There's a lot of fuss around the game right now so here's an honest review:

[b]Gameplay:[/b] This game is an action RPG. If you're expecting something like BG3, this isn't for you. If you like the genre, the gameplay is great. 

Exploration - You have multiple areas to explore, even though it is not open-world. I'd say it reminded me of the God of War type of exploration. You have some small encounters with enemies in that area, some loot around it, codex items, and chests. 

Quests - You have main quests, companions quests and area/faction-related quests. They definitely put more work into the main plot and for that reason, I had the feeling that every area/faction-related quest was somewhat tied to the story and I felt the need to complete those before moving on to the next main quest (probably explain the number of hours I've played), that being said I don't think you NEED to complete everything, but it was interesting to see how every faction was doing in the middle of that chaos and what their initial problem was. 
Companions quests as always are there to solve their personal issues, some are more fun than others, but overall it's pretty decent. 

Decisions - Some decisions were presented during the game, a few definitely had more impact towards the end than others, and some of those just changed a few details. And yes, people can die depending on what you do or well... don't do. 

[b]Difficulty/Combat:[/b] I personally loved the combat, and I played around with the skill tree a LOT until I finally decided what I wanted and which style I preferred. How hard the game is, is up to you. You can tweak it to your liking pretty much everything and have custom settings. Enemies health bar, aggression, how much damage towards you. Just play around and find whatever fits you. 

You can make combos with your teammates, using different types of abilities and I kind of decided my team based on as many combos as possible considering my own abilities and theirs.

Overall, combat is pretty dynamic and cool to see when you have multiple enemies firing at you from a distance while a huge ogre is trying to charge at your sorry archer's ass. 

[b]Story:[/b] This is a hero's journey to its core. No, you can't be evil. No, it's not the traditional RPG. And yes, everyone just wants to be hopeful that everything will turn out ok, yada yada. That being said, I adopted the "For sure this game has no interest in actually sad outcomes". I gotta say I was not expecting some of the bits towards the end when it came to it. 

Main plot - I personally enjoyed a lot following the main quests. There were no moments during the main quests that I wasn't fully into it. Nostalgia definitely hit me multiple times. It was engaging enough for me.

Dialogue - You have dialogue options that don't really impact outcomes (which is different than the decisions you are presented from time to time), so you know, dialogue options are there more as a do you want to be nice? Cope with humour and crack some jokes? Or just go straight to the point? It doesn't really affect anything but the other character's way of answering you too. A few times I noticed one or two companions approving/disapproving of something, by the end I realized that those rare answers were a minor decision on something. 
It can be goofy or cringe sometimes, but there were moments I laughed or I felt bad/happy about it. And to be completely honest the "bad writing" moments felt as stupid as every other Bioware game I've played, nothing new. And I loved those games as well. 

Factions - Your faction does change characters who talk to you and does allow you to see other dialogue options. It was interesting. 

Companions - This is probably where the opinions divide the most. Some of the companion's personal stories are definitely more compelling than others. At some moments I did have to push some of their questline a little bit with the hope that would have some payoff by the end of it. And you know what? I think it did for the most part. Not every companion has the "perfect resolution" no matter what you decide/do, and I liked that. 

For those complaining about "woke" stuff or "LGBT propaganda" related to one of the companions, I'll say: Yes, the companion does talk about their gender and if I put together all the bits of cutscene or dialogue related to that, it will give me around 5-10 min in total within the 60h it took me to complete EVERYTHING. So no, it's not pushing anything down anyone's throat. Whether you decide to do their quest or not, is completely up to you. You can love or hate the character but don't say that Bioware never had LGBT characters before, because it did. If that's your ONLY excuse to hate the game, then I'd recommend using your 2 inches of brain and time to play something else instead of crying all over the internet. 

[b]Conclusion:[/b] It's a pretty solid and fun game to play. Maybe it's not the Dragon Age many of the fans were expecting. I personally didn't know what to expect cause I feel like Bioware is always changing the way they approach their games. The essence is there. The lore is there. And it was a great 60-hour journey. If you're like me, don't care that much for the occasional stupid jokes or not being able to be the chaotic character/reason for despair of that world, then just give it a try.  Hope that helps.

author: {'steamid': '76561198205360327', 'num_games_owned': 393, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 7082, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7075, 'last_played': 1733337411}
review:
So. Now after i played this game at 100%.

You can roll trough barrels, chests and other things 9/10 game.
You can pet cats and dogs 10/10 game.
You can pet and cuddle with a GRIFFON 11//10 game.
You can play stone scissors paper with the cutes skeleton u can find out there 10000/10 game.

Jokes aside. Was it a good game? Did it deserve the hate? Is it a real Dragon age game?

Go find that out yourself. AND i mean actually try it, dont buy it, play it for 2 hours and spamm your negative review in here. TRY IT.

I played Dragon Age: Origins, Dragon Age 2 and Dragon Age Inquistion, more than one time. And i will play this game more than one time. Because i like it.

It took me about 70 hours to complete it with all the achievements and shit. And i wasnt bored for a single second.

The Gameplay was very giga big baba bubu fun! I enjoyed it really hard.
The Story was good. It won't throw Dragon Age: Origins off the throne, but it was a good story.

I can not say that all dialogues were written very well, some felt very...random/unnatural (in dialogues with companions). But the Voice Actors did such a good job, i forgot about that. Respect to them tho.

Also i had ZERO bugs or any other problems. I mean. This should be normal, maybe a few, but these days...its not normal. So yea!

Something that would also be worth mentioning: I liked many new...informations about the lore, how things are..or was...or will be, very interesting!

So overall. It's a good game. And for me: It's still a good game in the world of Dragon age. 

So im happy to see what the future will bring. Im already hyped for...yea 

SPOILER

SPOILER

SPOILER

This teaser thing after the credits...im already interested what happens in the next game. I hope sooner than 10 years...but yea, i will be patient lol.

Ps: I Love Dragon Age. Forever.

PPS: THE ONLY REAL THING I HATE ABOUT THIS GAME IS THAT THEY DONT BRING UP AN ACHIEVMENT FOR THE NIGHTMARE MODE?!?!? BIO WARE I DONT FORIVE YOU FOR THAT. PLS MAKE ONE!

Pps: Taash would say: "Who doesen't like Dragon Age?!"

Ppps: Still trying to win stone scissors paper against manfred...

author: {'steamid': '76561198219654637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4980, 'last_played': 1732306114}
review:
This is barely a thumbs up since I don’t feel like I wasted my money. I enjoyed aspects of the game. 

As a standalone game, The Veilguard is fine, and gets better after the weak first act. As a Dragon Age game, it’s the worst in the series. It would be easier if the game was just bad, but there are sparks of hope every now and then. I love the setting so much, and wanted this to be a return to form. 
Most of the story design choices are just baffling, if not downright insulting. They absolutely butchered legacy characters and all previous player choices. It feels spiteful. I hope that if we get another Dragon Age game, there are big changes with how the leadership and writing team approach the story. Trespasser was such a great set-up for new adventures, and the current dev team fumbled an easy win. It’s actually devastating to witness as a long-time fan. 

I know the culture war tourists have labeled the game “woke”, but it’s really not, and I say that as someone who would be called “a woke” by these people. This is pure sanitized US corporate fluff. It’s not about inclusivity, it’s about being as inoffensive as possible in order to sell more. 
You won’t find any uncomfortable politics here. Religion and basic cultural elements are barely there, when they’ve previously been central to the setting. The revelations in the game should be society shattering for the entire continent, but nobody cares. Everything is sanitized, and no one gets to be morally grey. You’re either good or comically evil.

Thedas has such a wealth of messed up situations with amazing story potential.
The city elf is one of the best origins, and it’s brutal. I still think about encounters like the Broodmother and quests like All That Remains. Or the elven inquisitor getting called a rabbit the moment they step into the Winter Palace, and starting the quest at a disadvantage. I wanted the kind of hopeless horror that shows the world and its people are very much flawed, but still worth fighting for. None of that is present here. 

The Lords of Fortune are a good example of the toothless writing. What do you mean these treasure hunters don’t loot tombs? Or that they have cultural advisers so they can return artifacts to their rightful owners? The faction is led by a pretty well-known cultural artifact thief! Let them be shady.
We finally get to see Tevinter, and it’s just a load of nothing. Why is there nothing with the Imperial chantry? The Magisterium? Slavery? What’s the point of the Shadow Dragons, when we see none of the horrors we’ve spent three games (and countless other forms of media) hearing about? Yes, Dock Town is the place for the lower classes, but you’re telling me that slavery isn’t visible in any way? At the docks?! How do you even make Tevinter this boring?
Show us the brutality of the Antaam occupation, instead of just telling us it’s bad. Let us see the casual cruelty of Tevinter culture, instead of hiding it in the codex. Let the elves be angry instead of happily embracing atheism and other species. 

The game tells you things without letting you see, shape, or just experience the events yourself. It tells you how to feel and doesn’t allow any deviations. 
I’m pretty much always a goody two-shoes player, so it should work for me, but this game made me wish for evil options. Or just the chance to tell some characters to go pound sand. I would absolutely embrace the Dark Urge with some of the story beats, and it’s such a weird feeling to have with Dragon Age. 
A big issue is the writing. I’m not expecting archaic language (though I’d prefer it), but almost all characters speak like they know what TikTok is. It’s not like the series ever had everybody speak like Morrigan, but the constant quips and meme-like reactions were too much this time. Everybody reacts like they know there’s a camera on them. The voice-acting being all over the place doesn’t help. The only consistently brilliant performances among the companions were Emmrich and Davrin. 
I get the devs wanted to focus on new players, but they could’ve done it so much better. Games like BG3, The Witcher 3 or WotR are good examples of how you don’t need to coddle new players. The games were worth the learning curve, and Dragon Age should be worth it too. 

I’m also confused by the reviews that said this is the most focused game yet. It’s really not? The pacing is wonky from start to finish. Most heavy emotional beats just didn’t land. The hyped “big choice” happens way too early and makes very little sense. My character doesn’t know these people, and I, as the player, only got here as well. At least let my character explain/defend their choice, instead of making him self-flagellate uselessly while basically being called a heartless war criminal. 
The game would be so much better if it started with Rook’s origin story, instead of constantly telling us how cool it was. The story also would’ve benefited from being much smaller in scale, or from spending more time building up to the initial ritual. I’m not sure how new players would even care about Varric with how lackluster his presence is. The same goes for the other legacy characters. They’re just shallow imitations of themselves, completely stripped of their context.

The friendships and romances are barely there. The game kept telling me that these companions were my character’s found family, but never actually showed it. It honestly felt like the others didn’t even like Rook. Having finished the game, I’m not even sure why he was there at all. 
A faction related quest for Rook specifically would’ve helped establish him in the world. 

I was interested in seeing some actual cultural clashes between the characters. You have two Dalish elves and a Tevinter mage, but there’s no real suspicion at any point. Bellara and Neve are just immediate besties. 
You can’t ask Neve questions about her upbringing or opinions on living in a mage supremacy as a lower-class mage. The game just tells you she’s a good person and loves Dock Town. But she’s still a mage from Tevinter. If she has no questionable opinions, why is that? Why does she think like she does when she grew up in a nation like Tevinter? I’d like to know.
Similarly, why are there no discussion on the different varieties of Andrastianism? Outside of Davrin and Bellara, all other companions would have lived under the rule of either the Orlesian or Imperial Chantry (I know Rivain is different, but still). Do they not have any misconceptions or suspicions about the others? Why is everyone so chill about the Qun?
It’s unfortunate that the ability to ask the characters questions outside of cutscenes was removed. I assume the justification would be something about boundaries, but these are not real people. Let me pester them! 

The combat is fun at first, but the limited skill slots hinder it. The companion limit is a horrible choice, as is the fact that they can’t be controlled. They might as well not be there, considering how utterly useless they are in a fight. I spent most fights running away and dodging, so my mage character wouldn’t get body-slammed every five seconds.
The inventory system is horrible. The vendors and the faction “rank ups” break immersion. I understand they’re remnants from the live service version of the game, but damn, such a poor system. 
I didn’t mind the art style. The CC is good, but somehow not as good as in DAI. The clothes and weapons are over-designed, so I’m grateful for the transmog system. 
The scenery is stunning but lifeless, just like in Inquisition. The NPCs are static and don’t react to anything around them. 
The music is so basic that I can only recall one moment (Weisshaupt) where I actually noticed it.

I don’t know. I could write even more, but what’s the point? In the end, I wish the game had been better, and I wish over a decade of being a fan hadn’t been dismissed so brutally. “Rocks fall, everybody dies” is a sad way to say goodbye.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068140228', 'num_games_owned': 583, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 7537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3653, 'last_played': 1733713433}
review:
First blind playthrough: 60hrs

I preface this with the fact that I've played the other Dragon Age games, the Mass Effect ones too. The TL;DR here is that if you liked Mass Effect 2, you'll be okay with this game. Its clumsy in places, but there is a lot of heart here.

Does it bother me that my choices from the prior games are ignored by the game? Yeah, it sure does, but those choices still matters. I still made them. They happened, even if this game doesn't show them. Such is legacy sometimes, there is a lot to record and remember, so many variables. I think they cut too much of the fat, but it's not the first time this series has done this, and anyone who denies it are kidding themselves. Remember when a Dalish warden sacrificed herself and so the clans got the hinterlands as their own? No? Neither do the games, don't worry. 

The game-play is pretty fun, I played on a custom setting to up the enemy damage but keep their HP manageable. I was a Mage, went with the spellblade and found that I could punch above my weight if I was careful. I will ashamedly admit it took me more hours than I'd like to realize that my allies didn't have HP and their support spells were to save my ass when I decide to go punch the level 40 superboss at level 29. (I eventually won, by the way.)

I enjoyed the companions, although I recognize this is a very subjective statement. The companions remind me a lot of my dungeons and dragons games, of the people I play with and the characters they bring to the table. I enjoy the mundane and almost domestic moments of getting to talk, I like the interesting dynamics that play out between them every time I head back to the lighthouse. I know it's not for everyone, but it was good for me.

If you got this far, I'm glad some of my words resonated. For good or ill. This game made a lot of mistakes, but there is a lot of love stitched into every seam. There is a passion here, to tell a story, to finish one chapter and move onto the next. The team had a heavy weight to bear, 15 years of expectation, 10 of anticipation and a name so big it could make or break them...  But, as an old dwarf once said, stories are about change. 
Dragon Age has changed and I think that's okay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198802405731', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3111, 'last_played': 1731118943}
review:
I recommend this game with caution. I will preface by saying that Dragon Age: Origins is likely my favorite game of all time with few contenders. That being said, I think every entry has something good to offer if you are willing to enjoy each game for what they are rather than what you want them to be. If I had to say where Veilguard ranks among the four games with DA:O being the top in the "amazing, with flaws" category, it would be right under Inquisition in the "decent and fun with big issues" category, and above "decent, but I hate it" category that Dragon Age 2 sits in.

Dragon Age: The Veilguard continues the series tradition following the first game, of ambitiously doing its own thing and failing to live up to its potential. It fully embraces the series shift over the last couple games from a dark fantasy CRPG to a high fantasy action ARPG and I would describe the experience like showing up for Dragon Age and getting Hogwarts: Legacy, which was definitely an unexpected (honestly unwelcome) change in energy and tone for me. There is still some darkness in the game, but it is pretty sanitized and shows up in specific moments before being lampooned by some cringy/witty dialogue (the Disney/Marvel approach). You can't ever really be a bad guy or be mean (every choice has a positive spin) and are firmly the cool Chosen Dude to stop the mainly cartoonishly evil villains from ending the world. Most of the choices you make don't really matter or change much, and the ones that do are often lame choices in my opinion. That all sounds pretty negative on the surface, but I actually think that broadly speaking, the main plot of gathering allies and going on the suicide mission delivers pretty well and the finale was pretty great. Though I don't know how I feel about how things actually resolved and what it will mean for the story going forward (if it does).

There is a lot of solid stuff here - beautiful environments, interesting lore revelations, some good character moments, pretty fun combat, and some cool cinematic moments accompanied by great music which all do the heavy lifting to make this a mediocre, enjoyable experience because there is so much that is... not solid.
The first 5/6 hours of game-play is tough to get through and really shows off the worst of the game, namely: bad line delivery of weird modernized, often unnatural dialogue; a bunch of repetition and rehashing plot-points over and over;  pointless choices that don't really change anything; weird characterization and development for existing franchise characters; and probably more. Quite frankly, a lot of this feels like it was written for a juvenile audience with very little attention span for plot, which is quite irritating given the last few games. This shows up even in how choices are presented to you which really is just "here is a sum of this side and that side, do what you want, we don't care," so nothing feels like it has real weight.
Of course there is good dialogue and good voice performances as well, but that is the minority as most just does the job. Companions are very hit or miss and really wasn't impressed by any of them or their story-lines, but I do appreciate that side quests were tied into the main plot and they do have some influence on events. Whether you choose to do all of the companion missions and strengthen your allies or not influences survival rates in the last missions of the game much like Mass Effect 2 which is about the only thing you can influence in this game.
The combat, while fun, gets annoying and repetitive as the game progresses and enemies get pretty aggressive, as there is often too much happening at once but you will learn to deal with it especially since the game isn't hard (subjective, I know). The fact that pretty much every approach in this game is to fight also makes the 50 or so hours of fighting you have to do get stale. I can think of only one time where I could resolve a situation with talking instead of fighting. 

Overall, I had fun with this game even with all the bad in it. I am not too excited about the direction the series has gone in, but I have felt that way since the second game. If you are looking for a game more like DA:O then we have Baldur's Gate 3 which is more that style. Or just play DA:O again...

author: {'steamid': '76561198037650969', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1129, 'last_played': 1731816173}
review:
Almost 20 hours in, 1/3 of story completed with some sidequests in between, I can safely say, that Dragon Age: The Veilguard is not a bad game. 
HOWEVER
It is also not an exemplary RPG and is quite different in terms of tone and style from previous DA games, especially if you're a fan of DA Origins.

It is a decent, higher than average action RPG set in the DA universe. It feels like the sort of junk food that you crave time to time or if you have no other options. If you compare it to other RPG examples, like the recent Metaphor, or last year's BG3, you will not find the same level of depth and character/story interaction as you might find there. Writing here is not the best (you'll find much better examples out there), and sometimes it's downright cringy (but at least not as often as some people say it is).

Gameplay wise, it starts strong and fun... for some time. I'm saying that because at this point I'm already starting to feel a slight burnout and I can also feel some mmo DNA sprinkled throughout (remnants of old scrapped ideas for this title). Some of the bosses are the highlights, but most of the regular enemies get repetitive real quick and the sense of depth to the combat is somewhat false. Yes, you have some options and flexibility, but you end up mashing the same 2 buttons and it just works. Also the game is not very challenging even on high difficulties. So, hopefully it'll get more engaging later, but I doubt it. In the end it's just ok, it works, and it can be fun.
Exploration and puzzles are just meh. I mostly do it to look at the environments and satisfy my game ADHD (I need all the collectibles man)

Music and sound design are decent, but sort of... generic? Even the fact that Hans Zimmer worked on the OST didn't really help, since you can find some of his previous works much more memorable. Voice acting is not bad, especially on some characters, but it often feels bland, almost like there was a problem with direction of the lines. However, I've heard much worse in other titles, so I'm okay with it. 

Hands down the strongest parts of the game are visuals and the overall optimization. In the current age where we constantly get half-baked games that also require you to run at low res, med settings and upscaling + frame gen on to get a somewhat decent performance (looking at you, MH Wilds), this game feels like a dream in that sense. No issues at all and it's always pleasant to look at. And that hair! Some of the best looking hair I've seen in a game to date, great stuff.

Anyway, my overall score is somewhere around 6.5, at high points it's more like a 7.0

I doubt that it'll increase in time since I already can see what the whole deal is about, so my advice - wait for a sale, don't get it for a full price unless you absolutely want to? Your choice. You'll probably still get a good bit of fun out of it. But if you're more focused on the roleplaying aspect, be warned, you might be disappointed. 

If my opinion suddenly changes once I finish the game, I'll return and write an update.

(I really wish there would be a 3rd option for reviews like "buy on sale" or "mixed", because this game would fit there pretty well)

author: {'steamid': '76561198403710759', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1731917444}
review:
There's a lot of things I can say on Dragon Age Veilguard. I don't think it's a bad or terrible game, not nearly to the extent that people are saying online. But I also don't think it's a great game either. I think the comparisons to Baldur's Gate 3 is kind of unfair, as I don't think they're exactly comparable, ignoring the fact that BG3 was kind of a lightning in a bottle situation. Veilguard is definitely a product of mismanagement, but not in the way that everyone thinks. I think we're seeing another example of a game that was stuck in development hell for too long, caught onto too many trends that there popular a few years ago and didn't really keep up.

But I also don't think that Dragon Age, as a series, really knows what it wants to be. You can look back through all four installments as evidence of that. Every time, there's new system, completely new combat overhauls, and overthunk and overwrought ways of doing things. Compared to Mass Effect, that series was far more tighter, where each installment simply built upon and refined what was already ther. This didn't happen with Dragon Age, and we're seeing it again. I like to think if Dragon Age 2 released in this year, it would've gotten far more hate now than it did initially, and it did take a lot of heat.

So let's get the big point out of the room right now. The writing. Yes, the writing isn't...great. It's basically servicable with a series of cringe moments and slightly stilted voice acting. This isn't to say it's BAD. Personally, I have a deliniation between what I call 'bad' and what I call 'servicable', and this game does fall more into the latter. There are brief moments, usually the moments where Solas or Varric is involved where the writing is far tighter and that shows during cutscenes. But those moments are not nearly as recognizable. 

This is more endemic to how EA does things, and I think many of us can agree there's a been a notable decline in quality of work ever since EA purchased the company, but it skirted by on that 'BioWare magic', which I'm fair to say died when Anthem came out and had been dying when Inquisition was being made. EA from what I can tell, from what I read going into various writing credits of the writing team involved, makes it clear that EA did not want to pay for compatant writers. A cardinal sin in any story heavy RPG. If one were to check the IMDBs of these people, you'll note that few have decent writing credits under their belt. These people simply weren't experienced enough, largely because I believe the publisher didn't want to pay for quality.

Now, one can make whatever 'DEI' argument they want to make, and really, I'm not here for that. I don't care. I will call the character doing pushups for misgendering as a cringe scene, because it is a cringe scene. But that scene does not damn an entire game. The game runs flawlessly on PC, with no bugs or hiccups and stays far above 60FPS. This is alien in a major title market known for having PC issues on Day One. The sound design and art is very well done and I have to admit, for all it's faults, it's probably the prettiest game I've played all year.

As much as I loathe to admit, I'm having fun with game's combat. Is it Origins? Hell no, it's so far removed from Origins, I struggle to know why one decided to add the Dragon Age label to it. But it's also not the MMO-lite slog that Inquisition was either. Making the statement of being a 'God of War Reboot' clone is partially apt, as I'd say there's enough variety to keep it from being a wholesale ripoff. But the point here is, the combat is fun. And entertaining, and really, I can't really argue for much else.

Basically, all in the all, the game is...fine. It's servicable. It's not GoY material, and anyone that says otherwise is selling something. But I enjoy the game for what it is, warts an all. Largely because I'm an adult and I don't care that trans and NB people exist. Those messages regarding them aren't for me. Could those messages been a little more subtle and written better? Certainly, no lie there. But to imply that's all the game is, is an unfair statement.

The jist is this. If you want to play a game that basically is gonna play out like a young adult TV series. It's popcorn entertainment, if you can unplug your brain long enough. Hell, I might even play through it again, given how things go. But for now? The game is fine. I'd dare to say to good, but the writing probably does hold it back. I'd say play it if you like RPGs, but everyone probably just wait till it's on sale. I'd say it's probably worth playing in any case.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069292690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 3400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3400, 'last_played': 1731053813}
review:
TL;DR good video game and poor Dragon Age game, but the ending sticks the landing

As a lighthearted fantasy adventure, Veilguard is immaculate. It's well-optimized, bug-free, DRM-free, microtransaction-free, visuals are gorgeous, combat is engaging (after you go into the difficulty settings and turn down enemy health so they're not such damage sponges), and its accessibility options and quality of life perks (including a transmog/glam system for your outfits!) should be the new gold standard the industry aspires to. On the whole, it feels like no expense was spared to bring the developers' vision to life, and on that merit, I can recommend Veilguard.

But only just barely. Because it's also a Dragon Age game, made by Bioware, that flees from its own pedigree. Veilguard seems absolutely terrified of the possibility that the player might ever be made to feel slightly uncomfortable with its narrative. It will never challenge you to wrestle with difficult moral questions, never put you into direct conflict with your companions, never tempt you to commit lesser evil in the name of greater good, and never force you to engage with complex topics like history, politics, and religion. Just sit back and watch as your family-friendly hero saves the world while miraculously never being made to challenge their ideals or consider compromising their morals. All Dragon Age games are ultimately stories about good triumphing over evil, but past entries demanded you choose what you valued and who you were willing to sacrifice, and forced you to live with the consequences. Veilguard also has choices, but will always insist that you did the best you could and shouldn't think about them too much.

At least until the finale, anyways. Veilguard may be the opposite of Dragon Age 2 in that it has dull writing and excellent production values, but it's also the opposite of Mass Effect 3 in that its ending is so well executed it might very well redeem the tedium of everything that preceded it. No spoilers here, but I can safely say this is some of Bioware's best work to date and easily proves itself the equal of Mass Effect 2's suicide mission or Inquisition's Trespasser.

Ultimately, whether Dragon Age: The Veilguard is a "good game" is something only you can decide. I strongly recommend all Dragon Age fans play it at some point, even if you have to wait for a sale. It might not be the game we wanted, or the game we expected, but it does accomplish the one thing we don't want to admit Dragon Age needed: it frees us from the shadow of Origins. Whatever comes next will be free to write its own story and take us on its own adventure, for better or for worse.

author: {'steamid': '76561199041125865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 16545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16545, 'last_played': 1731981082}

Play it casual, don't expect world state to carry over, don't expect great characters, don't expect range in decision making
