author: {'steamid': '76561198173100601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7885, 'last_played': 1731383826}
review:
[h1] Only recommend for casual Dragon Age fans - Not for OG Fans. [/h1]

I've never felt so conflicted over a single entry into a series as I do over this one. I only selected the thumbs up recommend option over the thumbs down option because I feel like Dragon Age The Veilguard is a good game overall... just [b] not a good Dragon Age game. [/b]

Pros:
*Beautiful and detailed environments.
*Engaging maps that are interesting to traverse.
*Game rewards player for exploration with meaningful rewards (ex: equipment upgrades, interesting codex entries that expand upon the world).
*Action combat is fun and didn't get boring for me (I completed game on nightmare setting).
*Third Act of the game is great - high action, tight high stakes story-telling, appropriate tone of dialogue for what was happening around the characters.

Cons:
*Dialogue is cringe worthy, shallow, and sets a tone that is in direct opposition to the game world's reality for MOST of the game's duration.
*Companions are OK, not memorable enough to be placed among the echelon of great companions from previous titles.
*Romance in this game is...there? I guess? I wouldn't consider any interaction with your companions REMOTELY romantic...but they give you "heart" options in the dialogue wheel if that is your thing...but I have feeling it won't be. 
*The conclusion of selected companion romanced felt shallow and unearned. Romance between companions outside of the player character felt more meaningful as they had much more banter that helped "grow" the blossoming relationship. I found myself more interested in helping my companions romance each other than I did in chasing my own romantic interests.
*Almost a complete disregard to the events that occurred in the previous 3 entries in this series. It cheapened the experience overall as player choice was a staple for the Dragon Age games as was bringing in the player's world states from the other titles. I think because this feature was lacking, I felt quite the disconnect from the events unfolding in this game, especially when the Inquisitor shows up.
*Lineage/Race has very shallow reactivity in the game. I played as an Elf and a Qunari. As an elf, other elves continued to over explain elf things to me, even after briefly acknowledging my elfdom. As a Qunari, being in Tevinter especially, I was hoping for more push back from citizens but there was nothing. I guess in the last 10 years between Inquisition and Veilguard, Thedas removed all of its racism. Yay.


Overall Thoughts:
6/10 for me. This is an action game, not a true role playing game. The only role you get to play is the hero. This plays in a style reminiscent of Mass Effect 2 with a Dragon Age skin but worse dialogue/writing. It is still an enjoyable game but I think people who loved Origins and DA:I, will have a hard time with this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995289448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1203, 'last_played': 1732381093}
review:
I'm really torn on this review.  The graphics are absolutely stunning and the gameplay, although different from it's CRPG roots, is really fun and engaging.  I'm also really enjoying the loot and upgrade systems.

The problems are with the story writing, character writing, and tone. I have no problem at all with the culture war topics that are dominating discussion.  My issue is that this feels more like a blockbuster Marvel movie, with overly quippy dialogue and no darkness or edge to be found.  Everyone and everything is too positive and happy-go-lucky for what's actually going on around them, and it really degrades the immersion. I think the developers were too afraid to take chances or offend and played it way too safe.

This is a pretty terrible Dragon Age game, but a pretty decent game if you can set aside those expectation, which I understand some people just won't be able to do. I wish there was a "mixed" recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165454820', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1731536278}
review:
With almost 8 hours on file, and a dragon age fan since i could remember, there is a lot to be said... 
The story and dialogue are pretty messy. It feels like an introductory to the world instead of the 4th installment. However, the characters do grow on you but won't make you crave the banter like between Leliana and Morrigan swapping stories about shoes, or wondering if Alistar has ever licked a lamppost in winter... 
I really hope that if they do another, because I would hate to see this franchise do a Fable Dive, they go back to the original humor, push boundaries for darkness, and suffocate us in world lore that actually makes sense. 

The combat is pretty fun! Actually! It does get "repetitive" but as someone who has played 10 years of FFXIV what's repetitive? Just hit your buttons man and let's not wipe pulls. I've seen some say the difficulties could be fixed so if you're extreme it might be less to your liking. 

Overall there is so much negativity about inclusion and such, but like... I was presented with an option to talk about inclusions and I picked something else and moved on? It wasn't that hard? Like if the option floats you pick it if not pick something else. Maybe choices don't matter but so far it's been enjoyable. I will come back to edit at the end with my final thoughts. 

if any devs are reading through these comments, please bring back actual problematic scenarios. We want dark fantasy and want to be good or evil. We want to be able to feel our choices and understand that we either helped or hindered the world. Nobody wants safe. If we wanted safe we would be playing fortnite I guess. (please don't come at me lol)

author: {'steamid': '76561198203679744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1732580935}

author: {'steamid': '76561198119347275', 'num_games_owned': 687, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 11023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11022, 'last_played': 1732764051}
review:
[h1]Good intentions, flawed execution [/h1]

As someone who has been playing Dragon Age ever since Origins was released and considers the series as one of his favorites, I feel that Dragon Age: The Veilguard was very much a mixed bag. It is a fun and entertaining game, but busy in their quest for winning the attention of new players, BioWare has not been able to capture the essence of the series very faithfully.

Having just finished the game, I’ll write down the different aspects I liked and disliked while they are still fresh in my memory.

[h2]The Good:[/h2]

1. Veilguard is easily the prettiest Dragon Age game, and that’s not just because it’s the newest and has the most updated graphics. I always felt that Origins was ahead of its time when it came to graphics and Inquisition was also a treat to look at. However, Inquisition had opted to go for a hyper-realistic aesthetic, while Veilguard goes for a very artistic look with gorgeous environments. I personally feel that is much more suitable for a fantasy game.

2. The combat of Veilguard can be hit or miss, but from what I have seen, the majority of players seem to love the fast pace. It can definitely feel more engaging and responsive than previous entries. The difficulty curve is very fair. I personally find it enjoyable enough, though it’s not my favorite. I prefer having an actual quickbar with a number of different abilities and not just be limited to only 3 at a time.

3. Veilguard lacks the kind of simple unimaginative fetch quests that often plague RPGs, which was a problem with Inquisition. Side quests are fewer but they are a lot more fleshed out, and often unlock new areas to explore. The companion and faction quests actually have an impact in the endgame, much like the loyalty quests of Mass Effect 2, and you would probably be penalized for ignoring them.

4. Just like any BioWare game the companions are, for the most part, very well written characters with a surprising amount of depth. From the trailers, I had expected to hate Emmrich but he ended up being one of the most wholesome companions BioWare had ever written. There has been a lot of criticism regarding Taash, but they also grow on you very soon. With their unique personalities and meaningful personal arcs, the companions are probably the most memorable part of the game.

5. The companions had excellent voice acting as well, as did most of the NPCs. Whether it’s Neve’s iconic drawl, Bellara’s fast, energetic speech, Emmrich’s warm, polite, properly enunciated words, or even Taash’s non-committal grunts, each actor really brought their character to life.

6. Since the maps are full of secrets and gathering loot is the main way of acquiring and updating new equipment, the exploration feels very rewarding. If you are a completionist like me, you will probably spend quite a bit of time figuring out hidden ways and puzzles that lead to the next chest, and when you do, it definitely feels worth it.

[h2]The Bad:[/h2]

1. The writing of the game is extremely inconsistent. Some quests, especially those involving companions or factions, do feel very much like the old BioWare magic. Then you come across some dialog that seems like it was written by a teenage fanfiction author, especially during the first half of the game. Some dialog options made no sense. The witty options often sounded less humorous than the serious ones. Sometimes the usage of certain words feels anachronistic. I guess this was to be expected after letting go of your most experienced writers halfway through development.

2. While the animation overall is excellent, I had no idea what was wrong with Rook’s facial expressions. Often, even during serious discussions regarding death or loss, his face would break out in a smile. This was very unnerving.

3. Though BioWare has not actually broken any existing lore, they [i]have[/i] been too liberal with it, which may cheapen the significance of some of the previous events. While the main storyline is more interesting than Inquisition, I feel like they tried to overcompensate with lore dumping and shock value. Veilguard gives you a LOT more information about the world, the Fade, and its history than all three previous games combined, and the worst part is that as players, you don’t find out these secrets organically like the previous games, but through ‘memories’ that you discover. This again seems like poor writing. I could do without a history lesson with a PowerPoint presentation in the middle of my game.

4. Veilguard is the least optimized game BioWare has ever made. Until now their PC releases were excellent. Mass Effect 2, 3, even Dragon Age Inquisition offered a great performance, but even if you exceed the recommended requirements of this game, you would run into FPS drops, stuttering, and graphical glitches, especially in crowded areas.

5. The Dragon Age series was being simplified ever since Origins. DA2 took away talents, Inquisition simplified skill trees and attributes, and Veilguard does away with the illusion entirely. It is now an action-RPG with a lot more focus on the action. You have less active companions, who have been reduced to background characters in combat, and you don’t even need to have a proper party with a tank and healer. BioWare seems to have bought into the myth that people want easier and simpler games, or that players don’t like to think too much. This is factually wrong, and honestly kind of insulting.

6. The lack of references from choices made in previous games was quite disappointing. Regular players would have been satisfied with some passing mentions and a few codex entries. These exist, but since the game doesn’t really import any choices, they feel very generic. What’s worse is that at times the game tries to subtly imply certain previous choices as canon while they continue to claim that a canon does not exist.

7. After the powerful last act, the epilogue was very disappointing. The ending slides just repeat what we already know, with no indication of how those decisions would change things in the world further down the line.

[h2]The Others:[/h2]

1. I felt somewhat disappointed that while the plot of Veilguard deals with an even bigger world ending threat, it doesn’t feel as [i]epic[/i] as Inquisition. This has nothing to do with the maps being linear. Origins itself felt very epic, as did Mass Effect 2 and 3. There is just something inexplicable missing in this game that couldn’t make me care that much about the end of the world. The soundtrack definitely did not help in this regard.

2. I have heard the criticism that Veilguard is not as dark as the previous entries and the game has been ‘Disney-fied’. Both these allegations are false. In many ways, Veilguard is the darkest Dragon Age entry, and you will not come out of it emotionally unscathed.

3. Despite the claims that the game is too ‘woke’ (whatever that means), I have not seen much discussions about gender and sexuality outside  one codex entry and a few personal quests for Taash, which might amount to 10 minutes of dialog in an easily 90 hour game. If that offends you too much, you may need some self-reflection. Thedas has always been a very progressive setting and Veilguard just continues that tradition.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

The Veilguard is a good game. It has a lot of life. But I don’t know if it’s a great Dragon Age game. To me, it’s definitely the weakest in the series in terms of writing, but it is not without its own strengths. Much like the Dread Wolf himself, Veilguard tries to be a rebel, but I don’t know if the rebellion was necessary at all.

Veilguard makes me think that I should adjust my expectations for the future of the series and be ready for more unnecessary simplifications, because some executives somewhere in EA headquarters think that players want to think less and have more flashy action. I guess these are just the times we live in now.

Final verdict: 6.5-07 / 10

author: {'steamid': '76561199157032392', 'num_games_owned': 33, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4426, 'last_played': 1734914801}
review:
7/10 (but I am a Dragon Age 2 10/10 truther)
For once, Bioware has made a game that actually plays brilliantly but often lacks in the writing department. Most of the failings in this game can be put down to EA layoffs or 10 years in development hell, to be honest. A good fantasy game, but nowhere near the best Dragon Age game and comes in near the bottom for me (as someone who is very generously patient with the older installments).

Minor dialogue and smaller things in the game are written almost atrociously at times, but I can excuse this for (what I assume is) the work of Trick Weekes and senior writers (every scene with Solas was a really strong idea of what the game could have been, as well as Act 3. [b]Act 3 was truly great, if you manage to get there[/b]). Early in the game has a lot of pacing issues - it's just Thing Happens, Thing Happens, Foreshadowed Unexpected Thing Happens. As well as lack of companion depth from lack of content, which is disappointing from Bioware of all developers. 
[b]Massive miss with the whole 'only 3 choices' option,[/b] especially because they truly don't matter whatsoever. I hope this is because of internal issues and NOT because someone actually thought that was a good idea. 

Combat is stupidly fun and the best thing they've done with this game. Inquisition combat was awful. It does feel like [b]they've listened to what people disliked from Inquisition and made it 100x better.[/b]

Biggest irk is the soundtrack. Only time the music actually impacted me or even felt connected to the game was when a motif from Inquisition would play. Trevor Morris I will avenge you. 

Overall, it is definitely a Dragon Age game and the closest to early in the franchise as you're going to get from Bioware nowadays. Tone is not nearly as 'Disney Pixar' as people make it out to be - although minor dialogue issues contribute to that. Bioware have overpromised though, and [b]*while the game is decent and I really enjoyed it*[/b], I can see how it could end up being left entirely unfinished by both new and old fans alike.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966335159', 'num_games_owned': 389, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 9341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1735059753}
review:
I recommend this game for it's combat, difficulty settings (customizable to a perfect degree) and gorgeous visuals. The writing is truly horrendous, some of the worst I have ever endured in an AAA game. It sounds like it is written for kids, I can't fathom how they ended up with this incredibly non-offensive basic tween Hollywood drivel. And yeah, I am one of those woke bastards that don't start immediately raging seeing pronoun options. That is not the issue at all.

The themes and events are dark, but the characters barely react to horrific things. It's like Peppa Pig but there's fantasy and violent combat. "Oh no oh geez, my friend is pierced by tentacles and slowly bleeding to death. Aw shucks! Anyway, let's go on having fun!!". It's impressive how hard the committe obviously writing this game tried to just be as basic as possible.

A small story plus for a certain someone that is my forever videogame crush returning hotter than ever, with a voice actor that obviously read the script and said "this is complete garbage, I will improvise" and immediately is therefore more likable and deeper than any main character.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004896901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3718, 'last_played': 1731251554}
review:
This game was made for a new generation, not for long-time Dragon Age fans.

This review focuses on DA:Veilguard from the perspective of fans who are coming to it with expectations from previous Dragon Age titles. In isolation, this game is a very good action RPG - one of the best on the market - so if that's what you're looking for Veilguard is worth your time.

Updated thoughts after finishing the game at the bottom.

TL;DR
8/10 - as a generic action RPG
5/10 - as a Dragon Age sequel

8/10 Graphics
7/10 Sound/Music
7/10 Voice acting
6/10 Atmosphere/Immersion
6/10 Story
6/10 Dialogue
7/10 Combat
7/10 Gameplay features
7/10 Level Design
10/10 Character creator
9/10 Technical Performance/Bugs

Veilguard pushes the franchise further down the path it's been on since DA2, diverging from the tactical combat and deep storytelling of Dragon Age: Origins in favour of a simpler, more broadly appealing action-RPG formula.
Veilguard is unapologetically action-focused, with limited roleplaying options and narrative choices, and simplified combat and dialogue. Combat is flashy, with exaggerated attack animations and over-the-top high fantasy visuals and effects. While it does boast expansive skill trees for the three classes, RPG elements are overall reduced.
Veilguard returns to a linear, episodic map structure (after Inquisition's open-world forray) which is effective, though some maps feel small, and the platforming elements (jumping around to solve puzzles) don't quite fit.

The writing is the real shortfall of this entry into the series, and a serious break from past titles.
While the visuals try to retain the darkness, grit and gore fans expect from this dark fantasy setting, Veilguard constantly undercuts the atmosphere with shallow, lighthearted storytelling, quippy one-liners and cheesy dialogue. The game ignores huge swathes of the established lore, and feels free to rewrite other parts to suit the current writing team, which will leave long-time fans with a sour taste in the mouth.
It feels intended for a younger audience, leaning HEAVILY on exposition and overly literal dialogue that spells out themes instead of allowing subtext. Dramatic moments are often undercut by moral lectures, sapping scenes of tension and subtlety.
Anachronisms in language - like characters referring to their 'team', enemies as 'bad guys', or yelling warnings about 'snipers' - can pull players out of the medieval fantasy setting. Additionally, while the series' commitment to diversity is a positive, its presentation in Veilguard feels forced and overly pretentious, detracting from the narrative flow.

Is this what I wanted from Dragon Age? Not really. But on its own terms, it succeeds as a highly polished AAA action RPG.
As an action RPG, it's enjoyable and impressively polished, and for that I can recommend it, but for those hoping for the deep, layered roleplaying experience of past Dragon Age titles, Veilguard falls short of the mark.

Ultimately, whether Veilguard is the Dragon Age experience you want is something only you can decide.


Updated thoughts after finishing the game
__________________________________

Dragon Age is dead. Long live Dragon Age!

My first impressions held up after completing the game: it’s a fun, polished action game - which I will be replaying to try the other classes - but it is not a Dragon Age game.
Veilguard feels like a streamlined fantasy action game with a Dragon Age skin, but the depth and emotional resonance characteristic of the series have been lost, and the tone would be more appropriate in a Harry Potter game or a new IP targeted at young adults.

Veilguard uses plenty of Dragon Age lore, but it doesn’t so much build on it as it burns through it for cheap impact, casually answering long-standing mysteries and dispatching major lore threats with little fanfare or reverence. 
The mysteries that made the world of Thedas so compelling—the darkspawn and the blight, the archdemons, the Tevinter magisters, the secrets of the Titans, the history of the ancient elves—all are wrapped up with blunt explanations, effectively closing narrative doors that older games had left open. At this point, the only mystery left is why anyone would care about this world going forward.

Dragon Age as we knew it is dead. This game closes the book on a 15 year old story, and sets the IP up for a clean reset.

I wish it had been done better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044399151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 7926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4250, 'last_played': 1733019415}
review:
This game's biggest failing is its rocky start.  The writing is the weakest there and things aren't given a lot of room to breathe in what I believe was an attempt to get the players through those initial quests as fast as possible.  Unfortunately, as fast as possible is still several hours.  I'd forgive anyone who assumed this game wasn't for them within that time period.

However, the writing picks up as soon as you're able to choose which quest to embark on next and, if you follow the game through to the end, you're in for an absolutely incredible ride!  The story is great, the lore stuff is cool, and interacting with companions has never been more satisfying as they all have their own storylines that intertwine with the main one.  Also, the faction stuff plays a much bigger role than I initially assumed it would.

I feel like this one blends the best parts of 2 and Inquisiton.  If you're the type of player who only enjoyed Origins then this one might not be for you.  It certainly doesn't have that crpg feel and you are limited to playing a good guy.  That's not necessarily a bad thing though.  There's always a trade off somewhere.  To me, Bioware has always excelled at telling stories through characters and this one aces that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003586562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 5677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5430, 'last_played': 1732032562}
review:
EDIT: Put in my thoughts after the ending at the bottom of this review. 

I'm an old school nerd, and I mean OLD. I played Baldur's Gate - the very first one - by buying it on a CD. When the sequel Baldur's Gate 2: Shadows of Amn came I was all over it and replayed it like a dozen times. I wrote fanfiction about the characters on old message bords. When Dragon Age: Origins came out it was for me the New Thing, the Different Thing, but I loved it all the same. It did weird things with the tropes I knew, and I wasn't always crazy about them, but it stuck the landing all the same. I'm saying all this to explain how to me, Dragon Age: Origins isn't where it starts for me, but rather way before that. 

So what's Veilguard like? Well... Playing the Dragon Age games is playing with an indecisive DM who houserules and modifies all the time, be it gameplay, how races look (remember the hornless Qunari), how characters look (remember how DAO Isabella looked) and many other things, so that must at this point be expected. DAO was largely a classic party strategy game with WOW-style bars to scroll up and down to find your abilities. DA2 introduced a faster pace and more arcade-y fighting, DAI tried to mesh the two and it went... so-so. Now Veilguard is here, and once again it's doing its own thing. The fighting reminds me or DA2  - with a bit of Mass Effect of all things blended in. The inventory management is once again a bit more on the arcade-y side as well, and generally I'm getting the sense of "action-adventure" more than the "strategy-lite" style of for example Pathfinder or once again DAO. 

Yet, do I enjoy it? Having accepted that Dragon Age as a series kinda goes all over the place trying different things? Yes. The combat's a bit halfway between DA2 and DAI, and seems to offer the same ability to combo things into insanity if you know what you're doing that DAI did. The companions are making an impression on me, and while I haven't seen that much of them, they certainly seem more interesting than for example Mass Effect Andromeda's. The world looks great - even if again a bit different - and I already had my first gleeful giggle at the verbal bitchslapping my Rook delivered at one point. All that is making me hopeful, making me feel like the Dragon Age I adore is back. 

Will this last? Who knows?! But at least right now, I'm happy.

EDIT: Sitting here now having complete the game, I can say that overall, it did last. Was it wonky in some places? Was it sometimes a bit stiff? Did it fumble a decent chunk of the previous lore? Do I wish they had actually made use of events in previous games? All yes. But did I have fun? Did I get excited? Did the ending satisfy me? Also yes. I won't begrudge anyone their issues with the game (unless they're the "weeh weeh woke" people), but all the same it was a satisfying game all in all. Still, I hope that Bioware takes the relevant criticism to heart, because yes, there were things to work on here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097327528', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1731641244}

author: {'steamid': '76561198072843692', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 5650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4167, 'last_played': 1731799927}
review:
First off the "recommend" should be a turned into a "recommend for new players". and "not recommend" for DA fans.

In general DAV is a good RPG for people with 0 knowledge about the existing lore in the franchise, the game has all the systems you'd come to expect from an RPG, it has a good skill tree, it has good combat design, it looks stunning, has tons of QoL features, tons of customization, it's very well optimized and polished, level design is awesome and precise. It doesn't suffer from open world emptiness and doesn't feel as much of a corridor simulator. Major quest levels are also really really well done and I enjoyed fighting my way through those missions, it's always a spectacle. It's a totally serviceable game if you don't take into account the Dragon Age title.

For existing players I cannot in good faith recommend this title at all. It honestly slaps prior fans in the face with the amount of lore discrepancies, contradiction, poor writing and blatant disrespect of choices in previous games.
It wouldn't be as devastating if at least the new cast of companions and our protagonist was written in a way that didn't scream like they got passed through 60 HR employees. Dialogue is bland, all the depth and morally grey aspects surrounding the lore is just straight up reconned or watered down to the point of bafflement.
You are not allowed to be anything but a "Yes-man" to these companions, there is no friction, no deep dynamic between Rook and companions, there is no true and proper bonding as it was the case in previous games. You are treated like a therapist running from room to room solving everyone's problem with a smile on your face. None of the companions except Davrin, Emmerich and Bellara give a single flying fudge about Rook. You interact with them as a narrative tool, not as a balanced dynamic between teammates. There is no comradery, just Rook forcing their way into conversations of the companions, unnecessarily even. It's at times a struggle to read through the dialogue because the writing's shallow and awkward. Rooks best moments are hilariously only present when they're in a dialogue with Solas. Why? Because they're allowed to have a personality for once that goes beyond "Yes!" "Yes. (joke)" and "Yes." they're allowed to disagree, agree, banter, exchange quips with Solas but denied when it's about the companions. Why is that? Why aren't we allowed to challenge them? 
The romance is also a complete joke in this game and feel like an afterthought compared to the advertised "best romance in all three games" you have to be kidding me. In the 70h I've been playing, the romance scenes accumulate to maybe 20 minutes. And that is stretching it with a companion that is actually well written (Emmerich). Romancing Harding or Lucanis feels actually painful, because those two suffer the worst case of "I only care about my own quest and just want you here to act as a meatshield." not because they have any interest in Rook, despite what the game is trying to gaslight you into believing.

Factions are also mostly useless from a narrative perspective. I still cannot believe how Nevarra doesn't play a bigger role in this game. The ones with the most impact are to no ones surprise the Grey Wardens, followed by the Crows (got butchered) and then the Veil jumpers (meh), to the Mournwatch ( the best faction) and lastly Lords of Fortune (awfully implemented). The last 2 have no significant impact on the story.

The way magic is treated in DAV also reminds more of sci-fi than fantasy, everything is now explained in science terms, "amplifiers" "resonating the XY to the XZ and tweaking the XY to get this fluctuation" you see that a lot with those magical gadgets. And it really takes me out when in all previous games magic was still treated as a fantasy element, not as a scientific element. And this tonal shift is echoed throughout the entire game, you don't get the sense that DAV plays in Thedas if it weren't for the similar names popping up. Minrathous isn't like the Minrathous explained from previous games. The Crows aren't the same as before, etc. and that is why it's so disappointing as an established fan to go into this game with all of this knowledge just to be let down by questionable writing quality and the blatant attempt at wiping the slate clean. 

Out of the 5 endings, the one considered "best ending" is truly the best in terms of satisfaction and payoff because it's the only time the Inquisitor actually plays a role. The other 4 endings are shockingly bad. 

I genuinely hope the writers take the feedback to heart, I love Dragon Age, enjoy all the games with 2 being my favorite despite its shortcomings. Narrative focus was always Bioware's strength, so I don't quite understand what happened here and hope we stop sanitizing the lore for whatever reason and go back to writing compelling characters with proper depth and balance between Protagonist and companion. Something that was a staple in previous games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043859885', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1725, 'last_played': 1731312513}
review:
The positives: Runs very well (surprising for an EA release, I know), graphics are great on ultra at 1440p. Gameplay is quite fun and I find it challenging on the harder difficulty (unforgiving?). Mage class is definitely a lot easier than rogue in case anyone cares. Coming from an isometric fan, I much prefer this to the odd blend we have had of genres in the previous two entries. The RPG system of levelling up lets you unlock new combo skills, so it has more depth to it than Inquisition did with its limited skills and passives. Edit: many hours in and the only bugs I have encountered have been clipping issues with some capes, and blighted water flashing in the Anderfells bog.

A lot of reviews I'm seeing seem to be from people that have either skipped all dialogue and cutscenes, or are reviewing in bad faith. My system is by no means top of the range, but its a decent system and i run it fine on the highest settings, no crashes, no bugs so far. I assume the other half of the reviews reporting crashes are not meeting system requirements, because my system is handling this without any issues which is something that cannot be said for some older games on their highest settings. A third camp of reviews are criticising the game's tone - while I partially agree with their sentiment, party members have been cracking jokes at the end of the world in all previous entries with hours of party jokes and banter. It's far from a grim dark setting, have you ever licked a lamp post in winter?

The negatives: Gutted world state continuity. We knew already we wouldnt be able to use Keep to transfer our previous game decisions over. The options are limited to four decisions during character creation (Inquisitor profile, inquisitor romance option, inquisition fate, inquisitors stance on Solas). This felt very lacklustre in my opinion and is a bit of a let down. However, it hasnt effected my positive experience in playing the game so far. Will come back and edit this if that changes. Edit: I think I'm a little past the midway point and there has been no mention of the mage-templar conflict or its resolution, no mention of any acts from origins or DA2 - this is also a let down.

Only other major negative is that some of the dialogue is a little clunky - i disagreed with people on this one during pre release, but I can see where they are coming from at times; but we should be fair on this one, really good dialogue isn't as common as we seem to think it is when criticising things. Still, I've perceived a few lines as clunky enough to distract me for a few moments. Also, the music isnt to my liking so far - was excited for dragon age with Zimmer, but it isnt scratching that nostalgia itch of visiting Thedas for me. Final negative: It doesn't stack up against BG3 so far, which I feel really set the stage for what modern RPGs can achieve. 

Conclusion: I like it so far, its fun. Could it be better? Probably. Was it worth just shy of 60 euros? I'll update my opinion when i finish the game, but so far yes

author: {'steamid': '76561198023790385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 332, 'last_played': 1731020424}
review:
Very initial impressions:
The bad- first characters you meet are a little goofy. Its not bad, they're just a bit pixar.  I don't hate them or anything. I have heard from others thats a common opinion but they grow on you.

Only bug I've seen so far is my character's makeup didn't carry in to the game from creation.  Not a big deal as you can change your character at your base. 

 Combat might be a little easy. I'm playing on Nightmare and it feels like this should be the standard difficulty. If I ever want to play again I don't really have anywhere to go up from here. I die a few times on some bosses until I learn their moves but overall not super difficult not punishing as the game seems to save before each boss. No runback or anything,  just try it again.

That being said, I'm finding the combat to be pretty fun. Playing as a rogue if it matters. Lots of dodging out, lunging in to exploit windows.  Overall works pretty good. You can bring up a window to tell your minions... er, friends, what you want them to cast and there are combo spells. If you've played any of the Souls games or Elden ring or other ARPGs I'd recommend starting on the hardest difficulty to get the most out of combat though.

Story is kind of generic but it's not bad. There's baddies that got released and you need to stop them. Not unique but that's alright.  They've definitely move back from DA: Origins feeling like an RPG to more of a combat oriented ARPG game, so expect that. If you come at it without expectations it works pretty well though.

Game's beautiful. Each zone is scenic and impressive.  The hair physics are amazing. Seems to run very well too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057319927', 'num_games_owned': 142, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 6710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6236, 'last_played': 1732651787}
review:
Is it a bad game? No
Is it the best Dragon Age game? No

The game is definitely not as bad as people are making it out to be. However, as a huge Dragon Age fan, it is impossible not to compare to previous games. There are both pros and cons. 

The writing is unfortunately the worst in a Dragon Age game. It's not horrible, but it's not good. There are also strong points, especially near the end of the main storyline.

The bloat of Inquisition is gone, in favor of few and better quests that don't take too long to complete, which is a win in my book. Exploration is also tight and fun, unlike the huge empty maps of Inquisition. Overall I definitely prefer this map and quest setup. 

Companions are likeable like every dragon age game. Do they top favorites such as Dorian or Alistair? Of course not. But they're fine. 

Romances so far have been a huge letdown. I romanced Davrin my first playthrough and I thought 'wow, that's very little content'. Now on my second playthrough romancing Lucanis and apparently, it can get worse. When there IS romance content, it's good. However, there is just so LITTLE of it compared to previous Dragon Age games. It's really a huge disappointment. I hear Emmrich is pretty much the only one who has proper romance content (why they did not give everyone an equal amount of scenes is also frustrating), and I regret not romancing him from the getgo to get the best experience. 

Another thing I don't like, and this is coming from a NB person, is the very modern terms and dialogue. In past dragon age games you had characters like Dorian and Krem, but they didn't say the terms 'trans' and 'gay'. It was still very clear what they were, and not saying it did not hurt their storyline. Suddenly hearing dragon age characters say 'trans' and 'nonbinary' throws me off. I wish they presented it like Dorian in inquisition. 

There is also no way to be evil in this game, something I reserve for second playthroughs. There is simply no dialogue option that is even remotely rude or evil. You are always a set nice character. It hurts replayability. Yes there are certain choices that change big things in the game, but the majority of the game will still be playing as the same character as your previous playthrough. A shame. 

Combat is the best that Dragon Age games have ever had. Thinking of going back to Inquisiton with the combat it has makes me miss DATV's combat already. But you don't play Dragon Age for the combat anyway. 

Overall, it was a good time. I don't see myself playing it as much as previous dragon age games. There's just not much reason to. I am planning 3 playthroughs to play as all classes, play as the romances I want, do all endings, and that's it. The different factions and races don't provide enough content to excuse more playthroughs. But still, I repeat, it is not as bad as people are making it out to be, especially people that have not touched the game in the first place.

Edit: Oh, also want to add, that despite the game looking wonderful and running great, I get random crashes that say that my 3060 was 'physically removed'. I've seen other players having this error. It's very frustrating and happens every 1,5 hours usually. Hope it gets fixed.

author: {'steamid': '76561199194216250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 6, 'playtime_at_review': 5725, 'last_played': 1735679638}
review:
I have played all of the dragon age games and consumed books and online content from dragon age.

I was a hardcore Solavellan player in DAI and I waited for this game for 11 years.

I am feeling a lot of things right now which means the main story was  good.  The plot did what it needed to do whether I like it or not, and the battle was okay too even.
BUT…

I hated the romance and relationships.  I was so attached to my characters in DAI, and I wanted those kind of attachments for Rook, but the relationships were bland and underwhelming and too short.

I will play again and hopefully find more to love, but in this moment, I am mostly just underwhelmed.

author: {'steamid': '76561199245151431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 3342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1732378588}
review:
No EA launcher or account required 
$60 not the new $70
Insanely well optimized, getting constant 120 frames on high settings on 3070 laptop on 1440.
Rogue arrow shooting is great with auto attacks/aim attacks with press/hold feels great.
Endless accessibility options.
Can pause during cut-scenes.


Nothing is disappointing for me excited to keep playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041940012', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 5508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1731008322}
review:
I like it more then I thought I would actually.

It's hard to shut out all negative stuff. It's hard to have faith in EA/Bioware after last couple of years.
But it's actually much better then I anticipated. 

Story seems okish so far. Some writing / dialouge is kinda' bad but it's not horrible and some of it is good. I am curious about where the story goes and what choices I will have to make. There's already been quite a few after only 5 hours. 

Combat is really great. Fluid and flashy. I really think they nailed it and it's a huge step-up from DA:I that tried to be more action-like.

Maps are not open but have enough exploration that you do need to look around and find loot. Itemization is a standard aRPG/MMO formula with rarity, stats and stuff. Nothing special but it looks ok so far. I assume there will be unique / legendary loot later on.

Companions are good (so far as I only have 3) and even the one many seem to be annoyed by I don't mind. 

For now it's probably a 7 or 8. Might go up or down but I really recommend it if you're into RPGs with actionlike combat. Do yourself a favor and ignore all hate that this game seems to get from so many. I really don't see any of it being justified if you are 1) a gamer and 2) a normal decent human. Just watch some gameplay and judge from what you see. For me it's so far a really fun and engaging game, no GOTY but still very fun and one of the better I played this year.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045625222', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1301, 'playtime_at_review': 6653, 'last_played': 1736058223}
review:
It's a good game. Story is pretty sound. A lot of the complaints are just the anti-woke crowd throwing a hissy fit, as usual. Though the they/them part does feel incredibly forced and not genuine it really is only a small part of the game, and it's not like it's the first Dragon Age game to do it. It feels enough like a Dragon Age game to make me start the series over again. So play it, and enjoy it. I did.

Unlike most games I play, I actually enjoyed this enough to play it to completion, and will play it again after my run through the originals.

author: {'steamid': '76561198328375036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1130, 'last_played': 1732917666}
review: As a general action RPG game I'd give this an 8/10. However as a Dragon Age game it's a 6/10. I am as a whole enjoying it, especially the scenes with Solas, it has amazing visuals, it runs very smoothly with no major bugs encountered, I am enjoying the combat and I haven't taken a disliking to any of the companions. It just feels like it's missing some of that Dragon Age DNA. It is still a fun and enjoyable game, but it could've been more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057933604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 7249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5830, 'last_played': 1735294029}
review:
I am recommending this game on the strength of its gameplay and astounding art direction. The plot writing was excellent, and the dialogue was not.

I nearly uninstalled and refunded the game in the first 5 hours due to the terribly paced tutorial and "tell, don't show" problem.

There was a moment in the first 5 hours where you go to a town which has recently been destroyed, and the art direction speaks volumes: fresh fruit overturned on the ground, not a soul in sight - it had striking, moving atmosphere and just as I was trying to take it in and look around, my companions behind me started shouting, more or less, THIS VILLAGE WAS A GOOD PLACE BUT NOW IT'S BAD. SOMETHING VERY RECENT HAPPENED TO MAKE IT BAD. Yes. I know. I have eyes. I would much rather have had them simply hiss in reaction to the disturbing sight - be affected by it to contribute to the atmosphere - than tell me word for word what I am supposed to take from the scene as a viewer. 

This problem mostly goes away further into the game.

[h2] The Writing [/h2]
The writing is STRUCTURALLY very good. The main quests are incredibly well paced, no side quest feels superfluous. Companion quests are relevant to them, to their (very interesting) faction, and to their personal development. The choices you make during their quests feel significant. Environments were varied and stunning, and there were plenty of quality of life touches like making it clear when a choice has a major effect, like locking in a romance or changing the world state. Choices about the plot matter a lot. This is fundamental, so I am glad they nailed it.

The game is at its best when it takes itself seriously. There were moments in the game where I felt like I was reliving some of the deep, intense moments from Origins, only fresh, and ten times more beautiful. Combined with [b]the combat system,[/b] I truly felt like a skilled battle archer taking down some of the harder enemies with quick timing and well-aimed headshots. 

[h2] Dialogue [/h2]
The dialogue from your protagonist, Rook, is abysmal. I wish my own protagonist were unable to speak. They have the air of a coworker who thinks they are funny. It was painful. The "hardass" option is the only one which half-reliably avoids making a poorly timed joke, and it isn't really hardass, it's just directly moving the conversation forward.

The dialogue from companions, while only sometimes cringeworthy, lacks emotional depth. There are moments which should, structurally, have emotional depth, but the characters struggles were never consequential, or have significant interpersonal conflict. Conflicts were resolved too easily, people agreed with compromise too readily. Lucanis never acted like a man who was tortured, for example, and Spite was too easily appeased. Bellara never fails at something from overworking or lashes out in grief. They expressed an emotion, they talk it out, it's resolved. It's too clean. It lacks gravitas.

The dialogue strikes me as a third draft - the kind of lines you put in when writing as a sufficient placeholder to move the scene along with the intention of going back over it later to add subtext. As-is the writing serves its structural purpose, with characters saying what needs to be said to continue, but not generally in a unique voice which obscures or complicates the basic conveyance of facts through their personality, background, or current feelings.

It strikes me as wise to drop this ball if you run out of time. All the supporting layers of writing that need to happen before polishing the dialogue are strong. But so much of the feeling of a game is carried in the character's voices, so it's unfortunate that it ended up feeling half-baked.

The very talented voice actors do a lot with a little.

[h2] Group Cohesion [/h2]
This game has much stronger group cohesion than Inquisition, and it's clear they made a point to cultivate it. It works. I appreciate that the efforts you take throughout the plot which focus on mending and repairing cultures, people, and places culminate in your ability to focus on repair and forward progress in the ending. The plot demonstrates the theme this way, through every quest cumulatively.

Despite this, it felt like an after school special at times. It veers into therapy speak, which took me out of the setting. The world itself was sanitized this way, too - Tevinter doesn't seem to have slaves anywhere? The Crows are all friendly batman vigilantes and not people who traffic children from brothels and torture them as training? At least the blight is still horrible. And characters other than Rook pull out their occasional marvel movie quips as well, undermining the tone and sounding unpleasantly like chatGPT.

[h2] Romance [/h2]
The romances don't seem to add much. An extra line or two of dialogue, and a scene near the end of the game. I wish it resonated more than it did. The protagonist was a big problem here, where tone is so crucial. The intimacy didn't hit because it didn't feel earned, and I could not avoid my Rook having the personality of a goofball camp counselor. If I clicked the "I like messes" button, I should have to tie my love interest up like he's Bhaalspawn.

[h2] Overall [/h2]
At the end of the day, the gameplay, plot structure, and art carried it enough that it was something I looked forward to sitting down with for a few hours every day. They did some series-long plot points real justice, and the only flaw is the inconsistency of tone. The dialogue is so bad it hurt, but I think it's worth enduring. It's too much to hope Bioware puts this back in the oven and releases a big patch that redoes all the dialogue, but if they did, it would be a nearly perfect game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092183884', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 675, 'playtime_at_review': 3953, 'last_played': 1736784703}
review:
Some people pay attention to wrong problems of this game. Inclusivity doesn't have to be the main focus, and inclusivity isn't bad. The lazy and kind of boring writing of it - is. 

Story doesn't feel that large-scale as it has to be, villains and characters are too stereotypical. Gameplay and mechanics felt really outdated, considering how many times project was restarted. In dialogues characters are repeating the same topics over and over again. Some of design choices don't work for me, too. Also, I won't call it a regular RPG, to be honest - the narrative and choices felt more like a Telltale game imo. But I really loved some plot twists, graphics and cinematics though! Character creator was pretty decent, I hope it will return in next projects! Voice acting is incredible. And little small details. With this being said - I didn't expect to enjoy this game at all but I will lie if I say it didn't bring me some fun. I will lie if I say I hated it. Hate is a really strong word. Just glad devs made it through and that story with Solas is finished <З the game is not this horrible, but I think it has A LOT of bad decisions and guidance

author: {'steamid': '76561198436043016', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3218, 'playtime_at_review': 4805, 'last_played': 1736778481}
review:
It DAV a perfect game? absolutely not. But I personally had a great time playing it. 

I like many others would have liked to have had more development between Rook and their companions, and some storylines felt a little clunky, but overall I thought it was a solid game and certainly (at least for me!) it wasn't the worst Dragon Age game, even if it wasn't the best either. 

Every time a new DA game comes out there is a barrage of hate against it. When DA 2 came out people complained about the repetitive dungeons and found Hawke's personality grating. When DAI came out the Inquisitor and story was boring - each new game has been critiqued and compared to the one before it and then has somehow become the standard. Even if Origins was remastered people would still have something to complain about!

Veilguard is not without it's disappointments, and I'd love to see some of these addressed in a patch or two if possible, but it did have some great quests, particularly in the main storyline - Weisshaupt was very fun, and I found Act 3 in general very engaging. The final quest is probably one of my favourites of all time. The VA's did a stellar job, combat was fun, and the graphics are stunning. I enjoyed the different maps and I liked that each companion really had their own role - it wasn't just down to Rook - and there were real stakes at play. My next run will be as a mage with an orb and dagger - super fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198090324066', 'num_games_owned': 594, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 4617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1295, 'last_played': 1732052473}
review: Dragon Age Veilguard is a terrible RPG, but a fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076464181', 'num_games_owned': 606, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6663, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6663, 'last_played': 1735422513}
review:
There are a lot of reviews that very eloquent about some of the issues with Dragon Age: Veilguard, but what I mainly want to say is: I really, really liked this game, and even loved it in some parts! I went slow to make the experience last longer, I enjoyed the flexibility of combat customization, I cried harder than I have in a long time during the scene in the Prison of Regrets (iykyk) and I am already planning my second playthrough (Grey Warden not afraid to make the tough choices) even though I rarely ever actually finish my replays on games, no matter how much I love them.

That said... As much as the beginning of the game made me go, "omg this is it, it's actually Dragon Age, after all this time!", I can't say the feeling lasted the whole way through. It's clear how much the game suffered in terms of development from all the people who were laid off, and the many who decided to quit the studio. Veilguard feels like it wants to be an introductory game for new players just approaching Dragon Age as a series while trying to appeal to old diehard fans. Instead what it does is deliver some pretty flat companions without a lot of actual development (especially compared to previous games), a lot of world-tilting lore drops that don't actually change anything, underwhelming romances, and very little roleplay.

I wasn't expecting Rook to be as influential to the world as the Hero of Ferelden or Inquisitor are. I always expected DAV to be more like DA2, where the game isn't about a big organization like the Wardens or the Inquisition, but about a person finding themselves knee-deep in shit and having to deal with things. But with Hawke, even with the repetitive maps and fights, and the very limited environments (given it all takes place in Kirkwall), you get a ton of zest and flavor! Hawke actually feels like someone with a personality rather than just a "one size fits all" good protagonist like Rook.

It barely felt like an RPG and more like many other streamlined games like Assassin's Creed or BioShock - which doesn't make it bad, unless you're expecting the level of depth Dragon Age was famous for. Even as someone who always strives to reach the "best ending" in DA games, it was annoying that the only person you can actually be mean to is Solas.

I still recommend it. It's a good game, if not a good *Dragon Age* game, but I hope the execs (and whoever they'll put in place of the people who actually created this world and its compelling story and characters) at least listen to constructive criticism. I feel like they were told to focus on the critiques about the combat and the character creator from the previous games and spent ten years perfecting those aspect, forgetting to put meat on the plate. EA probably forgot this wasn't yet another 60€ Sims add-on...

author: {'steamid': '76561197996450068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 330, 'playtime_forever': 2434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2434, 'last_played': 1731541429}
review:
Wonderful PC version of this game, played 5 hours so far today and it sure runs well! The performance is fantastic, hats off to Bioware for how optimized and how good of a PC version they did up for this game. Many modern AAA games have a average or poor PC version and not much effort put into it. This one though you can tell they put effort into the PC version to really take advantage of the better hardware people have.

As for the game itself it is good fun so far for me. The combat is improved from Dragon Age 2 and Dragon Age Inquisition (Origins still has my favorite combat as someone who is more into crpgs and turn based or realtime with pause combat), the controls are well done and its just fun to explore this world they have created.

The writing of the characters is good, but the overall story so far is not all that amazing like Origins story was but its not terrible story. So far the story is about on par with Dragon Age 2 for me. The dialogue though is terrible, especially with the characters banter. After the first 90 minutes or so the game starts improving alot, get out in the forest and get a few level ups and new gear for you and your companions and it really starts to get enjoyable. Def gets better each hour you are playing.

I need more time with the game to see how good it is once you beat the game, but so far the good outweigh the bad by a good amount so far. Yes I would like a Dragon Age game more akin to Dragon Age Origins, especially for the combat and overall story, but this game still has alot of things going for it. The combat is a good deal more enjoyable than Dragon Age 2 and inquisition, the controls are better and I am liking how they crafted the game world in this game compared to the previous two DA games.

At the moment though it is the Best Bioware game since Mass Effect 3 for me, its a good deal better than Mass Effect Andromeda and Anthem. And while not quite as good as DA Origins, so far this is better than DA2 and DA Inquisition for me.

Again, this is coming from someone who likes more hardcore rpgs like Neverwinter Nights 2, Pillars of Eternity 2, Dragon Age Origins, Wasteland 3, Baldurs Gate 3,etc.. So take it for what it is, just the opinion from one guy who loves crpgs the most out of the RPG genre but who also likes to try more action oriented rpgs to. The biggest issue as a big crpg fan though is the writing of the dialogue it is very cringe.

It is great to have Dragon Age back and also have Bioware back, while not perfect it is a huge step up from there past 2 games and even a slight improvement from the last 2 DA games. And while Origins still holds the crown for this series for me, this game would be my second favorite in the series overall (It might not have the story of Origins or 2, but it has better combat, better gameworld and is more fun than 2 and Inquisition).

And lastly I really must say it again but this is a really really good PC version. I am playing at 100fps with the graphics cranked and have not had any big performance dips or any crashes at all, hats off to the people at Bioware who made this PC version shine like it does!

The only negatives I have is that the art design could be better, its not terrible but its not 100% to my liking, the cities could have more people to interact with and the Main Issue is that the dialogue terrible, especially the character banter. I am loving everything else about this game. After a little bit of a slow start the first hour or hour and half the game gets alot better as it goes along. It is a shame that the dialogue is so bad because most of the rest of the game is very good, but the very poor dialogue does bring the game down for me a good deal.

The game also plays well on the Steam Deck to, I just played 3 hours on the Steam Deck while watching the football game (I was in offline mode and away from the internet so the time didn't count). I played it capped at 40fps and it looked good enough and ran well. Runs fantastic on desktop and good enough on Steam Deck, well done devs. I have played now 5 hours on Desktop and 3 hours on Steam Deck.

Lastly, as far as the whole "The Game is WOKE!" talk going on at the moment? The game is not woke imo. There was ONE time where I was asked if I wanted Trans options for dialogue, I said no and that was the end of that. It hasn't come up at all in the other 13 hours I have played the game. If someone else wants to have those dialogue options that is fine by me, it doesn't bother me personally at all. I answered no and the game left it at that. It was not thrown in my face all the time.

It is good, but not great, I would give it a 8/10 so far after 21 hours. While not nearly as great as Origins, I still am enjoying it more than I did DA2 or Inquisition.

Positives:
- The combat is great, despite me liking Turnbased & Real time with Pause more in rppgs. The combat just feels good, if you are going to go arcadey, this is better arcade style combat than Inquisition was
- The graphics are fantastic, everywhere you look there are some really gorgeous views
- Game world is well crafted, not overly open world, but not to small either, its a nice mix of linear and some more open spaces
- Overall story is not to bad, its not great like it was in Origins or DA2, but the overall story is slightly better than Inuqistion's story
- Characters, overall I liked many of the characters, the characters themselves are great, I just wish they where given better dialogue
- Customization is fantastic, the character creator at the start of the game is one of the best around imo. You can craft really cool looking characters if you take your time
- Soundtrack is stellar
- PC Version is very well done, I averaged around 90-100 fps the whole game, with most settings cranked and one of the 2 Ray Tracing things turned on (With DLSS and Frame Gen)
- Controls are very well done on both Controller and Keyboard & Mouse


Negatives:
1. The horrible dialogue, especially companion banter, biggest issue in this game by far
2. Cities at times feel a little empty, I would have liked to be able to talk with more people
3. Art Design at times is bad and other times its good, so this is a small issue for me
4. The Tone from Origins (or DA2) is not there in this game at all, it was missing in Inquisition to, but it is missing again here in Veilguard to, would have liked a more mature tone to the game overall.

Score = 7.5 or 8/10... Good, but not great. Better than Inquisition and Dragon Age 2 in many areas, but not anywhere near as epic as Origins was imo. Origins is still the king, 10/10. It is not a 10/10 as some critics said, but it is also not a 3/10 as some people who have not even tried the game have said. It is a mixed bag, some elements are very good, while others not very good at all such as the dialogue.

How is it compared to other Bioware games? Not as good as Dragon Age Origins, Jade Empire, Baldurs gate 1, KOTOR 1, ME 1/2 or DA 2. But for me this is a better game than Anthem, DA: Inquisition and Mass Effect: Andromeda.

***Just beat the game, the last handful of quests where good fun, the game got gradually better as it went along. Was good but not great. No it is not Dragon Age Origins, Baldurs Gate 3, Elden Ring, Fallout new Vegas, Wasteland 3, Gothic 2, KOTOR2 or Pillars Of Eternity 2 type of classic rpg, but it was still a fun action rpg and imo better than the last two DA games. Origins is still king of this series by a good amount, but Veilguard turned out better than I expected. Took me 45 hours, steam didn't record my 3 hours on Steam Deck when I was away from the internet***

1. Dragon Age Origins 
2. Dragon Age Veilguard
3. Dragon Age 2
4. Dragon Age Inquisition

author: {'steamid': '76561198030161178', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 8457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8455, 'last_played': 1732739677}
review:
So I've completed the game (twice) now and have decided to update my review.

All in all, it is a fun game; the combat is fun, the environments are gorgeous and I only encountered one rather amusing bug. The game itself is relatively polished.

However, the only main gripe with the game is the writing seems to flip flop between being extremely well written one minute and then the next feeling like certain story beats were written by an intern. It is largely a good game but it is far from perfect. The good parts of the game are wonderful and really outshine other lesser moments which leads me to still recommending the game overall.
