author: {'steamid': '76561198061370839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 6529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6521, 'last_played': 1735414576}
review:
[h3]Short version:[/h3] 
DAV (I refuse to say DATV) is a game that somehow survived most horrible choices and years of dev hell to be a completely bug-free, streamlined and reasonably good game on average, both flat and disappointing in some parts but terrific in others. Especially after going through the artwork book, knowing what we've lost from project Joplin and seeing what nightmare the actual DAV was going to be redesigned into, I find the result nothing short of a miracle. 


Now, for the long version... 
(and still spoiler-free)

[h3]the GOOD:[/h3]
- What lore threads were concluded in DAV are pretty great. Surprisingly, the whole Solas, Evanuris and lyrium business. 

- Many of the environments are breath-taking, from Nevarra's Necropolis to late-game Minrathous.

- The mid-game Weisshaupt mission and the last two story missions are nothing short of great, immersive and with fun boss fights. The ending mission in particular easily trumps BG3's buggy and unsatisfying conclusion. Just 9.5/10 on those.

- Music and boss design is also great.

- Combat, at least after playing a Spellblade mage, is great and versatile and surprisingly deep; respecs are free and easy, and items come with pretty new and interesting features. This comes after a trilogy of clunky, spammy and weirdly clunky again combat gameplays. Wouldn't have minded a couple more available abilities, and a way to save a current skill tree profile, but eh. The whole companion business is... odd, and gamey, but it surprisingly works well.

- The game, as mentioned, was essentially bug-free, which is completely unexpected especially for me, a notorious bug-magnet, and has excellent QOL features.

- Hair looks and physics are the best I've ever seen in any game. Pity they didn't add more haircuts and variations while they were adding stupid stuff like poodle cuts. 

- Some companions pleasantly surprised me (Davrin, Bellara, Emmrich), although there's more to them all and not all good.



[h3]the IFFY:[/h3]
- The advertised character customization is a bit odd. For all the buttons and scalars and stuff, I found it impossible to replicate my Inquisitor and real people I actually know. Also, you need to cherry pick your skin complexions because some just look horrid (see later). Some parts are genius, like hair physics and tattoo management, while others were just insufficient.

- Companions and their dialogues are hard to describe. They have very nice parts, while others feel... too streamlined and lacking in zest. Some companion quests left me with a distinct "yes and?" feeling. Romances feel like an afterthought, and some I'm told are downright bad, though I'm personally happy they did away with the cringe sex scenes.

- For example, the much rage-baited Taash was better than I expected, but the famous NB dialogue, even in-context, was IMO still badly-written and ham-fisted in (even for a teenager-mind-shaped character). It kinda ended up poisoning and dominating a good personal story with huge potential and a good message, and all it could have taken was a more fitting rewrite with the same exact meaning.

- In typical Bioware fashion, fashion can be either fantastic or horrible in an immersive way that nobody would seriously wear.

- I can personally understand that oh so many threads from the past games were severed or ignored. Honestly, I can't imagine the 5d chess of having to deal with so many player choices and variables. Though, of course, some glaring omissions are still a pain and could honestly have been handled.



[h3]the BAD:[/h3]
- The character art style: victim of dev hell and what I can only imagine as shiv-fights between artists and their managers (vis à vis concept art from the book), it's pretty wildly inconsistent. It's as if someone shouldered in during the last year and tried to salvage and redo what they could, but some characters still look like they came out of a PlayStation3. I'm looking at you, Illario.

- Specific mention of how awful non-Antaam (hostile NPC) Qunari look because of that restyling.

- Many returning characters from past games gravitate around a "presence token" tier, even with the very well-written mails by the Inqui offering excellent context (afaik added pretty much in post-production). Not to mention badly-dressed, seriously wtf Morrigan and Inqui. 

- Some setting features were heavily whitewashed. One or two mentions of the huge problem of slavery in Tevinter, one or two mentions of racism against Elves, both long-standing issues in the world that you pretty much SEE nothing of. The huge network of Solas-aligned Elves that destabilized everything during and after Trespasser? Must have imagined it. 

- Cut content. Rivain just reeks of it, and I'm big time angry about Kal-Sharok being dangled in front of us with nothing being done with it. Sure, everybody expects it after all that dev hell, but it doesn't make that any more appetizing.



In conclusion, this is a game that by all rights I expected to crash and burn, and probably would have if the post-Joplin management was allowed to continue what they were perpetrating, and instead even managed to pull "this is so fucking awesome" moments. I don't regret throwing 40€ at it, but I do grieve for what it could have been.


PS: as much as it was understandably also targeted for people who never played the previous trilogy, I'll always recommend playing it in full to properly understand and relate with the fantastic setting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002380993', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1315, 'last_played': 1735514258}
review:
I've played all of the Dragon Age games- though I'm not a die hard. I loved inquisition, and Origins is one of my favorite gaming experiences of all time- that said, if you were to compare origins and veilguard, you might think that these were two separate series, with some similar themes and concepts. 

However, if you played them all, you see the throughline. Dragon age has become brighter and more vibrant as time has gone on- the art direction is merely a continuation of the path they've been on. I guess I got over this change of direction as of the second one with its attempt at being action focused, because right now, veilguard is hitting just fine. When I got to the town where the blight hit, I was noticing all of the classic horror elements in origins cranked up to 11. The bodies, the way the blight absorbs- it felt practically cronenberg. If you're actually looking at the level design, you'll notice that it might be colorful, but the ultraviolence is still there; just not in your face. The dialogue writing itself is cartoonish at times, but it really depends on what options you pick and frankly, watching the character interactions outside of yourself is charming and feels dynamic in the way the bonds grow- I can't track how they're developing and I like that. It doesn't feel as complex as BG3, but it does feel connected. I feel like this is also the first Dragon Age game that seems to be showcasing its factions and set pieces in an efficient way- not one where you get lost in the world, but one where you actually get a complete picture of the powers in play. It may not be subtle, but it is effective story telling as far as accessibility goes.

Combat feels very good. I can see why people might say it could get repetitive, but its clear to me that the rpg elements are in the builds and combinations rather than a huge diversity in abilities- kind of like D4, but in a less obnoxious broken way. Frankly, zipping around the battlefield as a spellsword feels really, really, good. I'm curious to see what kind of character combinations you can put together as time goes on, because the game scratches the itch just right when you pull out a good combo attack with your allies. The character design is -fine- but then again, after origins I've never really been a fan of Dragon Age's designs. What was surprisingly good for me is the way it builds on itself. It feels linear at first, but gradually opens up- almost like it was answering my concerns as they grew.

This might be my second favorite DA yet- but we'll see how it goes!

author: {'steamid': '76561198057357018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 5068, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5068, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1735057271}
review:
Finished the game now, and overall this is a pretty solid RPG. The combat is easily the best in the entire series, though I will always have weak spot for the real-time with pause combat in Dragon Age Origins.  Level design is a bit on the linear side, but that puts focus on combat and story, which are honestly the core strengths of this game anyway. Inquisition wasn't improved by having huge levels with fuck all to do in them. 

The story told here is ultimately quite rewarding for series fans, though it is hurt by poor pacing. It takes ages for you to really see the big picture and care about it, and even then I would assume it's hard for new comers to really care too much. That is maybe Veilguards biggest weakness. 

Overall then, a decent showing from BioWare and perhaps something of a return to form, their most interesting game, in my mind, in the last decade.

author: {'steamid': '76561198172284203', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 26063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3209, 'playtime_at_review': 13671, 'last_played': 1736821071}
review:
After putting a couple hundred hours into it and being on my second playthrough, I can say with confidence that it's a great game. The reception of it is beyond unhinged so apologies for my bitterness about that, I do reflect on the game itself too, and it's long [b](tl;dr at the end, main points are bold)[/b]:

It's incredibly [b]well-polished[/b] and maintains consistent quality from start to finish. Aside from crashes related to Nvidia that got patched early on, there are no notable bugs that can fuel the ragebait trains on YouTube. Graphical performance is also stunning, runs really well on every platform it's on - which is huge after DAI's performance suffered due to old gen consoles holding it back, and eventually even having to stop supporting them before all DLCs were out. The hair tech itself, so long as you can turn it on, is worth literal gold to me.

In previous games, the story's quality and robustness was often front-loaded per dev reflections, leaving parts or the end of the game extremely half-baked. [b]This story clearly had the writers' full attention from start to finish, and it's lovely with lots of emotional highs and lows and unforeseen, but logical twists.[/b] I don't care about people saying the writing is weak, I heavily disagree but they have a right to their opinion. But people saying this is *worse* than the previous games' writing are objectively wrong and will end up in a future collage showing how with every release, people keep saying the same nonsense. People really need to get a grip on their nostalgic rose tinted glasses. Like, do I need to remind everyone of "swooping is bad" again? Because people don't get to call a story with warmth to balance the darker parts "Marvel writing" while not acknowledging how Gaider's (previous lead writer) writing especially in DAO is a fanboyish homage to Joss Whedon.

The [b]gameplay is definitely the biggest departure from the rest of the series. I find it extremely fun[/b] and for the first time I seek challenges to extend fights, not to skip them. There are definitely some things I wish were differently done, but overall I see why Darrah (previous director, now consultant) said this is the first time DA combat felt fun, not something to simply find acceptable or tolerable. It's completely fair if it's not for people who preferred the older styles. Fortunately we're having a banquet of RPGs these past few years, as one of Larian's devs have put it, so we're not starving for alternatives. Regardless though, Bioware couldn't keep trying to have RTwP combat and make it feel slow and deliberate, but also inject action and quicker decision making into the gameplay. Sooner or later they had to make a choice, if they didn't want people to keep saying "who plays DA for its mid combat anyway". The choice wasn't to everyone's taste, and that's okay, not every game has to cater to everyone. It's also okay to civilly mourn the feeling of being left out because of this.

Naturally, there are people who have communicated that the aesthetics and stylization are not to their tastes like rational human beings. But some people are literally insane. How are people going to nut over Arcane and Spiderverse for years, and then see the [b]painterly textures and expressive character designs[/b] and say it's Disneypixarfortniteetc. Especially when we see so much gore and brutality and people getting crushed to death. Get a grip. And any claims about not being able to make good looking characters? Self-reporting on skill issue, simple as.

Out of all the major categories for a game, [b]soundtrack is the one I'm least impressed with.[/b] I wouldn't want Inon Zur back himself for Reasons™️, but DAO and DA2 were definitely much better in terms of a fantastical, enchanting atmosphere, at least for narrative soundtracks - combat soundtrack was the brassiest orchestra that ever brassed. Trevor Morris' work was fairly plain, with some enjoyable pieces that unfortunately overstayed their welcome for me. But now we have the big men Hans Zimmer and Lorne Balfe themselves! So the soundtrack is even more mid and not at all memorable now. With each game becoming grander and more successful, the soundtrack becomes more and more generic. Truly the definition of suffering from success.

[b]Overall, DAV is probably the first time DA has really found its identity.[/b] This is something devs old and new, Bioware and non-Bioware alike agreed on. While Gaider had his own unique ideas, the series itself very much started as a generic fantasy to make it as marketable as possible. The title "Dragon Age" was mashed together because those two words were the most popular-in-marketing words of the era. Dragons were only added to suit the title. Darkspawn were only added because leadership wanted an orc-like race that the player could play indiscriminately. Magic was originally much more restricted narratively, but players would obviously want to throw around fireballs, so the related lore became more lax. This is the first time they had a strong vision for every element of the game, the first time they really respected the writers' vision too, the first time they had full time for development, the first time they didn't crunch and had high morale - and it shows.

Unfortunately, since [b]this is a game about themes of compassion, kindness, and solidarity in the face of imperialism, fascism, historical colonialism, and the devastating consequences of all that[/b], 2024 isn't exactly the best year for its release. In a saner world it would be sweeping nominations if not outright awards. Instead, we have people complaining about how the game is sanitized because "people are too nice to each other too soon". You mean to tell me you're not nice to strangers? That you don't try to understand others and work out frictions when they happen? Can you only play games where you can be exclusively the worst person ever? Because let me tell you, there are innumerable games out there where you can be the worst, and outright reward you for it. Let people have just *one* game where they can live the power fantasy of being radically kind and helping people in real and meaningful ways. Just because our companions are not tearing each other apart for the 4th game, and we can't eradicate yet another Dalish clan casually for no reason, you'll live, I promise. (Not even gonna dignify the people complaining about boobs being too small because woke with a detailed response. Touch grass.)

To the people establishing themselves as authority over what is and isn't a "Dragon Age game": enjoy the game for what it is, not what it isn't. And stop with the "I've been a fan since..." it's obnoxious and meaningless. I've been deep into the fandom for over 10 years now, following lore updates, dev interviews; put thousands of hours collectively into all DA games with 2k being in DAI alone, and had dozens of playthroughs in DAO and DA2 while still in high school; I literally got married to someone I met in the fandom - suffice to say I'm deeply invested in the series too and from *my* perspective, this is the best and most DA game to date. And this take has just as much weight as other people's "but I'm a real fan" takes. I'm not any more or less of an arbiter of what makes a true DA game than other fans - who btw in my experience, typically just played DAO on release, and have been complaining about every other DA game ever since. And if someone like that read this far, please know that you can find other hobbies too. You don't have to define yourself as a fan and lover of DA just because you loved one game. You don't have to stay miserable.

My humble thanks if you read all the way and found value in my words, this was admittedly as much a vent as my thoughts on the game itself. Otherwise, [b]tl;dr: the game is good, and I encourage you to play it and enjoy it for what it is, not what it isn't or what people think it should be to be a valid DA game.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970683458', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 4851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4851, 'last_played': 1734559504}
review:
**Review modified after completing the game**

Dragon Age: Veilguard is a mixed bag. On one hand, the game looks and plays great, scenery and lighting are fantastic and the game is definitely optimized when it comes to performance. The combat is flashy and fun, albeit a bit easy if you know what you are doing.

When it comes to the characters and the story however, it's not all sunshine and rainbows. The first and last acts of the game are good, but the middle act feels padded and drawn out, it's probably what caused me to take breaks and not play the game for up  to a week at a time.

All in all, it's a pretty fun game if you are willing to push through the boring parts and willing to be condescendingly lectured to by the writing team about a certain companion's identity.

Graphics, technical: 9/10
Graphics, aesthetic: 4/10
Music: 7/10
Sound: 8/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Story/immersion: 6/10
Overall enjoyment: 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198125078670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 8111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1771, 'playtime_at_review': 859, 'last_played': 1736697482}
review: Is it as good as origins ? Maybe not in terms of the writing - is it enjoyable ? Yes even if some of the combat is repetitive - it’s fun to try different builds- it’s definitely more ARPG than tactical rpg- the graphics are gorgeous and the maps have lush detail- I can’t say it’s the best dragon age game but it has its moments . Try it out, you may be pleasantly surprised.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013563425', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 4747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 825, 'last_played': 1730876867}
review:
I hate that this game once more has culture war nonsense around it. It's not the best dragon age and it's not the worse. It's like someone smushed it together with mass effect as far as combat is concerned and that's not a terrible thing. I prefer crpg origins style games more than this direction, but it works and has a lot of depth towards builds with a ton of customization in difficulty to make it more or less challenging.

The art outside of characters themselves is great, not a fan of the pixar direction on characters, but environments and spell effects are pretty. The set pieces are worthy of just standing a minute and taking in. 

Plenty of dialogue options for class/ race/ and origins are available. First 12 hours of the game and more reactivity than in any owlcat game I've played already. Only larian rivaling the reactivity here. There's even unique dialogue for an elf that has tattoos, just an example the level of reactivity. 

As long as you want an RPG where you play the hero and are OK with more action style RPG combat, then I think anyone will enjoy this. Especially if they are fans of the fantasy genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023271871', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1159, 'last_played': 1731984513}
review:
probably wouldn't have given it a review bc i'm too in the middle on if it's worth it, but half the negative reviews are for dumb shit

it's not a bad game, most of the writing is fine, the tone is fine half the time
it's just a little inconsistent i think, there are times where it feels like dragon age and times it feels like it's trying to be a movie and that's not really the identity of the series so i don't love it

game looks good, character creator is fun, cool that people have more options when making their characters (body size, better dark skin options, pronouns/identity) kinda weird people are mad at it, it's optional but whatever
as a trans woman it is a little jarring to just hear some modern gender/sexuality terminology thrown out in a fantasy game, but it's not like a bad thing, there have been queer characters since the series started so it's disingenuous to pretend this some new attack on something

some of the characters are a lil cringe at times but i dunno.. i feel like people are greatly exaggerating a lot of their feelings bc they have some sort of agenda against not every companion being some fantasy trope copy paste

i do wish there was more conflict within the group, people can only be mad at rook
there's not a lot of moral decisions, there's some hard decisions but like... none of them are morally challenging
would be interesting to take some of those tough decisions and add morally dubious solutions that have better results for you and the war effort but involve some sort of evil stuff idk! 

i'm not a reviewer just rambling. overall, game fun. sometimes it's a lil cringe but people are cringe sometimes so whatever. wish there were more meaningful moral decisions rather than "does A get hurt or B get hurt"
combat feels good once you get some skill points in, though it feels like some skills should just be part of the base moveset of weapons
7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198124656447', 'num_games_owned': 790, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 871, 'last_played': 1731168514}
review:
Secara action dan combat nya sebenernya ini game sangat seru untuk tipikal modern RPG, dimana sebenernya ini ngebawa sistem party yang lebih arcade dan terasa seperti main game MMORPG dengan party sistemnya. Sebenernya kalau di compare secara langsung dengan Dragon's Dogma yang baru masih ga apple to apple rasanya karena sistem partynya sangat berbeda, disini ada beberapa signature skill dari party yang harus kita aktifin secara manual dibandingkan dengan sistem skill dari DD2, tapi tetep sebuah combat yang cukup menghibur. Untuk variasi musuhnya, kayaknya masih menjadi sebuah hal yang kurang sama seperti DD2 tipe musuhnya masih sangat repetitif dan berujung boring, kalau untuk nikmatin story dan adventurenya saya rekomendasikan Normal difficulty aja karena yang jadi faktor pembeda cuman sponge HP aja dari monsternya, dan juga cuman nambah nambahin kerjaan jadi harus ngehit banyak button dalam durasi yang cukup lama.

Untuk dari storynya ini sangat undercook banget, sampah lebih tepatnya untuk franchise Dragon Age. Bener bener kaya cuman nonton dongeng disney dari anak SD, your choice did not even matter karena tidak akan mengubah jalan ceritanya secara major, memang masih ada gimmick dari choice matternya, tapi efeknya cuman siapa nanti companion yang memar permanen, atau siapa yang ngambek karena ga diturutin tp ujung2nya mereka balik lg available di party. Ini tuh lebih kaya cerita yang kita ini MC dan pasti bisa mengalahkan kejahatan, meh banget.

Gimmick RPG nya lebih condong ke arah MMORPG dengan konsep UI, Equipment, Enchanment dll nya malah seperti gim RPG gacha banget. TAPI untuk masalah VISUALNYA ini adalah salah satu yang masih bikin comfortable untuk bermain. Udah, itu aja.

Gimana ya, mungkin untuk saya yang beranjak dari BG3 kemudian mencari game RPG story rich agak sedikit kecewa dengan beberapa aspek dalam gim ini, tapi untuk yang masih bikin betah main sebenernya dari segi GRAFIK VISUAL dan COMBATnya saja yang memang mungkin mendorong saya untuk membeli dan tetap main DATV ini, mungkin kalau gambarnya sampah dan combatnya jelek saya refund dari awal hehe, untuk ditaruh overall kayaknya 5/10 banget itu juga ketolong karena masih optimize dibanding DD2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198322255942', 'num_games_owned': 187, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 7466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2918, 'last_played': 1732423824}
review:
Here is what I feel after about 30 hours-ish in-game time, though I'm still far from finishing the game—only 22% discovered across northern Thedas even I haven’t meet with Taash and Emmrich yet.


[list]
	[*][b]Character Creation (CC)[/b] is good so far, and even the hair is fabulous with physics, unlike the previous game. If you still think it looks bad, that’s more of a skill issue to set.
	[*][b]The Intro[/b] is different from the previous game and feels rushed—there’s just too much happening at the beginning.
	[*]It’s [b]not a truly open world[/b], but if you’ve played [i]DAO[/i] and [i]DA2[/i], you’ll recognize the typical map of it. It’s more like linear dungeons than open world.
	[*][b]Dialogue wheel[/b] is the same as in the previous games, with options to be diplomatic, sarcastic, or aggressive like in [i]DA2[/i]. There’s also a bit of [i]DAI[/i] style with sad, accepting, angry, etc., reactions when giving a response. I don’t understand the hate saying you can't be mean to someone. I mean, you can be sarcastic, right? This game doesn’t have a silent protagonist like the Hero of Ferelden, so it’s harder to convey the same meaning through dialogue text and the spoken words. Even [i]DA2[/i] and [i]DAI[/i] have to suffer for this as well, you pick a sentence, but after hearing the MC say the words, it’s not what you meant.
	[*][b]Combat [/b]feels like a mix of [i]DA2[/i], [i]ME3[/i], and [i]MEA[/i] for controlling which skills to use. I’m not a fan of this. It feels like Dragon Age doesn’t have its soul anymore, especially since you can’t control companions like in the previous games. But I do like the gameplay as Rook mage, as you can infinite dodge step-fade, iframes with skill and use shielding with some cool effects. Also, I think when using a dagger, it feels like you parry enemies when performing a perfect dodge—though I’m not sure, maybe it’s just a coincidence. I played in underdog just in case.
	[*][b]Exploration : [/b]You have to explore and not just blindly follow the main quest marker. Some side missions are secret unless you're in area, and if you’re not careful, you’ll miss them.
	[*]Prioritize [b]side quests[/b], especially for factions and companions, before advancing to main quest. Trust me.
	[*][b]Companion banter[/b] is still tolerable (not as bad as [i]DAO[/i] with Alistair whining or Morrigan disapproval of everything). Once you get to know your companions and do their personal missions, it gets better. For example, at first, I thought Bellara was like Sera—trying to be goofy but failing miserably and just annoy us. But after doing her first mission, I understood her more. Pairing her with Harding makes for some great lore banter, as they talk about elven language and dwarven similarities and lost overtime, which is a nice touch.
	[*][b]Teambuilding[/b] in RPG feels almost nonexistent in this game. The enemies mostly target the Rook, and if you’re playing as a mage, it’s worse. In previous games, we had early warrior tanks like Cassandra, Aveline, and Alistair. In [i]DAV[/i], Davrin comes too late, and even when you build him for a taunt build with Battle Cry, it only works for maybe 4 seconds before enemies start chasing your Rook again.
	[*]If you feel the game is too [b]colorful[/b], you can turn off the bloom effect in the profile settings.
	[*]The game still has [b]dark vibes[/b] at certain points, basically after the tutorial. If you missed it or didn’t notice, it’s probably because everyone’s too busy riding the bandwagon about the culture war.
[/list]


[b]Overall[/b], this is a good fast-paced action fantasy RPG if you’re new to the series. But by [i]Dragon Age[/i] standards, it’s mediocre. It lacks a detailed codex with relevant lore, and the entries are too short to be meaningful. Also there’s a Kossith (people of Thedas call them Qunari) as part of Shadow Dragon in the middle of Minrathous(Or Dock Town no idea still its near tho), a capital city in Tevinter..... come on, Bioware, even if they’re Tal-Vasoth, it’s a weak excuse for lore just to make it work for filling quotas. The worst part is the NPC reaction to the Elven Gods. No one seems to care, which is bizarre given that the Elven Gods are [i]real[/i]—like, F-word actually real. Schoolar across Thedas should be in shambles right now, same as Andrastian chantry in the south. Even [i]DAI[/i] handled weaks8 villains like Corypheus better with how Orlais and Ferelden act dired at that time. Lastly, the sacred of eluvian in crossroad to across Thedas its like common now that every city, ally, and acquaintance of the Veilguard seems to have one before meeting Rook and unlocking it from the Crossroads.


[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
I still haven’t finished the game, so I’m not ready to give it a final score. But if I had to rate it right now, I would give it a [b]7/10[/b]. So, give it a try if you still doubt it— ignore those ragebaiter youtuber who's always angry. Bioware has clearly shifted their focus to appeal to newer fans and put us [b][i]old fans as relic of the past[/i][/b], so if you enjoy fast-paced combat like [i]GoW[/i], you’ll probably like this. Whether you want to get the game at full price or on sale is up to you, but for old fans, it's probably best to get it on sale when it's at least 50% off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121825416', 'num_games_owned': 1385, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 4420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4420, 'last_played': 1732732254}
review:
Waited for ten years, not disappointed.
Couldn't stop playing but will come and write a hell of a review when and IF I can stop playing.

EDIT AFTER FINISHING(70 hours):

Buy it on sale(just got %35 not even 2 months after launch, isn't that amazing?), turn your DA brain off, have fun and forget it.

After finishing the game - watching every ending possible, I honestly fell into a love/hate relationship with this entry.

Pros:
- Visuals, graphics: The game has amazing visuals environment-wise. Some places are just breathtaking, I simply stopped and watched the scenery sometimes. 

- Gameplay: Look I’m a DAO fan when it comes to my favourite in the series; but playing recent titles like BG3 and replaying the trilogy before DAV came out made me realize they are janky as hell for today’s standards -doesn’t mean I wanted to see a similar gameplay- but, damn the DAV gameplay is frigging fun. I had the most fun I’ve had this year -besides LAD8- while I was playing. The mage mechanics are like a dream come true for me, especially the “spellblade” specialization. I don’T think I can even play another class. But from what I’ve seen rogue and warrior is also hella fun to play as well. 

- Hair mechanics/CC; Don’t @ me. I’ve played every entry in the series with and all DA fans know that the vanilla options were always godawful. Everybody lost their mind when a certain series 6th game has showed similar mechanics in their trailer and you’re telling me I’M exaggerating when I have those mechanics in front of me now? Shut it. CC is also one of the good ones we've got in these types of games. Is it perfect? No. Is it detailed enough to make me spend more than an hour trying to look at every single thing? Yeah.

- Linear open world: I don’t know if this is a thing, or I could call that. I’m someone who rarely complains about a game’s map being too much as long as it doesn’t feel extremely empty (I’m looking at you AC: Odyssey, love you but, seriously?) E.g.: DAI never feels to big or boring to me. The maps are big enough to give you the satisfaction of exploring them but not tire you out. It was definitely one of the nice parts about the game.

- Solavellan Content: Not exactly happy, but at least we got something, I am content with having a closure and can live with that.

Cons:
- Character designs: Don’t get me wrong, the characters look beautiful but I’m on the team that thinks body proportions are weird. That’s all.

- Godawful writing: The story is like a summary of what could’ve been. It feels like the assignment you remember you’re supposed to turn in but started working on it before the due date. In some parts it feels rushed, doesn’t even make sense, totally disregards or doesn’t mention the lore that has been established. Factions are just...there, not having very much depth to them, but existing so that you can grind something to get the best ending. Like, remove the LoF and nothing changes. I don't understand why Veil Jumpers are named like that while literally being artifact hunters. Races doesn't mean much because Rook is always conradicting themselves about their origin, doesn't matter how you want it to be -because you cannot tell what they'll say with some options- I understand wanting to attract new players to the series but doing it so by literally SANITIZING and DUMBING DOWN the lore of the previous three entries is a huge betrayal to your loyal fanbase. Quite a number of people told me that "Well, the conflicts weren't THAT well established in the previous entries either." which I agree, but they were building up to DA4, it was getting better and better imo and we have...nearly nothing in this game? Suddenly they're gone? The whole Tevinter and the nasty stuff is just mentioned in passing and literally the plight of the Elven, the most bullied race since the fall of Arlathan is just...gone? What the actual hell. And don’t even get me started about the Dev AMA on Reddit, ‘twas the day that I nearly started hating the game.

We all know that “Show, don’t tell” is -arguably- the best approach. This game? This game TELLS. It doesn’t show. At times -and not rare- it treats players like a dumb kid who needs explanation about even the simplest stuff. Worse part? It repeatedly does so. I don’t know what were those people were drinking to compare DAV to ME2 (I mean, it is similar in some sense) but while ME2 was peak in the series, DAV can never ever come close to that quality. I’m not gonna name names but I think some people are the WORST things that could’ve happened to this series with how they handled this game.



- Companion interactions: Again, before yelling at me, read the following. In the other entries, you’d go to your companions when you wanted to, would ask them bunch of stuff about themselves, about the world, about what’s going on in the game. Here? You go talk to them when they want to talk to you and you mostly talk about their needs and wants. To me that’s less organic than the previous entries. It’s all buddy-buddy and “team” with these guys. Don’t be nice to them and they’re just annoyed at best(and you don’t get the best ending) that’s all. Sure, they have nice stories and backgrounds; but no arguments, no discussions…no headbutting with any of them because of different opinions or how my MC handled things like we had in the previous entries? It’s just MEH overall. And all those talks about DAV having “oh so much romance”…yeaaaah. No. Just compare the length of DAI romance videos to DAV romance videos, that’s all I’m saying. 

- MC: I know everybody has their very detailed backstories for their Rooks and believe me, I like mine as well, but I’d prefer Hawke or Inquisitor to be completely honest. I understand why bringing back Hawke would/could create a problem and but Inquisitor -even as an advisor- makes much, much more sense to me. With all it’s continuity problems and faults, ME series will be always superior to me just because I use the SAME character overall and can see the consequences of my actions better (Yes, even though some choices are considered canon for the sake of not dealing with different outcomes; to me, it provides better consistency through the series even though some of the canon choices are total opposite of mine)

In short/ TL; DR: This game will never be a DAO or DAI for me. At this point, if not for the gameplay and visuals, it would be my least favourite entry among all. As it stands, it is barely above DA2; and hell, DA2 has better story and companions if you ask me at this point. Get it on discount, play it, enjoy the gameplay, and have fun for 60-70 hours, and try not to think about lore much because that’s where you start to get angry and sad about what could’ve been.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014148821', 'num_games_owned': 355, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 625, 'last_played': 1730665552}
review:
Surprisingly decent. 6/10.

Now to be perfectly clear if you're going into this expecting Dragon Age, you'll probably be disappointed - as the game feels a bit more like a spin off that doesn't have the same vibe as the previous games. Putting that aside, with my fairly short playtime atm - it is not horrible even if this review will be pointing out more bad things than good.

[b] Let's start with the good. [/b]
- Firstly kudos, the game runs very smooth - this might be expected but these days most games on release don't even work so for this to be running smoothly it's a great thing.
- Character creator is quite good, plenty of time can be spent in it with quite a few options to pick from (although some of the layout / ordering of items makes you go back and forth a lot)
- Combat while a bit basic, is smooth. Quite easy to pickup and provides few different options for builds (all fairly basic though).
- Decent variety between enemies especially special / boss types
- Intriguing enough where I didn't feel like refunding at 2hrs mark

[b] Now for the bad... [/b]
- Camera behavior is wonky to say the least
- Facial animation are bad
- Minimap is actually pointless - it doesn't even highlight enemies in the vicinity
- Story / writing is really flat and nothing worth remembering
- Climbing & walking the plank are tedious and infuriating
- Does not feel like much of an RPG - firstly your character feels quite disjointed from the world, i.e. my Warden has 0 reaction to darkspawn. Supporting characters have more reaction and lines to events happening around you. Secondly skills & level ups feel just like boxes you're ticking not seeing all that much of a difference in gameplay. Yes you get new skills, but that doesn't really change how you play the game all that much
- Weapon switching / Weapon selection - not only is the switch weapons on the fly a weird behavior but the weapon selection you end up is quite limited i.e. no greatsword (as well as many other popular weapon types)

Normally I'd leave a review after completing the game (or refunding it), but as much as I didn't feel like refunding after 2hrs I am also not pulled back into it - so I have no idea when I'll be done with it. If there are any other experiences worth mentioning I'll make sure to update this review.

But as a game this is an alright title that will provide quite a few hours of casual entertainment. However I do not see it as even close for a GOTY contender or even a DA game. That being said it's nowhere as bad as what people tried to claim it'll be before release.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998865115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1731192076}
review:
First 9 hour opinions. 

Combat is a big step up. Lots of yapping, so your mileage may vary based on your enjoyment of yapping (I enjoy a good yap). Writing is OK—people say exactly how they feel pretty frequently rather than struggling to process things like normal people, but I think a decade must've somehow given everyone an extreme case of amnesia because there isn't a single bioware game where people act like people. It's campy and plays to the tone of a TTRPG party, and the story thus far feels a little basic, but I like each of my companions and they're fun enough to make me want to continue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170217161', 'num_games_owned': 71, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5605, 'last_played': 1735553629}
review:
I just finished my first playthrough last night, and although I really want to jump straight into another playthrough to try out a different class and faction, the ending hit me so hard emotionally that I think I need to give myself a break. The last act was easily a 9.5/10 for me, and I think [i]with[/i] the context of that ending, the rest of the game is an 8/10. If the ending hadn't been so strong, my rating probably would be a 7/10. 

The following review will be generally spoiler-free, though I will reference some things that were part of the marketing material (as vaguely as I possibly can).

[b][u]Performance[/u][/b]
I played on a desktop I built in 2020, with a Ryzen 5 3600X, RTX 2070 Super, and 16 GB of RAM, on a 1440p monitor, with the game installed on a SATA SSD. With most settings at high or medium, and with raytracing off, the game still looked gorgeous. With framerates uncapped, they sometimes exceeded 100 fps, especially in the lighthouse, but I found the experience smoother if I capped framerates to 60 fps. Notably, I was able to keep the detailed hair physics turned on.

The only bugs I experienced in my first playthrough were: 2 crashes, 1 bug related to changing a keybinding, and 2 codex entries that showed up before they should have.


[b][u]Things I Loved[/u][/b]
For context, I played the entire series for the first time in 2015, and have replayed all three games multiple times since then. I loved them all, but DAO is not my favorite, so I had no expectation (or desire) for Veilguard to be Origins 2.0. I also have less patience now for DAI's open-world slog than I did even just a few years ago, though I still love it in general.

-- I LOVE Rook. She wasn't quite as strong a character for me as Shepard or Hawke, but she feels like a real person in a way that the Inquisitor never did for me. I played a Mourn Watch dwarf warrior, and there were numerous times throughout the game that I was reminded where she came from, that she had a past before she joined up with Varric, and that there are people from her past who care about her. Bryony Corrigan's performance was stellar.

-- There was a surprising amount of reactivity for her Mourn Watch background, for being a dwarf, and for being a dwarf from the Mourn Watch. Not all of those dialog options have the specially coded icons for Mourn Watch or dwarves, so it's like the game is actually paying attention to the background you chose. There was only one notable part in Harding's personal questline that I felt like dwarf Rook got ignored when she should have been included, but it definitely wasn't "what's a Mythal"-levels of jarring (and definitely not gith Tav in BG3 levels of rage-quitting). Just more of a missed opportunity. Rook felt more dwarfy to me than Cadash did, regardless.

-- When going back to the lighthouse, even if the companions don't have quest or conversation icons on them, they almost always still had something new to say. I like that they move around the lighthouse to interact with each other a lot, too.

-- Even though Rook was usually left out of the banter when out in the field, she got to interject occasionally, and I think it was more often than the Inquisitor got to interject. 

-- The overall story. While the situation doesn't seem as hopeless as the one in DA2, I do think the threat feels more real than what Corypheus presented in DAI. It's plenty dark. There are lighter moments (including a few that I think were too light in tone considering the subject matter), but fewer outright jokes than previous games. Early on, I got to leave someone to a pretty grizzly fate, so while Rook is generally a good-hearted person (they are Varric's hand-picked second in command, after all), there are a few opportunities to go a bit renegade.

-- The quest/level design. Fetch quests are pretty much gone. There are a few "collectables," in a way, but they all give you stat increases or skill points. No more endless pinging only to find out that the secret item you found is yet another useless bottle of wine. There is plenty to explore, with some verticality in each zone, but no more empty open-world zones like DAI gave us. They are more akin to the zones of DAO and DA2, and most (though not all) can be revisited after their associated quests for further exploration. 

-- The facial animations are pretty solid, and are a huge step up from Mass Effect Andromeda and DAI.

-- The good scenes are phenomenal. Any scene involving Solas was fantastic in writing, voice acting, tone, and direction, and I'm not even a Solas fanatic. And that ending is one of Bioware's best for its emotional impact. 

-- Due to the LI I chose for my Inquisitor (no, not Solas), their relationship was acknowledged twice, once in a codex, and once in ambient dialog (and possibly twice more in a vague way during dialog with Rook earlier in the game). While more would have always been nice, both instances were very sweet and in-character for the relationship, and they were both welcome bright spots during the amazing, but emotionally-draining, ending.


[b][u]Things That Were Fine[/u][/b]
The dialog. When it was good, it was amazing. A lot of it was just serviceable. I didn't see the Marvelesque quips that other people are complaining about. It was mostly just...average. Not Bioware's best, but definitely not their worst, either. It helped that most of the voice acting was solid (with the possible exceptions of Neve and Harding, who I found to be inconsistent).


[b][u]Things I Didn't Like[/u][/b]
My main complaint with this game is that companion conflicts resolved themselves too quickly. It isn't that they're always nice to each other, because there [i]are[/i] some conflicts between companions. It's that resolving those conflicts takes no effort and very little time, making the found family vibes that the devs were going for feel unearned. There are some companion pairs that got along well from the beginning, and I think those are actually the strongest ones, because there is no cognitive dissonance caused by thinking that they resolved their differences too easily. 

I don't agree with one reviewer in particular who thinks that the dialog is written as if HR is in the room, or as if Rook is talking to 10 year olds. It isn't nearly that bad. But I do think Bioware overcorrected in trying to not have a repeat of certain companions from DAI, who seemed to never get along with anybody. BW would have been far better off leaving some real conflict and tension in there with specific companion pairs, and giving that conflict time to grow before bringing them to a resolution. I don't think ME2-style face-offs are necessary, but some ability for Rook to tell them to knock it off and figure out their shit before they became liabilities would have been great.

For all that the devs talked up their focus on companions, the romances seem pretty lackluster. It's like they took the ME1/ME2 approach here, where you do some flirting, then eventually lock in the romance, and then have a culminating scene near the end of the game, with very little in between. I think some of the companion/companion romances got more acknowledgement in dialog and banter than Rook/Davrin did. Even the option for a repeatable hug or kiss scene would help a lot. If Bioware won't do it, then hopefully modders will be able to.

The timing of that culminating romance scene is bizarre, too, considering what happened immediately before it (which I will not spoil). Having the option to tell your LI to just sit, cuddle, and keep you company would have fit better, I think.


----

In spite of my criticisms, though, I loved the game. I think it fixed a lot of DAI's and MEA's problems, and while I don't think it's my favorite DA game, I do rank it higher than DAI. As long as you go into this game willing to accept it for what it is, I recommend giving it a shot for yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198238967460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1733966327}
review: I've seen a lot of people review bombing this game souly because it "doesn't feel like Dragon Age" or because they made the game "woke." For the first point, I have to ask, when has a Dragon Age game actually felt like a Dragon Age game? If we are chasing the experience of Origins I can assure none of the past 3 games have met it, but they are all enjoyable games in their own right. We need to accept that other than the overarching story, Dragon Age is a game about characters and the stories they tell through conflict and strife. This much I can assure you is carried out well in this game. All of the characters have distinct personalities that make me curious about their motivations. As for the woke part, who cares? No one is forcing you to be trans or date the big strong handsome elf (me, I am forcing you because I am weak). Just ignore it if it makes you that salty. On a side note, Dragon Age has always been "woke" to some extent. Zevran and Lelianna were romance options regardless of gender in the *early 2000's.* It may not be the beacon of progress we would expect today, but damn was it something. Veilguard, on its own, is a wonderful experience. The writing in the first portion of the game comes off a bit clunky but when the ball starts rolling, it's wonderful. The combat is engaging and good lord does Bioware know how to make some amazing areas to traverse and explore. Please, give this game the chance. It has more than deserved it in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067081510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1731292226}
review:
Really unsure about whether or not I can recommend this right now, especially with only being nearly 3 hours into the game. However, with that being said, I spent almost 50 minutes of my life trying to get the graphics to work for a PC that I've had for about 2 weeks... I had issues with the graphics looking fuzzy but with some help from my friends, I was able to get it to look pretty good, but not as good as I would've liked.

So far though, the game almost has as much charm as a Dragon Age game should, but I'd like to continue playing to really know for sure, and change my review later.

I am really enjoying the combat of this game, and I'm excited to meet more of the main characters, collect little secret jibbits so that I can fill my codex, and ruin Rook's life by accidentally picking the wrong dialogue option. 

Anyways, this review is being brought to you by someone who finished Origins on PC and Inquisition on PS4. Crossing my fingers that Dragon Age: The Veilguard actually contains dragons

author: {'steamid': '76561198055040235', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 903, 'last_played': 1731320721}
review:
Runs super smooth, no crashes, graphics are great. Created some Sauron look-alike elf character and have plans to eradicate every puny weakling. I hope game will let me.

UPDATE after actually playing a bit: still a positive review, but out of 10 I give the game 6. And that is because of super lame options they give you for answers every time. They are all leading to the same outcome, it really doesn't matter what option out of 3 you will choose. Let's say, as an example (imaginary), someone asks you:
"We have to help them! What do you think"
and your answers are 1)"Yes, of course, they are our friends", 2) "I have better plans, but I guess we have no choice", 3) "Haha, I can't help even myself, but I'll do what I can". 

Yeah, different tone and all, but ALL THE SAME. In Baldur's Gate 3 these answers would be 
1) "Sure, let's kick some as*!" 2) "I would rather eat a hedgehog than help these guys" 3) "Let's join evil guys and share the loot".

So the writing is bad. Twists are bad, everything is just an already written book. 

The battles are awesome, the graphics are great and the scenery is a-ma-zing! 

Will update :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970477239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 5338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5338, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1733603852}
review:
I really, really enjoyed playing this game.
I have been playing RPGs since they existed, Ultima, Bard's Tale and the Gold box series are still some of my favourites, so I know RPGs. And that's the thing, this isn't an RPG, it's a fantasy action game that plays and feels like Mass Effect 3 with swords and fireballs. If you are expecting the top down RTWP loveliness of Origins then you may as well go and play Pathfinder or Pillars of Eternity coz you aint getting that here. 
However, what you do have is a silky smooth game with gorgeous art design (never taken so many screenshots), zero bugs and rock solid performance that - playing as a damage dealing thief, at least - was a blast to play from start to finish.

I think the thing that really annoys people is the lack of 'grittiness' - Dragon Age was always a bit low fantasy with some blood, guts and moral quandaries and this does not fit AT ALL with  the 'niceness' of the party characters - the world outside their base is going to sh1t but they are sat around baking cakes or having bookclubs, etc and it does feel like a total disconnect to what the story is trying to tell.

Look at Emmrich for instance - on paper this guy is a bad @ss. An orphan who was raised to be a necromancer in a literal grandiose gothic city of the dead, surrounded by undead, ghosts and other such creatures from an early age. And despite living with all this death his whole life, he is paradoxically so terrified of his own mortality that he seeks to be an ever-living Vecna-style lich. How cool is that background? This guy must be some sinister, introverted obsessive who fights like each fight is his last, due to the potential immediacy of death, right? 
Nah, he is just a lovely old softly spoken grandpa with a Vincent Price quiff who just wants a cup of tea from his comedy sidekick skeleton and to perhaps play some cribbage.
Did I like him though? Yeah he's just 'really nice' like everyone else and they are all equally nice to each other. Bit of a step down from having Minthara in the party but there you go.
The only character with some spirit is Taash bizarrely, the one the anti-woke brigade were so hung up about. They are the only one that reminded me of the older games (the scene where they call Emmrich a 'skull f4cker' was great and made me chuckle).

So, if you can't get over these characters not really feeling like they are participating in the end of the world, (or indeed any of the actual 'gaming' parts of this game - none of them seem to be the type to be mass murdering wizards all day in an explosively cool fashion, except maybe Taash again) then you are not gonna like this - it is a huge disconnect, like I said earlier.
This same exact issue occurs with Marvel's Midnight Suns - brilliant tactical battles, but then a large part of the game is back at home base doing crochet with Captain Marvel or having a picnic with Deadpool. 
They both ascribe to the 'cozy game' approach outside of the main story and I guess a lot of people are finding that hard to swallow and I can see why. 
Me? I just kinda loved it in both games for its straight up weirdness. I glazed over when people spoke and then just enjoyed the actual fighting, levelling up, map exploration, trying to cozy up with Harding but somehow ending up with Taash and the main story finale was brilliant (which shamelessly rips off Mass Effect 2 - but hey steal from the best.)

To conclude: I really, really enjoyed playing this game.

TLDR: The HAIR, best I have ever seen in a game.
