author: {'steamid': '76561198028187611', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8697, 'last_played': 1734276171}
review:
After a 10 year long wait, this is the Dragon Age we got. I enjoyed playing it and will start another playthrough soon, but it's not without its (many?) flaws.

Let me start by saying the game runs great. I've encountered a whopping number of 0 bugs in the 90 hours I played. I feel like that's pretty rare nowadays, so congrats to Bioware for this smooth release.

The game looks beautiful. I was not a fan of the artstyle in the trailers, but the environments look great. All regions have their own distinct look and the maps are a joy to walk through. I don't like open worlds, which is why I played Inquisition only 2 times with an 8 year break inbetween. Maps are smaller than Inquisition, but bigger than Origins. It's also not filled with endless fetch quests. Much more of a nice stroll instead of painful struggle through the park.

From the marketing, it was clear that a lot of focus would be on the companions. Personally, I liked all of them. Everyone has their own story and struggles and I appreciated the amount of time we get to spend with them on different kinds of quests, outings and conversations. There's also plenty of banter between them, so make sure to return to the Lighthouse frequently to listen to the their conversations. (edit: and when they're talking while out in the world and they get interrupted by a fight, they'll start over again when the fighting's done! Very nice touch)

The story is mostly fine. It has some high points, it has some low points. The focus on the companions combined with the Suicide Mission-esque final quest(s) makes this game like Mass Effect 2 on steroids. I thought it was great to see everything come together in the end.

Combat is a blast. It's a bit too flashy and shiny sometimes, since it made it hard to see the parry indicator, so I was getting pummeled around a lot. But, as a rogue, it's fluid and fun to play. You're not stuck to preset difficulties, you can customize the settings so you can make it just the way you like it.

All in all, DA:TV did a lot of things the way I prefer them to be, so I got lucky in that regard. It's also why I'm much more inclined to play again as opposed to Inquisition.

However...

The writing, the worldbuilding, the lore... everything feels extremely clean. Sanitized. Sterile. It's not that DA:TV "isn't dark enough", since there's plenty of doom and gloom in various quests. It just feels like the doom and gloom is contained within these quests and nothing seeps into the world outside. There is no specific Dragon Age vibe.

Where is the injustice? Discrimination? Oppression? Thedas was filled with that in the previous games. You didn't have to play the city elf origin to figure out how terrible life is for city elves in the alienage. You didn't have to play a mage to get a sense of what it's like to live in the Circle. Kirkwall was a shithole, and you knew that because Hawke would find all kinds of trouble in and around the city. None of that in this game.

The Tevinter Imperium has been mentioned multiple times in the previous games. It's supposed to be this place where it's all powerful (blood) mages and slaves. So in DA:TV, we are in Tevinter... and it feels just like Ferelden. The only region we regularly visit is Dock Town, which might as well be Denerim or Lowtown. There is nothing to set it apart. There is nothing to really build the atmosphere. There are no NPCs to talk to. No bartenders to ask about gossip. There are newspaper stands, but you can't ask the sellers anything. There are some beggars on the streets, so you give them coins, and they don't even thank you. You have no clue what it's like to live there. It doesn't give you a reason to care. At least the cats purr when you pet them. (I LOVE CATS AND THERE ARE SO MANY OF THEM)

There are also no shades of grey. Everything is black and white. Factions good, enemies bad. Not once did I have to mentally justify one of the choices I made. The decisions don't really give any room for discussion. Why would you choose Harrowmont over Bhelen? Why did you side with the mages instead of the templars? Do I pimp out my love interest for a chance to survive the final battle or just go for the sacrifice? You just go from A to B or C, but you're never "wrong".

The big bads we fight and some of the revelations we uncover should be world breaking, but no one... cares? The Veil Jumpers, who feel like cheap stand-ins for Dalish clans, basically shrug and are immediately willing to join the fight from the start, without any sign of questioning their beliefs or anything. At some point, Rook is being asked if they believe in the Maker, and I suddenly realized that was the first time (IIRC) the Maker was even mentioned. 

It really feels like Dragon Age Light. It took 50 hours until I finally got a "ma serannas" and I felt like that Leo DiCaprio meme where he's pointing at the tv in recognition. 

Since the companions love to talk about food: This game is a nice soup, with a few meatballs, but it is sorely lacking noodles and spice. And probably also cheese. It's as if the cooks lost the original recipe and improvised.

If you're new to Dragon Age, then yes, I recommend this game. It's fun to play and not a bad game at all!
If you're a Dragon Age fan, then I can only recommend it if you're able to adjust your expectations. Think less Dragon Age, more Fuzzy Griffons Age.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982313500', 'num_games_owned': 692, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 51, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1736265769}
review:
Easy recommend if you like Dragon Age and/or RPGs in general. Each Dragon Age basically has its own visual style and while I prefer DA:I, this one has grown on me. It sits somewhere between DA2 and DA:I for mechs. There's still strategy here and has increased difficulties which REQUIRE it. So make no mistake, it is action based but issues commands and getting the right builds matter. 

This release also:
1. Went straight to Steam day one
2. No EA Play launcher required
3. No Denuvo
4. No MTX/store stuff
5. No DLC
6. Runs great

Its rare to get a release so polished and so consumer friendly these days. That should be applauded.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141647713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 11859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4745, 'last_played': 1733564683}
review:
I've been waiting for this game for 10 years. Just got done with my first run. Here's what I think:

-Combat is crunchy and fun. Finally some fluidity after the prior installation in there series (Inquisition) where all you did was holding down R/left click and picked spells/skills each cooldown.
-The art style, the environments are beautiful. The game looks amazing.
-Also, the game runs almost perfectly. I've seen people encounter some serious bugs but I haven't had the tiniest bug during my run.
-There are some serious lore revelations dedicated fans have been theorizing on for years and I've enjoyed finding out the truth of the matter. Also some pretty serious twists too.
-Love the new companions. Tho they can be a bit too squeaky nice at times.

-The qualitiy of writing is inconsistent. One side quest/main story segment can be one of the the most amazing storylines you've encounter in a game and the next can turn out to be the biggest nothingburger whatever.
-Same with the dialogues. More than once I thought to myself "huh? that it?" during conversations with companions or npcs.
-It wouldn't be a Dragon Age game without needless lore retcons and I'll be annoyed by them each time. The world of Thedas feels streamlined, the intricacies and complexities watered down, sadly.

Overall, I greatly enjoyed the game. It has its ups and downs but the entire Act 3 is one of the best segments I've played in a game in a while. A huge chapter of Dragon Age has come to an end, and it feels bittersweet for a long-time fan such as myself, but I thoroughly enjoyed the ride. If your criticisms can't go beyond "black elfs" or "trans people in my game rahrah" you might want to skip this one and go back to building blocks for much needed cognitive development.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147668762', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 19770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1927, 'playtime_at_review': 17843, 'last_played': 1736785483}
review:
Dragon Age: The Veilguard is a fun but flawed game that I genuinely enjoyed my time with but still have lots of grievances.
I only recently played through Origins - Inquisition in anticipation of this game so my feelings on certain reveals might not be as strong as someone who has waited years for this.

THE STORY
🔲 Awful
🔲 Nothing Special
✅ Good
🔲 Great
🔲 FANTASTIC

The Dragon Age series is known for its complex characters & morally ambiguous storylines, something that seems to be missing from this game in most of its quests.
Most of the antagonists/villains are simply factions designed as "evil" and that are trying to grab power. It gives the feeling that there is no unique qualities to any of these factions making them all feel like carbon copies of each other with little depth. Not all quests / storylines suffer from this but you start to see the pattern as you go through.
The main story isn't bad but it's not perfect either, some details from the early game are lost on me after how much time I spent gathering collectibles & doing side quests. I loved the whole final act of the game though, it felt very reminiscent of the final mission of Mass Effect 2 with important choices to make.
My biggest gripe with the main story was that Solas & The Inquisitor were sidelined in exchange for lesser characters for 90% of the story.

At the start of the game you pick a faction for your Rook which can add extra dialogue / context to certain scenes throughout main & side content.

I can't touch on the story without mentioning the dialogue. It's really rough at times  and some of the voice direction on certain characters felt off (especially compared to the same character in Inquisition) I do feel though that a lot of the times the dialogue was too modern and wasn't very immersive but it didn't bother me too much in the big picture.

I'm also not a fan of the removal of evil/antagonistic dialogue options that have been in Dragon Age/Mass Effect since the start. Rook feels like a more established character than even Hawke from DA2 did.

Overall I enjoyed what we got but the question lingers in my mind, could we have gotten better?

GAMEPLAY
🔲 Lifeless/static
🔲 Poor
🔲 Average
✅ Good
🔲 Excellent

The gameplay has been by far the WORST part of every Dragon Age for me. Veilguard has changed things significantly and its for the better in my opinion. I actually felt engaged with the combat on Nightmare but it didn't feel overly hard even on max difficulty. The parry timing felt strange for a while, I got used to it eventually and then it felt like second nature.

The Map design is leagues ahead of Inquisition's bloated open worlds. I spent countless hours scouring every map for chests to find the perfect items for my warrior's flaming weapons build, which really paid off in the third act. The skill tree has the right amount of variation between specialisations that make them all feel unique.

Instead of being able to control companions like previous games, you can now only command them to use abilities. I barely ever controlled the companions in past games so this doesn't matter to me but the new streamlined system helped keep the combat flowing for me.

The character creator is amazing and gives you way more options than any BioWare game previously has (it might also be their first good creator)

DIFFICULTY
🔲 Playing asleep
🔲 Some brain usage
✅ Easy to learn / Hard to master
🔲 Difficult
🔲 Dark Souls

GRIND
🔲 Nothing to grind
✅ Isn't necessary to progress
🔲 Average grind level
🔲 A lot of grind
🔲 Too much grind

The grind will depend on what difficulty you're playing. The side quests were generally enjoyable and didn't feel like filler to me. You will need to complete these if you want the best ending though. Gathering chest items for your build will be grindy at least until guides are out showing the location of every item.

GAME TIME / REPLAYABILITY
🔲 Long enough for a cup of coffee
🔲 Short
✅ Average
✅ Long (Completionist)
🔲 To infinity and beyond

The game has a lot of replayability on the gameplay side being able to pick between three very distinct classes which all have tons of build potential.

I could see the dialogue getting repetitive on future playthroughs.

There is also multiple endings to replay for.

GRAPHICS
🔲 Low
🔲 Average
🔲 Good
✅ Beautiful
🔲 Reality 2.0

I was sceptical about the art style before release but upon playing I love it. There are a few characters that look a bit off to me but I got used to it as time went on. Runs really well on max raytracing & ultra settings and looks gorgeous.

AUDIO
🔲 Earrape
🔲 Bad
✅ Not too bad
🔲 Good
🔲 Eargasm

The music is one of my major problems with this game. I like the music, but it doesn't feel like Dragon Age. A lot of it sounds more like something you'd hear in Mass Effect. They should've asked Trevor Morris to come back as the music from  Inquisition was perfect. The best part of this games soundtrack is when Lost Elf (from Inquisition) plays.

AUDIENCE
🔲 Kids
✅ Teens
✅ Adults
🔲 Everyone

The game has a less mature feel to it than previous Dragon Age games but I wouldn't call it a "kid's game" or "disney product" like a lot of people have been saying.

PC REQUIREMENTS
🔲 Potato
🔲 Decent
✅ Fast 
🔲 Rich boi
🔲 NASA

PRICE
🔲 It's free!
🔲 Not recommended
✅ Wait for sale
✅ Worth the price
🔲 Best investment ever done

If you're only going to play the game once and not 100% it, wait for a sale.

If you're a completionist or will play multiple times it's worth full price.

BUGS / CRASHES
🔲 None that I can recount
✅ Minor bugs
🔲 Infrequent crashes
🔲 Frequent crashes
🔲 Complete mess

Before the recent GeForce Driver update, I had no crashes or bugs at all. Since then I've had three crashes over 30-35 hours. The game auto saves frequently enough that it was barely an inconvenience.

MISC
🔲 Steam Workshop
✅ Steam Trading Cards
✅ Steam Achievements
✅ Content for Steam Points Shop

VERDICT
✅ Recommended
🔲 Not recommended

author: {'steamid': '76561198066969293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 15431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 229, 'playtime_at_review': 14118, 'last_played': 1735930973}
review:
235 hours update: I'm in my second run, enjoying every part of this game and planning at least another run still this year. The game is good, the story concludes what we've been hearing since origins. If you feel left out, I recommend going back to origins and playing close attention to Flemmeth's story and the codexes.

Disclosure: I've loved each Dragon Age despite and because of their differences between each other. This series has brought me so much happiness and I could not wait for Veilguard's release.

This game has a different pace than all other DAs, the game keeps you moving! The combat is so much more dynamic and it's really fun. You can choose to play just with your own abilities or to open the ability wheel to direct your companions and do combos with them.
Game difficulty is very customizable, HUD is customizable, the settings page is very detailed, worth the time to tailor the game to your preferences.

The maps are way more straightforward than before. If you're the type to rush to complete quests, you won't have much problem finding the place where the fight happens. However, exploration is still there for those that like to take their time to look in every nook and cranny, with useful rewards!
Quests are very action oriented, no collect 10 of anything. Collection can still happen, but only if you want to. Maps will tell you how much there's still to explore and collect.

Different than our Inquisitor in DAI, Rook knows how to use their hands when climbing, which makes exploration way less frustrating.

If you know the story, you're in for a treat. There's so much lore right away! It's very rewarding to get answers and to see familiar faces.
For those that will pick up this game as their first Dragon Age and want to know who is who and what is what, the codex is there to help but the companions will explain and expose the story for you, you won't feel left out.

The UI is so satisfying! Everything is so organized and neatly categorized. It identifies clearly when there's new stuff to look at and if you don't care for codexes and want to see the little indicator go away, there's a "mark all as read" option :)

I'm very happy with this game, can't wait to play more. Huge thanks to bioware for proving an experience that can entertain the players that gotta go fast and the ones that like to stop and look at every wall <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198020351592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1731967720}
review:
12hrs in. I'll update this later when I'm deeper, but for now... 3.5/5? TL;DR it's fun, but not memorable.

It's... a frustrating game. It feels like AAA game producers focus to get some elements perfect, while others they're happy to just check the box. Graphics? Lots of effort - the game is beautiful, I actually really like the slightly more stylized faces, the regions and backdrops are all beautifully imaginative and well realized. Dialogue and script? It's more checking a box. Great voice actors? Check, but it seems like no one proofread their scripts, and each line is weirdly taken out of context or re-edited so the emphasis is wrong. Everyone repeats proper nouns again and again and again in the same conversation. Realistic and immersive dialogue is so important to a modern game, but it seems like producers aren't interested in spending money to bring a voice cast together to actually run lines with each other or mocap. It's a shame, those little details and polished elements are what make a game great.

Then the script itself - again, it seems to have had interesting edges sanded down. It's... fine. Everyone is a little "I'm writing cool dialogue", Marvel-esque quips and asides. Some of that is fun, but EVERYONE is in on it. There's no straight man to play against, so rather than fun gallows humor it just feels like it lowers the stakes.

Overall, it's Mass Effect 2 only with swords and not quite as good. I'm enjoying it, but it's not an instant classic, and it's probably only getting one playthrough. I'm not going to feel the sudden empty sadness I felt finishing BG3 that I wasn't going to get to spend more time with these characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071615770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 295, 'last_played': 1731789752}
review: Longtime Dragon Age fan, been playing since Origins originally came out. Game runs well, no issues with crashing at mix of Ultra/High settings. Graphics are absolutely gorgeous -- the lighting, environments, effects are all great to look at. Combat definitely falls more on the action RPG side of things, but feels weighty and impactful. Enjoying the voice acting so far with the male British Rook. Will update regarding the writing and story, but the premise so far has captured my attention. Nice return to the rich lore of the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040913306', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4467, 'last_played': 1731567041}
review:
I recommend this game for any DA player, but only to get closure to Inquisition's open end plot-line.

There were great moments, but the "magic" of Bioware is gone and I am left feeling hollow and sad about the decisions that were made regarding it's development (and also regarding the loss of the writers/devs that made Dragon Age what it was). 

Solas, and every interaction with him (up until the very end, as a Solasmancer from Inquisition) was fantastic and I wanted more of it. 
By comparison, the romance/bonding aspect of all Rook's companions felt very lackluster, when it was like 20+ hours before the romance started happening. Not to mention a lot of the interactions felt "same-sy"; there were hardly any conflicts and those that happened were quickly resolved; between Rook and their companions, between the companions themselves, and between the cast and the world around them.

The combat system was fun, though the 3-person team felt very strange, especially when I realized I never needed to have a warrior-mage-rogue team anymore, and unlocking chests, traps, and doors is no longer a thing.
 
The style and design of the game (especially the environments) is drop-dead gorgeous, but the music is a hit-or-miss and sometimes feels very out of place; sci-fi/vaporware while travelling around in Arlathan forest.

Overall, this game barely felt like Dragon Age, and the story feels like a soft reboot for future games of this series. I'm not sure how I feel about that, but it's not good.

Get the game when its on sale; it's at least worth that much.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997831982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1732202652}
review:
I have played all the dragon age games, my favourite being origins. I have read a lot about this game and the plan for the story, so I came prepared. I think if I hadn't, then the story would have annoyed me more. I can understand that the DA universe is almost too large at this point, with so many different outcomes, that it is challenging to create a story that ties every single knot together. With that in mind I think the story is fine so far. The graphics are good and the game runs well. Not a massive fan of the music, and the writing is a bit cringe 40% of the time (giving me light andromeda vibes sometimes...). The combat is alright - a little too "consolly" for my taste sometimes but I suppose it is a preference. The character creation is pretty good, but the qunari looks very goofy, and the characters arms look way too long, especially on the qunari... Origins will always be my favourite game in the series and probably always will be. It seems that a genre have died and been replaced by whatever you would call this.
But all in all I like it so far and would recommend it still.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094691035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 521, 'last_played': 1735491282}
review:
If you like Mass Effect, you're probably going to like Veilguard.

Every Dragon Age game mixes up the gameplay formula and admittedly Veilguard is the game that deviates the most from the rest of the game. If you're looking for origins style tactics, you're not going to find it here. As someone who never really engaged much with the more tactical aspects of Dragon Age, I don't mind that. I never switched to controlling other party members and just focused on blasting the bad guys, it's not a feature I miss. 

To describe the combat I'd say it is as a mix of Jade Empire and Mass Effect. Lot of focus on dodging and attacking and timing, very modern style console gameplay. I'd even throw in a comparison to 2018's God of War because it does feel similar to that at times but it's not quite that either. You control your companions in combat like you do in Mass Effect, meaning you don't actually control them but can activate their abilities and the introduction of the combo system is pretty fun when you manage to pull it off.

The level design is also very reminiscent of Mass Effect. You have well designed mission levels with some combat arenas thrown in and then you return to your central hub to talk to your companions and touch base after story beats.

As for the writing, it feels like Dragon Age. Specifically it reminds me most of Dragon Age 2 but that's my favorite Dragon Age game so I don't mind that. Very quippy, a lot of banter, and I can play a purple Rook so it's all good in my book. Still meeting all the companions so far but all the ones I have met are great and I'm excited to meet the rest!

I will admit I am a little disappointed that past game choices don't matter as much but after getting my hands on the game, I understand why that is. I will say that the game has a lot of call backs to books and comics that have been released over the ten years since Inquisition came out so sometimes characters will pop up like they're kinda expecting you to know who they are and that's why you can get a cameo feel on some side characters when first meeting them. It feels a little strange if you didn't engage with all the supplementary dragon age media but its a fun nod for all the people who do know them. 

For people comparing it to Baldur's Gate 3, you have to remember that despite being rpg games, they're doing different things. Dragon Age is about being a hero and saving the world so while you can be a d*ck, you can't be evil. The game just isn't meant for an evil player the same way you can't play Mass Effect and expect to be able to side with Cerberus or the Reapers. If you're looking for something like Baldur's Gate 3 that lets you be a d*ck AND evil if you want to be, I'd suggest going to check out Owlcat's Rogue Trader. It's space fantasy but in gameplay and story, I'd say it's closer to Baldur's Gate 3 than Veilguard or any Dragon Age game is. Baldur's Gate 3 and Dragon Age/Veilguard are different games and as someone who loves both, I think they deserve to be evaluated on their own merits as they are different games trying to do different things.

Overall, I would recommend this game if you're a big fan of Dragon Age and are willing to engage with the game for what it is, an action focused rpg where you get to play an underdog hero against impossible odds doing their best to save the world. If you still have some reservations, maybe wait until it's on sale in a few months to try it or take a look at some of the other crpgs that exist that can offer the sort of tactical gameplay or story telling approach that you're looking for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029080528', 'num_games_owned': 578, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 4252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1731366398}
review:
If u are experiencing high CPU temps despite having a good WC, its the game fault. I fixed with this tutorial:

[olist]
   [*] Open Control Panel and locate Power Options. You can use search bar to find it.
   [*]  Click on “Create a power plan”, name it, click on “Next” and then “Create”.
   [*]    Click on “Change plan settings” and locate the “Chance advance power settings” option.
   [*]   Find “PCI Express” and then look for “Link State Power Management”. Choose “Moderate power savings”.
     [*] Locate “Processor Power Management” and set the minimum processor state to 80%, while adjusting the maximum to 90%. You can gradually increase these values, but only if your PC can handle it.
     [*] Save your new power plan by clicking on “Apply” and then “OK”.
[/olist]

This power plan should reduce your CPU usage while playing Dragon Age The Veilguard. Just remember to switch back to your usual settings for other stuff. While these settings may slightly impact your frame rate, it's a worthwhile trade-off to protect your hardware. You can also try closing background apps and overlays to help your CPU out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977608196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 7350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1734068638}
review:
It's fast, it's fun.

Or, okay, fine: it's what the series was pushing toward with each successive release, which means that unlike DA2 and DAI (which I both loved), it's actually a coherent game that isn't begrudgingly making token efforts to appease people who still pine for Baldur's Gate. It is instead a fun swords and conversation game, in much the same way the Mass Effects were guns and conversation games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981443799', 'num_games_owned': 3095, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1070, 'last_played': 1732945747}
review:
As a long term Dragon Age fan, I loved the hit the ground running experience. The faster, action oriented gameplay was a little offputting at first but it quickly became some of the most fun I've had with the series to date. The seemingly simplistic gameplay hides a very in depth equipment system with a huge skill tree, tons of stuff to do and explore and the character based storytelling that makes Bioware games of huge interest to me. 

Claims of preachy dialogue and "wokeness" vanish into the ether as you actually play this game and get to know the story. I'm not prepared for where this is going but I am glad it exists.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007322339', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1730887897}
review:
8/10 

Yes the art style is different. 

Yes the combat is based around light/heavy/abilities plus companion abilities. (God of War combat is literally simpler than Dragon Age for context).

No crashes with my rig and 4080. 

People are really digging to say this game is terrible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038980497', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3889, 'last_played': 1731883522}
review:
As a long time Dragon Age fan I can say that I do enjoy the game. But does it do justice to the series as a long awaited sequel? Not really. Though reading Tevinter Nights beforehand lead to some nice surprises.

The graphics look very good, even though the overall style needs some getting used to. 
The combat is fun, but the companions sadly feel rather redundant. 
I find the story and new lore enjoyable, yet the dialogues are for the most part underwhelming. The setting and characters are interesting, the voice actors do a fine job but the writing doesn't manage to tie everything together which leads to a weird mix of dark fantasy themes on one side and lighthearted, comically adventure on the other with neither being very well executed. It's rather irritating how in a lot of serious or dire situations the characters just keep smiling happily and throw around one liners, making everything feel less authentic.

The overall structure and flow of quests and mechanics have improved from the previous game and are more similar to Mass Effect. I just wish they had kept some things like "do companions quests" or "you have to make choices btw" to some tutorial boxes instead of having characters overexplain these things, leading to rather awkward conversations.

Everything considered Veilguard is not brilliant but it's not terrible either. If like me you get most of an RPGs enjoyment out of the characters and dialogues this game might be a bit more on the disappointing end though.  It's still worth a try, both for new players and fans.

Edit after finishing: The finale of the game was very well made. Personally I wasn't emotionally invested enough to fully enjoy it, but it definitely made the whole journey before worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044223358', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1731382290}
review:
Early Impressions from a DA fan who did not follow the development of DAV:

The good - 
 - The game is very well optimized for an EA game. No EA launcher, game runs very smoothly, and I have yet to encounter any bugs of any kind.
 - Combat feels really good, especially on Nightmare.
 - Character creator is robust enough you can make pretty much any character you want.
 - The story so far is good enough to want to keep going.

The bad - 
 - It feels like they were trying to achieve the quippy comedy style of the MCU Avengers and it falls flat 90% of the time. 
 - There doesn't feel like there is a lot of real choice in dialogue. Everything says something slightly different, but ultimately ends up the exact same regardless of what you do. It feels kind of empty.
 - The game feels way to streamlined compared to previous installments. 

As of now, I think it's a game worth playing, but it suffers from having DA in the title. As a standalone ARPG I think it holds its own fairly well, but the fact it is a flagship game in the DA series makes it feel off. It's a well optimized game and I'm having fun with it, but we will see how I feel in another 20-30 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997129999', 'num_games_owned': 703, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1732272000}
review:
So far it's been great. 
Only the occasional weirdness in conversation, wooden facial expressions and odd pacing, but its rare enough to simply brush it aside and keep playing. 
But the performance is good, graphics are amazing albeit stylized, companions are interesting, combat is flashy and fun! And the character creator is one of the better ones, my Rook looks amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010440960', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4397, 'last_played': 1734227042}
review:
[h1]An (I think) Spoiler Free Review![/h1]

As someone who has played all of the Dragon Age games (including their DLCs), watched the movie, TV show, machinimas, etc. Read the books, the comics, the anthologies and novels, and the Dragon Age Day short stories, and overall is just a big Dragon Age and Bioware nerd, I can wholly say I do believe DATV is a wonderful, beautiful game that strives to honour its universe and almost entirely pulls it off. Review below is off of one playthrough (around 70 hours).

[h3] The Good: [/h3]
- It's well written. The beginning can feel a bit weak but ultimately I was rather enraptured by it and my love for the universe pushed through anything. By the end of the first act, you will be entirely sucked in. This game is like a literary rolling ball of snow on a mountainside, it'll keep picking up snow and getting better and better. The point of no return and onwards is amazing.
- These are finally games that are not grueling mechanically. DAO, DAII and DAI have all, for lack of a better word, aged very badly in my opinion on the combat front and certainly show their age. It happens. This game's combat, movement, mechanics, etc. alongside a reworked talent tree system for player and companions are a breath of fresh air and help to keep something like the Great Hinterlands Slog from repeating itself as you chop your way to through the waves of side quests.
- Codex is incredibly expansive. Missive system is a wonderful way to show us extended show of what we done, and keep us posted on all the horrible things happening to the south. The new glossary system is great for new players.
- Speaking of new players, this is definitely designed in mind that with a 10 year break, to be able to introduce a new audience to Dragon Age. It is very easy to get in especially with the above systems, and (to the chagrin of older players, I'm sure,) the fact it is a whole new part of Thedas we've not really been in before where a majority of our decisions do not follow us (alongside the incredibly complexly evolving themes in Southern Thedas like the Circle of Magi and the ever-stoked conflicts of Mages and Templars), help to make it not as daunting in my opinion.
- The choices have good butterfly effects, and I found myself sitting there for a while (especially nearing the end) when you're quite literally balancing characters living and dying in your hands.
- Visually stunning. Probably the most beautiful game I've played in years. There is a reason games like WoW and Guild Wars outlast hyper-realism competitors, and the stylistic choices of Dragon Age (that have always been there, just now in High Resolution) are going to help this game keep its charm for a long time.
- Quite dark. It's Dragon Age after all! I've seen a lot of complaints that it's too lighthearted, that they've strangled the darkness from a grim IP, but I'm here to say that is definitely not the case. That darkness situates itself very early in D'Meta's Crossing, and especially in the end of Act 1. It only gets progressively darker, Dragon Age has not lost its edge, some of the darker political aspects are merely not present because we are in a very different political climate (that has its own issues, mind you).
- Solas is written as well as ever, Varric too. Inquisitor's OG voice actors return and do a fantastic job, alongside some other surprises!
- Companion stories were awesome, side quests were a lot better. Hurrah, the Hinterlands slog is dead! I think I only felt the weight of it once or twice (mostly because I was up way later than I should be), completing them was very incentivizing. My personal favourites were Bellara, Davrin and Harding. The others were great too, those were just standouts to me (sans Taash, who while I did enjoy and actually think had one of the best voice acted finale quests, I had a lot of issues with you can read about below).
- Map exploration is good, I 100%'d all zones (except Arlathan Forest... could not find that 11th chest for the life of me). I ended the codex around upper 80s percentage completion. There is a lot hidden, collectionists will enjoy it.

[h3] The Not-so-Good: [/h3]
- Yes, we lost a lot of choices, but in theory, the next game (fingers crossed) could pull from the previous three DA games and this new one if we return to the south. They do a pretty decent job at not making it feel bad, because we are so far away from Southern Thedas that a lot of those decisions wouldn't rubber band upwards. But I mean-- come on, no Well of Sorrows choice? That's a bit of a smack in the face. The added downside of this is because they don't want to invalidate those choices, they just avoid them. The most you'll get is small cameos.
- Above ties into an issue I have with this game: this game comes a few years too late. A few years ago, we were in the great nerd renaissance. D&D was becoming popular, people were getting hype about Baldur's Gate 3, etc. RPGs were becoming popular, but ultimately modified and watered down to suit a more mainstream audience. A lot of the role-playing in RPGs during this time lost its depth and detail. Dragon Age: The Veilguard delivers a wonderful game, but one that has somewhat watered itself down with its loss of carry over details and some narrative choices to suit a newer, broader playerbase. It ultimately comes in a time of people now deciding they are, actually, okay with heavy and lengthy RPGs like the original 3.
- Some of the scenes felt out of place, or sometimes awkwardly transposed. Dragon Age has always been 80s action movie adjacent so I didn't mind the modern speak too much, because it knew when to reel itself in. However, I did find some of Taash's insistent joking (and rebound to joking after a certain important narrative in their story happens) to be a let down. Taash's story is a very mixed bag for me, one I feel is... not amazing. Their voice actor absolutely kills it in their final companion quest and turned me around from hating it, but I found the message they were sending with their story to be well-intentioned, but ultimately clunky and almost preachy at times. I felt this especially in [spoiler] a choice you can make to tell them only to accept Rivani culture, or Qunari culture, sending a message to the player that someone who struggles to identify in their native culture and their lived culture is impossible, and you must just simply choose. For a story that puts so much effort into the gender struggle of Taash, it entirely fell flat (and offensive at times) in how they decided to tell Taash's struggle with cultural/ethnic identity. I didn't really want to choose and felt uncomfortable that Rook was the one to basically decide their identity in a player choice, instead of THEM shaping it. And this happens TWICE! Ugh. [/spoiler]

[h3] The Meh: [/h3]
- Music is good, but ultimately Hans Zimmer is no Trevor Morris (or even Inon Zur). The music is great, but where I would sit and sometimes just let DA play in the background for ambient zone musics, or find myself distracted by the BGM of an important scene previously, I did not find Zimmer managing to capture me in the same way that Morris and Zur did.
- My romance (Lucanis) felt lackluster, and sometimes even ill-timed. I enjoy what we got, but we did not get enough of it. The game could have easily added in at least two to three more companion scenes for romance, and I could say when too. The final companion intimacy scene also felt out of place. [spoiler] Nobody wants to freak it and giggle right after someone dies, seriously! [/spoiler]

[h2] Overall: [/h2]
100% my GOTY, and I see myself playing again and again. The good outweighs the bad here, and I loved it. Anyone claiming the writing is intolerably bad, that the game is all 'woke', or its not dark enough anymore hasn't finished the game, quite literally ever played a DA game before, or is just attention baiting. It's good, especially for 10 years of developmental hell.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054681740', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6544, 'last_played': 1731548767}
review:
Hi everyone,

this is my review about what i think of the game after 85 hours save with a rogue class. not here to have a discussion about what is right or wrong. didn't receive this for free or anything like that. just trying to provide my opinion about my experience.

the game is like a 8/10 for me. nothing exceptional or revolutionary to this genre compared to the past dragon age games.

what i think its positive about this game:
1 - The combat is pretty nice and fluid, weak spot mechanics for rogue works pretty well with bow.
2 - The choices the game provide and the difference between then. the impact of some choices actually matter for some choices during the game (if we have a new game in future and chance to import the save, they will matter even more)
3 - The plot and the quests/side quests are pretty good.
4 - The upgrade progression for the equipment is works well for the way they designed
5 - The skills works fine for 3 buttons (it will have negative about it as well) but for 3 skills setups isn't bad

the negative part about it:
1 - The game miss most RPG elements from the past games like a more group setup like a proper healer, a proper tank and some specifications for DPS.
2 - I really missed 4 members groups, its related about the missing more RPG mentioned on the first topic.
3 - Playing with only 1 automatic skill being used its not that fun, having more automatics skill or if I'm able to choose which ability i want to be automatic like the heal from Bellara or the Taunt from Davrin. would be nice if they can have at least the 3 abilities being used automatic.
4 - The companions have more gears slot and equipment, most of then are focused on detonation combos like this is a must happen mechanics. more skill related to their skills would be nice and better. we have so much gear on main characters and almost nothing to then. using ring and neck could be good.
5 - I missed in Inquisition and miss here too, the lack of the tactics we had on Origin. I know its an action game and not a tactical one like before but would be nice if we could have that option as well.

most of my complains about the game is related to the group and companions because that could be improved a lot to be honest, i really don't feel playing a RPG game like used to be because everyone kind have heal. only difference is the taunt but anything else its just action. the tactical like used to be wont be easy to anyone but the RPG elements of the game is kind important. not everyone should be able to do everything.

but this is a great game in general, please if you don't like the non binary thing you can ignore because its EA but they did a good job with this game this time. its ok for you to learn a bit more about it if you don't know, but if you don't like its ok too... don't let that ruin your experience with the game. so many good dialogues, a nice story telling game, good combat, amazing companions for you to know about it.

wait for a discount if you don't think its worth right now but the game is good. its an amazing RPG. its not a Baldur's gate 3 (nothing will be so soon) but deserve to be played as well

thanks if you read until here and this is just my opinion. have a good day

author: {'steamid': '76561198049370587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1493, 'last_played': 1731334013}
review:
The Veilguard is living proof that redemption stories do happen even with AAA studios that have seemingly long been bled dry by their corporate overlords. It's a very lively and modern Action Adventure game with light RPG elements that takes some of the best parts from its predecessors but is also brave enough to step out of their shadows.

The Veilguard has a very earnest atmosphere of a proper adventure supported by amazing visuals both in its various locations and the main cast you travel with. Some might say that the game feels too light and lacks conflict, and it's true may be less outwardly dark than some of its predecessors, but there are still plenty of grim and sombre stories to uncover as you play. Besides, it does pick up on some grimness in the second half if you're into that.

As for the characters, I found that cast to be pretty great — every character fills a certain pretty transparent archetype but all of them also have their demons and secrets that take time to discover, and this progression feels pretty natural for the most part. I will concede that dialogue takes a bit of a backseat in this one since the game is generally more streamlined and you get significantly fewer properly sprawling dialogue trees, but it works well with the kind of game that this is, and I don't find it to be a problem at all thought it might not be to everyone's taste.

The combat system is up there with Bioware's best attempts in the Mass Effect series, and it's certainly by far the best one we've seen so far in Dragon Age. It's simple on the surface, and if you play on standard difficulty or below you may not feel the need to engage with it beyond what you're given in the initial tutorials. But if you're having fun like I did, it's pretty cool to try out different skills, equipment, ability combos with your party, etc. It feels great, it looks great, it can be pretty chaotic but ultimately very satisfying.

I also enjoyed the light metroidvania touches in this one, running around unlocking new rooms and chests probably took me as much time as everything else, some of the puzzles are pretty fun, and I was relieved to find out that I didn't have to frantically switch out party members to unlock certain character-specific puzzle elements.

As is tradition for Bioware games, it's pretty great when it comes to accessiblity and inclusivity. You see lots of accessibility options right as you launch the game, and I can't be 100% sure but it seems to be pretty comprehensive. As for inclusivity, the game gives you plenty of options regarding your character's customization allowing to make them more like you if you're good at character editors (I'm hopeless with them), and you can customize your pronouns and gender as you like including changing them in the game as you go. The cast of characters is also pretty diverse, and all the inclusive touches feel very natural — one of the first characters you meet has a prosthetic foot and it doesn't stop her from being battle-capable and just generally cool at all.

Finally, and this might be surprisng for an AAA release in 2024, The Veilguard is also virtually bug-free and runs pretty smoothly right out of the gate, with lots of options to tweak to make sure you get a smooth experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201967494', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 13770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2318, 'last_played': 1733268110}
review:
I wanted to try and play through a good amount of the game before reviewing, but there is a lot of side content and I got horribly distracted so I'm only around a quarter through act 2. 

Good: 
Combat: Feels fun and fluid, I'm playing a spellblade and the move between ranged staff/orb to melee with orb and dagger feels great. The fights themselves are engaging, though definitely if action combat is something you're used to, they may not pose a high challenge on the normal difficulties (I went for nightmare, and I'm feeling it, but perhaps explorer would feel a little cut-and-dry.)

Overall lore/factions: each faction has a lot of history to find and learn, plenty of side quests, pretty high stakes. It's a very much fleshed out version of the way factions were sort of handled in DAI, and I appreciate that. The faction you choose at the start is fairly meaningful, when talking to those of that faction, you'll often have different voice lines from them and for you to choose. 
The lore itself is honestly very interesting! It fleshes out a lot of concepts we've always known in the DA universe with more information and explains some of the things DAI and 2 brought into question concerning the nature of the gods in Thedas. 
Romances: as always with DA, the romances are at least 1/4 of the active braincell of these games. Each seems impactful and diverse, and the characters are charming and have their own ways of showing care and overall affection. The story quests surrounding companions are also really enjoyable, and I highly recommend taking the time to do each rather than rushing the main story, as they really flesh out the story as well as the individuals. The banter is also brilliant, and vastly improves in timing and quality from DAI.

Cons: 
Overall Dialogue: this isn't really a slight on everything, the dialogue vastly improves in the game and really it's only the opening that feels overly 'dragging this player through the lore so we don't have to explain it later'. There are occasional lines that come off as cheesy or flat but previous installments of DA all had that issue on occasion as well and it honestly doesn't happen very often after the first few quests in act 1. 

Romances/companions(again): this is in both, partially because 1, I wish there were a system like the dial for rook that shows group affinity with eachother, as Romances between characters can happen and it would be nice to be able to know where they're at. 2, I wish there was a little more to the romances once established. It really doesn't need to be much more, but you can't often casually converse and typically need to wait for scripted moments. The scripted moments are great, but there is less of the casual interaction that previous installments have. 
Pacing: it's not a big thing, and it's definitely remedied by side quests which feels like it was probably meant to be, but the pacing is at times rushed. Act 2 has been better, but all of act 1 feels like we're going waaay too fast into each situation. It adds to the importance of everything yes and like I said can be remedied with side quests/puzzles/factions, but if you are not doing so, it also feels like the game wants you out of act 1 as quickly as humanly possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150867979', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2099, 'last_played': 1731541786}
review:
Haven't finished the game yet but am overall enjoying it despite some issues I have with it. 

The story is very good and those saying it is not as dark as previous games I feel like are missing something. Yes, it has its lightheartedness, as did previous games, but there are definitely sections of the game where the narrative and consequences on your team are quite severe. It definitely gets better as the game progresses as well.

Dialogue can be a bit iffy and cringe at times, but this isn't anything different than previous games. I do feel like some of the voice acting is a bit stiff at times and it does suck that while the game has insane graphics, the lipsync is off at times as well.

Combat is a departure from previous games but given the way combat has been evolving over the past three, it makes sense. It feels like combat from Dragon Age 2 but a lot more nuanced. I do miss having a lot more abilities to use, but it is fun to switch around my loadout and see what combos I can do with my companions. Even on a lower difficulty, it still feels challenging and you still need to think about what you're doing in regards to barriers, armour, and shields.

Exploration feels as if its been cut back from Inquisition, which is somewhat welcome. Inquisition had a lot of areas which felt empty and a lot of the sidequests were simple fetch quests. Side quests in Veilguard feel impactful to the narrative, but I do with the areas were a bit more open. Main missions are quite linear but this is fine in contrast with the explorative side elsewhere.

My biggest issue is the companions. Previous games have let you speak to your crew whenever, ask them questions about themselves and their backgrounds. You go up to them every now and again and they have new things you can talk to them about. In Veilguard, you can only directly engage with companions when the game tells you that you can. Your options for dialogue and questioning can be quite limited. You do occasionally get a voiceline here or there when you walk past them but it's nothing to engage with. This has severely impacted how long it's taken me to feel connected to the companions, and for a game that changed its name from Dread Wolf to Veilguard because they were so proud of your team... it feels off. 

It's a good game, the story is enjoyable, but it's not without fault as with any game ever made. Considering some of Bioware's recent games... This is a huge step up. Is it Game of the Year? Probably not, but overall the pros outweigh the cons for me and *I'm* having fun, and that's what matters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146110292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5953, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5953, 'last_played': 1731328974}
review:
I decided to write this review because I feel like this game gets an undeserved amount of hate. And it's certainly not great, but I've spent about 50 hours with it and I can say it's been a fun time.

8/10 as an action RPG
4/10 as a Dragon Age
2/10 as an Inquisition sequel

First, the good stuff:
1. The game runs well and looks great. The locations are varied and very beautiful, the character editor allows you to create a great character without resorting to mods. The game is visually pleasing to be in. The Necropolis, Arlathan are such magical unique places, and Minrathous brings back memories of Kirkwall.

2. The game really follows gameplay trends and has adopted best practices. Everything is designed for the player and creates a smooth gameplay experience that is comfortable to be in. 

3. The combat system is finally no longer so static and players are given the opportunity to dynamically participate in combat, I think it has benefited the game. The combat system is friendly to both beginners and allows for various build options for more experienced players.

Now about the bad:
The entire writing part of the game is VERY weak. And when I say WEAK, it doesn't mean that everything is terrible, everything is... uneven. There are good parts, there are not so good parts, there are frankly bad parts. And as everyone knows, writing is the skeleton on which the game is built, and here it cannot withstand the weight of it.

1. The entire narrative is built on the fact that we are the Hero and the Savior from the very first second of the game - no one asks us questions (even though the story we tell the world is frankly insane, and we ourselves are unknown to the world and have no authority), the world exists around us and the opportunity to give us a quest, and then praise us for completing it. We are not led to decisions, we are presented with facts. Many things are not explained at all, there are just gaps in the storylines.

2. Most of our companions have the character depth of a teaspoon. They are written lazily, shallowly, stereotypically and practically devoid of ideas. Okay, I apologize professor Emmerich, you are a great guy. In the end, instead of the unique characters we had in the previous games, here we just have a bunch of fun color-coded guys.

3. I got my suspicions when at the beginning of the game I was not being asked to connect my Keep - and my suspicions were justified. This game absolutely despises the entire previous series. Yes, we are given minor fanservice, mentioning characters we knew or events we participated in, but it all feels more like fairy tales from another reality. Veilgard is disconnected from the DA, disrespectful to the history of the series, dismissive of the lore. A lot of the threads that have been running through the series since the first game are just lost, others are handled poorly (remember, bad writing). This is the most annoying and frustrating part. I could live with a game with an uneven plot that takes 20 hours to get going and boring companions, but it shouldn't have been called Dragon Age. I rarely agree with "fans of the series", but in this case, I absolutely agree with the general consensus. Veilgard leaves the previous games like scorched earth.

And just fun details:
1. The new elf body models are ugly. Elves have always had this unique silhouette that gave them a regal look. Here they look like they're about to try to sell you turnips.

2. If you're going to use recurring characters that played important roles in previous games, treat them with respect. I was expecting Dorian to be some professor type character, but what we got was an uncle with a drinking problem who embarrasses everyone at family gatherings and looks terrible. I hope someone comes up with a mod to fix this, it was the first thing that really pissed me off about this game.

3. The first game in the series where I didn't develop a single romantic relationship. The only character that appeals to me looks about my father's age. Really?

4. Why did the Inquisitor come to the fight in pajamas and look like a nameless NPC in the finale?

To sum it up, I'm leaving this game a positive review because I'm having fun with it and it's mechanically enjoyable to play. But my level of annoyance and disappointment with the writing leaves me in a terrible state of mind thinking about how this game could have shined, but now that opportunity is gone forever and there's nothing I can do to change it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005400406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1054, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1730698123}
review:
As much as I would love to experience this trilogy, EA insists on making that as difficult as possible for no reason. Last year, the game was updated to use the EA app instead of Origin. No big deal, right? Wrong. This integration was poorly thought and haphazardly slapped together. Not only are you not able to earn achievements in ME2 or 3, but the app itself refuses to launch unless it can talk to EA's servers. If you're online when you start and then lose connection, you're fine, but if you have no connection to start with, your fully single player game that doesn't even include ME3's multiplayer will refuse to launch.

EA has never addressed this, but they have patched numerous workarounds the community has used to get around their stupid app. Absolutely ridiculous. I should not have to be online to play a single player RPG. I bough this collection specifically to play on the Steam Deck, and now I can't because of this nonsensical requirement. I feel ripped off.

author: {'steamid': '76561199042250142', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5658, 'last_played': 1713748459}
review: Love the game, but the EA launcher is terrible and I can't get it to work half the times I try to play. I wouldn't recommend any game that requires this busted launcher.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006109339', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 12016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1722260616}
review:
Arguably the greatest game trilogy ever. Unfortunately, tethered to EA online services. 
3 single player games that cannot be played offline. Big brain move.

Decided to make my review dynamic as i intend on playing through all 3 games. Will update after each game.

Mass Effect
Terrible inventory, sluggish combat and some piss funny, immersion breaking animations, cannot tarnish this ride. 
Near perfect characters, a rich, detailed history, vast world building, and a phenomenal soundtrack, drive this journey from it's slow burn start, to it's goosebumps inducing finale.

A deeply flawed game, delivering a nearly flawless experience. Outstanding.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972172045', 'num_games_owned': 530, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1717203735}
review: Great games but the EA login/DRM ruins this game for the steam deck. I can’t recommend a game that requires this kind of forced online connection on a portable gaming device. What a waste. EA continues to be the worst.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143430414', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 8078, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1455, 'last_played': 1722737469}
review:
It's a great game WHEN IT WORKS. Unfortunately, due to its connection with the EA app, there is a very good chance that when you want to play this game, it simply will not launch. 

If you've bought a game and own it, you shouldn't have to complete a voodoo ritual on your computer every day hoping that it will run. It's a single player only game. Why should I need your garbage app to run it. 

I'm Commander Shepard, and EA is the worst app on the Citadel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973260064', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1733, 'last_played': 1713320412}

author: {'steamid': '76561198014027119', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 11562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9339, 'last_played': 1708970980}

author: {'steamid': '76561198047349790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1695, 'last_played': 1724093915}
review:
This trilogy, in my opinion is one of the greatest game series ever made. But i can not on good concience recomend buying this while it requieres the crime against humanity that is the EA game launcher to run. 

First of all you can not run this SINGLEPLAYER game offline because it requieres that your EA account be conected to the internet. That would not be a big problem IF THE GAME WOULD ACTUALY RUN. I have not been able to start the game for three days now because when i click on the game all i see is the prepearing game loading window and after that nothing happens. I am tired of looking for solutions. I will not bother deleting and reinstalling a 110 GB game. All this bulshit because EA (a multi billion dollar company) cannot make a launcher that fucking works without bugs.  Oh and speaking of bugs they have not fixed any from the original trilogy so excpect the game to crash and doo all kinds of wierd stuff all the time

Fuck EA they ruin everything they tuch. Do not give them money untill they do better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016396106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 3096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1426, 'last_played': 1724288060}
review: Great game ruined by its worthless publisher. If you buy this game, or any other EA game for that matter, just be aware that you will have to use their proprietary launcher that requires you to be connected to the internet to play a singleplayer game, and there's like a 50% chance that the launcher will fail to connect to their servers, so you will be unable to play the game you paid for. Steam needs to just start telling these garbage publishers that if they want their game sold on Steam, it must be able to be launched from their launcher alone, end of story. If they can't program a game launcher that actually, you know, launches a game, they have no business forcing me to use it. But of course, if game publishers had to use Steam's launcher, that means they'd have to purchase all the data that's been mined from me from Valve instead of mining it themselves.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983888613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 784, 'last_played': 1715422361}

A PC Port held together by duct tape and elmers glue, with barely any options whatsoever, and requires EA's always online and always running in the background app that barely functions. All it managed to do is steal unnecessary information from the user.

On top of that, EA in recent years has fired most of their writers, artists, animators, and even some programmers and replaced them with AI. EA is truly one of the most evil companies out there. If you want to play this game, get a key for the original trilogy or otherwise. DO NOT GIVE EA YOUR MONEY.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995479609', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1713307487}

author: {'steamid': '76561198010681732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 1442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1009, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1723524133}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198027831904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1735116315}
review:
EA Background Service runs on your computer 24/7 with root access & elevated privileges, supposedly to improve the user experience by preloading patches & such. So you should ask yourself: Do you trust EA Games, purveyor of pay to win microtransactions, destroyer of great game studios, premature server shutdown specialists, with root access & elevated privileges on your computer? 

You should not trust them, EA Games has no soul & only exists to maximize profits. If you don't ask for or even authorize intrusive potentially predatory software, that software is malware. Spyware. Rogue. The fact that the EA Background Service installs without permission & runs 24/7 with no provision for turning it off or opting out means this is a drive-by installation, a hack. It should be illegal, if in fact it's not already illegal.

As to the Mass Effect games you get along with the spyware, they seem fine. The same as I remember. Frankly, without the spyware I think Mass Effect holds up pretty well.

But then there is that malware, the EA Background Service. It's a non-starter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062061679', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 685, 'last_played': 1719592399}

author: {'steamid': '76561198434935395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1719865070}
review: Never bought an EA game before and refused to believe the bad stories about the way they treated customers.  Saw this on sale and bought it. Created an EA account and installed the game.  Played it for about forty minutes and then went to bed.  Woke the next morning to an email saying that I had been banned for violations of either their purchase agreement or their TOS. Appealed and was never given the reason for the ban and was told it would stand. Refunded the game. The stories are true and EA is trash. I consider this an easy lesson learned and I regret spending any money on this company.

author: {'steamid': '76561199384395060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1723320360}
review: The Mass Effect trilogy is phenomenal. But I wouldn't recommend buying this version or the individual games here, because Steam requires you to use EA's crappy app just to play them.  If you legally own these games [I bought them for PS4 last year], I would recommend downloading the original releases from Fitgirl instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040633137', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1710013047}
review: Amazing series but the official release of this colleciton is terrible, you have to use the trash EA launcher and it has a 50% chance of just not launching the game when you launch it, and also messes with performance. Play this series but get it from fitgirl repacks and not here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002094068', 'num_games_owned': 492, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 900, 'last_played': 1736210813}
review:
Absolutely wonderful series of games that EA has decided to brick.  It now requires the EA app which refuses to function properly and loses link to your Steam account. When it does, you won't be allowed to play anymore (on launch, every launch: "Oops, something went wrong! Go back and try again!" [there is no back button, nor any other buttons]). This has been a known "High priority" issue for 3 years (per the dates on EA's support forum) and they haven't bothered to do one single thing about it in that time. The only potential fix requires you to *manually edit your fucking Registry*, and even that doesn't always work.

Yay, DRM that prevents people from playing the game instead of doing anything about piracy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013546574', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1077, 'last_played': 1722109418}

author: {'steamid': '76561198036171902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 12429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6219, 'last_played': 1734400390}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995859488', 'num_games_owned': 516, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1720567913}
review:
I'm Commander Shepard, and this is my favorite game on the Citadel. Likely, you have played these games before. This edition makes everything prettier and even makes the first game a *little* easier to slog through. If you have not played these games, look up another review. I'm not gonna explain why it's one of the best series ever made. If you like BioWare games, dig it. If you like Sci-Fi, dig it. If you like punching reporters in the face, dig it.

However, do NOT dig the PC version of this. Everything about it is perfect except the EA App/Origin/whatever launcher. It is a horrible piece of software that has no business existing. It has problems running, it creates problems with your game launching, and it needs to be connected to the internet to work.

What is it doing? Checking your license? I mean, Steam can do that. So I wonder what else...

Anyway. Fuck EA and their launcher, but this game is amazing. If you have access to a console, I'd pick it up there. No crappy launcher to deal with and still looks and plays fantastic.

Or if you're savvy, there's always the Bay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010382025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3161, 'last_played': 1719701776}

author: {'steamid': '76561199348901165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1735266601}
review: Has anyone read EA's EULA and privacy policy...? It's criminal what they give themselves rights and access to.  Send this game to GOG or some other completely offline platform (being a single player, offline game)... then a "license" to play THEIR game will be worth $5.  Origin launcher and internet access required, or this single player offline game won't run.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969782921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1733096863}
review:
Leaving aside the unnecessary presence of the EA App (formerly Origin) and its required login, the sound mixing is broken in Mass Effect 1 - gunshots are incredibly loud, while non-conversation dialogue is often incredibly quiet. There are only three audio sliders, so turning down the sound effects slider to reduce the gunshot sound results in all other sound effects becoming too quiet to hear.
Apparently, this issue has been around since the Legendary Edition was launched, and has never been fixed. I have been unable to find any manual fix or mod. Given that this is supposed to be a definitive version of the trilogy, this flaw is inexcusable and sours the entire experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967471651', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 8653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3196, 'last_played': 1713184360}
review:
Really great games, but the EA App launcher is just horrible. It's slow, unreliable, and conflicts with the Steam overlay at the best of times. At the worst of times it makes it simply impossible to launch the game.

Without the EA App Launcher I'd highly recommend this collection to anybody and everybody. With the EA Launcher, this is probably only worth it for die-hard fans of the series. It's just extremely unpleasant dealing with EA's launcher.

author: {'steamid': '76561199790804418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1733585125}

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198333615559', 'num_games_owned': 37, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2023, 'last_played': 1722557171}
review:
I wish I could give this a good rating but I can't. Not because the games are not good, they're stellar. No, it's all because of EA's dogshit client that does not let you play the goddamn game.

Every time I wanted to play this I had to open and close the client brought up by EA because it just would not start the game, I have to repeat this process around 10 times before I can even get into the game. While playing I have no problems because the game itself was developed by competent people, it's the goddamn client that makes the experience unbearable and I can't recommend it because of this.

 If this was purely on Steam it would be a good rating of maybe an 8-9/10 but the client makes the experience far too frustrating to recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074570924', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1728994176}
review:
The game is excellent. One of the best narratives in the entire Sci-Fi, not just in gaming but in the entire genre. Very good gameplay, great combat, your decisions actually have an impact on the story longterm, etc, etc.

(Nevermind the 6 hours of playtime, I have fully completed MELE before, on a different platform)

The graphics might be a bit outdated, especially in ME1, but you'll get used to it soon.

Easily in the top-3 of the games I love.

I am leaving a negative review, though, because of the utter idiocy with the EA launcher needed (for no sane reason) to launch the game. This stupid adware is an overhead even on PC. On Steam Deck, you need to follow a specific guide, actually two of them (google it), to get rid of the idiotic "launcher" completely in order to make the game reliably work.

Gosh, the corpoRATe greediness of EA has caused so much pain to the Mass Effect franchise, it's hard to even tell where to start. Won't change my review until the adware launcher is completely gone.
