author: {'steamid': '76561198061795684', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 13008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13008, 'last_played': 1729996580}
review:
[i]Detailed and extensive review. Playing Mass Effect since 2007[/i]

[h1]Quick resume[/h1]

I have never seen a launcher like this one.

"The Halo Collection" for example, lets you install any game of the list separatedly. ME:LE launcher actually forces installation of all the three games and DLC at the same time, weighing up to 110 gigabytes. There is no option to exit one of its three games straight to the OS neither, it is all very impractical. The launcher frequently behaves in an odd way, but its the "EA app" the real cause; slow, unresponsive, I had to turn off overlays. Sometimes after clicking "play" on Steam nothing even happened.

A remaster is not about rebuilding, but it should be an opportunity to adjust old things. Sadly, there are too many backsteps here to call it even. From ancient bugs and crashes, to animation and AI, gameplay issues either continues or worsened, negligence from the developers is everywhere. Honesty is my witness, there is nothing in this remaster that justifies the price since 2021. Even voiced translations never had that much effort, PT-BR and others were ignored.

The main benefit of this remaster may only be to reunite DLC material and ease old incompatibilities for newer systems, it's easier now to just install and play Mass Effect already. But none of that matters if decades old bugs or incompetent functionalities remains.

[h1]Mass Effect 1[/h1]

I love the game but I admit the gameplay has always been weird. Mako's painful exploration is prime example, but that was due limitations that they had. This only means ME1 needed more fixing than the others, but let's just say they didn't change enough screws, and it shows. And through the trilogy not only some old issues were ignored, some are now just worse.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3231562656&tscn=1714014744

[code]FIXED I GUESS[/code]

1- I guess graphics had some treatment

There's no ray-tracing or anything, but they did fix some bugs related to textures, including Garrus's low-res texture face bug. Added lightining, mesh models, even a real-time reflection and other FX and audible goodies. Problem is, it doesn't look like they adjusted it much. Uncharted worlds still looks like a pile of useless polygons, now with better lighting and grass. The "Community Patch" mod is essential to finish Bioware's attempt.

2- General compatibility

Now you don't need to worry about Windows OS since the first game is very old already. Even Asteroid X57 DLC is already with the game, so that made things easier too. Mechanical issues like joystick, now you can use an actual control of your choice to play the game other than the keyboard.

3- Unit interface

I'm not sure I like it but its more consistent with the trilogy. They did little tweaks in certain guns like some rifles (there is no "thermal clip" available, only in the sequel) and other good additions I should mention includes new gameplay options in the menu. Photo mode has been inserted, but without a freer mod its nearly useless.

[code]IGNORED OR FIXED BADLY[/code]

It is a great thing to preserve the original games, but technical adjustments and fixing should've been part of that respect too.

1- Enemy AI for some reason has gotten worse.

They stuck and even phase through floors or walls like never before. I have seen that happening several times. Its the same with allies AI, constantly unresponsive, sometimes won't obey or save commands. They messed with something and never adjusted logics leftovers.

2- Mako can now boost, trying to ease uncharted worlds' pain, but ends up with a weirder driving when you use it. 

3- Whenever a bunch of Geth dies, you're still force-flooded with items.

4- [url=https://www.youtube.com/shorts/WqlUePGw4r4?feature=share]Click here to see[/url] Jabber's video, comparing attention to details from OG to LE, you will be surprised how LE screwed it over.

5- Too easy. They dumbed things down too much, rather than provide classic or accessible options.

6- The Pinnacle Station DLC has been removed

Removing the arena ruined items distribution from stores and looting in ME1, never bothered to adjust it, even in late game you may not even see the Colossus armor for example. They claim they lacked whatever coding to fit that DLC into the game. I can install it from alternative sources in the original game, why couldn't Bioware do it officially?

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3231552081

[h1]Mass Effect 2 and 3[/h1]

I'm afraid this remaster will need a remaster.

I hate when companies depends on the fans to do their jobs, but the "Community Patch" for the trilogy does exactly that. The game isn't mod friendly and ME-Mod-Manager can be inconsistent, but these technical mods makes the experience a lot better. They can't do everything though.

1- They messed with squad commands AI somehow, so allies are dumber than ever before.

2- An old ram bug is gone for ME2, but no adjustments for the loading animations timing were made.

3- The trilogy now has joystick support, but mapping is only for keyboards. ME2 still has the best gameplay of the trilogy.

4- If you try hardcore mode in ME3 you'll see how the clunky controls have aged horribly. Too easy - they made casual mode the standard in ME3, and normal mode have been nerfed to easy. Ridiculous!

5- The remaster never fixed ME3 ridiculous single-key used for running, to cover, to revive, interact and parry (its always conflicting during gameplay)[url=https://www.reddit.com/r/masseffect/comments/pqryj8/i_love_mass_effect_but_having_interact_sprint/]click here to see it[/url] how the game often won't respond right.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zT29L7bWGkM

6- ME2 famous "typewriter bug" haven't been fixed. Expect the same negligence for other animation issues etc.

7- The screen resolution swap bug in ME2 is now 14 years old, because they never fixed it.

8- Instead of fixing Kelly Chambers wrong face in ME3, they replaced the wrong face in ME2 instead. (a simple free mod can fix that)

9- They removed the Galactic Readiness multiplayer from ME3, so you won't need to pace it anymore. They adjusted the missing rating with a few cheap Galaxy Map findings.

10- The Leviathan DLC still has the same bug from 10 years ago in the same ladder, when looking for Dr. Bryson's daughter. If it happens, swap resolution back and forth.

12- They changed [spoiler]Tali's face depicted in a photo[/spoiler] and still got it wrong.

13- They tweaked the ending cut here and there, but still is an jumble mess.

14- It is VERY recommended to download "Expanded Galaxy Mod" for ME3 and other mods such as Audemus' Happy Ending. Make sure you say thank you to "KkJiro". If he's not Bioware he should be.

[h1]Remaster final score: 4.5/10 Fans did it better[/h1]

I won't recommend buying, unless a reasonable discount pops up. In any case then follow my recommendations with patches. EA wasted a great opportunity to give us a decent Steam backgrounds etc. Also, we still don't have N7 emojis and other classic symbols.

If you liked this review, please subscribe to my curator's page [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/27184480/]clicking here![/url]

[code]THE ORIGINAL SCORES FOR EACH TITLE REMAINS[/code]

[b]Mass Effect: 9.0/10 Sacred Jewel[/b]

The game itself has a sophisticated narrative that reshaped the genre forever. You'd turn a blind eye for most of its outdated issues.

[b]Mass Effect 2: 10/10 Living Legend[/b]

Engaging story-telling and undertones. Variety and pace makes every little mission feels like the most important ever. One of the best RPGs ever made.

[b]Mass Effect 3: 7.5/10 Rushed Star [i](it can be a 8.5/10 with EGM mod)[/i][/b]

Anxiety inducing pace won't let you take a breath. Legendary sound-track, but could have had a better conclusion. Controls sucks and interferes with harder difficulties. Looks very rushed, and more action than rpg.

author: {'steamid': '76561198338942446', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 6112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1722175439}
review:
Well, I don't know how the 2 and 3 are in this collection as I did not get to them yet, but the first game is absolutely fucked, the legendary game buried in a pile of bugs and technical issues that, in my opinion, pretty much destroy the game. You are 1000% better of going to play the original release.

Examples:
- every couple minutes, the game stops responding to most keys, which means you can't get into the menu screen, or any of its sub screens (quest list, squad screen, equipment screen, etc.), only restart fixes it
- the AI is super bad, it isn't all that good in the original either, but here, it's somehow even worse - quite literally getting stuck in the middle of an empty area with no obstacles, not shooting enemies in the open and instead aiming and shooting at enemies behind cover, including shooting at walls when targeting enemies in another room, with closed door, that were never directly spotted
- the textures are absolutely fucked. especially skin of everything that is not Asari, the colors are all weird, some of them are sharper that the original, some of them are left super blurry which makes them clash a lot, Anderson looks like he wanted to get a quick tan, but didn't have the money for a vacation, so he stuck his head into an oven and fell asleep for a couple hours, Udina looks like he fucking died at least a week ago, his skin looks like it's about to enter the final stage of rotting, and I guarantee you that there is no actual human, in the actual real world, who has the skincolor of either of them, at least not naturally and while alive
- female Shepard's face is F U C K E D, like really fucking bad - it has been made appropriate for modern audiences, which means someone opened the model file and set the chin size to double what the in-game slider allows - or maybe it's simply because of how bad the textures are, that makes it seem like that. Default Shepard was never a beauty (the engine didn't even allow it really), but this malformed abomination is way way way worse.
- lighting is even more fucked than the textures, the in-built HDR is absolute ass, every light source is brightened into retina destroying levels, colors are all kinds of screwed up - how anyone managed to fuck HDR this bad, I have no fucking idea - it took several restarts and fucking with settings for 10 minutes on top of that to actually turn it off because it refuses to simply be disabled and will fucking fight for its right to burn out your eyes

I also encountered a bunch of old bugs from the original game, so whomever did this "upgrade" basically just ducktaped a shitty HDR system to it, edited an .ini file to allow higher resolutions than the original retail release got, and here we are - "The definitive way to play Mass Effect!"

The only thing legendary about this version of game is how fucked up it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561199375571709', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1686280504}
review:
A Legendary Trilogy, But a Lackluster Remaster

The Mass Effect™ Legendary Edition brings one of gaming’s most iconic trilogies back to life, but unfortunately, the remaster fails to live up to the “legendary” status of its name. While the core games are still fantastic experiences in terms of story and character development, the remaster itself feels underwhelming and misses the opportunity to modernize the series in meaningful ways.

The most noticeable improvement is the visual overhaul, but even this feels inconsistent. While certain environments and character models look stunning, other aspects—like facial animations or some textures—still feel dated. The updates to Mass Effect 1 are welcome, particularly the improved controls and UI, but the changes don't go far enough to fix its clunky combat and awkward mechanics. For a remaster, the visual and gameplay upgrades are serviceable but hardly groundbreaking.

Another issue is the lack of meaningful new content. Beyond graphical updates and quality-of-life changes, there’s little to justify revisiting the trilogy for those who have already played the original games. The exclusion of the multiplayer mode from Mass Effect 3 is also disappointing, as it was a fun and engaging addition to the original release that added replay value.

The Legendary Edition also suffers from technical problems. Frame rate dips, occasional bugs, and inconsistent audio quality break immersion and serve as reminders that this is, at its core, a remaster of older games rather than a true modernization. It’s especially frustrating when these issues arise in a collection that was marketed as the definitive way to experience the trilogy.

Perhaps the biggest missed opportunity is the lack of innovation in gameplay. The combat systems in Mass Effect 2 and 3 feel relatively smooth, but they’ve aged noticeably. The clunky cover mechanics and repetitive enemy encounters remind players that these are games from a different era. The remaster does little to bring these aspects up to modern standards, which may alienate newcomers to the series.

In the end, Mass Effect™ Legendary Edition is still worth playing for those who’ve never experienced the trilogy, as the story, characters, and world-building remain among the best in gaming. However, as a remaster, it feels like a missed opportunity to truly elevate the series. For returning fans, the lack of meaningful changes and the dated feel of the gameplay may leave you wondering if the nostalgia was better left untouched.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057007308', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 570, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1736213240}
review:
Game Crashing constantly? (Windows 11, Intel, NVIDIA)
- Windows Key + R 
- type "%Appdata%" , click 'ok'
- find 'Path of Exile 2' folder
- delete what's inside every 'ShaderCache' (D3D11,D3D12,Vulkan), folder leaving them all empty folders
- go to NVIDIA settings>Graphics>Global Settings 
- Set Shader Cache Size = 100 GB (or find PoE2 in program settings and check for the Cache Size setting)
- Run Path of Exile 2 
- Go to in game settings
- Disable ENGINE MULTITHREADING
- Apply Settings, Restart Game and Give it a crack. 
Hope this helps, (PirateSoftware is a MadLad for explaining this during one of his streams.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198062627140', 'num_games_owned': 190, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 20328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 4841, 'playtime_at_review': 13575, 'last_played': 1736813264}
review:
After 225 hours+ played on a single character, Path of Exile 2 is in my opinion, already a staple in the ARPG genra even with the flaws it has currently.

My cons would mainly be the endgame which can feel tedious at times, and punishing to a point where it is not hard, but simply annoying : 
- single try pinnacle bosses is lame, it forces you mostly to go on youtube and spoil yourself to learn the boss before even trying, because it took you X hours to farm for your single try and of course, you don't want to waste this chance.

- Waystones favorites has to be in the game.

- Tedious layouts on certain specific maps (yes I'm talking about you, Mire and Hidden Grotto, just to name two).

- Waystones sustain feels off, you start with a strong feeling where you are having a hard time doing you atlas talents, and end up with almost too much waystones even without notable nodes increasing their drop chance (which would be fixed with a waystone tab anyway).

- Allow us, in any way, to navigate our passive skill tree more easily. You’ve blocked the middle of the tree, which caters too much to what your class can do. If you want to play a ranger summoner, you would have to waste 10, 15, or even 20 levels just to reach the summoning nodes. Maybe "gate" nodes who would teleport you somewhere else could be a good idea to navigate the tree with fewer wasted talent points.

- I will not talk about drop rate, items balancing, class buffs and nerfs, as it is still an EA and easily fixable because it comes down only to numbers. Exept for one thing : ITEM RARITY ON GEAR HAS TO BE DELETED. Simple as that.
It is mind numbing to know that it affects not only gear drop rates, but also CURRENCY drop rates. It should come from "juicing" your waystones, towers and atlas passives. The current state of this precise stat, catters you way too much and sends you into FOMO mode if you don't run it on your character. Even 100% rarity, which is low compared to some, is night and day.

- Crafting needs to be implemented better and in a more polished way. For the moment, if you are new and poor, it comes down to gambling by using your exalts and praying you'll have a good modifier. The "real" crafting comes with omens, which cost an arm and a leg, and is a priviledge unlocked only for those who can spend tons of currency to buy them.

- Please GGG, try to work and developp the PoE Trade website directly into the game. We shouldn't have to go out of our way so often outside of the game to sell and buy what we want. The currency exchange is a huge step in the right direction.

Aside from perfomances, a few crashes and what I wrote above, I'm having a blast.
Game is fun and engaging. Character power is still very much where it should be. Bosses are the best I've seen in this kind of games.
The recent patches showed that the devs are listening for the moment. PoE 2 has the potential to be the greatest ARPG ever created.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067002702', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 2894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 417, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1736117115}
review:
I'm greatly enjoying this game. 

One of the most common comments i see around here and on Reddit is "the pace is too slow" and "the game is too difficult".
"Slow" and "Difficult" are indeed two true adjectives but they are not necessarily too much in my opinion.

I love having big maps and taking my time to carefully maneuver enemies as they are more threatening than it's predecessor, where even from the start you could 1 or 2 click clear the screen out of them with little to no effort. 

I love the game being slower paced and handling you resources you can eventually learn and rightfully implement in your arsenal rather than having everything shoved down your throat in a couple hours.

I love the QoL changes such as being able to refund passive points without needing to reroll a character or passing hours on the internet looking for the perfect build to follow religiously.

This is exactly the type of arpg i was looking for: tactical, dangerous, sober. If you love having your screen flash and moving at mach 300 while dropping nuclear bombs for free, you can stick to PoE1. Let us Dark Souls/Monster Hunter enjoyers savour this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019338462', 'num_games_owned': 3000, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 5826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1734579857}

-Go grocery shopping
-Block friend and family from texting/phoning you
-Take your weekly shower

1000+ hours later and it will be worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198306141620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1193, 'last_played': 1734300686}
review:
I'm nearing the end of Act2 and I am loving this game. Finally an ARPG where I have to think about what I'm doing and not just mindlessly melting hordes of enemies. I have played and enjoyed a few other popular ARPGS, but they always just felt like clicking simulators at the end of the day. 

I like that I die every now and then in POE2 against swarms of normal enemies, or need to take a few attempts to clear a boss. It gives the game some challenge and makes it feel more cerebral.

This game feels like it was made for real gamers. I don't smell corporate greed at every turn. It seems like their game design and philosophy respect real gamers who are sick of the diluted AAA experiences the large companies are trying to force. 

The graphics, animation, and soundtrack are all top notch for the genre. I would highly recommend giving this game a chance in Early Access or in it's full launch. 

Great work GGG!

author: {'steamid': '76561199558562334', 'num_games_owned': 44, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2792, 'playtime_at_review': 4230, 'last_played': 1736726592}
review:
[code][b]❧ I don't perceive my blog entries as traditional reviews; I encourage you to adopt the same perspective. The decision of whether these games resonate with your preferences rests with you.
❧ I urge you not to rely on my experience to determine whether you should purchase these titles. My blog entries reflect my personal experiences and viewpoints; it is important to regard them as such![/b] [/code]

[h1][b][u]Path of Exile 2[/u][/b][/h1]

Prior to this Early Access, I played around 70 hours on the original game, give or take a few dramatic rage quits, and let’s just say my experience wasn’t exactly award-winning. 

Most of the time, it felt less like I was controlling my character and more like I was a hyperactive cheerleader with no rhythm, waving pom-poms from the sidelines. Naturally, I cycled through a bunch of different classes, took some extended coffee breaks (read: months), and came back as clueless as ever. Long story short, I am, from my perspective, still a certified noob while playing both games. Sure, my wins early on, here, felt somewhat like actual wins, but I can’t shake the feeling that the game is secretly prepping me for failure all over again.

And oh, what wasn’t I wrong about that!

Fast forward to Path of Exile 2. I hit a wall midway through Act 1 with my first character. Naturally, I chose the same class I played in the original game. True to form, I ignored every single warning sign, like a signaler on an airfield, that I was completely botching my build. This led to a character that couldn’t even take down the King in the Mist. Many wasted uncut gems and support gems later, the cost of fixing my mistakes were greater than my entire retirement plan. In the end, I did what any self-respecting gamer would do: I rerolled and Googled [url=https://deltiasgaming.com/a-comprehensive-guide-about-the-witch-class-in-path-of-exile-2/] Witch Class for Dummies [/url], and got offered the holy grail, [url=https://maxroll.gg/poe2/build-guides/minion-army-infernalist-leveling-guide#skills-header] the Infernalist minion build [/url], which looked like the magical path for Act 1 to 3, or at least, that is what I thought!

Hoping this time I wouldn’t end up with a character that needs an exorcist, I dove back in and climbed my way up, passing through the areas I had previously flailed around in. I Finally reached Freythorn once again killing the mobs here with ease, and, to my absolute delight, managed to kill the bastard that previously kept crushing my sanity into oblivion fairly fast.

Pushing further into The Ogham areas, I noticed the difficulty spike once again. Near the end, it seemed like I was trapped in a personal torture chamber, and the Executioner definitely felt like he was auditioning to be my lifelong nemesis. What felt like an eternal struggle, I learned that I had to tweak my build a bit better, and he finally dropped dead. To my surprise, he left me my very first spirit gem. I used it to craft my Raging Spirit skill, and suddenly the game stopped bullying me, at least for now. It finally seemed like I had made a good choice with this build.

Maybe, just maybe, I was finally upgrading from clueless newbie to a real Exile.

Or maybe not, not just yet! Stepping into Ogham Manor was like entering a haunted house where the ghosts didn’t just jump-scare me, they burned my resources and kept me busy for a while. The guide I was following? Yeah, turns out it was more of a polite suggestion than the bulletproof strategy I thought it was. At first, everything was peachy; I was smashing mobs left and right, feeling like a legend. But then, this area decided to take things to another level.

The mobs got angrier, swarming me like mosquitoes at a camping trip. They rushed me, shoved me around, interrupted my spells, and just when I thought I could escape, BOOM! I was blown to smithereens. One mob exploded, another yanked the rug out from under me, and before I knew it, I was sprawled on the floor, defeated by regular mobs, hah, what a joke right?

Moving onward, I shuffled in and out of the manor to offload my loot that seemed to multiply like rabbits! Finally, I reached The Mad Wolf. He wasn’t here to play fetch. It was a wake-up call that the gloves were off. Either I stuck it out or admitted defeat with my tail between my legs.

What followed was a parade of deaths so ridiculous it could’ve been its own blooper reel. I tinkered endlessly with my gem skills, fine-tuned my gear with whatever scraps I had, and squinted at the boss mechanics like I was cramming for an exam. Every defeat nudged me a little closer, teaching me something new, like the fact that this wolf really hated me.

And then, finally, sweet victory! The boss fell to my last desperate blow, leaving me in a state of disbelief, as if I’d just stumbled upon a hidden treasure of everlasting glory.

I wouldn’t say the game is impossible, but it definitely has a “mess up and prepare to be roasted” vibe. It’s like the game’s saying, “You think you’ve got this? Watch me teach you humility!” While not everything is spoon-fed to you, there’s a whole community ready to hand you a metaphorical cup of coffee and help you figure out your build. You stumble, you adapt, and eventually, you’ll reach the point where you will be winning your fights. 

And honestly? That’s the kind of challenge I expect from every game I play!

📜 SIDE NOTES:

[code][b]⭐ For me the WASD and the added roll/dodge were a must for me to pull me into this genre.
⭐ Positioning, and reactive reflexes are very important, without them you will surely die!!
⭐ The lack of in depth knowledge en understanding boosts community interaction. ...
⭐ Visuals and voice acting are from the highest quality, they nailed it in this game.

I never expected myself to enjoy this type of game, but the Early Access drew me right in![/b] [/code]
[code][b]⚠️ While I believe this game is more accessible to a larger audience, it may still not be for everyone, particularly due to its steep difficulty, challenging learning curve, and significant time investment required. If you're not prepared to dedicate considerable effort to mastering the mechanics and overcoming tough challenges, it might be best to wait for the free version before committing![/b] [/code]
[code][b]📢 As this is an Early Access release, updates by the developers are inevitable, and my experience is likely to change as I advance beyond the first Act. Accordingly, this blog will be updated over time![/b] [/code]

author: {'steamid': '76561198072367055', 'num_games_owned': 1267, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 17444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 4555, 'playtime_at_review': 5810, 'last_played': 1736828941}
review: I had never played PoE 1 but decided to give this a try after really enjoying Diablo. If you enjoy the endgame in Diablo and want a more challenging experience that has a lot more depth and importance in crafting / gear / etc then this game is for you. Game will be free on full release with the only really game changing micro-transactions being extra/special stash tabs for you and your guild. Also if you are looking to get the premium currency PLEASE BUY A PACK AND DO NOT BUY CURRENCY DIRECTLY. The packs cost $30+ to get/upgrade but you will get a 1=1 premium currency conversion when buying a pack and will ALSO get all the skins/extras that the pack includes. DO NOT BUY PREMIUM CURRENCY DIRECTLY FROM THE STORE BUY A PACK.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045339445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 16513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5424, 'playtime_at_review': 2806, 'last_played': 1736815478}
review:
I did not play POE1, however, POE2 has been enjoyable to play. The combat mechanics are fun, and the class system is not overwhelming for new players. This is also the first ARPG that I have played for more than a few hours. 

It is early access, but the game is already in a really great place. Melee class feels like they're on the struggle bus though and substantially more difficult than ranged. I hope that aspect will be better balanced in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056824506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 18958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 9556, 'playtime_at_review': 14428, 'last_played': 1736802050}
review:
Path of Exile 2 isn’t just a game: it’s a lifestyle choice. You log in thinking: "Just one more map"... and suddenly it's 3 AM, you’re knee-deep in loot, and you’ve forgotten what sunlight looks like. The story? Sure, there’s something about Wraeclast being a cursed hellscape, but you’re too busy looking at your passive tree for the 20th time because you accidentally turned your sorcerer into a glorified punching bag.

The loot system is both your best friend and your worst enemy. Every drop feels like Christmas morning, until you identify it and realize it's a pile of garbage. But don’t worry, just slap on some currency and pray!

Trade chat is where you’ll develop an economics degree trying to figure out why your precious item is worth less than a Chaos Orb, but some random guy’s rusty helmet costs an Exalted Orb. And don’t get me started on crafting... it’s like gambling, but instead of money, you lose your will to live.

But hey, you’ve got companionship! Your summon skeletons are your real friends now! So yeah, Path of Exile 2 is a Masterpiece. 10/10 would sell my soul to delve deeper again.

Just remember to stretch occasionally and tell your family you’re still alive... maybe!

Ah! And don't forget to follow your Favorite Streamers (such as @aer0__, @Lolcohol, @Pohx, @ifnjeff, @ghazzytv, @omisidgg, etc) <3

author: {'steamid': '76561197988675325', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 17562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 18, 'playtime_at_review': 12062, 'last_played': 1736116746}
review:
Even in its' current early access "double-mint-gum" state - POE 2 is the best ARPG ever made by a significant margin. There are some hurdles to enjoying the experience though.  Please read the following guides below to avoid some of those hurdles:

- How to use weapon sets and allocation points in POE 2.
- How to use a controller and mouse simultaneously in POE 2.
- How to build a POE 2 skill tree as a strength/block character.
- How to make the most of POE 2 trade time / down time / town time.

1. Weapon Swapping and Assigning Weapon Set Allocation Points Guide:

You do not have to press a button to swap weapons. In order to swap weapons: First, press "O" to assign the inputs you want to use for your skills under "input." Next in order to assign the skill you want to use to a weapon set press "G" then click the arrow to the right of the skill.  A window will pop out to the right. At the bottom of that new window there will be weapon set check boxes. They are both checked by default (a strange choice). Just un-check the box for the weapon you aren't using for each skill. Finally, after you've un-chosen a weapon set for each of your skills, close the skill menu. Now assign your skills to different inputs by left clicking the squares in the lower right side of the screen and then left clicking the icon for the corresponding skill you want on that button. Pushing the assigned input button (shown under the squares in the lower right) will now automatically swap to that corresponding weapon set (the box you left checked earlier) and use that skill.

Second, after you earn some weapon set allocations, if you decide to allocate some your passive skill points to different nodes for use with different weapon sets you need to have both skill points and weapon set allocations to spend. You know if you have skill points by pressing the "p" key to bring up your passive tree; your skill point number is the number in the very upper right corner of that screen. Your weapon allocation points are the two numbers under the skill point number.  If the skill point number or the weapon allocation number are zero, then you cannot assign anything to that weapon set at the moment. Don't worry - you can respec skill points if you decide to use your allocations later. The weapon set allocations allow you to spend 1 skill point in two different passive tree locations by having a skill point and then left clicking the arrow to the left of the words "weapon set" then clicking a passive node. You can only do this if you have positive weapon allocations for that weapon set AND positive skill points. IMPORTANT: For some reason currently these allocations can NOT be used to allocate jewel socket nodes (jewel sockets are empty looking nodes on the passive tree where you can slot jewel items that have stats.)

2. How to Use a Controller and Mouse Simultaneously in POE 2 Guide:

If you are playing on Steam, there is a 4th hidden control method that is actually THE BEST method for controlling you character. First select the WASD input method in POE 2 then alt tab.  With your controller plugged in and turned on, if you are looking at POE 2 in your Steam library, there will be a controller button on the right hand side, under the POE 2 banner image. This button allows you to override each steam game's default controller scheme.  Dont worry you can press the button again to turn off the changes at anytime if you dont like them.  After you click the button, under Recommended Layouts - select "Keyboard (WASD) and Mouse." Then remap Left Trigger to Space Bar so you can use it to roll dodge in game. You can do this by clicking "Edit Layout" then "Triggers," then, on the right side, next to Left Trigger make Full Pull = Space Bar and Soft Pull = Space Bar. This whole process will effectively make your controller be detected as an additional keyboard/mouse. You can now use the left joystick to control your character and left trigger to dodge roll in game while simultaneously using your mouse and mouse buttons to aim and use abilities. You can also pick up items, mange inventory, and use skills/skill menus with your mouse and use controller to move/roll without logging out to switch control types.

3. One Way To Build A Strength/Block Character in POE 2 Guide:

While looking at skill tree, in the upper right hand corner utilize the "Search here" box to find nodes on the tree.  From Warrior or Mercenary Starting Area to "Giant's Blood."  Take "Cruel Methods" and "Pile On."  From Warrior or Mercenary starting area to "Colossal Weapon." From "Colossal Weapon" to "Unexpected Finesse." "Unexpected Finesse" to "Polymathy." "Polymathy" to "Iron Reflexes."  Now, in the upper right hand corner where it says "Search here," type "Strength" Path to any/some/all of the glowing nodes in southwest section of the skill tree.  Type "Block" in the same search bar and path to any/some/all glowing nodes in the southwest of skill tree.  See next paragraph for skills and gear.

Skills/Gear.  Left Click with Armour Breaker – Linked with Armour Explosion, Demolisher, and Martial Tempo.  Then Right Click with Sunder – Linked with Heavy Swing, Heft, and Super Critical.  Hat/Gloves/Belt – Resistances, Life, Strength.  Body – High Armor/Strength and Resistances.  Rings/Amulet – Resistances, life/strength, at least one with 5% mana leech.  Weapon – Any Cultist Greathammer, Advanced Cultist Greathammer or Expert Cultist Greathammer. Must have plus to "Level of all Melee Skills" and plus some type of ADDED and/or % physical damage. Other damage or some attack speed is nice but not required.  Shield – Some Armor and the "Life gained when you Block" enchant stat or the Recover % Life on Block stat.  Boots - Movement Speed / Resists

4. POE 2 Trade Time / Down time / Town Time Guide:

Respecing costs more as you level. Try to keep some gold on you to respec several points.

If you see a item with percent quality on it and/or an item with a socket in it, even if it's not good, pick it up to salvage it later. Also, if you see one of these in the store for a reasonable amount of gold from a vendor - purchase it to salvage. You'll get shards that you can use for upgrading gear and trading at the currency exchange market later on.

Finally, you can "disenchant" rare items for regal orb shards in town at a npc. It is "hidden" as one of the dialog options. (strange choice)  Unique items become chance shards if you "disenchant" them at the npc. Most unique items will be worth more to other players though - so I recommend you save them - wait for a GGG point shop stash tab sale and then buy one currency tab and one premium quad tab with your early access shop points (you can right click premium tabs in your stash and then make public for trading with other players, within the tab, you can right click items to list your items for orbs on the poe2 homepage trade search section).  The trade search on the POE 2 homepage can also be used to find gear for your builds.  For example for the Strength build above you would type "Strength" under Stat Filters then pick one, add a minimum value then search.


Good Luck Exiles!

author: {'steamid': '76561199487145569', 'num_games_owned': 979, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 1715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 263, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1735831958}
review: For veteran players of poe1, poe2 is an upgrade to the previous game. It not only inherits the core gameplay of its predecessor but also boldly innovates and optimizes in skill trees, class choices, and combat pacing. The skill tree in the second generation is more complex than in the first! It has more depth!! It's more fun!!! Every combination of skills and equipment brings a different sense of satisfaction, providing an experience akin to a roguelike, making you want to enjoy it even more. POE2 also adds more new elements on top of the original difficulty of POE. New enemies and new scene designs make the battles more exciting. The boss design this time is more complex, and the experience brought by the high-speed boss fights and gorgeous skill effects is unparalleled in treasure hunting games. The new rolling mechanism raises the ceiling of the game significantly; do you like glass cannons? Then just use the roll on him. Moreover, I have to mention that the guiding system in this game is excellent. Compared to the pointer in the first installment, every task in the second installment has clear prompts, ensuring that newcomers won’t go from getting hooked to quitting in one go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003479494', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 15163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2916, 'playtime_at_review': 7714, 'last_played': 1736651651}
review:
EDIT: 12/14/2024

After over 100 hours I can say that I recommend this game as an Early Access ARPG. I love a lot about this game and I'm a PoE fanboy so I'll be objective and take off my rose tinted glasses.

While the game has some pain points with the permanence of "choice" and does not subscribe to the industry standard of "Loot Piñatas," it is beautiful, vibrant, haunting, and provides something "different" from any other ARPG. 

There's fun to be had in experimentation but the wrong choice for gear or skill points could make you feel that time was wasted. Ascendancy trials are TERRIBLE and while on paper sound fun, are deep ball pain to attempt. Ascendancy ultimately only provides a different way to play and do not dictate the CORE of your build. I suggest waiting to complete the trials until you're SURE of what you want to do and be VERY CAREFUL in your choice of Ascendancy.

I'm aware of the nerfs and I demand justice for my fellow Exiles in the form of a free respec. As an Early Access game it should not be outlandish to provide one and it hurts me knowing people are frustrated by something they literally couldn't control. Sending my love.

I'll update again once I've put in more time or more updates happen.


ORIGINAL POST - 

Positive review to balance all the idiots who are leaving negatives for launch day issues and for just generally trying to bomb the game. I don't think reviews should be available for early access games because you really aren't getting a fair view of what the game will actually provide so I find it laughable that people can definitively just say "good" or "bad."

It hasn't launched fully. First day of server issues are nothing out of the ordinary for game releases. The highest player count on PoE1 was over 200k. This EA sold over one million copies and a majority of them tried to log on at the same time at launch. If you can't handle how EAs work and release days work I do agree you should refund. Leaves more server space for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964451103', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 4295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 48, 'playtime_at_review': 4247, 'last_played': 1736688024}
review:
Just a warning right away: This is NOT a Hack n Slay ARPG like Diablo 2, Diablo 3, Diablo 4 or Path of Exile. This is a bird view Dark Souls-esque Game. The Idea is that while you level and equip your Character traditionally to older ARPGs, Bossfights (which happen constantly) are about you learning the Phases, dodging and avoiding everything. The Damage Output is very high, so one shot deaths or almost one shot deaths are very common.  You will not just chill on the couch, deal AE damage and clear the areas, you will definitely have to focus, learn and adapt to encounters. The first real Gatekeeper will be the Act1 Boss and I fear that many Casual Players will not go beyond that.

If you want a chill Hack n Slay Looter-Grind Game, this is not the Game. If you like a Challenge and play a Dark Souls Game from Bird View, this is your Game.

Update: After finishing the Campaign, the Game takes a nosedive. The Endgame does everything PoE1 does right, wrong. Its still worth the playthrough, but do not expect any engaging or fun endgame in the current state. I will update this, if it changes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198843136395', 'num_games_owned': 1663, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1733536667}
review:
It’s really fun and addictive. I think it’s better than Diablo 4, and the price is pretty reasonable. You can play with either mouse or keyboard, and I’ve heard it even supports controllers, though I haven’t tried it myself. There’s also local multiplayer co-op, which is great. One small downside is that I need to use a VPN to play, but my friend doesn’t have the same issue, so I guess it depends on personal network conditions. But then again, most gamers keep a VPN around anyway, so it’s not a big deal.
I’m playing as a Monk, thinking that playing a tank character would let me experience more of the game’s content. It’s really fun so far, and maybe it’s because the monster difficulty in the early stages isn’t too high, but I feel like with a bit of gameplay, monsters can’t even scratch me. To be exact, they don’t even have a chance to attack. I just control the field and start enjoying the loot grind.
I haven’t really dove deep into build crafting yet, but I can already feel there’s a lot of potential. With skill gems, equipment, and the talent tree, there are tons of ways to combine things. What’s even better is that the talents can be switched on the fly during combat, making the class feel really versatile—one character feels like two.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028140827', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 788, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1736461353}
review:
The main menu music has a nice xmen 3 vibe to it, I would definitely recommend.
On the flip side, the error message writer should think twice next time because "Unexpected Disconnection occured" rings false and pretentious even to greenhorns. This is exactly what we expected.
Other than that, the menu has some great options you can turn on and off, loading it up and exiting goes smoothly. 
7.6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197972445514', 'num_games_owned': 1949, 'num_reviews': 261, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1735359268}
review:
PATH OF EXILE 2, a terrifying death drenched journey into a cursed land where you travel onward to bloodcurdling adventures. Thus far my experience playing a Witch has been silky sinful smooth as i cut thru monstrous entities with weapons sinister and magics darkly as she speaks of the sweetness of damnation with dialogue so craftily hers it must have been written by a real Witch.

Graphics groan and moan in artistic ecstasy as if drawn and animated to life by a classical artist of centuries past with a brush mystical yet fiendishly modern.  Animations dance and heave supernaturally in their excellence of form and.. EXECUTION without lag without pause smooth as a scorching hot blade thru buttered bellies ready to be feasted upon by conjured skeletal minions hungering for wet warm gutty entrails.

Audio whispers and sings upon haunted wings hunting as things most unnatural screech and scream piercing the senses with hair raising electrifying numbing terror with the sounds of battle soon following with clashing steel! thunderous spell! crushing! disintegrating flesh and bone perhaps to leave a bit of loot, a bit of coin to strengthen and enrich thee.

Vast and infinite is your potential upon a skill tree of countless fruits of knowledge. Which will you choose? What path shall you take? Will you be hero? villain? or a multitude of shades of grey defiant to all those who would dare label you in simplistic terms?

User interface throbs with intuitive life as if crafted and fused into my brain by some master blacksmith of the infernal realms where all is natural and stimulating the pleasure centers with much violent stimuli joyful in its informative properties! 

With my i9 12900k, 32gb ram, RTX 3080 12gb vram, NVME SSD, Windows 11, latest updates as of November 2024 at a resolution of 2560 x 1440p at 60 fps performance has been blood red fluid and blinding lightning swift with only one crash due to an " Unable to load texture " error after one hour of gameplay.   

PATH OF EXILE 2, Buy it! Play it! I beseech you to support this work most noble and right where integrity and respect command this conjured marvel of gaming magnificence brought forth by Grinding Gear Games keepers of gaming's flame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042447588', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 29314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 9496, 'playtime_at_review': 954, 'last_played': 1736844835}

author: {'steamid': '76561197968463258', 'num_games_owned': 1046, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 802, 'last_played': 1735001741}
review:
Early impressions for me are extremely positive. I've only played mercenary up to this point, so keep that in mind.
It's essential to understand how support and skill gems work and the effect they trigger when combined with each-other and with passives at the same time. You need a gameplan basically.

Once it "clicked" for me, the experience changed quite a bit. Not hard or tedious at all as some people is trying to convey, but fair and well balanced instead.
You need to squeeze the damage, or desired effects, out of your skill slots as much as you can.

Experiment as much as you can (support gems can be moved freely), it's fun and rewarding.
Of course it is also important to upgrade/change weapons/armor and the skills you intend to use as soon as you can.

The game will not allow you to "walk in the park" without teaching you the ropes first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027882187', 'num_games_owned': 486, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1267, 'last_played': 1734927205}
review: Feels great so far and the studio has a track record I trust. I hear people have complained about bosses being to difficult early on, but that feels like a skill issue tbh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076826717', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 2447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1116, 'last_played': 1734386071}
review:
I tried POE1 a while back but it never stuck. As a big fan of Diablo series it was just weird that some of the points/spec choices were kinda permanent and the fact I had to learn class specifics upfront to make a character that won't brick itself after a while put me off. Plus, endgame with 1000% speed increase blazing through maps is not something i really enjoy...

That said, POE2, even in its current EA form, is an obivious labour of love. Graphics are stunning, the atmosphere is superb (I would even go as far as to say it's better than D4), music is fantastic and the slower gameplay with more weight and tactical focus on skills and builds is a refreshing thing to see in the genre.

Sure, some bosses will literally wipe the floor with you, and that's where you stop, rethink your build/strategy and go again (and this comes from someone who never liked "soul-like" games)

Microtransaction shop is giga-overpriced but hey... it's a F2P game that is actually amazing so wait for discounts or buy stuff to support the devs.

An absolute must play if you like ARPGs

author: {'steamid': '76561198207871443', 'num_games_owned': 59, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 37999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 17217, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1736845825}
review:
So far, I’m quite impressed with the menu.
The game title is carefully placed in the center, framed by a beautifully crafted visual design.
However, the main menu of Path of Exile 2 takes it a step further, impressing with a dark, atmospheric aesthetic that perfectly captures the game's grim mood. The background features artistic animations that hint at a mystical world, and the music enhances the sense of adventure and danger.

The buttons feel satisfying to click and respond flawlessly.
Even in the options menu, thoughtful consideration is evident in the well-organized layout of individual tabs.
The navigation is intuitive and clearly structured, allowing you to quickly make desired adjustments. Every button click is accompanied by subtle sound effects, conveying a sense of high-quality craftsmanship.
The customization is particularly noteworthy: even in the main menu, you can easily adjust essential settings like graphics, audio, and controls without having to navigate through multiple sub menus.

The main menu is a prime example of how a game can draw players into its world from the very first moment – a masterpiece in its own right!

author: {'steamid': '76561198169590667', 'num_games_owned': 420, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 3855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1735142978}
review:
Cool sound, for almost 50$. I even forgot that I took it for the game, not the music.
But the developers are just great, as if young, young Mozart seemed to say to me so calmly, breaking the sulfur in my ear with this Angel sound: - sit down and listen!
Bravo, such a cool musical dessert should be listened to for hours, weeks and months. You didn't come here to play!
I applaud standing.
And what does it mean that she's alone there?
--But how beautiful!
And what the hell are those games?
-It doesn't matter!
When there is such music!

On BIS On BIS On BIS!




Класний саунд, за майже 2к. Навіть забув, що я брав її заради гри, а не музики. 
Але розробники просто молодці, як той молодий Моцарт немовби мовив мені так спокійно розбиваючи сірку у вусі цим Янгольським звуком: - седи і слухай!
Браво, такий класний музикальний десерт треба слухати годинами, тижнями та місяцями. Ти сюди не грати прийшов!
Аплодую стоячи.
І що значить вона там одна ?
-Зато Яка!
І на біса ті ігри ?
Коли є така музика!


Біс, біс, біс!

author: {'steamid': '76561198052901042', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 9144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 800, 'playtime_at_review': 8359, 'last_played': 1736547915}
review:
I'm not a sweatlord, but PoE is my fave game of all time, so I come into PoE2 as a bit of a fan girl, but not so much that I'm unable to give constructive criticism. To succinctly summarise my overall feeling: The PoE 2 campaign is excellent, but ascension is f*n ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that needs a complete overhaul, and the end game is unrewarding enough to not be worth my time. To elaborate:

[b]First some praise:[/b]
[list]
[*] Graphics, splash screens, audio, and voice acting are top notch.
[*] Besides the constant crashing, it runs well (though I do have a very nice PC, so not a hard feat)
[*] I deeply appreciate my stash tabs being transferred over from PoE1 and anticipate many of my aesthetic microtransactions will be too at a later date.
[*] I love being able to play with WASD instead of mouse click move. This makes running and casting spells a lot easier and just feels good.
[*] I love that the skills have been delinked from the gear, meaning I no longer have to worry about getting/crafting the right amount and colour of linked sockets every time I find better gear.
[/list]


NOW TIME FOR BITTER COMPLAINTS:


[b]No Blink Spells[/b]
I like the dodge roll, but not at the expense of no blink spells. I can live with this change, but honestly, I prefer my flame dash and frost blink to unlimited dodge rolls.

[b]Slow Pace[/b]
The bosses being beefy are fine, but the normal mobs have a little too much HP. Makes map clearing a bit tedious. It's already a lot slower without the blink spells, but now having to go through areas and maps slowly hacking through enemies instead of breezing through and making them regret their life choices does not give me the dopamine-fueled hero vibe I had in PoE1.

[b]Level Gated Skills[/b]
The gem variety seems a lot more level gated than before and the manner in which you level them, even more so. I much prefer the way it worked in PoE1. I also can't believe that I'm at the maps already and still working with only 4 links. In PoE1, I would have at least had a 5 link by the time I got to the atlas.

[b]Melee Sucks[/b]
The warrior attacks are SO slow. I've tried all the classes and this is the most unfun to play mostly because the attacks take an age to build up. As a warrior I expect to feel like I can rush in and slap things around, but he gets slapped around by everything before he can even get there to land the first hit.

[b]Lack of Loot and unfair Gambling[/b]
Compared to PoE1, there's not nearly as much loot. I like loot. You like loot. Everyone likes loot, but we get so little loot in PoE2, we don't even really need a loot filter. That's not only a shame because I'm GLOAT (greatest looter of all time), and an avid SSF player, but it also means progression is even slower due to to poor gear choices and not enough currency to do anything about it.

It becomes an even bigger issue with the sorceress and witch. If I embrace a certain skill attached to a specific staff/wand, it means that I can only use that specific staff/wand and all other types are useless for me. 60% of the time, after levelling up, the merchants did not sell that type of staff/wand I was using, and the only time their loot refreshes is on level up, so I have to go through a whole level before I can hope for the right staff/wand to appear in the merchants wares again because they mostly did not drop in game either (due to hardly any loot generally).

The gambling is unfair as well. With both witches and sorceresses, a wand or staff that does not have the spell you are using is absolutely useless but you can only gamble for a random staff which could have other spells you aren't using. Out of every 10 staves, I get maybe 2 of the kind that I actually want, and they're typically poor quality with stupid mods like "light radius" or "lower requirements".

[b]Ascension[/b]
Ultimatum and Sanctum can eat a whole bag of dix. Next to that necro whatever league recently, they are the worst mechanics from PoE1 ever, but at least there I could ignore it. In PoE2 they've been used for Ascension so I'm forced to interact with it. There was nothing wrong with how ascension worked in PoE1. Not sure why GGG had to reinvent the wheel. I miss Izaro. I happened to enjoy Ascension from PoE1. This new ascension method is not only horribly difficult (could not get past the third stage of chaos whilst being 10 levels higher), but the invites keep dropping at the level my character is at, so I can't get brutally overpowered and do them eventually. THIS IS NOT FAIR. Of course the sweatlords will put out a meta build and then a bunch of people will copy that verbatim and then feel like they achieved something on their own by getting through it, and and then have the gall to scream 'skill issue' at anyone that complains, but if ascension is only going to be for sweatlords and sweatlord build copiers, then I'll go back to PoE1, thanks.


[b]Atlas[/b]
The end game has no sense of direction. The thing that keeps me playing PoE1 is the mini achievements and milestones all along the way. My progression speed starts to taper off on the high level corrupted red maps and the game stops being fun and becomes a boring grind. It's at this point that I typically drop off PoE1. I'm sure telemetry data will show this is the case for many players. In PoE 2 it's even worse. I got to tier 1 maps, unlocked a hideout and now I have no desire to continue. The lack of loot (gear and currency) and slower progression are just boring for me.


After all that complaining I'm still giving the game a thumbs up because it will be free and I also supsect that GGG will make some changes to fix at least some of that. I hope my constructive feedback will be considered by the devs. I'm not the best player. I don't do meta or trading, but I do have almost 2k hours playing SSF in PoE1 (and loving it), so I'm not a noob either. So I hope this feedback will be seen as coming from 'your average player and fan'.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097121239', 'num_games_owned': 246, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 13415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3361, 'playtime_at_review': 5640, 'last_played': 1736813510}
review:
Early Access review all topics I talk about are subject to change. If this would be the full release it would clearly be a NO for me.

First of all, I never witnessed a game manage to crash and freez a pc to the point it needs to be shutdown with the powerbutton.

In my opinon the Early Access got way to much attention that hopefully don't end up taxing on the full release.

Moving all the mobility spells into the mid to lategame is such a bad idea, making monster pile up on the player with the only option to panic spam space in hope to escape.

Some Abilitys wind-up way to long making the player stagnate on one position for atleast 1s, while the monster move at 1,5x the speed of the player having enough time to cancel the players wind-up or make it impossible to not take damage.

Monster most of the time aggro offscreen independent of line of sight or elevation levels.
Lots of bodyblock, monster bodyblocking themself, players bodyblocking themself in multiplayer

a lot of maps are just squares with narrow bridges or big maps filled with so many details that its hard to understand what is accessible and what not

Gear progression is also pushed into lategame and without trading I still would walk around with my lv 33 boots at level 60+ cause they rolled good stats and making a new pair with the same stats would cost more then the game is giving to the player.

Bosses are fun to fight but most of the time they make big damage moves without indicator or they do a 1 shot ability with a save location, but at the same time the boss cast a second ability on the only save spot the player can stand.

Spirit is a great change to mana reservation making it way more manageable.

The new gem system also pushes all progression into lategame and gives little room to improve in the first acts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009695406', 'num_games_owned': 2373, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 6409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3125, 'last_played': 1734618297}
review:
Excellent game. Obviously this is Early Access so there will be bugs and some things might not work as intended, but overall the QUALITY of EA is huge. More content and it plays better than most of games that recently got out of early access.

Quick summary:
- Game is not too hard and not too easy
- Excellent art design
- Gameplay and skills feel soooo good, sounds of crushing bones, projectiles shooting and hitting enemies
- Loot is pretty rare so You do not get overwhelmed with 1000 items on screen after each mob pack defeated
- Vendors are useful

One thing i dislike is that bosses should give better loot, but that might be addressed in next patch.

Overall excellent game, worth playing either now or waiting for F2P. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104361263', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 6669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1735619228}
review:
I like it a lot so far. The addition of gold as a standard currency for buying/selling stuff, being able to buy and then upgrade a set of gear from the merchants in the first town that will last you several levels if you want to, weapons having skills/spells associated with them that you get access to by having them equipped and then being able to quickly swap between your 2 weapons sets in combat by using the associated button/key used for that skill/spell. For example, I found a better version of the staff I got at the start that gives me a fireball spell and as my secondary I have another staff that shoots out a spread of 7 ice projectiles that can freeze enemies, but I could have any other weapon my attributes allow me to equip if I wanted. I also like the uncut gem system of using one of those uncut gem items to make a new spell/skill gem or upgrade one you already have.

It all adds up to a lot of different options to approach combat and make it feel more fun than most other games in the genre because of the way the different skills/spells work together and how it encourages using a 2nd weapon set in ways others never really have. I've always made my main weapon set and had a 2nd equipped, but never use it. Here, I do constantly. In part cause it's offering more ways to deal out different types of damage in different ways, but also in part because of how they interplay with each other. The flame wall I didn't think I was gonna use cause they don't end up feeling that useful in these kinds of games is how I now handle a certain skeleton that likes hiding behind his shield that reflects my spells in a most painful way. He not only doesn't like standing on it anymore than other enemies do, but firing projectiles thru it gets fire damage added to them, meaning my shotgun blast of ice shards also deals fire damage if it passes thru that.

The way my fireball spell builds up the stun meter on bosses so that I can deal a ton of damage to them while they're stunned or my ice spells can build up enough freeze on them to do the same while they're frozen makes both options feel more viable. I usually don't mess around with those kinds of mechanics-at least not while playing a mage or sorcerer style class in these kinds of games-but here it feels totally viable. Sure, I'm not very far in the game yet and have died multiple times, but it's pretty much always been due to mistakes I knew I made and feels both fair and justified the vast majority of the time-with the others honestly being me getting stuck in parts of the environment I should have been paying attention to and not getting myself backed into corners.

I also feel like they did a good job of making a game with fewer, but more impactful enemies-rather than spamming you with a bunch of trash mobs you can instantly clear off the screen peppered with a few tougher enemies here and there that might take a second or 2 longer to kill than the trash mobs. It feels slower paced than I remember the first one being and maybe even most others in the genre, but it also balances that out by being more fun to fight groups of enemies, mini bosses, bosses, and generally engage with any of the combat related content. It may devolve into it at some point where I just end up spamming one or 2 main abilities/spells that kill everything with only needing to use the other spells/abilities on the occasional time I get into trouble, but at least for now, I feel like I'm using more tools in my arsenal to take down the different groups of enemies. In part because it feels fun to switch between my 2 weapons and how they attack and the damage they deal, but because I tend to need to. The frost lets me freeze enemies to get the breathing room to blow them up with my fireball and the firewall and lightning deals damage over time while they're trying to catch back up to me if they survived the fireball blasts to the face.

I know it's going to be free to play in 6 months or so when it leave early access, but I played a lot of the first one and I don't think I tossed them so much as a buck during all that time. I felt quite comfortable throwing them $30 now to check the game out early and help fund it while they finish the rest of the content. Speaking of, it looks like there are only 6 classes so far with each showing another coming soon and when you use the uncut skill gems, you see that flails, axes, swords, primal, and a few more are also coming soon. Don't let that discourage you from checking out the game, though. I haven't seen any of those things drop so far in the game, so I could be wrong, but it's just more stuff that's going to be added as they further develop the game rather than being something that's partially in the game without skills to use to make them more fun. Sure, that means things like axes and swords aren't in yet (they could be and I just haven't seen them), but it means that all the stuff you're seeing so far if you've watched any videos or people streaming/playing the game is BEFORE they added flails, axes, and the related skills to offer even more ways to play the game and make different builds for your characters.

I was a little worried that picking a class this time would more heavily restrict me from playing the game how I want, but aside from not having whatever Spirit is that's needed to cast the undead minion summoning spells that I assume the Witch class has to start off with to use those, I don't see any restrictions to what my class/character can use/do. Well, the Attributes I have impact that as well, but you can alter those thru the passive skill tree like always.

If you wanna check out the game earlier than normal and help support the developers and this game, then I recommend getting one of the supporter packs. Otherwise, there's likely no harm in waiting until it leaves early access and goes true free to play next year. I didn't want to wait and am glad I didn't cause this is probably the most fun combat in the genre right now, but that's just my opinion. If I end up getting bored with the sorceress class and their spells, I already scoped out the Mercenary class and their crossbows with different types of ammunition that make it act like a shotgun, long range rifle, or rapid fire ranged weapon in addition to the different types of ammunition that deal different types of elemental damage seems like a lot of fun, too. I'll probably check that class out next.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989108808', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 33, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1736648599}
review:
Barely played, but tried out three classes. Game is an evolution of POE1 with more action focused moment to moment gameplay than face rolling maps.

Difficulty feels closer to POE1 Ruthless than I expected. That's fine, I like Ruthless.

Ranged combat is more immediately gratifying than melee. For a more action-focused title than before, more love needs to be put into the feel and flow of melee. I'm definitely giving melee something of a pass with this being Early Access.

Overall, smart, smart design changes. I absolutely love the rolling and WASD controls. The active shield is also surprisingly engaging.

Time will tell if the moment to moment is too stressful to be gratifying.

2024.12.08. Update. Been playing on console and with controller, and whoa boy is the game designed for a controller. WASD rocks, but playing on controller feels like home.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960667339', 'num_games_owned': 653, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 8919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3762, 'last_played': 1734925803}
review:
I've had this game since Friday and am on vacation. I'm a working adult with a wife and dog for reference and this game influenced me to act like a degen from high school again.

Before recommending the game, it's worth noting the PoE fan base is a bit cancerous. It is very similar to Steam/Valve fans where nothing negative can be said about the game, or the vocal fan base gets extremely defensive whether passive aggressively or straight up aggressive. 

With that said, if you ignore the toxic fan base by not interacting with them, you have a mutation/baby of the following games:

Monster Hunter
Soulsborne (Elden Ring, Dark Souls, Bloodborne)
Lost Ark
Grim Dawn
Diablo 2

And the result is beautiful. The game rewards you for mechanically understanding how not to get hit, and returning the pain but also forces you to learn how to build (aka. have a long term goal/plan.) The target audience for this game would likely be a fan of any of the above games. The learning curve, however, is sharp, especially if you are melee. The build learning curve, thankfully, is much less insane than PoE1 due to the removal of gem links on items (thank god.)

If you are Diablo 4 player and found D4's end game extremely lacking, you will find PoE2 not only looks better than D4, it has a far more fleshed out endgame than D4 despite being in EA.

If the above sounds like your thing, you have nothing to lose playing EA as the game is quite stable and very controller friendly....but you'll probably have to logout and switch back to mouse to manage your stash and inventory (big con, take note GGG!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198047865567', 'num_games_owned': 491, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2377, 'playtime_at_review': 1270, 'last_played': 1736780754}
review:
Path of exile 2 is a stunning, beautiful and very polished game for an early access title. 
If you go into this expecting a game similar to the first game, you might be disappointed. Instead of fast paced "clear maps in seconds" game play, Poe2 is more slow and methodical in its mechanics. I've heard the comparison "a mix between diablo and Elden ring" thrown around which is exactly my thoughts. It is challenging and not for the faint of heart, but by god i'm in love with this game. 
It is much easier to pick up and play than poe1, you don't need a spreadsheet and a build guide to get you going.
There are some issues with the maps being insanely large and backtracking is not always fun. Currency is a little scarce, but these are all issues GGG are working on, and i see this game going on to be the best ever ARPG ever, and for me its not even close.

I am only at the end of act 3 so far, but i am obsessed with this game. If this review helps just 1 make up their mind to buy this game and fall in love like i have, then i can die peacefully knowing i did something good in my life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198362335062', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 13969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 30, 'playtime_at_review': 12526, 'last_played': 1736750833}
review:
This game is absolutely stunning! The visuals are gorgeous, and the mechanics feel fresh and distinct from POE1. I've tried the Deadeye and Stormweaver classes so far, and both are incredibly fun to play. Mobs just melt away—it’s so satisfying!

The boss fights are where this game truly shines. The mechanics are some of the best I’ve ever seen—intense, innovative, and incredibly well-designed. Each boss feels like an epic showdown, combining strategy, skill, and a touch of chaos. No other game captures this level of depth and creativity in boss encounters.

The progression feels rewarding, and the build variety keeps me excited for what’s ahead. Highly recommend for anyone who loves ARPGs. Grinding Gear Games has knocked it out of the park!
⭐ 9.5/10
