author: {'steamid': '76561198318134178', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 21177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 9858, 'playtime_at_review': 10800, 'last_played': 1736846330}
review:
[b]Alright, let's dive deep into one of the greatest and arguably the godfather of all action RPGs: [i]Path of Exile 2[/i].[/b]

[b]Story: 4/10[/b]
The storyline in Path of Exile 2 isn't anything great. It's just something there so you may have some kind of explanation for fighting monsters. Most often, one would just let it be and enjoy the game play - since that matters most here. You will utterly be disappointed in this game if you're on a story power trip.

[b]Graphics: 8.5/10[/b]
It really looks great. Dark and detailed environments, incredible spell effects-the atmosphere of every area is gloomy and pulls you in. Animations are smooth, and everything feels polished visually. If your PC can handle it, it's a treat for the eyes.

[b]Optimization: 6/10[/b]
Performance is an issue right now. I've had multiple crashes at random moments, be it during boss fights, loading screens, or just running around. It's frustrating, especially when you're deep into a fight. Hopefully, the developers fix this soon, as it really breaks the flow of the game. We will have to wait for the full release to make the final decision here.

[b]Progression System: 9/10[/b]
Amazing progression system in PoE2, giant skill tree with huge customization options, and this gem system is just fantastic, adding a whole another level to it. Will definitely be overwhelming at first, but when one gets used to it, it is incredibly satisfying. You will always have something you'd like to change or work on, so it feels fresh. 

[b]Combat Mechanics: 10/10[/b]
It's far and away the best part of this game. Currently, I am maining the Infernalist, an Ascendancy class of the Witch. The combos of spells are amazing, really. You commit to one element as an Infernalist, and mine is fire. The synergies between AoE Spells, Minions, and Fire Resistance reduction AoE are incredible. So dynamic in combat. You can set everything on fire, summon minions to do your bidding, and debuff enemies to melt them even faster. Adding in the dodge roll really changes the pace of combat; you're not just standing there, spamming abilities, you're moving around, dodging attacks, and repositioning to deal damage. It makes every fight way more skill-based and keeps you on your toes. Abilities hit hard, and controls feel tight and responsive so that when you land a big spell or pull off a perfect combo, it feels incredibly satisfying. Clearing mobs or going toe-to-toe with bosses, every fight feels like an engaging and rewarding fight.

[b]Grinding: 8/10[/b]
It's a huge part of the game, and it's done well. It feels really rewarding to find just the right item, even when RNG can sometimes drive you crazy. Hence, you need to grind for crafting and upgrading materials a lot since you will lose a lot of your lovely gear to RNG system :(. But still, you will find a +8/10 gear eventually and make your dream build with it. So, the grinding system for me is a solid 8/10. It's great but still needs a bit of work and might change drastically after full game release.

[b]Endgame Content: 7/10[/b]
Once you complete the campaign, PoE2 boasts a huge and challenging endgame. Maps are classified into 16 tiers; the difficulty scales up real fast as you progress, where enemies become more formidable in every way, including higher elemental resistances. And this means you will continually be upgrading your own resistances to keep up. But here’s the frustrating part : while enemies gain resistances, your character's elemental resistances are often drastically reduced, making it harder to survive in the later tiers. It's one of those mechanics that feels more like an artificial difficulty spike than an interesting challenge. You’re essentially forced into tweaking your gear constantly just to survive in higher-tier maps, which can be pretty annoying. You spend a lot of time dealing with this imbalance, and it feels like it just adds unnecessary grind rather than strategic depth.
Besides the maps, significant endgame content is provided by the Trials of Chaos and Sekhemas. You only need to complete four rooms in the Trials of Chaos to get the Ascendancy points, but you can challenge yourself even more by going up to room 10, which is true endgame content. These trials are made for up to six players, making sure it's a very cooperative experience, really putting to the test your skills and teamwork. Difficulty ramps up significantly, but the rewards are quite worth the effort, therefore making this aspect of the game both exciting and challenging.

[b]Overall Score: 9/10[/b]
PoE2 is an excellent ARPG. The combat feels amazing, the progression system is deep, and the grind is addictive. The crashes and weak story do hold it back a bit, but its still a great experience overall. The full release will likely improve the game further, especially with better optimization and possibly some tweaks to the endgame. If you're willing to push through some rough edges for now, it's definitely worth playing. We’ll have to wait until the full release to see how much it improves, but for early access, it’s already very promising.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047412913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2417, 'playtime_at_review': 1269, 'last_played': 1736809352}
review:
I’ve been playing Path of Exile since 2013, when Piety was the final boss. Clocked 1200+ hours on it and loved playing it for years, until I eventually stopped, mostly due to two main issues:
[list]
[*]Years of adding league mechanics into the core game made it extremely bloated, to a point where returning to the game required grinding through every mechanic from zero, over and over again, which just felt terrible.
[*]It felt bad to play the game casually while being aware of builds which allowed you to zoom through maps and delete whole screens of mobs in a split second. The game became too much of an epilepsy simulator, relying on major dopamine hits. It became too fast, where not using Whirling Blades or other movement skills constantly was a major disadvantage; without them you couldn’t farm currency quickly enough to buy build-enabling chase items.
[/list]
To my relief, these issues were resolved PoE2: there are fewer side mechanics (for now) and the game has slowed down. I am playing monk and I’m currently in Act 2 and absolutely love the synergy of skills, of movement and different effects. I don’t feel punished for taking my sweet time listening to NPCs, fighting mobs and enjoying the intensity of combat.

Other things I appreciate:
[list]
[*]WASD controls turned out to be super fun, makes me much more engaged and immersed in the game.
[*]The game is visually and aurally beautiful.
[*]It is much more difficult than PoE1 in its early acts; with its roll mechanics often described as Souls-like. Meanwhile, studying and recognizing boss patterns makes just enough difference to turn a hopeless fight into a win. With addition of checkpoints, dying is not as punishing as in PoE1 and minimizes frustration from dying to a boss multiple times.
[*]Skill gems system was reworked and is an upgrade in every way to PoE1, where it was normal to have dozens of useless gems. Getting a 5-link chest armor ASAP was always a major pain, not to mention 6-linking your best-in-slot chest in the endgame.
[*]The most common complaint I’ve seen so far is that PoE2 is too slow. It is exactly what an ARPG needs to actually enjoy the encounters with monsters of different rarities. Encounters are now more impactful, whereas it was expected in PoE1 to delete a rare monster in 2 hits, making it’s suffixes and effects meaningless.
[/list]
Some of my concerns:
[list] 
[*]When the remaining 6 classes are added, it will further dilute the item drop pool (atm there are no swords, axes, daggers, javelins, etc.). I hope GGG will add a preferential loot drop for the class you play, as it is already difficult to find upgrades for your character.
[*]While PoE2 already assists the player more in figuring out the build without consulting external resources, it would be good to be able to “wishlist” or highlight the passive tree nodes that you wish to unlock in the future. This was the best part of Path of Building, which I hope I won't have to use for PoE2, but without it I must remember where I need to go in the tree every time I level up.
[*]GGG said the crafting currency would drop more often to incentivize the player to use it for crafting. This doesn’t seem to be the case; the drop should be increased.
[*]Players with no prior experience may be lost as to what to pick in the passive tree, what direction to take with their characters. Ascendancies give that direction, so seeing them earlier at character select screen would help players understand what stats and attributes to focus on from the get-go.
[/list]
All in all, I am having a total blast playing the game and am hyped to play it as if I was 20 y/o again. Thanks GGG for creating this masterpiece; I will be coming back to it for years to come.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055512047', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 13739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5014, 'playtime_at_review': 1507, 'last_played': 1736824567}
review:
Absolute cinema. Imagine an ARPG where the login screen alone outshines Diablo IV and that’s just the warm-up act. PoE2 takes everything ARPGs think they know, tosses it into a blender, and serves up a beautifully challenging, story-rich cocktail of decision-making and gritty combat. It's slower-paced, smarter and actually lets you play your build instead of just running a science experiment.

Gone are the days of PoE1’s spreadsheet simulator; this feels like a game again—and a hard one at that. Think “Souls-like” in spirit but still uniquely “Exile-like.” (Can we normalize that as a genre tag?) It's clear Grinding Gear Games poured all the lessons from the first game into crafting this modern ARPG masterpiece.

It’s early days, but PoE2 is already redefining the genre while looking absolutely stunning. Whether you're here for the lore (yes, it’s shockingly good for an ARPG) or the gameplay, this sequel hits the sweet spot—and maybe breaks your mouse in the process. Highly recommend.

Path of Exile 2 is A Delightfully Brutal Masterpiece

author: {'steamid': '76561199120862514', 'num_games_owned': 803, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 2694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1734014854}
review:
13 Reasons why PoE 2 is better than Diablo IV

1. Deep Customization
PoE2 offers an incredibly complex skill gem system that allows players to build unique characters with unparalleled customization. In contrast, Diablo IV has a simpler, more streamlined skill tree that might feel restrictive to hardcore RPG fans.

2. Free-to-Play Model
Path of Exile 2, like its predecessor, is free-to-play with optional cosmetic microtransactions. Diablo IV requires an upfront purchase and has a battle pass and in-game shop, which can feel like double-dipping.

3. Skill Gem System
PoE2 revolutionizes its gem system by socketing gems directly into weapons, eliminating a common frustration in PoE1. This change enhances accessibility without sacrificing depth.

4. Regular Updates
Grinding Gear Games (GGG) has a reputation for releasing substantial expansions every three months, keeping the game fresh. Blizzard's slower content release cadence for Diablo IV may feel lackluster in comparison.

5. Advanced Endgame
PoE2 continues PoE's tradition of deep and varied endgame systems, such as maps, bosses, and Atlas customization. Diablo IV’s endgame, while improved, is often criticized for becoming repetitive sooner.

6. Challenging Difficulty
PoE2 is tailored for players seeking hardcore challenges, whereas Diablo IV is designed to appeal to a broader audience, making it less punishing and potentially less rewarding for veterans.

7. Unique Passive Skill Tree
PoE2 retains the massive, intricate passive skill tree from its predecessor, offering near-limitless build possibilities. Diablo IV’s tree, while functional, is comparatively constrained.

8. Economic Depth
PoE2 has a robust in-game economy driven by bartering with various currency items. Diablo IV’s gold-based system lacks the same depth and player-driven dynamics.

9. Two Campaigns
PoE2 allows players to choose between the original campaign and a new one, providing variety and replayability. Diablo IV’s single campaign lacks this option.

10. Class Flexibility
With PoE2's customizable skill gems, any class can effectively use a wide range of skills, whereas Diablo IV ties many abilities directly to specific classes.

11. Community Tools and Integration
The PoE2 community thrives on tools like Path of Building, trade websites, and build guides, creating a collaborative ecosystem. While Diablo IV has fan-made resources, it lacks an equivalent depth of integration.

12. Graphics and Style
PoE2’s graphical overhaul aims for a darker, grittier aesthetic, resonating with fans of classic ARPGs. Diablo IV, while beautiful, has a slightly stylized approach that doesn’t feel as raw.

13. More Frequent Changes
GGG’s willingness to overhaul systems and take risks keeps PoE2 evolving, whereas Blizzard is often conservative with changes, focusing on stability over innovation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032031125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1271, 'last_played': 1734711434}
review:
A New Benchmark for ARPGs

Path of Exile 2 isn’t just a sequel to a legendary game; it’s a full-scale evolution of the Action RPG genre. Grinding Gear Games has outdone itself, blending the deep mechanics of the original with groundbreaking innovations that make the gameplay even more engaging and rewarding.

Graphics and Atmosphere
From the very first glance, the game impresses with its stunning visual fidelity. The updated engine brings the dark world of Wraeclast to life, with every location meticulously detailed. The lighting and effects create an immersive atmosphere that pulls you deeper into the grim and haunting setting. The monsters are terrifyingly detailed, and their attack animations are so well-crafted that every battle feels cinematic.

Gameplay
Combat mechanics are smoother and more responsive, adding a layer of tactical depth to every encounter. The revamped skill gem and gear systems allow for even more unique character builds, which will delight players who love experimenting. The campaign grabs you right from the start, offering a variety of missions and epic bosses, each with their own distinctive mechanics.

Progression System
Path of Exile 2 has made significant strides in accessibility for new players while maintaining its complexity for veterans. The new archetype system and improved tutorials make it easier for newcomers to dive in without compromising the challenge. The expanded passive skill trees inspire creativity, enabling players to craft unusual and exciting builds.

Co-op and Endgame
The game stays true to its philosophy of ongoing updates and support. The endgame content is rich with activities, ensuring countless hours of replayability. The co-op experience is seamless, designed for maximum enjoyment with friends. Seasonal events and leagues add layers of excitement and longevity to the game.

Conclusion
Path of Exile 2 is a masterpiece that takes the best elements of the original, refines them to perfection, and introduces a host of new features. It’s a must-play for fans of the ARPG genre and anyone seeking a game that will keep them hooked for hours on end. Grinding Gear Games has once again proven they are masters of their craft!

author: {'steamid': '76561199313625509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1734706625}
review:
For new players, PoE2’s guidance and quest design are nothing short of a blessing. The game no longer follows the monotonous "kill monsters to level up" loop. Instead, it offers a series of carefully crafted quests that not only let players complete tasks but also gradually introduce them to the game’s lore and mechanics. Each quest feels like a mini-story, connecting to the larger narrative of the game. This progressive guidance not only helps new players get up to speed quickly but also lets veteran players find fresh enjoyment as they go through the tasks.
GGG’s attention to detail in this area has given me a whole new perspective on the PoE2 experience. They haven’t just created a game—they’ve created a world full of stories and adventures. And as I progress through the quests, I’m discovering that the game world is packed with hidden secrets and Easter eggs. These rich details have reignited my passion for exploration, and every corner seems to hold a new story waiting to be uncovered.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981353644', 'num_games_owned': 1549, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 13662, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 938, 'playtime_at_review': 787, 'last_played': 1736620580}
review:
A great game for fans of poe 1 or people who never played it and are wanting a good ARPG.


A heavily slowed down but massively improved upon sequel to the first game.

My main grip with poe 1? The leveling zones were boring. All of them were 'go from a to b' trying to blast through it as fast as possible. POE 2 fixes this. Boss fights are EXCITING. You can dodge roll, you can attack while moving, you can't just faceplant into a boss over and over until it dies. The areas have optional bosses, worthwhile loot, and visually have a lot of different stuff to explore. Most areas have an entirely unique look and various unique enemies and enemy types.

Ascending, a hassle in poe 1, is a lot more enjoyable as well. It feels like I'm actually playing POE when I'm working on ascending my character, and not a 'avoid a bunch of traps and be bored' simulator like the Lab from poe 1 was.

The music as always is stellar.

The visuals are heavily improved on, to the polish levels of diablo 3 and 4 in terms of animation quality. IMO diablo 3 was the best feeling ARPG in terms of how it 'felt' (not mechanically). POE 2 is now the king of that. The game feels fluid. I can attack/cast while moving. I can dodge roll to avoid attacks. Each skills feels GREAT to use, both on a visual and mechanical level.

Also, poe 2 no longer has messing with gem links, slots, and colors. You just use things. Have fun! 

It's worth getting the early access, and I'm excited to get to end game :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197996658883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 10304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 373, 'playtime_at_review': 9930, 'last_played': 1736096683}
review:
During one of develer streams about PoE 2, GGG director once told a story, that he saw people comparing their last expansion for PoE 1 to Diablo 4, and saying stuff like "Why couldn't Blizzard deliver us as much endgame content in their full game as GGG did in their free expansion?". He then looked at their own developing PoE 2 and it's lack of a meaningful endgame content at a time, and started to shift development from campaign toward endgame activities. That happened 3 month before early acess was launched. And that's a perfect descrition of a game right now.

Campaign is fantastic. Every boss is memorable, has a unique moveset that's fun to fight against, often has gimicks and overall just pleasent to look at and fight with. There's a noticible decrease in quality toward the end of act 3, but overall it's more then solid.

Endgame has a good idea, but it's really rough as of right now. From lack of good maps dropping, to endgame bosses requiring you to grind for tens of hours to try to fight them once, with "key" item consumed on entry, to ascension dungeons being poorly balanced, to problems with meaningful loot and economy in general, as well as auction being a total junk right now, it's all feels kinda clunky. I can see how it will work if they'll fix it, eventually, but as of right now, it's kinda broken.

Anyway, campaign alone is more then wort that 30$ that you pay for base game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198833198400', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 1812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1735384164}
review:
[h1]Dawn of a new Era![/h1]


Fellow Exiles, isn’t this quite the salient moment? I know thinking clearly is hard right now due to all the hype coursing through our brains, however this is not just an extremely exciting release, it’s genuinely the rebirth of an entire genre! Many are saying that ARPGs are now called Exile-like just to spite some petty losers in another company (you know who you are), but objectively speaking this game really does redefine the entire genre, and I don’t think we’re even fully aware yet of what a momentous thing this is. But let us not waste time on words since the corruption in Wraeclast isn’t going to fight itself, I just want to congratulate the mad lads at Grinding Gear Games for coming this far and making this possible. I have no doubt that an insane amount of work and dedication went into it all, and now, from underdogs in the genre more than a decade ago you arrive at the very top and claim the throne. 

Here's your crown, well deserved! 👑



I know there are also many new souls arriving for this and tasting exile for the first time, and before I myself depart for the cursed shores of Wraeclast again, let me give you a brief overview of what you can expect from this game, so that you can decide easier if you should be playing this and if this is for you as well:

[b]Campaign[/b]
Includes a three-act campaign for early access, with plans to expand to more acts for full release later. I don’t want to spoil anything, I’ll just say it’s very dark, so if you like that kind of atmosphere, you’re gonna love it.


[b]Classes and Ascendancies[/b]
There will be six new and six returning classes, so twelve in total planned for the full release, and at the moment there are six available to play (Witch, Ranger, Warrior, Mercenary, Sorceress and Monk)
Ascendancies also return, which are basically subclasses for each class, and right now each class has 2 available, with more coming later. The available ascendancies are:
Sorceress - Stormweaver and Chronomancer 
Warrior – Titan and Warbringer 
Ranger - Deadeye and Pathfinder 
Witch - Blood Mage and Infernalist 
Mercenary - Witchhunter and Gemling Legionnaire 
Monk - Invoker and Acolyte of Chayula


[b]Skill System[/b]
Completely overhauled. In PoE1 you had to socket skill gems (which give you abilities) into gear, that is no longer the case, they are now placed into a dedicated skill gem interface, allowing for easier gear upgrades without losing skill setups (and an easier overview is more beginner friendly). Support gems (gems that buff or affect ability gems) are linked directly to individual skill gems, with up to five supports possible, equivalent to a six-link system in the original game


[b]Graphics and Performance[/b]
Significant visual upgrades with a revamped engine, and enhanced character models, animations, and environments. Not gonna lie, game looks crisp af and everything looks amazing


[b]Endgame Content[/b]
If you think that there won’t be much to do in the endgame because this game is only in early access, you’re very much mistaken. It has more content right now than some other games have after full release and with an expansion, it’s incredible. The end game features the so-called Atlas of Worlds system, which is basically a whole lot of end game zones you need to clear and you can access them when you get map items (each map opens several portals to one of the zones). In PoE1 it was a limited amount of maps you could do, but they really outdid themselves and here in PoE2 it’s unlimited. Yes, you heard that right, unlimited!


[b]Difficulty[/b]
The first game also had difficult encounters in it, but in PoE2 it gets very similar to games such as dark souls, especially the bosses. The combat is slower, but more methodical, and you get a dodge roll. Don’t be afraid if that sounds too daunting if you don’t like difficulty, because there might be challenging stuff in this, but it’s overall extremely fair and rewarding.


All in all, I absolutely recommend you to at try it. Just keep in mind that right now this is the beginning of early access, so as impressive as the immense amount of available content is, some issues are expected in these early stages, but just like the first game, this one is absolutely worth your time.




See ya in Wraeclast!

author: {'steamid': '76561197996450068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 330, 'playtime_forever': 2353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 57, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1735862278}
review:
This game is amazing, its pretty a mix of POE/Diablo/Grim Dawn and Elden Ring/Dark Souls.

It is so nice to have a Gritty and dark game in this genre again to. It is also very challenging and rewarding at the same time. Die to a boss, learn his attacks, go level up once more and get another item or 2 and come back and get revenge, its so dang fun.

The combat is great, the atmosphere is top notch, its challenging, its rewarding, the controls are great, the locations are awesome, the graphics are gorgeous, it runs well. This game is a modern Diablo 2 and probably will surpass it when its done.

Top notch stuff all around to all involved. I respect the hell out of POE 1 but I didn't get super addicted to it, but after 5.5 hours of POE 2 I am already totally hooked. It does so many things well and once again it is so nice to have a really dark and gritty game in this genre again, Diablo 2 did that best and Grim Dawn did it decently, but this game just comes in swining and gives us a modern Diablo 2 mixed with the challenge and rewarding elements from Elden Ring/Dark Souls and all the stuff we love about POE1/Grim Dawn, Diablo 2,etc..

Already so good, I can't wait to see what it is like when it leaves Early Access. Pick this one up ASAP! Just played 5.5 hours straight and I am loving it, can't say enough about how good this is.

The game is mostly all positive, so many elements are top notch, the only negative for me is I have had a few crashes to desktop so far. Fix that and I will be playing this for 1000 hours + I bet.

If you ever wanted a modern Diablo 2 game, but mixed with Elden RIng's boss fights and rewarding feeling of coming back to a boss after losing and after you have got a few new items and leveled up once and also learned the bosses attacks. To then beat the boss down, and get that rewarding feeling, then this game is for you! This is Diablo 2 mixed with Elden Ring 100%.

Best game in this genre since Diablo 2, might end up being the best ever of this genre when the game is finished to. Huge and vast improvement over PoE1 in nearly every aspect.

review:
It exceeded my expectations.
It's fun right from the start. Challenging but not too complicated and most mechanics are explained well by tooltips. There is a lot of choice and variety through passive skill points, skills, items classes and the various content available. The boss fights are an absolute highlight and I am always looking forward to the next one. I enjoy building and optimizing my characters and playing them as well.
There is still a lot more content to come and I've only scratched the surface so I can warmly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198367137515', 'num_games_owned': 434, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 3661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3, 'playtime_at_review': 2154, 'last_played': 1736299731}
review:
Where should I begin? I didn’t play the first game and honestly didn’t even know much about this series, but the trailers for Path of Exile 2 grabbed my attention right away. I kept wondering, "Is all this stuff they’re showing real?" The answer? A big YES.

The game is massive, and I mean massive. The skill tree alone is a masterpiece—it’s huge, detailed, and gives you total freedom to build your character however you want. Whether you’re into magic, melee, or some crazy hybrid build, the options are endless, and every player can find a style that suits them. That kind of freedom is just awesome.

What really impressed me was how well the game blends different styles of gameplay. It’s not just your typical ARPG; the combat feels deliberate and engaging. And let me tell you, the boss fights are on another level. One of the campaign bosses was so epic, I just sat there for a moment after the fight, soaking it all in.

All in all, Path of Exile 2 takes the ARPG experience to a whole new level. Whether you’re a hardcore fan or a newcomer like me, there’s so much to love here. Highly recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999409475', 'num_games_owned': 329, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 6725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 133, 'playtime_at_review': 2493, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1736805879}
review:
As great as this game is, It needs some serious work. Half the time you feel like your going to smash your screen. It's got a great idea, but they need to improve on things. Maps are way too big, it's so easy to die, and you don't really feel rewarded when you level up. 

It can still be fun, but they need to fix these issues to keep players around

author: {'steamid': '76561198150012984', 'num_games_owned': 556, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 7464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 821, 'playtime_at_review': 3665, 'last_played': 1736740757}
review:
Very good skeleton for what could possible be [i] the [/i] ARPG for some years. 
Perfect middle ground between D4 and PoE1, with the cool looking/feeling skills and graphics of D4 and the huge variety of builds and customization of PoE. 

Content is, and always will be, free. Each league/season feels like an expansion of D4 but for free. This is because the mtx are expensive, but they're skins for the most part. And if i keep getting free content, i don't feel bad spending a couple of bucks every once in a while.

Not enough loot/enemies at the moment (they already fixed the loot drops, but it could be better).
Campaign's good enough, unfinished right now. It's a real slog to play tho, the early game's slow as hell for my taste. 

Once you get going and understand the gameplay enough, it's really fun. Here's hoping it only gets better on the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000250527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2188, 'last_played': 1735331820}
review:
This game is vastly different from the first one. You won't be clearing entire screens with a single button anymore, it's slower, more calculated and in my opinion, very fun. If you played the first one and poured thousands of hours into it, there's a chance you won't like the change of pace. But if you played the first one and [i]didn't[/i] like it you might fall in love with this one.

Play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016498499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 26643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2279, 'playtime_at_review': 1950, 'last_played': 1736059824}
review:
I'll start by saying there's a lot of things to like and a lot of things to dislike (even hate) with the game. Ultimately, you should play a game you enjoy. Expect the game to be nothing like POE 1 and enjoy it slowly instead of rushing through content. You might even find yourself enjoying the game.

Mind you, I'm only giving my opinion based on my experience so far. 

Things to like:
-Hard - Difficult bosses in terms of difficulty. 
Yep, bosses are hard. Git gud learning their gimmicks. Similar to POE1, if you are not prepared to fight bosses, you will struggle more than others. You also start over if you die.

-Diverse skill builds - to an extent. 
Creative freedom. All skills will have different passives you can unlock. New Skill = New Passives (usually) = New buffs for your skills. The limit here is that you have to unlock new skills to get more passives and you might not meet requirements for other skills due to stats or level. (This might be a con for people)

-The Passive Tree.
Learn it, understand it, build around it, get better. (Similar concept from POE1.) You also do not need a wiki to understand Keywords like "Ailment". "Exposure", "Elemental Damage",  etc. (If i could give it a rating, I'd give it a +100) There are also new keywords like "Magnitude" and "Pin". In my opinion, this is the best part of POE1 and what gives it so much creative freedom. 

-Currency has shifted to Gold.
Gold is the number 1 currency used for transactions with NPCs. Fortunately, you tend to pick up A LOT just for killing mobs. 

-The Orb Systems have been simplified.
You no longer need to learn 50 different currency orbs. It's been simplified to 21. Majority of them, you will never see early game. 

-Refunding Passive Skills cost Gold.
Refunding passive skills require gold and not orb of regrets. Enough said. You can also use the same NPC to identify your items.

-The offensive tab to the skill menu. 
You finally get to see the DPS breakdown of your skills without using Path of Building or similar tools. 


Things to not like:
-Mobs on the map reset when you die. (This might be a pro for some people). 

-Dodging has no i-frames.
Enough said, fund to use otherwise.

-Dodging does not go through mobs.
My biggest gripe. Having no i-frames is one thing, but why can't I roll through mobs...?

-Lack of movement skills. 
Blinks and Dashes have been removed from the skill pool (not sure if they even exist). What movement abilities your character DOES have, should be taken with a grain of salt as they can be slow to cast or go nowhere when cast, or both.

-Getting surrounded almost always means death.
Getting hit by 50 things at once that will not allow you to escape = death. Also, do not back up into a wall for this reason.

-Checkpoints are sometimes placed in questionable areas.
Some checkpoints will be in the middle of a crowd of mobs. It might also be on the opposite side of the map you died in (good luck getting back!)


Things that are meh:
-Character Menu
It removed the offensive tab. So, it's "simplified" into one page. 

-Idling
Maps areas will reset if you haven't visited them for a period, similar to POE1. 

-Lost Progress
If you managed to reconnect after disconnecting or the server crashes, you MIGHT still have the same map progression.

-Gamble for gear
It cost more gold to gamble than just buying gear from the NPC that would be better for you anyway. 

-Item drop diversity
1) Rare gear is VERY rare, let alone Uniques. You will be wearing either Magic Gear or white gear for majority of your early playthrough. 
2) I can never find gear that I need for my character. (Your mileage may vary which is why this is meh. Remember, you can always upgrade your white gear)

-Limited Flasks
You can only have 1 health flask and 1 mana flask. This is a weird change in my opinion. Why can't I have two health flasks or two mana flasks like in POE1? What if I don't want to play pathfinder..?

-Charms
Charms are meh at best so far. They add resistance but have to meet a criteria based on what kind of charm they are

-Belts
Belts not having stats are meh. Belts also determine how many charms you can have at once. 

-Weapon Switching
Feels very niche early game because why would you ever need to use 2 weapons at any given point? Also, the "Weapon Skill Points" are determined by how many passive points you have which you don't get a lot when you start. (This is probably a mid-end game concept)

Overall, I do enjoy this game because it is NOT like Path of Exile 1. Difficulty scaling on bosses are fine, but the mobs resetting on the maps is also a big con. If i could dodge/move through the mobs, this would not be a problem. In fact, it would make the game more enjoyable for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000217897', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 14749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 488, 'playtime_at_review': 2049, 'last_played': 1736385443}
review:
[h1]What do I think of PoE 2 so far. [/h1]
[h2](and does it matter? Let's see.)[/h2]

After three days of diving into this early access experience, I feel ready to share my thoughts. Overall, I've been enjoying the game—its pacing, combat, and new mechanics bring a lot of potential to the table. To organize my feedback, I’ve broken it down into key areas:

[h3]Combat[/h3]
The combat has been a standout aspect so far. It feels weighty and meaningful, steering away from the mindless “click-and-explode” style. Instead, every skill feels purposeful, and combat situations demand a thoughtful approach. I’ve tried three archetypes so far - Warrior with two-handed slams, Deadeye with a crossbow, and Monk with cold staff skills - and each required distinct strategies for the same challenges. This variety is refreshing and adds to the game’s replayability.

Of course, balance is still a work in progress, as expected in early access. For example, I’ve heard casters are feeling underwhelming, particularly in the early game. While I haven’t played them yet, they seem to need some tuning to feel more rewarding.

One unique aspect I appreciate is the lack of a traditional blink or instant movement skill to escape tight situations. While this adds tension and forces careful positioning, the current implementation feels rough. The dragging mechanics, in particular, sometimes feel more like rubberbanding glitches than intentional design. Polishing these elements could significantly enhance the experience.

[h3]Pacing[/h3]
The game’s pacing is slower compared to similar titles, but I find this deliberate approach enjoyable. While some maps are enormous—occasionally feeling a bit too empty - this slower exploration fosters a sense of surprise and discovery, reminiscent of other games I like. That said, trimming down the emptiness in some areas could make the pacing feel even better without sacrificing exploration.

[h3]Difficulty[/h3]
As with combat, difficulty tuning is a mixed bag right now. Early-game mapping can be tougher than boss fights. Monsters have substantial health, surround you quickly, and their movement speed can make escape tricky - especially without reliable means of dodging through mobs. While this can be frustrating at times, I believe it’s a numbers issue. Tweaking enemy health and behavior could create a more balanced challenge without making encounters overwhelming. Personally, I haven’t found it to be a deal-breaker yet (currently at the end of Act 3).

[h3]TL;DR[/h3]
This game has been a refreshing experience that challenges players to adapt to a new rhythm and gameplay style. If you approach it expecting the feel of PoE 1 (or similar games), you might initially struggle to appreciate its unique qualities. But with an open mind, there’s a lot to love here. Sure, it’s not perfect - it’s early access, after all - but the foundation is solid, and I’m excited to see where it goes with more refinement.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971890625', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 4584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 195, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1736846050}
review:
This is not PoE.
It's not as fast, and it's significatnly slower and harder. Like much harder. However, the game is incredible, fun, beautiful, and it offer so many possibilities AND JUST IN EARLY ACCESS.
Crafting is simplier and there is significantly less loot clutter. Gold is introduced and it's a game changer. Shops now sell useful items too. My main weapon was sold to me by one of them and it's better than all the loot I found.
If you don't like diffficult games, this might not be for you. If you are, this game slaps so fucking hard. Literally

author: {'steamid': '76561197968491365', 'num_games_owned': 387, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 6147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 299, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1736169603}
review:
Negative reviews regarding difficulty level - proof that this game is not for everyone. It is hard and expects you to think and plan ahead instead of just rushing in and pressing one button.
It is not overtuned, the loot is not bad - it is purposeful. It creates meanigful choice instead of updating one item to other as you go, since you're almost guaranteed to get something. You're most likely interested in picking most of the items instead of skipping 99% of them. 

Is it very much different game to the first one and its great so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970366246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 2423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1411, 'last_played': 1734964303}
review:
Love it!

I couldn't get into POE1, but this game is completely different.
Combat is slower (less ZOOMIE ZOOMIE), more meaningful and just generally feels really good.
Loot is more scarce and forces you to spend more time crafting.

My main complaint at the moment are the ascendancy trials, they are boring and overtuned.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968329361', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 9222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4652, 'last_played': 1734982737}
review:
[h1]TLDR[/h1]

-Dont.-

Unless you know what you're getting into. In that case,

Hells Effing Do.

Someone saw Lost Ark, a Souls game, Diablo 2, and said, 'We got PoE bones. Let's make some babies.'

This is PoE2. Hard af, white mobs that will wreck your face as an appetizer for the boss fight that will turn your butt cheeks around and give you the main course.

It has the depth of PoE1 repackaged and steamlined for the new player making it easier to get into than the original in terms of understanding the mechanics but retaining much of the depth. It's a much harder start for the new player in difficulty but that forces the player to really learn the systems or get gated.

If you're a glutton for punishment and are willing to learn and 'gitgud'. This is an absolute fantastic game. If you're just curious, wait. It's currently in Early Access and needs -A LOT- of balancing and tuning (which they're quickly doing). Just wait for the 1.0 launch and enjoy it when it's more polished, it'll be worth the wait. For everyone else, this is not Diablo, Titan Quest, Torchlight, or your average ARPG, it will punch you in the face and won't ask if you want more before pummeling it repeatedly.

[h2]RAMBLES[/h2]

Before we start, note that they are rapidly fixing issues and rebalancing things. It's currently effectively beta. But I -will- rant on the current issues.

[h3]Let's talk difficulty.[/h3]

It's effing hard to start. In PoE1, a filthy casual like me can run through a couple of acts before having to learn anything about why I'm exploding all of a sudden because I've thoroughly neglected all forms of defense and royally hodge-podged my skill tree. Then because I can't respec, I reroll. In PoE2, you can respec with just gold. It's a bit expensive to completely redo a character, but it's not super restrictive leading to plenty of experimentation without worry. And if you screw up, you can farm up in a reasonable amount of time and fix a character in most cases instead of rerolling being the best option.

In PoE2, things get hard, fast. You go into the 'Den of Evil' hole of temptation very early and can get your face smashed in by the first wiggly bit. Then ya learn to use that effing dodge button and feel good about yourself until you walk into the next area and get rammed by charging doggos because dodging does not give you invuln frames for normal attacks. The process of learning is fast, brutal, and quite satisfying. Until you're 30hrs in just trying to get to the next act and the checkpoints are complete butts (they're aware and working on it) and you restart an area for the 200th time dying to a stupid rare boar with temporal bubbles and lightning fast headbutts that stunlock you into a rock.

Boss fights are amazing. It's close to Lost Ark, though not quite as good or as polished, it's very satisfying. There's a constant issue with visibility and it's exacerbated by the boss fights with multiple phase and frickin spell effects all over the screen. This leads to a playstyle of outdps'ing mechanics more than doing them properly. But the mechanics themselves are often fun and the fight arenas are claustrophobic enough for the boss to feel threatening most the time. And my god, the fight start animations, beautiful, the first 10 times. It's sped up after the first, but some could really use a little bit more of that fast forwarding.

Maps are difficult and there needs to be some balancing on drop rate because losing maps is frustration in a can. They're large, they're long, and one wrong move can put all that progress in the trash.

Enemy attack rates needs adjustments. Having a single hag spam slow whirlies and balls of doom all over the place multiplied by spawning 5 frickin hags in a single spot leads to much frustration. Telegraphs need to be clearer with so much visual noise and PoE2's emphasis on 'don't stand on thing you can't see'.

[h3]PoE1 vs PoE2[/h3]

This is not PoE1. It has the bones and materials of 1, but it is it's own game. Personally, I'm happy it's this different as those wanting to enjoy a more traditional Diablo 2-like experience can still enjoy PoE1. This is a different game for different tastes. PoE2 is a slow deliberate building towards the power fantasy. Where PoE1 starts you out strong and ends in you being a Deity-slaying Demi-God, PoE2 is like Kingdom Come Deliverence. You are a Henry. You suck. Gitgud. And by the end, you are gud, you are damn gud. It's a reward-payoff that requires time, patience, and work put in either through skills, knowledge, sheer will, or all of the forementioned to reap the reward at the end. PoE2 in its current state does not hand out free participation trophies.

This can throw a lot of players of ARPGs off, even those coming from PoE1. The difficulty curve doesn't allow for the taste of power before getting reality checked as a lot of ARPGs start with. It throughs the player right into the gauntlet like a Souls game. And that's not for everyone.

[h3]Mechanics[/h3]

This is PoE through and through. You got skills, you got modifiers, you got your three pronged defense in red blue and can't touch this, giant-ass skill tree of 'use search to find big node then figure out how to get there', map crap, boss phasing, and effing ascendency trials (worst effing part of leveling).

It's pretty damn deep, but way more digestible in PoE2 as GGG can reflect on all the PoE1 league mechanics and explain them rather than putting down the railroad track in front of the train then explaining it after the fact. There's a lot of content to explore even in it's current pre-release state.

The controller support is huge. It's not the best, but very enjoyable. Certain times it's hard to target the right interaction (Act3 NPC standing next to a bossfight trigger, items pickup priority, the effing bell for Quarterstaff being a magnet) or to target the right monster but in general, it's a good enough compromise to ease my hands of ARPG clicky-hands.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

I've had a blast dying repeatedly and screaming 'bullshit' while deep inside knowing I just need more gitgudness. There were times when the game wigs out but that's what EA and Betas are for, polish. For anyone just curious, really just wait for 1.0. What's in PoE2 is great, but it needs some time to cook. Let them cook, then feast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032432025', 'num_games_owned': 2568, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 3378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1349, 'last_played': 1734215125}
review:
Just what i wanted from Path of Exile 2.
>WASD movement feels good
>Slow paced and not ZOOM ZOOM ADHD spam teleport skills and one spell/attack with super high speed and clear mobs from entire screen then die to 1hit randomly.
>feels like meme saying but this feels like dark souls of arpg/diablo style genre games.
>hard and rewarding to win against bosses who has mechanics and not boring tank and spank
>dodge roll feels great addition unlike D4 wich is bad btw.
>setting and graphics are still grim dark wich is good
>music is also great
>voice acting and sound effects are +

But the game is still early access so only 3acts, so we are missing tons of stuff like 6 classes and their "ascendancy" a.k.a masteries and 1 of each from current classes.
So there is "coming soon" stuff in UI but there is still tons of stuff to enjoy.
Either buy now and get 30€ worth of ingame shop currency and enjoy the game or just wait like 6months when game gets 1.0 release and becomes free to play.

Highly recommend for the fans of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989933081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 5412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 871, 'last_played': 1734179982}
review:
PoE 2 is incredible. Genre-warpingly revolutionary, really. But it is definitely Early Access and needs tweaks. DO NOT play the game with the expectation that it is finished. I've seen countless people complaining about the game's balance or difficulty without giving any heed to the fact that this is a GAME IN DEVELOPMENT and needs time before it hits the right balance regarding many systems. If you buy an EARLY ACCESS title expecting no problems, you literally deserve to lose your money.

The common complaints that hold water, in my opinion:

Too few support gems are available.
Item drop rate is restrictively low.
Gold drop rate is restrictively low.
Currency/Crafting Orbs drop rate is restrictively low.

These are all real problems, but I don't think I'd recommend the game any less for it. It's early on. Give the game some time. Get in and play it now if you don't mind these problems. I certainly am having a blast regardless.

Overall, the combat is incredibly satisfying and punchy. It feels like a hybrid of Diablo 2 and Dark Souls in a profoundly good way. The way skills combine and play off each other is genius to encourage the use of a full toolkit. The days of mindlessly spamming a single button seem to be dead, thank the lord. 

The art and visuals are breathtaking, and it's running shockingly well on my mid-high end system running a 3080. It really looks like what Diablo should look like. More faithful to the concept than Blizzard has been since Lord of Destruction. The sound design is also staggeringly good. Tremendous impacts, visceral noises, amazing music. Very good voice acting, and the story is clearer and more well fleshed out than PoE 1. It clearly wants to stand toe-to-toe with Diablo 4, and I think it wins in every respect, even though it isn't even finished yet.

The steps taken to improve the intuitiveness of building your own character without build guides being required has been very successful, and made the game extremely fun and welcoming to people like me who do not want to use a build guide to get anywhere. PoE 1 failed to successfully onboard a large number of people because it was impenetrable without guides, and that was what kept me from ever sticking with it past act 6 or 7.

PoE 2 is all but guaranteed to move the genre forward singlehandedly. You can feel the love and effort in almost every part of the game. As patches hit and the game fleshes out, it's only going to get better, and it's already one of the best isometric ARPGs ever made in terms of raw game-feel and enjoyability of combat.
