author: {'steamid': '76561198009723453', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 2031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2031, 'last_played': 1718572719}
review:
To be brief, it's Divinity with worse gameplay and better polish. The nebulous term "Gameplay" is going to be the focus of this review, because my opinion is firmly stuck on that being the most important part of a game, arbitrarily or otherwise. Skip the review if you don't care.

Most D20 systems by their very design are incredibly random, and this is fine in a tabletop environment with friends where you're all going on this journey together, and the hand dealt isn't always optimal but you have fun learning about things in the process - Plus it has a DM that can fudge the rolls from time to time from behind the screen so that players doing impressive and cool things can be rewarded by just pretending that they nat 20'd or something. This, for me, does not work in a preset, unchanging environment like the one found in this game.

This isn't a problem with RNG as a whole, just the breadth of it within BG3's design, which I'd assume is a problem that arose from trying to graft the D&D ruleset exactly how it is onto a videogame, without making enough concessions for the adaptation process. Different games handle this in different ways: Disco Elysium uses a 2d6 system, so that your roll bonuses are more impactful even early on due to the smaller window of possible results, whilst also including a bunch of situational bonuses depending on prior decisions. Fallout NV removes RNG entirely by just allowing you to talk about the things that your skills say you have the know-how to talk about. D&D's "Everyone can succeed and everyone can fail" mentality is suitable for the tabletop,  but since the other characters won't really have many interactions with your bad rolls, the story can't change too drastically because of them, and the DM can't make silly things happen in response, the one true difference between this and the tabletop begins to shine through: Reloading.

Outside of Ironman modes, all of these games allow you to just fail a check and then reload to roll it again, which begs the question why any of these games even bother to have dice rolls at all, except to waste your time reloading when the coin flip fails, or more likely, to better simulate the tabletop game experience for its own sake.

Your choices only matter when you want them to matter, so you might as well install a mod that bypasses every single roll in dialogue and you'd have the exact same experience, just much quicker. There is nothing enjoyable in the failures in dialogue, there's no Harry to leap through the air flipping the double bird only to crash into a disabled NPC, there's no silliness added in - It's all very classy, it's all played surprisingly safe despite how horny it is. Granted, this isn't what fully kills the game for me, I'm not averse to CYOA books after all.

The issues of gameplay are much more prevalent in the combat, which suffers the same weird RNG problems as the dialogue (with the same savescumming possibilities) and somehow fewer options. D&D's combat system (especially 5E's) is so simple that anyone can pick it up, and play it at a table with nothing but some dice and some scraps of paper. This is great for the tabletop where nothing is automated, and it works fine in the game - It's just so unbearably dull for me.

There are so many different variables in play, about the shape of the map and where you can stand, good vantage points for ranged attacks or chokepoints to prevent approaches, there's different status ailments and a dizzying array of damage types, weird surface conditions and even the light level - But in the three attempts I had of this game, all on different difficulties, none of that really mattered. Sure it'd be cool in the tabletop to stealthily shoot out a lit candle so your opponents can't see you as well, and have a nice narrative moment where your allies can quip (even if you bollocks it up), in BG3 there's no real need to do anything other than march full speed into your enemies' faces and spam whatever abilities you like best until the rolls have determined that you've won, and then immediately long rest.

The game's difficulty and complexity are rendered moot by the wealth of perfectly viable options, the presence of more viable options at all is rendered moot by the wildness of a D20, and any differences between the viability of those options is rendered moot by the ability to reload a save and succeed no matter what. Tactician mode's combat difficulty had two speeds: Standard, and nearly impossible without savescumming, brought on entirely by when in your progress you choose to approach an encounter. It added in JRPG grinding-for-beefgates into this D&D game, without any direct indication (For the record, I'm cool with JRPG grinding, it's just strange to see it here in a game that isn't conducive to it). Tactician doesn't make the game more "Tactical", as the most effective strategy I can think of off the top of my head is to have 4 Warlocks using max range Eldritch Blast on everyone, and just praying that the hit and damage dice both roll high. If they don't roll high, reload; You weren't going to win anyway. The game never requires you to interact with all this stuff that effort went into making, is what I'm getting at here. 

Combat feels like a (weirdly easy) slog, and despite all of the different abilities and classes, none of them really feel all that different to one another. The key differences seem to be what your effective range is, whether or not you can heal, and how many times you can attack in a single turn, or between rests, everything else ends up just being variations of the same gameplay loop for every character. Maybe at Level 20 there's some secret sauce I'm missing, but the game can just not hold my attention long enough with its Fisher-Price mechanics to have me journey beyond Act 2.

It's hard to describe exactly why it's like this.
Maybe it's the hard action limit per turn?
So many buffs and alterations are full actions when they feel like they should be bonus actions. It might be the AP system alone that prevents me from having the same gripes with Divinity 2. 

Maybe it's the lack of impact or indication that all of these different damage types are actually doing something, outside of "Well that enemy looks like it's a bit on fire, so I won't use fire on it." - Divinity 2's exploding poison puddles were always good for a laugh.

The real problem is likely not with the game, but with me, and people like me who have bothered to read all this way into the review who just want games to be more engaging than they are perhaps meant to be.

I almost want to say "I don't know who this game is for" which is bizarre and hilarious since it's such a popular and well-received game; It appears to be for everybody. Its narrative has gore, violence, dark themes, sex, even genitalia on the character creation screen, but then once the nitty-gritty of the gameplay rears its ugly head, it turns into Snakes & Ladders. It's like the opposite of a mascot platformer.

If you enjoy it, more power to you, I kind of envy that. I genuinely wish I could just overlook the game's boring combat to enjoy the parts about it that are actually pretty decent - My last attempt was even on the easiest difficulty so that I could just blitz through it as fast as possible, but it was still too much of a bugbear to get over.

tl;dr
Gameplay over all. You can still have the other things too, just do good gameplay first pls. If you agree with that, skip this game.

This review implies I know what good gameplay is, obviously. Lol.

The one positive thing I can share that isn't immediately obviously present in the blue reviews is that, I'm glad that what is essentially ERPing with someone's OCs is not only more widely accepted now, but one of this game's key selling points.
We're gonna' need a bigger AO3.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972190402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 20, 'playtime_at_review': 835, 'last_played': 1736215723}
review:
TLDR: With a heavy heart, I must admit that I am not having a good time, [i]but you might![/i]

TLDR2: [b]If you enjoy the cRPG genre, this game is almost certainly for you;[/b] (and I'm surprised you haven't bought it yet in light of its near universal acclaim, why are you reading this?)

I bought this game on the back of the universally positive reception. I can see why it has its stellar reputation. [b]I believe it deserves its reputation[/b], with a caveat: If you haven't been able to get into cRPGs in the past due to the various dice-based systems, but saw the reviews and thought that this product might transcend your expectations, I think you will be disappointed, primarily due to the prevalence of a large number of dice rolls that can instantly kill you or wipe your party.

I started off having a great time, the world is carefully crafted, the characters I've met are interesting and well written. There are so many options given to the player when wandering the world, from using abilities to talk to animals or corpses to gain special advantages or insight, to (expected for this genre) skullduggery of sneaking, pickpocketing, and lockpicking your way to success.

Unfortunately, as I started to get further into Act 1, I started getting killed by the dice; repeatedly. I found an enemy lying on the ground wounded and, though the game did warn me approaching was dangerous, I was curious about what I might be able to learn from them. The game threw a dice roll at me that I failed, and my character was immediately killed, forcing a reload. I hadn't saved in awhile, so I lost some progress. No big deal, I've learned my lesson, I thought to myself, I'll just save more frequently so that I don't lose so much progress like that again. So I approached the situation differently the next time and avoided death.

Hours of gameplay passed in Act 1. I was still having a decent time, and I was especially having fun talking to people, using my persuasion and clever wits to gain advantages and access new content. I scraped past some difficult fights with enemies that I thought were fairly challenging, and I've have to reload after mismanaging a fight or failing to take something into account.

Then the fights got harder, and harder, and harder. Enemies vastly outnumber you, each enemy gets their own dice to roll against you. More dice against you means they're going to roll more critical successes, which they did, frequently. I encountered a fight near a cave in act 1. The first time I entered the area, my party was wiped on the first round. The second time I was wiped on the first round. It kept happening. Critical success rolls given to enemies with multiple attacks would kill my characters in a single turn. I tried to prioritize the heavy hitters, but could not do enough damage before they'd wipe my party in short order. I gave up and tried to approach the fight from a different angle. I was able to initiate dialog and get one of the tough enemies on my side through my social and magical abilities, and barely squeaked out a victory!

All the enemies dead: [b]Dialog was immediately initiated by the character I had earlier convinced to fight for me with the closest of my party members.[/b] This party member was not my "designated talker", failed his dice rolls, and was attacked. Several of my other characters, wounded or dying, were unable to assist. My party was wiped. Game over. The fight had lasted nearly an hour. I'd need to reload a save again. I realized I was not enjoying being killed by the dice. I felt no desire to repeat the endeavor. I closed the game, and I now leave this review.

I might revisit the game again sometime, but I suspect that this type of game is just not for me. I don't have the experience with dice-based combat that could help me succeed in situations like this, and I find the experience so punishing that I do not have any desire to "get good" constantly reloading saves to try and figure out what I am supposed to do to progress. I desperately want to experience more of this game's writing, narrative, and interesting choices, but they feel inaccessible to me; gated behind tactical dice-based combat that is punishing and cruel.

My understanding is that in actual D&D sessions, a good GM is responsible for ensuring the players enjoy themselves, in spite of the challenges they are presented. I did not feel like there was a good GM behind the scenes. I felt a cold calculating computer, looming over me with murderous intent, forcing me to reload saves. 14 hours and FIFTY quicksaves later, I am putting this game down, disappointed; and can't offer a recommendation to any of my friends who aren't already in love with cRPGs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067322700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 34846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2984, 'playtime_at_review': 28662, 'last_played': 1736846745}
review:
I have mixed feelings about BG3. The first part, Act 1, was fun and engaging, with varied choices and consequences. Unfortunately after that, the quality becomes a bit uneven. By Act 3, interactions are significantly reduced, even minimal, and some story lines become a little frayed. This was disappointing because Act 3 is the most interesting part of the game and is narratively the most important. 

Characters who are clearly dev favorites are given an inordinate amount of attention, whilst some other characters remain stuck with odd, disjunctive character development, or remain underdeveloped in Act 3. All in all, this game was promising but did not live up to the hype. 

Fantastic soundtrack and voice acting though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010710116', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 17946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16537, 'last_played': 1723928474}
review:
Divinity Original Sin 2 with D&D paint. It has great moments, but overall, it feels unfinished. Wait for the; Baldurs Gate 3: Definitive edition, if you want the best experience.

I would recommend waiting until cut story content can be restored. It released a month early, and it's still being worked on. New updates are adding content that should've been in the game day 1, but were removed due to time constraints. 

PROS:
- Great production value
- Solid voice acting
- Phenomenal soundtrack & art direction

CONS:
- Turn based combat can feel slow 
- Story content is missing in Act 3
- 'Evil' path feels undeveloped & unfinished
- Writing can feel juvenile / overtly horny

author: {'steamid': '76561198154981104', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 11810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11810, 'last_played': 1712648207}
review:
The first two acts make you want to play the game forever, but the third act makes you never want to touch the game again.
Genuinely, I love this game, and I didn't believe the others that said Act 3 is a [i]large problem.[/i] It is. I get it now. I also want to fight whoever is personally responsible for rushing this game.
It is [i]so so good[/i] but unfortunately, there are glitches that are genuinely game breaking, as in you physically cannot play the game when it happens. That and instructions and quest lines in Act 3 are... unclear at best and non-existent at worst.

Once the issues that [i]stop you from playing the game entirely[/i] are fixed, I'd be happy to change my review. Unfortunately, there are some that are even showing up as early as Act 2. Here's a little list of things I have run into that, granted, [i]I do see them trying to patch,[/i] but are unfortunately still issues as of this review:

[b]*Getting stuck in dialogues.[/b] Either you enter the dialogue and no options pop up, or you are counted as in dialogue and nothing else happens. You are simply stranded, immovable and inactive, until a team mate can either pull you far enough away to end the convo, or worse yet has to kill you to avoid having to load a save that was a whole half hour ago.
[b]*Getting stuck at 100% loads.[/b] I am unsure why this happens, but sometimes loading a save will cause the game to load to completion, and then never actually put you in the game. This one is extra annoying because the entire party will have to Alt-F4 the game or use Task Manager to kill it, because even if the host kills it, the other players are still stuck.
[b]*Bugging out when trying to assign characters to the correct players.[/b] I am unsure why this happens, but sometimes when swapping characters between people, they will both lose the ability to use either character entirely, as well as any summons attached to them. Usually the host will have to reboot the save, and pray the above issue doesn't happen.

There are also some things that don't stop you from playing the game, but can badly hinder the experience:

[b]*Fights and encounters during long rests.[/b] If the host starts a long rest before all players have successfully joined, they cannot enter the game until the long rest is completed. This also forces them to miss any encounters that happen during that time. You wouldn't think this would be so bad, as most of the encounters during rests are minor and unimportant... [i]But![/b] There are a few very *very* important ones, namely with your dream visitor. Spoilers ahead on that: [spoiler]We had this happen on the encounter with The Emperor when he reveals his true identity. The entire fight, the reveal, and the option to become half Illithid were all missed by myself, and I happen to be the one romancing him, and gunning to become an Illithid.[/spoiler] Personally, I think if there is any combat going on during a long rest that players should be able to join there... not just for what I just mentioned, but also because the host likely does not want to deal with the entire encounter with their team mates' characters that they do not know how to play.
[b]*Turning invisible for no particular reason.[/b] This one is not too bad, but it is highly annoying and admittedly really ruins the immersion and playing experience.
[b]*Animation rig glitching during cutscenes.[/b] This one could get a pass, but it is a liiiiittle distracting to try and have a serious in game conversation, romances for example, where the head rig completely breaks at the neck for a few seconds. Again, immersion.
[b]*Lack of clarity on what you are supposed to do.[/b] I am looking particularly at Act 3 for this one. I'm not expecting it to hold your hand, but some clarity would be nice. The quests in that act like to tell you some vague thing you need to go get done, and then not give you a place to start. Worse yet, sometimes it will point it out for you on the map in completely the wrong location, if it gives you a location at all. I never had to use that function until act 3, and a good couple quests give you a location that is nowhere near where the actual place you need to go is at. Other times they give you the name of a location and then refuse to give you any guidance as to where the heck that is. In particular, [spoiler]the Murder Mystery quest to locate Orin[/spoiler] really likes to tell you to go do things and give you no good direction to start looking, and infuriatingly, is non optional [spoiler]if you want to kill her first[/spoiler]. If you want to go the other route, [spoiler] the quest marker for Gortash actually points you to the passage downstairs instead of upstairs, where he actually is.[/spoiler] All of this is fine and dandy, if you are playing the whole thing in one go. If you are playing it in short spurts, you will likely forget a lot of things, and wind up on a goose chase. It really doesn't come off fun or clever to me at all, just infuriatingly annoying. 

[i][b]I want to be clear I really love this game.[/b][/i] The game just... unfortunately... degrades too badly, and quite rapidly as the game goes on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160256951', 'num_games_owned': 374, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6228, 'last_played': 1722475779}
review:
I wish I could give an on the fence rating, as this game truly is extremely impressive. But I just want to put this out there for anyone who might be like me.
I went into this game having heard tales of its dedication to immersion, how every choice mattered, even the small ones. Maybe this set my expectations too high, maybe I was unlucky, but I can confidently say that, at least in my playthrough, this was not the case, at all.

Fundamentally, the moment-to-moment dialogue writing is just mediocre. There are memorable and charming characters, but, once you reach past the surface level, nearly every character has the most predictable, bog-standard reaction to every single situation they come across. Very rarely did any of the writing wow me with wit, expression, or character. It doesn't matter what happens, from simple banter to life-changing moments to deaths of loved ones, everything feels like a bland first draft you’d jot down before actually thinking of an interesting or moving way of writing a scene. Dialogue options are very obvious with what interactions they are trying to pull you into, sometimes even presupposing actions that make no sense for anyone involved (knowledge they could not possibly have, or referencing things I never did).
This lack of quality sadly extends to the story as a whole. I simply think Larian bit off more than they could chew, as the sheer scope of what they pulled off is unbelievably impressive, but still just not enough for what they were trying to do. Rather than even “just” a 100 hour game with tighter writing and more fleshed out characters, the game is ballooned to such a scale that few things feel fully finished and it leaves the entire experience feeling messy and hollow to me. There are a handful of key character progression points, but beyond those, I rarely had any meaningful connection to my party members. At the end of Act 1, the game suddenly shovels all their character moments on you in quick succession before pulling back again for most of Act 2. Fair enough, we’re in the thick of a dramatic plot, but the generic cultist villains just aren’t nearly as interesting.
I fully intended to finish the game despite my gripes, but the moment that finally broke me was this one (kept vague for spoiler reasons):
I was going through a dungeon that was important to one of my party members. They were raving about an ideology that I did not agree with, but every time the game gave me the ability to talk to them about it, the options boiled down to “Your ideology is fucking dumb” and “Yeah, you’re good C:”
I kept hoping to reach a point where the game would let me genuinely interact with their ideology and their character, but it never happened. I’ve heard there was some flag I could have set beforehand that would have made this character more amiable in this section, but that doesn’t fix my issue. In fact, it makes it worse, confining meaningful character interactions to whether you’ve completed a set scripted quest item is the opposite of immersive (except, it likely wouldn’t have been meaningful. i have reason to believe it would have been just as boring, but the character would have been easier to convince). By the end of the dungeon we reached a major decision point for this character, one that would further cement their ideology or let them break free from it. And once more, I was faced with essentially two options. “Don’t do it, I believe in you :,C” or “Yeah, you’re good C:” I then failed a persuasion check, the character turned hostile, and I was forced to kill them. This is all extremely disappointingly bland, but I could have lived with it.
However. The entire section had no further dialogue at all. Not from any of the other party members, not during the combat sequence, nothing. When I returned to camp afterwards, not a single one of the others had anything to say about the fact that we were just forced to tragically kill one of our friends and compatriots. Not a word of acknowledgment. I realized in that moment that Larian probably didn’t intend for anyone to actually go through with this story beat. Whether they lacked the time or the resources or whatever, I assume they figured players would just reload. Well I hadn’t reloaded once to change story outcomes in the 100 or so hours I had put in because I trusted the game to respect the choices I made. And what’s the point of having die-roll fail cases if I’m not actually meant to go through with them? I’d seen other character deaths go unacknowledged before (like an entire village’s worth of named characters being eradicated. nobody gave a shit. again, probably just figured the players would reload), but not a party member’s. That was one step too far and right then what was left of the immersion I had in this story completely shattered.
If you want a videogamey romp through a DnD world, you’ll have a good time. And that is a statement fully without judgment. I had a lot of fun with the combat and exploring the various locations is exciting and rewarding as a massive semi-open-world encounter-filled funhouse.
But if you want to be genuinely immersed in the story and characters and feel like your actions are meaningfully impactful, be prepared to potentially be game-ruiningly disappointed depending on what choices you make and how willing you are to look past the gaping holes left in the decision tree.

Minor grrr to end off:
The UI is straight up baffling. Randomly, things just won't stack, like you'll have 6 of an item and then just another stack of 2 more identical ones. Sometimes you can then manually stack them, sometimes the game just refuses. You can only send things to camp sometimes. Sometimes you can't mark and send multiple things to other characters or camp. Micromanaging your characters' inventories is a nightmare, especially in combat. Sometimes you can split a stack of potions to send to another party member, sometimes you just can't. I think this all has something to do with whether you’re sending from your main character, I honestly don't remember because it makes so little sense I probably compartmentalized the trauma.

author: {'steamid': '76561198316654606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1227, 'last_played': 1710550252}
review: I mean... I wanted to love it, I've tried no less than 10 times to even begin enjoying it. I just can't, the D&D pacing is the only thing I actually didn't love about D&D so for that to be the main focus of this game just impacts any chance I have to appreciate the rest of it. If you enjoy actions being limited by how often you see a load screen or "rest" then you'll be fine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051897145', 'num_games_owned': 254, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5198, 'last_played': 1722747207}
review:
I *want* to like it... but there is just something or several somethings that really keeps me from enjoying it.

First: I am not a big fan of 5e as a CRPG. Its too simple for a deep crunch. It always leaves me wanting more crunch to bite into or leaves me wanting it to go a ton faster. I think some of Larians changes to the game help it, but it still leaves me just wanting more and not in a good way. I dont get excited about leveling up because of the lack of choices many classes have. 

Second: The companions. I think when I got to act 3 I basically enjoyed... 2 of them? When I first played this in EA, everyone was saying "oh this is only half of the companions we will get, this is all the evil ones, they will have a bunch of other ones added in the end, etc." and in the end that was kinda a lie. Basically outside of the main 5(?) the rest that are there feel even more flat and not fleshed out than the main 5. And I can barely stand the main 5. One of the biggest things I enjoyed about DOS2 and other CRPGS is the companions, they add life to the game... These companions suck away the life from the game for me. 

Three: Act 3. Yea this felt like a huge letdown. When I first got to around the time the game came out it was unplayable on my comp. Now its better, but still kinda a huge letdown. It feels so unfinished. Its the same thing with DOS2. the game is so frontloaded and goes out on what feels like a whimper. The big bads of the area feel like they barely thought them out, and I was just left dissapointed.

Four: The vibes, I dunno how to describe this but the game is very nouveau dnd. Its kinda goofy, non serious while still trying to be "serious". It has the same vibes I got while playing a bunch of dnd5e games. kinda goofy superhero character driven, while not really caring about the world, story, etc. Its just really hard to describe how I feel, but the vibes are just something I never clicked with.

I feel like there is more, like how some choices end up being non-choices and not mattering [spoiler] illithid powers use [/spoiler] and just other random things that kinda just picked at me.


I dunno overall I really did want to like it, but typically I would go back to a crpg to play a second or third time. I love playing games, but this games just really makes me not want to play it again. I just get bored and uninspired while playing it, which I feel like isnt a good thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968062093', 'num_games_owned': 386, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4139, 'last_played': 1729910785}
review:
I will say that I have given this game more than its fair shake before posting this review.  My initial reaction when the game went to 1.0 last year was not a positive one.  Yet, with all the undying praise of this game and my enjoyment of this genre, I believed I had missed something that others had discovered.  I wanted to know what that was.  So over the past year I have started, stopped, uninstalled, reinstalled, and repeated this process numerous times.  I had made over half a dozen characters and new starts and only just in this recent play through finally was able to pull myself through Act 1.

I do not like this game.

It is final.  68 hours is more than enough.

[u][b]Presentation[/b][/u]

Let me get some praise out of the way before I get to the negatives.  Firstly, this game is beautiful.  The production values are top notch.  This is by far and away the most visually appealing cRPG I've ever played.  

In terms of sound outside of voice work, it is mostly passable.

[u][b]Story[/b][/u]

Here it comes, the bad.  

I do not think this is a good story.  

Not only is the story itself not good, the way it is told is downright awful.  It is disjointed and requires you to play through in a specific way to see it told in a coherent fashion.  This is a large failing because this game prides itself on being open-ended (not exactly [i]open[/i] world) and playing through the game organically (you know, actually [i]roleplaying[/i]) can lead to some truly bizarre instances where characters suddenly do or know something that did not happen in your playthrough.  

The biggest failing with the story is not that it is just poorly told, it is poorly conceived.  The main story is a bull rush of urgency.  You and your "friends" are not only dying, you're turning into a hive-mind tentacle monster that will torture you in unimaginable agony for days beforehand.  This is what we call, an [u]emergency[/u].  [i]Everything[/i] else should be not just secondary, but completely out of mind.  Does that matter?  No.  Quite the opposite, the game actively pushes you to do side content in order to progress in this silliness.

I'm old enough to remember people lambasting Fallout 4 for a similar main quest that completely eclipsed the rest of the side content.  Why was that awful and stupid and this is award-winning fiction?

Also, the setting is D&D Epic, but with low level mooks.  Epic settings lead to boring, uninspired, stories.  Mask of the Betrayer for NWN2 is a rare exception.

But hey, at least the characters are fun, right?

[u][b]Characters[/b][/u]

No, they are not.

I do not like these people that call themselves companions.  They are annoying.  They are poorly written, they are out of place, and in some cases, they are hilarious in the conception.

Take Wyll, for instance.  He is a chaotic good warlock that fancies himself the "Blade of Frontiers", a do-gooder that is willing to do anything for the greater good.  He has slain demons, minotaurs, devils, and assorted other fiends.  [i]By the dozens.[/i]  You meet him and he is level 2.

Alright Brenil, but the brain worms de-leveled him by 18!

Mhmm...  let me tell you a little something I learned from my experiencing DMing D&D.  Characters that have epic backstories, especially at level 1, are garbagemen.  They're terrible characters, usually Mary/Marty Sues that every one else hates and wishes would meet the gravedirt.

Okay, forget Wyll.  What about the others?  Oh, they're better.  But not much.  Astarion, Lae'zel, Karlach, and to some extent Gale, are all dumb and unlikable.  I'll give Gale a pass as he's supposed to be kind of a good-hearted goofball.  Astarion?  Edgy neutral evil vampire that belongs more in Twilight than D&D?  No.  Told him to go join the boar in the bush.  Lae'zel?  I gave her a try.  She played the lawful evil Githyanki quite well.  Too bad no one likes githyanki for a reason.  I told her to get in the brain machine in the creche and was disappointed with the semi-positive results.  Karlach?  See Wyll.

That leaves Minthara, Halsin, and Shadowheart.  Halsin?  Didn't interact much outside the story.  Shadowheart?  She's the most interesting companion you meet initially in Act 1, but she's a Cleric of Shar.  In Faerun, that usually means kill on sight.  Not exactly something you should [i]emblazon[/i] on your armor.  Unraveling her story is mildly interesting but nothing stellar.  I imagine her main appeal is that she is the most physically attractive character.

Last is not a companion you can recruit in Act 1, but she can become one later.  That is Minthara.  I actually enjoyed this character the most.  After choosing to side with her, you learn more about her and I actually cared to do so for the first time in the game.  Of course, siding with her means you do some dirty deeds, but by this point in my playing this game, I hated everyone anyway.

All that said, on the whole, the characters do not help the story.

But hey, Brenil, my man.  At least the game is fun, right?

[u][i]Gameplay[/i][/u]

No, it isn't.

BG3 uses 5th Edition D&D.  I am not a fan of 5th Edition, but I knew what I was getting into and I loved Solasta.  

The game is unfun to play.  The chief reason for this is two-fold.  

First, the UI.  The UI does nothing helpful for the player.  Finding out why X or Y enemies do Z is difficult and, sometimes, impossible to do in the game.  Like so much of the game, you have to look to an external source to help with a solution the UI should readily provide.  Add to this the awful inventory system that has learned [i]nothing[/i] from previous cRPGs, and you have poor inactive gameplay.

The active gameplay is the second problem.

This game has the worst encounters I have played in any cRPG in my life.  I have played a few of them.

The issue with the encounters in this game is that Larian thinks combat should be "challenging".  That's fine, I understand.  But challenging doesn't mean punishing.

Throughout Act 1 after the encounter at the Druid grove, the game decides to get cheeky.  Not just set pieces and boss fights.  [i]Every[/i] encounter.  Combat in this game is a puzzle.  The solution, more often than not, is metagaming, exploiting, save scumming, or all three.

To say this makes the game frustrating is an understatement.  Does it make it hard?  I suppose, but the solution is usually readily apparent - if you are willing to game the system right back.  But wait, isn't this a [i]roleplaying[/i] game?  Isn't meta knowledge an anathema to playing the role of a character?  No, shut up n00b, and sneak a barrel into the enemy camp and watch go boom.

Combat in this game is very similar to another cRPG series.  Divinity:  Original Sin.  I did not like those games either.  They were serious/silly RPGs that had bizarre mechanics and a huge emphasis on big explosions equals big fun.

[u][b]Final Thoughts[/b][/u]

Look, I have been harsh in this review.  I understand this.  I have been accused of being a contrarian.

I gave this game more than a fair chance to wow me.  The game actively frustrated me to the point of anger at times.  If a game is not fun.  Why play it?

I have seen other negative reviews here that follow my thought pattern.  Most will wave their hand and say something along the lines of, "It's a good game, its just not for me."  I disagree.  I believe this [i]is[/i] a bad game.  For what is a bad game if not one that gives you nothing but grief?  It can have well-made aspects, but the whole is greater than the parts and Baldur's Gate 3 is not worth your time or money.

Hmm... wait a moment.  I just remembered.  I didn't like The Witcher 3 either.  Crap.  Maybe I am just a contrarian after all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036186781', 'num_games_owned': 434, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 7025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7016, 'last_played': 1727646205}
review:
i can understand why people like this game i really can but personally i dont,

i finished the game getting annoyed and frustrated at alot of the choices in the game, way too often the game makes u feel like its doing as u wish while twisting everything to seemingly take the control away from u

the story in this game is for me at least just not fun,
the side quests tho in my opinion are great and a highlight to the game,
but u are seemingly forced to make story choices by dice roll on the screen over and over and i get that it is something that this game is known for and some like it im not taking it away from u,
but to basically sit there and constantly see fails upon fails of some dice rolls makes u feel after awhile like the game is just working against u, especially when they put impossible dice rolls infront of u, it makes it seem like most of the things u do in it are pointless and just luck based,

i wont go too much into spoilers but towards the end the twists that come up made me lose all the rest of the interest of the story, and essentially like the game basically took a dump on all the previous effort i went thru

the enemy encounters feel like the game doesnt follow its own rules as repeatedly basic enemies will do things that u cannot do at all, so often u have to manipulate the games mechanics to beat them to me that is not fun and its just annoying,

the game looks great and runs wonderfully, has no hidden purchases to see the full story or any of that nonsense that games these days do and i commend that

im sure there are gonna be fans of the game livid that i didnt like it and say its a skill issue and all that jazz so im gonna allow the comments so u can vent ur frustration if u want,

author: {'steamid': '76561198012005087', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 684, 'playtime_at_review': 1157, 'last_played': 1736635673}
review: This will certainly go against the grain of the general sentiment about Baldur's Gate 3, but I found it soul-crushingly boring. I'm impressed by the graphics, writing, cutscenes, voice acting, and world building. But I feel that the combat system is excruciatingly tedious, so much so that it has ruined the rest of the game for me. Success or failure in battle seems to have little to do with skill and more to do with luck. If the behind the scenes dice roll isn't in your favor, there isn't much your skill can do to compensate for it. The game feels more like gambling to me and it killed the fun. I want to like it, I really do, but if I wanted to gamble I'd go to a casino.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973864561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 12601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12601, 'last_played': 1721925999}
review:
I'm going to go against the grain here.

*BG3 doesn't feel like a BG game, it's more like a DoS game (which sort of makes sense, right?), which isn't a bad thing, but it says BG on the tin, right?

* Slow AI in battles. I mean, sometimes it's ridiculous how long some of the mobs take to do absolutely nothing on their round.

* Stupid pathfinding AI outside of battles, how many times have your characters jumped off a building to get somewhere, hurting themselves, instead or taking the safe route or just plain getting stuck because they can't make a jump, again instead or taking a slightly longer route?

* Just as you think you are going to kill an enemy they stay at 1HP, and you keep missing like an idiot. Does this happen a lot or am I just imagining things?

* Did anyone else feel that the magical items, like rings and so on, felt a bit meh'ish? Am I too used to the old rulesets with general stat boosts and what not? A lot of the items felt über-specific for a character and was worthless to anyone else.

* Timed missions like The Iron Throne, almost ruined the game for a adventure/casual/exploration player like myself. On goo-goo-ga-ga difficulty, I should be able to turn timers off. I want to explore in peace. Was there any critical timed stuff in BG1 or 2?

* Like above but timed world events. Durgh. Stop stressing me out man. Take one extra rest and people die and missions fail. Urgh.

* The worst camera in any game of this type I've ever played. So many beautiful shots of inside of walls though.

* Romancing is super intrusive. Could have been handled better. Feels super-weird having a whole bunch of people trying to come on to me all the freaking time. Then again, maybe it's a role playing thing. You are a bit of a celebrity in game, so maybe it goes with the territory? Still, eww.

* Shadowheart. Am I right? You could call the game 'Shadowheart - the eternal escort quest'. I've never seen a more useless character ever. She had shield ability yes, but did she ever land a shield blow parry thing ever? No. I can't name another character whose spells missed as often as hers. What's up with that? Maybe it's a thing I should have roleplayed too.

* As usual in most games, when you play on exploration/adventure/casual/goo-goo-ga-ga difficulty like I like to, because I like exploration and quests, the difficulty ramps up way too hard when you find a boss. It goes from "Hey, this is pretty decent." to "What the hell just happened?!"

* Tails and Cloaks. Minor gripe, but still. Tails and cloaks totally slid through QC. Tails just clip.

In summary:

If you played BG1 and BG2 and are expecting BG3 to feel even remotely the same, well, it just doesn't, and it's not only because of the 3d-ness of the game. Don't get me wrong, I like the 3d-ness. It's the problem with all late sequels, I mean this game came out 20 some years after BG2. They shoes are wa-ay too large to fill, the expectations are practically unobtainable. It is not a bad game by any measure, even with my many complaints, it is not. Yet, they opted to call it BG3. They went there knowingly, sucking in people like me who thought they wrould perhaps get a whiff of that beautiful, beautiful nostalgia. Yeah, you got me again. Damn nostalgia. When Will I learn? Anyway, I am infact recommending this game, but only if you can pick it up in the bargain bin. It just doesn't feel complete yet. Maybe a few more patches? Maybe the devs are busy trying to get a DLC out the door who knows?
If you think I'm full of it, remember that I was there Gandalf, 3000 years ago. My perspective encompasses so many games. So many. So much time wasted. Oh god, I should have stayed in school. Gotten a real job.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198981206280', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 166, 'playtime_at_review': 2960, 'last_played': 1736263745}
review:
Before I start, the story of this game and the choices you have and the exploration are great.

Now for what is bad:

In order to play this game you need to have the quick save key bound to your breathing because no matter what you do it will backfire into your face. The combat in this game makes you feel like you're walking on eggshells, NOT because of how "cool" or "intimidating" something might be, but because of just how many things can go so unfavorably for you. A dialogue will end and you'll just get chain attacked and everyone in your party will die and then you realized you didn't quick save and now you have to replay an hour worth of game to get back to where you were. The ONLY way to play this game is by save scumming. You can't go into any encounter without saving before, seeing what kind of gimmick is headed your way, and then loading the save to prepare for that gimmick. It kind of ruins the whole game honestly because you end up just being worried the whole time that something is going to go bad at all times.

Not to mention every character you face is a sponge to your attacks and can dodge everything you throw at it despite having the proper level, yet your character gets absolutely decimated by (almost) every attack. Every encounter is an ambush and every enemy is needlessly hard. 

I shouldn't have to save scum and min max to enjoy your game. If this game were a tabletop like DnD people would stop playing it in 3 seconds.

author: {'steamid': '76561198276835978', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2105, 'last_played': 1734630158}
review:
Update:  Game now crashes when loading any saved game.  Also now that I am further into the game (Act 3), the Woke / "The Message" elements keeps getting worse and worse. 

Original Post: 
Larian Studios' BG3 is a very good game, and I would recommend it.  However, Larian Studios' Divinity Original Sin (DOS) and Divinity Original Sin 2 (DOS2) are BETTER, and I would recommend those games over BG3.  
WARNING: BG3 has hidden Woke Agenda / "The Message" elements in it. 

Also, the Game Mechanics can be frustrating.  Unlike DOS & DOS2, BG3 does not provide guidance on how to neutralize/counter Status Effects/Conditions (such as Acid, Confused, Muddy, etc.). 

Despite these shortcomings, I still would recommend the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000589729', 'num_games_owned': 587, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1126, 'last_played': 1719186242}
review:
I can see why this game gets such high praise; when it works, it's phenomenal. Unfortunately this "Game of the Year" is riddled with tons of bugs that ruin the experience. The two most prominent for me and my partner are:

1.)  The forever loading of a saved game that can only be remedied by a hard reset of the game.
2.)  When assigning multiplayer characters, the player characters become transparent, cannot be controlled, and we cannot access load games or use the menu which can only be remedied by....a hard reset of the game.

There have also been hollowed out dialogue options that were bugged just because and story content was missed or a hard reset had to be done.

We have re-installed the game, verified game files etc--nothing works, and but if you look online, there are tons of other people who have the same issue but their criticisms go unheard because of the overwhelming love of this game. Cyberpunk 2077 on LAUNCH ran better for me than this game. After hearing all the GOTY praises, and the comments of how this is how a game SHOULD be made, I expected more.


***UPDATE***

Posted my original review January 2024 and I tried playing again this June of 2024...same issues no updates no fixes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998063253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1695160266}
review:
As a long-time fan of the Baldur’s Gate series, I came into Baldur’s Gate 3 with high hopes, especially after seeing the overwhelmingly positive feedback. Unfortunately, after spending a few hours in the game, I find myself more frustrated than impressed.

Visually, the game is undeniably vibrant—perhaps too vibrant. The dark, gritty atmosphere that defined the earlier entries has been replaced with an overly colorful, almost cartoonish palette that feels out of place in the world of Baldur’s Gate. Instead of a deep and immersive fantasy world, it often feels like a whimsical reimagining, closer in style to Divinity: Original Sin than a continuation of the series I loved.

The writing is where the game really falters for me. Too often, the dialogue feels shallow, at times even cringe-inducing, lacking the depth and sophistication that made Baldur’s Gate 1&2 so engrossing. Rather than mature, nuanced storytelling, it sometimes feels like the game is trying too hard to cater to a broader, less demanding audience. It’s hard to connect with characters or take the plot seriously when the tone shifts awkwardly between campy humor and moments that should carry emotional weight but end up falling flat.

Mechanically, Baldur’s Gate 3 stays true to its D&D roots, and while that’s something I appreciate, it’s the overall tone and approach that make the game feel like it’s lost its way. The charm and complexity of the originals have been overshadowed by a focus on flashy visuals and quirky moments that often lack substance.

However, maybe it’s not entirely the game’s fault. Perhaps it’s a reflection of how times have changed. I’ve grown older, and the gaming landscape has evolved. It feels like we live in an era where entertainment leans toward simplicity, and audiences are more content with surface-level experiences. What once felt rich and complex has now given way to what some might call a more “accessible” approach. Sometimes, it feels like we’re living in a version of Idiocracy, where depth is sacrificed for instant gratification, and people celebrate what used to be considered basic.

In the end, Baldur’s Gate 3 may not be for everyone, especially those of us who grew up with the original games. It may resonate more with today’s players, but for me, it just doesn’t capture the magic that made the earlier entries so unforgettable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198981724872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5517, 'last_played': 1709200328}
review:
Having saved up for all the BG series, IWD/2 and Planescape new on release I'm ending this adventure early as just arrived in Rivington and that Robot Security Guardian has pushed me over the edge. 
Time to just put myself out of my misery.

Barely enjoyed any of it - hard to crack a smile at Astarion's world view when they still can't fix character path finding in a BG game despite having nearly 25 years to give it a go. Occasional bits of goodness and generally excellent voice acting, nice textures for equipment and hair but aside this is instantly forgettable fare for early teenagers who likely spend more time modelling and then stripping the rather limited array of PCs than actually playing. If they did play then they'd have more of a constructive view on BG3's limitations. 

Comments are off so don't worry about trying to defend the game. Great you like it but I think it is a limited linear campaign with too much wrong despite years in early access.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998012752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 4628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4628, 'last_played': 1733109138}
review:
It's not [i]bad[/i], really, but on the whole I can't recommend it. It's essentially a Divinity game, so if you liked or disliked one of those, that will be much more predictive of whether you like BG3 than your feelings on earlier Baldur's Gates would be.

The production values are mostly good, but a number of points dragged it down for me:
[list]
[*] The game's content is far too densely-packed, and it tries far too hard to push it at you. You can rarely proceed a single screen-width without running into numerous quests, chests, NPCs, and points of interest. This might sound like a positive thing, but it quickly becomes overwhelming; if you try to do any particular thing that catches your interest, you'll be besieged by countless hooks for other stuff. There's no sense of pacing with suitable breathers between events, and the points where you can finally feel [i]finished[/i] with a particular area and ready to move on to the next are on the scale of 10-20 hours apart. The design seems not to trust the player to engage in self-directed exploration of the world; this might be the right choice on average, but it doesn't suit me.
[*] There's no true pause available: you can go into a "turn-based mode", but that only affects a small area around your party, and doesn't work for some things. Besides being inconvenient, this further contributes to a feeling of constant pressure and overly-intense pacing.
[*] The 5th Edition D&D rules are designed for tabletop play. They're not fully suited to a computer game like this. For example, tabletop D&D has the fundamental problem of needing to keep people interested during combat when they only get to make occasional decisions between a lot of laborious calculations; BG3 doesn't necessarily have to worry about that, but the combat systems are still heavily adapted to it. (This was something of a problem for earlier Baldur's Gates as well. 2e was jankier and less deliberately designed, and — largely by luck — a number of things kind of cancelled one another out and made it mostly work.)
[*] The party members are too-clearly written according to some kind of framework or rubric. They're superficially varied, but little effort was put into disguising their similarity at even one level of analytical abstraction. Moreover, none of them have rough design edges left over, but neither do any of them have passion or a soul behind them. I've certainly read many worse characters; at the same time, I'd rather read successes and failures alike than the output of a method that produces neither.
[*] The cinematography is the same kind of garbage you see in typical modern films and television. (Based on the popularity of the style, I don't think most players will dislike it, though. I'm just being an annoyingly artsy type.)
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197989865613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3093, 'last_played': 1711750065}
review:
I like the game, the story is cool, the voice acting is cool and the combat is neeto. But there are glitches that literally don't let you progress. I thought the game was out of early access, it has so many glitches that it might as well be so. Apparently, the recent hotfix they released broke the game and they haven't fixed it for like 2 weeks. A lot of nomies like me bought the game on the winter sale so I am not a die hard person who will praise this game just cause. This game is fun, but it is so frustrating that I am constantly having to google random reddit work-around for a game that I thought would work. It's not just one glitch, I have encountered like 4 glitches involving quest items not being recognized and it is just so annoying to be dragged out of the immersion because shadowheart keeps repeating the same line about needing an item...

So at the moment the game doesn't work, as a normie I would not recommend this game until you know... it becomes playable...

author: {'steamid': '76561198040912664', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1709596393}
review:
While i realize that tastes vary across the gaming world, this one just ain't for me. The accents, characters, and story were just too airy-fairy and ethereal. Meeting with Raphael just took me out of the game entirely. Campy Disney-esque. 
While I did not come anywhere close to finishing the game, I felt like they got a bunch of renaissance fair actors together to do the voices.
The game mechanics, the fights, and the loot did keep me playing for around 10 hours. Too much frosting and not enough cake

author: {'steamid': '76561197983468372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 13026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7051, 'last_played': 1731526620}
review:
I'll downvote it until the large amount of softlocks are patched out.

The game is great, and it's good fun with friends. But it's very buggy, especially once out of the areas that were early access

Keep frequent backups if you play honour/ironman for this, because it's likely not the combat/social that'll end a run - it'll be getting stuck in infinite combat where the enemy won't end their turn, or where the game gets stuck in camp mode, or where it's stuck in a dialogue. Some of the softlocks (like being stuck unable to interact, camp, or talk to NPCs, hence the game is over) can go hidden for a good couple of hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198981107788', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 31844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31844, 'last_played': 1726269601}
review:
First and foremost, the character creator isn't all what it's hyped up to be. When I heard that people spend hours in the character creator, I thought it was going to be the best thing since Oblivion's character creator. I was sorely mistaken. You get to decide a template facial structure and then color it. How would that take hours? If you're looking for a good, in-depth character creator, don't look here.

Secondly, the game was marketed like it was a 5e video game. This game is not like 5e, it has traces of 5e in it, but it's effectively not 5e at all; it's a bastardization of 5e at best. If you're looking for a good mirror of Dungeons and Dragons Fifth Edition, don't look here.

Thirdly, this game is packed full of unattractive and undesirable romance options. As a straight male, my romance options in Act 1 were:
-A dysgenic, shady half-elf.
-An uppity, frog person.
-A foul-mouthed, rambunctious devil.
-A chronically evil drow.
The game seems to be all about "player choice", unless your choice is something vanilla, like a normal human female for your normal human male. The closest "vanilla" choice you can get is a very untrustworthy half-elf who's extremely dysgenic. If that's the most vanilla you get, that's really disappointing.
Furthermore, along the lines of my previous point about player choice, this game has such a strong focus on degeneracy, that it lacks in the good morality region. This game allows you to have sex with a bear as well as a certain aberrant creature, which I will not disclose for those willing to stoop to such a disgusting level.
The next point following the last, the majority of origin characters have the same ideals: "Muh freedom and liberties." This game puts such a keen focus on hyper-individualism that it teaches a bad lesson to the youth who play the game.
If you're looking for a game that allows real player choice and a game that doesn't try to shove degeneracy down your throat, don't look here.

Continuing on, before I got the game, I was being told by countless others who already had the game, "Oh, I'm 120 hours in and still in Act 1." 120 is an example from one of the people I've talked to, but the average was right around there. So I was hyped for a content-filled game—a game I could sink more hours into than all the Skyrim I've ever played on all the consoles and PCs I've ever played it on combined. But that was far from the truth. I played the game at a leisurely pace, exploring all the side quests I could get my hands on and seeking out any secrets I could find, and I finished the game in 45 hours. Looking back at the people who are 120 hours into Act 1, I question their mental processing skills. Do they sit on one dialogue option for days on end? Do they seek to count every blade of grass? So if you're looking for a game that you could sink hours into, comparable to Skyrim, in one play-through, don't look here.
I've played for 113 hours due to all the multiplayer, and I'll get to that.

Lastly, multiplayer. If you're here for the story and to enjoy the plot, multiplayer is not the right option for you. Multiplayer in this game is far more fun when you know the story and the content and just want to mess around with your friends. If you're looking for a game where you can sit down with friends and do the story together, don't look here.

In conclusion, if you peel back: the poor character creator, the 5e bastardization, the degeneracy and lack of player choice (unless you're a degenerate), the mediocre amount of content there is, and the need to do a singleplayer run first before you multiplayer, if you simply ignore all the political agenda of Larian Studios that gets shoved down your throat and don't think of this game as D&D inspired, then yes, I will admit it is a pretty fun game.
It is quite a hefty task to enjoy the game.

review: great game, absolutely ridiculous amount of errors, crashes, bugs. Amazing that you can release something this incomplete and broken. Fought tooth and nail, dealing with the crap because of the excellent story. But now another crash, and back to weeks worth of progress gone. So essentially I cant finish the game without starting over, no fix, no patch.  Redoing from old saves lead to more crashes and bugs. But they've got your money, so no big deal. Such a shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972376555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8647, 'last_played': 1711919251}
review:
Not for me. I bought this because of the game of the year hype, but it's just tedious. If you want a game where your imaginary character can have fake sex with another imaginary character....I guess you'll have fun. The camera is annoying, jumps all over the place and is never where you want it. The combat is tedious, battles take forever. 

The worst part are the gotcha moments where a choice you make screws up a critical part of the game later on, and makes it 9x more difficult. Also the lack of save points can cost you hours if you're not constantly save scumming.

If you really love D&D and the whole dice roll thing in combat you'll probably like it. Excellent graphics, sound, and voice acting, but I got tired of it after 140+ hours and didn't bother to finish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051504963', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 17549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12787, 'last_played': 1721794365}
review:
Not just no, but I would rate this 2/10 stars.

I know... GOTY and all. Bazillions of positive reviews! Just who tf do i think I am?

But seriously. I waited for full release and multiple patches to get and play the game, waited until I had seen a number of positive reviews from people I trust, I and I still ended up with this disappointing, half-finished, buggy mess. I get it - the game was highly anticipated for a long time and a lot of you are just happy it exists at all. But you really deserve better. Here are my top three reasons for the big old nope on this game:

1.) "It's so easy to explore because the game is so freeing!" It's not. Not even a little bit. In fact, the only way to play this game without getting frustrated and/or wasting huge amounts of time going back and redoing sections is to do the complete opposite and follow a player-made walk-through. Turn the wrong direction and you're screwed out of a bunch of content. Click the wrong thing and you're screwed out of a bunch of content. There is a very deliberate order of events in this game, and if you don't follow the script exactly, you're doomed to miss a huge chunk of playable content. And there are no warnings for any of it. I had to restart my game twice just to get one of the origin characters in my party. Not everyone has the time or inclination to play a game 25 times just to see/play everything because the game was designed so badly to begin with.

2.) When I would get stuck and go to look things up, the responses were almost always "yeah that's bugged, you have to go back and redo it this one specific way" or "you need to install a mod" or people hoping the broken/unfinished thing would be fixed in the next patch (they weren't). This includes everything from the game's actual controls and UI, which are so awful I nearly quit within the first hour of playing, to the storyline, which most people feel is unfinished or tacked on in a lot of places. Once I caved and put a few essential guality of life mods in place, I would bump the rating up to a 6/10... which is ridiculous. Poor game design is relying on modders to do the bulk of the work for you, especially when there's only so much they can do to fix the broken stuff.

3.) Inclusiveness. The game was heavily advertised as super inclusive, but it's actually "sort of mildly inclusive" I guess I would call it? You can be gay and swap genders in the game - great, you can do that in Stardew Valley, too. You can also be non-binary - a step up from Stardew Valley! You can design a character with an appearance free of traditional gender constraints which... this is a fantasy world so should have always been a thing, but whatever. Of course, none of this has any bearing on anything until you get to relationships in the story where you are automatically locked into a very traditional sex-driven romance. If you do not cultivate a romantic/sexual relationship with anyone (and many characters are very pushy about having sex with you, btw) you again miss out on large chunks of the story. That means if you're asexual/aromantic, not only do you have no relationship options in this game, but you're also punished for your choice not to engage in something problematic for you. One character will even go so far to "mom at Thanksgiving" you about why you're not in a relationship yet. It should have been the easiest thing in the world to make some of the "romantic" scenes into "bestie" scenes when you reach high enough approval (insert comment about how even Stardew Valley does this) but nope. If you want to get any insight into a character's back story, you will watching a sex scene play out and you will like it. (Wait, how can you not like it - everyone else likes it!?!?!)

I'm determined to finish the game because of sunk cost (time) and also sunk cost (money) - it ain't a cheap game, after all. But I am genuinely disappointed with this one, and honestly, a lot of the hours I show as played were when I left the game on pause while I wandered off to do laundry or wash dishes because that seemed more interesting and less frustrating that continuing to play. Plus the constant redos and wasting time trying to organize stuff because the UI is so clunky... I would say my actual playtime is about a third of what Steam shows.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112144216', 'num_games_owned': 160, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 21574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 29, 'playtime_at_review': 20892, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 8792, 'last_played': 1736764994}
review: Loved this game to bits. But every update makes the game worse. I can't even boot it up anymore. Won't progress past the first loading screen. Even after scrubbing it of all the mods I've installed. It just doesn't work now. Thanks Larian.

author: {'steamid': '76561198451698097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 25824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16114, 'last_played': 1715393371}
review:
I find myself replaying the first act more than just finishing the game. There's a lot left to be desired from the character building that BG3 seems to lack. I am not saying its a bad game, I am saying it was not ready to be released the way it was. I really enjoyed DOS2, and I find myself wanting to play that more. I think Early Access is going to be the same with most games, where developers focus on what select group of people want rather than telling the story they should tell leaving a lot to be desired. Now, we have so many unsatisfied players in the community because this NPC doesn't receive the same attention as another NPC. I think early access is a great tool for getting rid of bugs and the like, but when the first act was worked on leaving 2 & 3 left unpolished after release, it feels wrong. 

My first play through of act 1 in early access was incredibly enjoyable, and I looked forward to seeing the second act but I feel like the intentions between act 1 and 2 were quite different. I also feel like the story took a different turn then what i was expecting. A lot of things were changed. 

All in all, I want Larian to start making stories without the input. Like older games, they were just games and you played them, and that was it, you didn't really have a say in every single detail you know? Perhaps the next game they focus on they return to their roots, that's just it really.


EDIT: I finally finished the the entirety of the game. I personally struggled with the last act the most, so while I had my criticism of Act 2 being left unpolished with act 3, I did like act 2 a lot more. Act 3 kept pulling my attention in every direction that it was a whiplash. I was constantly worrying about what I should do before being locked into the end. I enjoyed the epilogue and I think my good!durge had a satisfying ending. I'll replay this in about 5 years from now and see how it is. I do this for all my rpgs. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561199480967503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 18327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10596, 'last_played': 1709019149}
review:
Such a tedious game, I was expecting so much better with all the good reviews and awards.  I dislike RNG in general, but to have the dice shoved in your face like this really has me checking my calendar to see is it really 2024?

And if all the tedium (running back to camp, running to a vendor to sell stuff, etc) doesn't annoy you enough.  If all the dice rolling (Miss, Miss, Miss...) doesn't take you back to the 80's.  Guess what, now you get to feel like a real loser as you try and avoid your characters having sex with each because you actually have a sex life irl and aren't playing a game for soft porn.  Yeah this game sure deserves a lot of awards...

author: {'steamid': '76561198034014918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 6548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2853, 'last_played': 1733975116}
review:
I recommend waiting. The game has nice graphics, multiple engaging choices and fun combat, and the story so far is okay. But it’s also still bug-riddled even in Act 1 despite a long time in early access, and the user interface is terrible and under-explained, so if you’re on the fence or waiting for a sale, I would advise you to keep doing that and hope for quality of life upgrades.

I’m sure this will turn into a positive review eventually, but so far I don’t find that the game deserves an Overwhelmingly positive rating or warrants its price tag for what still feels like an in-development title.
