author: {'steamid': '76561198007243210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 34050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 16, 'playtime_at_review': 26844, 'last_played': 1735847428}
review: I love this game. I have Played and DMed for over 40 years. I played all of the Baldur's Gates and this is an amazing game... I DM 2 5e games curently. This game will teach you some of how to play and how the mechanics work. If it doesn't crash as you load up the menu. I worked with their tech support for months doing avery thing they asked and in the end they said the problem is my processor... I replaced it and it still crashes as the menu loads. This started about 4 months after release. The RAM ramps up to over 20k, and then the game crashes. I have replaced my processor, RAM, motherboard and Harddrive, and same problem. I cannot in good concious assume I am the only one and that a patch will resolve the issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989580468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 795, 'last_played': 1695604819}
review: I am old school D&D, played since the late 70's.  I don't care for the characters nor the story line.  I enjoyed the original Baldur's Gate game, but this story line is too Mary Jane and the characters are not ones I would want to adventure on a table top RPG.  Right from the beginning it is a linear story, starting with eldrich characters far beyond a level 1 would associate, leading to god like powers etc.  I knew I would have characters of 5e that I am not favorably inclined, but having almost every NPC basically turn out to be villains has made it not something I can get into.  I would suggest to anyone looking to buy, read up on the storyline and characters and see if this is what you want to play before making the purchase.  If this is what you like, you will most likely enjoy this game immensely.  Otherwise, find something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009011774', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1705953064}
review:
I don't understand the hype and love for this game.

This game is a beautifully presented D&D setting, where the DM is a bratty teenager who'll happily tell you that they've  read the whoooole campaign setting and the dungeon master's guide, and thinks that 'fun' is what happens when the players roll bad and die 'because the rulebook says so'. 

It's DOS2, but with an entirely RNG-based system that doesn't work when you don't have a DM to cobble together an entertaining experience out of your group's failures. 

It's a very nicely written Choose-Your-Own Adventure book, where the whole thing could be vastly improved by excising the 'gameplay' - aka random dice rolls - from it entirely and putting the (clearly well put-together) story back in the right order. 

Combat is the worst part, which is bad I imagine because it probably provides the most core gameplay for most people. I haven't reached the end-game (and probably never will), but the current combat loop is: cast a spell, miss, repeat until you run out of spell slots. Go into close combat and repeatedly miss opponents, even if your meaty, melee-build half-orcis a higher level with better stats than their wimpy ranged goblin. Get beaten. Reload, then savescum the preceding dialogue check to avoid the fight. Repeat. 

If you're the type of person who likes to min-max your D&D character to breaking point, you'll have the opportunity to do that here and probably love it. If you're like me, and you want to consistently roleplay a character, as part of an experience that's curated to be enjoyable for you, then consider finding find a D&D group. If you're after a beautifully-designed videogame with a reactive world that has actual gameplay in it, maybe play DOS2 or The Witcher 3 instead?

I know this is controversial, but I love D&D, love DOS2, and wanted to love this game - but I think it actually might be my least-favourite game in years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071510648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 27791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21427, 'last_played': 1735523355}
review: I lost my honour mode save twice to fatal errors and bugs, once at 15 hours played and again at 45 hours on my next try. The game isn't stable enough for anyone to fully enjoy its features, and I'm losing my motivation to keep trying, let alone recommend the experience to anyone else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048963871', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5937, 'last_played': 1699124434}
review: Gameplay is good, writing is terrible. Mindflayers should be an interesting cosmic horror but they are relegated to mindless goons/monsters. The true plot also should be interesting but by combining it with a mindflayer invasion, they dilute and ruin both potentially great story lines. Character writing feels like cringe fan fiction as all the edgy "hot" characters are chomping at the bit to be with you for just treating them like a decent person would. Meanwhile the actually decent written characters don't seem to get close to you even when applying all the effort. The game spends several story threads talking about far more interesting incidents in the past that I would much rather engaged in than wandering the woods for the umpteenth wondering what exactly I'm doing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970809070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 15340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 946, 'playtime_at_review': 4289, 'last_played': 1736653583}
review: Good graphics, great story line.  Enjoy the world building.  Crappy UI, the original Baldurs gate from the 90's had better camera/navigation system.  Combat is frustrating, especially boss fights.  You either save scrum or hack the game with cheese solutions.  Lame.  Boss battles really break this game.  High levels of frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058507648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 196, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1735866408}
review:
I'm honestly surprised this game was rated so high. The game is incredibly slow. Battles are too costly and not frequent enough. The battle mechanics take forever and the chance to miss is far too high in my opinion. The character and npc graphics are outstanding but the environment is underwhelming. I thinks they should of done a better job of walking you through the all the elements of the game like resting, camps, character development (especially how spells work). 

The game is better when you play on a mouse and keyboard rather than a controller. Which is tough for me because i am an amputee.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017807939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1719174740}
review: Maybe my hopes were too high, but I found the games controls and camera very stilted and combat was not intuitive.  Graphics are beautiful and the story felt like it was going to go somewhere but just couldn't get back the controls and combat.  I ended up asking for a refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010447907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 4700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4696, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1733456816}
review:
It's basically a shitty dating sim with bad combat mechanics. They prove that by making sure you got to see the bear sex in the showcase and tons of their updates were more romance options. 
None of the characters are like-able and all seem to be shallow parodies. The only thing you see people talk about is Karlach and only about her personality. No one ever talks about the story and I swear no one has gotten past the first chapter. They play long enough to do Karlach and that's it. 

Many people say it's a great game...but when you ask what they like about it, they can't tell you anything at all. They just say "oh it's good". This game is nothing at all like the first two, where the characters were not the sole important thing in the game. The city of Baldur's Gate wasn't even the most important thing but you'd think it was the ONLY place in 3 because NPCs won't stop talking about it. 

Combat is god awful, where the enemies get to go 3-5 times in a turn and you barely get even one action. All the dice rolls are terrible even with high skills. Where you should realistically get a successful roll, you more often get a bad roll, under 10 when you need 12 or something. Dragonborn were a joke and just rushed into the game. 

The multiplayer aspect isn't very good either. You better make sure the talker is the first person to go anywhere cause if they aren't, some other character will trigger cut-scenes and more often than not, you need to reload because it isn't the person that can succeed skill checks and you can't choose who talks to people. Also, why bother using one of the companions as your avatar character? You literally lose out on all their special dialogue and their voice acting. Conversation cut-scenes are awkward just staring at your character making stupid expressions. 

I like Larian. The Divinity games were stellar...but this game isn't even close to the mark.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081048536', 'num_games_owned': 1308, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 4021, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1519, 'last_played': 1734303638}
review:
The opening of the game is a lot better than Divinity Original Sin 2 however it falls so short so quick I genuinely can't believe that this is what the hype is about.


The combat is probably my biggest gripe. The 5e system is ass, it's too simple to the point of being mundane comparison to the Divinity system or Pathfinder 2e with it feeling like everything is very limiting. In terms of how it plays outside of that, the AI path-finding is awful for allies as they walk around ally spaces to waste actions even though if I baby them through it you can comfortably fit next to them and they're all so determined to walk into attack of opportunity. It also is extremely annoying when I'm sneaking attacking as a party, going into turn based mode and after the first hit is struck every single enemy has a higher initiative than the rest of my party.  Pushing is an extremely useful bonus action as it can create space in between you and an enemy unless the game feels like your successful roll means fuck all and just doesn't move them even though the blue lines says that they'll be sent flying. 
They got rid of a few arrow types from Div2 which is a bit weird.
Scrolls don't feel as powerful.


I feel like choice isn't as open in this game as it seems and as it's a video game will always go to combat, [spoiler] my triggering example is the Hag encounter in the swamp, if you get to her boss arena and sneak the woman out of the cage without being noticed nothing happens. No cut scene, no dialogue, no way to get her out until you start the final combat with the hag. Why bother having the cage interact with you if you can't do anything before combat? [/spoiler]

VAs, the performances are good but I hate the party members, just not as charming as the Div2 guys and gals
Graphics are good
UI feels slightly better than previous Larion games


Can't comment on the overall story as I didn't and won't finish but the world building through the map is very engaging and is the only reason I want to continue playing but I might as well just watch a playthrough as the experience is not enjoyable for me. 
For reference I got past the first map, the underdark but got fed up at the shadow cursed lands, skipped to the mountain pass but lost motivation.

TL;DR - Divinity 2 set the bar too high.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053252712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 4739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4739, 'last_played': 1719760305}
review:
How much is too much? 
I like games, I like RPG games and I like Larian games, but I do not think I like BG3.

The game meets every requirement to be the best:
* A good world setting
* Interesting characters
* An interesting and complicated plot
* Good graphics
* Good system

But there are two things that spoil it:
* The setting does not work good with the plot. It is just not a forgottern realms kind of plot. Both the gameplay and superb for divinity series, but it clashes with Forgotten realms theme.
* The tempo is failed. It takes to long for the plot to develop so the player just looses the interest. It was a problem in Original Sin serries, but here, it is much worse. The number of characters and side plots i so large, that it is completely impossible to navigate withot quest log. And all of those are important.

I played to Act 3 and decided to put it away for a time.

The game is acrually great. But there are flaws in it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045913600', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 6991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4195, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 4193, 'last_played': 1730129888}
review:
why have i not heard *anyone* talk about how unacceptably buggy this is? i don't think i've had a single play session without encountering at least something unintended. it's not a bad game by any stretch of the imagination but my god do the constant glitches make it hard for me to recommend. it's over a year old now so there's little excuse for it.

it's little things that add up, like quest markers being in the very wrong place, movement sometimes provoking opportunity attack despite saying it won't, some actions like jumping or specific attacks just not activating AT ALL!? this is shit you fix in a day 1 patch.

game starts off strong but there's really not much variety, half of main cast are elves and a quarter are humans, most with the same morals...... in my Anything Goes Crazy Fantasy Races game. i swear more than half the combat encounters in this game are generic undead hordes, act 2 is especially bad for it. most the dialogue options boil down to The Good Choice and The Evil Choice.

6/10 i guess, gets my "sure, try it out if you're interest" of approval :/ again, it's not a bad game, if the infuriating bugs were patched i'd probably bump it up to at least an 8/10 but it *has* been a year since launch. we'll see

edit: switched from recommend to not recommend because i got to late game and it's all just fucking luck. every strategy requires immense save-scumming or a myriad of walkthroughs. all my charity for singing this game's praises have burnt out. solid act 1, kinda boring act 2, irredeemable act 3. alongside the unacceptable bugs is a horrendously unbalanced game. pick a struggle

author: {'steamid': '76561198376720957', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 19327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8389, 'last_played': 1734403914}
review: The game has too many bugs that interrupt the immersion. After 140 hours of broken quests and clumsy interactions, I had enough. I can't "feel" the world of the game and I do not care about its inhabitants. I don't even go into details about game play, storytelling, animations etc. (which are problematic too) because in order to talk about those details one would need at least a functioning game. It's simply a buggy and incomplete product which is sold despite everyone reporting bugs left and right on forums. I personally know of people who had to restart the whole game after reaching Act 3 because of a fatal bug. And the game was awarded GOTY. We live in strange times indeed when a broken game is the best the industry can produce. Let's hope that it will be playable in a couple of years. Disappointing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198963684465', 'num_games_owned': 143, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4169, 'last_played': 1723880994}
review:
I wish there was a mixed review option for steam games. The game overall i would split into different segments:
Story/storytelling, Combat and general experience from the game.
As a Dungeon Master and a player of over 3 years in mostly dnd 5e and also other options like pathfinder i decided to buy this game to play through summer since it won the game of the year award. And i have to say that i found the game frustrating at times, whether it was unbalanced combat (either having to repeat the fight multiple times or sweeping through the encounter in the first 2-3 turns) or having no wiggle room for the dialogue, usually ending in a fight or a "morally bad" option. The biggest drawback for this game is the lack of a real DM. There is nothing balancing the encounters or allowing you to do stuff which usually would not be considered predictable. 
I loved the story and all the world building done, it really was a good written story, i've enjoyed all three act's more or less the same, but the quality of the game degraded over time. Ranging from drastic frame drops to bugs which caused me to roll back to the last save due to not being able to play. The third act felt generally not polished with a 50% decrease in fps from the previous chapter.
Then we get into combat... and here my opinion is very critical. It was adapted almost if not entirely from DnD 5e, however the main problem is that the open ended creative combat in dnd 5e was not made for a video game, or at least not for this one. In many areas you have to fight hordes of enemies ten times the size of your party. This causes the encounters to be very unbalanced, you miss most of the hits you make at first which causes you to get slammed in your fights and forces you to pray to RNG gods for a good roll.Another thing is spell slots, which are a good limiter for magic when you get one, maybe two major encounters per rest, this didn't feel like the case for me, even though there really isnt any drawbacks from long resting it feels unbalanced and out of character to do one fight and go back to your camp (wasting camp supplies) and reentering with renewed stats. Later on in the game i managed to wipe most of my encounters in no more than 2 to 3 rounds which just felt cheap and boring making the combat more of a punishment and not an enjoyable mechanic. There also are limitations to many of the game's spells and actions. In a normal game of dnd players get creative, this game has very limited interactions you can do with spells and such. Another thing is that the game is unforgiving and often buggy, that causes you to lose turns or spell slots because you simply were bugged by a game, and it doesnt really feel fair. Most Dungeon Masters often smudge rolls, give players a fair chance in an encounter or simply improvise when a bard starts playing his lyre in the middle of combat and rolls a nat 20 on performance. Here the game is cold hearted and unforgiving, if you do not save every 10 seconds that is. Another mechanic which just ruins the immersion and any chance of story depth, quicksaving. You can save at any moment in the game and if something does not go your way just press f8 and restart to the point where you were safe.
My overall experience with this game left me disappointed. Due to countless glitches and unbalanced encounters i did not have a great time with the game and kept playing to give it a chance hoping for it to get better later on in the story. I also dislike that most things won't matter at the ending, you can change with whom you end a game or which way do you end it but mostly all options won't have an impact until the final act.

Another thing is that it appeals to the modern day TTRPG player, firstly your camp is basically a harem. then most of the players will get zero consequences due to quick saves and of course the main character syndrome, which if a player moves to dnd or other games will be hogging the game from other players or just misbehave when playing. Personally i just feel cheated of my time with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199071491906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 990, 'last_played': 1718151923}
review: for me its hard too see this games bad camera angles and the majority of this game is just exploring rooms and nature. it shouldve just been like the last 2 baldurs gates with fixed cameras but instead youll waste hours spinning the camera in circles trying to explore every building. actually a first person view would bring me back to play this but as it is this bad camera turned a 20 hour game into a 80 hour game. ps3 quality graphics too and really bad outdoor environments and lighting. Im not sure why this game is even popular, its a mess and the pathfinder rules its based on are the worst in the d&d series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140952046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 911, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 864, 'last_played': 1722074794}
review:
I'm old enough to have played the isometric RPGs of the 1990's and early 2000's. I like these types of games, and I was quite hyped about something that scratched that itch. However, this aint it. I know I'm in the minority here, but I genuinely think there are parts of the design of this game that are just flawed.

The mechanic where abilities have a set number of uses before you have to rest, rather than having a cool down, is something brought over from the tabletop RPG. And it works in a tabletop context because the focus is on doing scenes, you usually don't put that much time into role playing walking from one scene to another. But in a computer game, where you play the uneventful parts as well, it just becomes another resource management chore. I get that they want you to have conversations with the companions in camp, but it feels very contrived and kind of breaks the flow of the game. 

Having dice rolls determine the outcome of situations is great when done right, like in [i]Disco Elysium[/i]. But for this to work, the result of failure has to be interesting in some way – it has to lead to character development, or progress the story in another direction than the one you expected. In a tabletop RPG, this is what a good GM does since save scumming isn't an option. But in BG3, failure mostly just leads to getting stuck or having to fight lots of enemies. Not once have I encountered a situation where a failure led to something interesting, funny, or story progressing. 

The companions suck for the most part. They're all rather one-note, and half of them are just grumpy assholes. I don't care about any of these characters, I have zero investment in them. Overall, the writing is pretty weak. The setup is rather rote and heavy handed, there's no sense of intrigue or mystery here. Why even have the big fight playing out in a cut scene, why not just have my character wake up in a broken pod with memory loss and then having to puzzle together what has happened (kind of like in [i]Planescape Torment[/i])? The quests mostly boil down to "kill this guy", at times using persuasion or stealth to kill them without having to fight quite as many minions. In act one, you have a situation where there are three leaders you have to get rid of. There is no way to play them out against each other, no way to poison them, no way to convince them their cause is doomed, no way to turn their underlings against them by framing them for something bad… In the end, you more or less have to fight and kill every minion in that location. And it's simply not interesting. 

As far as I can tell, my character has zero friends and zero attachments to the rest of the world – there are no old friends, they haven't been to any places before, they didn't have a job or a family or anything really before they ended up on that ship. Your only motivation is to get the parasite out of your brain, but because we haven't really seen anyone turn into a mind flayer it doesn't really feel like a pressing issue. The whole ilithid powers thing could have been interesting had they done something like what [i]Vampyr[/i] does, where giving in to the urges will make the game easier but also makes you lose more and more of your humanity. But there's none of that here, it's just a random super power that your character has because plot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009771324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 22055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7054, 'last_played': 1714033016}
review: Whomever was in charge if the bugs on the main quest should never develop a game ever again. Mid ways, or so i assume it's midway, through the game you need a small item to advance the main plot. No big deal. It drops from an NPC you can kill or otherwise defeat. Does it drop on his body? No. Loads of people on forums and reddit and anywhere people gather to help one another through the game, peolpe have the same issue. you can't find the little trinket and can't advance the main quest. No one should buy this game with a flaw that won't allow you to finish the main quest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052353167', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1032, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1731035332}
review: Really want to like this game but I just can't get over how incredibly boring the combat is. Turn base combat takes forever and absolutely kills any momentum I have going into the game. Every session works the same - I log in, I explore, I get invested in story, I get into a big fight that takes 30 minutes and I'm so bored by the end that I have to turn it off. It is indeed a faithful adaptation of 5e table top rules but combat has ALWAYS been the worst part of any table top rpg and that continues into this adaptation. Maybe I'll watch the cutscenes so I can enjoy the story but good lord is this game unplayable with it's current combat system.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992190187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 3968, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3968, 'last_played': 1732599920}
review:
Auto-save frequency is too low and no option to pause the game (in single player of course). 
It's a great game and I have a lot of respect for the Larians, but a car without a steering wheel doesn't do much. 
I just don't have time to keep playing the same sections over and over again. I'm probably about 1/4th into the game and I've player everything about 3 times now. The repetition starts wearing me out.

Why do some developers keep overlooking the most basic features or somehow think their game is the most important thing in our lives. NO, I want to go take a leak without having to worry that I'll have to replay the last 2 hours, I don't care about your online features or whatever reason you have for not being able to freeze the game.

Great game with a few dealbreakers for me. Sorry

author: {'steamid': '76561198052833570', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1578, 'last_played': 1726257383}
review:
I really tried to enjoy the game but I couldn't. 

I've played the previous editions and related games, all the Bethesda RPGs, and many others, and I liked them a lot. I loved Planescape Torment. But I feel like this game is a burden. Even in its easiest difficulty, it's still far too hard, stressful and frustrating. Enemies are twice as numerous as your party, of higher level, and call for reinforcements !?? Not what I signed for, and doubling my HP won't change that. Each fight feels like there is some sort of  super-secret strategy to handle it correctly, but with no tutorial and a steep learning curve your only choice is either watch spoilers or keep dying until the dice roll right.

Beside that, the game asks a lot for skill checks that dramatically change the story, basically forcing you to save before every dialog, or suffer consequences. Having to repeat almost every dialog is not my kind of fun.

I understand the hype, the game is beautiful and certainly is a labor of love, but to me it's not enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996729863', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 61003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2336, 'playtime_at_review': 42542, 'last_played': 1736812685}
review: The game is very good but it's obnoxious that 6 months after the release there are STILL multiple game-breaking bugs + with every new patch Larian delivers more new problems than they fix.

author: {'steamid': '76561199006215546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2931, 'last_played': 1723163289}
review:
I recognize that Baldur's Gate 3 has received widespread acclaim and has undoubtedly made significant contributions to the gaming industry. However, despite its popularity, the game doesn't resonate with me personally.

One of the main reasons for this is the characters. While I appreciate the effort put into creating diverse and complex personalities, I find the majority of them to be annoying and insufferable. This made it difficult for me to engage with the story and invest in the character dynamics, which is crucial for an RPG.

In terms of combat, I feel there's something missing. I'm no stranger to strategy turn-based role-playing games, having enjoyed titles like the original Fallout games, XCOM, and the original Baldur's Gate. Additionally, as someone who plays Dungeons & Dragons regularly, I was excited to see how the game would translate the tabletop experience into a video game format. Unfortunately, while the combat system is faithful to its D&D roots, it somehow falls short of providing the same level of engagement and satisfaction that I've experienced in other games and in my D&D sessions.

I genuinely want to like Baldur's Gate 3 given its pedigree, the enthusiasm surrounding it, and my love for D&D, but I find myself struggling to do so. It could be that my expectations were set differently based on my experiences with similar games and tabletop RPGs, or perhaps it's the execution that doesn't quite hit the mark for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054726480', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 150, 'playtime_at_review': 7470, 'last_played': 1736283318}
review:
Honestly, the game, at it's core, is absolutely great. The story is insane, the characters are well thought out, the gameplay is - again, at it's core - fun.
But it's overshadowed by the insane amount of bugs and glitches.
Characters just (visually) disappearing, enemies whom you've just pushed down a chasm to their certain death reappearing and taking insanely low damage, invisible walls you jump against, cutscenes or throws just appearing for one player while the other gets to glare at a black screen... I could probably go on for a couple more minutes. It turns the fun core gameplay into an unbearable bugfest.
Don't play this if bugs enrage you. You'll die of a heart attack.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078023942', 'num_games_owned': 167, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 11226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11205, 'last_played': 1721751207}
review:
For MacOS:
This game was absolutely fantastic, ranking in my top three favorite. The beauty of gaming, I would fall short to describe in right words... the narrative, game design, story, gameplay, and side activities etc. whatever it comes to your mind when you think of a game it has everything... 
But that was before the recent updates changed everything. It used to be an example of flawless, high-quality gaming – I could immerse myself in the highest settings, enjoying every detail without a single drop in FPS. It was the kind of experience that made you appreciate the beauty of gaming. 

However, everything took a downturn with the release of the latest patch. It appears as though this update was rushed out without sufficient testing, drastically affecting the game's performance. What was once a smooth, visually stunning experience has now become a source of frustration. I'm relegated to playing at the lowest possible settings, a far cry from the high-quality gameplay I used to enjoy.

This shift has been incredibly disappointing. A game that I once held in high regard has deteriorated, leaving me frustrated with its current state. It's a stark reminder of how crucial thorough testing and quality assurance are before releasing updates. The lack of this has not only impacted the game's performance but also the gaming experience for many players like myself. I had to rolled back the game before that patch #6 in order to continue that sweet experience; now I am just behind of every improvement but yet having the best experience while keeping the game from updating.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973301905', 'num_games_owned': 2896, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 25376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10368, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 625, 'last_played': 1731889931}
review:
There is a fun game underneath its many issues, but this is a warning to prospective players. This game was a buggy, unstable mess of poor performance on 1.0 release, even on high end hardware. Some improvements and fixes have been made since then, but the game is still not in an acceptable release state. The state of this game is comparable to Cyberpunk 2077 in its launch window. I expected better from a game coming out of two years in Early Access.

My Steam hours played of 170 is deceptive, because my in-game save file is about half that at about 80 hours. There is not a quest, encounter, NPC, or party member that did not break or have significant issues during my run. In a single save file, I had to replay almost every second of this game. A quest or encounter or NPC interaction would break, and I was forced to reload a previous save. If that didn't fix the issue, I'd keep going back to earlier and earlier saves until I found one that wasn't yet bugged or with a branching path that worked. Many issues were never solved, and there were quests, plotlines, encounters and interactions I was unable to see through.

And these issues are present from the very first moments of the game and throughout, not just in Act 3. In the current patch, many issues persist, and performance today remains poor on a range of hardware throughout the game.

That said, the character and class options are very impressive, and combat is a lot of fun. There is a very cool fantasy tactics game buried underneath its many issues.

Wait for this game to improve in performance and fix its bugs and glitches. There's a fun game buried underneath this myriad of issues. For those with a high tolerance for buggy and broken games, it can still be a good time. But it's not worth the money yet. Wait for Baldur's Gate 3 to be fixed and go on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054207159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 19013, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8799, 'last_played': 1712939193}
review:
First of all I'd like to say this isn't Baldur's Gate 3, it's Divinity 3 with a few Baldur's Gate references thrown in. I really wanted to enjoy this game, the graphics are gorgeous, the character creation is very satisfying, the companions are well written and voice acted (even if a couple of them are very irritating) and the story is interesting, so those are the positives. I have found this to be one of the most frustrating games to play, the turn based combat seems to take forever (make a cup of tea and have time to drink it while 30 goblins dash about, then have a turn), the combat is a definite step back from BG1 & 2, the maps are ugly and sometimes hard to comprehend, but most of all I play games to relax after work, I don't want to be massively challenged and I certainly don't want to be reloading to have a stupidly long fight all over again even in story mode. Oh and unlimited arrows but you have to collect sausages to have a rest seems just silly.
I would like to say that this is my opinion based on my experience of BG1 and 2 and various other RPG's and what I want out of a game, BG3 was game of the year for a reason just not for me.
I keep coming back to it and trying again (I'm on my third character and have got to the city) because I really want to like it, but that turn based combat and reloading all the time means I turn it off after a couple of hours annoyed... again. 
Ah well, back to Planet Zoo I guess.

author: {'steamid': '76561199112623629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 10623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10623, 'last_played': 1719524251}
review: i'm not sure how to write a review for this game. on one hand, i loved it; i loved the open world and exploring, i loved the side quests, the companion quests, you name it. Acts 1 and 2 were beautifully crafted and had a lot to show for it. However, Act 3 and late game is a mess. from minor things such as inconsistent frame rates, to quests that clearly aren't finished or well structured, to simple spells that don't work, there is content that must be skipped, which is a shame for a game that i really want to like. i may be complaining to much, but the bugs are there, and i hope that Larian recognizes these issues and gets them fixed. unfortunately, due to things mentioned above, and my patience, i was not able to finish this game. for a triple A game to release with this many issues that are still not resolved, is quite disappointing. 6/10 go ahead and buy but be wary of bugs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995916490', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1707690730}
review: I bought this game thinking that I would like the story. I enjoy all the videos I have seen of people playing it and I would like to see the different characters stories. I am not able to because of the combat in this game. I absolutely hate it. I am willing to accept that I am bad at it. I played Dragon Age Origins on PC and consoles extensively and loved it. I have played many other tactical rpgs. I played a good amount of XCOM and XCOM2. I  liked those games and I do not like this one. It is sad too because the game is beautiful and the characters all look really cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198193842623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2057, 'last_played': 1706408331}
review: Many great ideas, quests, dialogs, choices, but terrible implementation. Balance is probably the worse I have ever seen in any game. To bring this dice idea from board games is totally stupid idea, it is only affects how many thousands times you're reloading a save, nothing more. As a result progressing is awfully slow and the game, could be great, but becomes a disappointment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109982334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1714711305}
review:
Multiplayer cross platform is completely broken with no practical fix.

Edit: I am able to run this game on Parallels with poor performance. There is no option to disable updates, and unlike many other games, there is no option to lock BG3 to a specific version, as such, this review will remain a negative, due to the high price and problems this caused. The ongoing war cannot be used as an excuse for the lack of proper version control. Hire better software engineers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201933791', 'num_games_owned': 254, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1722812545}
review: If you don't know ANYTHING about DnD ... don't get this this game, you will regret it.  The learning curve is MASSIVE ... actually, there is no learning curve because the game literally teaches you nothing.  At 6 hours in trying to figure out what's going on, I hate this game ... it's not fun and a slog to play. I regret this being given as a gift for my 67th birthday ... they lost $60.  I've requested a refund to them but I doubt it will go thru since I "wasted" 6 hours in it and found it unplayable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198246803360', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 26997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1120, 'playtime_at_review': 24812, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1736392721}
review:
Co-Op is poorly optimized, and a vastly worse experience than single player. It's a good rpg, but a terrible representation of dnd. Your options are incredibly limited, with most dialouge ending in the same result, and most failed checks ending in instant combat. If this is an actual dnd campaign, it needs a better dm.

Don't get me wrong, it's a fantastic game, but these issues make it so hard to get invested in.

A good tactics game? Absolutley
A good exploration game? Nearly always
A good rpg? Most of the time
A good port of dnd? Not even close

If you don't give a fuck about dnd though, buy it now it's awesome

Edit: Patch 7 added a mod manager that corrupted all my saves. I'm not even surprised anymore. There is no reason for this game to cost as much as it does. In a word this game is underwhelming. It belongs back in Alpha. Since release I've experienced multiple game breaking glitches that all took straight up months to fix. Playing this game is an uphill battle against the developers that desperately want to see it fail. I've lost 400 hours, don't make the same mistake I did by trusting the devs.

My advice? Wait five years to buy this game on a 99% sale. A candy bar is about 1.50, and given that this game is almost as good as one, it'd be a real steal

author: {'steamid': '76561198082093390', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 14612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10652, 'last_played': 1733580498}
review:
Edit: Changed to not recommend since modding "support" was added. Please fix this. Multiplayer does not work if either party installed mods, even the same mods. The error message says the mod lists don't match which is incorrect. To help the devs, please reference the basic docs: https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/container/unordered_set/operator_cmp

Only complaints are the long load times, model not being loaded after the loading, and actors t-posing on save/load. Seems a bit nonsensical, but this issue goes away after a few seconds, so I can't say there's much that invokes my typical negative reviews.

author: {'steamid': '76561198365142689', 'num_games_owned': 99, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 12212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10883, 'last_played': 1723250321}
review:
Obviously a fine game overall, but it has TOO many flaws to consider it GOAT

1) Game is stupidly easy. No hard desicions is to be made.
On hard mode (tactician) you just boink people's heads and they die. Zero (0) strategy or tacticts, zero usage of consumables of any kind. 
Long rests are being used ONLY for story purpose, you never really need it. But if you do - they are UNLIMITED at any point, no costs, no consequences. 

For comparison - Divinity Original Sin II was pretty hard even on Normal mode, and really made you THINK your every move ahead. 

Balance in first act is especially broken because game pushes you to go to Underdark very early, and then all enemies are like 1-3 levels behind you

2) Bad equipment management both interface- and lore-wise
You get like hundreds of magical items, weapons, armor and shit, which weights like A LOT (because encumbrance sytemm is so fun), but it does not restrict you, because you can teleport your shit to the camp and back at any time, So basically its just tiresome clicking. Just make it x5 less, but cost x5 more, it will make sense. 

But not only that, you ll get THOUSANDS of scrolls, arrows, throwables, alchemy stuff etc, which also have weight and have to be distributed at all times.
How fun it is to have at level 5 10 fireball scrolls which you will never use because you will never ever have to, and you can wipe yourself with them. I can feel the LORE

It boils down to the factt hat you dont ever have to think - "should I use that scroll r should I keep it for when i REALLY need it?" because you will NEVER need it

3) Game is too freaking long and boring. 
I finshed act I in 130 hours (did not even went to Mountain pass yet) and I just dont want to play anymore - game iprovides NO challenge, is too tiresome, and most o the time was doing freaking INVENTORY MANAGEMENT and robbing traders blind, because they restock as many times as you want at any point and you have basically no limits on stealing

author: {'steamid': '76561198133028015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 6496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6496, 'last_played': 1726932820}
review:
Do I recommend this game? Yes, sort of, but not really. [Before I beat it review]

I like the aspect of Dungeons & Dragons, but the restrictions on the world in this game are a bit over the top. Stores do reset with randomized items to purchase, though not nearly enough like a true RPG (potions refill but gear barely randomizes if at all). Enemies and random encounters do not happen in this game which removes so much immersion and surprise to the overall game. It'd have been better if both or either options happened where enemies did respawn or if there were random encounters that'd offer some surprise, XP, and unexpected loot.

I would classify this game as a deep-lite RPG. The world isn't really there - so there's little to immerse yourself in. The game revolves so much around dialogue and choices, and removes the utilities of surrounding yourself in a world. Although, what you can interact with such as using jump or teleport anywhere - is kind of amazing. Another key note to mention here is that you never feel a sense in which you can explore or discover anything freely - because everything feels so rushed and timed (and there are plenty of timed events in which you're required to find something in the world, do something in the world, or speak to someone in the world or you will lock yourself out of options.

Another thing I've discovered which is a lacking shame is the max level. Contrary to 20 being about it in D&D, this game maxes out at level 12.

author: {'steamid': '76561199248645543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 914, 'last_played': 1703981459}

I thought it would be just a more up to date vision and new continued story. So if you don't like turn based games don't play this one. I do enjoy watching people play the story line.

author: {'steamid': '76561198208927111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 217909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3768, 'playtime_at_review': 164537, 'last_played': 1736835341}
review:
[h1]Rise, Tarnished![/h1]

Easily the best game I've played in many years, and it deserves a longer review than most of you have patience for. I highly recommend it, and here's why:

Like many who play this game, this was my first "Soulsborne/Soulslike" game, as it is the most refined and user-friendly version of FromSoftware's game design ethos. I avoided the Dark Souls series for many years. I had a presumptuous view of FromSoftware and their visual aesthetic that made me feel this game was just sad edgelord material. [b]I was so wrong.[/b] 

Like all FromSoftware games, Elden Ring revels in struggle. Only the most basic combat mechanics are explained to the player; the rest is trial and error. It challenges you to tease out its mysteries, not just of the world and lore, but of the combat mechanics and UI. The game asks you to [i]STRUGGLE[/i] (you need to be open to that to fully enjoy it), and oh boy, did I struggle...

I struggled to simply navigate the user interface, to find the extra info on weapon damage and scaling, armor ratings and status defenses, even item descriptions full of implicit lore that give the player a small understanding of what's happening in the Lands Between. I struggled to accept that not every field boss in the overworld was meant to be defeated when you first encounter them. I struggled to avoid traps and ambushes. Even when I gave up trying to play solo and attempted to use the Co-Op multiplayer system, I struggled to understand the seemingly obtuse system of items that enable it. Even after, I struggled against skilled and relentless Invaders, many of whom have been invading players since Dark Souls 1. I'm ashamed to say I struggled to not uninstall the game and play an easier one with a more forgiving learning curve. Such was my frustration.

Most of all, I struggled to get acclimated to the combat mechanics... Until, a whole 40 hours (and many deaths) in, something clicked. I started seeing and feeling a flow to combat, requiring a skillful dance between dodging perfectly [i]into[/i] attacks and identifying narrow windows for my own attacks. I started to understand every movement and attack option's purpose and viability in different scenarios. I started understanding how to most efficiently manage my stamina, consumables, and other resources. I started seeing challenges and opportunities where before I only saw difficulties and defeat.

This began a shift in my mentality. The developers were not taunting or trolling me, like many players seem to think; they were inviting me to experience a true power fantasy, to feel a tangible sense of actual progression in skill and understanding. The game does not say "git gud, noob"; it says [b]"rise, Tarnished"[/b].

So many modern AAA games are released with a product mentality first and foremost, and not even as good products; they are often unfinished, rushed, bugged, and bloated with profit-maximizing strategies like microtransactions. Elden Ring is the first game I've played in a decade that felt like a complete game, full of hundreds of hours of content. 

So many games frontload their "best" content and force you to engage with it to force your interest, but much of Elden Rings best content is hidden or blocked by combat and platforming challenges. I have almost 3k hours logged, and I'm still finding out new things the game has kept hidden from me. This speaks so much to the confidence the developers have in their vision of an adventure fantasy game centered around discovery.

The game is not perfect. There are still some bugs and glitches present from launch that have no clearcut development solution. Many bosses, enemy types, and other assets are re-used all over the map to mixed effect. Some lategame and endgame content feels rushed and spread out. Perhaps worst of all, like all games with an active PvP element, the player community is rife with toxic players who seem hellbent on griefing others into making them uninstall the game.

Even with these glaring imperfections, this game shines like a diamond in a sea of coal coated with cheap craft glitter. It stands head and shoulders above almost all other modern AAA games in terms of intrigue, combat satisfaction, exploration, and story, and it doesn't even flaunt it. An understated and nuanced gaming experience is such a delight in an era where games are intended to feel more like blockbuster Hollywood movies rather than progressive adventures. Elden Ring is the culmination of FromSoftware’s singular and robust design philosophy, honed over decades of trial and error. 

[b]If you experience only one Soulsbourne game in your entire life, let it be Elden Ring.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198254904299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 37082, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31814, 'last_played': 1732077569}
review:
I have spent hours in both the base game and DLC. Here are my thoughts.

I am in no way a hardcore player. This is the only game I have ever played by this company.  This game pissed me off so much because I didn't understand that is was out the box a difficult game.  

I have since then completed 100% of the achievements and got through the DLC.  The DLC is rough but if you you just want to progress and beat bosses with ease, there are options.  Spirit summons, youtube cheese videos.  

I enjoy exploring. I love the graphics and sometimes I want the challenge of a boss.  However I have completed the game made it enjoyable on my terms and don't care if I don't kill the boss without a summons.  I don't get paid to play games, so I take advantage of everything I can find and do in the game to go from point A to B.  

I recommend the Base game and the DLC.  I looked at the DLC as how can I defeat and cheese the new bosses.  Not how do I learn the mechanics so people will know I am a good player.  I just don't care, I want to beat the game start to finish.  If I can do this and I am not a good player, then spend the money and beat it your way in anyway you see fit.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981867244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 7713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7667, 'last_played': 1732603940}
review: Cute little indie game. There's a few cool hats and a nice horse. You can make friends with several charming characters and you can even farm (souls from fingers on the roots of an eldritch tree within an infernal mist) if you like. Perhaps one of the prettiest games I've played in a long time. Still, I have nightmares about the little men who play brass instruments, and I can never find the sewer. It's quite like Stardew Valley in that they both have a hidden sewer level.

author: {'steamid': '76561199507977893', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 12437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12426, 'last_played': 1732749877}
review:
The game is frankly weak. Let me start with the cons that outweigh the pros: the open world feels empty, and it copies mobs from Dark Souls, even though this is a new universe and game. It's very difficult to follow the path planned by the developers because if you find the boss later, you'll be too strong for him and will kill him on the first try. An open world is not suitable for this genre. The quests, as always in the games from this studio, are rubbish. In Dark Souls, they could be completed intuitively, but here, maybe 0.1% of players will finish them without guides. You practically need to get into Miyazaki's head to figure out where the quest character is standing this time.

There are few good bosses  8 come to mind, and it's even funny to call the rest "bosses." There's a lack of a coherent local plot, and instead, we get more vague, global nonsense about gods and aliens.

Now for the advantages of the game: the beautiful locations, a sea of interesting weapons and spells, and the 8 good bosses. I especially liked the capital, though sadly, it was the only location that truly impressed me

author: {'steamid': '76561198045456739', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 61008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39567, 'last_played': 1734153699}
review:
Cant remember the last time I could get so lost in a game's world.  Absolutely beautiful.  For those of you like me who enjoy comparing stats on your loot and figuring out the best build for the right situation, this is the pinnacle. 

The ONLY thing I would caution is that if you have a life, kids, etc. this game might suck 600+ hours of your life like it did me.

Thumbs way way up

author: {'steamid': '76561198965837789', 'num_games_owned': 677, 'num_reviews': 270, 'playtime_forever': 2999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2999, 'last_played': 1711497571}
review: Elden Ring is an incredible action RPG that I loved from start to finish. The gameplay is challenging and rewarding, with tons of variety in how you can approach battles. The open world is massive and filled with secrets, making exploration a real joy. There’s so much content here that you’ll never run out of things to do. The graphics are decent, but the art style and atmosphere more than make up for it. Overall, it’s an amazing experience that’s worth every second. Easily a 10/10.

You have to fight all major bosses, get all endings, and find most major weapons. This requires at least 3 playthrus although I will say that you can breeze through the game pretty quick on NG+. Could take anywhere from 50-100 hours depending on skill and how much optional content you do. No grinding though!

[h2]Final Thoughts[/h2]

author: {'steamid': '76561198095858267', 'num_games_owned': 571, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 15589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5657, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1719598821}
review:
[h1][i]I am Malenia. Blade of Miquella.[/i][/h1]

I still hear these words in my nightmares...
Other than that, I'd recommend Elden Ring.

I'm really bad at souls-like games but still enjoy them. 
Can't dump 1000 hours into any of these games to "git gud", so I thought I would give Elden Ring a try. 
I've read that it's a bit more forgiving than Dark Souls or Bloodborne, still challenging but not in a "git gud"-kinda way.

These articles and comments were right.
While I still struggled at a few points, it never felt unfair and I was never "stuck" cause of Elden Ring's open world. Whenever a boss turned me into tomato paste 30 times in a row, I turned around and progressed on a different route. Fighting a different boss, defeating him, getting stronger and returning to the other boss again.

I really enjoyed the game and I am looking forward to the DLC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149968622', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 5879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5872, 'last_played': 1731846034}
review:
"A man may be destroyed but not defeated." -Ernest Hemingway

This game is the first souls-like game that I actually played from the start to finish. I tried other titles but gave up on them quickly after a couple hours. So first thing I want to say is this game feels more welcoming to the genre than other titles.

I don't know where to start about talking this game. Rich open-world, very rich combat, interesting lore, amazing designs... It has been a while since I really really felt excited to keep playing one game. I wanted to push further my character, my equipment, my gamestyle as I progressed through the game and see different bosses. Especially the satisfaction you get from beating a boss after using your equipment optimally is unmatchable. I actually felt that I rose to Elden Lord title from being a Tarnished that others has been looking down at.

Lot's of the content is actually optional to progress in the game, and I usually skip most of optional stuff in other titles because they are mostly unpleasant chores. I felt different while playing Elden Ring, I actually tried my best to not miss anything at all. I wanted to see what every loot is, what enemies or mini bosses I could see and what missions I could progress. I could agree that NPC quests are a little bit hassle to follow and usually you might need to check wikis but I assume that is a standart for the genre. Even that really didn't bother me all because I liked NPC's too. They were pleasant to interact with and see how they progress with you as their quests go on. Even if you don't care NPC's I think anyone would still be excited to see what loot a dungeon contains in this game because there are lot's of fun stuff out there.

I found combat fun, it is still hard but they were aware about the game they were developing. Just go out there and grab those different items, spells, armors, swords, consumables... First it might be a little confusing and overwhelming but you quickly get used to managing items. Then fight anyone however you desire to. They gave you freedom with such a rich list of items. As you get better and your equipment gets better you feel the improvement on your way to kill your desired boss. If you are a hardcore souls fan you can also beat anything with a stick too.

Whole lore is actually pretty interesting but also hard to follow and learn. This is one of the things I assume "genre standard" so it didnt bother me much. Game doesn't tell you anything much, you read it all from items descriptions, NPC dialogues and other stuff like that. You also actually don't have to learn lore to follow the game though and just play for the combat experience. Another thing is game does not really lead you much at all so it might be really confusing and overwhelming. You can play it blind and keep wandering around till you find a lead or you can pop up a wiki page and follow it too. You might think looking at wiki's might destroy your fun but to be honest, as someone who finished their first souls-like game, it really didnt kill my joy because it is better than being stuck somewhere for hours you know. This game is a long journey and you'll get the hang of it, you just might need a little bit patience and help first couple hours.

Recent open-world games mostly felt %80 empty for me, but this game is different. Almost every part is a delightful adventure. I am both content and happy with the money and time I spent with this game, which is a rare feeling actually nowadays especially with the new titles. Even if you are not acquainted with genre, just don't hesitate and jump for a pleasurable adventure. Go wander out there and find your favorite equipment, find your favorite boss to fight with. Just sit and enjoy how a spirit of fighting rises within you as you progress through game. I am sure most people can enjoy this game as I think this game is really a welcoming and pleasuring one. I personally liked this game so much that now most of the other games that I play now feels dull. I am planning on buying the DLC now.


A protracted and tough adventure awaits you, Tarnished Warrior. Do not give into despair and keep fighting, be assured that you will soon be blessed with contentment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198447344048', 'num_games_owned': 646, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 32472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20770, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1733771098}
review:
Elden Ring was my first soulslike.
It was kinda overwhelming when starting but I had tons of fun in my first blind run.
Like that's the great part of Elden Ring: you don't have to be this awesome Souls-Veteran to be able to enjoy the game.
You can just take your time with everything, explore the beautiful world, enjoy the view and smaller bosses.
The game doesn't push you to kill a certain difficult boss in order to get somewhere in-game. You're not forced to farm the same enemies for hours on until you're strong enough to continue your journey. You can just keep exploring & will eventually level up in the mean time. & if you're not getting any further with a specific boss, then you can just leave it be for now and do hundreds of other things instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198255759388', 'num_games_owned': 92, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7269, 'last_played': 1728132707}
review:
After beating the basegame 3 times & the dlc there are a few things i noticed:

1. The game really likes tree's. Golden Trees, Big Trees, Sentient Trees, Dead Trees, Burning Trees, Tree Knights???
2. Never take a nap in a coffin, you will wake up at some f*cked up places. (Of course you do)
3. NEVER take advice from somebody who played the game before you did, chances are they are 100% wrong and biased because they think there is a "correct way" of beating the game
4. Just play the game the way you want to, this community has some really weird people thinking they do some sort of "pilgrimage" for beating this game a certain way & you're wrong if you dont do it the way they did.
5. Speaking of point 3, Age of Order Ending (Goldmask Dude) is the best one, you cant tell me otherwise

Great Game

author: {'steamid': '76561198102941556', 'num_games_owned': 780, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 12726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12726, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 383, 'last_played': 1732683376}
review:
[b]“The Fallen Leaves Tell a Story”[/b]
Across my years of gaming, few experiences have truly surprised me. But exploring the Lands Between brought back a childlike sense of wonder.

The lore, characters, and world-building pulled me in completely, leaving me hanging on every word spoken and each scrap of text uncovered.
The difficulty was never unfair; instead, it pushed me to adapt, learn new strategies, and grow, rather than simply banging my head against the wall. 

In the end, the greatest gift Elden Ring gave me wasn’t only its unforgettable journey—it was opening the door to FromSoftware’s rich back catalog and a world of Souls-like adventures just waiting to be explored.
[b]10/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198085425935', 'num_games_owned': 320, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 30267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 182, 'playtime_at_review': 9927, 'last_played': 1735766228}
review:
I'm only writing this review because Shadow of the Erdtree was finally announced and I want to go on the record for anyone who never got around to playing it yet for whatever reason. If you heard about the DLC and are thinking "yeah, maybe now is the time I'll finally dive in", then this is directed at you.

Elden Ring is not for everyone. If you don't respect the grind, then it will kick the shit out of you without remorse. There is no easy mode, no save-scumming, no cheat codes, and absolutely no hand holding. Yeah sure.. you can rely on Youtubers and Wiki pages to tell you what some of the ULTIMATE BUILDS might be... but even if you're relying on a crutch like that, you STILL have to put the work in and "git gud" when it's all said and done. It also takes a while to even get access to all the weapons/gear that those guides expect you to be using, not to mention earning the experience needed for the build to be viable. So my suggestion to you is to worry less about building an exact carbon copy of a character that some other person already played as, and just try to take it all in and experience it for yourself first.

I got every achievement, defeated every boss, and it was the most rewarding grind I've ever embarked upon in a game. I made a lot of mistakes along the way, but I learned from every single one of them. I got my ass kicked every time I booted up the game, but every triumph I celebrated was unlike any other thanks to all of those ass-kickings. From the hardest boss fights to the most annoying mobs, you truly feel every single victory... and that's where I got hooked because the sense of accomplishment you get from progressing in Elden Ring... I'm telling you, it is the ultimate dopamine shot.

Now, I personally loved the story, but it's definitely a subjective experience. Elden Ring is a mythological story about gods and demi-gods, and if you take the time to read through the item descriptions, look closer at the game world, and try to fill in the gaps kind of like a detective would, then you will probably enjoy it too. If you are expecting the cutscenes to be the only thing you have to pay attention to in order to know what's going on, you might be disappointed. 

Without a quest menu or anything like that to keep track of things, the game forces you to do your own due diligence and keep track of the NPCs you've spoken to, and to really listen to what they say because completing side quests isn't like most open world games that just plop a waypoint down for you to walk to after you've skipped all the dialogue. You need to listen and think about it, and if you've already progressed through certain points of the main-story, then you might not even get to experience some of the side quests. This aspect of Elden Ring can be a bit frustrating because you really aren't given any indication if you've missed a part of a quest or if you missed a quest entirely until it's too late. I will just say that if you're bee-lining it straight to the main bosses, you are definitely missing a LOT of what makes the game so good (and you're also missing out on side quests that lead to valuable ITEMS and EXPERIENCE!!!). So if you don't want to miss anything, my advice is to take it all very slow, and just try to clear regions and talk to everyone you see before moving on to new areas. If you think you missed stuff, keep in mind that you can always try again in NG+. 

Multiplayer is completely optional, but opting in to allow invasions can be rewarding because testing your build against actual players is pretty fun, plus you get to also see what other people are doing with their characters. Sometimes seeing someone else in action can inspire you to try new stuff, or it can make you aware of a flaw in your own character. I will say that I personally played with the player messages turned off though because I didn't want to read possible spoilers, and I felt reading messages left by other players all over the place broke my immersion.. but to each their own.

If you've never played Elden Ring before and are finally considering a run through the game for the first time... I truly envy you because I would do anything to wipe my memory and play it again for the first time. It is a game like no other, and it will test you in more ways than one. Just don't get discouraged when you hit a wall.. because we've ALL been there... all you have to do is learn to overcome it. Once you do, I promise there is no greater feeling in all of gaming.

author: {'steamid': '76561199186454804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 20258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19319, 'last_played': 1721102060}

author: {'steamid': '76561198273946022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 44257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44257, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 15999, 'last_played': 1732737816}
review:
As my first Souls game, the difficulty was overwhelming at times, but each victory over its merciless bosses felt incredibly rewarding. 

Elden Ring’s world is a masterpiece, with every detail telling a story of beauty and ruin, enhanced by an incredible soundtrack. 

The lore is hidden in the world itself, inviting exploration and discovery, making every step feel meaningful.

author: {'steamid': '76561199025152476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 16533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16533, 'last_played': 1723704359}
review:
[h1] Elden Ring [/h1]
[i] Every review is subjective and aligns with the perception, tastes, and/or interests of the person writing it. I’m someone who views video games as another form of artistic expression, which is why I do NOT assign a score. I don't believe art can be measured or quantified. I’ll simply share my personal experience while avoiding spoilers as much as possible. [/i]

Elden Ring is essentially a culmination of everything FromSoftware has refined over the years in their previous titles, wrapped in a vast open world that invites exploration and discovery. If I could describe Elden Ring in one word, it would be "Lost." Like other FromSoftware games, this one is filled with moments where you’re not entirely sure what you’re doing, who the enemies are that you’re fighting, why they’re there, where you should go, or what the correct path is. Yet, that sense of being lost isn’t frustrating; it’s a driving force that pushes you to keep going. There’s something magnetic that urges you to press forward, to explore every corner of the map in search of an NPC, an item, or any clue that might give you some direction. But as you progress, things only become more convoluted. When you finally defeat an enemy, a tougher one appears. When you think you’ve grasped a part of the lore, new information emerges that forces you to rethink everything. The game constantly keeps you in a state of uncertainty, wondering whether you’ve taken the right path or strayed into a dangerous detour.
The only clear indicators of progress in Elden Ring are the boss fights, a few scattered dialogues, and some of the graces placed across the map. The sense of accomplishment from defeating a boss is unparalleled, it serves as a reminder that despite the confusion and challenges, you are making progress.

One of the standout aspects of Elden Ring is the sheer size and richness of its world. In open-world games, I’ve always enjoyed exploring every last corner of each zone, and this title was no exception. The world’s vastness, both visually and in terms of content, is impressive. The thrill of discovering a new area or finding a well-hidden secret is what drives me to keep playing. However, as I explored, I encountered one of the game’s most criticized aspects: repeated bosses. While it’s a common practice in some games, I expected FromSoftware to maintain their unique touch of originality. Perhaps the decision to reuse bosses was driven by the ambition to make the world as large as possible in their first attempt at an open-world game. Personally, I wouldn’t mind it as much if these bosses became increasingly challenging or had new attack patterns, but in most cases, the fights feel nearly identical. Despite this shortcoming, the overall experience wasn’t “tarnished” (xD), I thoroughly enjoyed every battle, striving to improve with each encounter.

[h3] Erdtree [/h3]

The Erdtree expansion brings new mechanics and a narrative focus that complements the base experience of Elden Ring. When I first accessed the expansion, I thought it would be similar to the DLCs in the studio’s other games: having a high level would be enough… I was wrong. Erdtree introduces a unique mechanic that intertwines with the game’s lore. If you choose to ignore that detail, be prepared to suffer like never before. What’s fascinating is how this expansion not only adds content but also manages to maintain the essence of what makes Elden Ring special while expanding its world in a way that feels natural. Despite all the new content, both Elden Ring and Erdtree are, in my opinion, the most accessible and, to some extent, the easiest experiences FromSoftware has developed. That’s not to say they lack challenge, but the open-world design, with its emphasis on exploration and freedom, somewhat softens the experience.

In conclusion, I can confidently say that Elden Ring is the best game they’ve created in terms of ambition, design, and execution. However, interestingly, it’s not my favorite. Despite everything I’ve mentioned, I don’t feel the desire to replay it, cause it feels like a one-time experience. This contrasts with Bloodborne, my favorite game from the studio, which I could play over and over again. Despite being technically inferior in several ways, Bloodborne has an atmosphere and design that I find more appealing and invites me to a better "dream".

author: {'steamid': '76561199154430068', 'num_games_owned': 388, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 7325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7325, 'last_played': 1706631556}

author: {'steamid': '76561199700499218', 'num_games_owned': 123, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2392, 'playtime_at_review': 1578, 'last_played': 1736746698}
review:
Elden Ring was my first Soulslike, and while it felt overwhelming at first, my blind run turned into an unforgettable adventure. The game does not demand you to be a seasoned veteran to enjoy it. You are free to explore its breathtaking world, tackle smaller bosses, and progress at your own pace. There is no pressure to grind endlessly or overcome a specific boss to move forward. You can always leave and discover countless other things. 

It reminded me how much I have missed truly open world exploration, free from handholding or unnecessary distractions. Elden Ring is a masterpiece, a world that does not just ask to be played, but to be lived in, savored, and remembered long after the journey ends. I doubt I will be this captivated by another game for a long time.

--{ My Personal Opinion }--
This is literally the best game I have ever played.
Even after only playing it for a few hours, taking time to level up and enjoy the gameplay this game still gives me adrenaline after beating a boss. If I had the choice to change anything, I'd change nothing.

--{ Review }--
First of all, the game's visuals are incredible. And it's landscape is very interactive. See a giant with a battleaxe thousans of miles away? You are definitely fighting him soon.. see a massive cliff that looks impossible to climb? You most definitely can. Infact loads of cliffs like that have intense lore and precious items hiding right on them and behind is a whole new world you haven't seen before.
The game's lore is also very unique. Even if you might not get it's meaning the second you finish it, soon you'll realize how beautiful it is. 
Gameplay-wise it offers a classic Dark Souls system with a dodge, jump, attack, charged attack, consume and so so much more.
If I had to describe Elden Ring with one word, it would be customization. There is so many different things you can wear, consume, places you can explore and things you can kill it's hard to keep track of everything. It's soul upgrading system offers you so much freedom you may run any build out of thousands that exist.
Although it's a challenging videogame, you may also always come back. Stuck on a boss? Don't worry, with just exploring, you may uncover a whole quest line, that will make you find a piece of equipment or an upgrading material which will make the fight easier.
But don't rely only on weapons and level since since without skill you may not get far. Personally if you want elden ring to relax, use magic, if you want to have fun play tank.

--{ Two Last Tips If You Are Still Reading }--
If you are truly struggling at a boss, or a place or you are just lost, ask. If you have discord join the Elden Ring discord server and ask there. People there are very helpful and kind, if you dont have it, download it. 
I was thinking ER community is so kind as it's there on every piece of media, but i suggest staying away from it on media platforms such as TikTok or YT. Just warning you. - (Shout-out to "Tyrone" for literally carrying me in-game)

And if you are struggling deciding between buying it or not. Buy it, its so much fun.
