author: {'steamid': '76561199436155180', 'num_games_owned': 66, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 16323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10096, 'last_played': 1734126649}
review:
Elden Ring: Still Obsessed After 200 Hours!
Wow, 200 hours in the Lands Between and I'm still having a blast! Here's why you should try 

Elden Ring:
Giant, Gorgeous World: Explore amazing landscapes, fight cool enemies, and find hidden stuff everywhere you go! It's like a never-ending adventure.
Super Tough Battles: Be prepared for a challenge! But don't worry, beating those tough bosses feels amazing.
Be Who You Want: Play as a strong warrior, a sneaky mage, or anything in between! There are tons of ways to fight.
A Few Hiccups: Not everything is perfect, but the good stuff definitely outweighs it!

Overall:  This game is incredible! If you like exploring, fighting, and feeling awesome, Elden Ring is for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561199010036535', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7484, 'last_played': 1735497747}
review:
pros +
- It is a Fromsoftware game.
- This game even has a DLC NOMINATED FOR GOTY (2024). I repeat: A "DLC" nominated for GOTY. What more can i say ?
- A baddie redhead chick kicks you in the ass for 234th time while you stare at your screen like a Tesla robot.
- Easy to 100% compared to the other souls games.

cons -
- Mental breakdowns
- Might lose your virginity to the first boss if you don't put your foolish ambitions to rest
- Bloodborne pc when ?

overall <3
- If you're an Atheist, this game literally has you looking to the Bible for help.
- Don't be a casul, git gud and play this masterpiece.
Best of luck everyone !

author: {'steamid': '76561199470049613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4028, 'last_played': 1721515151}
review:
Brilliant world, you can get lost for hours. Sad to say this was my first Souls like game but now I want to play more which I feel is what Elden Ring was made to do. There is lots of variety in weapon choice and fighting styles which again makes it more appealing for people new to this game style. 

I would say for people starting out in Elden Ring, don't get disheartened when you cant get past a boss, take time, level up and try again!

author: {'steamid': '76561199261295567', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1918, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1723243027}
review:
i am not very good at it, but it is
complex in every system, from crafting to combat to the graphics ( <--- which are gorgeous and captivating in their own right ) The difficulty is in a sweet spot where it is challenging but you also are making progress no matter what you do or how you do it in game, so you can really take it at your own pace. This honestly might be up there with one of my favourite video games of all time. Truly Innovative for the genre of souls-like as a whole and with that it sets the bar very very high.

please pick it up and give it an honest shot, it won't be easy all the time, but it deserves it in my opinion. 
absolutely recommended, 10/10, 5/5 stars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063236476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 14270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14270, 'last_played': 1719958535}
review:
Well, after almost 250 hours of playing Elden Ring at the time of writing this review, I can't go without writing a review for this game. It's not going to be a copy paste review, nor is it going to follow a strict baseline. 

Quick note: will refer to the DLC as SOTE (abbreviated for Shadow of the Erdtree)

First off, kudos to Miyazaki and the FromSoftware team from learning from all their previous games and compiling all their knowledge gained over the years into creating this masterpiece. You can clearly notice design choices picked from here and there and trying to integrate them into the game, which somehow manage to blend wonderfully together.

Recurring 'soulslike' design elements as well, well known and (jokingly) hated in the community like the poison/rot swamps as well. But what's a Miyazaki game without any poison lake to make it traversing difficult?

Which brings me to the first point, the graphics. In typical FromSoftware style, the graphics are there but aren't too burdening - allow me to explain from a pleb's standpoint. Basically, the polygons aren't that crisp, looking up close at things isn't so graphically marvelous, however the fidelity is there and you without having to blink can figure out what is what, which is great.

[h2]Now the views, however, are stunning.[/h2]

You open the door to Limgrave and your mouth gapes as soon as you step out. It's absolutely beautiful, and you can see quite a few landmarks as well which make sense with the mapping system (i.e Stormveil, the Erdtree, a bit of Caelid etc). This will constantly happen through the game when (not all instances, however) you will be greeted by such a view when you step into a new area, be it Liurnia, Altus [spoiler] depending on the entrance chosen [/spoiler], and even in SOTE when first accessed and entering the Gravesite Plain. Every area is also very, very atmospheric, with great colour and artistic choices (you can expect Nokstella and Nokron to be indeed, starry and with a beautiful view). 

[h2] Exploration [/h2]

It's an open world exploration game with a humongous map. Lots of areas to explore, diverse in thematic and enemies. You also get a mount this time as opposed to all the other soulslike games. Jumping also makes exploration a bit more intricate and parkouring (platforming) will be required in some cases either for smart shortcuts, or flat out progression.

[h2] Equipment [/h2] 

Great slew of weapons to choose from, really, appealing to all sorts of pre-established fantasy roles and ones you can also make and bake yourself. The freedom is there with the stat system and the way weapons scale with stats (some better than other, indeed) however the weapon's scaling isn't the only thing that has to be considered when picking a weapon. Souls-fashion, coolness factor, the ash of war (in case it's unmodifiable) and how well it scales with your preferred stat also matter quite a lot (the last one might matter most in case of min maxing). Very good, thematic armour pieces as well which allow you to craft fashionable outfits or just wear full sets that look great. 

[h2] Combat system [/h2]

Focused on the classical I-frame (Invulnerability frames) roll, with enemies that can easily punish you if you're not being careful due to all decently packing a punch but easy to figure them out and defeat from clumsiest knight to the most nimble SOTE enemy. The addition of a jump button also makes some attacks and some AoE attacks avoidable via jumping if timed correctly, which adds another welcome layer to the combat. 

[h2] Bosses [/h2]

Allow me to preface by saying the story bosses are epic in their own right with great movesets that make the fights fun. They also come accompanied by brilliantly composed OST-s to go with their personality, the buildup until the boss and in the boss arena as well. The few quotes bosses have are quite memorable and overall make the encounters even more enjoyable.

[h2] Storyline [/h2]

Like any FromSoftware (Miyazaki) game, the storyline is not directly exposed. You get to know some things in the beginning, and then you will have to piece together the intricate story from multiple sources: NPC dialogues, item descriptions, cutscenes and environment in some cases. Bonus points for having George R. R. Martin working on the story as well, there are clear influences seeping from his previous works into this story as well, with a unique blend from FromSoftware making it rather unique.

[h2] DLC [/h2]

I will start by saying I enjoyed the SOTE story and the SOTE bossfights to the fullest, as it is a hot topic in the community now (due to the perceived increase in difficulty thanks to a more aggressive AI). The SOTE area is also immense in scope and could have well been a game on its own right under other circumstances.

The Scadutree Fragment / Revered Spirit Ash system is not the best, however. It's main scope I believe is to enforce exploration which is great, there's definitely a lot to explore in SOTE. But, with the nature of the game being an open exploration one, means that some DLC content, if not visited at the right time with the right amount of fragments, can become trivial and can make some character builds extremely strong, especially after the buff the fragments received.

With that being said, the DLC contains probably two of the best/most atmospheric boss fights in the entire game and probably from a lot of souls games, namely: [spoiler] Messmer, The Impaler [/spoiler] and [spoiler] Bayle, The Dread [/spoiler] with one of the harder final soulslike bossfights in [spoiler] Promised Consort Radahn [/spoiler].




Finally, a small qualm I have with the game is some archetypes being unexplored to their fullest which makes them lackluster in comparison to others, namely: [spoiler] Sleep [/spoiler], [spoiler] Madness [/spoiler], [spoiler] Messmer-Flame [/spoiler]. They are all cool in their own right and you can definitely make builds with them but not many tools to use, unfortunately. 


All in all, I would give the base game a solid 10/10 and the DLC a 9/10.

That's it, thanks for getting this far and reading the entire review, was a joy to write.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023759684', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 24294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24063, 'last_played': 1722851075}
review: This is definitely one of the best games ever produced, and clearly one of the bests from From Software. The graphics and quality are stunning, the fluidity is amazing and you will never get such an amazing open world for a Souls-like again. The fact that you have to puzzle the whole story together also makes it feel never ending. I feel like this is a generation's accumulation of gaming and Data all put together to create one huge masterpiece. I cannot wait for "Shadows of the Erdtree" and am getting sooo impatient about it. Would recommend to anyone trying to get into Souls-like games.

author: {'steamid': '76561199758209207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 48, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1736013731}
review:
The game is awesome but I cannot help but be frustrated with the steam deck version.

Being marked as "verified" is misleading as I have not had any game cause me more issues on my steam deck than Cyberpunk 2077 ; audio issues, performance issues, crashes, problems with the launcher...

A little tweaking around could probably lift up a fair amount of annoyances but that is not what a "verified" experience is about in my opinion. 

Its a hard game to run and crazy that it is possible to do so on steam deck but straight up pretending it is a flawless out of the box experience for the deck is false information.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066378703', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1732, 'last_played': 1707415554}
review:
I've never seen worse shooter game-play in my life, even in its 2.0 form. Games 25 years ago are more responsive and intuitive then what is seen here. The only way I can describe it is as if your character is a moist noodle - not cooked but not raw - flopping around helplessly. This game falls flat on its face in every game-play system it has. Skill trees are a clusterfuck, confusing, controls half baked. Gun-play is awful; every animation was stiff as a board, weapon sounds were a joke too, bullet sponge moron enemies are standard. 

Story wise the game flops too. It has the beginnings of ideas but essentially does nothing with them. Anything that could be profound is ruined by the intense railroading of the story.

The setting is cool, but that's it. A puddle miles wide and centimetres deep. Huge missed potential which is what frustrates me most; if it was just all in all a bad game I wouldn't care but there clearly was something brewing here but someone just turned off the burner early and served it up... :/

author: {'steamid': '76561198078674243', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 976, 'last_played': 1719682279}
review:
The game starts well but reaches the peak of its story at the end of Act 1 then goes downhill from there.
In 2024, after a lot of updates, the game still has a lot of bugs!

Pros:
+ Graphics.

+ The art direction of Night City.

+ Interesting characters especially Johnny Silverhand, Judy, and Panam.

+ Soundtrack is awesome especially johmny silverhand theme.

Cons:
- Tons of glitches that will stop you from progressing your main story. I had a problem with every mission that required you to wait 1 day and you'll receive a call. Not to mention the T-pose, people disappearing and respawning out of nowhere, crashes .. etc.

- Awful gunplay and gameplay in general.

- Story becomes boring after Act 1 and repetitive missions.

- Mission design is so basic. Go there, kill this, and report back either by phone or talking to NPC.

- Stupid AI that I literally abused it to basically kill every "boss" without getting any damage.

I'm gonna update the review after finishing Phantom Liberty.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994704068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3786, 'last_played': 1707867089}
review:
The Good:
-City design, buildings, ads do a good job of recreating the feel of cyberpunk as a genre
-Lots of options for how you want to approach challenges
The Bad:
-Most missions are 70-80% sitting there while people talk at you, with very little choice in how you want the dialogue to go.  Many conversations happen while you are literally in the passenger seat as an NPC drives you somewhere.  It's like a masterclass in taking control away so you feel less like a player and more like a viewer. 
 The actual gameplay parts of missions where you sneak or hack or fight your way through levels is so short it feels like an afterthought.
-On top of the above, story pacing is glacially slow.  The opening action setpiece that actually gets you invested in your character and the world happens after ~6 hours of tutorials and filler missions.  And this pace doesn't let up, I frequently put the game down and came back weeks later because it feels like there is just too much filler in between the meat of the game.
-Extremely backwards tutorial system has entire missions to teach you obvious things like to sneak by going when guards aren't looking, but almost no useful information about how to manage less intuitive systems like attribute points and crafting materials.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046571728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 684, 'last_played': 1734870847}
review:
Steam should really have a "mixed" option instead of recommend or dont. This game has certainly achieved some very impressive things since its release. The fact that it released in such a terrible state and they actually managed to turn it around alone is impressive. It can also be pretty immersive at times for those of us who like Metro style immersion when we play.

Unfortunately, the list of negatives is quite significant as well. First there is the optimization which makes my head spin. Don't even bother buying this game unless you can play it at max settings. For whatever reason, if you try to play it in 1080p it literally looks like a game from the xbox 360 era. I guess make sure you have a 4060TI or better to play at higher resolution which I was lucky enough to be able to. On the plus side, it requires much less power to run this at max settings than GTA V... an 11 year old game that wasn't even graphically impressive 11 years ago. 

Another issue you will run into are the settings. There are a metric ton of them and they randomly reset. I was going to play this morning and literally just played something else after seeing that every setting had randomly changed. 

My final complaint is that nothing is polished. This game very much feels like a million ideas, none of which were given the needed attention. The vehicles are not creative or interesting to look at, the cities are empty and the mechanics for shooting/driving are arcade at best. 

Overall, if you can run this game at something above 1080p, and it is on sale for like $15 you really cant go wrong. It is certainly one of the extremely few "next gen" looking games of the last 15 years. If you like games such as Metro you will appreciate the limited but present immersive aspects which allow you to sometimes actually care about the logic behind a mission. My opinion on this game is simply mixed. It has its pros and cons.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969427263', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1727829930}
review:
I cannot play this game without navigating through windows explorer and deleting a JSON file. Every. Single. Time. I. Wish. To. Play. I have paid 100% of the money to access 100% of this game and I have not received it. How many times do I have to uninstall and reinstall? How many times do i have to verify files? How'bout the company/devs just do their jobs and make a game that works instead? After all, I/we have paid them to do so. Playing this game should require ZERO effort on my part other than clicking "Play".  

After 11 more hours of play: I have been playing this game by navigating windows explorer with each play. Otherwise the game will crash. My hours go up, my thumb remains down until they fix this issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075931333', 'num_games_owned': 405, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 26160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26160, 'last_played': 1726128415}
review:
Cyberpunk is the kind of game that definitely deserves an elaborate 8000 characters review, but it was also so draining, with me making an effort to finish it, that bullet points is the best I can give you. Long story short, it's a great "experience" kind of game if you're into the cyberpunk theme, but as the RPG to pour a few thousands hours into I absolutely don't recommend it:

- ludonarrative dissonance with your struggle with a terminal illness ultimately being a fake sense of urgency that doesn't exist outside of story missions
- a story that really overstays its welcome
- boring Ubisoft-esque open world with tons of samey "markers" to clean up
- bad and tedious stealth
- poor variety of cyberware for such a game, with the most impressive one being... slo-mo
- very curated and "confined" experience with low number of viable builds/playstyles
- lack of New Game+ or skipping long story segments utterly devastates replayability factor

Cyberpunk is at its best when you're double-jumping around districts doing gigs. But then you start to realize how it's all a very simplistic and dumbed down take on Dishonored and Deus Ex. How you pick a single playstyle and are stuck with it for the next 100 hours due to how the game is designed. How the open-world segments are inevitably followed by long and boring story missions you have to sit through...

In my experience, the best way to play is to stick to the starting area (one that also happens to have the most content), complete every gig and scanner inside it, and then instead of doing the story start over with a different build.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060289606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4640, 'last_played': 1710120538}
review:
I'm old. I played Cyberpunk 2020 back in the day. I was hoping for something that brought that to life as a video game, faithfully recreating that beguiling, dystopian future past setting.

Instead, this is a shallow impostor. A thin illusion. A broken promise of something that could have been revolutionary.  Instead, they went for lame style over meaningful substance.

Where even to begin with this dumpster fire?

I'm not even overly rumphurted over the glitches. I have played some glitchyAF games that were still funAF. Though, be warned, the glitches in this game, even years on, are almost crippling at times.

I'm not even going to spend much time harping on how CDPR just abandoned this game after one major content DLC, because there are old games with no continued support that I still love. Still, how much money did you make off us rubes, only to leave us hanging with nothing more to look forward to?

Nah. I got all my complaints in one nutshell:

I got bored. I went on a rampage. Runnin', gunnin', and laying out the bodies left and right. Gang goons? Check. NCPD? Check.  Random passers-by? Check.

You'd think after leaving a trail of dozens and dozens of unalived meatbags everywhere, something major would happen. Merc's and bounty hunters falling from the sky. My face on every holo-screen. PD mech suits stomping after me.  Heck, maybe even the Militech and Arasaka wanting to take a crack at me.

Nope. Just get bored, clear out an area, loot, and run until they lose track of and forget about me, sell of the scarps, and then rinse and repeat.

IT MAKES ZERO SENSE!!! Especially when what stopped me was not death or arrest or just returning to the main story for the grins and giggles of it. No. After a seemingly endless and unstoppable rampage, the game just crashed.

Oh. Also, the city is mostly un-enterable empty boxes.  Lots and lots of buildings with lots and lots of doors. Can't enter them. It's just meaningless backdrop. Guild Wars also did this.  It was ok for Guild Wars... because that was with game technology from 20 years ago!

Also, side quests are *yaaaaawn*. And, the main storyline is so on rails, it's like a glorified visual novel with faceroll across the keyboard combat that barely equals a quicktime event. Why am I doing this? Why do I care? What doesn't my character just say, "Fong with this noise!" and open a soy-lent stir-fry shop? Who knows? I don't. Nothing feel impactful.

FFS, this game has been a huge disappointment. The Cyberpunk IP deserved better. Way better. And, CDPR can do better.  So, WTF happened here? I will tell you what. Corpo greed.  Almost ironic, isn't it, considering the story material...

author: {'steamid': '76561198212692520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 4308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2391, 'last_played': 1721190868}
review:
This is getting a do not recommend from me for the following reasons:
Terrible and rushed launch and the game is still broken (multiple glitches and crashes).

Cyberpunk was a game that could of been great. Its a cool sci-fi concept mixed with an immersive world. However, the game was rushed and released in a terrible state. Its playable now but glitches and crashes are not rare. Gameplay is fun and worth a try, however I don't think we should be rewarding the concept of rushed development and half-baked products.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146974538', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 22071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22071, 'last_played': 1726936007}
review:
TLDR: I loved this game. But since the major patches and DLC, can't enjoy it anymore.

IMO, the major patch changed a lot more things than it should have. Changed the game from a somewhat serious game to a much more arcade version. Number of items in your inventory doesn't matter (specifically, medical items and grenades) and you only get 2 which then "reload" automatically. Throw a knife and it automagically comes back to you after a few seconds. The whole perk tree got revamped, requiring you to unlock silly perk trees, and it has overall become a very arcade game.

The game's launch, subsequent patches fixing it, then the newer changes kinda show which direction CDPR is headed in. :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198934878102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1645, 'last_played': 1715888600}
review:
Game seems great, but I faced one game breaking bug I couldn't ignore (IDK how people called Cyberpunk a polished game. I have seen so many bugs for the 12 hours I played, but mostly visual bugs. but still.).  

decided to give Cyberpunk another try and after 11-12 hours of gameplay I cannot run anymore. I already checked (key bindings, settings, nothing helps.) It is the second time I am facing this issue, first time I lost about 30 minutes of game and started with older save file, but right now I faced it again and I cannot do anything. It is happening consistently when I pick up Panam's sniper rifle.

Overall. dropped the game because I couldn't fix it. Will give another chance for the game since it looks like a good game, when I upgrade my PC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026932320', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 7918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7918, 'last_played': 1720817286}
review:
I have been following and playing to completion CDProjectRED's games since the first Witcher game. I have been thrilled to see them get better and better as time goes on culminating in the Witcher 3. Cyberpunk 2077 has a benchmark that allowed me to find fantastic settings that served me well the whole way through the game, enabling a level of immersion other games only dream of. My issue is that you get pulled out of that immersion a lot, and by really silly things that shouldn't be an issue, but are.

The music for the game is great, the music on the radio is terrible, each station has 2 or 3 great songs, 2-3 okay songs and 6-8 garbage songs, if it's the future let me spend eddies to choose what is on my radio. One of the Witcher 3's strengths was its music, it unified the whole of the game IMHO. For Cyberpunk 2077, music very much fails it.

I hated playing Cyberpunk 2077, it felt like a slog. You could go to a mission or a gig and then feel like the game is just talking at you for 15 to 30 minutes (while not building the world, just building drama) and then make you fire from some silenced sniper cannon in a mode never seen before and will never be seen again. This habit of forcing you to play the game outside your comfort zone and outside of the strengths of your build constantly frustrated me. Those missions or gigs could end up lasting more than an hour. I'd find some time to give Cyberpunk between other things and I'd shy away from missions or gigs because I might not have time to finish them.

There are also TONS of shards that have varying amounts of world building lore on them that if you want to learn you need to pause the game to read through, hundreds if not thousands of the darn things. I want to play the game, I don't want to take a history course in a place that doesn't exist. This could have been covered over by taking a page out of Fallout's book by having a mechanical AI voice "read the shard" while you keep playing, to keep the frenetic pace when Cyberpunk 2077 is at its best. The world and lore of Cyberpunk should have been a strength when it turned out to be a weakness, both in the embrace and delivery of it. If there was an in game audiobooks I could buy on the different subjects I could buy for in game currencies I TOTALLY would have done that while I explored the city. This is the theme of Cyberpunk 2077, odd decisions just piling up in a crash to ruin the game. There are tons of vending machines everywhere, let me use them to get the food and drink buffs instead of buying them in bulk from specific vendors and then ever forgetting I had them (I believe I complete the game with over 100 hot dogs rotting in my inventory because I kept forgetting to use them).

Ultimately the game is still a little janky, even after 2.1. I also see the blank spaces on the canvas where a much greater and grander game with mutliple DLCs was supposed to be. I believe Cyberpunk 2077 did not get the time in the oven it needed and it never recovered from that. Like Starfield I put it to you that it was supposed to be a platform for other products well into the future, putting off some of the most interesting aspects of the world for a future DLC that never came. Don't get me wrong, it is a staggering achievement in many areas and it is let down by so many little decisions that make the game painful to play. It is a game that is less than the sum of its parts and honestly has much in common with Starfield because of it.

I see what could, and perhaps should have been and it makes me sad. I wish I could recommend this game, however it is a deep cut and certainly not for everyone.

review:
Cyberpunk looks better on the outside than it actually is and fails to be an rpg and turns more so into a looter shooter, the base game has a decent amount of good content but not enough for a huge open world, alot of good dialogue and characters but with very boring progression, skills and combat that lacks depth you just end up with a shooter that is fun at times with some good narratives but falls short for the scale of the world.

The DLC is much better adding choices that have meaningful outcomes and consequences to go along with them but it doesn't fix the problems with the game.

Bro said one of the best games ever made? I wouldn't even put this above borderlands (1, 2 or 3). Even on sale, I consider this a pass.

review: I enjoyed my first couple of hours, but then the game began to crash within 20 minutes of loading. I can look at the menu screen all day, but I can't get into Night City for more than a half hour without the game freezing and crashing to the desktop. Like an idiot, I kept monkeying with it to fix it and went past the refund window. Now I have this unplayable albatross in my library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140193828', 'num_games_owned': 27, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1729472367}
review:
About four hours in...I actually pretty much hate it. I do not understand what all the hype is about. This game sucks and it makes me mad how corny it is, it's like a poor mans GTA.
 It kind of reminds me of the sequels to The Matrix, Over the top and kind of ridiculous with out how serious it takes itself even though the whole premise is kind of silly.  I was hoping for something really immersive, I'm just wrapping up Red dead redemption 2 and THAT is how world building, story telling and immersion should be. Every game dev who is going for a game with a large and believable world should look to RDR2 as the gold standard. Overall I do like the concept of Cyberpunk 2077, I'm a huge fan of Blade runner and general future dystopian scifi so I was coming into this assuming I'd like it but the balance between showing me a fully lived in world thats believable and trying to hard to seem cool isn't working out too well. It's also not completely failing either, not to the point where I feel like putting the game away. There are a lot of concepts I like and I'm seeing a lot of potential as the story and the way the gameplay unfolds so I'm hanging in there for now hoping for it to get just a little better. I can say at this point in the game that I'm a little disappointed with how linear it's been so far, from what I've heard it's supposed to open up to more open world pretty soon but god damn, four hours in and there's still a fair amount of hand holding and 'go here and get this, go there and meet them' kind of missions going on. Hopefully soon it opens up and I can really start exploring and get the sense that the city and the world is a living breathing place and not just a backdrop.
As far as performance I've heard a lot of conflicting reports on it but for me it's been pretty much perfectly smooth, I'm running it on a Lenovo Legion i7 pro with a geforce rtx 4080 and 32gb of ram, I have almost everything cranked to ultra and I'm getting a consistent 100+ FPS so no complaints there. I can say I have seen more glitches than I would expect in a AAA game with this much hype around it. Nothing game breaking but plenty of immersion breaking glitches, people walking though objects, people responding with dialog that clearly isn't right for what's happening, people clipping into each other, clipping though walls etc etc. It hasn't been anything that's made me want to quit at this point but it's crazy how much of it I've seen at only four hours in (insert Bethesda joke here I guess). 
The combat is okay, nothing that I'd get excited about, at least not at this point, but again I see a lot of potential in terms of upgrading weapons and body mods etc. so maybe that will get better.

Over all it's not a bad game, I spent $30 on it and I think it's worth that for sure. I wish they would tone down the "Super cool" aesthetics it's a little over the top and takes away from it being world that I want to participate in but I guess I should have expected that being that the name of the game is Cyberpunk.

TLDR
At four hours in I'd say
It's not bad for $30
wish it was more like RDR2 in terms of immersion and maturity but I would probably say that about any open world game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035719963', 'num_games_owned': 189, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1734716406}
review: Ya know what I love after spending this much fucking money on this game? Getting blocked from finishing an entire questline because of a bug that has been reported since release. Truly, the cyberpunk experience of companies not giving a fuck to you or your feedback.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189139947', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1702122281}
review:
Shooting robots in a colorful large depressing world, for nothing.
I tried to play this game, multiple times, but I can't.

Team changed, people changed. Now I know I will never see another real witcher game.
Goodbye.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068492865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1716669809}
review:
Been playing the game for barely a few hours. Crashes were happening randomly in game a few times, up until two days ago when a crash happened in the main menu randomly. After that, I couldn't even run the game. It crashes like a second or two upon launching the game. I thought this game was fixed. Disappointed, especially because I was quite enjoying the game up until recently.
Edit1: Well, I can't even refund the game, even though I literally can't run it anymore. And I tried every possible fix that was recommended. Clean GPU driver install, chipset driver update, everything. I've even reinstalled the whole Windows, yet I still can't play it. Flatlines 2 seconds after launch with Unknown GPU error. This is embarrassing, seriously. I have no idea how this game is getting so many positive reviews.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088340386', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6355, 'last_played': 1715607000}
review:
Spoilers ahead. I would like to mention it right off the bat: I think I had very high expectations for this game and avoided any content related to it so as not to spoil anything when I finally get to play it. But then again, the developers have promised so so much that it is only fair to judge the game using the "high promises=high expectations" method. 3.5 years later this game is still a buggy mess, although 99% of the bugs are visual and almost harmless, even hella funny for the most part, it's mostly the random crashes for absolutely no reason that make you lose your mind. The main story, while catching and thrilling, is very short. I thought that by the time you meet with Hanako at the Embers it's like 1/3rd of the game where you have to make a choice to either side with the corpos or become their enemy after which a huge crusade with or against them follows (with well-written characters to meet, setups, battles, intrigues etc). Freedom of choice is non-existent; at first there are strict rules set by the narrative only to be tastelessy and blatantly sharted on hard later on in the game in the form of countless plot holes as the devs didn't care. The world is empty with none of the activities that can be found in GTA games. Well, you can drink at a bar in some places and on a singular occassion play a game of poker as a part of Phantom Liberty's main quest, even then I am almost sure the outcome is scripted, and that's pretty much it. A total bummer as during the development stage devs continuously aggressively advertised the game as almost "second real life" never-seen-before type of experience in terms of roleplay and freedom of choice capabilities. said every NPC you saw would have meaningful unique dialogues, routines, that every building would be enterable etc etc. What we see in reality is a game stripped of everything but shooting. Aside from the main story, there are 200+ come&kill scenarios which include all the NCPD "quests" and the vast majority of side jobs/fixer gigs. You can collect 20 tarot cards and read notes and that's it. Then there are braindances... Whoever thought even one person would find this cancer of a game mechanic entertaining and whoever approved it should all never be allowed anywhere near game dev again. Speaking of cancerous game mechanics, "quickhacking" and "scanning" are both amped up versions of the "witcher sense" mechanic which is horribly cringe on its own, but somehow this game makes it even worse. I do understand the thought process behind those though - quickhacks exist so that poor bastards who use gaming consoles can deal with the countless enemies this game throws your way. You'd think at least you can take advantage of the beautiful city cruising around in your car getting all the aesthetic pleasure in the world but then you're dead wrong - while there are numerous flashy cars, they all handle like absolute $h1t, no exception either as I've tried them all and driving them is nothing but painful so I just resorted to using fast travel all the time at some point. I can not remember a single game that has cars where they handle worse than in this one. Also, there's that stupid and unasked for faction that is Aldecaldos, they only exist in the game alongside their respective meaningless quests that are mandatory (at least half of them are) so that you have a reason to go to the desert portion of the map and thus it is at least somewhat incorporated into the gameplay process. They do not have a goal, their whole idea is to live like bums and rob military companies and corpos and that's pretty much it. Then there's Panam who is an absolutely lame character who has no personality whatsoever and her conflict with the other Aldecaldo leader is very stupid and lazily made just to create some sort of tension between otherwise entirely bland characters. Having all of the above said, this game doesn't differ from all the countless looter shooters out there that much and doesn't have much going on for it aside from its looks and Keanu Reeves as well as Idris Elba cameos. The looks are unbelievable though, gotta hand it to CDPR here. Especially the DLC portion of the map that is absolutely jaw-dropping: every single angle, no matter where you are, is incredibly picturesque and worthy of admiration. The interiors are well-made as well. Thank God I figured that the pistols build was OP, otherwise I would've had to list the shooting mechanic as "poorly made" as well. Once you get the hang of it, shooting non-automatic weapons in this game is actually fun.
Bottom line:
"She's nice, six outta ten" (real quote from the game and I thought I'd use it for comedic value but if I were to give it an honest score it would be closer to a 4.5)

author: {'steamid': '76561199073704877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 6996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4935, 'last_played': 1732503197}
review: Where to start. Well first off I do like this game and want to like it, but it makes it difficult for me to come back to it sometimes. Gameplay and story are prem, but there are still tons of major glitches i keep running into. First major one is the map just not loading or taking like five years to load everything in and sometime i just fall through a unloaded chunk of the map (note i was all going fast). Second glitch and it only happened in the begining of the dlc is that the lighting will just disappear and everything will be dark (Note just had to restart to get it back to normal). Now to give credit to the devs it use to be alot worse.All of these are minor inconveniences, but are prominent 2 to 3 years after the game has  released still. tldr: Game gud but bugs Make ME ANGY >:(

author: {'steamid': '76561197973562766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8932, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8890, 'last_played': 1734914496}
review:
Over hyped pre-2020, yes. But I've read recently that with all the patches and fixes, it would be GOTY material so I installed it again. 

Have I spent a lot of time in this title? Yes. Have I enjoyed my time and completed the story? Yes. 

Have I also ran through literally dozens and dozens of cops ranging from standard donut munchers to tactical war robots, battering each to death with a pleasure toy, then sauntered across the street and into an empty train car for them to all completely lose me, then jump out and do it all again when they forgot about how many of their brethren I willy-slapped to death? Yes. Just recently. It wasn't as fun as it sounds. 

So 4 years on and it's still not GOTY material.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011082013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3885, 'last_played': 1713139379}
review: My mistake was having a preconception of this game being a "cyberwitcher" in terms of narrative. I can't recommend it as the side quests are forgettable. Main history was a little better, but not that great. the gameplay at first was good enough for me to try the game past the refund period, but later on I understood that I should have asked for that refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052551356', 'num_games_owned': 33, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1712540139}
review: O jogo é simplesmente ruim. Menus confusos, muita informação desnecessária na tela. O enredo, ao menos até onde joguei, não tem nada de especial, e é apresentado sem cutscenes, o que prejudica muito o storytelling. Só o que é soberbo mesmo são os gráficos, realmente muito bons. A ambientação é muito boa, porém os cartazes e banners dos ambientes, comércio e máquinas, poderiam ter um ar mais realista, é tudo muito forçado para o lado cômico. Pedi reembolso e talvez quando esteja mais no clima do jogo, retorne a jogá-lo. Mas a simplicidade perfeita de the witcher 3 faz muita falta aqui em Cyberpunk.

author: {'steamid': '76561199097071136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 4830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2658, 'last_played': 1714313758}
review:
I'll start by saying I only started playing this after all the issues about overpromising and underdelivering.

The game as it is now is a bit underwhelming. Characters are ok, story is cool but this is not what I want to write about.

[h2]Stealth[/h2]

[--] [b]You can walk behind enemies just fine without being detected[/b] unless you get REALLY close like until when you get the silent takedown prompt. I was walking during an "assault in progress" thinking I was crouched but I couldn't notice the difference, really.

[--] [b]Falling from a ledge doesn't alert nearby enemies.[/b] And neither does jumping above items like the trash containers. I can jump on stuff right behind the enemy and they won't hear a thing. I can drop from them or jump off and they won't hear a thing.

[--] [b]You can be tracked after throwing a knife.[/b] I get that enemies can start tracking you if you use a traceable quickhack, but by throwing a knife while crouched and undetected? I did not use tech at all. Make it make sense.

[--] [b]Enemies can "discover" bodies you have already hidden.[/b] This only happened when I moved a body into the back of a car (due to unavailable trash containers), and the game soon after that said "Body has been discovered" but there was nothing on the ground let alone in their line of sight.

[-] [b]The camera keeps moving in the same direction while scanning[/b] even if I actually stopped moving it. It keeps going in the same direction I was going but doesn't stop, to fix that I have to disable the scan.

[+] [b]Camera automatically shifts a little if you are behind cover and you are aiming/scanning,[/b] making it possible to aim your throwable knife from cover without actually moving out of it since the camera automatically does that for you, this is quite helpful.

I honestly want to think the game was not created with stealth gameplay in mind, but it has its own perk tree with enhanchments to throweable weapons and the "cool" trait that improves stealth... but then there are all these issues that just ruin the experience.

There is also exclusive dialogue to certain quests if you complete them without drawing unnecessary attention, so to me it looks looks like stealth was supposed to be an integrated part of how you play the game, but developed poorly.

[h2]General[/h2]

[--] [b]Main line quests automatically become tracked after completing a side quest.[/b] This is mainly annoying because I am the kind of person who tries to clear all secondary quests before proceeding, but the main quests keep getting tracked every single time and I have to disable them because when I track a secondary quest then both paths are shown and I get confused. The main issue here is that you can track multiple quests at the same time, just replace the old track with the new one instead.

[---] [b]Fan-service is everywhere.[/b] I am seriously getting tired of seeing ads and posters with obviously sexualised women. The game's first mission has literally you holding a naked woman and since it's in first person you see the b00bs up close. I just want to play a game without unnecessary fan-service elements. I don't need to see sexualised women everywhere as I play.

[-] [b]Some T-Poses[/b] here and there. it shows the game is not polished.

[-] [b]Some NPCs have clothes that keep glitching[/b] and you see random stuff on the screen as if it wasn't rendered properly.

[-] [b]Some animations are skipped entirely[/b] for example when you open the back of a car to put a body, it justs shows the end of the animation skipping the part where you actually do it.

[/] [b]Controls to select different dialogue options are the same for moving,[/b] which I found rather odd. You can pick different options with the mouse's scroll wheel and arrows as well though.

[/] [b]You only get a static image preview when you are checking which car to buy.[/b] I can't rotate it to see if I might actually like it or zoom the picture either, just a small static image on the PC. I got fooled with my first car because I thought I liked it but I missed a big detail. It didn't have a hood... I am stuck with an ugly car.

[h2]My biggest gripe[/h2]

[---] [b]You can't see your character.[/b] Although you start the game by creating the character you'll play. you won't be able to see any of that except through occasional mirrors which is in no way enough.
There are clothing shops, you can find clothes as drops from enemies or through chests, you can dress your protagonist however you like but... it all comes to who actually sees that? Not a single soul. 

Every time I pick new clothes or see shops that sell them in the map I honestly feel bittersweet because it makes no sense and is such a waste. I want to see my character in a new style but nope I am denied.
I tried using a mod that forces third person but shift lock is enabled which means that if I rotate the camera so does my character. And not to mention the ugly third-person animations and such which are intended for first-person. 

Also a bug that my hair color gets changed when I wear a hat, but you wouldn't notice this considering the game is locked in first person.

[--] What you can notice though is that [b]while inside a motor bike, where the view is in third person, your character becomes bald if you're wearing a hat[/b]. This is the case for when you check yourself in the mirror too; even the hat disappears.

Gameplay is fine, I'm going through by oneshotting with knife. It's saddening that I can't see how stylish I am though.

There's some fun to be had, but the game is clearly unpolished and these points need to be addressed.

review:
Great Game just too much going on all at once. Some people will take that negative, but for myself I've reached a point with gaming that having too much to do isn't always a good thing for me. It sounded great when I was younger now it's just a chore if feels like. 

Maybe my opinion will change once I start going through the game itself.

UPDATE: Since changed my review to negative then game is the most overrated game in the history of any medium at this point. Like I'm thinking about stopping it where I'm at and definitely trying something else now. 

Story is bland and boring thus far, and even the part where Jackie dies is so weak that I feel no type of emotion at all. Driving is horrible in this game this is the worst experience driving anything I've ever dealt with. 

The only problem is it didn't feel this way before 2.13 update when I made my positive review the driving wasn't this loose with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034095005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1571, 'last_played': 1710080773}
review:
The game still is buggy regularly. The game world feels empty beside the quests. Often the game locks your actions in scriptet scenes e.g. sometimes leaving you stuck in rail-shooting sequences without being able to equip a proper weapon. Then you end up being stuck on objects sometimes and you couldnt save the last few minutes leaving forcing you to reload and do weird bugged railshooters again. 

This game either had to be good to be great or is forced to feel hollow. Sadly the latter, even after loads of patches that seemed to have fixed loads of the initial problems.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041607666', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3430, 'last_played': 1713919511}
review: I love this game, but it's an absolute shame it now crashes every 3-5 minutes. This does not get a recommendation from me. I want to enjoy it so badly, but at this rate I'm losing my mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089263979', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 21302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1713600622}
review:
I really wish I liked the game. I've loved the cyberpunk universe since the 90s.
The game is beautiful and the NPCs are well written with a pretty cool take on the cyberware.
Those are the only things good about it. 
The story telling is trash, I would of rather watched a long cut-scene than play through any of the railroaded tutorial. And there is no 3rd person perspective, that alone is a dealbreaker but with such shitty writing it is possibly the most painful game I am actually playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198283141305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4519, 'last_played': 1712543632}
review: La historia del juego está bien, el problema es que sigue mal optimizado; el texturizado tarda en cargar y varias veces se ha cerrado el juego de repente. El DLC, en la primera misión, al hackear la computadora, se queda atascado sin desconectarse de la computadora; se vuelve molesto jugar así.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023263037', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2214, 'last_played': 1709673477}
review:
Just in short, the only cool thing is night city. It's fun to travel through the city, also its just mostly empty backdrop. The most parts of the main story are mediocre to annoying.
There are a few quests (especially side-quests) that are fun and interesting. But most of the time i got the feeling the game is playing me and not the other way. There is a lot of `follow this one, do that` without having a real choice of what to do or how to do things.
If you like games where you could find your own way to do things (like the most open world games) stay away or wait for a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086901970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 208, 'playtime_at_review': 6489, 'last_played': 1736123523}
review:
I want to love this game so badly. I pre ordered the second it was available, I've played during it's good months and it's bad. I respect the dlc that CDPR put out, but Phantom Liberty completely broke my game. I've done a fresh install, I've turned HDD on and off, I've toggled cross save on and off. I've ran the game on completely low settings. I've turned RTX on and off, MY GAME CRASHES WITHIN 30 SECONDS. I've tried loading old saves, still the same. I can sometimes walk around dogtown for a few minutes, but as soon as I attempt to leave and go to the gate my game "flatlines." 
This is unacceptable, and my willingness to start a fresh game is non existent because what if this happens after another 100 hours? I've had games crash on my 3080 desktop maybe 80 times, cyberpunk has been 79 of those times....... It makes me sick that 3 years later the game still crashes on me over and over and over again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198357093188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 10415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8105, 'last_played': 1731961209}

author: {'steamid': '76561198005352559', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1888, 'last_played': 1735397509}
review:
Dumb open world skinner box with some GTA thrown in.
A smaller world and more focused design would really have helped the game.

Don't trust anyone who tells you that it's good after dozens of patches.
Both times I started the game I was confronted with bugs from the get-go, like not seeing myself in the mirror in the literal first scene of the game.
There's still items floating in the air, T-posing NPCs, etc.

The entire loot aspect bogs the game down. As do the random encounters and the lack of anything meaningful to do within the sprawling environment.
In my second playthrough I also had the "pleasant" experience of deciding that I would do a hacker + "cool" playstyle with sniper rifles and shit.
I didn't find a single sniper rifle within six hours or so, despite having at least one plot mission that seemed geared towards allowing for snipers.
As it also turns out, playing a hacker is boring as all fuck. You are literally sitting in a corner and playing an idle game with enemy HP bars.

Even the guns and cyberware are rife with seemingly randomly generated stats that just bog the game down with meaningless choice. It would make much more sense to have iconic guns be the only ones you can find and everything else dispensed freely at merchants without any gating based on level or whatever. Maybe put different weapon categories into different shops and then add a little extra customization.
In fact, customization over loot would really help with the thematic aspect of playing a hardened veteran of the cyberpunk underworld. What professional depends on randomly finding a halfway decent tool in a suspiciously immobile hobo's blanket, instead of consciously perfecting his loadout and avoiding over-encumbrance like superfluous weapons and entire waggons full of literal, actual, trash that was on the ground?
Make me cut a deal with a corp to get the real good cyberware and then have some plotlines from me inevitably catching some kind of backdoor, instead of randomly generating an endless list of different eyeballs that range from "1% faster reload" to "1% more invisible" or something.

Some of the UI is completely fucking arcane. Crafting is shoved into a semi-hidden sub-menu. Weapons can only be equipped with mods if you have them equipped. Weapon types (Tech, Smart, etc.) have no indication outside of the tooltip, but only in the tooltips of some menus, but total ammo pool (I think?) is displayed on the weapon icons as if it mattered at all.
It's a complete mess.

The mere existence of an ammo pool in this game is so ludicrously braindead that I wonder if there was anyone who didn't live in a 24/7 delirium during this game's crunchtime. As it stands now, you have 9999 of every bullet on you at every time and constantly find ammo crates everywhere and can also turn used condoms into more ammo and then also spend money to buy some more.
If you are so worried about players running out of ammo that you make it effectively infinite, how about you just remove the fucking system?
I thought rupees in Zelda TP were bad, but this shit is next level.

The clothing system is bad. The idea of applying a skin so that you don't look like the creature of the trashcan is okay enough, although only necessary because of this game having this pointless loot mechanic.
However, some of the pieces of clothing are pretty much broken in how they interact. For example, you can wear a spandex undersuit and then apply something on top. Some articles of clothing show the undersuit where they'd normally expose skin, which makes sense. Some, however, apply the character's skin *over* the undersuit.
Also, again, you are at the mercy of trash can dives to assemble your wardrobe, instead of just choosing what you want to get more into the immersion of the missions.

Also, I opted to play with a controller on my second attempt. Man, that control scheme is just awful.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983225161', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 313, 'playtime_forever': 5221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3284, 'last_played': 1708379520}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042154807', 'num_games_owned': 617, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 13967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13967, 'last_played': 1491861878}
review:
As you can tell from the ~250 hours I've put into this game, I truly loved it.

However, the company and publishers who've made this game are a bunch of greedy cun7$ that deserve no money from me and won't be getting it ever again. This game was only special because of what it could have been,  and the love and dedication that people put into the mods for this game truly completed it, as when it was released (in a rush i'm sure for that stupid 11/11/11 date) the game was a complete buggy Bethesda mess. I only enjoyed my time in the game being able to mod it and try the things that other people were making out. Since this game's release Bethesda has continued their dramatic decline into money hungry sh!tshills. Everything they've made it seems like post the release of this masterpiece seems to have had $$$$ as it's sole focus. 

Screw the game, screw the story, screw the engine it's fine it works. These people disgust me and you should support them. smaller and smaller studios have been making better and better games, no need to waste time on over marketed, soul-less, money grubbing, bullsh!t like this. I mean truly, the last good games Bethesda made were PERHAPS fallout 4, and for sure fallout new vegas and 3.

Anything newer has been obviously reaching for your wallet and somehow worse and worse in performance each release. The games aren't fun, their engine sucks. You want to experience these stories? watch youtube videos, they respect your time and wallet more than these b@stards.

Curious if the old workshop files are still live with those l@zyCun t$ trying to charge for other people's passionate mod work. 

It's infuriating. Todd Howard is a POS.  I'd have recommended this but nobody will see this review, cause Bethesda missing half it's chromosomes and can't come up with a new idea to save its' life.

This comment is specifically written on the off-chance that some Bethesda executive or employee might read it some day. You suck, and you destroyed the love I had for your games. I  will NEVER pay you money for a damn thing again. My attitude has only been vindicated by seeing how awful Starfield is. Not worth a cent.

Hope y'all get your Sh!t together.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020595897', 'num_games_owned': 2722, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 12183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12183, 'last_played': 1580664078}
review:
They delisted this version of the game and all the DLC just to force users to buy the re-releases, typical Bethesda behavior, shitty move, and anti-consumer.

The game itself is ok if modded, but there are still a lot of bugs in the vanilla version of the game (even in the new re-releases, again, typical Bethesda behavior). The story is pretty boring (fighting dragons is cool at first, but become kinda annoying after a while, as there's not much variety to them, the civil war story is pretty straight-forward and nothing unexpected happens in it, some side quests are more fun than the main story: The Mind Of Madness, Lost Knowledge, A Night To Remember, Hail Sithis!, Blood On The Ice, Ill Met By Moonlight), the writing's not very interesting for most of the main storyline and most NPCs are forgettable (some stand out, like Cicero, M'aiq The Liar, Sheogorath, Neloth, Paarthurnax) the combat is average, but the world is pretty pleasant to look at (it has a pretty strong art-style and aesthetic), it is quite fun to explore.

Personally, I really hope they'll return to the more complex stories and RPG elements of Morrowind with the next installment in the series, but given Skyrim's huge success and mass-appeal, Bethesda will most likely dumb down TES VI even more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211496363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1049, 'last_played': 1724982166}

author: {'steamid': '76561198007233194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 2134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2134, 'last_played': 1480100534}
review:
Skyrim Special Edition is at 40 euros.
No way to convert to SSE for a free, or a clearly mentioned way for Skyrim owners.
No option on SSE to upgrade for a nice price (such as 5 or 10 euros).

This is clearly not a proper support culture.

Very heavily disapproved Bethesda:
you made us care for Skyrim, you made us want to play it, and then you put such limitations on its supported mods, such as [i]"oh you should have been there during the special promotion moment, sooooorrry"[/i]. Support should wake up and provide another route now, for all people who did not watch these news.

Where is the upgrade option on store page? And no, no way to pay 40 euros for a graphical upgrade. Current game owners should have it for much cheaper (10 euros at most). This is not console world here.

"Bethesda I hold a grudge against you now", which is fairly disappointing and non-logical for a good & great game you initially made.  This is what this lack of support and upgrade option is making. Give us upgrade options!

author: {'steamid': '76561198058388324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2997, 'last_played': 1724981560}
review:
I picked this game up on steam when it first released, played through it for a bit during the time and what I remember it was ok.  However, every couple of years since I've tried to replay and can't for the life of me make it in a new game.  Thoroughly overspec'd machines for this.  Windows, Ubuntu, both intel and amd cpu's, 2080ti, 3070, 4080 super GPUs, ddr4&5 32gb+ ram, nvme ssd's separate from OS ssd.  Unmodded vanilla install.  Horses bug out during the intro, either flipping the cart or just straight up flipping themselves and unable to park the cart in the intro.  On the occasion I do get out of the cart successfully, game freezes during character creation.

I'd love to replay this on PC again but literally can't.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970505434', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2796, 'last_played': 1567566215}
review:
So I loved Skyrim when it 1st came out It had a lot of bugs even a few gaming-breaking bugs that prevented me from completing the main story without googling console commands. but i forgave the bugs. And they fixed a lot of the game-breaking bugs.  But there were a lot of bugs still left. Then they sold us the Legendary Edition didn't fix many bugs, then the Special Edition without fixing many bugs, and again the Anniversary Edition without fixing many bugs. 

So they keep Selling and use the same buggy game over and over. We shouldn’t have to mod a game to fix bugs they are activate making money on.

review: Tried to get into it multiple times, got to the third act twice, about 30-40 hours, just felt kinda bland and wasted. The quests (both main and side quests) and voice-acting is all great, but when the gameplay and combat are this mediocre, just don't want to force myself into playing it. Weirdly, Elder Scrolls Online however, was great, so unsure why this didn't click, but that could be the group play in ESO makes me feel far more like I actually have my role as a mage/archer/brute etc. I don't think it's a "bad game", I just don't find value in it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981719788', 'num_games_owned': 619, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 24973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24973, 'last_played': 1716770244}
review:
i used to love this game, then they removed mod support.

then they removed mod support.  the base game is great, a huge open world you can do anything you want to, can be anything you want to be, but will probably end up doing stealth archery.

the base ui sucks, it is clunky, hard to navigate, clunky, hard to sort items, when you do work on things you have to do three mouse clicks, after you figure out what you are doing, it has short timers on potions that require you to maximize usage and save resources.  they made a mod to fix all this, but now you cant use it, they made mods that fix the outdated graphics, cant use those anymore, they made mods that let you control your followers, cant use those any more, they made mods that made the default races actually different and changed how you could play, got rid of those too.

i cant recommend this game anymore, well and it is now 13 years old, has been released on every platform, multiple times, and they still have not come out with a real sequel

author: {'steamid': '76561198274857141', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 18002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17456, 'last_played': 1717529717}
review:
Love this game ever since I first played in 2012 on the PS3, but either Bethesda or Steam screwed up something pretty crucial.
I remember buying the DLCs for this game (such as Hearthfire), I remember building a house, adopting a kid, hiring a bard, making a massive library in the tower of the house I made, and now its just..gone. The DLCs I once had are gone, I don't remember how many I had but I sure as hell owned Hearthfire and they removed it. 

This is an issue I had for ages and every time I get back into this game I remember this and how it infuriates me. I didn't know if it was possible or maybe I was losing it but I checked with a friend who has the same edition as me and they don't have their DLCs anymore either. Thanks, Todd

author: {'steamid': '76561198083722849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1710470812}
review:
Skyrim itself is a great game, but this is the first time playing it on a computer in a while. I was having trouble getting the game to respond because I forgot that it disables any changes I make to the mouse, such as changing it to a left handed configuration. I can play the game, but it requires me to play using the mouse RIGHT HANDED, which I am not. So if you are left handed I don't recommend buying the game from Steam.

For the record, I've played Skyrim on Xbox One and on 360 for literally thousands of hours, but after buying this copy as well I've only played on this account for 4 (according to steam). If you want me to play your game don't make me play right handed ... I should not have to rewire my brain to fit your software decisions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138934876', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1195, 'last_played': 1709221331}
review:
In any game I expect a small bug here or there, it happens and it gets overlooked
But when you start the game, and the horse + cart that you are on glitches all over and comes to a stop, never finding its destination, its not the kind of buggy that you would expect from a tittle like this. Before, it was at least playable, but seems it just got worse over time
Waste of time
Piece of shit
Rather spend your money on drugs and hookers

author: {'steamid': '76561197980424715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 755347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740979, 'last_played': 1728345635}
review:
Firstly, the game has been very decent to play, though a good chunk of the issues lie from 2 things:

1.  Bugs in the game that were never fixed, make game play laggy, crashy and downright unplayable (corrupted saves).
2.  Steam has this revolving issue where the keyboard works only with the overlay and never with the game, right now, I can't even play it (again) because Steam again has changed something that has broken the keyboard input for the game.  As I said, the overlay works via keyboard, but all I can do is use the mouse and quit the game.

For those wanting Skyrim, avoid this one, Steam has done it a disservice and move onto the Anniversary Edition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126832288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 5403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5403, 'last_played': 1718402790}
review:
This review is basically useless because Bethesda hid the original release of Skyrim from the store page when the anniversary edition came out, but I don't care and I have opinions I want to shout into the void regardless.

I remember playing this game all the way back in 2012 and being completely entranced by it. The combat was fun, the spells were awesome and I loved the world I explored.

My windows pc broke and was replaced with an apple computer which could not run the game so I was essentially locked out of continuing my journey. Fast forward to about 2020 and I was ready to play the game again after so long only to realize OH NO ITS MID.

Everything I had once enjoyed about the game seemed to be gone. I thought that perhaps this was because as a child, I was barely able to interact with the game on the depth I had come to expect as an adult. Maybe I would enjoy it more if I was able to grasp it on a deeper level than I used to. I went to sink my teeth into the critically acclaimed open world rpg I had loved so fondly as a child only to shatter my jaw on the realization that the often parroted "mile wide, inch deep" was in fact, painfully true to the highest degree. No amount of nostalgia could salvage it and nothing new that I discovered or explored filled me with any joy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073093646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 31485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31485, 'last_played': 1716586317}
review: I bought Skyrim back when it first came out.  It was the greatest game out there.  Then Bethesda got greedy, and came out with Skyrim Special Edition.  Many Skyrim players left the game.  SE had very little in the way of mods at the time.  Then Bethesda got even greedier, and doubled down on the stupidity, and came out with the "Anniversary Edition", which pretty much killed modding.  I own Skyrim, and Skyrim SE (Gog version).  Most of my my favorite mods either no longer work, or you have to jump through hoops to make them work.  I have over 524 hours logged, over many years, so I know what I am talking about.  At this point,  I am done with Skyrim, and I will never buy a Bethesda game again.  They had a great thing, and their greed and stupidity screwed it all up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051795337', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 8879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1337, 'playtime_at_review': 4371, 'last_played': 1736797562}
review:
Lets say it first. Skyrim shouldn't get a negative review. It is a good game with plenty to do and good wiriting. But the game itself is such a buggy mess that it deserves the negative review.

So we all know that Skyrim is a lengthy open world RPG with very open rules for how you can build your character. So all good on that front but then there are the bugs...
The game is pretty buggy and at least for me any water makes the game almost unplayable as drawing and striking with weapons becomes almost impossible. The draw/sheat animation just repeats itself and even when you think that you finally have the sword at hand the game still thinks that you want to draw/sheat your weapon.
Then there are the floating objects, scripts that don't work, enemies that lack hit boxes etc.

Seriously the fact that I have already played this much of the game is a testament to how good it is as a game! Too bad that the game is held together with bubblegum...

author: {'steamid': '76561197983064292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 16791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16791, 'last_played': 1587711562}
review:
When the game came out in 2011, it was pretty good (for it's time), but even back then, it was still a downgrade from previous iterations, specifically TES:III Morrowind and older titles. It might be considered an upgrade over TES:IV Oblivion, but that isn't saying much.

The only way you'll get your money's worth in Skyrim, today (2024 and beyond), is if you are modding it (and not paying for those mods). Only with mod support does this game hold up today. The core game is pretty shallow, Bethesda has gotten worse every year since 2011 and they have been subsisting off re-releasing Skyrim over and over every console generation, even trying to port it into VR.

People thought that Bethesda still had some gas left with Starfield, but it was another lie sold by Todd Howard.

I am an older gamer and somewhat of an elitist when it comes to decent RPGs. Skyrim had it's day in the sun, but that day has long since passed. Skyrim had some pretty graphics when it came out, but that's about it. Today's gamers don't know the joy of playing games that were hand crafted by artists, not suits. Pick up TES:III Morrowind, and heavily invest your time into modding it. The game will look as good as Skyrim, graphically, the combat will suffer slightly, but you'll have an immersive RPG experience like no other. Alternatively, just give Bethesda $30-$60 of your hard-earned dollars to keep them going. Maybe they will release Skyrim again for the PS6 and you could buy it again...

author: {'steamid': '76561198025860030', 'num_games_owned': 1527, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 25185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25185, 'last_played': 1722006913}
review:
[h1] Classic Experience, Aged Technically Like Milk [/h1]

It's funny.  I remember first playing this game on a gaming laptop, and back then my laptop was the problem.  Now it seems the game is the problem.

This version of the game suffers from some crippling technical issues.

- Fails to launch numerous times in a row
- Must be frame limited (to 60 fps) or else the physics engine breaks to the point you cannot advance past the beginning cutscene
- Restricted to lower display resolutions 

However, this version allows you to mod the game for free. It may actually be better than other versions of the game if you are able to avoid the technical issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201836575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 30686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30573, 'last_played': 1735013611}
review:
I have so many hours playing this outside of steam, I was too stubborn to move on to the special edition, even less to the anniversary edition... After trying the anniversary edition recently, after all those years playing the legendary edition, I just have to say that this is by far the worst way to play Skyrim.

There's nothing good this version can offer, it runs terribly, looks a lot worse, crashes are the norm, has a 4gb memory limit so you have to juggle your graphics settings and mods to delay the crashing that comes from just rendering the game, mods are discontinued or have less support, this is when it even has said mod because there's not really that many in comparison to the other versions, finding a cool mod and later discovering it doesn't exist for leg edition is quite the common occurrence.

Playing Black Ops 3 for the 360 is a better experience than modding this 32bit piece of shit. Modding the anniversary edition is so much easier, even doing the fixes for some of the few mods that still don't work with it has been so much easier and more documented than whatever the fuck leg edition has for its barely functional mods.

It feels surreal playing any other version at higher settings and getting more fps with 99% less crashes, even at low the performance is smoother and at the same time the game still looks so much better, I can't stress enough how awful performance is on this borderline unplayable version. If I could I'd bury every copy of this crap at a landfill in New Mexico.
