author: {'steamid': '76561198060979940', 'num_games_owned': 225, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 5372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5372, 'last_played': 1703716295}
review:
[h1] Why Skyrim isn't great [/h1]

[h2] Introduction [/h2]
after many years of this game just sitting in my library i finally decided to actually play it to see if Bethesda actually makes some good games since Skyrim is arguably the most popular one.

When i booted this game up and had to go through the intro sequence, which is [b] unskippable [/b] i just got reminded of the numerous attempts of trying to get into this game and the frustration that comes with it. 


[h2] Game Mechanics [/h2]

[h3] Fast Travel [/h3]
ah yes, the classic Bethesda fast travel system. i must say i'm not the biggest fan of this, it just makes the world feel more disconnected and unimmersive.

[h3] Quests & Story [/h3]
main story quests are kinda whatever and most side quests are fetch or target quests, but there are a select few that do have some semblance of quality content like the guild/faction quests or the daedra-related ones. still, most of the time i was mindlessly following the quest marker on my compass going from objective to objective

[h3] Combat & Stealth [/h3]
it's a very bare bones basic combat system. left click to swing weapon, hold left click for heavy attack, right click to block, simple.

stealth is a weird mechanic because it's very overpowered and boring at the same time. it only works with bows and daggers because every other weapon makes sound and instantly alerts every enemy in the vicinity.

[h3] Magicka [/h3]
very uninspired iteration of magic in a video game. buy or find spell tomes, use/read them, and there you go. you learned a spell and can equip it in either or both hands and cast away.

[h3] Crafting & Leveling [/h3]
again, very basic, very boring. most of the materials you can just straight up buy and thats probably what you want to do because farming is tedious and there is no way to know where to get certain materials unless you discover it by chance or progress in the main quest.

leveling is just tedious, especially when it comes to crafting, you just spam craft the best value item because otherwise it takes waaay too long, how is this supposed to be any fun at all.

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]

sure, if i turn my brain off it can be fun sometimes, but there are way too many things that make me question why i even play video games anymore.

this is a soulless game and i can't understand how anyone can see this as more than just a half hearted effort from bethesda.

calling this a masterpiece is a huge stretch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198226757328', 'num_games_owned': 674, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 13813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13813, 'last_played': 1668968548}
review:
"the funk soul brother at the back of his head has gone dark. Forever."

It is, without a doubt, a unique and extraordinary experience that has changed my life and my outlook on it. Now, moving on to the game, what an incomparable experience! "Disco Elysium" is more than a video game; it is a form of art that changes the way you see politics. In real life, you can say whatever nonsense you want, and nothing happens, but here, every decision you make has consequences. It's like having a philosophical debate in a bar, except instead of discussing, you end up kicking inanimate objects, and you feel like a damn monster for doing so.

This game left my mind reeling, and I can't fully explain what it made me feel. It not only offers a fascinating universe filled with multiple plots and charismatic characters, but it also transforms how we see the consequences of our ideas. If reading a book is anything like this, I should definitely give it a try.

[b]Warning[/b]: Before diving into "Disco Elysium," I advise you to pirate the game through third-party sites. After all, the bastards at ZA/UM stole the IP, and the real creators don’t see a single cent from the sales. Apparently, there’s financial crime behind all this, and they even kicked the original developers out of the studio. So, in honor of the revolution, down with the capitalist pigs!

author: {'steamid': '76561198127328232', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3311, 'last_played': 1729067246}
review:
I downloaded this game expecting a Sherlock Holmes-esque mystery thriller. What I got was a lethal dose of human experience. Politics. Suffering. The detective work is a vessel facilitating intimacy and conversation. A nihilistic world, burning in the flames after leaping from the frying pan. At the epicentre of chaos; a man who has forgotten trauma, unwittingly using his condition to gaze at the world with a juvenile, somewhat healed perspective. A man vulnerable to proselytism from all angles. A man that can completely embody the choices you make as a player; a world that can echo these sentiments. Disco Elysium is incredible and I would recommend it to anyone who can withstand some reading.

PS: This review is solely in praise of the individual people who worked on Disco Elysium. Since its release ZA/UM has been wrung of its creative liberty by investors and greed. Acquire this game through alternate means, then praise the people that scroll by in the credits when you finally reach its conclusion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103103579', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 2142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2142, 'last_played': 1724192649}
review:
Disco Elysium feels terrifyingly [b]real[/b]. It reminds you of the hard truth that existence can be a headache. Throughout your life, you're mostly sad and alone. You might feel like some of your memories are brutally unforgiving. Burdened by a world trying to tear you apart, you try to get by. Still, you always come back to the same old question: Why? What's the purpose of all this? And the game answers in all seriousness: [i]"There is no purpose. You're all alone. Everything is insignificant. Just give up."[/i] It's the heavy truth handed to you by the game like a hard-to-swallow pill.

Of course, nobody can pinpoint what this game is mainly about. Psychology, the inner workings of our mind? Philosophy, the meaning of life? Finding your identity when you feel like you're all alone in the world? Politics and ideologies? The moral of this game can be interpreted in a lot of ways but I think there's an obvious message it's trying to convey: [b]Being right doesn't exist.[/b] No matter what you think or do, it seems like everything is simply wrong. And when you try to choose a side or develop an opinion about something, the game critisizes you harshly. It defines you. But it also makes you change your outlook on life. You become more skeptical about yourself, making you question your beliefs. Although, in this game, even your own mind isn't a safe or trustworthy place. You can try to ignore your thoughts but they are too loud.

However, if you stop focusing on an end goal - in this case, why you came to Revachol in the first place - for even just a second, you can make living worthwhile and life beautiful. Explore yourself and get sidetracked from the main case, make the best moments by seeing what makes *you* feel like you. By having small conversations with the locals and paying attention to details you can truly enjoy life and come to a conclusion about your identity. In all honesty, solving the case might have been the worst part of the game because it ended it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104032233', 'num_games_owned': 3058, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1636339195}
review:
Inside Out walked so that Disco Elysium could run.

The game tells the story of a drunk, amnesiac police lieutenant DuBois with his partner, the stoic no-nonsense Kim Kitsuragi having to solve the case of a reported lynching near a hostel, only falling down a deep rabbit hole once they investigate further. The writing in Disco Elysium is outstanding, not just in RPG, but in all of games;
the story of the game is quite thrilling and does use plot twists accordingly to advance the story and reach it to its conclusion, while also subverting some of the tropes of police procedural series, it is pretty original for an RPG to play detective. The themes of starting over, working hard to see the end, not giving in to despair, reconciliation and above all, dealing with failure wind throughout the game which gives it a genuinely mature feel.

Disco Elysium is a very, very political game, several times pointing to how the gears of politics not many are interested in shape the world and each nation and group's place within it. Instead of a good/bad moral stance, it is instead a political stance that are decided through conversations and although all worldviews are treated with intense scrutiny and criticism, are given nuance, so keep that in mind when you talk to someone.

The characters in this game are some of the best and most developed I've seen, with the two main characters, Mr. DuBois and Kim might as well being as iconic (and kind of reminiscent of) Holmes and Watson;
and the game doesn't stop there, every character, major or minor, has something distinct, each having their own complexities and struggles, having to deal with their views on you and the world, and ways you can get them to open up about the case and reveal the depths they're hiding, in that you feel very immersed in the game's setting. The characters don't feel like props put to a game for the story to progress, they feel like actual people with their own things happening in their lives. The voice-acting as well is done with great effort and since The Final Cut makes the game fully-voiced, it prospers.

The worldbuilding is one of the best, hands down. Taking place in a large but rundown city of Revachol put under a strict international military occupation following an attempt at a revolution, giving a rather powerful backdrop to the happenings you encounter along the way, the lynching becoming a small piece of puzzle in a much wider set, the world being reminiscent of ZA/UM's Estonian origins and its post-Soviet socioeconomic landscape. The developers spared no effort at creating a colossally-detailed world, with its own vocabulary, history and progression, yet very similar to our own, giving it an alien but familiar look that creates a wonderful mix of feeling like you're there.

It helps with the very good handling of the exposition, DuBois suffering from amnesia serves himself as a surrogate for the audience introducing the concepts slowly through the dialogue or the thoughts in his head, one is quite motivated latching for more information about Elysium by searching every room or investing in Encyclopedia skill to hear what a "radiocomputer" is. At the least showing the potential in setting in an different world that doesn't need to be Sci-Fi or Fantasy.

The visuals here do show the priorities set, the in-game 3D models are pretty flat with primitive movements, but is more than made up with the beyond moving artwork by lead artist Alexander Rostov.
The game's art style is incredibly distinct in that it doesn't look like a painting done on a frame or tablet, but a mural on the walls of rusted buildings, the game's landscape has a very painted-on look to it like you're walking on an interactive panoramic masterpiece, meanwhile the portrait of characters feels like commissioned portraits worthy of ending up on the museum, each one having different motives to it and what they feel.

I told a lot about the design in the story, but what about the actual gameplay...

The gameplay of Disco Elysium is... not that good. While staying true to the pen-and-paper RPGs and to me, it doesn't really translate well into a computer game partly due to lack of real action on screen. I will say it is very unique, rather than levelling up your weapons and armour to attack more enemies, you level up your inner thoughts that serve as your party members that guide you to a satisfactory outcome when talking to people, with a sufficient level passing a check where you can hear its thoughts.
For example, Rhetoric helping you see what are they trying to say and helping you better convince them, or Inland Empire making you have conversations with things that can't talk; crafting an extensive and thrilling game of shoulder angels. The skill levels are also capped to encourage replay value.
The issue comes from how it's not really balanced, most of actions occur in INT field so focusing on other fields can lock you out of many quests.
Then there are the checks, roll a dice and see if it advances the plot. While care is given to cases where the check is failed since the game is about accepting it,, you'd rather want the best outcome like in any other game and one could be pushed into save-and-loading over and over to get it, which kind of pushes down the enjoyability.

The good thing is that the checks can be curved by completing side-quests but not all; will say, even the side-quests are very engaging and can have twists of their own, even a minor one like finding and recovering a corpse on a boardwalk has its own share of gravitas. Problem came when it piled quests on me at the beginning and gave nothing to do with them until later, a thing that made me feel under pressure and got me to put the game off for a few months.
Either way, it is a game without much action with combat mechanics not existing, making it more like an interactive Poirot novel than what you expect for a game. If you're familiar with pen-and-paper, you'll probably enjoy this game a lot more, most of my issues with the gameplay come more from my particular distaste in RPG anyway.

The music, well, just by exiting the first building you're in, you start to get greeted by the game's distinguishable score. It goes in several places, whether the gloomy "Instrument of Surrender" or the Pop-y "Whirling-In-Rags" or the gratifying "La Revacholiere", it stays in your head. Just the soundtrack alone has its place in games history. Honestly, with a name like "Disco Elysium", I was expecting Disco music.

Conclusion:
+:Deep and complex characters, amazing and emotional artwork, otherworldly worldbuilding, engaging story, great voice-acting, distinct and beautiful music.
-: Gameplay is barren at best, frustrating at worst, slow and badly-paced beginning.

Disco Elysium has its flaws, but they can be forgiven easily by the marvelous might of its storytelling and the art direction. The game may not be great to play, but it is extraordinary to look and hear, and with that ends up as the one game I can hold to prove computer games are an art form. While it had its humble beginnings, it truly ends up as one of the greatest indie games ever made, standing on the shoulders with Cave Story, Papers Please, Undertale, Cuphead and such.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058549675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3092, 'last_played': 1626786289}
review:
I'm not taking a stand against the publisher of this game or any drama surrounding the game. I'm only talking about this game, Disco Elysium.

Disco Elysium is by far the best game I have ever played. Ever. Its world is compact, but full of exciting details, and its story is genuinely touching and philosophical: Disco Elysium reinvents the wheel and teaches the player that failure is just as important as success. Perhaps even more important, because our mistakes define us and our history.

The game is also extremely funny and witty, and the text it contains is of top quality. Some have jokingly stated that "Disco Elysium is the best game they've ever read" and they have a point: the game has a lot of text, but none of it is empty or without purpose.

This is the so-called "thinking person's game". It's a game for those of us who are tired of the numbing nonsense that modern games so often are. So if you want to challenge yourself intellectually, politically and philosophically, Disco Elysium offers an unforgettable and unique experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062048863', 'num_games_owned': 820, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 15, 'playtime_at_review': 742, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1736531262}
review:
Without having experienced Disco Elysium, one may easily think I'm overhyping this. But this game, particularly in its Final Cut form, with skillful voiceovers, is quite possibly the most groundbreaking roleplaying game of the century so far. Probably the most genuine representation of roleplaying itself, and getting into a character in videogames so far.

Unlike most "RPGs", this isn't a combat simulator dressed in metrics and a story, centered around a main "character" that is largely a hollow shell for the player to inhabit.

Disco Elysium is a masterful combination of outstanding techno-fantasy worldbuilding and superb writing which has you take over a flawed, unique character and discover him as you discover the game's systems. Which equal his personality and physicality, which you can mutate with each reaction to the game world and what happens around you. Skills are physical and mental parts of your being, and they chip in like characters of their own as your guy runs into situations; "Feats" are your thoughts and ideas, which you can foster or suppress according to how you want interact with the world.

WTF are you talking about, reviewer? Get Disco Elysium and find out. You won't regret it. It's so unique it's very difficult to describe, but I guarantee it's like nothing you've ever played.

PS: Gametime count is off because I played the most on my Steam Deck (flawless compatibility, just upsize the UI), and it glitched out in relation to my desktop. You're looking at 30-50 hours depending on your thoroughness.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041010151', 'num_games_owned': 222, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2652, 'last_played': 1709209811}
review: The creators of this game have been completely cut off from profits by illegal action of know fraudsters. This game is a masterpiece, but this might be one of the rare cases where sailing the high seas is the morally correct choice.

author: {'steamid': '76561199240416787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 380, 'playtime_at_review': 1301, 'last_played': 1736460766}
review:
Like all good detective stories, what appears simple at first becomes so much more than that in Disco Elysium – and here it gets so, so much weirder, too. It takes the age-old mechanics of tabletop RPGs like Dungeons & Dragons and twists them in strange ways around a macabre tale of violence, poverty, and a society on the brink of collapse. Through sharply written dialogue and an expertly crafted world, it uses some unique game mechanics - such as debating against 24 different sections of your own brain - to create a story that will stay with me for a long time. And, somehow, it manages to make all of this fun and, surprisingly often, funny. Now with the addition of a fully voiced cast and even more side quests to embark on, The Final Cut makes an amazing game even better.

The premise of Disco Elysium is straightforward: A body has been discovered, hanged from a looming tree in the backyard of a hostel, and it’s up to you to work out how it got there over the course of the 30-hour story. Everything that surrounds this core mystery is far from simple, however, not least being that you kick things off with an almighty dose of hangover-induced amnesia. You can’t even remember your name, let alone that you are a cop on a murder case. A part of your consciousness described as your ancient reptilian brain – which you literally engage in conversation with – attempts to persuade you to give up your quest even as your snivelling limbic system battles against it. As you stumble around your wrecked bedroom searching for remnants of your former self, it quickly becomes clear that this isn’t simply a whodunnit, but a journey that will challenge you to solve crises on both profoundly personal and societal levels. It’s a gorgeously designed isometric RPG that makes you think at every turn of its painterly streets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114586751', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 4794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4794, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 3419, 'last_played': 1719512942}
review:
Disco Elysium | ★★★★★

It seems like the developers behind this game were located in Doom Commercial Area. Sigh.

Anyway, if you're like me—a somewhat illiterate person whose second or third language is English—and then get slapped with different ideologies and political theories you have no idea about or just don't care for, don't worry!

The game initially throws you into interactions with some insane characters (or maybe it's just your character?), which can be intimidating. But as you progress, the NPCs become more mellow, and you become more familiar with the fictional world and its history. This makes absorbing their interactions easier.

Overall, without giving too much away, this game has become one of my top 3 games of all time. I played it again immediately after finishing it, which I've never done before.

It's not a traditional game I usually play; it's more like a novel with DnD mechanics. Yet, it has many memorable moments, and the ending ties everything together perfectly.

author: {'steamid': '76561199080217495', 'num_games_owned': 49, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6069, 'last_played': 1722736277}
review:
psychoanalytic theory to the back drop of a has been amnesiac cop working a murder mystery with his newly acquainted partner in the remains of a disheveled post-war island city under the thumb of both a logistics company and a morally and ethically questionable workers union. 

the medium of video games has never seen writing with such bold "thisness" nor art direction with such distinctive style and cohesion. disco elysium is a masterwork.

WARNING: this game is a genuine work of ART, meaning upon completion, this game will live inside you. you can leave Revachol, but Revachol will never leave you. 

for fans of: doom, despair, unending aches of the existential variety, redemption, disco-superstars, the heart broken, the drunken & drugged, both the honorable and dishonorable, detectives, criminals, thinkers, artists, fascists, capitalist pigs, silly commies, and the a-political alike.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061586708', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 9797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9797, 'last_played': 1732333871}
review:
This has unironically changed my brain chemistry.

I tried it once YEARS ago, didn't immediately get a handle on the skill points/thought cabinet, and put it down.
Coming back and trying again, going "Just do it, who cares, if you do things wrong its fine, just dive in" and I'd like to say that was possibly the perfect was to start the game.  

You may not "get it" immediately, you may feel foolish as you try to ground yourself, and maybe you become emotionally dependent on Kim Kitsuragi.  That's all okay, I dare say its intended, and you are all the better in the shoes of the main character who is just as or MORE lost than you are.

author: {'steamid': '76561199682429844', 'num_games_owned': 12, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3246, 'playtime_at_review': 2240, 'last_played': 1736664828}
review:
Disco Elysium completely surprised me. I’ve never been someone who enjoys reading, but this game had me hooked for hours without ever feeling bored. The writing is sharp, immersive, and filled with moments that make you think or laugh unexpectedly.

What really stood out to me was how it explores so many different themes—politics, identity, loss—without ever feeling shallow. It’s a game that lets you discover things at your own pace, making the experience feel unique and personal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058587212', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 7519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7519, 'last_played': 1708004829}
review: Aside from the mess with the developing company, Disco Elysium is hands down one of the best RPG games I have ever played. The writers must be a mix of genius scholars, and hilarious comedians. Even after playing it multiple times, I found that each playthrough brought entirely new things.

author: {'steamid': '76561199564391393', 'num_games_owned': 16, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 21238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21238, 'last_played': 1725205358}
review: Disco Elysium is a narrative-driven role-playing game that is brimming with dark humor and adult themes. It is a finely crafted game that has an intricate and engaging story, and a unique world that brings mystery, grim, and wonder. The game is profoundly political that it is completely filled with its own history and beliefs. It has an extraordinary and sophisticated writing, supported by an intriguing and outstanding voice acted characters. The art style is incredible and imposing, and the soundtrack is remarkable. Despite having a couple of bugs and glitches, Disco Elysium is a memorable and satisfying experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062801622', 'num_games_owned': 657, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 7887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3813, 'last_played': 1733179532}
review:
Holy hell. Probably the most in depth RPG I've played to date. More of a piece of art than game, yet still a phenomenal game and commentary on social structures of real life as well as certain game tropes. 

The only issue I myself came across was the voice over sometimes not aligning with the text, but honestly, with how many lines and variations of lines this game has, it is entirely fair to have an oversight here or there.

A masterful and finely crafted piece of work. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021552181', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 1950, 'last_played': 1736367986}
review: The pinnacle of creativity, the developers had their skills maxxed out, in particular creativity, perception and inland empire. This is doubtlessly one of the best video games ever made.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041090308', 'num_games_owned': 807, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 765, 'last_played': 1724200317}
review:
[h2]A rather hilarious but also dark rpg story-driven game.[/h2]

It gives DnD vibes due to the heavy mechanic based upon your character's personality and traits. Resulting in dice rolls to determine things like detecting if someone is lying or keeping calm in conversations.

The game is very unique and i haven't played one such as this before, it starts off being very overwhelming with the mechanics, but once you get used to it, you cannot wait for the next dialogue sequence or investigation.

Tip: The game can be quite difficult to get into at first due to the vast amounts of dialogue and brutalness with checks. I suggest to stick with it and focus on the "Main Task" to begin with. Exploring right away can burn you out, without much reward.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977155194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 4927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4926, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 822, 'last_played': 1732296909}
review: One of the most unique, replayable, story rich RPG's I've ever played. Everyone should give Disco a whirl. Some of the funniest, most touching, sad, disturbing, screwed up, mind expanding scenes I've ever experienced in a game. Unlike anything else I've ever played. Top five games of all time, honestly. I'll replay this one several more times at the very least, there's just so many things that effect the story in fun ways, especially failed skill checks. Go extreme with your initial build, max out one of the categories. You'll be glad you did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116512198', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2360, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 488, 'last_played': 1731305313}
review:
disco elysium is not a particularly good mystery, i fear, but if you go into it expecting the mystery to be the main draw then you are misled. what can you even say? the particular combination of beautiful and heart-wrenching character writing, thorough and engaging worldbuilding, and political tenderness and consideration are unique; you will struggle to find another story that hits these notes so squarely in the entire body of contemporary fiction writ large, not just within gaming. this game is a work of art, and the choice of medium and the branching paths it makes possible turn this story into something so much greater than it could have been in any other form. a real testament to the medium, and something that reminds you how great a video game can really be.

by the way, kim kitsuragi is the closest thing to jesus christ humanity has had in the last 2000 years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198269622047', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3832, 'last_played': 1734374999}
review: Disco Elysium is a captivating dance between despair and hope, like a melancholic waltz in a neon-lit detective's office, except there is no office. Solving crimes and unraveling the character's tangled past felt like a poignant tango with destiny - a bitter embrace of tragedy and redemption, leaving me both shattered and strangely fulfilled.

author: {'steamid': '76561198857060587', 'num_games_owned': 351, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2319, 'last_played': 1724923027}
review:
I love this game, it's a beautiful piece of art. The world-building, writing and voice acting are phenomenal. It's a whole experience full of mystery, laughs, and absurdity. The descriptive writing about the smell, the texture, the shivering cold, the sound, just so you can feel it in every scene.

The game is less about detectives investigating a crime and more about uncovering your character and the major emotional themes that surround them - grief, loss, yearning, existential dread, alienation, dehumanization, being haunted by the past, inability to let go. And every character in the story is spectacularly well-written with a lot of depth and complexity, not so one-dimensional to be hated on for which encourages you to look in a complete different perspective.

The map itself isn't that big but it does offer a lot with side quests and many hidden details to find. Some tasks that require you to wait until specific time schedule to proceed which I find very tedious due to how clock behaves differently in game because time only advances through dialog. If you run out of things to do, you will unfortunately have to read a book over and over to pass time, but hey, at least that contributes to the immersion should you find a book worth reading through.

The ending could've been more than I had hoped for but overall, I enjoyed it. If you enjoy the role playing aspect of Table Top RPGs over the combat and don't mind the reading (lots of it), buy it wherever, give it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991657455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 4862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4862, 'last_played': 1706988131}
review:
Truly fantastic, there's no other game out there that comes close to its writing chops.

HOWEVER!

Don't buy this. The publishers ZA/UM are scum, and screwed the creators over, creators who will see no money from your purchase. Find another way.

A true shame that we will never see a game from this creative team again it seems.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971755007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 1240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1228, 'last_played': 1710442881}
review:
Politics, philosophy, intrigue, double crossing, the game or the publishing of said game?? Life is a mirror.

Disco Elysium is a detective RPG, literally like nothing ever made before. Extremely political, very immersive (no 2 games of this would be the same) and huuuuugely talky, like no narrative game ever. It's one of those rare games you think about when not playing. Creativity at its finest. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198070257999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1580, 'last_played': 1717215699}
review:
[b]TLDR: S-Tier Detective Game, S-Tier Game PERIOD. Unique, incredibly successful & perfectly executed.[/b]

[h1]Disco Elysium has earned three incredibly impressive, RARE distinctions in my opinon:[/h1]


[table]
[tr]
	[td] 1) You hear frequently about a game having "good writing".  Almost always this observation is entirely held in context to just video games. These games have "good writing" FOR a video game. They are good in comparison to other video games, but the quality of writing in these games often pales in comparison to the quality of writing in other mediums. Vast majority of the time, a game's "good writing" is really only exceptional within that context, but mostly average when held in comparison to other mediums. It's like an always present mental asterisk, that we all know and are aware of, but don't mention because it's just the way it is and we all understand that.

Disco Elysium is one of the very few games that escapes this. Disco Elysium legitimately is greatly written. PERIOD. No mental asterisk, no contextual shackles. Its quality stands firm for ANY medium you will find, and far beyond what you will typically find in a video game commonly regarded as having "good writing". 
[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td] 2) It is possibly the closest thing I've played to a flawless game in all my years of gaming. I know this sounds dramatic, and I don't mean to mislead or confuse so let me clarify. This isn't my favorite game of all time or anything like that. I don't mean to say that I believe this game is "better" than other great games. It certainly will NOT be a game for everyone.

Instead what I mean by this, is the examination of the balance between intention & execution. What the game set out to do, what it aimed to BE, [i]versus[/i], what the game actually did, what is WAS. I'm viewing "Flaws" as objective issues that directly contrast or betray the goal of what the game is trying to be.

There are other games with better visuals, better gameplay, superior animations, superior OSTs etc etc. But few I've seen, who so closely MASTERED accomplishing exactly the game they set out to as this one. This balance is so perfectly accomplished, that if imagined as scale, would look perfectly horizontal. Of the very few criticisms I did have, they were EXTREMELY subjective, so much so that they are more appropriately described as preferences then flaws. But none that obstructed this game from being what it set out to be.

It is, so perfectly & so exactly: "Disco Elysium".  If you understand what I'm saying by this, you'll know how rare and excellent a feat that is.
[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td] 3)"Unique" has no inherent value in a vacuum. Unique for the sole sake of being unique is one of the biggest traps a game can suffer from. There is "Bad Unique" & "Good Unique".  Forced, cumbersome mechanics for the sake of declaring in bold "But! We are unique! Praise us!" can truly detriment and get in the way of an otherwise good game.

However, ORGANIC unique, where an idea is fresh but not forced, and works seamlessly is a whole different story, and one of the best achievements a game can have. 

This is the latter. A completely fresh breath of air, and an entirely unique, different approach to the "Detective" genre of games that I've never seen before. And yet despite it's unusual approach, never once feels unintuitive or working against you. It's organically unique and works in a way that is so satisfying, it will change how you view the genre.

Majority of detective games basically play as "Clue Retrieval". You enter an environment, or an interview and there is a thing to discover. You use the tools of the game, the game shows you the discovery in question, you retrieve it, you move onto the next thread.

Disco Elysium approaches this formula differently. You instead develop separate, distinct parts of your mind & body. It's up to you as the player to determine which aspects you choose to develop or ignore. There are no correct answers. It's your creation.

These aspects then all work in sometimes tandem, other times even directly competing against each other as they all contribute their respective observations & perspectives. Each able to sense or even misread things that the others can't. You don't receive definitive answers, you receive essentially thoughts, of which YOU the player have to navigate and consider. For example: A "Logical" oriented thought process can pick up some things that a more "Empathetic" mind would miss, just as an "Empathetic" mind may understand motives more then a "Logical" mind would. Too much of one can leave you too singularly focused to the point of tunnel vision, too little can leave you incapable of all the information that aspect COULD have yielded. 

It's not just changing how YOU interact with the populace/environment, but it also alters how the populace/environment interfaces with you. It's a fascinating dynamic that quickly begins to feel natural and immersive. Perspective is everything and the people/environments and the literal entire game itself drastically changes depending on how you build & maintain this dynamic, opening entire new methods, secrets & possibilities.

Quite literally a game changer and possibly, HOPEFULLY a system that will prove to be influential to the future of the  "Detective" genre of games.

[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

author: {'steamid': '76561197992598511', 'num_games_owned': 930, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 1426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1426, 'last_played': 1705429720}
review: Disco Elysium is a fantastic, nihilistic, depressive but also encouraging role-playing game that completely avoids classic combat and draws you deep into a familiar yet unknown world. It draws heavily on real customs, countries, languages and even racial stereotypes but wraps it all up in new names and places. In most cases, this creates the pleasant strangeness of an uncertain fantasy world. Occasionally, however, the flood of unknown nations, names and ideas in never-ending dialogues can be quite exhausting. And while we're at it: There is a lot of talking. I mean a loooooot of talking. So if you're mainly looking for action, you're definitely in the wrong place. With The Final Cut version, however, the game now also has a superb voiceover, so we no longer have to read pages and pages of dialogue. The dubbing is one of the best I have ever heard in a video game. Especially the inner voice of our protagonist alone would be award-winning in my opinion. But in general, all the voice actors and actresses do an excellent job of portraying the incredibly diverse and varied cast. From the grumpy barman to the sly chairman, old truck driver lady or a bratty child. Listening to them is usually fun, even if the content sometimes varies. There were times when I thought to myself "Come on, get on with it" and read faster than the character spoke in order to click next. Compared to the game as a whole, however, this was a rarity. The dialogues, like the voice acting, are of an incredibly good quality. It's just a pity that the dialogue tree has a small shortcoming, namely that higher-level selections remain "greyed out" even though a new option underneath has been unlocked through new discoveries. But what is Disco Elysium actually about? We are a party animal of a detective who should be investigating a murder but has lost his memory. A role-playing game couldn't start in a more clichéd way. But the development of this party animal draws you in so much, makes you feel excited, make supposedly good decisions, make "Now more than ever!" decisions and want to know more and more about who we actually were, are and could become. And the run-down town of Revachol doesn't make it easy. Fortunately, we get the sympathetic detective Kim Kitsuragi from another Precinct to help us with advice and support. In my opinion, the chemistry between these two alone makes the game worth playing. The gameplay consists mainly of dialogues, gathering information for further dialogues and... Dice rolls. And oh boy... I got strong X-Com flashbacks here. Because at least in my playthrough, I completely messed up a lot of >70 rolls. Fortunately, there don't seem to be any soft locks in Disco Elysium and even if a failed dice roll hurts for a moment, it still advances the story. And that's exactly what makes the game so charming because we do our best and live with the consequences. Here I would strongly advise you not to save scum because that defeats the purpose of the game. And this theme of "it is what it is" runs through the whole game with its depressive undertone. We chat our way through the districts of Revachol (with a semi-successful fast-travelling system that forces us to go to one of three points before jumping to another), learn more about the world, the murder, the parties in the city and ourselves level up our skills and listen to the fantastic soundtrack. Which is also great and emphasises the game with its melancholic and sombre tones (except for that damn tent in which I couldn't hear myself think!). I can only advise you not to get too attached to the murder case. Because this is basically just the hook for the game. I made the mistake of finding the end of the game very disappointing. It's better to accept the long journey of self-discovery, self-knowledge and healing. That way, this almost masterpiece of an RPG is completely open to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045434451', 'num_games_owned': 344, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 1285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1285, 'last_played': 1728057809}
review:
Great game, just be prepared that its mostly reading and less gaming. If that's not your style I cant recommend it. (Also kinda not replayable unless you like seeing all the paths to solving some things I suppose?)
Also buy it from a [NON STEAM SOURCE] seller :) the original devs got laid off, so don't support that kinda behavior

author: {'steamid': '76561199442512814', 'num_games_owned': 204, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 2, 'last_played': 1724595699}
review:
The prose in Disco Elysium is exceptional. Despite the wealth of descriptions, it flows effortlessly, rarely descending into obvious overwriting. The authors skillfully convey character traits and a range of emotions, managing to amuse, tug at the heartstrings, and provoke thought. 

It’s a delight to see such fine writing adorn not just another fantasy tale, but a blend of steampunk infused with the spirit of both the French and October revolutions. A multitude of events, ideologies, and movements intertwine here, with the developers deftly juggling between presenting matters in a serious light, digging deep into politics and philosophy, and, with the other hand, sketching caricatures that mock everything.

Russian as an English localisation is brilliant, with strong words and linguistic puns. 

Downloaded soundtrack as well and had a pleasure to listen it on repeat. 

10 hanged men out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198808225717', 'num_games_owned': 293, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 2508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2508, 'last_played': 1735202137}
review:
a simple review cannot this game enough credit. 

disco elysium is a game that is essentially a listening and reading simulator 90% of the time, but never does it have a dull moment. from beginning to end, the game is completely enthralling, unpacking the complex world of revachol and harrier, learning about what was, what is, and what could be; and how you, the player, impact this world.

the world of disco elysium is expansive and abundant offering so much to do and see, giving the game plenty of replayability. to say disco elysium is worth every penny would be the understatement of the century.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080141856', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 1459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1459, 'last_played': 1708134662}
review:
This game is a masterpiece. I got it as a gift some time ago but never got around to playing it, but during my first hour of gameplay I was already regretting that I didn't start it sooner. I literally went from looking at the trailers and previews and saying "I'm not sure if it's for me" to "there's almost no one I wouldn't recommend this to" after playing about half the story.

It just excels so well in everything it's trying to do. The tragicomical narrative is amazing and the simple TTRPG resolution mechanic just keeps it moving seamlessly. Whenever you feel like you've hit a wall there are always ways to go around it and every interaction - be it part of the main mystery or just a random dialogue - entertains you and gives you more resources to progress in other parts of the game. Its "fail-forward" narrative design is so elegant that I think it communicates better how a TTRPG feels than the more traditional TTRPG-inspired games such as Divinity and Baldur's Gate, since your huge array of unconventional stats and skills makes it so solving problems never goes the way you were expecting.

The characters are extremely charismatic, the world-building is a brilliant mixture of realism and absurdity, the investigation is thrilling and unpredictable and it's all tied together by an amazing visual design and the impeccable voice acting. 

My only real warning to anyone wanting to buy Disco Elysium is that the company behind it has been very controversial. If you really care where your money is going, you should do a quick search about that and come to your own conclusions (but then again, if you really care where your money is going you wouldn't be buying your games here). Whatever the case, you shouldn't let that stop you from playing this amazing game (interpret this sentence as you wish).

author: {'steamid': '76561198117807268', 'num_games_owned': 437, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 14743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14743, 'last_played': 1717510979}
review: You start the game as a regular detective, and a few hours in, you suddenly realize you've turned into a fascist. Thanks, Disco Elysium, for the unexpected self-insight! This is now one of the best modern CRPGs for me!

author: {'steamid': '76561198077096264', 'num_games_owned': 2130, 'num_reviews': 167, 'playtime_forever': 2354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2354, 'last_played': 1723348047}
review:
It's a great game with excellent writing, fun characters and an interesting format.

With that being said, this is much less a game but a book. The factors you can change seem minor and the game play is just deciding how many of the pages you want to read. This isn't a detective game, you can make deductions, but it doesn't matter, the game doesn't want anything from you. This is especially evident in the last chapter, the place where you would expect your choices to come together and actually matter, but instead it's just waved away. Which is understandable but disappointing.

8/10 - had much more potential but it's understandable given the small team - a shame the main creatives were forced out so we might not get the game that utilises this world and mechanics to it's best ability.

author: {'steamid': '76561198177445786', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1792, 'last_played': 1730821442}
review: Genuinely one of the best games I've ever played. Even as a person who was very skeptical about the game, as I do not like reading books, this game clicked for me. The amazing story, well written cast of characters and excellent voice acting came together beautifully in this one of a kind game. Thought provoking, insane, hilarious and depressing all come to mind when describing the game, but above all a must play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051344700', 'num_games_owned': 901, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1389, 'last_played': 1726253595}

Possibly the best writing in any video-game ever, with a massive number of choices and branching paths.

Too bad we'll never get a sequel due to corporate shitfuckery.
