review: Became one of my favorite RPGs, favorite GAMES of all time. It is a SHAME that we will never properly get more from the creators planned world of Elysium, but this was excellent alone. I am at a loss of words for this review, if you enjoy 90s rpgs like FALLOUT and maybe some odd story games like Sanitarium there is no real reason not to try this out. You have nothing to lose. I recommend pirating it though since the scum at ZA/UM stole this from its creators.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031223198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 2523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2523, 'last_played': 1732723026}
review:
I admit, I've procrastinated on writing this review. Part of that is the length of the game. Disco Elysium isn't a long game, per se, but it's long enough that I had to find time to play it from start to finish. Part of it is my own schedule. I played this game in November, during which I also did NaNoWriMo and wrote a full novel in a month, so, y'know, busy. Most of that procrastination, though, is me being intimidated by this review and what I can add to a discourse that has, at this point, been thoroughly had. Most elements have been picked apart by reviewers more adept than I, and the pure gameplay elements I usually discuss seem a bit meaningless beside the overall picture Disco Elysium presents. There is a conversation around this game, it's been had, and I am late to it, stumbling and stuttering as I struggle to interject a thought already long since said. 

But I'm still here. I'm still writing about it. Because maybe there is something more to say.


https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3378374058

For the precisely no one who is unfamiliar with Disco Elysium, yet still reading my reviews for some reason, Disco Elysium is a detective RPG. You play as Harry Dubois, an amnesiac detective tasked with solving the murder of a mysterious hanged man. He is joined by his partner, Kim Kitsuragi, as he investigates the murder, rediscovers himself, and reshapes the future of the district of Martinaise. 

Disco Elysium is a non-violent (mostly) RPG, creating a fairly distinct style of gameplay. Rather than investing in combat skills or weapons, players invest in ways for Harry to approach the world and the thoughts he has about it. A player might choose to invest heavily in empathy at the expense of logic, or in pounding athleticism rather than perception. The choice, as the game's tagline suggests, is entirely what sort of cop the player wants to be, and how they choose to interact with the world around them.

Disco Elysium is also almost entirely text-based. While Harry does move around a beautiful landscape, the problems he faces and barriers he must overcome are text-based, using a set of invisible dice to resolve whether he has the skill to overcome a particular challenge. His interactions with the world are based on the conversations he has and what he says, with the player's choices informing who he ultimately becomes. 

There's a lot within Disco Elysium that makes it clear why it's held in such high esteem. Its writing is some of the best writing in video games, with fleshed-out character after fleshed-out character filling Harry's world. Kim Kitsuragi alone is one of the best companions in the grand canon of video games, and he is one of many, many characters in Revachol. The world is lush and lived-in, and the ideas interesting to engage with. The history of the world is as much a character as any of the people, and Harry's grappling with it and placing himself within it as compelling as any relationship he builds with other people. 

Similarly, the very feeling of playing the game is phenomenal. Both its artistic style and music do an incredible job of building the world and its emotion. The plaintive horns of British Sea Power hit me every single time I entered the square outside the Whirling-in-Rags, and I kept being delighted by it. 

The sum of Disco Elysium's parts work together beautifully to create a masterful experience. The whole is greater than that sum, but even then, it's with the knowledge that each individual part is itself a masterpiece.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3378373893

The puzzle with Disco Elysium, then, is more of a meta one. This is a game with universal acclaim, that everyone agrees is a modern classic. And yet, despite that acclaim and despite the real desire on the part of the game-buying public for more Disco Elysium, ZA/UM has not produced another game. There is no true sequel to Disco Elysium. Indeed, ZA/UM itself has splintered, with the devs and writers responsible for Disco Elysium scattering out to a variety of new studios and a variety of new projects. Much of this splintering is specifically because of the success of Disco Elysium. 

In many ways, the story of ZA/UM reflects the story of Harry Dubois. They were good at what they did, and they fell apart because of it. Also there were probably blonde ladies smelling of apricots involved, but I can't confirm that part. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3378374198

This is not to say that there are no successors to Disco Elysium, or that it hasn't had a lasting impact. Instead, it's fair to say that what made Disco Elysium so successful is also what makes it hard to reproduce, and arguably means its greater impact on games will be minimal, even while it remains one of the greatest games of all time. 

There are successors to Disco Elysium, games that likely owe their existence to the ground Disco Elysium broke. Games like Citizen Sleeper are very much games in the same vein as Disco Elysium, with a rich world explored through text, and a layered, living backstory that needs to be understood for the story to make sense. However much I love these games, though, they don't have a large impact on the industry. Instead, they remain indie darlings and cult favourites, games that everyone who plays them agrees are amazing, but whose success is based on criteria that don't appeal to a more general audience. 

Disco Elysium has a long tail, but it is a shallow one, lapping up against games that might never have otherwise succeeded, but drenching them when it does find them. 

This is the conversation that still remains about Disco Elysium. It's this conversation about its legacy, why it's complex, and why it's shallow. It's that conversation about what it takes to move the needle in an industry consolidating around the most profitable ventures to the exclusion of games like this one, and how, even when a game like Disco Elysium is successful, it's almost an act of self-sabotage. 

Disco Elysium is an incredible game. I wish there were more like it, but equally, I understand why there aren't.

[i]Developer: ZA/UM
Genre: RPG
Year: 2019
Country: United Kingdom
Language: English
Game length: 20 hours[/i]

If you enjoyed this review, check out [url=https://www.jannekeparrish.com/game/] my other reviews [/url] and [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44626948-Loons/] my curator page. [/url] Thanks for reading!

author: {'steamid': '76561197969290082', 'num_games_owned': 408, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1998, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1729235551}
review:
Disco Elysium is nothing short of a masterpiece in the realm of narrative-driven gaming. From the moment you step into the shoes of the amnesiac detective, you're immersed in a beautifully crafted world that feels both rich and incredibly detailed. The art style is unique and evocative, blending a hand-painted aesthetic with a gritty, urban atmosphere that perfectly complements the game's themes.

What truly sets Disco Elysium apart is its writing. The dialogue is sharp, insightful, and often darkly humorous, with choices that genuinely impact the story. Each character you encounter is multifaceted, bringing their own struggles and philosophies that enrich the experience. The game’s depth of choice allows for a myriad of playstyles, whether you lean into your character’s intellect, charisma, or physical prowess.

The skill system is revolutionary, allowing players to engage with their own inner thoughts in ways that feel both personal and profound. It’s not just about solving a crime; it’s a deep exploration of identity, morality, and human experience. The way the game tackles themes of politics, addiction, and existential dread is both bold and refreshing.

The soundtrack perfectly complements the atmosphere, enhancing the emotional weight of pivotal moments without overpowering the narrative. Each encounter and revelation feels earned, leaving you reflecting long after the credits roll.

In summary, Disco Elysium is a stunning achievement in storytelling and character development. It’s a game that invites you to think, feel, and reflect, making it a must-play for anyone who appreciates deep narrative experiences. Whether you’re a seasoned gamer or new to the medium, this title is a journey worth taking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053532460', 'num_games_owned': 508, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 1729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1729, 'last_played': 1710765483}
review:
Real quick, I have since my purchase been made aware what happened to the original creators now not earning monetary gain for their creation due to being muscled out by someone previously convicted for investment fraud. So uhh, pirate this game lol. Sadly I was unaware when I had already played 7+ hours.

Disco Elysium is a game that  actually takes advantage of being an interactive medium, a trope sadly under utilised in the RPG genre of video game. Anyway aside from a spectacular story and fantastic character throughout the entire run of the game I can't say much praise or anything about that game that just playing itself doesn't convey better.

So instead I'll highlight some random things I really enjoyed. Taking damage from sitting in an uncomfortable chair, not ever being able to get my tie off the fan because I kept failing the check, founding a nightclub, being a communist, finding many racists and giving all of them shit for it, telling a rich lady she should kill herself (effectively) and the pinnacle of this game, the autistic mechanical engineering nerd Kim Kitsuragi. 

Additionally I'll swiftly praise the games amazing choice of how dialogue functions. Not only are you speaking with the characters parts of your personality which you actually invest attribute points into and gear affecting whether or not they'll show you behind the curtains during a conversation as well as allowing you to interact with these characters differently. Now not only is this INSANELY charming your various traits of personality are actually unreliable, sometimes they'll misjudge the situation or completely lead you astray for their own desires to go do drugs or have sex. Conclusion fantastic game system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160543205', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 3202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3202, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 3202, 'last_played': 1723459928}
review:
[h1] Beautiful [/h1] 
[u]9/10[/u]
Disco Elysium is not a game, it's an experience. I have personally never played a game like it, but I'm happy I finally did. Have been hearing about Disco Elysium for so long, how big of a masterpiece it was, and how everyone should play it, and how it has 97 on Metacritic, and so on. It was 90% off a while back so I just picked it up. Great investment. Around 55 hours of playtime, beautiful story, memorible characters, and finally, a 'Choices Matter' game where your choices actually matter. I only have 1 'negative' thing to say about it, and to be honest it's not even that bad, it's just something that could get a bit annoying. This game has a lot of dialogue, and I mean A LOT, 95% of the game is just talking to people, which is not necessarily a bad thing, however, sometimes it feels like some dialogue is completely unnecessary. Other then that, it's an unique experience, just experience it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198277564841', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 4830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4830, 'last_played': 1721306921}
review:
Disco Elysium has been so many different things to me over the time I've spent going through it. A masterclass in narrative design, an exemplary RPG given the amount of freedom it provides to the player, a game filled with memorable and well-written characters; I could laud the game on and on, but instead, I'd like you to try it yourself. If the genre and gameplay looks something remotely interesting to you, you won't miss with this one.

P.S. Kim Kitsuragi is a great man and an even greater bro

author: {'steamid': '76561199402603178', 'num_games_owned': 123, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2281, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 2281, 'last_played': 1728596989}
review:
Let me start off by saying it ran flawlessly on my Steam Deck. No glitches, no problems whatsoever.

Ok onto the review of the game itself:

What an incredible game. Truly among the best video games I have ever played in my life… and completely unlike what I would personally enjoy, typically.

Genuinely the weirdest video game I have ever played in terms of tone and dialogue etc, but I mean that in a very positive way.

The level of choice in terms of what sort of person you want to be is sort unprecedented as far as I have ever seen.

The world building is up there with BG3 and TW3 as the best I have ever experienced in this medium.

It’s dreary, it’s gray, it’s SUPER depressing… but once you’re in you can’t pull yourself away. Not just because of the main story’s mystery, but also because you HAVE to see how things unfold for the protagonist PERSONALLY.

This game is not about graphic fidelity. It almost looks like older CRPG games; just a little smoothed out… but this isn’t the game to play if you’re looking for visuals… it’s a gritty RPG, choice-and-consequence, story-based game… and it’s among the best ever, at that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086791194', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 7857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6001, 'last_played': 1706849334}
review:
[h1] Disco Elysium - The Final Cut [/h1]

My very first time hearing of Disco Elysium, like most people, was during The Game Award 2019, where it managed to win four awards -- Best Narrative, Best RPG, Fresh Indie Game, and Best Independent Game -- shocking the world in the process. I knew at that moment, I had to check it out. Eventually, five years and more than a handful of world-altering events later, I got around to it. Now hailed by many as quite possibly the best-written video game ever made, it's suffice to say that the game's reputation has only gotten more legendary since -- especially with the release of The Final Cut. With a word count surpassing even that of The Lord of the Rings trilogy, the prospect of playing is an enormous undertaking that had me more than a little intimidated. But, as someone relatively new to the genre, I loved every second of it. A hardcore point-and-click narratively driven role-playing game through and through, Disco Elysium won me over with its sheer creativity, imagination, and raw storytelling prowess. Never before have I played a game such as this.

[h2] The Positives ▼ [/h2]

[b] 1. Exceptionally Written [/b]
Over the course of decades and hundreds of games, the ongoing list of what I'd consider to be the best-written games is constantly growing and changing. Titles such as Bioshock, Yakuza 0, Nier Automata, Persona 5, and Soma, to name a few, are kings of that list and have been for several years. Now, allow me to dethrone them all in one fell swoop of the pen. Ladies & gentlemen, there is now a new reigning monarch in the kingdom, and his majesty's name is Harry motherf#cking Du Bois. Clever, creative, highly imaginative, nuanced, mature, and funny as all hell, Disco Elysium set a new benchmark for writers across the industry for how to write compelling characters, conflicts, and dialogues. Frankly, it's an achievement for writing as a medium in general. Without a hint of hyperbole, Disco Elysium is the greatest written work I've seen in a video game, and I can't praise it enough.

[b] 2. Incredible Vocal Performances [/b]
The Final Cut brought a heap of additional content and improvements, one of which is fully voice acting. I cannot even begin to stress how phenomenal and life-changing this is for the game. Besides making it more digestible for readers of all skill levels, the vocal performances themselves are world-class. As a matter of fact, I would go as far as to say it's the best vocal performance I have ever seen in an indie title, surpassing even that of Hades. I tried to look up the actors - expecting to see the usual credits and faces, but to my surprise, it was nobody I knew. Just a bunch of relatively unknown actors and musicians with strong theatre backgrounds that I am only now hearing of for the first time. Genuinely, it's some of the best voice acting in any video game. 

[b] 3. Strong Emphasis On Player's Choice [/b]
Much like its other core endeavors, Disco Elysium is unrivaled when it comes to giving players agency, freedom, and choices. Want to take the beaten road and become a good cop? It's yours. How about becoming the most corrupt bastard in town? Done. Wanna become a raging communist? Go for it. There are myriads of different ways to tackle the murder case at the heart of the story. There's no such thing as the "right" path, and players are encouraged to role-play and experiment to their heart's content. And this isn't just some veneer thrown in for good measure, either. What you do and say will have real consequences for the characters and plots of Disco Elysium, and the world will change in accordance with your choices. As a result, Martainise feels like a living breathing district, and it's refreshing to see how reactive the writing is when pushed to its absolute limit. 

[b] 4. Failure Is Not The End [/b]
What I love the most about Disco Elysium's gameplay is that it is equally as rewarding and fun failing a skill check as much as it passing one. When I see a game implement these kinds of mechanics, it's often to the detriment of the players. Luck-based mechanics almost always lead to frustration and save scumming, but Disco Elysium found a way. By making it so that white checks are retriable so long as one invests a skill point into it and by making failing a check equally as hilarious, satisfying, and interesting as succeeding one, the game sorely feels cheap and unfair when you do inevitably fail. I adore this about Disco Elysium and found it to be one of the game's most innovative aspects. 

[b] 5. Great Soundtrack [/b]
When it's commonplace to spend upward of thirty minutes to an hour engaging in an average conversation, it's not just important to have a great soundtrack -- it's an existential imperative. Disco Elysium not only survived -- but thrived. As players, we can explore and see the poverty-stricken district of Martainise firsthand and read all about the political limbo of Revachol. But, to feel and understand it through the power of music, now that's powerful. The heart and soul of Disco Elysium wouldn't be the same without the beautiful music composed by Sea Power that made it so nostalgic and memorable. 

[b] 6. Excellent Art Style  [/b]
While not the most technically and graphically impressive game out there, what Disco Elysium does have is a unique and beautiful-looking oil painting art style that sets it apart from its contemporaries. Drawn by Aleksander Rostov, it's hard to overstate how crucial his unique art direction is for visually communicating the tone and feel of the game. Everything from the skill and character portraits to the environments and the surreal thought backgrounds -- the game has a certain indescribable feel to it that makes it so distinctive and beautiful to look at. 

[h2] The Negatives ▼ [/h2]

[b] 1. Technically Unpolished [/b]
No game is without fault, and in the case of Disco Elysium, that has to be for its lack of polish. For all of its incredible achievements, the game has a habit of feeling janky and unpolished more often than I would've liked. Technical bugs, voice lines not matching with what's written on the screen, poor animation, mechanics not working consistently like fast traveling, and more. And if you're truly unlucky, some bugs can even be game-breaking. As much as I love the game, this list of technical issues is impossible to ignore and frankly -- unacceptable. 

[b] 2. No Sorting System? [/b]
One of the core gameplay loops of Disco Elysium is collecting articles of clothing that, when equipped, can raise particular stats rendering skill checks easier to pass. By the end of the game, it's not uncommon for the average player to amass anywhere from a few to a couple of dozen, and going through all of them every time you want to increase a stat is a pain. Why is there not a simple sorting system that allows players to choose a stat they're looking for and filter out the rest? Having this kind of system would've greatly reduced time players spend in the inventory equipping gears. I can't believe such a simple and obvious solution somehow got overlooked. 

[h3] Final Thoughts [/h3]
The success of Disco Elysium lies in its focus. The writers and designers had a strong vision for the kind of game that they were trying to make and the audience that would play it. No compromise, no surrendering. Five years later, the result continues to speak for itself. Celebrated by fans worldwide for its narrative brilliance and as a generation and genre-defining game, Disco Elysium continues to be a game that fans and developers point to as a glowing beacon in the industry. A standard for all to aspire to and, most importantly, dare to surpass. It's been one hell of a ride, but all good things must come to an end.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960905056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1019, 'last_played': 1732491863}
review:
This is my first review, and I feel compelled to share my thoughts because Disco Elysium is one of those rare games that really makes you think. It's not your typical RPG, and it's unlike anything I've played before. If you're looking for a traditional action game, this might not be for you. But if you’re open to something different something more focused on story and choice then this game is worth your time.

 What I like about DE is that there are no “right” answers, you’re allowed to be as idealistic or as cynical as you want. The game really lets you shape your character’s personality through your choices, and the dialogue reflects that. It’s a lot more about conversation and internal conflict than about solving puzzles or fighting enemies. You really feel immersed and often times you feel like you're a real somewhat f-ed up Detective. 

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561199186646459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3477, 'last_played': 1728084476}
review:
Absolute must play 10/10
Reasons for recommendation:
-Incredibly immersive experience 
-Rich world building 
-Fun dialogues 
-Great Art
-Great soundtracks
-Amazing character designs that are close to life
-Interesting character relationships and interactions
-Unique gaming mechanisms 
-Heavy reading that improves your English reading skills
-Full voice-over that improves your English hearing 
-Fun themes like politics, philosophy, existentialism and disco 
Don't worry about not being able to understand the political and philosophical themes (Cuz I can't), the game is still fantastic without them!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198082609364', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1657, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 1598, 'last_played': 1733287812}
review:
This game is beautiful, and worth your time.

I will play through this game, which is short relative to other RPGs, every year. Eventually there will be a year that I forget, and will never play this game again. Eventually I will not remember this game, its story, or its characters. I will, however, have been permanently improved by this game.
I cannot imagine any other set of 20 hours being more beneficial than a single playthrough of Disco Elysium.

Plays great on SteamDeck by the way.

author: {'steamid': '76561199379994617', 'num_games_owned': 102, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1731311593}
review:
I purchased this game perhaps a year or more ago, played it for 25 minutes, and never touched it for forever. I ended up losing my computer (currently writing this on mobile) and was incredibly disappointed that I was not able to get back into the game after my interest in it piqued again- all until very recently as it was released on the Nintendo Switch. 

Now, after about 20-ish hours playing the game on the switch, I’m absolutely enamored. The music is gorgeous, a cacophony of horns and twangy rhythmic guitar, droning synth, high tempo disco music, etc. I highly reccomend listening to it, even if it’s just in the background. 

The art is beautiful, the portraits able to capture the unique faces and personalities of all the amazing citizens of Revachol that you meet, as well as the hauntingly captivating portraits of your skills (clearly, I really like half-lights portrait) that can convey so much emotion. The background are meticulously designed and capture the perfect eerie feeling of walking through this recovering post-war city. It’s like walking through an acrylic or oil pastel artwork.

As for the FULLY VOICE ACTED CAST, Lenval Brown absolutely nails his roles as the skills and your inner thoughts, the overall narrator of everything that happens. It’s really like listening to how my brain talks to itself, arguing and making decisions, like it took a peek inside my head. Anyways, not just Brown, but also every single other side character, has amazing voice work. They all feel like real, tangible people.

Where this amazing game really shines is the writing. It’s said that there are 1.2 million words in the game, which is literally longer than the entire LOTR trilogy. (In fact, it’s more than twice as large, as the LOTR trilogy is only a measly 480,000 words!)
With that, I’m not gonna sugarcoat it, Disco Elysium is honestly like reading a really long book (and that may be obvious to some), but it’s a book you cannot put down. The lore and world building of the entire town is so well thought out, it almost feels like reading genuine history. There’s so many little lore bits about the city and world that I’m sure a large amount of players will miss their first time through. 
The writing for the interactions with NPCs and Kim are so natural, so fluid and realistic it’s almost like watching a genuine conversation, or even having one. You can see all the minute details of a person you’re talking to, you can draw conclusions from the composure or even see into their souls with empathy- All of these are small things we subconsciously do in real life, and Disco Elysium nails how it feels. Just, mwah. Amazing writing my god.

Finally, I’m not quite fully in on the scoop of what’s happened with ZA/UM; I’ve only purchased the switch version about a week ago and haven’t kept up online, but from my rough and limited understanding, the original creators *are not even being payed for this absolute masterpiece.* It’s a fucking travesty against art and almost cruelly ironic given some of the anti-capital sentiments discussed in game.

Overall, a 10/10 game, a genuinely life changing experience to play, yet- don’t buy it here. Don’t give this shitty corpo your money. Go pirate this game on your own. And go check out what the RIGHTFUL CREATORS are doing, and maybe even find a way to support them.

That is all. Have a wonderful day, whoever you might be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039580049', 'num_games_owned': 495, 'num_reviews': 491, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1717930218}
review: This game presents a rich narrative set in the complex world of Revachol. With detailed character development and atmospheric visuals, it offers a unique RPG experience. However, its slow pacing and text-heavy gameplay may not appeal to all players. Overall, it's a thought-provoking game worth exploring for fans of narrative-driven RPGs. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3243962811 https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3246492900

author: {'steamid': '76561198160931757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3300, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 3286, 'last_played': 1689145534}
review: Absolutely stunning writing. Even setting aside the excellent artwork, the moody voice acting, the solid soundtrack, the fresh game mechanic of your stats effectively being characters that get more to do as you level them, the world that was clearly fleshed out well beyond what we see in this game...it's the writing that truly stands above them all. There were multiple moments where I played this game and actually had to stop and just re-read and linger on the prose that was being used.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142273525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2086, 'last_played': 1730575239}
review:
What a wonderful game. The music, the colours, the scenarios, all the little details, the actions the players are forced to undertake—all come together like a beautiful symphony. as the story unfolds. The voiceovers and dialogue options (especially the skills) create an incredibly engaging experience. I am really in love with this game. I can't wait to play it again. 

I highly recommend playing it seriously first to get all the juicy drama out of it, then go for chaotic runs. What a delightful game.

P.S. I got an "error" message twice when saving my game. Thankfully, it only made me waste around one hour of gameplay that I had to redo. Did not bother looking into what caused the error I was so enthralled by the game. So be careful with your save files. The game can be a bit buggy, but the positive greatly outweigh the negative.

author: {'steamid': '76561198303849063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1936, 'last_played': 1726437064}
review:
To the people who think that the gameplay lacks action and excitement;
It's true, but the game will keep you in once you understand it's mechanics, the action and excitement will be along the way too.

It's a great RPG experience which shines with it's unique narration and it's ways of customisation; These two here, are more than powerful enough to keep you entertained.

Even if you don't want to listen to all the things or notice everything, you can be that kind of character as well. It's like the real world, not all things are important to every one. (and the game notices it, it notices which topics interest you more and shapes your experience. I remember that one time I watched my friend playing the game and his experience was quite different compare to mine because of his different character build)

And there are some unique things and themes in this game that you have not seen before, from a company who develops "Radio" Games, to a man who hunts imaginary animals.

author: {'steamid': '76561199165642244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 2328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1040, 'playtime_at_review': 1287, 'last_played': 1735981781}
review:
There were aspects of the game I enjoyed and some I didn't. Playing on an Xbox controller, I found the movement controls, especially moving up or down steps, frustratingly slow. The terminology used throughout the game was confusing, often leaving me opting for option D just to get through dialogue-heavy scenes. I missed a lot of achievements but all the dialogue pulled me out of attempting a second playthrough.

The game's confined and straightforward setting was something I appreciated; a larger map would have been exhausting. One major issue was the autosave feature. Without manual saves, a single mistake could cost nearly an hour of progress, which became a painful lesson learned too late in the game.

Despite these gripes, I would definitely play a sequel and still recommend this game to others. I hope to see improvements in control responsiveness and the save system in any future releases.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966918646', 'num_games_owned': 1967, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 5196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4981, 'last_played': 1719779789}
review:
Despite multiple playthroughs, apparently I never dared to write a review. In the hopes of catching one of my friends looking at this game tentatively over the upcoming Steam Sales, here goes...

This is the best narrative-driven CRPG in the last 25 years.

The writing feels so alive, every word of it. The art is evocative, as if Hieronymus Bosch reincarnated and painted a triptych depicting our modern broken world. The soundtrack by British Sea Power fits the game perfectly. The story and characters pull you in right away. The combined vibes are just off the charts. This is a real work of art.

The game gives you tools to shape your character with a one-of-a-kind skill system. In addition to typical skill checks it provides additional internal dialogue interjections and options. Thought Cabinet gives you further bonuses and maluses as you choose what kind of thoughts to internalize. These systems are mechanically perfect for this style of game. As in any good RPG, you roll a lot of dice. The failed rolls are often funnier than the successful ones. If you can't accept the outcome, most of the rolls can be retried later. Trying again fits the theme of the game perfectly. There are tons of hidden modifiers unlocked by exploring the world and engaging with the game. The game consistently rewards exploration and engaging with it.

The game lives and dies by its script. Over one million words, now fully voice-acted in The Final Cut, with delightful acting  throughout. The game doesn't hesitate to be real -- it isn't at all afraid of confronting and calling out the player. Some of the topics it deals with are incredibly heavy, and not often encountered in games. There is a lot of black humor weaved in. It's [b]very[/b] Estonian in character, something I bonded with right away as a Finn. The failures of communism, socialism, capitalism, fascism and centrism are all explored here in depth. The game gets crushingly sad at times, yet nonetheless it is permeated with a sense of vague hope. It can be a journey of healing.

The [i]only[/i] reason to skip this game is if you're not a reader or suffer from attention span issues. The full voice acting only helps up to a point. It demands attention and rewards patience.

The only relevant point of comparison is to Planescape: Torment, an obscure CRPG from 1999 that was previously my uncontested favorite CRPG of all time. It is a similarly word-heavy story, with a similarly amnesiac main character, but if we are being real, Planescape suffers from its Dungeons & Dragons engine and combat. The setting is completely different and the story being told hits completely different beats. Clearly Planescape: Torment served as a faint inspiration, but the comparisons don't do Disco Elysium justice.

I'm frankly surprised that five years after release, this style and the mechanics haven't been copied by other games. Perhaps that is for the best. This is a unique masterpiece, and unluckily for us the studio that made it has disintegrated since, in a very Disco Elysium fashion. (Most negative reviews you see are kneejerk reactions to what went down.) [i]Life imitates art.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198261634412', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 674, 'last_played': 1729301203}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000861562', 'num_games_owned': 3281, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1730654314}
review: Disco Elysium is such a special game, nothing quite like it on the market. The final cut adds so much QoL (quality of life). This game is designed in such a smart way and you will be hooked right from the start in the mystery plot. Replayability is good because you can make so many decisions and different directions to explore. A dark and gritty game with a good detective story and flawed characters. Some decisions can be frustrating since the game is very unforgiving, so I ended up having to reload a few times when I screwed up in ways that made it hard to come back, but I do enjoy the storytelling so much. The gameplay is simple but the RPG aspects with choices and the vibe of the world and detective setting is super cool. The artstyle is interesting and fits well. The voice acting is really good and it is very impressive how much work has gone into this product. Well worth playing, a true gem. This is a game you will remember long after playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198803835961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 1365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1345, 'last_played': 1727199072}

I played this game at launch in 2019 and now (2024) I just finished my second playthrough. The game is so great that I wanted to forget as much as I could before doing a second run. I can't wait for future projects by Kurvitz and Rostov <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198021104001', 'num_games_owned': 1853, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 2415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2415, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 2158, 'last_played': 1718794226}
review:
This is one of those games which will stick with me for a while. It slowly grew on me the more I kept going, and while playing it I felt totally immersed in its world.

Disco Elysium was on my backlog for a while, I had heard great things about it and so I finally picked it up and pushed through it. Well, actually “pushing through” is probably non the appropriate terminology since it took me a long time to complete and I don't have much spare time lately to split between my many hobbies. I should just say I savored it, piece by piece, and it actually tasted great!

I should say the incipit is a bit of a cliche, probably overused in too many games, but it works well here. The game starts with an amnesiac character (us) and we will have to backtrack and piece together what happened up until that point, before alcohol and drugs abuse caused us to trash our room and forget everything. 

We will soon find out we are detectives, tasked to solve a murder case in Martinaise, one of the poorest and degraded areas of the city of Revachol, a former capital of the world now in decay.

Alongside us we will have the trustworthy lieutenant Kim Kitsuragi, in my opinion one of the best characters ever conceived in videogames history. In fact, all characters in this game are extremely well written and really feel human more than NPCs. The fact the entirety of the dialogues are dubbed is an even more surprising fact, given how many lines of dialogue there are overall. Aside from other characters, we will often have thoughts, represented through internal dialogues with different parts of our psyche and personality. As I said before, the quality and depth of the writing is paramount and it really is the key factor which kept me immersed in the story.

The overall atmosphere is great too, the semi open world hub areas aren't really big, but they are densely packed with things and characters to interact with, and almost everything opens up new branches of the story, side quests which are often linked to the main one or simply just help getting a better grasp at the world we are into, both socially, politically and economically. 

I was baffled at how the overall experience was tightly tied together, and how seemingly random things ended up connecting later on and forming such a cohesive world feeling. Every piece of the puzzle nicely fits together in the end. 

The story is also great, it's a detective noir rich with plot twists, as it should be. Alongside it, we will be choosing which kind of cop we want to be, through ethical and moral choices we’re presented with.
I won't spoil anything, but nothing is what it seems and no stone deserves to be left unturned.

Talking about graphics, Disco Elysium has a very peculiar hand drawn style, which is timeless and will help appreciate the game even many years from now. There are lots and lots of fine details which convey a feeling of decay from the world aesthetics. Every character and even each personality trait has its own hand drawn portrait. I truly appreciated the effort in this regard.

The sound in this game is absolutely brilliant. As I said before, all the countless dialogues are completely dubbed, and trust me when I say there are lots and lots of lines. And the voice actors are really good too, “S” tier dare I say.
Aside from the stellar voice acting, the soundtrack is great as well. Every hub has a main theme, but music dynamically adapts to the events, in order to properly convey all the emotions and feelings of the moment.

Playing Disco Elysium is basically like reading a dynamic book. Writing is brilliant, and dialogues often go really deep into many different topics, ranging from more serious socio-economic and political subjects to lore, religion, science, and much more. This really succeeds at making the fictional world really believable and immersive.

The only real complaint I have towards this game is that some dialogue trees are really massive and it's not possible to save during these. Some dialogues can easily last the better part of an hour, thus the ability to save midway would have been really appreciated. It also would have made it easier to save scum dice rolls, but you can do that anyways, it's just more inconvenient.

All in all I'm really happy I finally completed Disco Elysium, I would recommend it to anyone who loves RPGs and great writing in general. I also found the english translation of the book this game was inspired from, and I will for sure give it a read eventually.

Great experience, recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561199324281280', 'num_games_owned': 90, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1009, 'last_played': 1726774025}

author: {'steamid': '76561199035978258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1437, 'playtime_at_review': 1093, 'last_played': 1736633308}
review:
Disco Elysium is my first time diving into an RPG like this, and it’s been an unforgettable experience so far. The game sets an incredible standard for storytelling in video games. The script is easily one of the best I’ve ever encountered, full of sharp wit, emotional depth, and meaningful dialogue. Every conversation is a masterclass in writing, and the world-building feels both intricate and alive.

The voice acting is phenomenal—each character is brought to life with performances that perfectly match their personalities, adding even more weight to the already incredible writing. While there were a few moments where the audio dialogue didn’t match the text, this was a minor issue and didn’t detract from my overall immersion.

Visually, the game is stunning. The hand-painted art style is both unique and beautiful, capturing the bleak and mysterious atmosphere of the setting in a way that feels fresh and memorable. The music is equally impressive, with an atmospheric score that perfectly complements every moment, whether it’s quiet introspection or a dramatic turning point.

That said, there are a few aspects that may not be for everyone. It can take a few hours to really click, as the game’s systems and narrative style aren’t immediately conventional. The lack of combat may also turn some players off, but for me, it was refreshing to see a game focus so deeply on dialogue, choices, and character development instead.

Additionally, the setting is quite bleak. This isn’t a feel-good game, in my opinion—it’s heavy, introspective, and at times uncomfortably real. If you’re looking for something lighthearted, this might not be the best fit.

For me, though, all these elements come together to create something truly special. At just 19 hours in, I already know this is a game I’ll be thinking about long after I finish. If you love superb writing, stunning art, and deeply immersive storytelling, Disco Elysium is an absolute must-play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997048743', 'num_games_owned': 511, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 2285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2285, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 2227, 'last_played': 1661107715}
review: Shame about the real-world politics and issues this studio & developer are facing, but in isolation of that - this is one of the best RPGs I've ever played. It's weird, it's esoteric, it's philosophical. It's very, very political in the way a group of folks who grew up in the communist bloc would be politicised. I loved it all the way through and played it start to finish on my steam deck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033366207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 3890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3890, 'last_played': 1716783641}
review:
I'm aware about all the situation concerning the *buisiness controversial*. I just want to shortly review the game itself. 

The idea of disintegrated ego that's trying to recollect itself through body, mind, ideology is so powerful. How they made it not boring and interesting is ingenious. Playing that game was sometimes very deep, transcendential expirience, that i somehow feel that i will never expirience from any other game. 

It was a great litarature and narrative expirience. I've never thought that any game could quote and develop the ideas of Hegel, Zizek, Fisher and others. What I'm surprised about is how lots of people love it. In the times, where people could not concentrate more then 15 seconds on anything, they made a game where you read all the time and it is not that easy reading. 

 The main character, Harry, he represents many of us. He is good, intellegenent, descent man, who just can not handle this world, like so many of us. Such a deep glance on depression in contemporary society and all destructive practices that come as a result. (Harry was so lucky to meet exactly Kitsuragi as his partner. This parental figure, who otherwise do not treat him like a child, but shows him, that he is a person with his own capabilities, strenghth and weaknesess). 

The ending was very Lacanian for me. They showed a man who lived all his live in his fantasies not even guessing that he is in the phantasm of his. If i ever want to work on something in my life it would be the game like this. The game like this perhaps is not possible in any time soon. Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198806304887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1136, 'last_played': 1688323481}

review: It's a masterpiece, there's no doubt about that. Literature grade writing, super rich and interesting characters, mesmerizing atmosphere. It's not a RPG, not an adventure, it's an incarnation. You live a colorful life inside this game. The only thing that made me scratch my head about this game is a very strange choice of narrator. The guy cannot read two words in succession, he makes pause every time he sees a space. Thankfully, you can turn him off. But oh well, even the sun has spots.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043015378', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2957, 'last_played': 1732132657}
review:
The best graphic adventure that I have ever played. And it seems to be the same opinion that almost everyone that opens it has. I mean, it's one of the highest ranked PC games on all Metacritic.

You need to come to Disco Elysium with an open mind, and mentalized that this piece of software is text based. You are going to read. And you are going to be moved by what you read.

Still, it's necessary to comment that the game's property has moved hands and by buying it you are not supporting a lot of the people that made it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199526971525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1514, 'last_played': 1719876950}
review: One of the best games Ive played in my lifetime, this game has climbed to the number one spot on my top favorite games of all time. This game has made an impact on my life, disco Elysium made me cry, laugh, and make tough choices, and im so sad to hear there will be no other game to continue harry & Kim's story. Disco, Elysium, 20/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066259242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 3225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2693, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1719939521}
review:
Disco Elysium – an unprecedented game from an incredible team with a sad story. Somehow, the dramatic and depressive mood of the world of Revachol has spread to the ZA/UM studios. Despite the fact that Disco Elysium is one of the highest-rated games in the entire history of games, ZA/UM went through such a series of scandals, problems, and dismissals of key employees that we can’t even hope for a continuation of the game anytime soon.

Visual 10/10

There are no vivid visual effects, but the style and art are very deep and interesting. Many companies try to earn marketing points by not using AI instead of real artists’ concepts. However, usually, these human-made arts are dull. Disco Elysium’s art is the rare case where artists have really done great work. The genre is poorly visualized but still, the environment conveys the depressive and melancholic mood of the world; the portraits of the characters are made in different styles and highlight their personal traits. My favorite art in the game are the pictures of the skills. They are absolutely amazing, and I've seen many people on various parts of the internet use these images as avatars, including myself.

Narrative 10/10

The plot is not overloaded with delusional elements like parallel universes, but there are still plenty of crazy and interesting things at the junction of reality and madness, which give you space to interpret and guess what is happening. The basic story is solid and interesting, developing alongside the game as are the character arcs. One of the best indicators of the high caliber of the game's characters is the fact that there are plenty of groups on Telegram, Facebook, and other social networks where people create and share memes and fan fiction about the game's characters. But the main gem of the game is a bunch of philosophical, social, political, and historical questions, which the authors explore through dialogues between the player and the characters. In some ways, this is not only a game but also a socio-political and philosophical treatise and discussion at the same time. And precisely this aspect makes the game so amazing and unique.

Gameplay 10/10

I’ve seen plenty of discussions about the gameplay in Disco Elysium: some people assume there is hardly any gameplay at all, and it’s more an interactive book than a game. But look – it’s not just a big text that you read. Instead, the entire dialogue tree depends on your character traits and personality. I’ve played twice, and each time I created completely different characters, resulting in all the dialogues being different. This is a main feature of the game: the role-playing aspect is truly inimitable here. You can find something like this in very old-school RPGs like Fallout 1 and 2, but there are very few such games, literally a few. And Disco Elysium is probably the best among them.

Sound 10/10

It might seem odd, but yes, even the sound is magnificent and flawless here. Musical tracks from the game have become legendary, and you'll understand why if you have played. The voice actors have done truly amazing work; I haven't seen better voice acting anywhere else. I’ve heard that the development team did not plan to voice all the dialogues in the game since the whole game consists of them and there are tens or hundreds of thousands of lines of text. But in the end, they voiced 100% of the text in the game, and I am sure that the voice acting has become one of the ingredients of the wonderful cocktail that is Disco Elysium.

Overall 10/10

I hope I have explained why you should try this game if you enjoy role-playing gameplay, an interesting plot, distinctive arts, and good music. I am really happy for you if you have not played this game yet. But I am also happy for myself and everyone else who has played it, because, first of all, we gained an amazing game experience over dozens of hours and, secondly, we still have the opportunity to return to the game, create a new style of character, and play the game from almost scratch. And I am also happy for humanity because ZA/UM created this miracle for us.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021087888', 'num_games_owned': 234, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 11365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10824, 'last_played': 1705519440}
review: Easily the best novel you'll ever play, and, well, words fail to describe just how standout this thing is compared to just about anything else. Whether it's a better *game* than whatever you compare it to can be a fair question, but it's better entertainment and certainly better art and a better experience than most media products in the last several decades at least... in any media.

review: Game is wonderful it is as if I am walking through a story and even if I have not completed it yet I still would recommend to those who love a slow but lovely story with lovely characters.

review: one of the best RPGs EVER on the market; can easily sink so much time into, with such a story-rich plot, and beautiful design. heavily recommended

author: {'steamid': '76561198263374418', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1079, 'last_played': 1717033436}
review: A game that stands out for its deep storytelling, complex characters and immersive atmosphere, DE offered an unforgettable gaming experience that's both captivating and thought provoking!

author: {'steamid': '76561198114357075', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 1962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1962, 'last_played': 1691748069}
review:
So apparently the rights to the game were stolen from the actual creator/s and we will most likely not get a Disco Elysium 2, so get the game through other means if you can since this doesn't help the main creator/s anymore.

I don't know why I didn't review this right I finished it but here I go. 
First of all approach the game with a very open mind as it touches many subjects that are sensitive to some, including and not limited to politics, if you have any kind of strong views towards something chances are those views might get insulted in the game eventually or questioned at the least.

If you enjoy picking at the human mind on a daily basis and really like a good story with well acted voices then this is the game for you. Let me tell you this game will crawl deep into your mind and take you on a self discovering journey, you will become who you really are meant to be (if you play the game seriously). At first I didn't think much of the game when I played it but I'd put it in my top games played ever out of the hundreds of games I played. 

If I could say what the game felt like to me I would say that. 
Rediscovering the human nature in such a beautiful way couldn't have been more fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561199653192140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1616, 'last_played': 1710948392}
review:
I've had an absolutely phenomenal experience with Disco Elysium. This game is a masterpiece of storytelling, brimming with deep thoughts and intriguing conceptions that captivate you from the start. Every decision feels meaningful, creating a unique adventure tailored to each player.

The voice acting in Disco Elysium is nothing short of spectacular, adding an incredible layer of depth to an already rich narrative. The actors' performances are compelling and truly bring the characters to life in a way that's both breathtaking and, at times, wonderfully insane.

Playing Disco Elysium has been an investment of time that I consider absolutely worthwhile. It's a game that not only entertains but also challenges and inspires. I cannot recommend it highly enough to anyone who appreciates games that are not just played but experienced. A genuine gem in the world of interactive storytelling.

author: {'steamid': '76561198397419509', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2168, 'last_played': 1709752193}
review: If you like to read about politics, play this. If you like to read about philosophy, play this. If you like to read detective stories, play this. If you like to read in general, play this. Writing is really dense and at times poetic. Good stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133942453', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3068, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3068, 'last_played': 1727439519}
review: Contains overtly pro-LGBTQ+ messaging. Features multiple gay characters, including the player character. Heavy social commentary regarding communism. Whether pro or anti is unclear... Highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038045911', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2672, 'last_played': 1704935633}
review:
This is one of the only games I have ever played that I would classify as literature. It plays heavily into personal (mental health, substance abuse, healing) and political themes, though I personally found it more valuable for the former than the latter.
I find it extremely easy to recommend to pretty much anybody who doesn't feel the need for combat for a video game to be enjoyable, or who isn't easily upset by the presence of ideologies with which they disagree.
Empathy, Esprit De Corp, Shivers, and Inland Empire are my boys.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040943549', 'num_games_owned': 47, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1692, 'last_played': 1705069776}
review: Point and click game with progression driven solely by dialogue choices. No combat whatsoever. Great characters and music. Not a fan of the expansive exposition presented in dialogue and inner thoughts. Still, interesting overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134189715', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2012, 'last_played': 1705444340}
review: After 32 hours, I have finally completed my first playthrough. Wow.  This is one of those games that fundamentally changes you as a person.One that makes you pray for amnesia, just to be able to experience it for the first time again. It was one of the most memorable gaming experiences of my life, the care, passion, and attention to detail in this game is ASTOUNDING. No game has made me think more, feel more, or get so emotionally involved with the characters and plot lines. The political satire is genius, and regardless of ones views going into the game, it will make you re-evaluate things you held as true. The world building is incredibly thought provoking and painstakingly crafted, after my 30 hours, I barely feel as though I scratched the surface. With multiple endings, and varying builds, this game has an astounding amount of replayabilty, and I'm very excited to see what the other endings hold.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006669811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 2494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2457, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 3, 'last_played': 1705789092}
review:
It's true; we finally have a worthy spiritual successor to Planescape Torment. Though, I hear Tides of Numenera is also worth a run, for some of that same experience. But that's where Disco Elysium excels, in that it also manages to distinguish itself sufficiently.

What Disco Elysium is, is a great murder-mystery and very thorough detective story, surrounded by slight political satire and critique, touching on everything from ultra capitalism, racialism, neo-liberalism to socialism and communism. While also managing to expose the player to some very thoughtful, mature and heartfelt stories involving just regular people and the drama of the human condition.

It ranges and very easily shifts from absolute heart-wrenching stories, to grim and depressing, to the most wacky and out-there experiences that almost feel like the writers were on acid. At least that's what I'd imagine being on acid is like.

The amount of physical and mental skills used in the game, and because of that the amount of skill checks for various context and information, is astounding and really encourages experimentation and replays. Though, one area that I really did not dabble in very much is the cabinet of thoughts. It looked cool in theory, and I love the flavor text, but it forcing me to choose between skills and thoughts kind of made it too complicated. So I just stuck to min-maxing the main skills. Maybe on a replay.

The music is also wonderful, as is the pastel art style.

About the only negative I could find was the voice actor of one character, Ruby, that for some reason was very monotone and really stuck out like a sore thumb. And the very final 1-2h of play feel very railroaded. But even so I enjoyed the ending and the explanation of what started the whole story. Very mature and subdued.

A 9.5/10 from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031456026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3291, 'last_played': 1719225631}
review: Disco Elysium tells a great story based on a vast, deep world. For me, it's surprisingly fun. Initially, I found it hard to enjoy its style and the overwhelming amount of dialogue text, but after the first day in the game, I started to enjoy the amazing story telling. Like the real world, Almost every character in this game has a unique and firm standpoint, making it difficult to deceive but much easier to persuade if you are willing to pay with your money, support, time, or life. Rich characters lead me to curiosity, and curiosity leads me to immersion. At last, the old cop found himself, and I realized maybe, I was that old cop.

author: {'steamid': '76561198382166790', 'num_games_owned': 126, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2608, 'last_played': 1718395126}
review:
I adore Disco Elysium. It is truly a one-of-a-kind experience, and sadly after almost 5 years have passed since its initial release, it seems even more mythic and unrepeatable now. The creatives behind it delivered a narrative experience that is frankly unparalleled with anything I’ve ever played. From the mesmerizingly melancholic world of Elysium to its riveting plot and conflict informed by the detailed politics and history of Revachol. This being conveyed naturally through tidbits you learn from its inhabitants and the environment as you explore it. Every character you meet along the way feels as though they really live and breathe, existing separately from the player’s interaction, they communicate their own views and temperaments in a way that is astonishingly lifelike and individual. This is bolstered by the diverse array of voice talent, each of which sound exactly how they read, perfectly understanding the nuance and tone of the script. A particular highlight for me was the presence of Kim Kitsuragi, he feels like a real companion throughout, having him by you side at all times facilitates intricacy in your interaction with the environment and other characters which otherwise wouldn’t be possible. The way he voices his interpretation of the investigation as it progresses, interjecting in interviews, pulling you aside to talk over things in private, scolding you when you act up; it lends so much legitimacy to the role of the detective you are playing as well as the experience overall. To sum it up Disco Elysium’s writing is vivid, wry, authentic, and truly singular.

The genius of Disco Elysium’s design lies in its decision to abandon conventional gameplay, so that it can tell a story completely unconstrained, while importantly maintaining a traversable, interactable, and compelling world to explore and immerse yourself in. I’m really hopeful we will see future games adopt this approach as it will allow for new and more sophisticated stories to be told, furthering games as a narrative medium. The gameplay in Disco Elysium is essentially there to reinforce the story, there is no twitchy real time combat to keep you hooked, purely exploration, interfacing with the environment and others and roleplaying in the form of decision making, equipment and stat distribution. For example, the commitment to make certain choices partly up to chance in the form of white and red checks, is exciting, adding tension and gravity to key moments. This in combination with the skill system determining Harry’s abilities and thoughts makes each playthrough feel unique and I’m eager to see what changes on a replay using a different archetype. Crucially the gameplay makes you feel like detective Harrier Du Bois, its unglamorous but immersive and cohesive with the story and because of that its pacing is excellent throughout.

author: {'steamid': '76561199025141639', 'num_games_owned': 89, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2700, 'last_played': 1728858686}
review:
Disco Elysium is a once in a life time game.
and an absolute work of art
the writing, world building, characters, artstyle & direction and OST are truly one of best pieces i have experienced, this game gave me a ton of feels like a roller-coaster of emotions and laughter.


at first i wasn't really feeling like it would be something for me but oh i was so wrong about that, it became one of my fav games if not the best 

it may not for everybody but i fully recommend giving it a chance at least once, it probably could leave a big impact.

kim/10


also as many stated in the reviews, dont buy the game directly off steam, the publisher of this game laidoff most of the original devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198865353535', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1784, 'last_played': 1718684506}
review: i say this with no exaggeration this may be the greatest piece of media of ever experienced in my entire life this is the first game ive ever felt that my choices truly mattered where i would be on a response for tens of minuets thinking how it would affect the game and the writing of these characters made me feel like they were real living breathing people i could feel the detectives confusion through out the whole game trying to discover who i was trying to solve the case chasing leads anything that would lead me back to my memory of my old life and the art oh my sweet lord the art is beyond outstanding the first photo kim takes of the body left me speechless it was almost beautiful in its simple grotesqueness and the music it perfectly sends you into the world making you feel like your roaming the streets of revachol i could feel the cold bitter wind on my face i could smell the rotting corpse i could feel the pain of the detective this game is truly whole heartily unequivocally a true masterpiece of art

author: {'steamid': '76561198113047261', 'num_games_owned': 304, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4238, 'last_played': 1718739066}
review:
I won't lie, this game took a while to click. I picked it up in a sale a few years back, would start a playthrough but drop it after a few hours. There's a lot of reading, it wouldn't be far wrong to say that you don't play DE, you read it.

But holy shit, when this game clicked, it *clicked* hard. Hardcore. Hardcore to the mega. 

The way that the game interacts with itself, with every choice you actively make (dialogue, walking around and picking stuff up, investigating it, etc) iterating on itself to further influence that specific playthrough. Not to mention the passive ability checks, and how they're always more than they seem. 

But the game also iterates with the opposite: the options you *don't* choose, the checks you actively and passively fail - with the end result being an experience that you'll find hard to replicate.

The game is incredible. The art is incredible. The story is like nothing I've ever quite come across: utterly compelling, terrifying but kind, despairing but hopeful. It's exceptional.

However, after all this, should you buy it? No.

I won't go into excruciating specifics on the horror show legal drama surrounding ZA/UM and the writers/creators of the world of Disco Elysium but in short, the studio was bought out by the producers/shareholders (using very sketchy sources of financing, look into it) , the creators and original project team bullied and harassed out of the company and away from the world they'd spent over a decade building. 

Those thieves who wear the skin of creativity, touting accomplishments that don't belong to them and enjoying rewards that they didn't earn do not deserve your time or your money. 

But while you shouldn't buy it, you should still play it. Nay, you need to play it. 
Though, I'll leave it up to you to find ways of playing without paying, as it were ;)

tl;dr mr evrart is helping me write my steam review

author: {'steamid': '76561198146794592', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 3451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2155, 'last_played': 1722493698}
review: A masterpiece of an RPG that keeps you hooked from beginning to end. Action-packed despite having no tactical combat, and only a couple violent moments. The writing is unlike anything you've ever seen, dropping clues for the end of the game at the very beginning that you wouldn't even pick up on due to how outlandish these clues are. Not to mention how philosophically profound the game is, changing my own mind about my sense of self, politics, and the reality we live in. Play this game, and replay it. It's wonderful and moderately life changing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198805612657', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2966, 'last_played': 1716300849}
review:
Disco Elysium invites players into a complex and captivating storyline. The game unfolds as a deep and poetic journey exploring the fractured life of a man trapped in the struggles of alcoholism, navigating the vast emptiness of solitude. As the narrative unfolds, we witness Harry's past unravel which exposes the unsettling realization of his mistakes and the harm he has inflicted on others.
The emotional moments with Dolores go beyond mere incidents, transcending the digital realm and leaving players immersed in a mix of tears. It truly blends sorrow with a glimmer of hope for the redemption of our main character.  

While the game's world may radiate a sense of hopelessness, it also holds a unique beauty that encourages us to hold onto fleeting moments while looking ahead to the future. Within the core of Disco Elysium, I discovered a deep connection with Harry DuBois, surpassing many other fictional characters. The surprising revelation that Harry reflects aspects of myself adds both discomfort and a sense of release to the experience. The game skillfully reflects elements of the human psyche and shared human experience. It is all seamlessly woven into its characters, dialogues, world, art, and music. The musical score orchestrates a symphony that resonates deeply with each melancholic note from the trumpet echoing the complex emotions flowing through the narrative. 

The excellence of the voice acting, especially through Kim Kitsuragi, lends the game a soothing voice. A true embodiment of understanding and reason who is by your side through this immersive journey.

Disco Elysium stands on its own, a narrative that goes beyond conventional storytelling, leaving a lasting impact on the soul. It unfolds emotions in an unprecedented way, showcasing its unique prowess in the realm of gaming artistry.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077588428', 'num_games_owned': 230, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 3064, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3064, 'last_played': 1720645630}
review: "This is all you have, but it's still something". Disco Elysium's world is a broken one, but very human, the interactions you have with other people, all  the motives behind the characters' actions, everything is  very well written and done. It is a game that is deeply human.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000402775', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2567, 'last_played': 1717215810}
review:
The simplest thing I can say is: Yes, this is absolutely worth playing.

Disco Elysium is one of the few experiences that I can say has truly approached "masterpiece" status. The setting that has been created here is genuinely enthralling to explore and learn about. The writing is genuinely fantastic, and there are so many impactful moments that I'd love to quote - but that would be spoiling an experience that is truly best experienced blind. The art and music both help build upon the setting and make it feel unique. Above all, the narration provided by the voice actors was incredible and the delivery lends SO much more impact to each and every line.

As a warning, this game does explore some dark and heavy topics, and if you're not ready for that, it can be a challenge. But as brash and difficult as it can occasionally come off, the game still takes a delicate and respectful approach to them.

You'll find plenty of other reviews and sites covering everything [b] outside [/b] the game. Whatever your opinions are there, the content [b] within [/b] the game is truly remarkable and memorable, and I cannot recommend it enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081983365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 56915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56915, 'last_played': 1716393809}
review:
Ah, Skyrim, my very first Steam game and the reason I got an account in the first place... it's been quite the ride, playing this game in some shape or form over twelve years, and as of this review, I finally got all the achievements.
Pretty sure there ain't much to say that hasn't been already said, but I will say that the Elder Scrolls is perhaps my favorite video game series, Skyrim is kinda like a nice warm bowl of soup in that sense, some days it just sounds good.

On another note though, man I forgot how crash-prone this version is, I know folks have gripes with Special Edition (Well, Bethesda's attempt to destroy their goodwill to be exact) but Oldrim is not the most stable, Falkreath may as well be renamed to Crashkreath (Seriously, that dopey little town became the bane of my last couple of hours)

But regardless of whatever gripes I may had with the lack of stability, it's been tons of fun, playing this game, and while this isn't much of a review, it feels good to write up. So Thanks Skyrim, for all the good times, you've truly earned the title of Legendary in my book :)
