author: {'steamid': '76561198069734989', 'num_games_owned': 86, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 11552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8460, 'last_played': 1720651403}
review:
This is for the DLC //  Base game is 10/10

OMFG get the Lube!  I don't even know if I'm enjoying this anymore or not.  Reason being that bosses hit so frequently and hit like a god damn truck.  Due to this, using anything with a windup is literally impossible in fights unless you utilise a summon.  If you value your sanity, use quick hitting weapons or Reduvia and max out your dps in boss fights.  My biggest gripe with this game is that I can't play it the way I want to like the base game because the developer got a hard on against speed runners and thinks everyone is rolling over his game.  If bosses got some much needed delays between their attacks so more weapons are viable and the lock on camera doesn't have a seizure I'd be an amazing expansion.  I recommend the game for its exploration, but when it comes to boss fights, I can't recommend it yet.

Environment:  10/10
Music:  10/10
Aesthetic:  10/10
New Weapons:  7/10
Enemy Designs:  11/10
Camera having a seizure:  OVER 9000!
Number of times you'll swear on bosses:  11/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198097382072', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 12018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10908, 'last_played': 1727597663}
review:
I almost finished this game, but I ran out of patience on the penultimate boss, so I quit the game. I even killed Malenia. I can say with confidence that this game is the biggest scam in the gaming industry in recent times.

The game has amazing visuals, it has a stunning style and atmosphere. But Miyazaki gradually destroys even those only positive features that the game has.

I would even call Elden Ring an ideal NON-game. It is a collection of certain game mechanics that could have been quite successful, but it is in combination that they break and stop working.

I will immediately make a reservation, the author of the game has a huge fan base that denies all the disadvantages of the game, citing the fact that the player simply has not trained his skill enough. I am not even going to argue with these strange people, some of whom would do well to visit a drug addiction specialist and find a job.

I would like my review to save time and money of people who can be deceived by an advertising company.

In short, the game is bad in absolutely everything that can call one game a video game:

- The game's lore is a rather mediocrely written mythology that is not interesting to understand. In addition, it does not deserve the time and effort required to unravel this tangle

- There is simply no plot in the game. Remember the terminals with stories from Fallout 76? Now imagine that the terminal with chapter number 3 is not in the third cave, but at the other end of the map. And to get there, first level up and kill a couple dozen bosses. And all this so that when you get to this stage of the game, you will safely forget what you were looking for at all

- Nothing motivates you to cover huge distances back and forth on the map and look for a boss suitable for your character level and skill

- And most importantly, the combat mechanics are simply disgusting. This is something Miyazaki should be fired from the industry for and even jailed. This is exploitation of gambling mechanics to get you to try and try the boss, wasting hours of your time. Are these bosses difficult? No, the game is just cheating. This is not Zelda, where you can fence and dodge real enemy animations, and be sure that your hitbox does not match the enemy's hitbox. And where the enemy reacts exactly to the beginning of your hero's animation. No. In this game, the enemy's movements do not match the animations. And the hitboxes do not match. Imagine playing an online MMO, where the boss cast a fireball at you, but you hid behind a wall. The fireball will still fly at you and cause damage, because it was already written into the code on the server. The same goes for Elden Ring, if the boss strikes and the code says it should hit you, then nothing will help, even if it seems to you that you made a perfect dodge and the axe flies past - in a few seconds it will be magnetized right at you and you will die, even if there is half a map between you and the boss. Miyazaki wants you to memorize these features for hours and use a certain ability in time so as not to die.

- Well, you can forget about scaling. You can level up as much as you want, but you will still fly away from ordinary monsters with one hit throughout the entire game. You will not be allowed to enjoy the locations. Death and anxiety all the time. By the way, you will die many times because of the crooked camera and the inability to hit an ordinary monster in time due to some problems with the animation

- I quit the game not because I can't beat the boss. No. I am completely ready for it, I just don't enjoy running away from respawn every time after death, because Miyazaki decided here too that respawn will not be in front of the arena with the boss, but far from this place and on the way there will be several strong opponents who kill with one hit. Why do I need this?

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME AND STAY AWAY FROM MIYAZAKI'S GAMES!

author: {'steamid': '76561198160127593', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 9434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7428, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1721701725}
review:
I have completed the entire game, and even gotten every trophy but this DLC is a MASSIVE letdown and disappointment to me. I'll try to keep this concise and clear so my arguments won't be misconstrued in any way.

- The difficulty
The DLC is too hard, but it's in a different way than you might think off of a first reaction to that statement. The DLC gives you these fragments that you have to explore and collect in order to do any worthwhile damage to the bosses and enemies of the game. With the fragments the bosses are still more difficult compared to even end game bosses, but in the classic from-soft style where learning the moves and dodging is engaging and fun. Without the fragments its absolutely horrible and that's where a lot of criticism about the difficulty is coming from. My main issue is that this fragment system should even exist in the first place and that it is clearly a poor fix from poor game design decisions made early in the games  development. Let me break it down a little bit better.

-Why do the fragments exist?
     Because the game needs a way for you progress without throwing off the difficulty of the main experience.

-Why are people complaining about difficulty when these fragments exist?
     Because the game makes exploration monotonous and tedious for almost the entirety of the DLC. As if it's punishing you for trying to explore before a difficult boss fight.

I wanna talk a little bit more about that first one. This game has the fragments purely because they don't want your main game character to be insanely powerful, and that's okay. I can absolutely understand and get behind that. The issue is however that to even have a decent chance at the DLC you need to be around lvl 150-200 which is endgame/post-endgame. So why have this system in the first place if it doesn't even matter anymore how strong your character is??? It absolutely feels as if From-software wanted to make this game take place around the section of the main story where you enter the main city (Godfrey and Morgott) but quickly realized that the core design of these characters for the dlc are simply too difficult to be place still so early into the game. Which is FINE!!! But, instead of working with the balancing to make it work as an addition to the endgame parts of the main game they implemented the fragment system which only work if you literally look over every single inch of land or use a guide, and that just isn't satisfying for me and majority of other players. It's not that the bosses themselves are too difficult, it's that the entire area meant to prepare you for said bosses are just horribly designed for a game of this type that has been made into an open world game. I have a lot to say about the base quest design but ill mostly save that. I will say that, with Elden Ring being a game that allows you to go anywhere, having quests that are designed for you never to progress past a certain point without giving you any warning or heads up that going here will ruin the quest-line is absolutely bad game design. It's like they took the quest design of DS1-3 and bloodborne and threw it into an open world setting regardless of whether that particular way of designing quests works for a game as large as Elden Ring. Because that is literally what they did. I say this as a fan and as someone who loves this game and the DLC bosses very dearly. I say this because I want this game to be better, I'm not trying to prove something to myself about how i'm better than other players, I just simply want to have the satisfying gameplay that these games have never failed on before, until at least now.

-Performance.
This right here is the main thing that got me to make the review, everything else I could have easily lived with and still gotten a decent amount of enjoyment from, but this is downright reprehensible for a game of Elden Rings size. I don't know why so many people give this game a pass when it comes to performance. First it was Bloodbornes horrible frame pacing and now it's this DLC that from a technical viewpoint is EMBARRASSING for a AAA company. At the lowest settings I am getting sub 30 frames on an RTX 3060 with a decent CPU. This game is reaching sub 30 on even the PS5 and XBOX Series X performance settings. Literally how is this in any way acceptable. I love this game to bits but jesus christ being able to play it would be nice. I have a good pc and even a console copy but neither of them provide anything I'd call close to an enjoyable performance experience. From-software should be ashamed of releasing this DLC in the state that it's in. Amazing bosses can't outdo the damage that's been done to the core experience of the game. It's embarrassing for it to be this way and for people to defend it as if those rightfully complaining are just poor at the game. Stop excusing bad game design. I want this game to be hard, but this simply breaks the core of what makes soulsbourne games so satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085540551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 8491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7696, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 6538, 'last_played': 1723492420}
review:
I kinda have mixed feelings for this game, I enjoy the new area map the DLC gives, but that's just that, the bosses are really fun and enjoyable. one of the things i wished weren't part of the DLC is the, new artificial attack and defence levelling system, i feel like this levelling system was used in another game i used to play, but it flopped, i forget which game (that's how bad it was). the new system just creates more tedious work for the devs.

Replay ability:
I enjoy games with replay ability, ie Monster Hunter, Mass Effect 1 & 2, but for some reason, this game doesn't give a good feeling replaying it, i have 130 hrs currently on this and on my 2nd play thru with 1 character. I just feel like its a chore to do another play thru, (I get that others will have a different opinion on this, just my take).

 Multiplayer: 
I like multiplayer games as much as anyone, I don't mind getting my steam and IRL friends games so that we can specifically play multiplayer, but FROMSOFT failed at this, why do I or another player need to craft items to play? took me and a friend like 30 mins to set up multiplayer, and we killed 1 boss, and that was it, we played for about 1 hour, and half that time was just trying to connect with each other. if the item used for multiplayer was in an infinite amount, that would be fine, but having to go thru the game world and look for materials to craft it and then play? 

Please FROMSOFT, fix the requirements for playing multiplayer Co-op. (though I understand returning to my characters world after a boss fight)

system requirements: 
I kinda understand the requirements and system being mostly catered to consoles, but i wish PC users had a better "port" or version of the game. I have a rather good system capable of playing in 4K and in Ultra-wide monitor as well, but having half my screen just black and only having 60 FPS is rather really meh, especially with the requirements at the time of release. 

some controls:
the mount "Torrent" is a nice touch since the base game is really big in design and having a faster way of travelling without fast travel is great, but this fails in controls same as MHRS (Monster Hunter Rise: Sunbreak) palamute controls, jank, the turning aspect feels so weird, like it becomes a little bit too rigid, if this makes sense.
lock on controls needs to be fixed a lot better, if there was an enemy right in front of me, and trying to lock onto them, it'll lock onto an enemy that's, half way from the map instead, how does that happen? and when i'm trying to lock onto an enemy a bit far away, it'll lock onto an enemy in my characters peripheral view on the left or right, why does this happen? is the lock on mode targeting centre of the screen? or is it targeting on the left/right of my screen? when do I know if im locking on a close or far enemy? this HUD/UI needs to be a bit clearer.

some stuff I wanna vent: 
Levelling the character stats, is... something I don't like that much, based on other games that have similar levelling system.
if i have to invest in health more than other stats, I don't really like this system, since you can upgrade weapons but not armour is just.... why even have armour and level health....... why can't we upgrade armour to have more defence stats? 
and why is it easier to upgrade some weapons than other weapons? why aren't ranged weapons good? these are questions i want answered, since i'd rather play range than close quarters. (Lemme cosplay as Turok man)

I'm open up to learning some stuff regarding what i said in this review, but unless it's compelling and digestable, i'll probably just finish the DLC then go back to Monster Hunter and other games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198291959145', 'num_games_owned': 56, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1722739236}
review: Bought this game after 5000h Vr gaming and without having played any Soulslike Games before. I must say I'm not very impressed by the way the game tries to stimulate my fun receptors. I seem to miss the fanboy genes. Thought the best rated game might make a difference, but Desktop games don't feel as rewarding as I remember them to be. My honest feelings about this game: Its full of cheap mechanics to stop the players progress. Mostly without proper explaination. Learning by dying. Im not talking about overall difficulty. Repetition is okay. things like the double jump of the horse can't be used to slow down jumps from a height. Thats really lazy programming and I really dislike when devs do cheap sh!t like this. I mean, the horse can jump up to 300m, but can't survive a 8m drop with double jump. Animation on impact looks like monster hunter 2004. That's just lame, get your physics fixed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079798985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 8041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5855, 'last_played': 1721614547}
review:
Tldr: No ultrawide support

It's a fun game. If you're on a 16:9 monitor there is nothing bad to say. One of my most played games on steam.

That being said, I upgraded my monitor to 21:9 this past year. I'm just learning Elden ring doesn't natively support ultrawide resolutions. I'm forced to play 16:9 or play offline in 21:9 with mods. So if you want to play in 21:9. Pirate the game, you won't get online features anyway

author: {'steamid': '76561198198410821', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 40362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 46, 'playtime_at_review': 39294, 'last_played': 1735699183}
review: every single time anyone finds a fun weapon or a fun build, it seems to get nerfed into the ground. which i would understand if it was for PVP or any sort of competition. Nerfing weapons and builds in PVE seems like a slap in the face for the player base who dont enjoy pvp. i dont understand why having an "overpowered build" matters when we pay for the game and play it the way we want. I understand that its supposed to be a "difficult" game but i have beaten this game in every way you can think of: summons, no summons, Only summons, LVL 1, Max lvl, just fists. you name it ive done it. but when there are fun weapons that are strong or op just leave them, players who have PAID for this game should be allowed to use/play with op weapons if they so choose. NERFING PVE IS JUST RIDICULOUS.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067630014', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 34445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21875, 'last_played': 1733400399}
review: Honestly I have to say From software is one of the best studios in the game industry at art, animation, and atmosphere. However, the gameplay has been the almost the exact same for their games for over a decade. Sekiro was a huge step in the right direction, rewarding a more aggressive, in-your-face playstyle and an actually fleshed out narrative. Instead this game is the same roll and light attack spam fest as it was in Dark Souls 3. Bloodborne encouraged an aggressive playstyle as well. Frankly, this game feels a lot like DS3-2 instead of a new game, and it shows with a lot of the same reused animations and enemies. Making the game open world only exacerbates this problem and highlights the monotonous combat further, as the gameplay loop is pretty much the same thing the whole time and this is a long game. There is a huge imbalance in the weapons, and as you get later in the game you tend to rely on the same weapons with the same movesets in order to deal with damage sponges. The bosses in this game and especially the DLC aren't as fun as it could be, as you are almost always forced to be on the defensive and play reactively the whole time. I only wish they put as much effort in the player's moveset as the bosses. I hope From software reinvents their gameplay, as the DS3 style combat is now dated in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071794257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1463, 'last_played': 1706777107}
review:
I get why people say it's an amazing game. In many aspects it is.
However, I don't think it's for any type of player. I am in that category of casual gamers that do not enjoy dying hundreds of times in order to get pitch perfect moves. Often the alternative is a very cheesy way, where it leaves you feeling like you've cheated the game.
I've been playing it for 24h, and the amount of stress and anxiety this game has caused me does not justify it.
Graphics, details, everything else is amazing. But the gameplay/style is just not for me. If they had a more ascendant learning curve it would've been a different story.  But it throws you into the lion cage from the start. 
So far, the main bosses were actually easier for me that some random intermediate NPCs.

author: {'steamid': '76561199147005394', 'num_games_owned': 50, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 931, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1736792530}
review: game sucks when you start from scratch and bs bosses that do an obsurd amount of damage like why the hell is there a misbegotten warrior and crucuble knight just together in a 2v1 unfair and unfun

author: {'steamid': '76561199110221725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 9701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7184, 'last_played': 1723238030}
review:
My problem with this isn't its difficulty, these games have always been tough, especially in early game.  My problem with this DLC is the leveling system.  The DLC scales to your character's current level, and the only way to increase your damage and resistance to enemies is to find a seemingly finite item to level your stats.  This means that if you just cant get past an enemy or a boss you can no longer go grind levels to make yourself stronger and come back better prepared.  Instead you have to go searching for an item in the world, and if you've already found them all well too bad! Now you have to bash your head against a concrete wall till you beat whatever was stopping you... IF you can even beat it.  It's a poorly designed system, that makes defeating enemies feel worthless, since the "currency" they drop does nothing for you.

Its a beautiful game, and it's incredibly fun to explore just like the base game, but holy crap I cant state enough how much I hate this this new leveling system.  This needs a change, somehow.

author: {'steamid': '76561199027624021', 'num_games_owned': 297, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 6891, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2509, 'last_played': 1721413632}
review: Elden Ring is the worst Soulsborne. Open world is boring (reusing bosses and structures), unpleasant to explore and breaks many things that made Soulsborne games good. Most of the bosses are hard in an unfun way. Instead of fast and fun fights, you have bosses ridden with delayed attacks, unexpected combo continuations, etc. Games like DS3 or Sekiro showed that you can make fast, fun and fair bosses that are still hard to beat.

author: {'steamid': '76561199237648013', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 22132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21742, 'last_played': 1734936832}
review:
broken game, doesn't load. ground doesn't appear, SoE isn't working properly and seems to have caused the game issues when moving between graces. switching equipment doesn't show and you may find your weapons are invisible long past being funny.

Old character saves may be locked from progression while anywhere near mogh I have found. Your game may not load past 75% indefinitely, Elden Ring also has issues closing for up to 45 mins.

All in all I used to like this game but as of the release of the SoE I've found it to be subpar and unplayable until these issues I'm having are fixed.

On the bright side the few times I've been able to play I found theyve fixed frame issues of enemies holding torches and such (the particles would occasionally lower the frames of the individual enemies animation causing them to jitter.) while not major it was displeasing to look at.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049255950', 'num_games_owned': 731, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2646, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1719417946}
review:
Still can't believe someone sat down, saw the tight worlds of the Dark Souls games and said: "Okay, but what if the world was really empty and boring, so we could waste our players time."

Waiter, more repeat bosses and empty caves that all look the same, please.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008609849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 23970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20727, 'last_played': 1720113852}
review:
Stop complaining about the difficulty of the game. The problem with the game isn't that it's difficult, it's that the combat design is crap.
 V Rising Brutal Mode is a difficult game, I spent 6 hours fighting Adam. On Malenia I spent 3 hours without a single cheeze. And Malenia's combat design is rubbish, while Adam's combat design is fucking awesome.
Malenia's waterfall is impossible to figure out where to hit box damage, in phase 2 another attack like that is added, the whole difficulty of which is that you can't see where or how the damage will be dealt. The boss just jumps on your screen throwing various hit box damage, to which you have only one answer - the dodge button. Of course you can throw a freeze bomb at it, you can summon a mimic, friend, brother, LetMySoloHer and so on. But none of that cancels out the bad design. 
In V Rising I didn't need any guides or help from friends, just honest reactions and knowledge of mechanics that the game doesn't hide from you.

author: {'steamid': '76561199093657360', 'num_games_owned': 57, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 11600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11327, 'last_played': 1719286746}
review: This game isnt good. Making things annoying isnt making the game hard. A rat should hit harder than a dragons breathe. Multiple Bugs and crashes. Almost one of the worst multiplayer experiences to deal with. So many reused assets. FInal boss isnt new. New weapons and armor are mid. Shadowlands.....More like empty lands. Back and fourth through tedious geographical puzzles

author: {'steamid': '76561198030006843', 'num_games_owned': 22, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5240, 'last_played': 1726760165}
review:
First things first. I'm a big fan of Dark Souls series and Elden Ring appeared to be Dark Souls 2 in the open world for me. It's fun how people hate DS2 and admire ER, utterly escaping the fact that the two games have much in common. ER has 238 bosses against 41 bosses of DS2. Also, here you will meet hoards of mobs and dogs at every corner. Stonesword key instead of Pharros lockstone. Both games describe the destruction of the kingdom and depict the protagonist as the chosen lord who must sit on a throne. ER even has its own Fume Knight - Draconic Tree Sentinel, an extremely over-leveled, broken boss whose duty is to kill ANY player at ANY level with 2-3 strikes. After the appearance of Yui Tanimura as a co-director in titles everything made sense to me. So I definitely don't understand the gamers who hate DS2, playing the same game in a new setting and saying that it's a masterpiece.

Here I'll try to explain step by step, why I don't like ER anymore and why it makes me sad.

1) Level design is the strongest part of the game and its first problem. ER isn't DS. Except well-made castles game contains a variety of fields, desolations, and woods. All the characters I met were spread across The Lands Between. Example Nepheli Loux. I met her in Stormveil Castle, then in Roundtable Hold, and then purely accidental in Village of the Albinaurics... Why? Level designers seriously though that players will visit that big stinky cavern in Liurnia first instead of Academy or Capital? The same formula worked well in the location-based games. In the open world idea of putting the quest characters in random places is stupid! The same situation is with Alexander, an amazing character with the saddest plotline. I met him at the Radahn Festival and, thanks to Wiki, got that he can be found at the beginning of the game. After The Festival Alexander was placed in the lake of lava, far away from any road at the edge of the map! Some characters, like Millicent, after saving stand in the wild with no reason to be there and without any chance to find them. 
 
2) I didn't get the story itself. In the beginning, I met many characters. To know who is who, I read Elden Wiki. Hidetaka Miyazaki and George R. R. Martin did a magnificent job describing the history of the world. It looks great... in the text. In the game, Miyazaki did his best to destroy it with maximum disrespect. The absence of information is his strongest point! All characters remind me hard trained spies whose duty is to keep the information as best as possible; other NPS complain about something, giving info in an extremely dosed way; some heroes disappear for half of the game; another talking nonsense (my personal choice of dislike is Finger Reader Crones). A small number of in-game lore books might solve the problem. The expanded dialog window with NPS could also grant us some information. I mean it's an alternate reality game where we know nothing about the story of the world and its disasters in the beginning! 

3) Bosses. This is the biggest problem of ER. They are the soul of the souls games. Fighting with them is frustrating. I've heard many opinions about excellent combat mechanics, but behind this "excellence" hides the stupid idea of using combo attacks with input delay. Would you imagine, Morgott is able to jump and stop in the air for a second before strike! That's not fair and utterly ridiculous. Seeing "the fog wall", I knew that a new boss with the delayed attack was waiting there, and I must circle around him until learned all of his delayed movesets. It's similar to "double clicking" option in DS2. The parry is also broken. Instead of one parry player must parry twice against the strongest bosses. Why? Of course to make the dull fight longer. This is artificial difficulty and many enemies became annoying obstacles.

4) Crafting. There are so-o-o many in-game cookbooks that you can easily layout and print them to make a real-life book. In ER you will know how to craft items with tens of berries, flowers, fungus, insects, sprouts, liver, meat, bones, feathers, etc. Yes, this is what I expect when starting "souls game". I want to play Cooking Simulator! Give us more! Litter our inventory sack, so we try to find a rare useful item a little longer. Some of those crafted items are useful, like greases, others pointless trash (throwing pots, darts and daggers, soft cotton, even arrows). Rainbow stones - utterly useless item for we have Torrent in the field and the messages in the dungeons. ER is not Morrowind. This tinsel makes no use after leaving Stormveil Castle. Face it, all players are eager to find weapon equipment, armor, smithing stones or scrolls, not another bunch of berries!

4) Imitation of the living world. Is this supposed to be alive or dead? Mobs patrol the streets and ramparts, sometimes even clashing each other. Thank you for creating animals in the wild. So this world is definitely alive. Right? Then why do soldiers in Castle Morne look like undead from DS, but Warden Edgar looks normal? Why is Leyndell covered with the bodies and the royal knights walk the streets like it's an ordinary day? If this is an effect of The Scarlet rot, then how did it spread beyond Caelid region? Maybe The Shattering and destruction of The Golden Order caused this effect? According to wiki this order is a set of beliefs and The Shattering is a destructive civil war. Let's make it clear, The Lands Between are not dying, they were devastated by war. It seems Miyazaki was in need of another horde of undead mobs to copy Dark Souls. And, yes, magic explains everything.

5) Farum Azula. It is the worst location ever with the most confusing and horrible design. Hanging in the sky temple full of overleveled enemies, undead creatures with the ability to resurrect themselves. This is the traditional formula of Yui Tanimura: add as many enemies as possible and make them twice as strong as General Radahn, make the player run long distances again and again, add Dragon-boss who is able to oneshot you with lightning. This is what I wish to see after the breathtaking ending in the Mountaintops of the Giants. How did a hero appear there? Why I should waste my time jumping from platform to platform surrounded by enemies and archers and then jumping over the arena in try to get Beast Clergyman? The answer is to make gameplay longer and keep me away from the main plotline. 

So why did I stop playing? The answer is the bosses. They are boring. Beast Clergyman of Farum Azula was the final straw. It is sick when you enter into the fight and think not about the fight itself, but calculating how long will it take to press the dodge button before a delayed strike. Btw, the character's rolling and attacking input are also delayed by about 0.100s. All this makes the game dull math homework. It's fine when you meet 5-6 enemies behaving like this, but in ED 90% of bosses have delayed attacks. They are not difficult, they are annoying and the fight with them is time-taking. Moreover, I don't want to fight for the world I don't understand or interact with the characters who speak in riddles like the oracles. I would like to spend more time with Melina or Ranni, but the first girl appears at will and fights with me only once, while the second disappeared after her first introduction.

My verdict, Miyazaki became too lazy. Elden Ring is his worst creation, full of blank patches. I better go and play Dark Souls 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067950534', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 16802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15047, 'last_played': 1720382199}
review:
If there was ever a neutral rating this game would be it. 

One thing From Software does well is create interesting and well designed levels. Similar to the games that came before it the 'legacy dungeons' in this game are great. Thoughtful level design, secrets to find, good enemy placement, among other positives.  Excellent environments, etc. Which is why it's confusing to me that these dungeons are such a small part of the game. Instead the majority of the game will be spent outside of these areas in the large open world.

The vast majority of the open world will just be the same scattered nodes you can harvest for crafting materials coupled with uninteresting wildlife that can also be killed for crafting ingredients. In between you'll find various dungeons and crypts that all manage to feel similar to one another under a certain archetype. The mines look like mines. The crypts look like crypts. The caves look like caves. It brings me back to The Elderscrolls: Oblivion where Bethesda created like 10 or 20 generic tile sets per area and recycled these assets in different configurations to make different layouts for a dungeon that by the end of the journey you'll have seen dozens of times. If you've seen one crypt you'll have seen the same wall and floor designs dozens and dozens of times. Not to mention that the enemies are almost always the same as well.

Speaking of enemies.. Elden Ring has the largest number of unique enemies in any of the 'Soulslike' games. Yet when you play the game you will be continually disappointed when it feels like you're bumping into the same enemies over and over again. When it comes to bosses this is particularly annoying. The game subjects you to the same Ulcerated Tree Spirit boss like 10 times over the course of the game. Not to mention they even added these to the DLC. If anything they might slightly change the color palate of these enemies but ultimately it's the same boss patterns over and over again. On a positive note the one-of bosses are great. Those typically found in legacy dungeons, but sometimes out in the open world.  Additionally the weapons and combat feel as great as you'd expect.

I just think the open world design is what really holds back this game. The world feels much less like a tree with branching paths and more like an open field with various things you bump into here or there. The game has a lot of seeing something up on a cliff, or down in a valley, and having no idea how to get there. It could be any one of the various caves that will bring you out to the location you wanted to be. The vertical level design in that sense feels very flawed. I think this could have been helped with the various merchants around the game selling map markers or having them draw on your map to show connecting points. 

While I could get into the nittygritty about every little detail of what I liked and didn't like my ultimate feeling about the game is that it fell below my expectations. I'm a huge fan of the previous entries having started right from when the formula was really introduced with Demon's Souls. I hope that the next entries will return to the more handcrafted level design that we've known and loved out of From Software's games. If the future is open world game design running around to pointless feeling copy/paste dungeons, I'm out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198218316741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 220, 'playtime_forever': 1623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1721757801}
review:
Elden Ring is the weakest Fromsoft Souls game to date, and the cracks in the intrinsic design are showing fiercely. Souls games have never had deep combat comparatively to any other action game like Ninja Gaiden, Sifu, Devil May Cry, or even Sekiro from their own catalogue, but the issues which could be glossed over due to dense deeply lore rich worlds with tight enemy design and a cyclical world that loops round with satisfying shortcuts....can't anymore with Elden Ring. 

For starters, Elden Ring's open world is anathema to the tight Fromsoft design I'm used to: the dungeons come across as slightly better Chalice Dungeons from Bloodborne, and whilst there was a lot of novelty to them in Bloodborne, when you make so many, and litter so many with reoccurring bosses, whilst approaching them with a lego-like design, they become tedious, uninteresting, and vapid. If you want an example of modular dungeon design stretched across an open world then I'd argue Breath of the Wild handles it better because each Shrine (dungeon) is pithy, with a unique engaging puzzle that has a variety of methods to deal with it via the sandbox tools you've been given. It's not perfect...but it's a lot better than this slop.

I can list so many bosses off the top of my head from prior games that had interesting designs, and somewhat engaging mechanics, but most of all, they emotionally meant something to me. Sorry but stone cat no.6 isn't hitting me in the feels. Almost none of the bosses in this game do, and for those that do? By golly it's not even close to the older titles. To make a Fromsoft game with the tightness of design from prior series with such an open world would take years upon years, and a ballooning budget approaching Star Citizen. It cannot be done, and it absolutely shouldn't be attempted. At least if you want tightly constructed encounters with engaging thoughtful environmental storytelling, and solid boss fights with heavy emotional impact. The world is stretched too thinly....like butter...over too much bread.

Souls combat also gets stretched to its uppermost limits.....and it's not well designed. There aren't many ways to increase the difficulty of a boss in a Souls game. The route From have taken is, broadly, to add severe feints and delays to attacks, whilst increasing the frequency of them, whilst upping the quantity of AoE attacks: to understand my frustration, this isn't 'git gud'. I can route memorise bosses; I've played enough action games and Souls games to be good at that by now. The issue stems from how almost no attack animation can be trusted now. Not only does this look daft, removing gravity and inertia from many attacks and making the weapons look as if they have wildly different weights between moves, but it starts to force route memorisation where the only engagement I'm having with the boss is tedious pattern recognition. Fathom a real sword fight where a dude cartoonishly reals back a swing for three seconds, and then stabs......no. Just no. The community have collectively gaslit themselves into thinking this is acceptable after everyone lashed back at From. 

Now, with regard to AoE attacks, I'm glad they - theoretically - force the player to think about how to alternatively dodge attacks. Of course Sekiro overtly does this better, with far better telegraphing and move readability, but that's besides the point. Whilst this *is* slightly deeper, this alternative dodging mechanism is never telegraphed particularly in the game, and I can't think of a place where it's more naturally taught to the player, so I can't blame anybody with less action game experience for not considering it an option. From players that have played Sekiro might, but....it's a Souls game they'll go back to 'Roll Roll R1 Roll'. You need to break players from that habit, and the best way is teaching it: but they don't! Additionally, AoEs are chock-full of blasted particle effects which block player vision, and make the battlefield less readable. From this is an action game: telegraph attacks, and ensure attack readability. If I'm dodging things I can't see purely because of route memorisation....then sure you've succeeded at Simon-Says rather than interesting mechanically deep encounters. Though at this point I'd rather pull out my discus with four coloured buttons on it and play Simon-Says.

Then there's horse combat.....it looks silly and goofy. The camera can't keep up with it and you don't have the mechanical depth to make it engaging. And jeepers.....that one boss? I'm sorry he looks bloody ridiculous. You all know he looks bloody ridiculous. I don't care if there's an insane lore reason to justify it: it's bloody ridiculous, and makes the boss a laughing stock without an ounce of intimidation. Though....'loathsome dung eater' comes in a very close second there.

Furthermore, the horse trashes a variety of other things in Elden Ring: firstly, it ruins the open world; because you can travel faster and further than ever before, From had to ensure areas were vast open spaces which spread the content even further than before, and demanded a variety of filler content or items to fill the void. This mitigates my investment in each item, as the vast majority are throwaway items I'll be button mashing to pick up quickly as a mild distraction on my way from A to B. In prior games, I always considered why things were where they lay, and what significance they had in the world. To this day I remember finding the Ring of Great Strength in Demons' Souls, and suddenly getting a flash of inspiration for why it was there from context clues and bits of lore I pieced together in the game. It begs the player to consider the world as real and alive, and immerses them by asking them to theorise. Elden Ring doesn't....lack this, but when I'm mashing a button to pick up the vast majority of items, I don't have the investment to wonder why random sword No.3 is by this tree, nor do I care to look through such a quantity of item descriptions. In prior games you couldn't move this fast, and so it shrunk the speed of traversal, and gave you higher density, with a smaller item pool to become invested in, whereas this game incentivises me to mash to pick up random crafting ingredient no.45. The rare times this game has smaller more considered areas like the prior titles, my horse incentivises me to trivialise them, bulldosering through to grab all the items, light all the tears, and then pop off to the next area. Very few enemies can pose a threat when you utilise the horse.

Well, how about platforming with the horse? Do any of you remember Skyrim'ing up cliffs with a horse? Well, it's the same. Janky, needlessly finicky, and especially confudelling when you gave players a jump button. Don't make me jank my way down a stone brick wall on a horse, cuddling the crevices From....it's not fun or engaging, it's a hassle, and it looks downright daft, rather like the horse combat.

Then there's the bonfires....oooh the bonfires. Do you remember the heightened fear you once had as you scourerd for a bonfire in unfamiliar territory, only to feel the wash of relief as you lit it and restored your estus? That fury as you charted the best way to get to a boss for another go, or the shortcuts you could unlock to make traversal a little less arduous? Fromsoft don't...Removing the thematic relevance of a bonfire within the Souls series for a second, the bonfire, alone, is the epitomy symbol of explorers: they're the warm glowing source of refuge a weary explorer lights after a hard day, letting them relax to the spit and crackle of flames as they drift off into sleep. It keeps animals at bay around them, and grants them respite. Sites of Grace look like a bit of glowing lint on my monitor. Their design is plain, they're copiously littered throughout the world, and all I do is run from tear to tear to trivialise the world even faster than my horse can.

- continued in the comments because word count!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198103487651', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 3137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2344, 'last_played': 1734810471}
review:
I really wanted to love this game but honestly I just cannot recommend it. The game is so glaringly unfinished, unpolished, and in many cases, seemingly designed specifically to waste the player's time. Quality of life features that have been standard in every game for the last 20 years are entirely absent. Core mechanics simply do not work as intended or at all. For every brilliant game design element of this game there is another or two that are just irritating beyond words. The game offers so much to enjoy but it suffers from death by a thousand cuts.

The following is a list of issues I can recall off the top of my head at the time of writing:

The game has no brightness slider. It's an exceptionally dark game even in the daytime, and I find it very difficult to see what's going on in indoor locations if there is any ambient light in the room while I'm playing.

The map, while aesthetically beautiful, is a nightmare to interact with. The player icon is much too large and obscures nearby details. Furthermore there is no button to directly open the map, and instead you must open the menu, switch over several tabs, then hit another button before you can even begin to interact with it. That adds up to several minutes of wasted menu navigation every play session because you will need to consult the map every 30 seconds while attempting to locate anything. The game does have the standard horizontal map bar on the HUD, but it's much too small to be particularly useful on any larger display, and the icons do not include vertical indicators, which is unfortunate because your intended target is frequently an NPC somewhere inside a 3 story building. 

There is no mechanism to allow faster, larger selection of number of items when moving inventory. Trying to put 10,000 currency in a chest? Well you're going to sit there and watch it slowly tick by 100 because there's no button to move in larger increments.

You have approximately 20 armor and clothing slots in this game, which is realistic and I do appreciate, but there is no way to sort your inventory by what body part equipment belongs to. You can however sort them alphabetically, which is useful to exactly no one. If you already know what a porpoint, a cotehardie, a jupon, and a waffenrock are, then you're golden. Everyone else will spend a lot of time waffling around the inventory.

The game uses an archaic consumable-based save system. Which means you must either go through an alchemy minigame to craft your own or constantly buy more, the latter of which is cost prohibitive early game. In either case the game simply creates busy work around saving, which contributes nothing to gameplay or immersion and is not fun. Furthermore, the game has limited save slots but does not allow you to choose which file to save over when saving, instead creating a new save every time you do so. This results in needing to occasionally manually delete 50 saves in order to make room for new ones.

Several important quests in game are timed, yet the game gives you no indication this is the case, no concept of how long you might have to do them, and also will not inform you that you've exceeded the time limit until after you've completed them or attempted to turn in some step. This is one of a handful of components of the game that purists may argue is technically "realistic" and therefore somehow fine and forgivable, but from a gameplay perspective is simply cruel and a significant waste of the player's time and effort.

You will frequently be outnumbered in combat, sometimes very unexpectedly so, and because of the game's realistic approach to combat, that means you will quickly die with no recourse unless you find a way to cheese the AI or you manage to run away, neither of which amount to fun or satisfying gameplay.   

The devs presumably played Elder Scrolls games and were understandably turned off at how easy it was to hop and skip up steep slopes and circumnavigate intended routes. So they remedied this by going completely the opposite direction and made even the smallest pebble an insurmountable obstacle for the player character. If you ever try to engage in combat anywhere near rough terrain you WILL get caught on everything.

Many of the game's realism elements only apply to the player character. You are required to get sleep and can only use rented or owned beds to do so without the risk of being awoken and charged with trespassing or murdered by bandits. Yet many quests take the player far away from towns or inns, requiring you to waste large amounts of time riding back to a viable place to sleep while the other NPCs joining you on said quest will stand like statues all night. Additionally, many of the large towns have a law against moving at night without a torch, but many NPCs wander the streets without one. I have on two separate occasions fast traveled to a city and made an immediate beeline to my sleeping quarters only to then be awoken in the middle of the night by a guard who is charging me with walking the streets at night without a torch. While he is standing over me in my bed indoors. 

While I do not take issue with the core approach to the game's combat in the way many others apparently do, there are still elements of it that just don't work. Many of the shorter weapons will just fail to hit the opponent even when executing a perfect counterattack because they lack the reach. So you will watch a small animation of yourself parrying a blow and striking the air in front of your opponent. Also halberds flat out don't work and weren't programmed. Like, they just didn't bother to finish implementing them, so while they exist in game and can be equipped, they cannot be put away like other weapons, they can't be stowed on your horse, and they can't be sold. They're just broken.

The game is defined as an RPG, yet the skill point system is barebones and doesn't really allow for any sort of customizability or differing playstyles. You will gradually become a jack of all trades regardless of how you want to play. If you max the level of a particular skill you can generally acquire every perk, or all but one perk, with the exception of the handful of skills that are explicitly mutually exclusive. Yet none of them make an appreciable difference in gameplay outside a small number of passive combat oriented perks. Also, there are tons of unlockable weapon combos all of which are entirely useless because they require between three and five uninterrupted specific strikes to execute, and any enemy in the game who poses any sort of threat to you will be proficient enough to counter the first or second strike you make at all times. Fighting higher level enemies essentially demands that you never strike first but instead try to counter, which is a separate skill not even acquired through the leveling system.  

You will spend a lot of time just standing around waiting for things to happen. The sun rises at 5am yet in this medieval world everyone seems to adhere to modern sensibilities and sleeps in until 8 and stores don't open until even later than that. The game is effectively too dark to play when the sun is not up and the darkness lasts for a good 9 hours, yet you only ever need about 5 hours of sleep to restore your energy to maximum, so you will frequently go to sleep when the sun sets and then immediately use the wait function to pass another 4 hours after waking because there's nothing to do other than fast travel so early in the morning.
  
I feel an inexplicable compulsion to return to this game day after day yet I cannot ignore the fact that approximately 50% of my play sessions end because I am annoyed with the game and/or I've just lost half an hour of progress because the game ambushed me with 6 fully armored bandits and a dog while attempting to fast travel. Perhaps I'm some sort of secret masochist but in any case I could not truthfully tell anyone that I think this game is worth buying and playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039980994', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 1930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1930, 'last_played': 1722713318}
review:
The game by all rights is amazing in every category.....except combat. This game still has probably the worst combat system ever put down in a video game ever. And not because it's "hard" or "realistic", it's neither of those things, it's just badly designed on so many levels and broken. 

You have archery and crossbows which make you a god that just murders everything without trying. Boss fights that are easier than fighting a peasant because they don't wear closed face helmets so you just stab in face. The combat system is clearly designed for 1v1 duels, but 90% of the game has you fighting groups of enemies. The combo system is convoluted and janky and just face stab is more effective 99% of the time. Enemies needing to be winded to be beat just ends up with you always on the attack when fighting groups, which winds you. And they just constantly block and dodge perfectly. 

There's just so much wrong with the combat system on a fundamental level and it's a huge part of the game, that I just can't recommend it. This is also the MOST complained about thing on the internet about this game. It's amazing in every other aspect, but the combat never gets better, it never gets fun, it's just tedious, broken, and a slog the entire game. Hopefully they learned and took feedback and KCD2 has a reworked system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064679803', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 3640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 746, 'playtime_at_review': 3640, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1736399605}
review:
This has been on my backlog for a long while, and now with KCD2 release drawing near I finally decided to give it a go.

I was trying very hard to enjoy this game, and I can't say it's all bad, it definitely has its moments, but it also has so many broken mechanics and bugs, and they are so annoying to deal with, that in good conscience I can not recommend this game. 

And before you dismiss me as yet another casual player, let me tell you this: I'm a history nerd, I was one of the very first bakers of this game on Kickstarter, and I was absolutely willing to make sacrifices for the sake of immersion, to live this fantasy of a medieval lay person, playing along with the game where it asks me to achieve this goal.

But I couldn't. For all the fans talk "Don't expect Skyrim!" this game is literally a TES clone with some "realistic" mechanics and pet ideas sprinkled on top, with very little attempt to innovate on the core of the Skyrim formula. It isn't nearly as immersive as the fanbase would want you to believe, despite all the official "realism" dogma surrounding it. A lot of mechanics seems to be frustrating for the sake of being frustrating, contributing nothing to the touted immersion. Sometimes it even feels like the game deliberately (o, heresy!) abandons realism where being realistic would make it less tedious and annoying.

For instance, when you gear breaks down, you can't fix it all in one place. Your tunic, helmet and shoes all need to be fixed by different people, which takes a lot of running around. Well, I hear you say, this is realistic, right? Cobbler shouldn't be able to fix your breastplate? Ok, but then why does my gear breaks down in like, couple in-game days? Shouldn't it last, say, an in-game month, at least? See, now this type of realism the game doesn't like, the type that makes your life easy. 

There's just so many weird decisions like this, like why doesn't the bow have a reticle? The game has no problem giving you UI, you have a dot in the middle in the exploration mode, you have 5-star hit direction indicator during melee fights, you even have a blatantly anti-medieval magic GPS map! And the bow reticle is where you draw the line? Seriously?

Saving the game takes a consumable that's limited and expensive, heavily discouraging frequent saves. And you know what, I understand the idea behind it. Don't save scam, let disasters play out, live by your choices, all the noble goals. But it simply doesn't work here! For a subtle reason: the game has to be designed around this mechanic, and this one just isn't! If things go wrong, most of the time the ONLY recourse is to reload an old save, there's almost never a plan B. You fast travel and get ambushed by unbeatable unescapable gang of bandits? Reload. You picked a wrong dialog option in a main quest and got attacked by 5 people standing around you, with your sword sheathed? Reload. You got arrested, and failed a timed quest while sitting in a jail? Reload. You barely scraped a few grosses for 1 lockpick in a scripted quest sequence and it got broken? Probably reload. Dozens of other examples. Each reload can easily put you an hour behind in progress. This is the opposite of being immersive, breaks the flow and pulls you out of the experience.

I can go on about things that just don't allow me to enjoy it. They hit me every minute, every time I try to play it. This is why it's so hard to write a short review for this game. If I try to list a few examples of things that don't work, are poorly designed or just buggy, it will sound like I'm nitpicking. Almost none of these things are a deal-breaker individually, but the sheer amount of them is a bigger problem. 

There're bugs, not just random animation glitches, but legit game braking issues that force you to reload the previous save. Inconsistent immersion-wrecking dialog options are rather common, both in side and main quests. People knowing something they really shouldn't, because you haven't told them yet, or vise versa, you having a dialog option commenting on something they haven't mentioned yet, or them repeating the same thing in different sentences as if two possible branches of the quest somehow merged together, or you completing a quest and the quest giver says something implying very different circumstances of how you picked up the quest, and so forth. The quest's logic itself is often fragile and sometimes if you stray slightly off the expected order of things, things fall apart so easily. Again, I'm struggling to list all individual issues, they're just so abundant. 

Navigating the world isn't smooth either: if you stray off trails you'll get stuck in the smallest of obstacles, bushes, tiny streams, etc. There's a lot of janky interactions between various game systems. E.g. a soldier which is part of the quest trying to arrest you, and then carrying on with their quest lines with a different voice and tone. In another quest I fought a guy, and there was a scripted scene where he cried and begged for mercy, asking not to call for guards. I spared him, and the next second accidentally pressed "pickpocket" on him, after which he screamed at me "you criminal scum! guard!".

Sometimes you may run around the city and not realize a guard wants to frisk you, you ignore him, while doing your business, only to realize a minute later there's a small army of guards now trying to legit *murder* you without even giving you a chance to explain yourself. In one city you're supposed to carry a torch at night, and if you happen to fast travel through this city and the night comes in, you may get arrested during fast travel! There's just so much absurdity like this, I didn't even scratch the surface of it, you will hit it all the time. All of that is such a massive immersion breaker. 

To be fair to the game, I also want to name a few things that kept me playing despite all of the negatives. 

Historicity. I like it. Some cities, churches, buildings are like virtual interactive museums. In-game articles on medieval history, although a bit dry, still pretty interesting. Realistically scaled world. Sprawling forests, you can get lost in and feel very remote. Pitch-black nights. Story... Some parts of it, the parts where it feels personal and true to history and societal structures of the day. I didn't mind the fact you die so easily in a group combat, this is a realism bit I can live with. The game never forced me to fight group fights in all of my playthrough. I don't mind eating and sleeping, although for some reason very few spots are available to sleep at night (e.g. you can't sleep in a barn in a haystack which are so abundant in the world and is such a natural place to crash into).

Anyway, this game has (had?) a lot of potential, but it feels like the team just didn't have enough experience to build something of this magnitude. A lot of weird game design choices and so many bugs to this day (6 years after the release!) ruined what could've been a really nice experience. Also, it feels weird to say this, but it's not the most immersive game by far that lets you live a day in a medieval world. It's just a stripped down TES clone with bunch of annoying mechanics and bugs. And it doesn't become more immersive just because you're hit with a 'hunger' debuff every 15 minutes, which you clear by double-clicking a sausage in your inventory. Nope, it's still a TES-style RPG full with the typical unrealistic conventions of the genre. It’s no more immersive than most, but it’s definitely a lot more frustrating.

The game developers and PR people truly have done a remarkable job to chalk up all the game problems to "realism", and present them like some sort of unique feature for a few connoisseurs who will "understand it". But I tell you what - time for hard truths, folks! - you don't have to be so frustrating and tedious to be immersive, realistic and true to history! You really don't. Let's hope KCD2 will be better than this.

author: {'steamid': '76561199496679416', 'num_games_owned': 84, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 6666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2515, 'playtime_at_review': 1373, 'last_played': 1736825868}
review:
I really wanted to continue playing this as the graphics, the world,the story and realism are top notch, but god almighty is the combat dreadful, you can't fight more than one enemy at a time or you get wrecked even full plate, because guess what, when you take damage you lose health AND stamina which means no attacking or dodging, so you are forced to use archery and stay on horse most of the time or stealth killing.

Again, I really wanted to enjoy this but I cannot for the life of me enjoy the combat and how awful the aiming mechanic as i cannot block or evade even if I press the right direction, I almost smashed my keyboard because of the frustration, but i guess it was fun for 6$.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075460227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5803, 'last_played': 1720154655}
review:
Despite having invested 96 hours into the game, my overall experience is mixed, leaning towards negative. My attempt to finish the game in preparation for the sequel highlighted the persistent issues that ruin the experience. Although I advanced further and found some enjoyment, it often felt like a chore to progress through the main story. [spoiler] The realization that the siege mission was not the final task, but another extensive fetch quest, was particularly disheartening. Similarly, the night raid mission, which I meticulously prepared for in stealth, turned out to be a predetermined sequence where stealth was not an option, undermining my efforts. [/spoiler]

The game suffers from a lackluster story and frustrating gameplay mechanics. While the narrative has interesting elements, it is frequently interrupted by tedious tasks, such as real-time following of NPCs walking, like the drawn-out walk with Sir Hans Capon to the hunting area or trailing your assistant in Pribyslavitz during construction tasks. These prolonged periods of inactivity disrupt the flow and engagement, especially when they extend beyond 5+ minutes, which is completely egregious to me, literally worse than doing nothing, following an NPC with no dialogue.

The combat system, a critical aspect of the game, is particularly unenjoyable. Victory in combat is determined more by your character's skill level than by actual player skill or strategy. Perfect parries are the key to success, making direct attacks risky and often counterproductive. This binary combat system, where you either overpower your opponents effortlessly or are doomed to fail without grinding, removes any semblance of tactical depth or player agency. Again, the absolute slog of combat of literally just standing there wanting to attack or risking it just to get perfect parried, or risking a clinch just to clip into the enemy so they beat you 68 times while you cannot resist in any way, until you eventually commit to never attacking and exclusively parrying, and then you easily win every fight without any challenge and there is now even less weight to your victories.

Kingdom Come: Deliverance excels in its ambitious scope and historical accuracy, providing a visually and contextually rich experience. However, the story's pacing, repetitive and monotonous tasks, and a flawed combat system significantly detract from the overall enjoyment. While the foundation and systems hold promise, the execution falls short, making the game more of a slog than a thrilling adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966360931', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2574, 'last_played': 1719359279}
review:
It's really to say I don't recommend KCD.

I love the graphics, the setting, the characters, and a lot of the game systems.

But I have to say even after two attempts at playing through the game, I'm giving up again due to the combat. Now, I know you can find a TON of discussion that amounts to go practice with Captain Bernard and git gud. What is rarely mentioned is that when this game released, the play base complained so much that the combat was too easy that the devs went in and made a lot of changes to make it more difficult. This means that it is likely that you'll hit a wall of combat in some mission that will essentially be impossible to beat without going and literally training for a lengthy amount of time to just be able to use the combat system.

Now I KNOW there are people reading this review screaming 'GIT GUD! GIT GUD! GIT GUD!', and I get it.

But for me, it's not worth the time. Look, I banged my head against Malenia for hours, but when I finally beat her I felt as if I had, at least in some small way, gotten gudder. However, I don't get that feeling when I complete a difficult combat in KCD. I get the feeling of relief that it's over and I can finally just move on.

Totally possible that it'll click with you, it obviously does with a lot of people. But for me, the combat is just so bad that it's a hard pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052449433', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1361, 'last_played': 1721943806}
review:
The only thing this game has going for it is the story and the realistic medieval times approach. Realistic as far as armor, weapons, clothing, etc.

BUT this cancer has the worst, most broken, mechanics I have ever witnessed.

1. COMBAT - Holy **** the auto lock is HORRENDOUS.  God have pity on your soul if you must fight more than one person at a time.  The only way to switch locked targets is moving your mouse, which is also how you choose where to swing your attacks from. Therefore you just get locked into one of your targets while the others sprint spin circles around you. Half the time as one sprints circles around you he will take that target lock and cause you to have a brain aneurysm whilst trying to even see straight without your camera attempting an uncontrollable 900 degree spin.  And once you are able to see straight without vomiting you'll click to perform a strike and Henry literally just stands there because the input registration is non existent. "Press F to knock out (assassinate)" lol presses F 10 times and nothing triggers except my anger issues and the combatant turning around to give away my position to the rest of the 8 guys.  As a whole, combat is the worst thing about this game, and the worst mechanical implementation of any game ever in the history of gamers gaming games.

2. GRAPHICS - meh... literally just, meh.  Character mesh clipping is worse than Skyrim mods.  Wearing a shirt with a low cut collar? Half your neck and clavicles are invisible.  Equip a hood, literally a clothing piece called a hood, nah... hood is permanently down essentially giving you a glorified scarf.  Environment from a stand-back view looks good, not great.  Look any closer to the details and you feel like you're watching a 1956 episode of Gumby.

3. MESHES / COLLISION - Realism sooo realistic that a 1 inch diameter stick prevents you from just walking.  And to make it worse, you can't even jump over it. Bushes? Impenetrable. Creeks with a knee-high bank? Try vaulting and you clip right back into the creek. A 1-foot rock, go around it because you aint walking or jumping over it.  I don't understand how a developer company could fuck up collisions so bad.

Get this game on a MASSIVE sale at your own risk. DO NOT buy this one full price.  And if you grabbed it on sale, get mods. IMMEDIATELY download mods to help ever so slightly correct the the intern quality coding. And if all else fails, download WeMod and just straight up cheat.  The originality and style of this one is awesome, but they didn't even come close to falling short at the least.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083019629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 3772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3631, 'last_played': 1726859938}
review:
It's really hard to recommend this game.

First few hours of play through you're actually impressed and immersed. Game seems really complex and deep. But few more hours in and this feeling washes away and a dread creeps in: maybe it's not complex but simply overcomplicated. The world that felt immersive at first is actually really static. It became apparent that the combat system is not that deep but simply hard, due to unintuitive controls and lack of proper feedback. And archery.., oh man, it's truly "realistic". 

It feels like it was a design decision to waste your time in many places. Alchemy is "cool" for first few tries. But hell if I'm going to waster half an hour just to make 10 potions. And then there's wait/sleep where the last hour ticks like 10 times slower on purpose. Why? And in order to do actions that you are expected to perform regularly, like ordering a bed in an inn you're forced to waste half a minute of dialogue. All those unnecessary animations. Yeah, there's Esc button, which makes this game an Esc button bashing simulator at times.

Then there are random encounters that you can't avoid. Moreover, maybe it's a bug but there are places where you get ambushed, kill all bandits, run a hundred meters ahead, get back just to be ambushed again. And this repeats constantly. Or moving down a road, forgetting something, turning around, running ten meters and bam! an ambush with a tree blocking a road that wasn't there just a minute ago. 

Most missions force you to run around the map along the same, exact static world. Yeah, there is a fast travel system. Only it wastes literally half a day on a trip that yo make in 30min of game world time. With an additional bonus: you can't avoid ambushes when fast travelling. While on a horse you can travel manually avoiding roads and never risking getting jumped by bandits.

Aaah, nights. Nights are make so dark on purpose that you're literally unable to travel even along the roads. It's as if in the middle ages the moon wasn't invented yet and people never travelled after sunset. Better yet, bandits have some perfect night vision and able to simply track you by smell.

The save system is actually cool. I would like it, however the everything said above makes it a chore. Did something important, got some good loot? Run for a bed immediately, simply to save the progress. Because at any corner you can be ambushed by two guys: one in front of you, blocking and one behind you bashing the hell out of you. And the "super intuitive" controls of a "deep" combat system won't even allow you to easily turn around or run away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021068443', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2208, 'last_played': 1724687563}
review:
Game requires you to run back and forth through the same areas repeatedly. When fast travelling there's a chance you will unavoidably start an encounter by being thrown from your horse and beaten to death by multiple enemies. 

No way to avoid being unhorsed.

No chance to talk your way out of it. 

No chance to run (enemies in heavy armour with shields are faster than you with weapons sheathed and light armour). 

Realism at the expense of choice is missing the point of making a role playing game. Just have Henry die of dysentery in the opening act if you want him to die so badly. 

I want to finish this game but reloading for the 10th time to replay a quest I just spent 2 hours completing because I died from some random dice roll I can't do anything about is boring and ruins a game which otherwise has lots of redeeming qualities.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113319661', 'num_games_owned': 77, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1550, 'last_played': 1729406339}
review:
TLDR: Only manual saves, which are not cheap. Else you lose all progress even if the game crashes or you die to bugs.

This is already the second time I've played this game, and I love it. I love it so much that I can't recommend it to anyone who hates bugs and losing progress. KCD 2 is already coming soon, yet this game still has as many bugs as the day of release. I've died countless times to randomly getting pushed miles away from looting, and the worst part is that the game has no autosave feature. My game crashed for the first time, and during then I hadn't saved for almost an hour. Imagine experiencing that countless times. This game only has manual saves that you have to buy with in-game currency, and it is not cheap at all unless you farm for money. I have screamed in frustration many times despite having fun most of the time. It's worth it for me, but really, shame on this game for having such a frustrating buggy game with few opportunities to save.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059229551', 'num_games_owned': 149, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4845, 'last_played': 1724429219}
review:
Even after learning and mastering the combat system, it remains so unfathomably dogshit that it ruins the entire game. The vast majority of the skills and techniques available to use in melee combat are either broken, useless, or completely nonfunctional past the beginning of the game.

Play it if you're ok with slowly pin cushioning bandits and soldiers with arrows for 95% of encounters, or are ok with an "action combat" game that devolves into a hopelessly boring 2 button turn-based combat system due to explicitly making aggression always the wrong choice, rendering everything else your character knows useless, and making literally every peasant you meet a freshly retired veteran of 20 war campaigns that breaks the rules of the game in their favor.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983419516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 11376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11376, 'last_played': 1706655315}
review:
I had some fun with this. The combat felt good.  I like when I learn skill at a combat system as the character is learning combat. But I play game less for pure gameplay anymore and want a story too. On one hand, this is a long game and poorly paced. Several times there were several long cutscenes in quick succession making it like a movie I was watching. On the other hand,  the story just ends unresolved. I never saw any indication this was supposed to be "book one" of a series. It seems like the devs were far too enamored with the portrayal of real historical people and events. 

 I did like the last two conversations in the game,  one each with the character's real and surrogate fathers. 

I had some fun and might check out a sequel,  but the last few hours left a bad taste in my mouth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022490675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1050, 'last_played': 1718458107}
review: I absolutely love a lot of what the game has to offer. The setting is impeccable. That said I've tried this on multiple machines over the years and bugs are too much. The combat is interesting but falls apart the moment you're fight more than one enemy. Add to all this loading loops, crashes and a game that punishes you for saving and it falls apart just a bit too much for my taste.

author: {'steamid': '76561198247702656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1775, 'last_played': 1707804820}
review: I want to love this game so badly, but the amount of time I've lost due to bugs and crashes makes me want to cry. Ooh, I was ambushed and died, that's ok I slept 30 minutes ago, nope, game didn't feel like saving after sleeping, there goes the last 4 hours of progress.  I'm gonna keep on playing because I love the mechanics and feel, but the bugs that exist after so long are just painful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198266838343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9375, 'last_played': 1729267457}
review:
I really love the atmosphere the dialogs and the quests that this game is offering. But I have a big issue with the combatsystem. Fighting 1v1 is fine but 1v2 or more is impossible unless you´re onehitting each and everyone of them. I even tried drinking a whole bunch of potions before a fight with multiple enemies and the only outcome was that they were able to  swing at me for a lot longer. And since the bow is practically useless the best thing you can do when you see multiple enemies coming at you is just turning around and run. 

And honestly the whole combat story ruined the fun at this game for me way to many times hence i am giving it a thumbs down.
