author: {'steamid': '76561199032085512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2038, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2038, 'last_played': 1706460979}
review: This is the first review I'm writing ever, because no game ever held such high promises for me and failed me so completely. Brilliant story, immersive, beautiful world, fun game mechanics, fun combat mechanics... everything seems perfect except the difficulty lvl. I finished Witcher 3, Skyrim and many such games with ease on normal and I enjoyed them because I'm here for adventure, for story and immersion. I have a job, I don't have the time, energy nor desire to grind some meaningless mechanic for 50 hours just to 'git gud'.  All the immersion, everything the story represents is gone when you die all the time at one point, then you have to go back and 'git gud' and it's still not enough, then you go back make different choices, return and still it's just cheesing to survive. I'm 34 hours in and I literally gave up because it feels like I'm doing a most meaningless, tiring job in the universe. I've been looking what others are writing, especially regarding some quests I've had problems with... it seems those who've succeeded where I've failed were prepared to invest much more time and energy into this game. They were also prepared to cheese all the time, for example, exploit bugs. This is not a game for gamers like me who are here for adventure, for the story and some challenges that sweeten the deal. This game is for people that are ready to play this game in continuity with focus and dedication and whose immersion is not ruined by meaningless grinding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198272381832', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1719053478}
review:
Decided to give this game a try since it was on sale for fairly cheap and I saw the trailers for the sequel, I like the idea but found the gameplay pretty terrible and the tutorial does not do a good job of explaining some of the very important game mechanics. 

It took me 4 hours to make it out of the prologue due to both unknowingly making choices that prevented me from progressing (causing me to have to load an old save) or misunderstanding the game mechanics (e.g. giving a trader more money instead of haggling for a reduced price because the trading interface is not very clear). The small amount of combat I was finally able to experience was super clunky as my camera kept getting dragged around into angles that meant I couldn't see the attacks coming at me. The AI also seemed to be able to grab and hit me with unblockable attack animations and it wasn't explained how I could avoid or block these. 

Personally found the dialog pretty bad, some of the conversations I had with characters at the start of the game just went on and on without really touching on anything interesting and a couple times the text prompts did not accurately portray what the character actually says, leading to situations where I lost reputation or started fights I could not win due to choosing a prompt that I thought made sense. 

In terms of realism and immersion it seems pretty authentic, but I've found the game more frustrating than enjoyable so far.

Edit: Added some more below after playing another 8 hours

After playing some more, there is a more in-depth combat tutorial further into the game however even then some of the more complex techniques such as master strikes (unblockable counterattacks) are not explained well and the AI can perform them perfectly very frequently. All of the combat training also focuses purely on 1v1 combat, which is almost never the case in an actual fight since you can run into heavily armed bandits in groups of 3+ not even a short walk from the starting area. Since the combat has you locked onto a single target, the enemy you are locked onto simply has to walk slightly to one side and now your back is to the other two enemies who will tear you to shreds. In some cases I couldn't even flee either as my horse seemed to instantly get spooked and buck me off or they would somehow pull me off my horse while riding past them at full gallop.

The dialog picked up a bit a little bit later into the story which is what has kept me playing so far, but what started to annoy me was that there is very little choice in what the main character says or does. e.g. When arriving at a new town I made sure to choose dialog prompts that were respectful and tried to be kind to those who generously helped me, then (minor spoilers) [spoiler] the game forces you into a cutscene where you start a fight with the local lord[/spoiler]. This just seemed completely out of character based on all the previous dialog I had selected and at that point I really just stopped caring about what dialog I chose because I realised it wouldn't matter.

Finally, the game encourages you to think outside the box and use common sense to solve problems except this only seems to apply when they want it to. For example, at one point I had a quest where I had to rescue someone who was captured. I scouted the camp and saw that there were two heavily armed soldiers there and I (at the time an untrained blacksmith with shoddy broken equipment) thought that I would stand no chance against them. So I tried to go to the friendly castle a short walk away to get help but the quest failed since I left the area. So I fought them and beat them easily, which gave me confidence to take on riskier fights. Shortly after, I came to another quest where I had to take out two bandits hiding in the forest. I thought that would be a cakewalk compared to the previous quest, so I took them on and failed like 6 or 7 times before giving up (especially frustrating with the games limited saving system). Then by chance I was talking to the guard captain who was back at another town about a different quest and had the option to ask him for help to take out the bandits. :/

TLDR: The combat is decent in 1v1 but painfully bad in 1vX, most of the dialog only gives you the illusion of choice and does little to change the story or your character and many quests are railroaded with few alternative solutions which can be frustrating if you get stuck repeating the same quest over and over trying to complete it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199095124147', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1729553996}
review:
I'll be blunt, this game is not for me.
Just from the early part of the game, it felt unimmersive.
The codex that gives me paragraphs on what to do, a combat system that just isn't fun fighting multiple enemies, even when fighting normally
When I was playing the game, I wasn't enjoying anything.
I was doing basic tasks that were trying to teach me the mechanics of the game, but just didn't feel right.
I can tell that the team behind this game knew what they type of game they wanted, a realistic game over quality of life details. I respect the work they put in this game, but I shouldn't have to force myself to enjoy a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984492989', 'num_games_owned': 123, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2592, 'last_played': 1719076836}
review:
Kingdom come Deliverance is a 9/10 game ruined by -5/10 combat giving it a 4/10.

The rest of the game is fantastic but you will not be able to get around how awful the combat it.
Imagine taking Mount and Blade Warband, a game that is 11 years older than this game and using that same combat system of directional attacks and blocks... and then making it worse in every conceivable way.

The combat is rigid and contrived it is not free flowing like mount and blade, chivalry, war of the roses, mordhau, etc.
When you enter combat(and yes there is a distinct change in all your characters movements and actions in combat), you are locked onto an opponent and you rotate with them no matter how you or they move.
THIS IS FORCED AND CAN NOT BE DISABLED.
It takes real effort to swing your mouse away to turn away from an opponent to move away from them.
When you fight more than one opponent which will be frequent, the computer player will exploit this to rotate you away from the other opponent so that they are always behind you and you can not defend yourself.

The combat is basically a series of QUICK TIME EVENTS (no that's not a joke) when you swing an attack and wish to change it's direction at the last moment or wish to perform follow up attacks you don't just swing in succession, you have to click the mouse button EXACTLY when the game arbitrarily wants you to.
If you don't even though it may feel like you attacked correctly, your guy just stands there staring at the enemy and not attacking, like you didn't win the quick time event and now you're not allowed to attack.

When you defend an attack you get another quick time event, and you most only block at this specific arbitrary moment.
You can't just raise your shield or weapon even though would make all the sense in the world, if you do this then you are punished for it.
When you try to attack someone with a combo and he succeeds his quick time event, he does a super special magic block that stops your attack and freezes you weapon hand(seriously the game absolutely will not let you attack during this time).
However if he attacks you and god forbid you fail your quick time event then he will combo 3-6 attacks, and even if they all hit your shield they will all drain stamina then stagger you then you will die.
You saw an attack late because the camera is awful and so you block but not when the game wanted you to?
Then you are going to block the attack but you'll take huge stamina damage, this is the same if you were TOO QUICK and raised your shield ahead of the attack... you're punished for being too good.

This is one of those games where everything uses stamina and yet you never ever have enough of it.
You need stamina to run, to jump, to swing your weapon, to block if you didn't win the quick time event, and you lose stamina when you get hit as well!!
If you run out of stamina and you block a hit but you don't win the quick time event and block exactly when the game wants you to then you are staggered, then the enemy basically gets a free hit on you.
When you run out of stamina then you can not attack, you can not defend yourself and you can not run away... you can't do anything, you just wait for death and then the inevitable reload back a couple of hours because you can't save out in the world.
As a result you are stunlocked to death regularly and it is no less frustrating in this game as it is in any other game that does it.

At some point your armour and skills will be high enough and good enough where you may fight two enemies at once, so long as one of them isn't a dog.
Oh my god dogs... they way they are implemented into combat in this game will have you pulling your hair out.
What is scarier? a man in full plate with a large axe and steel shield, or a scrappy little hound that looks malnourished!
You're wrong it's the damn dog, they will stun lock you almost completely alone, but in pairs or with a man fighting you it's a death sentence.
They grab your arm and drain your stamina until it's gone and i click the mouse button until ive split my mouse in two, my guy just won't attack.
It doesn't matter anyway because you are forced to camera lock and the system was clearly only made to fight man sized targets you can't even hit them unless they're close, but if they're close they will automatically enter a grapple with you and drain your stamina.
Remember with no stamina you can't fight back and you can't run away...

Oh and you're stamina is tied to your health because we needed another way to reduce this absolutely critical stat even more.
If you have 50% health then your stamina bar is also capped to 50%.
So you can't fight back you can't defend yourself you can't run away and the more you're hit the worse it gets, oh and your blind as well... didn't i mention that? when you are low on stamina the screen goes dark.

There's no point talking about anything else, the game is fantastic until you get into a fight then it is the worst combat game i have ever had the misfortune of playing in my 40 years of life.

If you go online for help you will find lots of it, but it all boils down to three main points.

1. Avoid combat, the stealth in the game is actually quite good and you can one button kill enemies with skills that you can get early on, so do that until there's only one guy left then try to enjoy a fight with him.

2. Cheese it, there are many mechanics that can be exploited to get a lucky hit in, many people on forums talk about exploit the clinch(grappling) to get a guaranteed hit in. I myself have noticed that if you constantly walk backwards and make space sometimes the enemy will run on to you and when they enter the run animation they can't defend themselves. Getting them to vault over something in front of you like a stool also works.
Any enemy you you haven't locked onto will never defend your strikes, it's like he can't see them coming if you're not locked on. So getting a non locked enemy to pass between you and a locked enemy then attacking will work but is very unreliable, it's just proof of concept.

3. Brute Force, When your armour and weapon and skills and stats get so high you can just brute force your way through the combat. I already have the armour that will resist most bladed weapons and they basically don't hurt me so i can get hit to deliver a big hit from my Heavy Warhammer.

All of those methods though show how bad the combat is because they all avoid getting stuck in and actually using the combat system.
Even when you do it is deeply unsatisfying.
Every time i win a fight against a strong opponent i come away feeling i was lucky rather than i did well.
When i actually manage to hit a tough opponent it feels like it's because the computer let me hit him.
This is a terrible feeling and is not at all enjoyable or entertaining which is the reason we play video games in the first place.

I absolutely can NOT recommend this game!
DO NOT BUY IT the combat will spoil it for you go and buy something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064344018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 4656, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4656, 'last_played': 1718979158}
review: Absolutely garbage combat system. Fighting one or two enemies is trivial but the game loves to throw larger groups at you and at that point you are fighting the lock on system and the camera and not the enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040628070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1706313503}
review: Bizarre combat system that sounds fun and realistic on paper, but is actually a clunky mess. Makes the rest of the game not worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070162520', 'num_games_owned': 187, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 6275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6275, 'last_played': 1716416169}
review:
I have to say, as someone who's recently been playing KCD because of the new upcoming game, I have mixed feelings about this one. KCD is undoubtedly one of the buggiest single player open world games I’ve played so far but I think there’s a good and bad thing there. It really seemed like Warhorse studios needed a little bit more time to cook and the game would’ve been amazing, unfortunately many of the flaws are steadily apparent for a game like this and I think some of these flaws are so bad that it’ll turn people off completely. 

The game can be tedious. There are a lot of things in the game and the systems seem somewhat relatively fleshed out. Henry can’t read, Henry can’t fight. He doesn’t really do anything until you go seek proper guidance to learn and then make your way into the world. Saviour Schnapps, an ingame item that allows Henry to quicksave is a good addition but for how buggy the game is, is unfortunately a loss to me. 

The game unfortunately doesn’t incentivize players to progress up until a certain point and that means you’ll likely need to finish a bit of the main quests so that you can really get a-hold of your place in the world. Moving from Skalitz into Rattay into Neuhof is really where freedom begins as well as obtaining your first horse. You should also note that training with Captain Bernard is also the bare minimum to even learn how to do other combat moves in the game. From a personal standpoint I find that to be a big flaw since I tried moving past that only to find it extremely frustrating to see enemies be able to riposte and never be able to figure out why I couldn’t do the same 30 hours in.

The dice game is actually quite fun once you get the hang of it. The explanation for the game to some people doesn’t make sense because they overcomplicate things but it’s actually not bad. The only other thing is that it requires some experience beforehand but otherwise it’s quite intuitive and buying additional dice to use as your own as an upgrade is interesting. The game is good enough that I feel that it would actually warrant a decent dice tavern game for a D&D game. 

The game itself requires your full attention foremost. So within the AAA space I would say that this is definitely one of those games which can be very annoying.as the game requires you to read (big shock) and listen to dialogue. I do think however that this can be highly inaccessible to many folks who are more casual gamers as sometimes clues to quests are merely said in dialogue once and they never say it again. The good thing is that you can complete quests in whichever way you wish so there are a multitude of ways to do something. The bad thing is that since the game is so in depth with certain ways NPCs work with day/night cycles and daily schedules to pathing, when something breaks, which is quite frequent it feels absolutely horrible. However, when the game does work together it’s absolutely magical. 

One of the worst things in the game has to be the fact that combat is so janky. One on one combat is usually fine in itself but when you’re surrounded, your only way to overcome many fights is with the bow which is one of the most broken weapons in the game if you can aim, and use potions. The potions in this game make it an absolute breeze so it’s incentivized that you learn how to read, learn how to brew potions and try your best to speedrun level 10 potions for autobrew. 

The other thing is stealth. There are a multitude of instances where stealth as a mechanic is utilized but it’s not entirely explained or utilized correctly. Places are way too bright which can likely reveal you, utilizing armor sets that reduce your noise and visibility is okay but man, it’s so ass when it’s a non-existent option when you’re likely to be noticed unless a quest designates and programs npcs for a free stealth kill. 

It feels extremely hopeless to be tossed around like a bowling pin by a ton of bandits wailing on you as your stamina bar disappears even with maxed traits. The story of this game is okay at best. While it’s your standard hero's journey of Henry of Skalitz making his way in the world, Henry/Hal is extremely dumb in the game and so playing Hal and being Hal in a cutscene feels in many cases disjointed as players are likely to be bandits that rob, steal and kill for groshen.
The game itself has a ton of content hence that 100 hour mark and even after I was done, there was still content I likely missed. However, not all the content was good. There were a lot of times that quests were simply broken or main quests were connected to certain side quests and so they were mandatory to main quest progression. 

An example of content that I personally skipped was a huntsman telling me to capture nightingales in the forest where I had to drop baskets. The baskets would disappear never to be picked up when I dropped them and I had to search up the quests to figure out how to place the baskets. That quest is an absolute nightmare. I didn’t even choose to finish because of the menial rewards and absolute pain it is to finish. A short hand is to just look it up on the wiki if you’re unsure. 

I do think that the DLC was okay, I think Woman’s Lot should have a pre-message that you’ll be going into a cutscene or notice that you have to finish the entire thing to get back to Hal. The treasure map DLC is ass, it’s such a pain to find the treasure that it’s not worth doing as even though it’s free loot and a huge upgrade on gear sets early on, I wouldn’t use it unless I was desperate. The Hans Capon quest was a nice little touch but imagining that coming out and paying full price? That’s a stretch to me I think. Out of all the DLC the best ones are probably Band of Bastards, and From the Ashes.

You get so much gold by the mid to late game that you’re not exactly struggling as much as before when it came to economy. The From The Ashes DLC allows players to claim Privislavitz as a fief under the supervision of Sir Divish and it’s a great sink and healthy for players to prevent having too much gold. By the end of the game I had 97,000 Groschen just as an example of how much gold players would get by mid to late game if they didn’t spend it. 

When the game finishes, you’re kind of left going “that’s it?” And it’s one of the reasons that prompts that 2nd game as the next installment. I really think that this could be a dream game to some people if it were possible to have it be like a Mount & Blade situation but then the details of the game were similar and much more polished on the interior parts likewise to this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069352065', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1709040172}
review:
i get what they were trying to make but the combat is such a deal-breaker tbh. 
its unbelievably jank controls feel unresponsive i got no idea if what im trying to do has any impact such as blocking or hitting more that once, which feels like it has a 50% chance to ignore inputs even with stamina. your head will clip into your shoulder essentially blinding you. foes will ignore damage and stun lock you 
point being combat just feels off. game seems fun otherwise. 
i will update this review after more hours but to a beginner its got a sharp and annoying learning curve

author: {'steamid': '76561198073389853', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1725030927}
review:
Held off on buying this for years since the combat always looked goofy when i watched videos. 

Now that i have played it i can safely say yes, the combat is in fact as goofy, and unsatisfying as it looks in the videos.

Think about the mount and blade directional combat but somehow done significantly worse with basically no hit response when landing blows and a terrible lock on system and that's basically what your signing up for. 

The sound of hitting an enemy with a blow is literally some comical call of duty hit sound and attacks feel so floaty and unconvincing that you start to feel like your literally larping in a video game lmao. Attacking anyone from a naked bandit to a knight in armour sounds and feels like your lightly beating on some dude with a wooden stick which is not what you want your realistic sword fighting game to feel like.... 

Fantastic game otherwise and most of the bugs are gone at this point but since the combat is such a large part of the gameplay loop i would say wait until the sequel drops.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996892429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1719596878}
review:
Heard a lot of good things about this game, and that was probably to my detriment as maybe I was simply expecting too much.

In trying to be as much of an 'immersive medieval peasant' sim as possible, it ended up making the gameplay unbelievably slow and very unrewarding for my tastes, personally. Nearly every gameplay mechanic also felt janky and unpolished. I had heard that one should 'stick with it' until it gets good and I'd otherwise consider myself a fairly patient person, but I just didn't have it in me for this one and ultimately tapped out after playing an unquittable 4+ hour long DLC that I didn't even realise I was starting, that was 90% silently walking around doing peasant chores and 10% flavour storyline to slightly flesh out the plot of the prologue to the game.

If you have an exceptional amount of free time and patience and a particular passion for the history and vibes of medieval bohemia (old timey czech republic, from my understanding) then you might get more out of this game than me.

However, if you're the typical person that works full time and doesn't have a massive amount of free hours to play games and wants to feel like they've achieved absolutely anything within a full hour or two of gameplay, you should avoid this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198409616631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 9634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8500, 'last_played': 1733350663}
review: the game is all fine and good, up until the final quest where i got stuck with loading screen. It is 2024 and they still haven't fixed this bug!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198016633633', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1719758731}
review: Start of the game is very slow, so you get to combat after 2 hours of gametime... so... when you taste how awful combat is, your money is already gone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005622597', 'num_games_owned': 694, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 5708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5708, 'last_played': 1714486561}
review:
Kingdom Come Deliverance is a game that I would give as a neutral review, and as I absolutely would not give it a positive one, I'll give it a negative instead.
It's not a bad game, but it's got an immense amount of issues. Primarily the combat.
The combat is absolutely atrocious. Not because the system is bad, I think they can pull it off well, but when you get to a high level Henry who is a beast at swordfighting, and you get master parried by a peasant of all people, is just frustrating. And this will happen a LOT. The combat basically becomes a borefest where you just spam master parry yourself because that's just the optimal way to play, and playing any other way will get you killed in combat. Good luck trying to attempt combos most of the time. Fortunately, it seems devs have recognized this, and will allow for more aggressive combat in KCD2.
On a good note, it will really immerse you in its environment, and I loved the side content, like alchemy for example.
I enjoyed Kingdom Come Deliverance, I do have 95 hours in it. And while I did enjoy doing a lot of what the game has to offer, it left a bad taste in the mouth.

author: {'steamid': '76561199677331376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1719483407}
review: terrible combat. whoever came up with the lockpicking system has no business being in game development. no clear way to complete tasks, just throws a bunch of random map markers at you in the beginning. the horseback riding is the worst, you can literally get stuck in a small stream that even a small puppy could find it's way out of.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104463928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1428, 'last_played': 1725502369}
review: I love the atmosphere, i love Henry's character development but I can't get over how buggy and janky this game is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045754364', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1194, 'last_played': 1725639884}
review: The game jerks it's own dick about realism but everything is so clunky it all feels like garbage. Good luck ever enjoying a group of enemies. Even 2 bandits will stagger and shake your screen with 1 missed block. Give up on fist fights because of the constant clinching as well. Also, It feels like the function of the yellow dot is completely flipped? It's just a random sun spot on your screen until you need it to aim the bow in which case you lose it and have to just vaguely guess where the arrow will go? I am not a master archer but not being able to use the incredibly straight arrow as an aiming point either just makes it feel almost RNG. Doesn't help a bandit will take an arrow to the chest and still run at you. The rest of the game seemed okay though. The limited saves seemed like an interesting concept until I had repeat the same journey through the woods over and over to attempt a quest. Sometimes not even saving and quitting the game will actually save your current progress between their "checkpoints"

author: {'steamid': '76561198882401336', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 905, 'last_played': 1721612104}
review:
I really wanted to like Kingdom Come: Deliverance as it touches upon so many features and aspects for a medieval RPG, but I can longer continue playing due to various aspects within the KC:D. 

1. Save function. You save your game by sleeping or drinking a Saviour Schnapps potion. You can sleep at designated sleeping areas such as your home, Inns and Campsites. I understand this function was designed to prevent players from repeatedly saving and loading games to avoid certain outcomes, but even after 6 years this game still has plenty of bugs and crashes. It's truly pathetic when you lose progress to a glitch all because your game enters into the infinite loading screen bug. I would like to see an auto-save function after key interactions, like trading transactions or bathing services.

2. Tutorial. The tutorial is somewhat thorough, but also incredibly vague in some areas. As soon as I learned I could lockpick chests, pickpocket, or knockout sleeping denizens and rob them of their valuables - I did just that. To keep things short, engaging in any of these activities regardless of stealth status results in a hefty fine or jail time. It's also not like I can just load my saved game and revert my curiosity because of the limited save function unless I want to repeat the last 30 minutes. 

3. Combat. It's horrible. I absolutely abhor swordplay and archery in KC:D. Combat feels extremely sluggish and the lock-on system still needs polish. I'm unsure if it's just me or controller players in general, but I lose my right joystick functionality because the target lock-on system aim assist is too powerful. I am unable to switch between targets and running away isn't an option when my view continually snaps back to the bandit. Look, I get it. It's historically accurate for the time period. That's fantastic; keep falling back on those flimsy excuses. It makes no sense a bandit decked out in full metal armor and a shield can keep pace with me as I'm running to find an advantage. 

4. Collision. Every NPC has a 2 foot bubble around them. I've been stuck in a house because an NPC/dog is blocking the doorway. Towns also have extremely narrow passageways with guards walking on an invisible treadmill. Slightly brushing past a small bush brings you a full halt when horse riding. 

5. Reputation. For a game that strives for realism and historical accuracy, I'm surprised at the current Reputation system. I can steal, pickpocket, and knock people out in stealth with no witnesses in the middle of the night and still lose Reputation for a fiefdom. Other reviews have defended this by claiming there would be obvious suspicion of a new arrival in a fiefdom following the disappearance of personal items. Yeah, maybe. It all seems too circumstantial and breaks immersion for me. It just sounds like a terrible excuse for a truly broken system and requires major tuning. 

6. Quests. Kingdom Come: Deliverance has an abundance of fetch quests. It's a lot easier to understand how players have hundreds of hours logged after completing a few of these main/side quests. Also, there are so many 'follow me' quests - As in, please follow me as we walk around the entire fiefdom at half speed. KC:D is a game with a strong narrative, where its story-telling is rooted in history. That's really neat, but aside from the towns, the open world feels very dead. There are occasional bandit encounters and accidents, but not much else. With most quests it felt like I was just traveling miles to talk to 1 person before returning. 

I didn't expect the entire story to be told through cinematic cut-scenes or character's lip movements to be misaligned with their speech. It's like I'm just watching a poorly dubbed European film.

I did expect the game to have a bit more free roam, but it seems most skills and features are elaborated through the main story progression. I'd like to explore more on my own and put the story aside for later, but it seems like a waste of time without a mount (main story quest reward). 

I did enjoy my playthough. The open world is visually stunning, even down to the finer details like how the morning sun shines through tree branches. All things considered, there's a ton of available activities. However, I wasn't thrilled about having to forgo certain criminal acts to avoid losing reputation. Ultimately, I think the game being in first person was the final nail. The camera shaking during mount transportation and combat just felt dizzying. I believe most people who praise this game use plenty of mods to improve their combat and performance experience. I'd rather just wait for the Witcher 4.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054956365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 9092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9092, 'last_played': 1729299846}
review: If you get this game now a days, make sure it is on a full sale. I had 25-50 crashes and bugs on the main story line alone that kept me jumping back and having to reload from 10+ minutes from where I was. They didn't update these bugs in the many years since release and it i sad. The game could be great otherwise. For now, it isn't something you should get into without knowing about the bug issues that are still persistent and throughout the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040726584', 'num_games_owned': 661, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 1428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 277, 'playtime_at_review': 1428, 'last_played': 1736699784}
review:
I think I'm broken.

Over decades, I’ve spent countless hours immersed in video games, exploring both fictional and historically accurate worlds. I’ve loved the adrenaline-fueled action of fast-paced thrill rides and the slow, meaningful experiences that make you truly appreciate the artistry. As a fan of the medieval era, a lover of sword-and-axe combat, and someone who’s always craved Mount & Blade-style gameplay, you’d think this game would be perfect for me.

But for some reason, I just can’t enjoy it.

I’ve tried everything—setting goals, creating milestones, playing modded and vanilla versions—but no matter what, it doesn’t click. I deeply respect the developers’ efforts and recognize this as a great game. Still, I’d recommend anyone on the fence watch some gameplay first. Despite being an undisputed masterpiece, it seems it can’t please everyone—including someone like me.

The irony? Despite my buyer's remorse (having purchased the game at launch,with all the DLC piecemeal as it slowly released and I still have the sequel on pre-order), there’s this persistent, nagging thought: What if I try it just one more time? Maybe, just maybe, it’ll finally click.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043828545', 'num_games_owned': 686, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1727925336}
review: I can see the merits of it being a grounded game, but ultimately it's just a bit too unpolished and janky of a game for me to enjoy. The scenery is stunning and the characters feel pretty nuanced and interesting for the most part, though the main story has been dog water, but the inventory system is hot trash. Combat is genuinely abysmal. For the argument that you get used to it, it's hard to play a half a dozen other games with similar directional combat that does it far better. For example, Chivalry 2? And I've played plenty of games with... interesting, combat mechanics (especially older games. Looking at you STALKER), but this one is just not good. I get you aren't supposed to be good at combat as a lowly son of a blacksmith. Played plenty of those games too. But tell that to the drunk old man too pissed to stand but still hitting me with Master Strikes like they're going out of fashion. Every single task is a major chore. Fast Travel genuinely takes ages. Quests have no fulfilling rewards even in early game. Perks are either meta or useless. Overall, wanted to like it more, but it just feels like a giant chore to play and it just isn't for me. Maybe some day I'll come back, but even with Vanilla+ QoL mods this game just didn't click.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039016253', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 793, 'last_played': 1730133742}
review: COMBAT is a pain in the ass. Ok, I knew it before buying it, but I said: -`it's a realistic RPG, there will be other ways to finish the quests...- The answer is NO, even in the main quest you are forced to fight. The saves are limited and when you die you have to redo km, as if it were a soullike. I understand the attempt to make a game realistic, but it too often ends in frustration. Add to that the fact that a good part of the quests are really boring. I like the setting and the story and I reserve the right to update the review when I have done more hours, but for now I find some choices of the developers too castrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997643799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1599427865}
review: One of the worst tutorial experiences I've ever had. Spent a couple of hours doing absolutely pointless things like throwing shit at someone's wall.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089874555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1253, 'last_played': 1721139131}
review:
Summary: if there was any other middle ages sim I could play I would but I am stuck with this.

Update 2: be ready for crashes and more bugs than hollow knight.

Update: the more you play this the more the problems show themselves. Do you want to be able to bandage yourself when not in direct combat? sorry your going to bleed out. Do you want a camera that might be the worse in video games? well this is your game. Do you want to constantly be killed becuase the camera locked onto the guy 30 yds away and not the guy stabbing you? perfect we got you covered. 

If you want a game where you constantly die in combat this is the game for you. every mission pits you against 5 to 10 enemies its impossible to kill them all before they kill you. I have never played a game with such a mismatch in balancing. Disappointing to cause I wanted to love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051085502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1002, 'last_played': 1718987230}
review: One of the most frustratingly ai sided combat systems imaginable. With enemies being able to pull you into their attacks despite being out of range. Literally as I was turned around and sprinting in the opposite direction I watched my character slide backwards and into a swing of a strike. Yet somehow the same the same gravitational forces repel enemies away from your strikes and some of them even go so far as to input read your attacks. If I hadn't gone over the 2 hours of playtime on accident I would have refunded it immediately. I only kept playing because I had seen the mechanics were really in depth so I wanted to learn them. But after putting in time to the game I see how lopsided it is. Even if it is on sale avoid it like the plague.

author: {'steamid': '76561199040906518', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5685, 'last_played': 1729022671}
review: Combat is unrealistic regardless how many fanboys tries to defend it. The devs implemented unlockable combos as means of progression yet at the same time the npc's master strike and perfect parry you 90% of the time rendering combos useless. The lock on directional camera combat is the most brain dead choice the devs ever made for this game, It works brilliantly in 1v1 duels where you genuinely have to use proper timing and skillful strikes to defeat your opponent until you have to fight multiple enemies at a time then all of a sudden you realise henry is incapable of moving his head and can only move in circles around 1 enemy (and no you are unable to manually side/back-step to create distance or reposition, which is what you would realisticly do in order to keep sight of multiple enemies!!!) Don't waste your money on this grabage rather spend it on mount and blade (whose manual directional combat system is way superior and more realistic especially when fighting multiple oponents!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198190825113', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1692, 'last_played': 1730075105}
review:
This game is almost a really great game. The combat is infuriating. Dogs are the most overpowered combat mechanic.. they can grab your mf arm and let the others wail on you without you being able to do a damn thing. That huge horse that you ride around on? As you ride, it gets stuck on the smallest rock, or slight incline ... so good luck using it to fight baddies with. 

The best part is if you fall through the map, you cannot fast travel out. If you haven't saved in an hour, you're just SOL. 

The second best part is, if you have issues sleeping at a tavern because nobody seems to be offering you a bed, so you decide to go to a bathhouse to bath, sleep, save, etc ... the game may freeze on you :)

Its unplayable without cursing and restarting from saved games over and over and over. I think I paid about $5 for this game, at that price ... maybe I would buy it again but not for full price. I would 100% never buy this game at full price

author: {'steamid': '76561198990319540', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4364, 'last_played': 1730155184}
review: The story is great. The setting is good And I love the Historical accuracy. But what I dislike the most is how slow everything is. You gotta wait for A specific time of day for everything which makes it painfully slow. Also the combat very confusing. And slow. Not just how long combat takes, but how Unresponsive Henry moves. It all just causes me grief and makes me not want to play It.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107285887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 706, 'last_played': 1730489845}
review: The combat, fighting, and archery systems are by far the worst I've encountered. Initially, it was refreshing to see something different from most games, but it quickly became frustrating. I'm sorry, but I don't want to waste hours of my life learning how to fight or flee from threats in this game. I play games to enjoy them, not to suffer. They should have included difficulty settings for players who want to master the combat mechanics. The inability to adjust any of these aspects completely ruins the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028092076', 'num_games_owned': 63, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6660, 'last_played': 1719681135}
review:
Horrible control system.  Levelling up your skills is a lesson in perseverance.  People who like repetitive grinding may have a smoother experience.  The controls are awful.  Nothing is intuitive.  I hate combat.  I hate lock picking.  

Frustratingly there is probably a good game in there.  I like the world, the story-line is compelling, and I have to say I'm not surprised there are people who loved it.  But as far as I'm concerned those people are sadists and the idea of mastering this horrible mess gives me PTSD.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967772030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 6127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1723413771}
review:
There was a lot of effort put into this game and it shows, but unfortunately the game just isn't fun to play. The UX design is just bad. The story is very interesting though, and the atmosphere is amazing, but if you're used to a better class of games like Elden Ring, anything that the player has to do feels like torture. 

If you are looking for medieval serf simulator, this is it. Many aspects of serf life come to pass. You're useless at everything, especially combat. It appears to be designed for VR or something, because it doesn't work smooth with neither a controller nor a keyboard. All you're good for is mule labor, but your character is also very weak. If you wear armor, carrying small things will overencumber you very fast. Everything is a chore. You'll be doing things like picking weeds and getting berated for "doing a poor job" even though there's no more weeds left because the guy wants to scam you. Your character is very low IQ and uncoordinated, but also some kind of languages savant that learns how to read his own language but also Latin in a day. The travel system is really awful, just like it really was in those times. There's a hunger system, but you don't have to drink or use the toilet. There's little bits of "realism" sprinkled about everywhere, but it's really inconsistent.

All in all the game has too many anti-fun elements. Devs should definitely play something like Mount & Blade and stay away from the quick time events type combat.

Story 9/10, compelling story about revenge and survival
Combat 1/10, it's annoying and gets in the way. It's not difficult, it's just annoying and doesn't work smoothly.
Gameplay 1/10, lockpicking is somewhat acceptable but annoying. Pickpocketing is extremely annoying. Doing quests where you have to carry anything is torture due to Henry being too weak to wear armor before you level strength, but without armor everything kills you immediately. You get a dog companion, but you have to level it up by feeding it 300 times and you get the same cutscene every time you do this. The dog does not have a cooldown on feeding him, it just takes about 6 seconds to do so every time as you can only feed 1 item at a time. WHY? Devs just went out of their way to make it a bumpy ride. Don't even bother with archery, Henry is always drunk with a bow in his hands. He's supposedly a blacksmith and has been training with a sword for a long time, but also he's super weak and has huge input delays on account of his low IQ. I really want to like this game and get through the story, but playing the game is a chore.

author: {'steamid': '76561199736190158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1725513006}
review: now this game is good on its own decent sword fights and all that good story i got 6 hours in and it was good but as realistic as the combat is it hurts the game massively sword fights only really work 1 on 1 the second its 2 or god forbid more then 3 you have litterally no chance of winning unless your some kind of god brought down from the heavens and even then its challenging like i get its supposed to be realistic but realism doesnt always mean good or fun gameplay everything else was great but i just could not stand the sword play it brings the game down tremendously but thats just me others could like it more then i did but i just could not stand it

author: {'steamid': '76561199214447768', 'num_games_owned': 28, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1725198448}
review: I cannot get past the first chapter because I am really bad with the combat system. The combat system is really difficult, especially when it throws everything all at once in your face, with some going left unexplained. I can't really see myself playing this when the combat system and its explanations are as it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198219076795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1729022443}
review: Worst RPG I've ever played. Can't even complete the stupid tutorial due to the serious lack of instruction for the controls, as well as just how unresponsive the player character is to the couple controls given. End game Dark Souls bosses are easier than whatever crap this is. I tried this game a handful of times on my Xbox shortly after it came out and its still just as bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198295927358', 'num_games_owned': 43, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 775, 'last_played': 1734259319}
review: I had high expectations for Kingdom Come: Deliverance, but unfortunately, the game left me disappointed. The biggest issue is the disastrous combat system. The fights are unintuitive, unnecessarily complicated, and often frustrating. While the game aims for realism, the result is a clunky and unenjoyable experience. It feels more like fighting the controls than the enemies. This flaw overshadowed any potential enjoyment from the game's story and atmosphere.

author: {'steamid': '76561199644467780', 'num_games_owned': 22, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1730768342}
review: the concept is great, ambiance, detailles, realism, etc. But the combat system itself is bullshit. it doesn`t matter what is your gear or experience, it's just a bully simulator, where you are being just bullied by the NPC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081293616', 'num_games_owned': 427, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1729574698}
review: The world design and historical accuracy are good but its still meant to be a video game and its still meant to be fun. the unnecessarily punishing save mechanics mean you regularly lost large chunks of game time and it just makes it tedious to play. Getting chain pinned by a dog so you lose combat would be acceptable if it didnt erase an hour of gameplay. Unless this is the only game you play and you have a lot of time to play it in then i wouldnt recommend. Would probably have made a better Movie/tv series than a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199568140265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 676, 'last_played': 1725554752}
review:
The Story is designed extremely well and is very immersive.
But the unmodded Gameplay is exetremely slow, unintuitive and frustrating.
The Game is partially buggy (NPC teleporting around mid fight / stuttering).
Solo fights against more than 2 Enemys are withaout a companion almost impossible.
You have to do a lot of Internetresearch to complete some Quest, because the design of the Quests themselfs is tells you nothing about how to complete it.
Mods are great, but you gotta check the compatabilty.

You arent going to fight knights, without going to fight the game itself.

The Story is very interesting. I wanna know how it continues, but im stuck in a quest again and so fed up at this point that i just give up on this beautiful yet frustrating game.
Im dissapointed, I just wanted to have a chill medieval adventure after work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080672171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1751, 'playtime_at_review': 2017, 'last_played': 1736754310}
review:
The combat system is by far the worst one thats ever been created. Its sluggish, extremely frustrating and it punishes you for doing it right... Its not even realistic, pure tedium for 0 satisfaction. Even when you finally kill a group you arent filled with satisfaction, just relief that its over... Fights can take multiple agonizing minutes and the enemies will punish you for parrying them well... 

Even the rest of the game is designed to waste your time. Fast travelling takes literal minutes of you looking at your screen doing nothing, same with waiting or sleeping, it makes you wait while the clock moves painfully slow... Theres so much pointless running around and absolutely nothing to discover, the world is immense but utterly empty, all towns look and feel the same, etc. 

Do yourself a service and play anything else, no amount of good story or realism is worth this level of suffering. It feels like the devs wanted to design a game to test the patience of RPG players as some kind of psychological experiment... Hell, go outside in full armor and you're going to have a better time than this...

author: {'steamid': '76561198387904462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 2496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2496, 'last_played': 1728930960}
review:
Abysmal combat, and that's sugar-coating it. Other than that great rpg. Surely a blast if you love medieval stuff. Questing around is ok (sometimes quite janky but eh). I'd like to see how it ends but anything combat-related gets me one step closer to uninstalling this.

I mean, I won't even talk about the combat being hard or easy, I've got no problem accepting that I'm bad lol; the problem is that it itself feels bad to the point I don't even feel like trying, I don't feel compelled to get better, I just want to avoid it; it's simply unfun, and that's tragic since it's an obstacle to enjoying an otherwise great game I think.
I dearly hope they come up with something better in the sequel...

(And I'd like to know why I can't flee combat since no matter how fast I run the enemy can always catch up making them inescapable - I'm ok being a mere peasant unable to hold a sword but I should at least be able to outrun attackers, especially since I'm light clothed and thus supposedly faster.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198096194308', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 3393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3302, 'last_played': 1727990203}
review:
[h1] Kingdom Come Deliverance: Great Story, Broken Mechanics [/h1]

Kingdom Come Deliverance is a game I’ve enjoyed and spent a significant amount of time playing. However, despite my experience with it, recommending this game would not be entirely fair. The game suffers from a large number of technical issues, to the point where I would almost describe it as a "bug fest."

The problems range from a clunky horse-riding mechanic—worse than even Skyrim's—to flawed dialogue interactions where subtitles often don’t match the actual conversations, sometimes pulling text from entirely different scenes.

The save system is notably weak, with tagged saves that have caused me to lose hours of progress, forcing me to replay large sections of the game.

One of the most glaring flaws is the combat system. It stands out as one of the worst I’ve seen in a video game, particularly because it contradicts the overall gameplay experience. The combat works only in 1v1 scenarios, but the game frequently throws you into situations where you're fighting multiple enemies, which the mechanics simply cannot handle. The system is not designed to accommodate combat against more than one opponent, making encounters unnecessarily frustrating and tedious.

Beyond these significant technical issues, the game does have an engaging and interesting story with some great twists, as well as a decent level of customization. It sets the foundation for a game that could become something exceptional. However, for any potential sequel, the combat system would need a complete overhaul, starting from scratch, with more dynamic gameplay and more varied missions. Additionally, significant improvements are needed to bring the game up to acceptable technical standards.

[i] So, yes, I would still recommend you play Kingdom Come Deliverance. I believe, or at least hope, that a future sequel will resolve these issues and turn it into an outstanding game. That being said, I cannot leave a positive review at this time. The volume and severity of the problems—especially those tied to the save system—are too critical. [/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198015156357', 'num_games_owned': 142, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1726693214}

author: {'steamid': '76561198065378715', 'num_games_owned': 440, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 2239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1911, 'last_played': 1714045513}

author: {'steamid': '76561198037997249', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 900, 'last_played': 1726188427}
review:
I REALLY want to like this game - but the combat, especially when fighting more than one opponent is absolute horsepiss. 

Switching targets is awful, and if you go to sprint to try and hit someone else with their back turned, your character runs around in some stupid fashion, gets hit like 5 times, and then dies. 

I've got full chaimnail, plate cuirass, and more - still getting the living dick knocked out of me. 

I'll go into an alleyway to reduce their numbers advantage (2 vs 3) and it doesn't help - even though they shouldn't be able to swing horizontally, they will! Even though trying to run past me should be heavily punishable, it isn't :) 

I have done live swordfighting, SCA/HEMA type stuff. Plate armor, live steel. Fighting multiple people sucks ass, but the way the UI works in this game makes it infuriating. Sometimes I will be trying to hold off three people, backing up the entire time with my guard up, while my ally just walks behind them casually. But if I end up between them, they immediately turn around and hit me in the back; without it being punished by my ally. 

Also the dog is worthless unless you train it forever - it'll fight off Szbyeck (however it is spelled, sorry) to stop him from looting his old owner, but it doesn't know how to attack someone on threatening their new owner on instinct? It just ends up getting in the damn way and growling, getting hit by me or the enemy in the process. That's all. 

I am gonna keep going a bit longer, but holy fucking shit is this frustrating. I have had a easier time in Soulslike games fighting more than one enemy in pvp than this. Mind numbing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122030869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 3251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3184, 'last_played': 1725937621}
review:
would be a really good game if it wasnt for the combat system, every fight is you outnumbered, or getting parried before you can do any sort of combo. It makes the game very boring because the only way to get anywhere is to do constant fetch quests. I like the story and characters are pretty fun but after putting over 20 hours into the game it'd be nice to be able to fight without dying. not to mention how fawking janky the game itself is and the boooooorrrrrinnnnngggggg quests.

I would like to add that I do like the game, I find it very fun and rewarding when it wants to be. But I cant say I recommend it to casual gamers that can't sink a bunch of time into it.

Well I just finished the game and god damn, that as a good story, the combat did get easier over time but I still wont recomend it to people who just wanna play a fun RPG. if your up to it, kcd is prob gonna be one of the best rpg's you will play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062366225', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 987, 'last_played': 1729666253}
review:
Don't bother. This game is not worth the aggravation it will cause. Combat is an unintuitive mess because almost every encounter is a group of enemies. Every minigame you deal with; either lockpicking, or pick pocketing is god awful regardless of your choice of controller or keyboard. They might as well have added that you must manually breathe by pressing both joy sticks or both alt key's every couple of seconds. 

Fast travel; while there, you shouldn't bother with it either - because you'll die before the load screen ends after notifying you of your options on what you happen to run into. You can't run from encounters because every enemy regardless of what they're equipped with can run forever, and hits you do take chunk your stamina into oblivion further making it impossible. Ultimately any and all combat is worthless to pursue outside of 1v1 duels because well - you are alone - and have the survivability of an infant freshly thrown into a meat grinder. Btw said 1v1's are like Halley's comet. You'll see it once.

I gave this game a fair shot, but there's up hill battles and then there's this shit show. Did I mention the only way to save is at 'specific' beds, inns, or if you're in the mood to pay 130+ gold/gresche or w/e the fuck its called a piece for a "Savior shnapes" which lets you save anywhere? I get not wanting a save scum community, but jfc when you make the main character so laughably bad a *living* or doing remotely anything, courtesy of a well known and accomplished father who's apparent first intelligent thought was teaching his only son fuck all. Oh, scratch that - he taught him the 'forge'. Which starts at 0 too. So nothing actually.

-10 out of 10. Shit, maybe the developers should add in zero save files, infections and realistic wounds. Won't be able to fast travel, much less walk with an amputated leg. How bout getting hit with a rock or clipped with an arrow or sword and lose half the screen because your eye was damaged? Keep the stupid mechanics coming. I'll laugh at my housemate who defends this games terrible design from the sidelines.

author: {'steamid': '76561198875426266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1408, 'last_played': 1719081324}
review: The Story is awesome, the graphics look good and the atmosphere including music is well done but what drives the fun away from this game is how punishing going into any combat is. You can be 200 hours into the game with end game level gear and the simplest of foes even a peasant with a stick is able to "master strike" your great sword that does the highest damage in the game then keep you stun locked. The combat as it is forced people to either cheese any forced combat in this game or to simply use console commands as less than 10 percent of the people who played this game actually figured out how to master the combat system that is so terribly made. The hardest dark souls level cannot compare to the prologue of fighting a guy with a small blade in this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198208258643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1107, 'last_played': 1725132328}
review: There are a lot of great things about the game and i really want to like it, But the combat targeting is such absolute Bullshit, especially in group fights that trying to play through them is hell. And huge groups of people ganging up on you is very common in this game, so expect to suffer from the shit combat targeting a lot. And it makes it next to impossible to retreat since it will force you to stop, turn around and look at an enemy every time you take a hit so its unavoidable that you WILL be doing lots of these. 1v1 the fights are admitably pretty fun, but in the end combat is such a big part of the game that its just flat out not worth it. Especially if you live with people who don't want to listen to you swearing and cursing all day like i do.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998148720', 'num_games_owned': 61, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1021, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1021, 'last_played': 1733260796}
review:
Dude this is game dope, I got it and put like 20 hours in immediately.
It was kind of disappointing. 
The game is beautiful and the background is cool but...
the combat is ridiculously hard, cool idea, but hard implement
limited saves is really weird
I went through a long part of the game thinking Henry would eventually be knighted, he wasn't
Really cringe and kinda dumb twist of Henry being a bastard was really dumb
On rails, every quest is a go here find this person, then go find another person, combat epitome, return, reward
every NPC has a routine and that routine is effected by the player, is a lie.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009307367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2467, 'last_played': 1725494761}
review:
I tried for 40 hours to like this game. After the DLC went on sale I bought it and gave it another go (I only had 20 hours back then) and yet again, I stopped at the exact same spot for the exact same reasons. I thought years of patching and polish would do something to make this game playable but sadly it did not. Whether its the fights that last ten minutes each with you both slowly swinging into each others blocks (and yes, i trained with bernard, miss me with your stupid fucking "you don't know how to play the game" comments), the absolutely asinine save system, or the continuously low stakes and unimportance of literally every single thing you do, I searched high and low in every corner of this game for redemption and I could not find it.  The only time the game felt remotely playable is when I finished the girl's dlc and got the dog so every fight was over in two seconds since I could now cheat and stun the enemy. I stopped yet again at the pestilence quest after you beat runt because yet again I felt like there was no reason for me to continue. There was zero challenge, no fights, no epic battles minus one single one in my 40 hours of playtime. Even for 2 dollars, you're getting scammed if you buy this shit.

There is no enjoyment anywhere to be had in this game. Anyone who says otherwise is swallowing a mouth full of garbage with a grin on their face and trying to pretend they like it, which is basically the life of a medieval peasant, so at least they got one thing right in appealing to humanity's lowest common denominator.

author: {'steamid': '76561199082064889', 'num_games_owned': 549, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1710593788}
review:
I really wanted to enjoy this game, and there's elements to it that are great. You can tell a lot of hard work went into making it, and it's part of why I want to like this game. 

Unfortunately the combat system makes it completely unplayable for me. I followed the tutorial at the beginning, and yet all that goes out the window when you're up against multiple enemies. You're kinda locked into fighting one guy at a time, so the others are free to just mess you up. I try to run away but that's clunky asf and the enemies have the same stamina for running as the terminator. Okay, so the game wants to be realistic, but you know what isn't? Stabbing a guy in the face multiple times and he's like "tis but a scratch!" then bonks you on the head to death.

I'm gonna keep this game in the hopes they update it with an option for folks who just wanna enjoy the story and unwind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198259342200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1369, 'last_played': 1729595430}
review:
I love the concept. I love the lore. I love some elements like the menu UI. I love the world, I like many of the characters, and dialog options too, so the RPG elements are on point.

I cannot recommend the game, because I dislike most of the rest. It is like the makers had two different ideas when making the game: A fun medieval open world game, and a medieval realistic simulator. Many gameplay systems reflect it.

There is an alchemy system, basically you make potions. Doesn't fit the realistic simulator aspect at all. The mini game for it, is very fantasy like with you using containers that magically auto refill, and they have borderline magical effects. It is super FUN!

Then there are things like the combat or even worse, archery. Because you are a peasant, but one who was born useless, as if you somehow matured from baby to man in a week, with no life skills, you cannot wield a bow. In other words, you cannot hit ANYTHING. Like, the lower level you are (which means pretty much dozens of hours at the start of the game) all you can do is maybe sorta shoot 5 arrows to hit a target once, that is just a bit further from you. There is no reason why you can have magical alchemy that just happens, but not magical archery that just happens. You can't really call it skill based either. It is deliberately janky to make it a "true simulation", as if shooting with a mouse and keyboard is somehow realistic and can feel the same, or that the on purpose janky mechanics somehow realistically emulate true archery.

There is a level of love for this obviously bad game play in the community it seems, comparing it to souls like games. I can't really agree to it, but I suppose some people just love for their games to feel like work to spend hunders of hours on. If you aren't into that, maybe steer away. If you are into it... maybe pick something more polished, like the previously mentioned souls like games.

But at the end of the day, my biggest issue is that the game does not respect the players type. You know those quests where you get one but all you are doing is walking forward to get to point A, click interact twice and go back, and that takes like 10 minutes? Yeah, I had those... many many times. The quest points are in fact set almost deliberately far away to make the content "longer".

So no, I can't recommend the game. I think it has some great elements. The writing, the creativity, the world building, but the gameplay and time wasting quest design is off putting, I can't help but regret ever playing it, despite having found a few hours of fun in it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099375670', 'num_games_owned': 132, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2090, 'last_played': 1725734248}
review:
After about 40hrs into the game I would never recommend this at full price. I bought it for $3 and I am not going to continue playing the game because of the dumb and frustrating game mechanics. 

1) There are still a lot of bugs and glitches with the game after 6 years, including main quest issues, character inconsistencies, etc.

2) The combat in the game makes the the game unbearable. Yes it has a cool idea, but the issue lies with "master strikes" and parries. Meaning there is no point to actually attacking anyone in the game because the likelihood is that you'll be hit with a  "master strike" which is an unblockable attack from the AI and theres nothing you can do about it. There are also combos that the AI will randomly throw at you which sometimes you are not able to parry or block it for some reason. This only drags combat out for 10 minutes at a time for no reason. The AI also tends to parry or dodge every 2-3 swings you throw at them so you can't even hit a combo skill that the game offers. Not to mention if you're involved in a 1v2 or more situation then it is basically a death sentence.

3) Fast travel, can't save the game whenever, time consuming. The game is plagued by this back and forth between towns which is fine, but the issue lies with fast traveling. When you fast travel theres a chance a random event could happen where you are ambushed. This results in a coin toss of whether or not you "avoid" it or not. If you fail then you're thrusted into a 3v1 situation which means instant death. So fast traveling is not the best and now you're forced to travel without which takes even more time. Also, you can't save the game unless you sleep or have a consumable item in the game which is extremely inconvenient.

Point of the matter is, the game has a good RPG foundation but everything else is terrible and makes the game unbearable. 

It's bad because I had to install mods to change this around to make the game bearable but there is still too much to deal with that I am giving up on playing the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199062457025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1733007366}

When in-engine cinematics plays, the framerate drops to around 10 fps completely ruining the experience. 
Mounted a horse and got permastuck inside the roof of Talmberg stable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198887398431', 'num_games_owned': 60, 'num_reviews': 273, 'playtime_forever': 568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1725146068}
review:
When Kingdom Come: Deliverance first hit the scene in 2018, it promised an epic dive into medieval realism and a sprawling open world. Sadly, what looked like a groundbreaking RPG with its emphasis on historical accuracy and complex systems quickly became a bit of a letdown.

Let’s start with the positives, because there are a few. The game’s setting is genuinely impressive. The medieval Bohemia feels alive with its detailed landscapes and historically grounded design. The developers clearly poured a lot of effort into making the world look and feel authentic, which is cool if you’re into historical accuracy.

But here’s the kicker: after a while, the shine wears off. The main issue with Kingdom Come: Deliverance is that it quickly turns into a tedious grind. The game throws you into this massive open world with what often feels like a million tiny tasks and side quests, but good luck figuring out what’s actually important. Objectives can be vague and the story doesn’t do much to keep you hooked. You might find yourself wandering around, wondering what you’re supposed to be doing next, and frankly, it can be boring.

The combat system also falls flat. It’s supposed to be this intricate and realistic melee system, but in practice, it feels clunky and awkward. Fights can drag on, and the lack of fluidity makes them more frustrating than exciting. And don’t even get me started on the bugs. Yes, patches have fixed some, but encountering issues that break immersion isn’t uncommon.

The character interactions are another letdown. NPCs often seem stiff and lack depth, making it hard to get invested in the story or care about the people you’re interacting with. Dialogue choices feel shallow and don’t really impact the game in a meaningful way.

In short, Kingdom Come: Deliverance feels like it bit off more than it could chew. The ambition is commendable, but the execution is lacking. If you’re after a richly immersive medieval RPG, you might want to look elsewhere. This game’s promise of realism and depth ends up feeling more like a chore than an adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009298638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4454, 'last_played': 1732482817}
