I rly tried to like the game because I love open world and rpg and the story is very good at some points but at some point I always ragequit out

author: {'steamid': '76561197978074231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1733260376}
review: 4 hours in and wondering if I should continue.  It's filled with lots of interesting historical  information which is great (if you like that sort of thing), but aren't games meant to be fun?  This is just constantly punishing. You carry a sword, but are not allowed to use it, even when being attacked by bandits with knives?!??!  Really.  So combat is ruled out.  Instead you have to either gallop around as fast as you can on a horse and hope people stop chasing you, or you have to creep around over long distances and hope nobody spots you, otherwise you're dead.  Just not my idea of fun.  Such an interesting concept, but entirely unenjoyable.  I'll perhaps try it again in a few months once I've forgotten how frustrating I've just found the whole thing and maybe have a better time of it, but for now, I've run out of patience.  Grateful I got it for £2.60 in a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097864546', 'num_games_owned': 438, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1732800846}
review:
I have never experienced a game that hates me for playing it as much as this one does. 
It's so janky it's insane. I have had entire stealth missions botched because Henry gets caught on some geometry in the woods and the only way to get unstuck is to jump, which alerts everyone within a country mile. 

The jump function just barely works at all, I've tried to jump forward and been sent shooting backwards and it then damages my feet and makes Henry more clumsy. I just wanted to jump! 

That's not even getting started on the worst combat I've ever seen in my life. I genuinely can't believe this game made it out of QA. Using a bow and arrow is insane in this game. Theres no reticle, there's no clear indicator of where your arrow is going, you have to figure it out by what knuckle on Henry's finger the arrow is at and use that to guide where your attack is going to land. Who made it this way??? Can Warhorse get their money back from whoever did it?? 

That said, it has some of the best character writing in the genre, and the game really makes you feel transported into this time period. I'll be finding a nice long play to watch on YouTube instead of playing this though. 

If they can fix the jank and fix the combat in the next one I'll definitely pick it up though.

author: {'steamid': '76561199126394614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 679, 'last_played': 1719093594}
review: The combat is not difficult in a way that is fun to learn, it is difficult in a way that is just tedious. You shouldn't have to spend 15 hours in the stupid training minigame so your character is finally capable of dealing damage to a single enemy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044414208', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 1342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1342, 'last_played': 1734011749}
review:
Story and world-building is mostly fine. The world is pretty immersive, voice acting is particularly good, maps are mostly pretty even if it’s too big and leads to boring travel time.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
[list]
[*]Combat is atrociously janky and clunky; often the attack buttons & dog commands are unresponsive, making combat unnaturally sluggish. 

[*]The 5 attack direction reminds me of For Honor's 3 stances, in which it is just as unrewarding to use against AI opponents who can block mostly everything without rhyme or reason; At least in For Honor you get the full complement of combos, parries, feints and whatnot to keep it interesting, KC:D is stripped and simplified of anything at the start (you can learn combos and other stuff sometime later, but if the combat is bad for the first few hours, that’s the game’s fault, not the player’s responsibility to stick through). 

[*]Even after you get to learn the more advanced combat mechanic it does not improve by much. A good combat system have predictability, and rewards those who understand patterns and react properly. KC:D’s combat is pretty random, you can swing at enemies and it’s a crapshoot whether it lands, get blocked, or countered. 

 [*]Combo system is pretty shit, using the mouse to string multiple directional attacks don’t feel particularly good, and even if you’re good at it, it’s generally not a good idea to string multiple attacks together due to random block & counter potentials.

[*] Defending is mostly just spamming the guard button and hoping one of them is timed to the perfect guard (which causes an auto-counter). The dodging mechanic isn’t worth it because if you miss the perfect guard you can still block the attack; whereas if you miss the perfect dodge, you’re standing still and getting a lobotomy. I think they also share the same window to proc, so they'e mutually exclusive and there's no need to get good at both.

[*] The camera’s auto-lock is annoying, moving the mouse too far for attack directions causes you to accidentally disengage the lock on and probably get stabbed in the side, which is a bit of a bad design when they already give you a specific button to intentionally disengage.

[*]The stamina system kills pacing of fights a bit as you back away periodically to restore it. So you strafe around for several seconds while the enemy walks towards you menacingly, probably without attacking. If they do attack, it means you need several more seconds of strafing around because blocking attacks also drains stamina.

[*] Archery is @ss, the game feels the need to give you a dot reticle when you’re not using the bow and taking it away when you are, so you’re incentivized to stick something to your screen as a replacement reticle.

[*]Overall, combat fails in being 1) realistic (people who think it is have lost grasp of reality) 2) rewarding to learn its complexity (it's as deep as a puddle) & for skillful play. and most importantly 3) fun.
[/list]

[h1]Other complaints[/h1]
[list]
[*]Quests are sometimes time-wasting, making you walk slowly from point A to point B which are needlessly far apart from each other because the world is designed to look expansive and pretty rather than being actually fun to play in as a game. (looking at you, Woman’s Lot DLC)

[*]Stealth (& stealth kills) mechanics in this game are terrible, there's a reason most competently made stealth games gives AI predictable movement patterns and view cones. Unpredictability of AI movement also makes lockpicking and stealing a bit of a crapshoot rather than a strategically timed activity.

[*] The save system leads to time-wasting, just let players save and load freely like every other game instead of spending in-game money to buy or spending time herb picking and crafting schapps. it just makes the game more tedious if they have to reload to an autosave that's 0.5-2h ago.
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198413491005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1733119192}

The remaining player base now has an incredibly hostile "GIT GUD" mentality. 0/10 Do not buy this game unless you are paid by the devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025618584', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 873, 'last_played': 1734489507}
review: I find this game frustrating, janky, and full of great concepts but mediocre execution.

author: {'steamid': '76561199120620998', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 4215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3868, 'last_played': 1719129749}
review:
Before you guys made the "royal edition" you guys should've focused on making a working edition on this game. The game only plays when it feels like to some times I get a full day with no crashes and then other days it crashes every 5min into the game I have 60 hours in this game and half of that is me just testing the game to see if it won't crash. I would refund it if I can.


Edit: Ive found out that the game has problems due to high cpu usage in order to fix it i had to use a cpu limiter in order for it not to crash my game.If you are using a amd cpu this is nearly essential because ppl has told that its even worse on that hardware though now i can play it without crashing i still cant give this a thumbs up. How can the devs release this as the final version is beyond me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070719684', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1726263293}
review: actually some of the worst, clunkiest most unenjoyable combat I've ever had the displeasure of trying in a video game. I get what they were going for but prioritizing historical accuracy this much over good gameplay is just unbearable to play. It was clearly designed for duel type combat, but with the amount of enemies ganking up on you, you're fighting the camera more than the enemies. Which also wouldn't be a problem if the enemies weren't omniscient about their surroundings. The combo system also sucks, and combat in most scenarios just boil down to jabbing their eyes out with your sword while keeping a safe enough distance so they don't WWE grapple you to the ground and 10 hit combo you to death

author: {'steamid': '76561198087665316', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1713553797}
review: i want to like this game I truly do, but with all the bugs that are in this game that have yet to be fixed by the devs of this game especially with the second game coming out it makes it hard to play it.  Now it could be a compatibility issue with Linux, but the bug literally makes it unplayable.  You might as well go get something else as it's obvious they aren't fixing the really bad bugs that make this game literally unplayable.  If the bugs are ever fixed then maybe it might be a fun game especially since you gotta develop your skills in game to use them better, but until then it's literally unplayable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049030130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2422, 'last_played': 1705805124}
review:
I've tried and tried and tried to play and like this game but I just can't. Every system is over complicated from combat to picking locks to crafting. You can't even save whenever you want. You have to craft an item for that. 
I've tried picking it up after some years but can't even win the first fist fight no matter how many youtube tutorials I watch. The idea is nice, I suppose. Some players like that sort of challenge. But damn it, gimme a "Casual" setting for people like me who just want the story.

After some time everything just becomes tedious instead of challenging. Save your money and just watch a "Let's play" instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025213708', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3004, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3004, 'last_played': 1730814796}
review:
The combat system is obtuse, unintuitive, unresponsive and generally frustrating, couple that with the backwards save system and unavoidable dangerous encounters where you're routinely ganked, and you're in for one frustrtating adventure losing tonnes of progress and having to repeat what you just did multiple times.

I just don't have the time for a game that doesn't respect mine. Don't make saving anytime a precious resource. There's a reason most games allow you to save progress at anytime these days, because losing significant progress is not fun, and the tension from the threat of that is artificial, there are plenty of other ways to create tension in a game in a more organic way.

And yes I'm writing this just after rage quitting and uninstalling the game, apologies, but I think it's telling of the game. I've never been driven to do this by a game before (in fact, this is also my first review ever), and I play plenty of challenging action/RPGs. The whole Souls franchise among them. I enjoy a challenge, but when it feels fair. This game does not provide that experience. All I wanted was to collect some god-forsaken belladona and finish the alchemy quest in a reasonable amount of time.

It's unfortunate, because the game is fun and immersive in a lot of ways, but the combat system is really clunky. I never feel like the character does what I intended it to do when I want it to.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045926331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 2503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1509, 'last_played': 1731558212}
review: I was enjoying myself until I lost of ton of  progress due to the restrictive save system. Keep trying to convince myself to play more, but don't want to grind my archery up again just to be shot by my opponent in a friendly competition, then arrested for "stealing" the arrow sticking out of my body.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084410507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1713571313}
review: Great game in some ways and VERY detailed however it's very nauseating when fighting which is kind of the point of the entire game. I will continue my play through but I can't recommend something this chuggy when my frame rate/frame times are fine

author: {'steamid': '76561198017544035', 'num_games_owned': 506, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1733003229}
review:
There's too much of a focus on being historically accurate over being a fun video game. Tutorials are next to useless; "we'll kill you til you figure it out" is very un-fun, especially when the saving mechanism is gated behind item usage. Unexpected cutscenes really hurt the pacing of the game.

Quest waypoints are less than useless due to arbitrary obstacles in the game. Unbeatable fights are a sin. If you're throwing a hard-coded immortal being at me, just make it a cutscene instead.

I can't really find a positive thing to say about this game. Imagine Skyrim, but most aspects are either removed or made considerably worse. I wish I had those 4 hours of my life back not playing this frustrating experience.

I definitely recommend not getting this game. I don't often say this, but I will say that this is actually a bad game

author: {'steamid': '76561198043805989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 911, 'last_played': 1729605319}
review:
I gave it a thumbs down, but it's really a thumbs sideways.

Beautiful game, honestly. Legit best historical medieval rpg out there. Can sometimes be a bit of a chore, but if you're into that...

The combat system is, however, ass. Like real ass. I know, I know... practice, practice, practice. The game tells you to git gud dozens of times, I get it. But combat is just annoying af in this game. This, of course, is just my humble opinion. You may enjoy it and be really good at it, which is awesome, as I'm sure it's rewarding. But I'm out

author: {'steamid': '76561198001421762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 209, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1736633213}
review: The movement feels clunky, controls suck, battle system sucks. At start of game it is on rails which, errr, sucks. The game doesn't teach you the battle mechanics properly. I found it a very difficult game to play because of all this. The menu is weird. i found myself bored after 6 hours and gave up. I'm used to Bethesda RPG games, can play those games on highest difficulty, this game is not that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198237853682', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 787, 'last_played': 1710720431}
review: Slow story progression and save system mechanics make for many lost hours repeating missions which is amplified by the bad direction the game takes you in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198357036511', 'num_games_owned': 78, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1931, 'last_played': 1717169653}
review:
Alright, here’s my take after 32 hours of playing. The person who worked on the story deserves all the praise, the one who did the dialogues deserves all the praise, the artists did an amazing job, the visuals are just heavenly. The work on the map, the outfits, the weapons, it’s all just top-notch. I won’t even mention the small stuff like the dog constantly getting in your way or the horse appearing out of nowhere. Lots of games have these quirks and it’s not a big deal. But YOU! The one who designed the combat system, you’re gonna burn in hell. Literally. Everyone who has played this game curses you out in combat, and it’s totally deserved. Let me try to explain why.

You wanted to go for realism, right? Okay, tell me this: if you’re fighting two guys and one flanks you, but you’re swinging your sword at the one in front of you, would your arm continue the swing even if the other guy is whacking you on the head with a club? Or would you stop and look to see what the other guy is doing? I think the answer is obvious. So why the hell does the character keep turning and spinning around when I want to focus on one enemy? You completely ruined the combat system. When you get surrounded by a bunch of bandits near the mill, the player can’t do anything because the character is just uncontrollable. Do you get it? YOUR COMBAT SYSTEM MADE THE CHARACTER UNCONTROLLABLE. The player loses control at the most crucial moment, during combat!

In these 32 hours of gameplay, I’ve had so much frustration and I’ve been enraged multiple times, literally to the point where I smashed my expensive mouse. I have a question for you, the one who designed this combat system: have you ever actually used it, tested it? Have you played this game yourself? I’m out of patience with you, idiot. Burn in hell.

UPD: Tried more 29 hours. Result. This is the worst game with the most disgusting controls I have ever played. I have never experienced so many negative emotions from a game. It's a shame I spent money on this piece of shit. Burn in hell. Uninstaled

author: {'steamid': '76561198303189627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 980, 'last_played': 1725827663}
review: Played for another 9 hours and man not much has changed the game definitely has it's moments, drinking with the priest, finding a sense of belonging with Radzig and dealing with the one off bandit and Cuman soldier. But the combat is god awful. Highlighted by the baptism of fire mission. I haven't changed my mind about the controls being wonky asf. The stealth is terrible and any other play style than the do-gooder christian is heavily punished. The game is just does not hold up in 2024 in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561199143848674', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1719608131}
review: I usually enjoy tedious open world gameplay. I play games even more tedious than this one but this one is something else. I have never felt so negatively frustrated by an open world survival than this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198299187857', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 992, 'last_played': 1733536204}
review: Way too frustrating controls, very bad inventory management, abysmal combat system, and time waster quest design, just to name a few of the issues. I get it, its not supposed to be a streamlined rpg experience, more like a simulation, medievil Stalker, but after spending the past 5 months only playing Elden Ring and it's DLC, I just dont want to do this, which is a pity, the historical background and story seems decent and engaging, but the gameplay is overall exasperating, that I just dont want to deal with this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044741088', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 2028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2028, 'last_played': 1715007536}

author: {'steamid': '76561198065419151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 2089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1759, 'last_played': 1731502320}

author: {'steamid': '76561198032030490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 9221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8183, 'last_played': 1734022313}
review:
I like many things about this game, but........ There are SO MANY bugs that it frequently is a PAIN to play it. And I don't want to support dev teams that don't fix their bugs. Period.

- "wanted" status (with no additional details) appearing at random (yeah, at random, like after a fast travel or after a night in a bed), sometimes leading to guards arresting you and telling you "I'm keeping that stuff", although you didn't have ANYTHING stolen in your inventory...
- caught in the act by God knows whom... There is NO ONE in the area, but I am still "caught in the act"...
- enemies head-shotting me at 150 meters in the dark, with no torches, during the night, and my stealth at top level + bonus for crouching + stealthy outfit, whereas I can barely see them even with a "nighthawk" potion
- enemies turning towards me when I'm crouching, but they "did not see me", yeah yeah... reminds me of Blood Money
- enemies who could hear/see me when I am at sound=0 and stealth++ (potion) during the night and crouching with all bonuses in the Stealth skill... and I lost SO MANY hours of gameplay because of these bugs... and SO MUCH frustration!!!!
- enemies who could hear/see me put a few drops of poison in their cauldron during the night whereas no one was even watching the said cauldron (I seriously don't know how it could be possible to do what was asked in a stealth way, without having to waste every single bandit first...)
- 70% of HP lost because my horse rode... I don't know at which angle of the road... I did not fall or anything, just my HP dropped all of the sudden because my horse was walking funny for a few meters
- walking "head on the bottom and feet on top" (the view was reversed, the sky was at the bottom) when falling from horse in a slope... had to mount the horse again to get back to normal (but until then, I could run in the prairies, with the sky at the bottom and the grass on top)
- enemies with strange movements (halberd men running towards me and turning around me like they are trying some pathfinding)
- the bow is PAINFUL to use, there is no "assist" like there is with melee combat, no crosshair, nothing... sometimes you can aim at a guy who is like TWO METERS away from you, who is not moving, and still miss the target somehow... also it is EXTREMELY slow to reload which makes no sense because experienced archers are actually quite fast with bows
- impossible to repair items below 60% durability even at the highest skill level
- no bedroll FFS
- guards arresting you because you don't bear a torch at night, whereas 100% of the population is NOT bearing one either
- people getting mad at you for no reason (not trespassing or anything, but somehow you are still doing something suspicious enough... go figure)
- some people can't be stolen properly of their clothes and other stuff (e.g. the Locator, of whom I wanted the nice hat)
- sometimes you get teleported to a very inconvenient place after a cutscene and/or dialogue (e.g. when stealth-discovering Runt's camp, you get teleported in front of guards after a cutscene... nice... or if caught in the act of trespassing in town, even if you run away from the place but you are caught afterwards, you get teleported back inside the "trespassing" area after the dialogue)
- losing health when falling down even just one meter or something (you have to pick a talent to prevent that, at least partially)
- also a VERY VERY VERY FRUSTRATING issue: bushes can't be walked through!!! and the same applies to some other places like the sides of a small stream: it is only 30cm high but you can't jump it and your horse can't either... and as for the bushes, you can get stuck in them, and if you succeed jumping above them somehow (on a horse) and there is a slope, be ready to get seriously hurt when you land
- many things don't work as expected, e.g. applying a "sleep potion" to your arrows is supposed to drain the enemy stamina to zero, but the guys could still run faster than me and multi-strike me with no respite
- enemies with surprisingly greater stamina than mine, even when they are wearing full plate and I'm only wearing some black pants ; also they can strike you 3 to 4 times in a row very rapidly, whereas when you want to strike, your character takes a couple of seconds to land a single lousy strike that they easily block
- some painful things, like having to follow the Locator when building things, or the freaking hunt mission with Capon that takes ages and is boring as hell because first I don't want to hunt bunnies and also how on Earth are you supposed to aim at a 20cm target with in mind what I said above about the bow (I even went to another city to do some other stuff because of how long it was)
- the bow angle is very limited when on horse, it is painful to use...
- you can't talk to people while on a horse
- from time to time I got a message "your reputation decreased" just while walking the streets or picking some flowers, I don't even know what happened
- having to drink alcohol to save the game makes no sense, it breaks the fun
- sometimes there are some reaaaaaaaally slow loading times when "fast traveling" to a city (slow like 20 to 30 seconds) ; it feels random
- some guy went into the bed of an already sleeping girl (in the bathhouse) and I don't think it was meant as a funny way of saying they were going to "share a bed" ; in the same manner, sometimes there are two guards in the exact same pixel-perfect position (although their animation may vary) (e.g. at the front "door" of Rattay)
- you can't stop a fast travel (or I didn't find out how)
- you can however stop a sleep session, but to my knowledge it prevents the save from happening
- some enemies disappearing all of a sudden, or re-spawning all of a sudden
- when a named enemy holding important information surrenders after a fight, you can't interrogate him to get the needed information, because it was not scripted that way, which makes no sense
- I am the bailif of a city, and the guards are warning me that I can't bear a weapon
- I wanted my character to be faithful to his lover, but it was apparently not scripted that way
- pickpocketing is WAY (!!) too much random: sometimes you get caught when just pressing the key (in that case I hope for your sake that you saved not too long ago), sometimes you get a full 15 seconds of "time", and sometimes only 3 seconds... it should clearly be more consistent, depending on the player stealth, and the state of the "victim" (sleeping, unaware, walking, etc.) ; because sometimes, even a sleeping vagrant caught me when I just pressed the key, which makes not much sense
- my companion guards (when attacking a bandit camp) not moving an inch because it was "my job" to waste some archers... so they stood still, even when getting shot at
- the UI is not quite convenient (e.g. when trying to compare armor/clothes for a specific area of the body, or when looking for a specific item, or to mark stuff as "garbage to sell", etc. also you can't "store in horse" directly when looting, which makes the process painful)
- loading a game is very painful (and I mean "the most recent save"), it requires at least 5 keystrokes + clicks, or 8 keystrokes if only using the keyboard ; and because you are going to load a savegame quite regularly because of bugs, it makes the process painful

And I'm beginning to feel really dozy, so I'll stop there, but I'm quite sure there is more that I should/could have jotted down and written here...

The game has great potential: sure there are potions, but other than that it is somewhat realistic (which feels nice from time to time), it features beautiful scenery, interesting lore, etc. and don't misunderstand me: it is refreshing!

But honestly there are WAY too many bugs that they should have fixed (and I don't want to support lazy devs), which makes the game painful to use... and which in turn makes me somewhat masochist I reckon!

author: {'steamid': '76561198086770308', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 3829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3829, 'last_played': 1725360196}
review:
'UPDATE after finishing the game: (might have some spoilers) it had loads of potential but I'm not satisfied with the overall experience. I don't think I've ever seen an RPG game where your main quest is just hanging and its impossible to complete or even come close to it. Like when I beat Istvan I just let him go with the sword that I was looking for the whole time just because of honor? Come on... The main storyline has just kind of vanished from the story.
Looks like the sequel will continue from right the end of this game which really makes me wonder how they gonna do it? What equipment will I have in the next game? Will the DLC contents like From the Ashes vanish? etc. I just hope they will fix most of the issues and make the game make sense.'




Really hurts me to give a negative review... I'd love the game if it didn't have some of the issues.
+ I was really surprised and amazed by the depth of the game at first
+ Really appreciate the writing and setting
~ Graphics are weird. Some things look cool while some are straight up ugly
- It's a bugfest
- Combat system is something different
- Worst DLC of all time ("A woman's lot" - never try it!)
- Save system is also something I can't agree with
- Quests are turning into chores and sometimes it feels like a walking simulator
- Game is pretty difficult which wouldn't be a problem normally, but in this case it's because a lot of things are not explained, you learn by making mistakes. And also bugs can make things hard.

I'm really looking forward to the sequel though

author: {'steamid': '76561198164013736', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1718755038}
review: Can't Pause cutscenes and the game has unwinnable fights with invincible enemies. Character movement physics pulled from GTA 3. States it's "Realistic" but I doubt any of the devs have ever handled a sword, fenced, or even used a butter knife. A two foot hop will break both your legs an you will bleed out but stabbing someone with a sword 15 times does almost nothing. Fetch quests galore where you end up staring at awful ground textures for ten minutes trying to find items. Some of the worst inventory management menus I have ever encountered. Back to back timed quests with no prep time in between even though the game shows cutscenes of hours/days going by. No brightness/gamma settings, devs must have spent too much time in their mommys basement and forgot how the world really looks. Equipment that has less durability than scotts single ply. Worst part of the whole thing is the Story, character, and world building all seems great but everything else just gets in the way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020313592', 'num_games_owned': 1027, 'num_reviews': 609, 'playtime_forever': 8039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8039, 'last_played': 1705732457}
review:
[h1]Sum-Up[/h1]
[h3]In-depth analysis further down.[/h3]

If you’re looking for some screenshots [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/tho545454/screenshots/?appid=1328670&sort=newestfirst&browsefilter=myfiles&view=grid]click here[/url] to view all the ones I took for this game.

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟩 [b]Pros[/b][/th]
[th]🟥 [b]Cons[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
• Exceptional value. 110-140 hours of content depending on completion rate; even at full price it’s a great deal.

• Solid visual upgrades overall, with ME1 receiving the most benefits by far.

• Hardcore / Insanity difficulties are available from the start in all three games, unlike in the originals.

• Balance reworks and quality-of-life improvements across the board, especially with ME1’s UI being markedly improved.

• “Galactic Readiness” mechanic in ME3 was removed.
[/td]
[td]
• ME3’s entire co-op multiplayer component is not available, which is a shame; it was great fun.

• Interface bugs and performance issues, especially in ME3, that were not present in the original.

• ME1’s rebalance made it significantly “broken” and too easy.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟨 [b]Bugs & Issues[/b][/th]
[th]🔧 [b]Specs[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
• In the Citadel area, major frame drops can occur in some areas regardless of settings.

• Rare crashes, mostly in ME1.

• Antialiasing option doesn’t work well, be prepared for heavy aliasing in most locations.
[/td]
[td]
• i5 11400H
• 16GB RAM DDR4
• 512 GB SSD
• RTX 3060 6GB
• 1080p
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[td][b]Content & Replay Value:[/b][/td]
[td]It took me 134 hours to complete ME:LE on Insanity difficulty in all three games, taking considerable extra time to complete all side activities and explore thoroughly. With many significant choices, varied classes, and the renegade / paragon dichotomy, the replay value is high.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][b]Is it worth buying?[/b][/td]
[td]Absolutely, especially if you’re new to the series. The value of this package is exceptional, and barring a few bugs, probably the best version of the Mass Effect Trilogy you could possibly play.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][h3]Verdict: Very Good[/h3]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2548409603]Rating Chart Here[/url][/td]
[td]An iconic RPG trilogy that comes back shinier than ever. Not without flaws, but overall it’s an exciting story you don't want to miss.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]In-Depth[/h1]
[h3]Mass Effect 1[/h3]
The one that began it all, and that’s a merit of its own - even with all the clunkiness and half-assed mechanics it may have. In this Legendary edition, ME1 is the oldest and, of course, has received the best uplift from its former self. The remastering work, in some fields, borders on the “remake”; the UI was completely reworked and modernized in comparison to the unwieldy, clunky disaster of the original. Everything feels smoother, more responsive, more fluid. The visual upgrades are impressive, and a far cry from the original in almost all aspects; however, this probably weighed more on its dated engine, and that’s the reason behind the sporadic crashes and frame-drops in specific areas. 

Gameplay–wise, an effort has been made to rebalance the economy, loot tables, weapons and enemy difficulty. On one side, this makes the early-to-mid game phases more challenging on higher difficulties, so much that you might get 1-shot but snipers and other shenanigans; on the other it makes late-game much more trivial compared to the original. This is mainly due to the massive power creep in both weapons and attachments, other than absurd amounts of money gained from sales, and imbalances in the XP gained from side missions, far more than it would be reasonable. Result: Shepard will become an unstoppable killing machine, capable of 1-shotting most enemies with heavier weapons and ragdoll the rest across the battlefield by sheer bullet impact force.

The controls, UI, movement and cover systems have been largely overhauled, a large improvement over the clunky mess that were the controls of the original ME1, as now they’re more similar to the far superior sequels in handling. For the rest, the game remains largely the same, including the tedious side-exploring of planets for collectibles or the time-consuming meandering through locations with dubious fast-travel solutions, if any. It’s a good RPG, but in my opinion the weakest of the trilogy gameplay-wise.

[h3]Mass Effect 2[/h3]
Considered by many, myself included, to be the overall apex of this trilogy, ME2 has undergone visible but comparatively-minor overhauls if compared to its older brother. The lighting solutions are markedly improved, same for textures and effects quality, overall offering a crispier visual fidelity, but not without downsides. The visible, annoying aliasing (jagged edges) can’t be countered very well by the shoddy anti-aliasing solution, so you’ll either have to live with it, or use GPU control panel fiddling or external mods (such as ReShade) to alleviate the problem. Moreover, roughly the same results, except for lighting, could be achieved with existing mods, like the popular “ALOT” to name one. Is the remaster version better? Yes, it is, but not without additional performance issues, especially at the Citadel.

The balance shenanigans of ME1 Remaster are fortunately gone, and the game offers a consistent, well-balanced challenge (unless you play on Insanity, which I did, and is pure pain) that you will enjoy. The story and character arcs of this second entry are the best in the trilogy; most people that aren’t my dead-inside self will become emotionally-invested in the characters and events surrounding Shepard’s space opera epic in saving the galaxy. 

Unfortunately, the devs didn’t want to alleviate the tremendous pain that is planet scanning, which will take literally dozens of hours to 100%, if you’re a completionist or, like me, an autist. Be prepared to put an anime on your second screen (if you don’t have a second screen, buy a cheap one) and scan endless planets for miserable resources and the occasional artifact collectible. You don’t have a choice anyway, if you want upgrades.

[h3]Mass Effect 3[/h3]
This last chapter is, of course, the one that benefitted less from the remaster, as it’s the most modern and, even in its original state, had pretty solid visuals. The remaster’s results are not as noticeable here. Barely any change was made to the gameplay, UI or balancing compared to the original release. Considered by many to be the worst entry of the series (except Andromeda, but we don’t speak about that one…), I don’t think it’s fair to say that, especially gameplay-wise. Sure, the story is a downgrade from ME2 and the ending a train wreck, but it has its great moments; its gameplay is hands down the best in the trilogy, by variety of weapons, builds, combat feel and mechanics. It’s still better than Mass Effect 1 as far as I’m concerned, and having played this trilogy four times in my life, I can tell.

It’s downright a shame that the fun, engaging, varied multiplayer of ME3 was mercilessly scrubbed away. It may have been infested by dumb microtransactions, it may not have been well-balanced, but with some friends or even randoms it was a blast, and had plenty of content not available in the main game, like being able to play as enemy characters with unique abilities, unlocking unique weapons, and even unique enemies like “upgraded” Collectors.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972097840', 'num_games_owned': 743, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 5837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1354, 'last_played': 1715723716}
review:
Having played the original trilogy when it first released almost 20 years ago, I had forgotten just how great this series is. Filled with amazing imagery, solid writing / voice acting and immersive gameplay that really makes you feel like a badass flying through space saving the galaxy. For me it feels a bit like a spiritual successor to the Knights of the Old Republic games in many ways, tying space sim elements to a story-deep action RPG. As the series progresses, so does the quality of life changes and positive changes to some of the weaker elements of the first game. Visually, the whole thing is stunning and still manages to hold up today - though I would recommend installing a couple of mods just to make your experience that much greater. I used the ALOT and ALOV mods which feature upscaled textures and videos. 

For those completely new to the series, essentially this is a third person action RPG, using a cover system. The game tends to split between exploration, gunplay and the story-driven narrative, employing a morality system that lets you determine what kind of galactic saviour you are. You might be a paragon of hope, making decisions to be kind and benevolent, or a renegade who takes any action available to them to get the job done. Of course, many difficult decisions are present in this series, ones that will certainly carry over even from the first game to the third. That renegade decision might ultimately be the right move for example - or it might just be funny or cool! 

The first game of this series released in 2007 - and it mostly holds up very well. That said, some of the controls and gunplay feel a little restrictive, and I would have liked to see more features such as FOV control or shoulder cam switching. That said, the second game vastly improves on the shooting elements. The other thing I feel I should mention is the awful EA launcher that tries forcing you to launch after you install. I highly recommend looking up the 'F@@@ EA guide' which gives you a very useful way of avoiding it altogether. Of course, there was some controversy with how the last game ended back in the day, and this ended up with a lot of drama unfortunately. Without giving too many spoilers regarding that, I'll just say the ending felt quite rushed. There are a lot of mods and a patch that Bioware released, though I never tried it myself as this is the first time I've replayed the series since completing it all those years ago. 

On a final note, as anyone who is a fan of Star Trek or similar, RPGs or Sci-Fi stories, this collection is a must-have, and probably for me one of the best game series of all time.

[b]Recommended mods:[/b]
For the entire trilogy, I recommend ALOT (Texture improvements), ALOV (AI upscaled videos) and Lighting Restoration. These mods are available for each game as packs and make a lot of improvements that bring the ME series almost to the current gen in a lot of ways. 

To vastly improve the ending of ME3, I highly, highly recommend getting CEM (Citadel Epilogue Mod). This basically places one of ME3s DLCs at the end of the game, which basically acts as a heart warming goodbye to all the characters in the game. It just fits so well, especially since the DLC contrasted with the grim narrative of the final game.

Lastly, for ME3, make sure to get EGM (Expanded Galaxy Mod). This adds a huge bunch of new quests and truly difficult decisions that effect your final army for the last fight, in a totally meaningful way. It adds so much more immersion to the game - I mean a LOT. The maker of the mod deserves so much credit. There is one scene that allows you to call in the final battle near the end of the game that is genuinely one of the most kino moments in gaming I've experienced.

[b]Pros:[/b]
Immersive and gripping storyline.
Incredible soundtrack.
Great writing and decent voice acting.
Graphics that hold up well today.

[b]Cons:[/b]
EA Launcher (can be fixed with guide)
The ending was definitely rushed.
A small bit of clunkiness in the first game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114586751', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 2146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2146, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1729905156}
review:
Mass Effect 3 | ★★★★☆

I played the previous games in their original PC versions, and I’d say they did a fantastic job polishing this final release, adding newer features like Ultrawide support, HDR, and controller compatibility. However, to continue your progress, you’ll need to manually transfer your old save files to the new save location.

There’s a bit of an issue with the EA app (as usual, unfortunately). If you’re playing on multiple devices like a Steam Deck and a Windows 11 desktop, the app prompts a sync at every launch, which makes it far too easy to accidentally overwrite or delete your save file—potentially losing hours of progress. The game’s cloud save relies on EA’s system, which feels clunky compared to the seamless integration of Steam Cloud saves.

I’d put off playing this last entry in the trilogy for a while, but it turned out to be well worth it, offering a satisfying conclusion to many characters’ storylines. The included DLCs also enhance the companions’ backstories and make Shepard seem more personable and connected to the team than in previous games.

It’s hard to spoil the series, as there aren’t any single plot points that drastically alter the overall story. So even if you’re starting now, you’re safe from major spoilers. Aside from the gameplay being a cover shooter typical of its time, this remains one of the best examples of storytelling and world-building in gaming. And, of course, Tali and Garrus are still the best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114804207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 38901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38784, 'last_played': 1732428345}
review: The best thing about this game is that it's done. Sure there's Andromeda and that new one they're developing, but the trilogy is done and it hasn't been expanded on in about 10 years at this point. Every moment of the trilogy that the developers want you to scream at, cry, celebrate, it's all there and it aint changing. At no point is there a threat in the near future that a moment of sincerity is going to be undercut because of some call back in the next installment or a dead character is gonna be revived for the fan service. These games are sincere because they're done, and I think we could all use that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086046965', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4915, 'last_played': 1723707732}
review:
I have played the Mass Effect series 5 or so times in my life. This was one of my favorite game series to play while growing up. Being able to play the entire series again has been insanely fun and a great use of time in my life. Excusing a couple of DLCs here and there that I wasn't able to play when I was younger, I remember this game like the back of my hand and it has been a treat to revisit.

All of this to be said; I had never played all of the DLC's in the third game and I didn't know what I was missing.

The Citadel DLC in Mass Effect 3 has easily become my favorite part of this series by far. I wish I had played it sooner. The insane switch to a more comedic, lighthearted experience in the Mass Effect universe was jarring at first, but I quickly came around to enjoy it so much. It genuinely made me laugh at times, and being able to play with characters that you haven't seen much in this game was really nostalgic in a way. The scene where you fight with everyone was really cool to experience as well. 

But I think my favorite part about this DLC had to be the Party. Being able to mingle with everyone, see how characters that never met interact with each other. My heart felt so full and happy the morning after. After I had talked to everyone with their hangovers, I felt a sense of peace and calm. Something you rarely get in this series. It felt like waking up at a sleepover with your friends, and it was a feeling that genuinely made me say to myself "Damn, I wish I didn't have to leave this moment."

The next time I play this series again, it will be for that moment. 

Amazing series. Everybody should play these games. 10/10 forever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007284599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 14990, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13852, 'last_played': 1728842647}
review:
I've never written a review on Steam before, but for the Mass Effect trilogy I'll make an exception because this game means so much to me.

Even after 15 years, the trilogy is the best and most unique thing I've ever played. I don't know of anything comparable, where 3 games build on each other directly and across the story.

That's what makes the experience so intense. You will be taken on a long journey with the Normandy crew, you laugh and cry with the characters, you try to make the right decisions and discover one of the best science fiction stories I know.

It's worth taking the time to get to know this amazing and complex world.

+ an emotional experience
+ intense and exciting story
+ cut scenes are staged like an action film
+ great squad members and characters
+ despite the serious main story, there's always plenty to laugh about (hello Citadel DLC!!)
+ many decisions / most characters can die
+ decisions made are carried over to the next game with the save
+ you create your own main character and get your own personal story
+ I like the gameplay of ME 2 + 3
+ a well-developed world with many complex and moral questions

- if you don't have HDR, the game is sometimes very dark
- EA play connection doesn't always work and sucks

author: {'steamid': '76561197996574751', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1952, 'last_played': 1734923763}
review:
One of the best, if not the best Sci-fi RPG franchises out there. This trilogy is currently on sale for less than the price of a McDonald's meal and you owe yourself to play it if you're a fan of RPG's/3rd person shooters.

Also, there are people (fake ME fans) that will tell you to skip Mass Effect 1 but don't do it. Mass Effect 1 is arguably the only actual "RPG" in the series, has the best lore/atmosphere, and the best cast.

Mass Effect 1 - Best game in the series IMO. While the shooting mechanics can be a bit jank, it's still a great game and the "fixes" in the Legendary Edition will definitely help ease newcomers to the game. This game is tragically misunderstood. It's an RPG first and a Shooter second. You're not supposed to be a god with every weapon that lands in your hands. You're supposed to level up your skills and get better with the weapons/skills your class is designed to use.. you know, typical RPG stuff. But for some reason this has really flown over peoples' heads and they just immediately label this game trash for it. 

Mass Effect 2 - 2nd best game in the trilogy. This game is more of a 3rd person shooter in the sense that it's basically a cover based shooter with cleaner mechanics but with RPG elements. The atmosphere and world building are still really good and the cast is largely fantastic. The story and main quest can be a bit disappointing because essentially 80% of the game is just you building your team and doing side stuff and the final boss is a bit of a let down.

Mass Effect 3 - Worst entry in the trilogy. It's basically a Gears of War game but in the Mass Effect universe. It's not a BAD game but it's just not a good Mass Effect game in my opinion. The game has the weakest cast and won't satisfy you if you're a fan of actual RPG's. 

Overall all these games are worth a play-through. I rate the whole trilogy 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561199384810880', 'num_games_owned': 96, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 9037, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9037, 'last_played': 1723273070}
review:
Mass Effect: Legendary Edition is the pinnacle of video game storytelling, distinguishing itself not because of grandiose scale, but due to the meticulous attention given to the individuation of its cosmos. Each planet, species, and character is endowed with a distinct ethos and pathos, contributing to an extremely rich, multi-layered narrative that's accompanied by branching reflective of the finest out there; repercussions of player choices extend far beyond immediate consequences and arise much later on in the trilogy.

Moreover, the series eschews simplistic moral binaries, opting for a game resplendent with dilemmas that are rich in moral complexity and ethical nuance, sure to gratify even the most scholarly of philosophers. With a foundation in philosophical study myself, I was deeply engrossed in the ethical quandaries and choices that permeate the narrative.

Ultimately, within the vast expanse of video game history, no narrative has achieved the depth, intricacy, and emotional resonance I encountered in Mass Effect: Legendary Edition. I consider myself exceedingly privileged to have experienced this magnum opus for the first time at the age of 25.

On a final note, this title is one of only three games that have ever succeeded in moving me to tears—a testament that, I believe, greatly surpasses any accolade I could provide.

author: {'steamid': '76561198291760714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 10611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10611, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 10611, 'last_played': 1732498316}
review:
I'd always heard about this series being good, but I always dismissed it as some horny soap opera since most just talk about the romances. But damn was I wrong. I am a sucker for good characters and their flavour text, and this game has it in abundance, all voiced too, and well, which is such a rarity. I remember hearing the end was bad, too, so I was reluctant to get into it. It's not. 

This series is timeless, especially with this edition giving it modern visuals, and I pray this doesn't get another sequel because we all know it would be absolutely terrible and a disgrace to the amazing job they did with this series. It is an experience you will likely never find anywhere else.

I went into this expecting it to be a difficult shooter and using a mage-like class instead, but after locking in the default no-magic class in the first game by mistake, I discovered an interesting truth: this series was not designed to be challenging. And don't misunderstand-- I avoid shooters like the plague because my aim is absolutely terrible. But after walking through a giant mass of enemies and shooting them one-by-one with a shotgun on Veteran, I needed combat to be more mentally stimulating and switched to the hardest difficulty, Insanity. Made the game more fun for sure. Battles were slowly feeling like just a nuisance before it, which isn't ideal. 

Regarding each game in detail:

--- 1 ---
The first game was never any trouble whatsoever, not even at the final boss. I only ever died when I was messing around running straight into them, or letting snipers shoot me in the head. That only kills you on Insanity, so you might want to play it straight off-the-bat if you want enemies to actually be threatening. You can get an achievement for sticking with it without having to restart, too. I know I regret not doing so... And you can change your class at the beginning of the next game, so consider trying the Soldier class out before resigning yourself to magic because the first game is super easy anyway. Bring Wrex and Liara to Noveria for flavour text. Use the Citadel elevators with different combinations for more. Bring Ashley and Kaidan to Virmire for the optimal experience.

--- 2 ---
In the second game, almost every boss/final stage is actually challenging, but never feels impossible... for the most part (Insanity only, wouldn't be very engaging otherwise). I play on the Steam Deck though, and taking cover is changed in this game in a way that makes it very easy to accidentally get yourself killed trying... I might just suck, though. Yet I beat the game on Insanity. Do yourself a favour and play on Insanity. As for flavour text: 
- Consider recruiting everyone first before doing sidequests by advancing the plot, as bringing people you normally get later on can make them very interesting. This is especially true when rescuing a father from a ship infested with geth-- just keep in mind, though, that there may be consequences to this that you may not realize can even exist. But they're expected to happen, FWIW. Up to you. But decide before the IFF. And don't bring Archangel to the ship if you want dialogue, they don't say anything. 
- Bring Archangel and their friend on both recruitment missions in Illium for an unusually larger amount of dialogue. The Citadel too, for a special staircase convo. Consider taking Archangel on the cab, too. Their friend has no dialogue.
- Bring Zaeed to the special missions for flavour text on the ship, if there's no one else you want to bring. Keep in mind what I mentioned earlier. 
- Bring Archangel's friend to the ritual for a peak comedy reaction. 
- Bring Miranda and your romance (if you have one) after the seeker swarms at the very end, specifically in that order, for special dialogue and to spice up the final cutscene. It might also save a life...
- The new characters don't rejoin you in the next game, they only cameo, so it's not worth save scumming if they die. Their deaths also make the next game more interesting. And everyone can die. Do with that information what you wish.

--- 3 ---
The third game is the only one that is actually designed to be difficult. On Insanity, I think some are intended to only be beatable by using heavy weapons on the ground. I'm almost certain the game never acknowledges their existence until the final battle. It's definitely still worth playing on Insanity, just make sure to look around on Palaven. There's a new roll mechanic implemented, but from my experience on Steam Deck, it is a curse. What I said before about accidentally dying very easily in the second game is even worse in the third. Want to take cover? Nah, you roll and get shot while exposed, aaand you're dead. Using a panel? Nope, roll, enemies in hiding run up and fill you with holes before you get back up, you're dead. Running? Nope, roll. Now you're dead. Vaulting? Roll. You vault after too late and get gunned down in the open like the degenerate you are. This might seem unnecessary to go through, but sometimes you have to rush through enemies to progress. The encounters can actually be really difficult, so failing a winning attempt because the game keeps making me roll was incredibly frustrating, especially because you usually die within 2 seconds on Insanity (I'm not exaggerating--and I'm playing the class intended to take hits. Do not invest in health boosts on Insanity). You can't rebind Steam Deck controls either. Playing on PC with a keyboard is the best way to play if you have that option, I think. 

I discovered a way to enjoy Insanity despite this, however, but it's undoubtedly incredibly overpowered and I have no idea how it got in. There's a shotgun called the Venom that, when charged up, one-shots a lot of enemies in the game. Not the bigger ones and bosses thankfully, but Centurions and weaker. Their health will drop fast though, so if you use it, the battles can become a fiesta running around and stalling for flavour text, which can be fairly entertaining. Just don't run ahead or you might cut some of it off. If you want to be able to beat Insanity without a doubt, the Venom guarantees it. Going back to flavour text:
- Bring the originals to the first priority mission on Tuchanka.
- If you cheated and can do this, bring both to the dreadnought. Mind this one is theoretical, this might be nothing special. It's probably what I think, though. Otherwise, bring the duo.
- Bring the duo to Grissom Academy and the asari request.
- Bring Javik to Thessia.
- Bring your romance to Eden Prime, when confronting the Leviathan, and when the robot is mandatory. Recall the ones from the second game only cameo. Priority missions don't need to be done within a timeframe, it just advances plot. That being said...
- Avoid the sidequests until you get the crew back together, minus Wrex. They don't expire until a fairly obvious point, and nothing bad happens if you stall. I'd speak to Jondum Bau last.
- Avoid the Personal Apartment until you get the crew back together, minus Wrex, and after Eden Prime. For comedic purposes, don't meet with Ashley for lunch at the Citadel until after the gathering at the Apartment.
- When you go to the final area, dog-legs says nothing when you first arrive. Take them in the battle after if you romanced them, or whoever you did. If you take dog-legs, take Scars too for maximum emotional impact. Javik doesn't say anything special in that fight.
- Some convos between characters have multiple lines before speaking to them. Walk away and back to check. Also check afterward. "Support" ones loop, don't feel rushed to choose.
- Take your time between battles, there's no negative consequence. You might get ambushed at one point... but flavour text.

Tl;dr this game is very good if you care about story the combat segments are very very easy play on insanity try soldier then switch when importing

Just play it

author: {'steamid': '76561198108200473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 7476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7476, 'last_played': 1728839444}
review:
I can't explain how genuinely I wish that I could have played Mass Effect as a teen. This story is breathtaking and heartbreaking and there are so many phenomenal moments that left me openly crying in front of my screen. I leave the final game with my heart both full and mourning. Only wanting to spend a hundred more hours with the crew from the Normandy at the very least.

It's so funny ... all my friends begged me to play it, saying it was something I'd love. I wished I listened to them sooner. I'd heard how the ending went, I used to watch all the Shepard/Vakarian scenes on YouTube as the games came out. And despite knowing so much, there were a lot of secrets still to be had within the game, and the final moments of ME3 still hit so hard that I could only sit there and sniffle and watch through my tears at the impact of Shepard's final sacrifice had on the galaxy. 

I don't play games for combat really, so I'm not really up in arms at how annoying the first game is to play. I feel like the Legendary Edition fixed a lot of the issues I had when I tried my hand at playing the first game all those years ago. And I'm so glad because it made it so enjoyable that I finally got past the place I had always gotten stuck. 

Quite literally one of my favorite stories I've ever had the joy of interacting with ... I can't give it enough praise. All I can say is that I will come back to this game over and over again in my own lifetime to relive the legend of Shepard. <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198055887506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 6178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1980, 'last_played': 1718284789}

As much as i love Knights of the Old Republic and Dragon Age, Mass Effect trilogy without a doubt Bioware's best creation, unmatched sci-fi adventure that inherited world building and character development this studio was loved for. 
Getting package of 3 games with 40! dlc on 90% discount is biggest steal Citadel ever seen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198169896053', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 8941, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6582, 'last_played': 1715548408}
review:
At 110 hours and barely even starting ME3, I can confidently say I've thoroughly enjoyed this purchase so far. I'd never been able to play the games as they came out, due to finances and never having a system to play (cheap laptops can only do so much, as well), but a little over a year ago, I purchased my very first gaming PC and began to invest in some of the games I'd always heard were amazing, but never got the chance to play.... and Mass Effect was one of those series I missed out on. 

I've since travelled full star systems and hopped relays to new ones, probed the hell out of planets and asteroids for resources to strengthen my ship, fought aliens and hivemind robots alike, saved the galaxy several times, and fallen in love thrice with the personalities of the characters around me on my journeys. I've enjoyed this franchise so much, it's brought my love of sci-fi back to the forefront of my brain, and has renewed a hyperfixation I'd lost for some time. 

The game runs well, and while there are a few bugs, that's kind of to be expected as an older set of games. ME1 came out in 2007, and it can be seen in the way the character models look, but if you get into modding and download some texture packs for their skintones and whatnot, I promise you that It'll be even more enjoyable as it'll keep up with a lot of the play style of story rich rpgs today, and look visually appealing. It's definitely worth the purchase, even if you've played it before on console! I also really enjoy the voice acting, and the soundtrack is fantastic at setting a scene (even passively; the galaxy travel map music lives in my brain rent-free). The environments are delightfully varied, and I have really enjoyed that my choices from each game has carried into the next. Overall, I would highly recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198150241048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2914, 'last_played': 1724614173}
review:
I just finished the trilogy in 2024 and boy was it a ride. Having so many meaningful and impactful choices to make, so many memorable companions throughout the games, and a grand story being shaped by you.

This is easily one of the best moments of story writing in gaming as a whole. I thoroughly enjoyed every part of it, even the somewhat controversial ending of the third game.

I was expecting a third-person RPG shooter, and instead got one of the most memorable and enjoyable stories in gaming. Overall I would recommend these games to everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198277407443', 'num_games_owned': 121, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 8594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8594, 'last_played': 1723479979}
review:
[h1] MASTERPIECE [/h1]

It is sad...
It is sad, that there are no games like this created nowadays. 
This game is the ultimate masterpiece of a story-telling shooter RPG, giving you many different opportunities to shape the story according to your own will, with all the small decisions carrying weight not only in one game but through the whole trilogy. 
This game is, and will forever be, my favourite game of all time in the space-science-fiction area, and no other game like this will ever be created in the genre.

The weakest part of this game is the shooting, though it's still great imho.

I completed all 3 games 5+ times, as I own the original hard copy on the EA (Origin) launcher. I bought this remastered version and it was stunning, beautiful, and simply perfect. The full 100% completionist with all Steam achievements and nearly 100% in all 3 games took me something around 150 hours.

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS MASTERPIECE

12/10 at least

author: {'steamid': '76561198115774428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 7728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7728, 'last_played': 1723227707}
review: Loved this trilogy!! The EA launcher never really bothers me.....but I'm old, so not a lot bothers me any more. Playing each game all the way through, really made the differences between them, very evident. I loved ME1, even though it was a bit clunky in many ways......and simple.....but there was beauty in the simplicity. The graphics got better as the games went along, and the controls etc were refined each time. I imported my male Shepard character into each game, so starting ME3 with a leveled character, lots of good gear, and established relationships with the other characters, really made the whole thing magic. At the end of ME3, I thought long and hard about the final decision, and I was perfectly happy with the outcome. This trilogy is a MUST-PLAY.....even in 2024.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201014223', 'num_games_owned': 351, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 32903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28180, 'last_played': 1733390673}
review:
The first time I played Mass Effect 1 I thought it was boring as hell and quit playing after only the first few hours. Some time later I picked it back up again, completed it, and enjoyed the hell out of it. I followed that up with ME 2, then 3. I played them several years ago through EA Play. The writing isn't always the greatest, the action isn't always the greatest. but I've had immense fun with this series and I highly recommend it.

TLDR: Yes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090489484', 'num_games_owned': 2393, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 8456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8456, 'last_played': 1718290832}
review:
Each game has it's own flaws. 1 is sometimes clunky and rough around the edges, 2 has an obscure system that brings unwanted consequences to uninformed "choices" (uninformed as in impossible to know without having played beforehand or reading a guide), 3 has a drop in writing quality and cohesion...

author: {'steamid': '76561198037233972', 'num_games_owned': 1186, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4856, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1725185761}
review:
[h1]Mass Effect Legendary Edition: The Sky’s No Limit[/h1]

[h2]TL;DR version[/h2]

☑ Very deep lore
☑ Incredible storytelling
☑ Outstanding soundtrack
☑ Charismatic characters
☑ Intuitive gameplay (even if it starts feeling old nowadays)
☑ Improved graphics (but same as gameplay)
☑ Currently on 90% sale, omfg what are you waiting for???

19/20 Recommended!

[h2]”I have some time to read a complete review” version[/h2]

Context: I’ve bought this trilogy 3 times already: PC (EA), PS, PC (Steam). Saw the 90% sale and thought it could be cool to buy this “new” version and do it all again. So, I did.

Even though it’s on sale now, it's important to note that the regular price can be quite steep. However, given the enhancements and the convenience of having all three games and their DLCs in one package, it's a worthy investment for both newcomers and long-time fans of the series imo.

To go into further details, here’s why I think everything in these games is top-level:

[h3]✓ Deep and Engaging Lore[/h3]

The most captivating aspect of the Mass Effect series is its rich and immersive lore. From the intricate history of the different alien races to the complex political landscape, every detail is meticulously crafted, making the universe feel alive and dynamic. If you’re a fan of sci-fi, the depth of the world-building will keep you engrossed for hours on end.

[h3]✓ Incredible Storytelling[/h3]

Mass Effect's narrative is one of its strongest points. The trilogy offers a compelling story arc that spans all three games, with decisions in the first game impacting the story in the latter ones. This interconnectivity creates a sense of continuity and consequence rarely seen in other games (granted, I haven’t played much lately). The plot twists, character arcs, and moral dilemmas ensure a memorable experience.

[h3]✓ Outstanding Soundtrack[/h3]

The music in Mass Effect is nothing short of phenomenal. Composers like Jack Wall and Sam Hulick have crafted a soundtrack that perfectly complements the epic scale of the game's narrative. From the hauntingly beautiful melodies to the adrenaline-pumping battle themes, the music enhances every moment of the game. My guilty pleasure is to stay on the galaxy map, watching the planets and listening to the background theme, imagining how many years it would take my spaceship to reach those distant worlds. This ambient music not only sets the mood but also deepens the sense of immersion, making the universe feel even more expansive and real.

[h3]✓ Charismatic Characters[/h3]

One of the defining features of Mass Effect is its diverse cast of characters. Each character has a unique personality, backstory, and development arc. The relationships you build with your squadmates are pivotal to the story, and the emotional connections you form are genuinely impactful. Whether it’s the loyalty missions or the casual conversations aboard the Normandy, these interactions are deeply satisfying.

[h3]✓ Intuitive Gameplay[/h3]

The gameplay mechanics, while slightly dated, still hold up well. The blend of third-person shooting with RPG elements creates an engaging and strategic combat system. The inclusion of different classes and abilities allows for varied playstyles, keeping the gameplay fresh. The only downside is that some mechanics, especially in the first game, might feel a bit clunky compared to modern standards, but you can use mods to counter these (minor) annoying aspects of the games. It's also worth mentioning that the game itself can feel a bit slow at times, compared to more recent games.

[h3]✓ Improved Graphics[/h3]

The remastered graphics in the Legendary Edition are a significant upgrade from the original releases. Environments are more detailed, character models are enhanced, and the overall visual fidelity is greatly improved. However, while the graphics are better, they still can't fully mask the fact that the games are over a decade old (even almost 2 decades for the first game).

[h3]✓ Great Value for Money (on Sale)[/h3]

Currently, the Mass Effect Legendary Edition is on a 90% sale, making it an absolute steal. For the amount of content and the quality of the experience, this is an offer that’s hard to pass up. That said, it's worth mentioning that even at full price, the trilogy provides countless hours of entertainment and replayability, making it a worthwhile investment for any fan of the genre.

[h3]Conclusion ✓✓✓✓✓[/h3]

If you’re a sci-fi fan, love deep storytelling, and enjoy character-driven narratives, the Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a must-play. Despite some dated gameplay mechanics (that can be countered with mods), the overall experience is unparalleled. The combination of improved graphics, engaging gameplay, fantastic soundtrack and a rich, immersive universe makes this trilogy a timeless classic. Grab it while it’s on sale, and embark on an unforgettable journey across the galaxy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198094887252', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4474, 'last_played': 1624468045}

author: {'steamid': '76561198048647305', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 8814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8814, 'last_played': 1722335061}
review:
Mass Effect, needs no introduction... 
Is what many would say when asked to speak of it. 
It is a giant in the RPG genre, and I know many who consider it to be their favorite franchise. 
I do not know many games, where different choices pass onto and influence the following game and ITS choices in meaningful ways. 
It's not something that happens really.
What developer would have the courage, and gall to create a game, knowing the fulfillment of choices made, might never come to fruition if the franchise fails. Such a tailored experience is almost doomed to fall through on paper. 
Bioware did it though. 
And what a massive achievement that was, and still is. 
That being said Mass Effect was never perfect, EA certainly didn't make it better on that part. 
Whether you prefer the original RPG system in 1 or the compact more fast-paced ARPG system in 2 and 3 there is enjoyment to be had. In the end we were/are all here for the story, the characters and the universe. 


I bought Mass Effect legendary edition for 3 euro, prior to this I had completed Mass Effect 2 with no DLC's exclusively. When I first played 2, Characters were gone. I didn't even know I was missing so many of them or so much knowledge from 1. 
Playing the full trilogy from start to end....  
It's an Experience you take with you, truly.
For that alone it needs your consideration.
 There is also no shame in doing what you need to make the dry parts palatable, install mods if you have to. 
 <!-- Hack skip and fast probing were a must for me >_<  --> 

IN SHORT 

Buy it on sale to spite EA
Discover the mysteries of the galaxy 
Punch the reporter if you're a chad 
There's no Shepard without Vakarian  
Write the review because you love the devs not the company
Be happy, whatever choices you make. 
What matters is that you made the right choice in playing this game. 
Thank you.
