author: {'steamid': '76561198190380543', 'num_games_owned': 692, 'num_reviews': 666, 'playtime_forever': 18349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18349, 'last_played': 1730056179}
review:
Mass Effect Legendary Edition remasters the entire Mass Effect trilogy and its DLC is a single package, making it the ultimate way to experience these amazing games.
Mass Effect, given its age, received a lot of improvements to make it feel more modern. But despite that, it remains the weakest game in the trilogy. Its biggest strength is without a doubt the story, characters, and overall presentation. Despite being part of a continuous trilogy, the story here is contained with a satisfactory ending, without baiting you for the next entry. Well, it actually baits you, but in a good way, because you enjoyed it and want to see more. It’s a sci-fi adventure in space, with great lore and characters, both the major NPC’s and even smaller ones. The game also has lots of different dialogue options and choices to make, which carry over to the other titles. In a nutshell, you can be a Paragon, making the altruistic and “best” choices, or a Renegade, by being a jackass. While in the end you’ll probably want to do a Paragon playthrough for the save import, I highly recommend you try a Renegade one before that. The game is just way funnier that way.
The gameplay, unfortunately, is just meh. It’s a third person shooter, aided by 2 squad members. There’s some special abilities and “superpowers”, but overall, the shooting mechanics are nothing special. Still, I wouldn’t say they’re bad. There’s a lot of RPG elements, and those thankfully fare a lot better. It’s the usual stuff, getting XP to level up, getting and equipping better and better loot, and upgrading your abilities. Since the game is set in space, there’s also a lot of optional exploration to do. Unfortunately, it’s also meh. Basically, you drive a vehicle through barren planets collecting stuff and entering recycled buildings with fights to complete side quests. It’s mostly boring. Some planet sky vistas are pretty, though. But there’s no denying that exploring planets is mostly a chore, unfortunately.
Mass Effect 2 just blows the first game away. It is so much better in almost everything, making it one of my favorite games of all time. So, how exactly it is better than the original? Once again, where the game really excels is in its story, characters and presentation, although here it’s a bit different. The original title focused on introducing this universe while telling a mostly contained story. This time, the main story is shorter and feels a bit filler, to be honest. Instead, the game this time focuses on its characters, telling a lot of different, more standalone stories that are more self-contained. The main game revolves around gathering a lot of crew members to attempt a suicide mission, tied with the main story. And for that, you’ll need to recruit them, get involved with them, and optionally you can further help them with their personal problems, in the form of loyalty missions. While they’re optional, the game advises you to do them, and their quality is the same as the main game. Basically, they’re optional main missions, instead of side quests. So, most of the game is focused on its characters, and of course, they’re varied and interesting. And there’s a lot of them, 12 in your squad, your ship crew and a lot more NPC’s. This is what Bioware used to do best, and you can fully see it here. The morality system returns, and this time there’s even some real time “interrupts”, which are awesome to perform. Once again, even if in the end you’ll want a Paragon playthrough with the “best” choices to import your save, I highly suggest a Renegade playthrough first, it’s funnier and perhaps more impactful. Speaking of save import, you’ll see a lot of your choices made in the original game reflected here. Most of them just impact small stuff, but together they make you see why the series is designed as a trilogy. Also, a lot of choices (and lack of) throughout the game will have an impact in the final suicide mission, which even today few games can reach that level.
So, the story and characters are better, but what you’ll notice is the greatly improved gameplay. While it may feel a bit standard for the third person shooter genre, it is miles better than the original. The gameplay is completely redesigned, and it’s basically a solid third person shooter. Again, in the end it’s nothing special for the genre, but it’s great after playing the original. There’s a solid cover mechanic, and an ammo system, which I disliked. Classes and powers are rebalanced. It’s just a way more solid experience. Another thing I noticed was that a lot of the RPG elements from the original are streamlined or just gone. It is more of a shooter and less of an RPG. But I didn’t mind it much, especially because I loved the leap in gameplay from the original. Another big omission is the Mako planet exploration. Instead of improving it, they just removed it. Instead, you’ll have a planet scanning minigame, which is addictive at first but quickly gets repetitive. You’ll need it to find side quests, which are basically mini missions, and resources to get upgrades. This is perhaps my main complaint about this game. I preferred to have improved Mako explorations, which seemed like a natural improvement for a sequel instead of just removing it, but the game has so much content that in the end it isn’t a big deal, just a missed opportunity. The soundtrack is also just as great. It was great in the original, it is also great this time.
Mass Effect 3 plays similarly to 2, for the most part. Perhaps the biggest difference is in the story and its scope. 2 was focused on recruiting and bonding with your crew. This time it’s about an epic galactic war, where you aid the various alien races, and get resources to help create the only weapon that can defeat the enemy forces. It also brings closure to some of the biggest lore plots, like the genophage and the war between the quarians and the geth. And of course, most choices are up to you. You can be a Paragon hero, or a Renegade jackass (still worth a playthrough for that, the Renegade options are way funnier).
The graphics are slightly improved, and the soundtrack is good as usual. What the game does best is making you feel that you are in the middle of an epic galactic war. The endings are decent, but the problem is that for a huge trilogy focused on player choice, most of them just translate to resources, affecting your ending options and some slightly different scenes in there. However, don’t forget the plot closures, that act as semi-endings of some sort.
This game also includes one of the best DLCs in videogame history, the Citadel, and it has everything that a final game in a trilogy like this should have: a lighthearted story focused on comedy to give us some change, an amazing party with all alive crew members that you prepare and throw, with plenty of interactions (the best part) and even an arena for more replayability with end game combat, if that’s you thing, with more squad mates joining you for those battles. And the more you are invested in this universe and its characters, the better it will be. It’s just that good.
Despite its rough past on Steam, where you couldn’t get all the 3 games and DLCs on Steam, I’m glad that finally everything is conveniently available in one title, making those issues a thing of the past. And for me, if you count this as one game, it’s one of the best of all time, and of course, an easy recommendation. The cherry on top is that it’s often dirt-cheap during sales. You must install and use the EA app, which is annoying, but to be honest, for the most part I forgot it was there. I didn’t find it to be intrusive, but that doesn’t mean I’m ok with third party launchers. I still hate them.

author: {'steamid': '76561199278246660', 'num_games_owned': 289, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 934, 'last_played': 1726477891}
review:
Only in Mass Effect can you have an epic standoff and still be cool-headed enough to make dialogue choices. It's like trying to defuse a bomb while casually ordering a coffee: 'Yeah, I'll take a latte, two sugars, and... uh... just cut any wire, they're all red, right?'

The game's blend of action and thoughtful decision-making is what makes it so unique and special

author: {'steamid': '76561198193197510', 'num_games_owned': 86, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 38676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19332, 'last_played': 1717012642}
review:
From my personal favorite to least favorite:

[b] Mass Effect [/b]

The first game in Legendary Edition is absolutely monumental. Its epic story and breathtaking presentation bring every emotional fluctuation I would hope for in such a heroic space adventure. And the music! There are all sorts of games with great music, but very few if not none of them can reach the quality in this game. The revelation of Citadel is no less an enchanted grandeur than that time Frodo enters Rivendell. Not to mention the final battle and from the wreckage scene, the latter being one of the most powerful moments I have ever experienced in video games.

Sure, there are lots of empty worlds and repetitive level designs, but the diverse scenery is actually enjoyable and brings plenty of Star Trek vibes, that is, if the player is not OCD over every collectible. Fortunately, most of them just give money (you will have much surplus without them) and a little experience (can't hit max level in one playthrough anyway), so you won't be missing anything. Nevertheless, there is hardly a more rewarding moment when all these efforts culminate in the final events. If all comes down to one thing, this game delivers a good adventure, which is just a bit too good.

[b] Mass Effect 3 [/b]

My first complaint is its inconsistent production quality. How can a game boasts some of the best narrative executions, but at the same time being so ridiculous in audio implementation? And where are the great soundtracks? Even the reused ones from the first game feel out-of-place constantly. Don't even start on details like distant husks in tutorial mission, yikes!

The biggest letdown IMO however, is the lack of credibility in world-building contexts. I can sense how much effort the writers make to convey the desperate and people banding together in overall atmosphere, but suddenly every civilian/soldier/refugee from all species start loving each other and talking honor and ready to sacrifice? It just seems too fairy-tale and ideal. It really should take notes from Halo: Reach, which had very similar story contexts and was released two years earlier than this game, but it portrayed a more authentic scape without sacrificing any of its romanticism. 

That being said, Mass Effect 3 undoubtedly excels at certain defining elements that makes this series special. The heart-stirring cinematic stroytelling, the rich interactions between crewmates, and the exceptionally memorable side characters; what this series sell on, this game does the best. By comparison, the previously mentioned flaws would seem trivial. With the addition of a more sophisticated combat system and upscaled level design, this game elevates the brand to a new level of excellence.

[b] Mass Effect 2 [/b]

I enjoyed this games as much as the other two games, in fact I probably spent longest hours in this game. The problem is, I am constantly reminded by the game that I am manipulated by it. 

I liked it in Mass Effect 1 and 3 and many other RPGs, that I met all different companions under vast varieties of circumstances, and discovered why/how we are going to work together in the process. It is an enticing and natural flow, just how I imagined an adventure. I liked it less when being thrown a list of people to hire, without even knowing them. Why these particular people are on the list? There is very little explanation in this game, and for some of those people, I still don't understand even after finishing the game several times.

Also I enjoyed the immersion when my choices have moral consequences. But it is much less enjoyable when forced onto a moral compass without a compelling context, while all choices are unpleasant or extreme not of necessity. In this game, there are too many such instances. [spoiler] Work for a boss everyone hates while being verbally incapable to explain; kidnap a girl to protect her while required to hate someone opposing it out of good intention; promise to help a friend but must betray him to save some people. [/spoiler] The pattern is that, the game makes it seems the players are intentionally making choices of being a zealot or a sociopath while there is not really a "different" path, and then it judges the players either way. On the opposite side, picking from my favorites with comparable scope and release date, Dishonored (2012) made itself the exemplar of "make our choices and take what comes"; then in 2015, the Witcher 3 perfected the meaning of "I’d rather not choose at all". In both cases, the games provide enough compelling contexts and reasonable divergence for the players to stay true to their characters, only to be judged by themselves from the within. Although Mass Effect 2 should not take the blame for being released a little sooner, its choice-matter narrative part is hardly an enchantment to me. [spoiler] But Mordin’s story is really good [/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198332810455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 14918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12372, 'last_played': 1709892528}
review:
Mass Effect Legendary Edition: A Stellar Compilation with Heartfelt Additions

The Legendary Edition of Mass Effect is a breathtaking journey through the captivating universe of Commander Shepard. Packed with visual enhancements, gameplay improvements, and all previously released DLC, it's a definitive experience for both series veterans and newcomers.

Notable DLCs:

Lair of the Shadow Broker: This DLC dives deep into the enigmatic world of the elusive Shadow Broker, offering intense action, gripping narrative, and a chance to reconnect with Liara T'Soni. The added cinematic flair and impactful decisions make it a must-play.

Citadel: A love letter to fans, Citadel brings humor, camaraderie, and heart to the forefront. It's a perfect blend of lighthearted banter and emotional reunions, allowing players to forge deeper connections with their squadmates in a farewell celebration.

Omega: Immerse yourself in the gritty underworld of Omega alongside Aria T'Loak. This action-packed expansion adds layers to the Cerberus threat while offering a unique perspective on the galaxy's darker corners.

Jack's Romance:

For players seeking a passionate and tumultuous romance, Jack's storyline delivers. The scarred and rebellious biotic powerhouse opens up layers of vulnerability, making her a compelling partner. Navigating through Jack's tough exterior to discover the complexities within adds a poignant touch to Shepard's personal journey.

In the Legendary Edition, the visual enhancements bring these emotional moments to life, allowing players to experience Jack's romance with a newfound depth. Whether revisiting the romance or discovering it for the first time, Jack's storyline remains a poignant highlight in the Mass Effect trilogy, contributing to the emotional tapestry of the entire saga.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054004608', 'num_games_owned': 3453, 'num_reviews': 475, 'playtime_forever': 9430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9430, 'last_played': 1648247515}
review:
Mass Effect Legendary Edition - Man...what a game. From the original stand alone games to a game that houses all 3, this is THE Mass Effect experience.

If you are familiar with Mass Effect, this one has all the DLCs included so now you have another reason to play the game again!

If you're not, not to worry, no spoilers here. All you need to know is that choices have an impact in this series. Some are small, some are huge, but it all depends on how what you choose.

This will be a very brief overview of what each game has to offer:

Mass Effect 1 - Introduction to the characters, environments, terminology, mechanics and the overall universe that is Mass Effect. You get used to how the powers work and how your weapons and shields handle during firefights. You scan/mine minerals directly on the planets with the Mako (never really liked this because it just felt flimsy and ragdolly, although in ME LE they did improve the mechanics a bit). Paragon (good) and Renegade (evil) has been introduced and each choice always has one or the other (sometimes both) impact on how good or evil you are.

Mass Effect 2 - A return of your character and the combat mechanics have been seriously upgraded to be even smoother and combos of powers have been introduced. They have swapped out the overheating mechanic with an ammo based system for your weapons and it works better in my honest opinion. You have access to scan and mine a world from orbit without having to drop with the Mako (it's been removed in this one) which I find a lot better! Lore has been improved and is even more solid noow. You meet new characters, meet old ones again and make even more decisions. New weapons and armour to use and equip. Customization to armour has been added. Bigger enemies and more fleshed out backstories of characters in the DLCs.

Mass Effect 3 - The one where everything ties back together again. New and old characters, combat is even tighter and powers are fleshed out more, but relatively stay close to what is in ME2. Characters are also more developed and you really start to love these characters for their personalities. The DLC Citadel brought tears to my eyes because it was an ode to what has happened to these characters and how they have grown over the years to where they are now and how your choices have affected them. Amazing attention to detail and an amazing story that concludes.

I can't stress enough how much of an amazing game this is. Everything in this game clicks extremely well. The Paragon/Renegade system works, the dialogue option wheel was patented for this game and it shows! It works amazingly well and you learn it super fast! Top left is ALWAYS Paragon (in blue) and bottom left is ALWAYS Renegade (in red). Top right is good response, middle right is neutral and bottom right is sarcastic/evil response. This game's art design, the music, the story, the characters, the DLCs even! Everything of this game just works extremely well.

If you haven't tried this yet and you're looking for a reason, this is it. It's hands down, one of my top 3 favourite all-time games. I even added some extra mods for Quality of Life stuff and added armour and weapons and graphics enhancements.

This is what made BioWare such a great company and it's such a shame they didn't stick to this formula. Solid 11/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150988648', 'num_games_owned': 153, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 8998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8998, 'last_played': 1733015728}
review: Has one of the greatest story lines of any game. Your decisions carry over between games, and there there are mods for nearly anything you could want. All for $5 since it's on sale all the time. Don't think, just buy it and you won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008502070', 'num_games_owned': 589, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 14849, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14849, 'last_played': 1716641773}
review:
The worst part about this trilogy for me, is that I find it hard to imagine anything else ever coming close to it. The game mechanics are nothing to write home about, and the plot can be a bit formulaic at times, but the characters are absolutely stellar. The characters in this trilogy made me smile, laugh, and cry more than every other game I've played combined. Mass Effect will always have a special place in my heart as the only game series that actually made me burst into tears over a fictional character, and I will always remember Priority: Tuchanka for being the most narratively satisfying quest ever written.

I'll leave you off with the lyrics to a song that a certain character sings during one of the most memorable moments in the series:

Let the moon's shining light
Light two lovers with it's rays
Though I know that dawn will set
Us on course for separate ways
I will hold this night in memory
For all my living days

author: {'steamid': '76561198169133553', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 11710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2792, 'last_played': 1726776491}
review:
Condenses the entire mass effect trilogy into a single package.
Got this for 5 quid on sale, might as well have pirated it.

Initially I was going to stick with the original release for my next playthrough, but I ended up giving it a try due to the sale.

Legendary edition, compared to the original version, has way more modding options.
Gameplay-wise the games are the same except for LE1, which had the combat system greatly improved. 
The classic combat was serviceable, but not that good, this version feels much more responsive now.

https://www.nexusmods.com/masseffectlegendaryedition/mods/1500
Mods like these were the first things I installed for MELE, since its biggest flaw is that the technology being used is superior, but you can very clearly tell the design team is different and much less talented than the original team who made the game. A lot of the lighting is much more washed out and soulless, but you can correct it with mods like MELLO that preserve the original artstyle while still giving you the enhanced textures and gameplay.


TL;DR:
Gameplay in ME1 is enhanced, lots more mods than the original versions, and puts all of the DLC in the base game so you don't have to go faffing about on EA's websites. 
Pinnacle Station from ME1 isn't in the game which is lame. 
But that's honestly forgiveable since after playing it in the OG version on my last playthru I can 100% confirm it's just a glorified arena.

Biggest flaw by far is the inferior lighting which makes the game look plasticy and soulless, but if you're willing to install some mods and the ME3Tweaks manager, you can rectify these errors.


Overall; wait for it to go on sale, and play with mods.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983155187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 4885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1467, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1736617279}
review:
TLDR Masterpiece. One of, if not THE, best sci fi action game series of the xbox360/PS3 era. Recommended at full price, its a steal for sub $10 prices.
I played all these way back when they originally released and would even recommend the original versions to purists. However, IMO these updates are amazing. So far I have not encountered issues of any kinda, just lots of graphical update beauty. I couldn't find references to cut content online, so I assume its all there and more. If anything changes, I will update.
Currently playing on Insanity and its pretty easy.  If you're a modern gamer looking for a challenge, you might be disappointed. Play it mainly for the story and the retro gameplay/exploration loop. I would also recommend all the additional media, especially the novels, and reading all the codex entries as they appear for additional lore.
This is a game you enjoy slowly at a pace set by the game. Don't try to blaze through it.
Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198141320850', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 4959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4959, 'last_played': 1712282444}
review:
I loved this game! Ever since I started playing this game I was hooked by the story! You can see that the game is already old by looking at the game's movement and graphics.
When playing ME1, ME2 and ME3 I became more and more engaged in the game. You can see clear improvements from one game to the other, so in my opinion, anyone who likes Mass effect 1 will definitely like the other two too! Not to forget that this bundle contains 3 games with more than 40 DLCS. This game can be played between 60 Hours and 136 Hours! Which is a lot for a game that can be bought for 5,99€. When this game goes on discount it becomes an excellent option for anyone that wanna experience this game!!

10/10★

I'll be keeping an eye on possible promotions for the other game from the franchise :)

review:

[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198103186740', 'num_games_owned': 449, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 25925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12008, 'last_played': 1721282057}

author: {'steamid': '76561198813448787', 'num_games_owned': 156, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2674, 'last_played': 1720393515}
review:
First time playing this franchise and as a gamer of 15 or more years I cannot believe I slept on this ABSOLUTE MASTERPIECE, if your thinking about picking it up then do it! 

The world-building is insane on par with games like Cyberpunk and The Witcher 3 if not more in-depth in my opinion. The story is just legendary and it speaks for itself in terms of awards. The RPG elements like decisions are one of the key aspects to this game and it's one reason which makes the game so incredibly memorable, especially when you can import your character/save into all 3 games so ultimately you end up with a Shepard who you've gotten to know for 50 plus hours alongside all your companions. The gameplay is surprisingly fun too in ME1 and ME2 with the "companion system" being done the best I've ever seen. 

*Disclaimer I have just completed ME2 at the time of writing this review and I cannot wait to start my Journey on ME3. Part of me is excited and the other part is feeling kinda sad as I know I'm getting closer to the end of something I've gotten so invested into. 

A Captivating Story, Mesmerising World building and Addictive gameplay. An experience  I cannot wait to tell friends about and this is all before playing ME3.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080729844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 13338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13338, 'last_played': 1726241635}
review:
If you haven't played these games before, this is the best way to conveniently experience them. I'd give this a stronger recommendation if Mass Effect 3's multiplayer were included. But this is still a solid set of games overall. It includes most of the post-launch content for each game. All three games can be breezed through in a short amount of time if you just want to focus on the story, or they can take a while if you're interested in doing all the side content.

Mass Effect 1 has the best main story, Mass Effect 2 has the best side stories, and Mass Effect 3 has the best combat.

Downsides:
- EA App required. 
- Some stuff can get lost when transferring saves between games. I'd recommend using a save editor to ensure things are going as intended.

author: {'steamid': '76561199065140794', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 7709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7047, 'last_played': 1733260701}
review:
My favorite moment in the trilogy is when Jeff "Joker" Moreau says "it's joking time!" and smashes the bad guys - and this actually happens in the game! Insane, right? But seriously, this is one of those stories that you wish would never end. Play all three in order and explore as much content as possible and you'll feel like you've lived another life

I am Commander Shepard, and this is my favorite science fiction media franchise ever

author: {'steamid': '76561199388672440', 'num_games_owned': 175, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 10654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10654, 'last_played': 1733867305}
review:
Playing this trilogy for the third time felt like meeting a friend you haven't seen in years. When i first played these games 7 years ago i had never played an RPG before so i didn't know what was going on for the most part. The first game was good but everything clicked when we got to Virmire. That whole mission from the difficult decisions to the big reveals and character moments made the first mass effect special to me and made me fall in love with RPGs.

In my opinion whats at the heart of this series like any good Bioware RPG are the characters. From the moment you meet them, to how they change and the culmination of their arcs based on your choices, they are what makes the trilogy so special. My favourite part of the games isn't the combat or any single mission (I do love a lot of them) it's walking through your ship and talking to every member of your squad and see how they are doing. That's why The Citadel DLC works so well. It's a love letter to everything great about the series and what makes it so special.

The main story is good in all three games (although its barely there in ME2) and very enjoyable with it's twists and turns. What Sets it apart is the choices you make. They might be small choices that affect a small thing or major ones that carry their weight in later games each choice whether small or big has a consequence you see later and makes the story all the more personal. It can be as big as killing a companion in the first game so that an event plays out differently in the third or as small as meeting someone you saved before. You can even kill most of your crew and have a shit third game where barely anyone is there but it's your choices and it makes them special. The culmination of every arc and issue introduced in the first game is determined by your actions and in my opinion makes ME3 as a whole The ending rather than the final 15 minutes of the game.

If you are here for the combat its not really the main focus. Even with the changes to ME1 it can feel clunky and i tried to avoid it as much a i could. ME2 becomes more action focused but ME3 is what makes the combat really work. Weapons feel different and powerful, the encounters are balanced and even on instanity it's fun which is what really matters. Your class can make a difference in your abilities and the guns you can use but the three classes i played as all felt fun in their own way and it doesn't hold you back from enjoying the games.

If you like RPGs or other Bioware games or just want a fun story and a memorable journey give this trilogy a try. You might grow to love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057687775', 'num_games_owned': 9207, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 9489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9402, 'last_played': 1716007446}
review: What a story. BioWare really nailed it with this series. I've done four runs with the original release and my first with Legendary. There is a lot of content here. Is this edition perfect? No. What EA didn't, modders did. From bug fixing, restoring lost DLC, and other content, this is what Legendary should have been. I will continue to revisit years to come. Note: At the time of this review, Steam has this at 90% off - what a steal!

author: {'steamid': '76561198392671248', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 15332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4646, 'last_played': 1730278243}
review: Mass Effect™ Legendary Edition: an interstellar journey where I saved the galaxy while flirting with aliens. Who knew the survival of the universe depended on my flirting and strategy skills? A must-read for any budding commander with a cosmic sense of humor!"

author: {'steamid': '76561198037589489', 'num_games_owned': 616, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 11600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11600, 'last_played': 1709180897}
review: Legendary Edition, is perfect name for this trilogy. It is Legendary. And it is not just nostalgia talking. All three games have amazing story, characters, lore, visuals (yes even ME1 thanks to LE upgrades), gameplay, music. All of those aspects can still rival majority of new games. It is not perfect of course and every entry has its up and down, but even then, there are always other aspects of the game that outweigh the parts where the game is lacking. This was an issue especially for Mass Effect 1, but thanks to LE upgrades, it can now proudly stand beside the others. It might be still a little bit rough for first time players, but please endure. It will get better until amazing. Give the game a chance and you won't regret it. It is well worth the full price even today.

author: {'steamid': '76561199122407581', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 14603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14188, 'last_played': 1728585217}

author: {'steamid': '76561198002893566', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 9532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9532, 'last_played': 1713048511}
review:
Best trilogy in anything ever, maybe save the original Star Wars trilogy which is on par with ME. The ending sours the journey a bit, but what a journey it is. One of the handful pieces of media that have made me cry in my adult age, and leave me in a depressive state after the ending because of all the emotions it makes you feel. 

I'm guessing the LE will be a project every few years from now on. Simply the best game series ever made, and possibly one of the best pieces of media ever too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198869141715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 18712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16028, 'last_played': 1731981545}
review:
I find this game to be a rather profound experience. It is unlike anything we have now or likely ever will. Despite some issues regarding story telling and mechanics it seems to be one of the last great AAA "rpg" games out there with a wonderful cast of characters you will find very easy to form lasting connections with and a compelling story line you will find yourself eager to see to its end. Have the patience to truly listen and be a part of the world and you'll see it for the worthwhile experience it is. 

8.9 - 9.4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198046378367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7999, 'last_played': 1730135594}
review: The games are great. I didn't engage with the combat that much (played on easiest difficulty), but the story is already enough. In the end I liked 2 the least (I know others like it the most), but it was really close. In my opinion 1 has the best narrative, even though it is quite straightforward, and has most RPG elements, which I like. 2 has great companion side missions, but the main story is quite week. 3 has good story and some very strong moments. I cried 7 times during it. And the ending is also not THAT bad, as some people say.

author: {'steamid': '76561199089454839', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3005, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2955, 'last_played': 1722631291}
review:
Figured it's been about 10 years since I last touched this series and want to go back and experience it again. Summer break was when I first played the first and second game and thought it would be a great nostalgia kick to come back during the summer!

This trilogy is one of the best ever made, and definitely deserves a play through if you have not done so yet. Do not listen to these idiots complaining about the EA client, these are the same people who complained about EA taking over for Mass Effect 2 onward, to then now praise the second entry to be the best in the trilogy. The game(s) just need the client to boot the game up, you don't need to do anything with it other than maybe make an account. Once you close the game so does the EA client. 

To those commenting about your hatred towards the EA client, shut the hell up, grow up. It's not that serious you will live I promise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198823689840', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11398, 'last_played': 1715026478}
review:
Mass Effect Legendary Edition is an impressive remaster of a series that demands playing if you value meaningful choices and memorable characters. Each game has strengths and weaknesses, but put together with this polish and this trilogy synergizes into one of the best trilogies ever made.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060418631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 5399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5214, 'last_played': 1714836524}
review:
I consider Mass Effect to be one of the best written games of all time. The gameplay is definitely more early 2000's RPG than what we expect nowadays, but the clunkyness of it is easily seen as the start-up gremlin of an amazing trilogy. The game lives and breathes 70s science-fiction like nothing else, with a great soundtrack to boot.

Mass Effect 2 takes everything of Mass Effect and improves it. More streamlined gameplay, more action-focused, a deepening of the story, with better graphics and even better sound. I consider it one of the best games of all time.

For Mass Effect 3, they changed writers and it shows. The writing is a big disappointment and as generic as they come. The gameplay is devolved from RPG with a bit of shooting in ME1, to full-out shooter in ME3, and the graphics can be qualified as "lots of blue and lots of bloom". Still, you do really feel the desperation of a society suddenly collapsing, and the emotional bond with the characters you've met over the course of 2 large games is a strong as the best games out there.

The only gripe I have are the Mako missions in ME1, and the planetary resources gathering mini-game of ME2. They are just not fun.

On sale, this collection is an absolute steal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086985355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 9232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9232, 'last_played': 1711734263}
review:
Best trilogy ever. 

Shepard and his crew are my favorite video game characters of all time. Each character is unique and has their own distinct personality and unmatched vibe. 

The story is excellent and the world building is phenomenal. On top of that, the score is one of the best I've heard. 

The performance is not the best, even though my rig blows these games out of the water.

This is a 10/10 product that every serious gamer should play at least once in their life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070043745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 21113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18106, 'last_played': 1728586586}
review:

A great series to return to when I'm feelin the itch for sci-fi action and a wonderful, colorful cast of characters. 

Too bad ME4 is probably gonna suck though. Why do you do this to me, EA.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100608621', 'num_games_owned': 350, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 5101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4326, 'last_played': 1711901441}
review:
I never played Mass Effect when I was younger and when I saw that I could play the trilogy on steam I was excited to try it out. 

I love this game, I love this trilogy. I take Carth (kaidan) with me everywhere I can, reliving when he'd shyly tell me about admiral Saul murdering his family. I love starting out as a by the books good guy (paragon) and by the end of the third game hitting a "ends justify the means" renegade. I didn't have sex with my crew because I'm their commanding officer but I did do an exclusive overnight interview with the reporter to keep Alliance morale up. 

The EA app requirement sucks though. For the first 72 hours I could hit play and go and it worked perfectly. Now almost randomly the EA app has no idea whats going on when I try to launch this game and it closes ME out.  This is mindnumbing. 

10/10 game, 7/10 requirement to use EA through a steam purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097617110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 8521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8521, 'last_played': 1704072045}
review:
Had a lot of fun with the series but spent almost the entirety thinking that they should have just built on mass effect 1's rpg style of gameplay because mission start > wave of enemies > decision gets boring very fast and feels like it limited the series from a narrative and gameplay standpoint massively. 

For as much as it can make you feel disconnected from the rest of the world it is insanely funny how awful of a shepard you can be and barely anyone you know cares

Good series but because it was praised as one of the best in videogames i was expecting it to not be playing it so safe with such a boring format later on

author: {'steamid': '76561198214073156', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 8347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8135, 'last_played': 1711744241}
review:
Probably the best Game Series I have ever played. God, I wish I could forget it all and play it again- it's that type of game.

The Remasters are pretty good, ME1 is still fairly aged, but if you can get over that, ME2 and ME3 are modern-adjacent titles, and they play very well- look good too. The Story of these games is phenomenal, the characters are some of the best in gaming, and the world building is so immersive. This game has charm in every corner, if you're sick of modern triple A titles and want a game that respects you and your time, a game that wants you to love it, then get this. You will not regret it, it's worth every penny- especially when it's on sale. 

10/10. Few games make you cry and laugh, make you feel and hurt. Fantastic shit right here, modern classic, and one I'll never forget. Bioware hits.

author: {'steamid': '76561198246952712', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7290, 'last_played': 1711165242}
review: What an absolute masterpiece. I can't believe I've missed playing this trilogy for so long. Excellent storytelling, compelling characters, and to top it all off a well-developed universe with a ton of lore. You can tell a lot of love was put into making this trilogy. I'm a huge fan of games that let you decide how the story goes with your decisions, and the consequences that come with them, and this game certainly is a masterclass in this category. Quite frankly, I feel like I went on the journey of a lifetime, and it was MY personal story. This game made me feel so many emotions. Pain and loss, pure giddy happiness, love, and a lot of laughter. The friends that were made along the way will also always have a special place in my heart. Am I going overboard with this review? Maybe, but how often is a game so awesome you wanna pour your heart out about it in a review? A very rare case for me, I almost never review anything. Would I recommend this game? Absolutely. Replay value is immense. Regrets? Not being able to wipe my mind and relive it all over again for the first time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051490812', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 14200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14152, 'last_played': 1734303776}
review: One of the moest overrated RPG series of all time, but still perfectly alright, enjoyable even. Unlike its contemporaries like Witcher trilogy or Dragon Age, Mass Effect does truly feel like a trilogy, with one big narrative spanning all three games. And while I would argue each individual Witcher game is better than each individual Mass Effect game, those feel more like separate installments, that just happen to star the same protagonist, in the same setting. Mass Effect 1, 2 and 3 do feel like they push the same narrative forward, having a certain conclusion in sight at all times(Crucible debacle and Space Magic notwithstanding).

author: {'steamid': '76561198089269573', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 4008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4008, 'last_played': 1715032214}
review: Might be the best Sci-Fi video game series ever made. A rich story complemented with a diverse range of great and dynamic characters (except Jacob, screw him).

author: {'steamid': '76561198018868166', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5882, 'last_played': 1707522942}
review: This is one of the greatest gaming trilogies and the three games I have probably replayed the most. The first one has some janky feeling combat to be fair, but it has an incredible story with some pretty great RPG elements. The second one puts the combat front and center and gives you some of the best feeling combat in the series. What the game may lack in overall story, it more than makes up for with wonderful characters and world building. Then the last game is a non stop ride through some incredible moments and pay offs. While the ending leaves a bit to be desired, the whole ride getting there is a great one. Can't recommend these games enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198370533144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 8399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8360, 'last_played': 1710870665}

author: {'steamid': '76561198064539313', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 4690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4690, 'last_played': 1713167429}
review:
[h1]My name is Commander Shepard, this is my favourite game on Steam[/h1]

One of the best trilogies in entertainment history now bundled, remastered into 1 accessible package for future generations to enjoy. Mass Effect is an epic sci-fi, 3rd person shooter RPG that spans across 3 games. 
Each game will carry over decisions and outcomes from previous game, which makes it mandatory to play the game chronologically. 

[h1]MASS EFFECT 1[/h1]
Intro to the series, some of the gameplay mechanics has been reworked to make it feel more modern compared to the rest of the series. You can freely use any guns now without being restricted or penalized for using specific weapons in a class you choose.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
+Great introduction to the universe
+Great class systems, each class have unique abilities 
+Good squadmates with cool personalities
+Unique sci fi aesthetics

[h1]CONS[/h1]
-Repetetive map layouts for planet outpost missions
-Bad waypoint system for quests, sometimes its very annoying to navigate a map when quests dont appear on map
-It is still a 2007 game but with some touchups 

[h1]MASS EFFECT 2[/h1]
The goat of the series (supposedly) it has several gameplay upgrades, even the graphics got better obviously, more squadmates than the 1st game though some dont join us anymore

[h1]PROS[/h1]
+Better gunplay and combat than the previous game
+Better graphics
+You can bring up to 5 weapons to missions
+Plot is more dark, Illusive Man has great voice acting
+Epic final mission that has very high stakes
+Fantastic missions, both base game and DLCs (Though all content are now included in this version)
+Epic set pieces

[h1]CONS[/h1]
-A bit streamlined perks progression but not really a big deal
-Weapons lack of customization (This is fixed in ME3)
-Cannot romance non squad members who were previous squadmates 

[h1]Mass Effect 3[/h1]
The series finale. Every decisions that you made in previous games all comes to this game.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
+Best combat and gameplay in entire series, the guns just feel so good to shoot till this day its still has the best shooting mechanics out of any 3rd person shooter i ever played
+Best graphics in the series
+The mission intro debriefs before mission starts are a nice touch and adds to the immersion
+All DLC missions (Leviathan, Omega, Citadel) are epic
+Epic missions and setpieces throughout the game

[h1]CONS[/h1]
-The endings are still super controversial to this day, you may like or not like it at all
-Multiplayer mode not included sadly, this mode is coop horde shooter and it is a lot of fun and you can play as any aliens in the series
-If you skip to this game without importing your save from prev games, the outcomes will suck.
-The final battle should have been longer (Its clear Bioware were rushed and ran out of time back then)

Overall this is a great package if you want hours of content and the replayability is there if you want to try out different classes and replay doing different decisions.
It is easily a must have game for any Steam Library

[h1]9.5/10 ITS PEAK[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198255625915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5938, 'playtime_at_review': 8181, 'last_played': 1736648080}
review:
I want to start by saying the ME trilogy is one of the best and my most favorite game series ever. I haven’t touched ME:A yet but I’m fixing to, but only cause all the bad I hear. I hear they are making an ME4 but if the new dragon age game is to go off of, I do not want Biowoke touching this series and honestly in my head cannon the series should end here. that being said these 3 games are absolutely amazing.

Pros: fantastic story, fantastic character development, Tear jerking endings, fantastic game play in all ways.

Cons: some minor graphical glitches. Particularly weird animation glitches, on a handful of occasions hit markers not registering when I was using a sniper rifle despite being aimed directly at the head. 

other than that, 15/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198037426403', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 5444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5038, 'last_played': 1715718356}
review:
This is one of the few remasters I heavily recommend. Mass Effect 1 was great and innovative but does not hold up with time and the modding capabilities of having all 3 games running on the same engine makes this package THOROUGHLY worth it. Mass Effect 2 remains one of, if not the, best games ever made, full stop no qualifier (and I am a CERTIFIED picky hater!!!) and 3, despite the (uuuuugh) ending and lack of surprisingly good multiplayer, kicks serious ass for a good 95% of the playthrough. Each game would have been fair price at full cost, remastered; 60$ for all 3 is really generous.

A 50% off sale means 30$ for these 3 games is excellent.

The current sale means you get them for SIX UNITED STATES DOLLARYDOOS. DO NOT PASS THIS OPPORTUNITY. REALLY.

Mod the game to your heart's content and enjoy Shepard's story! (Def find a better ending lol.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198030961035', 'num_games_owned': 570, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 15061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8397, 'last_played': 1727957579}
review:
An epic and captivating storyline, well-developed characters; it's a must-play, even more if you like shooters and RPGs.

[i]Consider playing the DLC 'Citadel' at the end of Mass Effect 3, just before 'Priority: Cerberus Headquarters'. Otherwise, some characters won't be present, and it offers a beautiful escapade before the end.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198882972098', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 71423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61525, 'last_played': 1729320440}
review:
I've been playing these games since their respective launch days... I must have well over 11,000 hours of combined playtime from all the games (ME3 Xbox 360 multiplayer and ME: Andromeda included) under my belt.

I have nothing but good things to say about this videogame franchise:

1) Your actions & dialogue choices have major consequences & effects that result in triumphs, deaths, losses, and victories. And it’s clear that an immense weight is put on your shoulders to do the right thing… but you don’t have to shoulder that burden alone, because you have incredibly loyal squad-mates & crew who’ll follow you anywhere.

2) Speaking of squad-mates, the level of depth of connections you make with your squad-mates are unmatched by any other game out there. 2a) You can take your squad-mates with you on missions—where they have unique responses to what’s going on around them, & in response to your actions.

3) There’s a dark & foreboding undertone that gets more dark as the games progress, which finalizes in ME3; all of which, has purpose.

4) Most of the aliens in the game actually LOOK and behave alien… plus, you can romance some of those aliens that have unique physical features!

Besides Skyrim, there has been NO OTHER RPG that just... KEEPS bringing me back to do another playthrough. I truly believe that the Mass Effect franchise is the BEST RPG series ever made. Baldur's Gate 3 comes close in being 2nd place, but even it, with all its bells and whistles and WAY more in-depth control over the story than you do as Shepherd in Mass Effect, can't claim the title for being best RPG ever made in my book... there's just something nostalgic, epic, and inspiring about the Mass Effect franchise has that trumps all other RPG's out there. I think a major part that makes me keep coming back, is just the level of depth of connections you can make with your squadmates in these games. No other RPG's have been able to forge such impregnable bonds I have with my squadmates.

author: {'steamid': '76561198196887863', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 15170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7257, 'last_played': 1724929042}
review: Mass Effect trilogy is an absolute masterpiece that immerses players in an epic universe filled with unforgettable characters, heart-pounding action, and thought-provoking choices. From the breathtaking vistas of unexplored planets to the intense battles against collectors and reapers, every moment in this trilogy is packed with emotion and excitement. Remastered visuals breathe new life into familiar landscapes, while the iconic soundtrack sets the perfect tone for each encounter. Whether forging alliances with alien races or grappling with the weight of galactic decisions, every decision feels significant, making for an emotionally gripping experience that will stay with players for long. Mass Effect isn't just a game; it's an emotional journey through the cosmos that leaves a lasting impact on the heart and soul.

author: {'steamid': '76561199163720903', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1383, 'last_played': 1720806126}
review:
This is the best game I've ever played. The OST, the story—everything is phenomenal. It's a true masterpiece.

But there's a problem: Do not support ZA/UM. Avoid buying the game, their merchandise, or anything from their atelier. Not a single cent should go to them.

One individual wrongfully took control of ZA/UM from the original creators. This person needs to be held accountable for what was done to Kurvitz, Rostov, Hindpere, and others. Art should win over greed.

In 2021, the creators sold company stakes to a trusted investor to fund the game. This investor was later bought out by two others, leaving the company in untrusted hands. The ringleader, Toni Haavel, has a history of fraud. When Kurvitz and Rostov asked for financial documents, they were fired.

Kurvitz and Rostov accuse Haavel of fraud in acquiring the company and are pursuing legal action in both the UK and Estonia.

Support the artists, not the exploiters. Let art triumph over greed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040455001', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 12456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6911, 'last_played': 1735362596}
review:
!!DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME!!

Disco Elysium is one of the greatest games of all time, and is, perhaps, the best written game of all time. 
Due to extensive underhanded, but "legal", methods, the creators of the game were the victims of a hostile takeover, and no longer receive any of the profits at all from purchasing this game.

Thusly, to summarize: DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME, and if you do, DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME AT FULL PRICE. It is frankly priceless, there is no amount of money you could apply to the quality of the game, but the people responsible for this masterpiece have had their work ripped away from them by a greedy, malignant body intent on empowering themselves off of the work of others. 

There are ways you can play games without paying for them, by the way. That's all I'm going to say on that matter.

!!DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198020249112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1762, 'last_played': 1665204753}
review:
This is the best video game I have ever played, but under no circumstances should you ever buy it. Have a look at what ZA/UM, the developer, is up to these days after purging many of the original creators of this game:

https://videogames.si.com/news/disco-elysium-dev-zaum-layoffs-last-writer-speaks-out

[quote=article]
As part of looking into the layoffs yesterday, one source told us that they didn’t think “women were treated the same and that their work wasn’t as valued” at ZA/UM. We asked if Tuulik had seen these issues at the company as well. “Absolutely,” he said. “You’d have to be blind not to. In the PMG documentary, the former DE: Final Cut Lead Writer Helen Hindpere describes a call with the Chief Executive Tõnis Haavel, where Tõnis is screaming at her. It's so loud that a fellow writer who walks in hears the screaming through her headphones and asks what the f**k was that? That writer was me.”
[/quote]

[quote=article]
Dora Klindžić broadly echoed Tuulik’s sentiment: “I've seen good work done at ZA/UM. I've also seen management and production staff terrorizing creatives, lying, playing power games, turning people against each other, destroying relationships and people's self-esteem. For this, there have been no repercussions.”

She also emphasized that some workers would not only lose their jobs, but would have to upend their whole lives as a result of the layoffs: “As a reward for our hard work, some of us are even slated to lose our immigration status in the UK and will have to evacuate the country. We will be gone by next week, but those who remain are grappling with a place irrevocably changed.

“The mask has slipped from the face of capital. What remains at ZA/UM is a cold, careless company where managers wage war against their own creatives, where artistry is second to property, and where corporate strategy is formed by an arrogant disdain for their own audience.”
[/quote]

Borrow it from a friend or find some other way to play it without giving money to these monsters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071742415', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2359, 'last_played': 1708351642}
review:
The game is 10/10, it's an absolute masterpiece. However, I'm leaving this negative review because I stumbled upon some concerning blog posts years after buying the game. I'll explain why you shouldn't buy the game.

The game and the IP were stolen from the original creators and developers, in one of the most unhinged fraud plots I've ever seen. 

To summarize it, some fraudster used his girlfriend who worked at the studio to buy some concept art for $1, then turned around and sold that very same content for 5 million dollars to the studio... he then used that money to buy a majority stake from the unsuspecting first investor who wanted out for personal reasons. Naturally, the creators -- who are a minority shareholders at this point-- were deeply concerned by this whole nonsense, and were ultimately pushed out of the company. Insane, right? Some criminals basically stole the money from the studio to buy the studio. In any respectable jurisdiction this scenario would be a textbook fraud case and the perpetrators would be sitting in a jail cell right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031116815', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 6447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6447, 'last_played': 1727797873}
review:
I understand that the publisher absolutely dicked the developers, so its worth snagging as a resale key or sailing the seas. I absolutely recommend playing it tho, a little link at the bottom with info. With that out of the way....

This game is my favorite piece of media of all time, its basically an interactive book about a man coming out of a blackout with no memory whatsoever and being told you have to solve a murder. Its got themes of love and lust, sobriety and addiction, and most importantly loss. But also making something new, picking up the pieces of your shattered life and turning them into a mosaic. Or if you prefer, grinding them and your body to dust with the furthering of a drug and drink induced spiral. I've played this game in the throes of addiction, in the midst of sobriety, clear headed and ran ragged and it is ALWAYS relatable. Maybe its just me, but i can see myself in Harry's shoes no matter which path you take.

In the end this game is a story, a choose your own adventure novel and the hardest hurdle to get over was failing checks. My advice? Don't worry, you'll be able to get through the game regardless of success or failure at any point even if you might have to reload at a game over, (keep a few saves) but the failures are part of the experience. In fact, theirs a few hidden things in the game that can only be experienced by failing at certain points. 

It's a narrative worth experiencing, especially if you've ever battled addiction, that will hit home hard. It's permanently altered how i view and feel about the world, for the better. I urge you to give it a go.

in regards to the opening of this, the publisher had a member use fraud to takeover then lock out the creators of the game, so if you buy it here you're supporting scammers
https://thedirect.com/article/disco-elysium-zaum-controversy-explained

author: {'steamid': '76561198045196858', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5355, 'last_played': 1705628326}
review: Fantastic concept with fantastic writing. I think I enjoyed every single character. However, it's definitely a game where you must love the journey MORE than the destination. If you focus too much on the destination, it will sadly fall flat and I am unfortunately that type of person. If you are this person, I would say at least watch a playthrough of it. Also it is very unfortunate what happened with the developer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081154798', 'num_games_owned': 789, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 559, 'last_played': 1689432706}
review:
Munkee is divided.
I love this game, and think it stands on its own legs as a masterpiece of world-building and character writing. The (original) devs behind this are incredibly talented and have done an amazing job of representing and exploring a myriad of ideologies without making one in particular feel "right" or better than others. Your choices are really your own, as are your mistakes. They did a fantastic job of making Revachol feel like a real place with real history, and its inhabitants are all unique and have very distinct personalities and preferences. The world of Elysium and Revachol is humorous but dark, with great stories fleshing them out. I have nothing but great things to say about the game itself. 
So why the "Not Recommended?" The creators of the game were forced out of their studio by a scumbag (investor Toni Haavel, convicted of fraud prior) who only cares about profiting off some else's work. That in and of itself is criminal considering that ensures we'll never get the sequel we deserve, and the writer and the others who worked hard on this piece of art now have nothing to show for it. Kurvits and Rostov, the main visionaries and creatives behind the game, recognized the injustice of losing their IP to suits, and asked for documents and financial data to ensure this wasn't what is was: fraudulent. They were fired not long after that. This is a must-play, but I highly encourage you not to pay for it, if you get my drift. 
If you want a better explanation: https://www.reddit.com/r/Games/comments/yqkuvv/to_fans_of_disco_elysium_concerning_the_situation/

author: {'steamid': '76561199086082634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 10181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10156, 'last_played': 1713518763}
review:
[h1]My Disclaimer.[/h1]
[h2]DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.[/h2] The original artists, story tellers, and dev team had their masterpiece stolen by fraudsters. For more information, see [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K1b5zyvsUBY&t=592s]this video.[/url] If anyone tries to tell you that piracy is bad, let them know [i]they are insane and grotesque.[/i]

But how does the game itself stand up?[hr][/hr] [hr][/hr]

[h1]My Review.[/h1]
[h2]Gameplay mechanics are fun and charming.[/h2] It's a click and point adventure game where you're trying to solve a murder. This is done through the use of a skill checks system. Your odds are improved/worsened by your allocated skill points, equipped clothes/items, previous dialogue choices, etc. [i]Failing a skill check's often entertaining in its own right and is sometimes sufficient to progress the story in certain useful/entertaining ways.[/i] You can conceptualize thoughts to help reveal the past of the mentally ill amnesiac detective you play as or adopt multiple often contradictory beliefs. 

[h2]It's profound and narrative-heavy.[/h2] It uses around one million words (like my reviews) to give a voice to its diverse cast while describing Disco's all-too familiar history. Despite this, [i]more often than not this game will be reading you, not the other way around.[/i] Its lore is expansive and detailed. If anyone is looking for pointers on how to describe a scene, a character, or a history, consider Disco a masterclass.

[h2]Sound design is delightful.[/h2] Every footstep on the pavement, note scrawled in your notebook, and thought internalized has an appropriate sound that sucks you into a world [i]you already live in.[/i] The music is great (I play whirling n rags 8:00 when I want to be productive), though the soundtrack has its highs and lows for me. 

[h2]Art direction is inspired.[/h2] This makes sense, as the game had its beginnings in a artist collective. See [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wpp54B3RuyQ]this video by Jamrock Hobo[/url] to hear from someone more qualified than me to discuss the game's artistic merit.[hr][/hr]

[h1]My Suggestions.[/h1]
For Disco Devs or people hoping to improve upon the formula, here's a few changes I'd make that likely won't make sense unless you've played it.

[h2]-Rework the archetypes available at the beginning of each game.[/h2] There should be a 4th archetype for motorics. Then distribute the skills to make the differences between the 4 archetypes more pronounced. The thinker shouldn't be 5,1,2,4. It should be 6,2,2,2. The Sensitive should be 2,6,2,2. Physical should be 2,2,6,2. The "Mover" should be 2,2,2,6. 

This would've allowed for a 4th attribute portrait (likely tinted yellow and with the theme of "speed") of the detective fit for artistic expression and analysis. [i]This alone would be reason enough.[/i] It would also give confidence to new players so they know that however they  allocate their points, the case is likely solvable given how low 3 of your skills can be. I imagine it would also make balance testing easier.

[h2]-Each attribute should have a trippy or extra sensory skill.[/h2] Psyche has both Inland Empire and Esprit De Corps. Physique has Half Light and Shivers. I'm thinking Intellect and Psyche could trade Conceptualization and Esprit De Corps. Physique could give Half Light to Motorics in exchange for a completely new skill. Half Light could replace reactions speed. Then each of the [b]4[/b] archetype would have this skill be their signature one. For this to have the effect I'd want, both Esprit and Halflight would need more fleshing out imo. 

Inland Empire and Shivers are fan favorites. Every attribute should have a version of this. This change would've accomplished this. [i]They wouldn't all be equal, but the attempt would likely mark an improvement.[/i]

[h2]-Add a New Game Plus Mode.[/h2] You would unlock this after beating the game or its hardcore mode. This would remove the cap on skills and allow you to be a god detective. You could choose infinite money. Perhaps you can choose which clothes you've found on previous playthroughs are in your inventory (dialogue that comes with item finding would play once you first equip them instead.) Perhaps you can start off with certain thoughts conceptualized.

It'd be fun for testing. It'd also be nice to see how easy the game is if your detective is a lot more put together. 

[h2]-Thoughts should always enable roleplay, not inhibit. Also, thought synergy should be strived for.[/h2] The most egregious example of this is with Fascist related thoughts. Revacholian Nationhood, the thought that embodies fascism for the detective, punishes your morale every time you use fascist dialogue. [i]I'm aware that this is a clever and funny statement about fascism, but from a gameplay perspective it doesn't make sense.[/i] If I want to play as a fascist and see what disco has to say about it, I am incentivized to limit myself and pursue this by not having the fascist thought. To avoid this, I am compelled to put more points into Psyche. What if I don't want to be an empathetic fascist?

Also, Revacholian Nationhood [b]buffs the positive impact of alcohol.[/b] However, the guy you get this thought from will also likely be the one to offer you the Waste Land of Reality thought, which [b]nerfs the impact of alcohol.[/b] So what's the point?

[h2]-Every Thought and Clothing item should have a skill buff and nerf of some kind. [/h2] Homosexual Underground does not give you a skill buff, just a dialogue option. [i]I get that this too may be a political statement[/i], but it sucks to have your thought cabinet crowded with a thought that doesn't aid in the detective's misadventures or investigation. The thought should at least be free to remove. 

Similarly, there are clothes that only buff and don't nerf. This removes strategy from the player.

[h2]-You shouldn't have to spend skill points to expand the thought cabinet.[/h2] I think spending points on skills should automatically expand the thought cabinet. Testing would be needed to ensure balance.

I might add more later. Who knows?[hr][/hr][hr][/hr]

[h1]My Conclusion.[/h1]
Play it if you're an avid RPG fan, reader, artist, or [strike]mentally[/strike] politically ill suspicious element. Don't expect a politically unbiased game. An "apolitical" game, though sometimes appropriate, [i]is a political decision in its own right.[/i] Don't worry: there's enough criticism to go around for everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001253264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1033, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1033, 'last_played': 1667289504}
review:
I tried to like it, but it wasn't for me.
Not a fan of having a pre-built character forced on me in an RPG. 
Also has the sarcastic/amnesiac combo that a semi-retired GameDev I follow, Tim Cain (Fallout, Pillars of Eternity, Arcanum) has stated as generally overdone. Not saying it's bad here, but that's more of a warning for those people who don't like that type of stuff. 

And just because it didn't work out for me, does not mean it is a bad game. It just wasn't a good game for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975494712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1675052595}
review:
I feel bad giving this game a negative review - but I just don't think most gamers (including myself) will actually like the game. It's not an RPG game - it's a choose your own adventure detective novel disguised as an RPG game. 

Look - the writers did an AMAZING job creating the story (and back stories), and there is some truly laugh out loud moments in conversations with NPCs. However, in the end, the game is just a point and click mystery. While there are multiple ways to "solve" problems, ultimately NONE of it matters. You can get to the ending / solve everything (I think as I quit after 8 hours) just with brute force clicking on everything. I stopped caring about leveling up my character - because strategy does not matter (unlike a classic RPG). 

In the end, I burned out on the exhaustive dialogues with NPCs - which seem like an end unto themselves. I kept finding myself spam clicking to solve puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028215265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 221, 'playtime_forever': 1081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1081, 'last_played': 1714909024}
review:
Got the game from Humble Bundle, where money went to charity.

Made it to end of Day 2, didn't really wish to continue anymore.

I liked the premise at first, but I think the game is a bit torn with how there's a good amount of politics involved (not my cup of tea really) but it also goes heavy on being over-the-top silly with player character inner dialogue and mentally insane dialogue options you can take. Though it is certainly unique in that aspect, I think.

I suppose having one doesn't mean the other can't exist? Though it makes me wonder who this was intended for, making it a bit of a niche audience, in my opinion.

The writing strikes me as a bit pretentious, telling in long words about things that could have been summarised more densely without losing any context. There's also a lot of info that just doesn't appear relevant at all, making the experience boring.

The progress, rarely, also seemed to feel like it was dependant on getting a skill check right, but if you were unlucky, it may act as a big roadblock. This only happened once so far, but it was off-putting.

Considering all this and  that original developers no longer see any of the money coming their way due to, in my perspective, immoral reasons, I can't really recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146153323', 'num_games_owned': 893, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 9834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9834, 'last_played': 1673322086}
review:
[u][i]“Capital has the ability to subsume all critiques into itself."[/i][/u]


I am simply incapable of describing the depth of Disco Elysium. 
Was never really bothered by my lack of proficiency in literature -- until I've finished this game.
Disco Elysium changed me. It took me to a fictitious, nonexistent place suspended in codes, animated through digital paintings, voiced by people who ontologically do not exist in that world, and viscerally poured its warm, palpitating, still bleeding heart out to me. I could not, for the life of me, articulate the melancholy, the sudden manifestation of dread, the overwhelming grief, and the almost child-like sense of hope that's been thoroughly dragged through the mud, beaten up and spit on but nevertheless still ever-present, hopeful for a tomorrow that may never come. 
My words plainly fail to capture Disco Elysium - I've felt so much, experienced so much, and have had so much I want to say; yet the moment my hands touches the keyboard, I am at a loss of words - I just don't know how to even begin. This is the first time I have ever truly resented my inability to put my emotions into words.

Perhaps it's for the better.
Disco Elysium is a vigorously crafted piece of art. Its expressive art style, phenomenal voiceover, fleshed out characters and carefully laid-out composite of a post-Soviet eastern European city seamlessly meshed with the unrelenting dialogues and monologues that serves as the backbone of a journey into the back alleys of Revachol through the inner turmoil of a drunken, disheveled husk of a detective. The story itself is nothing but compelling, and the setting itself is so full-of-life that you could almost feel the saltiness of the evening breeze, hijacked by a hint of nicotine leaking from the Whirling-in-Rags linger in your nostril. To describe any more is to rob you, my dear indecisive friend, of an experience that cannot be had again.

Which is why it's imperative that I recommend against buying this game.
ZA/UM in its current incarnation is nothing but a hollow corpse, reanimated and puppeteered by the oh-so-infallible invisible hand with the sole focus of milking the last penny out of Disco Elysium as an IP. The people who made the game -- the artists, writers, programmers, have long been driven away and the studio itself now serves no other purpose than a blood-soaked stele of corporate greed.

[h1] DO NOT PAY A SINGLE DIME FOR THIS GAME! [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198429936820', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1720042782}
review:
Get the game off of a key reseller or a download site. ZA/UM's current owners are scum and do not deserve compensation for others' work. 

Game's fantastic. It's an extremely thought-provoking RPG that manages to be mature with its themes without coming off as pompous or pretentious. The entire idea of a game where you hear every thought going through the main character's head and can act on them accordingly is genius. You hear everything - his small intrusive thoughts, random things he notices, times where he doubts himself, times where he's assure of himself. The game gives you just enough control that nothing feels obtusely unfair, but takes away just enough as to keep you on your toes.

The way your ideology can also push people away and also bring people to you adds even more depth, as it allows you to be true to yourself and see how the characters react, or go completely off the rails and act in ways you never would in real life. Again, truly genius stuff. 

I love the experience so far and I plan to continue it for a long while. Just don't support the "creators" (rightsholders). They're not the people responsible for this magnificent piece of art - they're just a leech who took it from the real creatives.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994345983', 'num_games_owned': 1190, 'num_reviews': 552, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1723562186}

Seems to have been some drama with the developers getting conned out of their own game so just go watch it on youtube until you fall asleep.
