author: {'steamid': '76561198217955477', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 801, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1714941536}
review:
I really didn't find this enjoyable as a game as it's hyped up to be. Gave it 10 hours, never really felt hooked into the story.
I think this would have been better as a book series or something considering one of the things people love to hype up this thing for is the word count. 
The skill check system makes you feel like you're banging your head against a wall until you waste enough time to get a lucky roll. 
There's a big story in here and a lot of characters but little direction and power for the player which makes it feel like reading a book where the printing company mixed up the page numbers at random.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047749163', 'num_games_owned': 845, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1718715755}
review: The reasons people have stated for liking the game are the reasons I really don't. There is a lot of dense and heavy dialogue, and realizing my character was a loser, I just felt like I had to go around apologizing. I generally felt unhappy with the character path I chose, which involved maxing empathy and trying to learn more about the characters in the world. I realized that this game doesn't really want you to invest in specific characters; it wants you to talk to a lot of different characters. I just got overwhelmed, and when I got to the boat lady, I was done. The 3 hours I spent talking to all of these characters and being so poor that a map was a massive expense just made me quit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048327997', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1733173640}
review:
I'll keep this brief.
I like the idea. Very very much.
But JUST can't stand the execution.

The game is very morbid, very damp, very raw and it made me feel like trash. The internal and all dialogue, in fact, are very, very well written, don't get me wrong, but it's just so depressing to read and listen to the musings of a degenerative mind that.. I have enough of that in my own life.

This is coming from someone who likes high difficulty levels and challenges and I really like the setting of depressive worlds, but this game is for masochists.
No judgement. No rating, play at your own risk, I know it's highly regarded, but for sure this isn't for everyone.

Oh yeah, don't buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980932967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1687235411}
review:
It's a beautiful game, very well made, and the depth and psychology of the story telling is unmatched. However, it's simply too dark and depressing. If you struggle with metal health, depression, or are prone to negative thinking at all, the tone and ambiance and grim subject matter of this game could easily trigger a downward spiral. 

The main character struggles with depression and addiction, and one of the primary elements of the game is a dialogue between yourself and your inner parts (see IFS therapy). These conversations can be too real and quite triggering for anyone who's battled with their own demons. These parts don't hold back, and it can be too easy to start feeling like these "voices" are speaking directly to your own IRL insecurities and pain points, which not everyone will find enjoyable or be able to detach themselves from. 

As I said at the start - brilliant game, and masterfully executed - but proceed with caution if you're prone to depression and negative thinking, because this can be a very dark and depressing game at times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009207435', 'num_games_owned': 670, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2100, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 41, 'playtime_at_review': 2058, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1735945492}

Do NOT give ZA/UM money though, that money should go to the artists that were cheated out of the company. I definitely recommend playing it, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972197955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1732687694}

author: {'steamid': '76561198216891911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1705526753}
review:
I really tried but i think it's just not for me. 

I can see the story down the line will be developing deep questionings about life, humans, etc.
I love the look and the ambiance. 
But the gameplay is really working against me, it feels sluggish, half of the game's vocabulary is outdated since the 70s at least, and I know it's on purpose, it's obviously part of it's style and identity but it makes it feel posh as hell regardless of that is actually being said.
Also playing as a damned cop is not really my jam. 
I can't feel engaged with it for longer than an hour and the idea of launching the game disinterests me, I feel like there's always more fun games I could play. 
I know it's not the fault of a lack of quests markers or a lack of a map, my favorite game, Outer Wilds, doesn't have any of those on purpose and I loved it partially because of it's part of its identity to not have them. 
I'm just, really, really, really not vibing with Disco Elysium.  

Maybe it's a me thing, maybe I'm not ready.
I was gifted the game so I really wanted to give it a try, but I just can't get into it at all.
I might try again at some point but as it stands I'm just not into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160291726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 859, 'last_played': 1724104778}
review:
The plot looks promising so far, and the way it's conveyed is a very unique experience.

Upd.: but after reaching the ending I got an impression that this game is unfinished or, rather, it should have finished at the Tribunal part. That extra island part: what was the point in making it a detective story for such a random unsatisfactory shallow solution that is not linked to the all preceding story build-up whatsoever? This game may be good and novel in terms of art and methods of conveying the story, but it's a disgrace to the mystery genre.

Don't get me wrong, though, the story was generally good, I really liked all of the characters, even though few hours worth of reading of my life could probably be saved if game did not use so much sentences to discuss political views. Don't know what was the deal with original creators conflict, but possibly that lukewarm ending was a f*ck-off parting gift to the project.

author: {'steamid': '76561198884980164', 'num_games_owned': 96, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 8113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 49, 'playtime_at_review': 4021, 'last_played': 1736593300}
review:
Disco Elysium - Wow, you've completed the game, verily, that was a remarkable experience. Such a unique game, unique concept of helpful (mostly) voices, incredible worldbuilding and amazing voice acting, and undoubtedly, the best writing a game possibly can have, at least from your perspective.

Logic [Trivial:Success] - Yep, makes sense.

Drama [Easy:Success] - Ist complete truth, sire.

Conceptualization [Medium:Success] The world building is absolutely beautifully tremendous, one might say even the best part of game itself, oh, and the ART of the game, the graphics, it all fits together so well.

Inland Empire [Challenging:Success] Yet you feel as you've missed something, the feeling that there is something more to this game, that is hidden behind the curtains, that is beyond your grasp.

Disco Elysium - The choices in that game feel like more than just branching dialogue options, Every little decision you made, whether you sided with certain political ideologies or how you treated characters, changed your playthrough. Even "Yourself" can change depending on your choices and beliefs.

Disco Elysium - And look at this, you were a shining super star cop, ranging between communist and moralist, even if that was not what you wanted, those were your own choices. You've never even had alcohol in your hand, didn't do any drugs, and haven't light a single cigarette. Abstained from alcohol completely.

Volition - I am proud of you, you held your will to the very end, not every man could do so, but you did, you should be proud of yourself.

Electro-Chemistry - [Easy:Success] You're a fuскіng рussу, not even a single fuскіng bottle. You missed out on a lot of fun.

Horrific Necktie - Brathan, you've been wandering through this chaos and never even had a drink? What's wrong with you?

Disco Elysium - The game masterfully immerses the player in a wide range of emotions, whether it’s the intense weight of pressure, creeping fear, a sudden wave of sadness that washes over you,, or a moment of awe that leaves you speechless. Every situation is designed to evoke a specific response, drawing you deeper into its world with a blend of atmosphere, dialogue, and pacing that makes each emotion feel real and immediate.

Pain Threshold - [Formidable:Success] Dolores Dei...

Authority - [Medium:Success] That man on harbour gates. when you face a wall like that, it’s about showing you’re not afraid to push back.

Half Light - [Easy:Success] That sick freak on gates. 

Empathy - [Medium:Success] Deep down you believe, every moment draws out something deep, these feelings are sincere.

Shivers - [Godly:Success] The distant city stands still, its towers reaching for a sky heavy with the promise of rain. A lone man, content in his silence, gazes down happily at his dog. The world seems to breathe with him, quiet, calm, just before the storm. He feels the first cool drop touch his skin, and for a moment, the only sound is the dog's soft panting and the whisper of the wind, the rain has started.

ZA/UM - So, considering all of the spoken facts, let's leave a positive review, shall we?

Reaction Speed - [Challenging:Success] - Hold on, don't make any rash decisions

𝟭.[𝗛𝗮𝗻𝗱/𝗘𝘆𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗼𝗿𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 - 𝗚𝗼𝗱𝗹𝘆 𝟭𝟲] 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝗮 𝗽𝗼𝘀𝗶𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝘃𝗶𝗲𝘄 [𝟰𝟮%] -𝟭 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗦𝗽𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗲𝗱 𝘆𝗼𝘂
2.Leave a negative review
3."Eh, i'm too lazy for that." [Leave.]

                                                       CHECK FAILURE

Hand/Eye Coordination [Godly:Failure] - One moment you're running your finger, like the wind, to the YES button, then you suddenly shudder and press the NO button, leaving a negative review to the game.

ZA/UM - Why?! What is wrong with our game?

Drama [Challenging:Success] - "Your" game?

Encyclopedia [Formidable:Success] - The conflict at ZA/UM revolves around the firing of key Disco Elysium developers, including lead writer Robert Kurvitz, art director Helen Hindpere, and lead artist Aleksander Rostov. They claimed they were unlawfully ousted by the studio's new leadership, which took control of the Disco Elysium intellectual property.

Half Light [Medium:Success] - You feel anger building with every word, it's in your chest, crawling through your veins, you find your fists already clenching.

Encyclopedia - The developers accused the management of financial mismanagement and fraud, while ZA/UM's leadership argued the dismissals were due to internal disagreements and financial issues.

Logic [Easy:Success] - Therefore, there will be no sequel to the game, nor any continuing content.

Esprit De Corps [Heroic:Success] - There was that time a cop took too big a bite of his doughnut. One second, he’s fine, the next—powdered sugar everywhere, choking, eyes watering. He wasn’t dying, but for a moment it sure looked like it. Half the precinct tried not to laugh, the other half waited to see if they’d need to step in. Classic.

Disco Elysium - You sit in front of your screen, hands hovering over the keyboard.

Empathy [Medium:Success] - You have enjoyed the game, and you know it.

Volition [Legendary:Success] - Do it. Press the button. It's not betrayal, It's justice

Disco Elysium - And so, despite the love you felt, despite how deeply it resonated with you, there was only one thing left to do. You type it out-a negative review.

Conceptualization [Heroic:Success] - The game was art, no question about it.

Suggestion [Medium:Success] - Brother, you should have had pirated it instead, now the money's gone to them, and you're stuck with regret of undeservedly paying them.

Disco Elysium - You finish your review, the game, with its intricate twists and turns, left you with more than just a sense of sorrow, But Hope. You feel an undeniable urge to dive back into its world once again. The allure, the depth, the unique experience-it's still calling to you, you're not ready to part ways, you want to explore it once more.

Volition [Challenging:Success] - In honour of your will, lieutenant-yefreitor. That you kept from falling apart, in the face of sheer terror. Day after day. Second by second.

Inland Empire [Medium:Success] - DETECTIVE

Esprit De Corps [Medium:Success] - ARRIVING

Authority [Medium:Success] - ON THE SCENE

author: {'steamid': '76561198115253889', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1710588384}
review:
Note: Scummy company stole the IP. Consider this before buying I guess.

The game is quite literary and it's not really my jam, but it's playable the more you get into it. One advice - leave Intellect at 1 point otherwise the game will info dump you with hundreds of extra worldbuilding fluff that's not even of the interesting kind - mostly politics and uninteresting history. Similar with Psyche - the game will delve into madness territory really fast, but it's a bit better than the info dump from Intellect + I like the bonuses from Psyche - Suggestion, Empathy, Authority are quite fun for roleplaying (winning fun dialogue options; main story related too)

author: {'steamid': '76561198341998948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1715768553}
review: It's a point and click game, which no one seemed to mention before I purchased it. I feel that perhaps I have failed in not being arty or intellectual enough to appreciate this game: to be honest I really did try to like it but it bored me: I drowned in it's endless dialogue about politics and other (fairly irrelevant to "solving" the case) material which to be honest I kept skipping. I suppose it would be OK for people interested in basically reading a strange (and laden with drug references) political novel about an alternative earth, but no I had to quit. It really isn't a detective/cop story at all, it's a "deconstructed", very arty story, perhaps best appreciated by people who are really into drugs.

author: {'steamid': '76561199563079648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1140, 'last_played': 1733014562}
review: I didn't hate it but I just probably wouldn't recommend to most people I know. The game focuses heavily on narrator/character dialogue.....LOTS of it. There's specifically a huge emphasis on the moral/political/social direction your character goes in (which is definitely a draw for some people but I didn't care either way) and lots of discussion about topics related to that throughout the story. I'd say the pacing is pretty slow and my biggest annoyance is that the story moving forward is often behind checks that are easy to fail. Often, I'd find myself with not much to do or in order to move the story forward, I'd choose an option I didn't want to just progress. My last critique is that the music in the main square is so jarring and starts again and again every time you enter that area. Good things about it though: the art style is AMAZING and so unique (the downside to that style is it's not always easy to know where to walk and certain areas are hard to walk through even though it looks like you should be able to). There's a lot of humor laced within the story that's thoroughly entertaining. The side character who joins you is really enjoyable to interact with. The checks are a good idea, I just wish that more of the main story wasn't reliant on successes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198173359483', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1196, 'playtime_at_review': 1196, 'last_played': 1736529651}
review:
TL;DR version on the end of this review
Really good game(10/10).One of a kind. Ideological delight, very charismatic characters, a lot of inner dialogue between certain aspects of your character's personality. Questions popular political and social ideologies from both sides of political spectrum in a fictional world to the extent that average human will understand and enjoy this intellectual dilemma. Shines a light on certain human perspectives and on the people that believe in them. A game manages to give you a lot of information to process and manages to do this in a way that's captivating, which is really hard when you read wall of text(Game has more words in it than LOTR). Truly a treat I'd recommend it to everyone, but... not from mainstream sources. What makes this game so special is TOP tier writing mixed with in-depth game mechanics. The people that created this piece of art got screwed by the investors in the company they worked for ZA/UM, the group that kicked them out stole their money to buy major shares in the company and kicked the writers out, taking the Disco Elysium IP in the process. Good writing in games industry is becoming a scarce resource and any instance of it should be preserved and given credit, by supporting writers not the corpo-egoes stealing all their work which fuels existing lack of good writing(common theme in culture industry). Other negative comments on this game offer alternatives that don't support corporate greed.

TL;DR - Really good game you should play it, just find other means of gaining access to it(check other negative comments) if you want to support the people that created this masterpiece.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998505557', 'num_games_owned': 975, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 969, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1706779956}
review:
If you have the time and money to give it a try just to see for yourself, it is worth it just to make up your own mind. This game is very different than most games that come out, and it deserves credit for that.

That said, I do not think it is a [i]good[/i] game.

[b][u]The Good[/u]:[/b]
[list]
[*][b][i]Setting[/i]:[/b] The only other game that comes to mind being similar in setting/tone is [i]Papers, Please [/i](which is a better game, imo).
[*][b][i]Art Direction[/i]:[/b] While not necessarily "beautiful", it is a distinct style that fits the game and stands out.
[*][b][i]Voice Acting[/i]:[/b] The voice acting in the Final Cut is mostly quite good.
[*][b][i]Inner Monologue[/i]:[/b] The different aspects of your character's psyche arguing in your head is by far the most entertaining aspect of the game.
[*][b][i]Kim[/i]:[/b] Your partner is the best character.
[/list]
[b][u]The Bad:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*][b][i]UI/UX[/i]:[/b] Almost impressively bad. I can't think of a single positive aspect to it. Clunky, inconsistent, and confusing. Both m&kb and controller are terrible. Just climb the goddamn stairs!
[*][b][i]RNG Skill Checks[/i]:[/b] Having high skill in something and then having to retry a skill check 4+ times (but not all at once, come back later after you level in between each try) because you have to roll dice is not compelling gameplay. And despite what others say, few of those checks are "funny" or "rewarding" to fail. Most simply halt your progress and force you to retry later. Swapping clothes/items around using the terrible UI to try and improve your odds is also not compelling gameplay.
[*][b][i]Role Playing[/i]:[/b] Here is where my opinion probably gets controversial. The rest of the gameplay could be overlooked if it offered a robust roleplaying experience, but... the role playing in this game is not very good. Sure, you get to make some dialogue choices, maybe pick between different approaches to a situation, but not in nearly as many as I wanted, and rarely with the nuance I was hoping for. It's not a simple binary option like lazier RPGs, but it's not nearly as many as the glowing praise made me anticipate. I don't care about skill trees or anything like that, "role playing" can be entirely about choices and behavior, but there just isn't enough of it here. I felt more like a tourist who could choose who to offend with my dialogue choices. I had a character type in mind when I started playing, and the game repeatedly told me "no, that's not one of the choices".
[*][b][i]Writing[/i]:[/b] This is where I really disagree with most people. This game has better writing than a lot of video games, but that is a bar so low you would struggle to trip on it. The good writing is absolutely buried beneath hours of exposition dumps and NPCs droning on and on about hyper-specific fictional history and politics. Speaking of politics, I don't mind that the game is highly political. I [i]like[/i] political games. But I [i]do[/i] mind that it feels lazy, shallow, and particularly unsubtle about it. It makes no sense for some random working stiff to suddenly give you, a stranger, a college lecture on their personal politics, then demand that you also espouse your own. And when you do, you must choose from a small list of hardline positions, or be mocked by the game for "not picking a side" (another example of sub-par roleplaying options).
[/list]
Ultimately, I just did not find this game fun [i]or[/i] compelling. I would rather spend my time learning about and discussing [i]actual[/i] history and politics than playing this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155719435', 'num_games_owned': 67, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1744, 'last_played': 1678229833}
review: One of the biggest disappointments when it comes to PC gaming. On paper, everything is on board. An interesting world, interesting mechanics, a crime story. However, it turned out to be quite a superficial facade, completely inconsistent with what the game really is. I won't say that I regret the time spent with it, but I'm definitely not satisfied with how the plot developed and I definitely don't feel encouraged to play it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972280831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1700, 'last_played': 1726327273}
review: Interesting writing and concepts, but feels a little clunky and not super engaging. If you're into visual novels and choose-your-own-adventure narratives then you might love it, but it doesn't offer much engaging gameplay or challenging puzzle/riddle solving in my view. Plus it's got a very bleak/nihilistic sort of aesthetic, which can leave you in not such a pleasant headspace after playing a while.

author: {'steamid': '76561198276941338', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 2003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2003, 'last_played': 1732384420}
review:
Do some research and consider finding an alternative source for this game. 

Disco Elysium is extraordinary in many ways, but the original creators have been removed from the studio, and the game is not playable with either of my PlayStation controllers, despite the false advertisement from ZA/UM saying that it is. When I boot Disco Elysium, the game does not allow any input to be received from my DualSense controller as a gamepad. I can only play with a controller by emulating mouse-and-keyboard controls, which is not ideal.

If ZA/UM ever properly fixes its controller support, I'll probably change my review to give credit where it's due for a good update. But for now they're catching the down thumb for wasting my time making a config due to their lack of testing.

In a sense, ZA/UM is continuing to profit from the high quality of the core narrative content primarily inspired by the people they fired, while failing to do its presumably primary duty of providing a fully functional game engine as a medium for delivering the dialogue and story content that was largely created by the people ZA/UM removed from the company.

I mean the controller input should be the literal easiest part of making a bug-free game, to be honest. Leads who allow this are really dropping the ball.

UPDATE: Game doesn't work with an 8bitDo, either. I assume it works with an official Xbox controller, or Steam would surely take its tags away.

FINAL UPDATE: ZA/UM pretended to look into the issue and reported that DualSense works for them, which I have no doubt it an outright lie, and never sent me any of the information I requested about what settings they allegedly used, or what instructions I should follow according to someone who ACTUALLY used DualSense with their game, or anything else that would help resolve the issue. I have therefore concluded that they are either too incompetent or too apathetic to properly solve the issue, and that this game will never be supported on DualSense controllers, despite the false advertisement.

Official Xbox controller did seem to work, but off-brand Xbox controllers, PS4 controllers, and PS5 controllers do not. ZA/UM is as shady as ever to say otherwise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032113308', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 3228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3228, 'last_played': 1634348355}
{'steamid': '76561198799688128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1710, 'last_played': 1720712357}
review:
Probably the worst CRPG ever made. I'm genuinely angry with myself for slogging all the way through this piece of shit.

10% interesting mystery, 90% extraneous bullshit. Wonderfully pointless story specially crafted for r/PoliticalCompassMemes browsers who form their political opinions based on the fiction they read in high school English class. RNG and a "choices matter" story that's secretly on rails take away any meaningful agency that the player could have. 

For a bit, I wondered why Disco Elysium is a game instead of a book. Now I know--it's because the only way to get people to interact with this piece of garbage was to pair it with sound effects and pretty pictures (to keep from intimidating anyone stupid enough to think this thing is a meaningful piece of art). Disco Elysium sucks as a book and is even worse as a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106090810', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1420, 'last_played': 1732301992}

author: {'steamid': '76561198048132673', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3078, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3078, 'last_played': 1718416876}
review: After finishing the game and completing the main story, I have no strong desire to go back through to see what I missed.  The story falls off the rails for me after the Tribunal.  The final explanations for events seems like a let-down after all the exposition I sat through.  The whole capitalist/communist/fascist angle isn't as interesting to me as the story of a messed up cop who is tempted to either go down a redemption arc or descend further into addiction and madness.  Gameplay is ok but understanding where I can go is unclear at times.  The fast travel mechanic is easily missed.  It feels like this game should be about 50% shorter.  Many dialogue options were funny but not worth going through more than once.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996454519', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1709910043}
review: This game froze my computer twice in a relatively short amount of gameplay, which since there doesn't seem to be a reliable autosave means having to replay a bunch of stuff I just did while hoping it doesn't freeze again. This would be annoying enough, but it also turns out that many dialogue options are lolrandom type of things, which lull you into a false sense of getting to mess about with the world, only to find some of them lead to sudden death or gameover, with no warning that they were going to be any more important than any of the other goofy options you picked, once again leading to replaying a bunch of dialogue you just did. No thanks.

author: {'steamid': '76561199216899881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3413, 'last_played': 1694323840}
review: This game is undoubtedly one of my favourite games of all time, and one of my favourite written works of all time. The soundtrack of the game perfectly captures the feeling of each and every moment, whether that's being in a dumpy motel late at night, a dance club in a very shoddy building, or having a very strange dream. The visual/art direction also beautifully paints everything that is happening. There is not a single bad voice performance from anyone in the game. It manages to say so much about so many things while also feeling somewhat relatable and human. Play this game, but don't support the corporate greed which drove out the games development team and stole the IP from them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054453078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 7766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7652, 'last_played': 1730516875}

author: {'steamid': '76561199036464460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2144, 'last_played': 1721604046}
review:
This is honestly a perfect game. The only reason I say not recommended is due to the greed of the company, which pushed out many of the original creators of the game. It is a truly wonderful game, and it is a shame that it too has been "subsumed by capital."

Sail the seas to play it. It is probably one of the greatest works of theory-fiction in this century. If philosophy or critical theory is your jam, everything from the world to the dialogue to how gameplay mechanics work oozes legacies of discourse and thought. The lore is phenomenal. The characters are complex, interesting, and beautiful. Disco Elysium grants you passage to a world that feels genuinely lived in, who's history is both in you and coming from you as you unravel a crime and the world around you. It vacillates between goofiness and profundity, making for many moments where I found myself captured by a provoking thought, only to shortly after laugh a dumb joke. And I think it is the only game to ever make me tear up.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198284168938', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1721005127}

author: {'steamid': '76561198134219338', 'num_games_owned': 1100, 'num_reviews': 837, 'playtime_forever': 1564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1564, 'last_played': 1717305750}
review:
This is a high-quality game but it got on my bad side early and never managed to redeem itself in my eyes. The second half of the game was SIGNIFICANTLY more enjoyable for me, because it got out of its own way and just lined up back to back bosses nonstop and felt like a completely different game than the slog of the first half. The visuals are beautiful to look at in most areas but the gameplay elements of Souls games that I find interesting are not present in Sekiro, mainly the exploration, creative build diversity options, and level and upgrade systems.

Unlike souls you cant recover currency or level up progress with you die, and there is no stamina so you can infinitely block, run, or attack spam which feels like it takes the tempo out of fights. Mini bosses are surrounded by grunts so the fights aren't as memorable, I've just fought a bunch of ninjas in the same exact method, and major bosses have gimmicks that are supposed to be used to shortcut the fights and they aren't required but they trivialize the encounters. The first boss is riding a horse that you can scare with firecrackers unless you missed the upgrade, the second boss is a summoner whose summons you can dispel with a consumable that I have ONE (1) of by the time I got to their fight, the fourth boss is monkeys that run away unless you use the stealth consumable, even the second to last major boss has two items that take the fight from super difficult to easily manageable: an umbrella that blocks all its fire attacks and a whistle that stuns it so you can do a quarter of its health immediately. The gimmicks bleed into the minibosses too who can have their health bars halved if you can sneak up on them with the consumable or one miniboss towards the end that is more like a duo the second guy can be lured away and assassinated, any spear miniboss is crazy difficult unless you get the spear-counter skill, any ghost boss requires TWO consumables: one to even damage them and another to cleanse the OHKO effect from yourself. These things change the difficulty of a fight so drastically that it feels either oppressive or trivial. This is just a personal preference and doesn't make the fights or combat bad, I just should have expected more of a contrived spectacle fighter style of combat rather than the diligence of traditional souls.

Due to review character limit three nonessential points here have been moved to a comment.

These things would all be fine just personal subjective qualms but my real objection is this game suffers from textbox overload. The text and systems interference reminded me of Monster Hunter except that game is structured into a prep phase and action phase so the player expects learning new things and popups which allows an uninterrupted action phase. If a game has to dump so much instruction about the systems onto a new player then maybe it should fix the system itself to not be so burdensome, or the obvious answer of convey the info to the the player in a more effective way.

The start of this game bothered me to the point I almost quit. The introductory popups happen after the first time you take an action so when you press the block button instead of seeing what it does it stops the gameplay and there's text that says "hey this is blocking!" which I would have been able to see if I wasn't inturrupted. Same thing for picking up items, trying to stagger enemies, trying to jump on ledges, and then when I want to figure out if there is a mechanic like rolling or sprinting I can't tell if it's not a thing in this game or if I just haven't stumbled upon it yet because I would only get a tutorial popup after the fact. When still trying to learn the basic controls and mechanics of fighting I have to choose weather to revive after a death or not which I don't know what purpose that really serves, so I revive and get stopped by the popup for reviving that says Hey you can revive, just to get immediately killed again when I close the popup. Then after a few times trying to practice there's popups for "unseen aid" which is cryptic so I don't understand what that additional system is yet, then one more death and I'm in a cutscene about  Dragonrot from repeated true deaths and the Rot Essence corrupting the land, I'm just trying to play the game here let me go fight that guy I was fighting. After dying more thoughtout the game random popups about rot essence son and rot essence daughter keep spamming me so I look it up and apparently it decreases the chances of unseen aid. Unseen aid should stay unseen, apparently it had a chance to keep some of the souls you would lose on your next death, who cares about that you lose them all anyway since theres no way to pick them up from your death spot I don't need popups telling me my CHANCE to HALVE that are decreased. Big giant about to grab me so I am trying to time a roll to get out of the way "Grab Attacks" popup freeze time and read this cuz you couldnt just have been shown what a grab attack looks like en vivo now I have to close this popup and try to continue the timing of what I was already trying to experience. Every time I pick up an item even if it is a consumable that I already have there is a popup that pauses gameplay that shows me the item and I have to click out of it. I don't want to pick up anything at all now because its just going to be another fistful of ash or pottery shard that I am never going to use. Even when acquiring the item that lets you level up and going through three pages of what the item means and ending the dialogue I KNEW as soon as I took a step away there would be another pause for a text box and sure enough even thought it just told you to level up it's gonna stop you to tell you again, and yet again when you rest at the bonfire to actually put the skill points in, and once more when you click on the skill point menu. Then three more during the process of putting the point in and equipping the skill. Previous souls games were fine with pre-placed text that you could read and then go forward and learn about the mechanic, very disappointing to see this huge step back in the instructional method here.                          I am aware this sounds like nitpicking but gets to the essence of why Sekiro is not satisfying, it's got some good stuff but gets in its own way with bloated systems and inturruptions. The prime example of this is after defeating a boss, where there should be a moment of achievement there are instead two popups about the automatically-collected loot. If the fight is supposed to be intense and the player is on a bit of a rush from victory this is not the time to introduce two main progression mechanics through text. Let the accomplishment play out and have the player go to a chest or something after a few seconds just one second after the fight please. I don't want to read that soon after what should be a moment of triumph with the player's heart pounding from victory. This happens after every single boss and miniboss, and actually robs the surprise from one boss [spoiler] the guardian ape who has a surprise second phase, except I was not surprised because I knew the fight was still going because I expected the text box popups that have happened after every boss up until that point but they did not come up so I knew the fight was still going despite the "shinobi execution" marker trying to trick the player into thinking the conflict was concluded.[/spoiler]This boss was the first fight in the game for me that I actually got wrapped up in because it felt like it actually had some soul in it and the mechanics were very enjoyable, so to see a potentially huge moment of surprise nullified due to textboxes is very disappointing to me.

Overall this game has plenty to offer but committed the cardinal sin of annoying me. Sekiro feels like someone trying to copy FromSoft with a knockoff souls game. A soulslike without the soul.

author: {'steamid': '76561198396278573', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 4344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1271, 'last_played': 1733548166}
review:
This is a really fun game at times, but it ends up being frustrating a little too often, more than being fun. When you're fighting a mainline boss, you can get into a really nice flowstate of blocking and attacking and it feels really nice. Unfortunately, the combat doesn't translate well into fighting multiple enemies at once, especially when the enemies can use thrust, sweep, or grab attacks, all of which have the exact same symbol show up but require different responses, which is really difficult to tell when fighting more than one enemy specifically, usually fine against one enemy though, but I really wish it was a different color or something depending on the type of attack, it would just make things so much better imo. 

Basic enemies don't really do a good job of teaching you how the combat works to then use against tougher enemies, most enemies in the game simply aren't able to deal with you just attack spamming them, which only just further incentivizes you to keep doing that. The leveling system is also fairly brutal at times. and works much differently than the other from soft games. That in itself is totally fine, but the way you increase your health is by getting prayer beads, which are dropped by bosses, or tucked away in hidden areas. This is once again, mostly fine, but that means you are going to be underleveled if you don't fight every boss and find every hidden bead, which really sucks late game because every enemy is going to be killing you in one to two hits because you simply just aren't familiar with every prayer bead location, because why would you be on a first playthrough. When I got to the final boss, I was told that your health is supposed to be around 18-20, but mine was only 16. Tying your health and posture to a level system like that is only going to screw over newer players. Not to mention how hard the game already is. 

This is such a fun fighting style that it's a shame I ended up getting too upset at it all, because some bosses are truly great. But there are a lot of bosses that are just not fun at all, the amount of bosses that can apply terror status to you(this game's insta-death mechanic) is surprisingly high, and I really wish they just didn't exist, insta-death just isn't a fun mechanic in any game imo. The prosthetic system I'm very torn on because a lot of them are really cool, but forcing me to continuously farm them just sucks, I really wish you just spawned with your max count every time, when I'm fighting a boss, I don't wanna stop in the middle and go farm, I want to keep trying, but you feel handicapped without prosthetic tools, so the game clearly wants you to go farm, but that's just not very fun for me. The death penalty in this game is also weirdly high, there isn't a system of grabbing what you lost when you died, you just lose half of your money and exp and that's it, it's just gone, there's nothing you can do about it. Which just means more farming if you want to make up for what you lost. All in all it's a fun game, but it's very punishing while demanding a little too much from you. I wish I liked it more, but it's just too stressful and becomes less and less fun over time

author: {'steamid': '76561198231403756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 633, 'last_played': 1735423994}

I came back to the game after a few months' break, with the controller working before the break, but all of a sudden, the controller stops working. Absolutely no idea why. It just didn't want to work, no matter how many hours or countless videos and community posts I look through to fix the problem. It just won't work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058903807', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1954, 'last_played': 1713747308}
review: Having to spend hours learning patterns isn't as fun as some make it out to be. The gameplay is OK but don't buy this game thinking you'll play a Dark Souls game. I've played all From Software games and it's the only one I didn't quite like. The lack of stats makes the progression too linear and you can't really feel much of an upgrade at any point. Prothetic upgrades are the same, could not really see much of a difference between base and max upgrade. All in all, this game felt more like work than fun. You must get killed to learn patterns at least several times. The game forces you to simply run around/away or in circle in order to survive the toughest boss battles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054187217', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1538, 'last_played': 1712886327}
review:
I just want to start with saying I'm a huge fan of fromsoft games and I've beat dark souls 1-3 and eldenring all solo at least once. People are in these communities are incredibly rude when it comes to any criticism and just like to tell people to "get good". So I have a lot of experience with these kinds of games.

I don't think this game is for most people including most souls fans. It's just too damn hard. Combat especially some bosses just requires absolutely perfect timing for deflections. I enjoy a challenge but fighting bosses like Genchiro 50 times and not getting any closer to beating him isn't fun. Especially when You've already done everything else you can. You're required to beat him to move on. Most bosses have strategies or cheeses you can look up but good luck figuring it out yourself. And even when you know it some bosses are just too damn hard. 

The combat overall just required too much perfection with timing and movement. Miles beyond anything in a souls game.

I don't have the best controller and due to personal problems I'll never have perfect timing. I broke down and had to cheat because I just don't think this game is beatable for me. I don't think it will be for most people. I just can't recommend the game because of that. I don't get much enjoyment out of beating a boss after breaking down and looking up a guide to fight them. But if you do or you enjoy dying 100+ times per boss to figure out how to beat them, go for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198885947270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1707728477}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025417603', 'num_games_owned': 335, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 2003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1431, 'last_played': 1723656507}
review: Sekiro presents a streamlined take on the Souls formula. I personally dislike how it railroads you into a specific playstyle, but the combat is crispy, the sights are breathtaking, and the lore is surprisingly deep. Its weakest aspect is its unclear feedback, which often left me questioning the inconsistent cues and attack tracking to the point of detracting from the thrill of boss victories. I’d recommend Sekiro if you’re seeking Fromsoft’s distinctive charm and are willing to overlook some rough edges. Otherwise, consider the rest of the Fromsoft catalog first, as this isn’t their strongest showing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005625830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1716724956}
review: Similar to other From Software games (ie Dark Souls): Difficulty curve of a brick wall. Looks cool tho and story seems good too but I'll never see it. If you're into these games I'm not knockin' what ya do if you like it, I personally don't tho because I don't find enjoyment in a game where bosses can take literal days of trial and error to defeat. If I feel like I'm getting nowhere then it feels like I'm wasting my time, which isn't a feeling you should have when you just wanna have fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126161605', 'num_games_owned': 358, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 1374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1374, 'last_played': 1717441960}
review:
This game has some of the best fights and mechanics. Why do I not recommend it ? Because it doesn't understand what makes it great. The longer sword fights are absolutely awesome. You get into a flow of parrying and attacking and it feels so satisfying. 
But thats such a small part of the game. Most bosses aren't even like that. Fighting against a giant ape that starts screaming and you just die from that scream is such a lame and cheap mechanic for a game that has exceptional sword play.
Addtionally the mini bosses often times deal equal or even more damage than the actual bosses. They have less health though, which makes these fights rather short and you don't get into a flow.

Its not a bad game, but I stopped playing, because the strength of the game, which comes from prolonged back and forth in sword fights, comes far too short and I don't want to spend hours playing something that I don't enjoy just to get to a great fight again. And no, I do not need to "git gud". I like games like these and after lies of P I don't have a problem parrying either, Sekiro is more forgiving even.

review: the sunken valley is the worst location in all games ever made, the miniboss is harder than butterfly and guy with lightning, and the guardian ape is a funny joke, I hate this game, I don't recommend this game for people with weak nerves, you can get serious mental disorders by playing this game

author: {'steamid': '76561198034578617', 'num_games_owned': 231, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1711690979}
review:
I've played a bunch of other FromSoftware games. I have over 1000 hours on Elden Ring to give an idea; my playtime for the other games aren't too far off (excluding DS2).

I hated this game. Controls felt clunky for a game that's all about timing, something that irritated me to no end. I get they like to punish players for dying but I really, really don't like the fact that the NPCs start getting sick as a result of me dying. I'm an older guy, I value my precious time; isn't repeating a boss or encounter punishing enough? And the fact that I have a REDUCED chance for keeping my gold and special art charges as I continue to die makes little sense to me. Why would you like to turn away new players who are obviously going to die a lot on average when starting out? It's such a dumb design decision.

I really, really tried to stick with this game. I hated it from the first few minutes I started playing but I wanted to try being patient. After dying a few times to the first boss then dying several more times on the 2nd boss with a spear in a certain memory, I decided to stop playing. I'm fine with the dying mechanics from the other Souls games because there's always a chance to reclaim your currency but this one is purely RNG-based that gradually gets worse. The bosses are also mostly intended to be killed in a certain way, leaving very little room for creativity. It's heavily skill-based, and considering that there's sometimes lag for my PC setup that had no trouble with Elden Ring I think it's pretty understandable why I became very frustrated while playing.

I bought this game because I thought I was going to have fun, especially as a Souls veteran. I wish I could get my ~3 hours back.

author: {'steamid': '76561199022282953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1982, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1255, 'last_played': 1715108696}
review:
This might be the worst game I've ever played. It's fun for the first few hours, after midgame it become so incredibly infuriating that i don't even have the words to describe it. It's not like you see in the trailers and images "oh fun ninja game", it requires levels of autistic perfection that are not humanely possible to achieve. Paired with the fact that the controls randomly won't work sometimes, it become a great recipe for a sprained wrist and a broken monitor after 9 hours of repeatedly fighting the same boss. 

You'd be better off taking the 60$ this game costs and lighting it on fire, unless you're a no life who can spend every waking hour mastering it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071262013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1711051561}
review:
Never been a fan of enemies sliding all over the place to make contact in a game where health is limited and difficulty is high already. The tutorial tips are horrible/pointless.
Might just be me, but too many bugs. Killed a giant chicken and got slid across the map into a bunch of enemies while in the "finisher" animation.
Unlocks not actually occurring after picking up the unlock recipe/item (after pickup instantly went back to the "home base" to try them out but nothing happened/was available) till I travel multiple times to the "home base" area and I suddenly get multiple unlocks.
Plenty of ghost hits, thought it was just me tilting so I started recording moments I thought it happened and the minor enemies seem to get away with it a bit too often for sure.
I did make it through the first bosses, but still not enjoying the game. For others I'm sure it is great, but not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198272672499', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1705901228}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009386636', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1707390864}
review:
I've tried to play this game several times since release, but it just isn't fun. It is the weakest of the modern From Software games.

The bosses aren't particularly hard, but the amount of enemies you need to fight before them is frustrating. This isn't a "get good" moment, but a fundamental design flaw. This is the first time I feel like saying "the game doesn't respect your time".

The hitboxes and lack of i-frames make losing feel bad when you react correctly. It feels even worse when it took a long time to get to the boss.

The gameplay loop is enough to earn a bad review. The intrusive and boring story, uninteresting hidden items, bad optimization, and no gamma slider further subtracts from the score.

author: {'steamid': '76561198392399764', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 810, 'last_played': 1720742382}
review:
First thing's first, Sekiro is not a souls game. You do not get to create a "build" using a wide variety of weapons and armor with unique move sets. There is no stamina bar. You do not choose which stats to level up as you gain experience. It is a third-person action game where you swing your sword at things, but that is the extent to which it resembles a souls game.

With that said, the combat in Sekiro is extremely boring. Unlike other hack'n'slash games like Devil May Cry or Ninja Gaiden (which the game more closely resembles than any souls game), you have a VERY limited move set to use in combat, most of which is useless. Half the time I find myself mindlessly mashing R1 until it's time to dodge. And the boss fights are such a SLOG. They have WAY too much health and usually overstay their welcome. 

The platforming feels bad and functions bad. Losing half your money and experience on death with NO chance to get it back is a horrible design decision, as is pressing and holding a button to do a universal loot action... which still doesn't pick up the items that are placed in the world. 

And, is it just me, or do all the characters speak painfully slowly? I'm done reading the subtitles and the characters are only halfway done speaking. I don't have this issue when watching anime, so I can only assume the cadence is unusually slow. 

I'll be honest, I didn't beat the game. Not because I got stuck or I couldn't beat it. I just don't want to fight anything using these mechanics anymore. If it weren't for the 2 hour steam limit, I would have refunded it, but I decided to give the game a chance since I love all of From Soft's other games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198895032761', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1719565575}
review: Coming from Elden Ring, I was eager to get into this game. Unfortunately, I encountered several issues. First, fullscreen mode locked me out of the rest of my PC, which was quite frustrating. Then, when I tried windowed mode, it didn’t even display the cut scenes. Surprisingly, there was no option for a border-less window. When I finally decided to stick with fullscreen, I discovered that I was hard-locked to 30fps, with no way to change it. The only solution seemed to involve tinkering with game files, which made it clear to me that this was a poorly optimised PC port. I would have liked to leave a neutral review if that was an option as the initial issues were too annoying for me to even try the game play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198235917166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1845, 'last_played': 1723842436}
review:
Title: Sekiro: Shadows Die Bored

Rating: ★☆☆☆☆

If you've ever wanted to play a game that punishes you for merely existing, Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice is your ticket to digital misery. This so-called "masterpiece" by FromSoftware is a frustrating exercise in masochism disguised as a video game. Here are a few reasons why Sekiro should be left to gather dust on the shelf.

First off, the difficulty curve isn't just steep – it's a sheer cliff with greased edges. The game's combat system, which fans laud as "precise" and "rewarding," feels more like a convoluted mess of poorly-timed button mashing and rage-inducing reflex tests. Every enemy encounter becomes a tedious trial-and-error grind, sucking all the fun out of what could have been a thrilling samurai adventure.

Speaking of adventure, the storyline is about as engaging as watching paint dry. With characters that have the emotional depth of a puddle and a plot that’s thinner than a rice paper screen, you’ll find yourself skipping cutscenes just to avoid the mind-numbing boredom. The developers seemed to think cryptic dialogue and vague lore were substitutes for actual storytelling. Spoiler alert: they’re not.

Then there's the environment. While some players praise the "beautiful" scenery, the reality is a repetitive, dreary landscape that quickly becomes monotonous. You'll trudge through the same bamboo forests, dilapidated temples, and snowy mountains, all of which blur into a forgettable backdrop for your suffering.

The game's much-touted stealth mechanics are another major letdown. Clunky and unreliable, they often leave you exposed and scrambling, defeating the purpose of sneaking around in the first place. And don’t get me started on the clumsy grappling hook – it's more likely to send you plummeting to your death than saving your skin.

Lastly, let's talk about the bosses. Each one is a soul-crushing reminder of why you should have picked up a different game. Instead of feeling a sense of accomplishment, you'll be left with a throbbing headache and a growing sense of resentment towards your controller.

In summary, Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice is a tedious, infuriating mess that mistakes extreme difficulty for depth and convoluted mechanics for challenge. Save your time, money, and sanity – play something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054626843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 967, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1714767909}
review: Really interesting premise but the gameplay feels like a rapid QTE simulator; there isn't much room for creative builds or playstyles. Suffers greatly from camera jank moreso than other Soulsborne games and the character movement feels way too slipperly (not in cool cant touch me way but a why am I on ice type). Area design is pretty nice with lots of elevation that is accessible with the grappling hook. Level-up system is pretty aesthetic but limited since we only main hand a katana. Sekiro does have a really great bonfire menu though that allows you to replay certain bosses and provides interesting lore bits. Dragonrot is a questionable design addition since not only do you lose skill progress from dying, but it also hurts the npcs which makes me feel bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964674095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1553, 'last_played': 1731611732}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040648606', 'num_games_owned': 985, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 3007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3007, 'last_played': 1717438126}
review:
I'd say to skip this one.
There is some fun to be had but I don't think it's worth the time investment needed to get there.

This game is very difficult and it [b]can not[/b] be played like other soulslikes. You will [b]need[/b] to learn to parry. The games gives you no other options. The window for the parry is very generous but at least for me that did not help as a beginner.
For me it took about 9 hours of pure misery until I finally managed to understand parrying. I can not stress this enough. I absolutly hated the game for 9 hours until it became bearable and then another few hours until I could confidently say to have fun. The only thing that kept me going was the fact I spend so much money on it.
To me this just isn't worth it. It also did not help that in my opinion the first 2 areas are the worst in the game.

It may actually be easier to learn if you have no experience with the genre. Before this I beat Dark Souls, Dark Souls 3 and Lies of P all multiple times and struggled immensely. Due to how different it plays I'd say Sekiro is barely the same genre. That that as you will.

(Also screw those grindy achievements.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198258776105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1713747198}
review:
I've completed all the dark souls games and elden ring without farming at all and usually ending those games at level 60-80 (aka a lower level) so what i'm trying to say is I have some aptitude for these games but this game is on a whole other level The current boss i'm on is this drunk dude and on the way to him I have to fight through an axe dude with infinite poise that takes 7 hits to kill and 2 swordies whilst getting shot at by 2 archers (each arrow does 20% of your hp and they fire rapidly). Then when you get to the boss fight there's another 6 minions sitting with the boss and when I finally dispatch them I LITERALLY get one shot by the boss. This trend of having minor enemies with the boss happens over and over again btw. Before I got to this there was also a purple ninja that was impossible to fight and when I looked it up online people said you shouldn't fight him at this stage because you don't have enough health lol.

The phrase people online use is "hesitation is defeat" but if you don't know the boss attack patterns yet it's impossible not to hesitate. Atleast in dark souls the bosses are larger so it's easier to see when they are doing an attack but the last 2 mini bosses I encountered where literally the same size as my character and it was really hard to tell when they were doing an attack vs when they were just approaching me.

The combat is way harder than dark souls and reminds me more of a fighting game where you have to do a specific thing to counter each type of attack your enemies do whereas in ds you can either roll, block or parry in response to all attacks. I imagine this game will be fun to replay but my god it's hard to learn. So enemies can do sweeps which you must jump (x), thrusts which you mikiri counter (B when the attack lands), normal attacks which you should parry (LB when the attack lands) and grabs that you need to evade. It's a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561199528704324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4067, 'last_played': 1712946349}
review:
For the sake of God don't play this game unless you have a lot of time and nothing to do, The level of the bosses and mini bosses difficulty is crazy which will drive you out of your mind unless you have an OCD and won't let go until you finish.

The game mechanics and graphics are absolutely stunning but if you think that you would have a fun relaxing experience and pass some time don't get this game, because the more you advance further the more it feels like a job not a pleasant experience, unless if you're obsessed with Samurai/Shinobi games and got a lot of time to waste.

After every boss or mini boss fight I felt on the top of the world, and things can get normal now but in every next boss fight I was hit by the reality of the difficulty of this game and it's demand of perfection with no window of flexibility to do the things your own way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089261333', 'num_games_owned': 58, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1725558089}
review:
Well I'm gonna be honest, the game is beautiful and the combat idea is cool, but it's not meant to be fun at all. 

What I think is that Sekiro is more like those pretty damn hard college courses where you have to dedicate 300% of yourself to learn and master, the only thing is that this is not going to take you anywhere in life, so it's basically a waste of resources and time. 

It took me so many attempts to defeat Genichiro that I forgot who he was and the reason I was fighting against him. I had to watch youtube videos to remember the main storyline  because I was wasting so much time trying to learn his movements and of course dying like CRAZY that I realized that playing the game just became an stressful burden.  

To sum up, if you're trying to have fun you better avoid any games from this developer, specially this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137027380', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1708708623}
review: For me the game was just too frustrating. This is due to the runbacks to bosses combined with the fact that you can't redo miniboss fights after you've finished them (which I would very much like to do for practice), and the fact that the game penalises you for dying (deathrot...). While the combat feels very good, the game is just too punishing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198978383638', 'num_games_owned': 192, 'num_reviews': 150, 'playtime_forever': 2714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2714, 'last_played': 1714739641}
review:
[h1][b]Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice[/b][/h1]

[b]Rating: 6/10 - Fine[/b]

[b]Sekiro[/b], to me, isn't that fun. I really wanted to like it, I'm a huge fan of the [b]Dark Souls Trilogy[/b] as well as [b]Elden Ring[/b] but the combat, while certainly refined and good-looking, just isn't something that I find enjoyable - and since the majority of the games content revolves around fighting enemies that made me dislike the game as a whole. I didn't like a majority of the bosses and I found that mistakes are punished a little too harshly for my liking, especially in the early game. I also don't like the fact that, unlike all other modern fromsoft games, this game only has one playstyle, mostly because it's a playstyle I actively never use in any other game I play.

But besides that the game looks beautiful, the art direction is [b]Amazing[/b], as is typical for fromsoft, the level design also isn't too shabby either. But none of that could get me to like the game. In the end it just wasn't for me.

I'm also shit at the game, so there is that...

author: {'steamid': '76561198239844368', 'num_games_owned': 393, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2420, 'last_played': 1720478749}
review:
It's a fun game but 10 hours turning around in search of the next step of the story to find out it was locked because of a SIDE QUEST. The Bad and the Good ending was great, but found out i miss one item for an upgrade so one success is impossible because Demon of Hatred is unkillable, killing its 3rd phase will just make him resurrect on his 3rd phase endlessly, probably hidden by a side quest or a mystic item somewhere ? Missing one Chapelet for the last upgrade, even following a guide from a to z would not helps, so one other success missing.
And the second illusion in the domain is unreachable because of one missed step (I did everything to did this in order, following a damn guide).
The worst is that : The game is good and not hard at all. But If you want to do 100% of the success, its just stupid and non-intuitive. 
As a success and 100% lover, i can't recommand it. I'll probably download a 100% savefile to unlock content i've missed and fight bosses i missed. That's sad.

author: {'steamid': '76561199254636172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 4250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3186, 'last_played': 1721532770}
review:
Recommend if you have a lot of time and energy to invest in the game.
Don't recommend if you have other priorities.

You could invest hours into the game learning every attack pattern and timing. Anyone can. Most players will tell you to "git gud", but it comes at a cost of time and energy that could have been used elsewhere. In the end, you pay the price of the game to access it, but you also have to pay with time and energy to be able to enjoy it. If you can afford that, good for you.

I'm just a tired person who wants to wind down when playing games. This isn't for me, and may not be for you either, but that's up to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073835681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1714672186}
review:
Myth: "Supports your Xbox Controller" 

Truth: Good luck getting your controller to work, There are over 100,000 hours of people using emulated m&k controls just to play this game on PC. It makes the movements jerky and choppy. It's 2024... A fix would be simple. I guess the developers got their money from this one so there will be no official patch.  

I value my time and system security. I will not download controller emulators and delete controllers out of device manager  to fix something that the devs could easily address. Maybe if I ever get another console, I'll get to experience this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047378934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1720048564}
review: I love from software games, but the camera in this game is really rough. 3 or more enemies just felt awkward to fight. Maybe I could of powered through and got used to it, but generally the inability to track enemies easily or parry an enemy without locking onto it is just not fun for me. Somehow I did it totally fine in the other Dark Souls games, but in my short time in Sekiro, it put many groups of enemies up against you. I thought Ghost of Tsushima did this well, but not Sekiro.

author: {'steamid': '76561198876384113', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1732382178}

author: {'steamid': '76561198829079814', 'num_games_owned': 60, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1718225100}
review:
I understand this technically isn't a "souls" game however this it by far the worst feeling, clunky and stupid combat in a souls game. The hitboxes are all over the place and enemy tracking feels like they have permanent aimbot, which are not mechanics that should be in a souls game.

The game also teaches the player to dodge and jump grab-attacks which might seem fine however this simply doesnt fit with the rest of the game, again, because of the hitboxes being so unreliable. A game, which combat is focused on being able to deflect and parry enemy attacks should not have so many unblockable/unparryable attacks from bosses.

Also, the stealth mechanic is a fuck*ng joke. Enemies see you through bushes and target you through walls.

I admit that i suck at the game and that it is definitely an okay game however with it being a FromSoft game i certainly expected it to be a lot smoother, and i personally dont enjoy playing such a clunky "souls" game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096564358', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3060, 'last_played': 1716450692}
review: 为了难度而难度。如果不是一流设计能力托底，魂系游戏根本不会起来，但这类游戏没有难度就不成立了，硬伤。增加数值并没有增加机制，难度增加不代表体验更丰富，为了达到魂系特有的体验改俩数值就要玩家多花几个小时练习，始终不会认可这种设计理念。

author: {'steamid': '76561199191855563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1715500680}
review: If you are used to the precise nature of mouse and keyboard games, this game will be quite the disappointment. You must be ultra precise in order to kill enemies but the controls are not precise or consistent. This game requires a very methodical approach to kill dudes but then it has inconsistent delays from pressing a button to the action happening. There are SO MANY mechanics and so much goes unexplained. It isn't that the game is ''difficult''. The game is janky. The story is kinda cool. But why should I care about any of the story. The game gives me no reason to care about any of the characters. All the places it should be strong, it comes up short. I will probably play the whole game, but it definitely isn't sucking me in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012993614', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3068, 'last_played': 1716244193}
review: The art, story and sound teams did an amazing job. The gameplay team lags so far behind it is not even funny. It's a rhythm game. That its, sure there are some tools beside the deflect mechanic but they are extremely situational and usually worthless compared to just spamming attacks against normal enemies or deflecting agains bosses. Most of the bosses fall under the "I kill you in 3 hits but you will need 60". So you have to be good at deflecting otherwise the 8 hit combo will send you to the last checkpoint and you will probably have to go through several non threatening enemies again before you can try the boss again. Rinse and repeat. And let's not forget the amazing camera. I sure do like fighting enemies that do jumps and flips and dashes, especially in tight corridors.

author: {'steamid': '76561198259869673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1712509214}
review:
I guess its a matter of preference but the rhythm based combat is a bit boring after a couple of fights. And the camera controls are also lacking, 

Definitely not a bad game though, just doesn't play like the what the trailers show.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015454849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1730598027}
review: Fun, but a little too hard. You can't really pick your difficulty so you eventually reach a point where you just have to be extremely good or be stuck for hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015134765', 'num_games_owned': 1219, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 1376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1351, 'last_played': 1720915104}
review:
I don't understand why this title gets so much praise. It is a terrible game? No but I find it quite insulting the general consensus says this game is better than any other modern FS title. This is easily Fromsoft's worse modern title to date. Its not a terrible game at all but it just cannot come close to their real behemoths in the soulsborne series (even Armored Core VI is better than this game). I found the story and the "lore" extremely lackluster and disengaging. The world design is terrible I have never played a game with such a disorientating map design like bruh this makes the surge's trash map look decent. Massive amounts of backtracking its sickening (yeah FS titles have that occasionally but wow it is rampant in this game.) The combat is probably the thing I have the least issues with. Am I fan. Not really but in FS fashion its very difficult and punishing.
        Peformance is also not ideal especially considering the year this game came out. Thermals are high for a title that doesn't have the best graphical fidelity and microstutters are out and about.
          All of this led to a game I played in bits and pieces due to the fact I did not care for the title. I had to force myself to beat the game. And I only did it because when you criticize a difficult game the first rebuttal is oh you didn't even finish it you're probably terrible. So I literally beat the game for posterity as to criticize this game only means get ready for the mob mentality to show up. At the end of the day comparing to other games yeah its alright but it was an extremely weak FS title. Heck you could give me this game without telling me who the devs are. I'd never guess Fromsoft. If you are a Fromsoft fan just keep in mind your two hours for the refund button as a hardcore FS fan I did not like this game one bit. The general population rides this. But hey they also ride kakis like horizon.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963475787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1715416946}

Losing XP when you die is the opposite of a game that wants a difficult combat. I
I've played Remnant II Apocalypse mode, but that game doesn't punish you for trying and failing.

This game does. Not for people who don't have a lot of time to waste.
