author: {'steamid': '76561199416082633', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1727473526}
review: Honestly, not only is the game unplayable, but it's extremely difficult to the point that it made me break the controller, but it also doesn't tell me where to go, making the game quite confusing, causing great waste of time for a person who only has one day off, that is, I work from eight in the morning until six in the afternoon,  being that when I get home I have to pay attention to my son, and when he finally goes to sleep and I have very LITTLE time for me, I try to play something to relax but I find myself in this situation where I only get angry in this game that they had recommended to me, AND THAT it was never really my intention to buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198803061274', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1732925305}
review:
As much as it pains me to write this review, I can't recommend someone this game as I myself enjoy it.

I feel like Sekiro is a good game that some people could truly enjoy, but take heed on what you're getting into when you buy this.

This is not an RPG, it is not a character builder, it's barely a soulslike honestly. It is a half stealth game half rhythm where the slightest mistake bitch slaps you in about 20 different ways. Every enemy kills you in two hits, making fighting any more then one absurdly difficult. The bosses are surrounded by enemies that you have to fight through every single time you want a chance to fight them. You lose half your gold and XP on death, with a CHANCE of that not happening, which is diminished by each death, making dying even more punishing then before. Saving up enough to purchase something feels like a mountain, exploring to find a bunch of consumables that slightly increase your stats feels unsatisfying, and the combat while fun at times is just so brutal and unrelenting combined with all the game's other tactics just feels like being punched in the balls over and over again.

I might be given jesters for this honestly, people will laugh and tell me to get good, but honestly as it stands this game just broke me, I hope I can come back later and maybe enjoy it and maybe even beat it, but as of this moment I just have no motivation to play it or try and hone the skills I would need for the absurd difficulty curve.

Should you buy it? If so, prepare for what in my opinion is the hardest gaming experience I've ever had, blowing all of FromSoftware's other works out of the water.

author: {'steamid': '76561199016594128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1714946925}
review: Too difficult. I thought it would be similar to Elden Ring but it's far more difficult. That alone would be fine, but there's no way to level up and get stronger so you can progress. You are just stuck with no way to continue. Checkpoints are too far apart so it's excessively punishing without easing you into it's somewhat unique and confusing combat mechanics. Unclear where to go at times even though the game is linear, (questionable level design). When one enemy sees you, every enemy on the map starts heading over to you, forcing you to deal with several, leaving you with less health for the giant later. The grappling hook was interesting. Timing in combat is excessively strict. I hesitated to get a refund because of how infamous the game is, forgot about it & then it was too late. So if you are unable to beat the giant enemy that shows up pretty early on, (I have 90 minutes in game) a ways after the pack of wolves; I suggest you refund right away so you don't pass the two week mark of no refunds.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993088943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1730817778}
review:
I never quite understood why FromSoftware games are as popular as they are. Their stories are often called deep or meaningful, but I find them soulless and superficial. Theres a certain jank and lack of fluidity in the character interactions, both in fights and in regular interactions with NPCs that makes the game feel both dated and sterile, and as such the whole game world never seems particularly convincing. I accept most people seem not to share my opinion, but nevertheless I wanted to offer a dissenting voice.

The combat and gameplay is in line with most souls games, except more linear. The level design, as in most FromSoftware games, remains beautiful. All in all, sadly Sekiro fell flat for me, and its unlikely I will try it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561199259112993', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1732914243}
review:
This game is a classic FromSoftware installment.

You will get pummeled, staggered, ganged up on and destroyed. That would be all cool IF bigger sized enemies would flinch to your attacks. But they don't, unless you get in a counter hit. Bigger enemies are so impervious to your attacks that it renders the whole attack button useless; the only time your attack does any damage is after a dodge or parry. Parry is key, and yet most unreliable.

Don't get me wrong. Graphics, sound, gameplay, level design - these are all masterful. But the core gameplay, the thing that makes you progress in the game, is horrible. It is all dependent on the one mechanic that is unreliable or at least hard to master.

This brings me to my only frustration with this game. Dare I say that you will spend more time practicing the parry than playing the actual game. This is a gigantic frustration because when I started Sekiro, I wanted to play a single player action game, but now it wants me to play it like a fighting game.

If I wanted to spend hundreds of hours in the lab practicing my moves, I would play some Street Fighter. NOT SEKIRO. I play fighting games and I know a little bit about the rewards of spending time in the lab. Those rewards are largely realised in a fighting game owing to the nature of the fighting game itself; after spending a hundred hours in the lab, the match is over within minutes. You are playing against a character who you could choose to be yourself. There is NEVER A LOSS OF GAINS in a fighting game. You do not lose any items or skill points etc. The game does not make you feel like YOU SUCK.

The reality is that I do not have the time or patience to put hundred hours of lab time in a single player action game, and this game offers me no motivation to even want to get better at it. If I really have to spend that much time to get better in a game, it does not have to be Sekiro.

So at the end of 3 hours, I am dropping this game.

#### you, FromSoft.

author: {'steamid': '76561198298059154', 'num_games_owned': 360, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1722168475}
review: I'm sure the game is amazing after the first Boss, but as someone that always hated parrying in Souls Games this game is just not good for me since 80% of combat is centered around parrying.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972821531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 3655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3655, 'last_played': 1723585507}
review:
While I loved the slower, more tactical combat of the Dark Souls trilogy, I never really warmed up to Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice. The further I progressed in the game, the more annoyed I became with the overall package, especially confusing level design that left me disoriented, and uninspired fights where you had to memorize enemy moves to defeat them.

The difficulty level is absurdly high, and the boss fights, in particular, often force you into countless attempts to achieve victory. The learning curve is steep, rewarding patience more than skill. While I replayed all three Souls games multiple times with joy, I gave up on Sekiro after several attempts at the final boss, as the thought of finishing the game started to feel like a compulsive waste of time. Conclusion: Thanks for nothing, Sekiro, we're done — I simply hate you. Uninstalled and forgotten.

Normally, I open my reviews for comments, but I’ll save myself from the “git gud” comments from fanboys here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049641253', 'num_games_owned': 645, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 4903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3981, 'last_played': 1723533221}
review:
This game is amazing but has one of the worst camera systems I have ever experienced. Why did they design cramped spaces with objects you can get stuck on in a game where everything one-shots you? I am all for difficult combat, but managing this camera constantly is so infuriating I can't handle it.

I will be playing Lies of P next and will report back If this is a general problem or If FromSoft are just incapable of doing a good camera system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002827910', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1733027427}
review: Don't fall into the trap of thinking this is a souls-like, it is a fundamentally different type of game. Unfortunately, it is one that I dislike immensely. Stealth mechanics, tons of gank fights, entirely parry based making it feel almost like a rhythm game. On top of that I found the exploration to be extremely poor, you will be relying on guides to find anything you need.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962492323', 'num_games_owned': 164, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1708250634}
review:
UPDATE: nothing has changed, so im just going to say its a 4/10, devs are objectively sub-standard, many might argue that, but objectively it is a factual statement, folks are just to well accustomed to being served less these days while paying more for it, so even if something is objectively not that good, in absence of anything better, most liken to what they wouldnt if games were actually top tier and not just in name only, thats why folks arent all rushing to play Atari games, as outside outdated visuals, most the games werent very good to begin with, despite at the time gamers dumping hours into them, it was just it was the best they had available to them at the time and not much has changed in that regard.

Sekiro is objectively sub-standard far as the gameplay is concerned, visuals are a mixed bag, being either ok or sub-standard, even after being bored many times since my original review i have had no reason or desire to go back to this game, as the first experience was terrible and indicative of a developer of low standards and care for their product and likewise the opening segment of the game simply drilled that in even more.

sure there are far worse games, but this is why i gave Sekiro a 4/10 as thats the objective score and not my opinion, were for my opinion i would give it a 1/10 because i dont even want to get my $$$ worth, its that bad of a experience to me, even a 1/10 is probably to high and a 0/10 would be more appropriate as i doubt i will ever get my moneys worth, so its effectively paying for grief as a experience at this point and giving a positive score for grief doesnt make any sense, a negative score would be more appropriate so lets just give -3/10 far as my opinion is concerned... again not the worst experience i have had in gaming, but thats why it still has a better opinionated score then many other games id rate much... 

yes i have standards and i aint lowering them, they continue to increase as technology and software gets better, so if devs arent keeping up thats tuff cookies, objectively i cant score their games higher, when they dont want to even push the min bar possible at the time of their games development vs what they could easily do...

so just because a game is believed to be top tier, that is just often a opinion, not a objective fact vs what the software, hardware and DEVELOPER could do, but didnt, with much having nothing to do with creativity or talent, just a question of wanting to do it or not, like deciding if you want to put good tyres on your car or not, its not a talent issue or a time issue and for games often it isnt even a $$$ issue either, yet we still get sub tier products despite time, budget and staff being more then enough to do much better at a BASELINE level, but because it means less is expected the more they do it and get away with it = creativity and talent will never be needed to make a new product that sells and its a easy win release after release long as nobody raises those standards to min levels... 

though if your bringing in a DEI consultant or making the whole game DEI compliant you might just waist 400+ million the way Sony did with Concord or many other games in recent times that flopped hard due to such idiocy and likewise outside gaming in general... 

ORIGINAL review: Starts up in controller mode, you have to change it to keyboard/mouse or nothing works properly = seriously WTF? who did they employ to port this to PC?

Doesn't have complete keyboard keybind customisation either, a bunch of standard keyboard keys are not detected for binding, any decent dev will have a keybind template for the computer languages they work with eg what they always get employed to use, so there is no excuse = which they can just copy paste for each game that includes every standard key found on a keyboard because why would you leave out standard keys found on EVERY PC KEYBOARD IN EXISTENCE? you have to be a moron to do so. Especially since they will obviously need to do this for every dam game they do keybinds for, ultimately you will end up wasting time if you dont have a complete keybind list. so there is no sense writing the code manually each time for each game unless your a moron... you do it once, save it as a template (like with all repetitive stuff) and just modify and adjust it for your needs.

I have done solo game dev, so i would always just copy/paste a keybind template and other common stuff etc etc, normally i just copy the whole thing and just delete whats not needed, saving myself a few hours, including testing since i know there arent any typo's etc in the copy/paste part = i can immediately go to the manual section of code and focus on that... so this sort of crap in AAA games has no excuse, it shows people have no idea what they are doing when it happens and who ever is responsible should be immediately fired, including any QC that ignored it and anyone else that it had to be passed by before being approved/finalised as it directly red flags them as being a wage leech. were if the folks paying the bills dont care = i have no plans to support this dev in the future as = they will do it again and more, so regardless how good the game may be otherwise (i dont know have yet to play it) it basically makes me raise a skull and bones flag on my ship for all future encounters with this devs releases, they clearly dont deserve my $$$... assuming i can be bothered when i have to waste so much time before i can even play the game how i want to even when i get it for free... think i will probably pass, but suggest a skull and bones flag for everyone who can be be bothered to try this game.

due to this in-excusable sloppy joe employed by the studio to do such a simple job, it basically means in order to use my default custom keybinds that work for basically every other game by default, i have to create a new profile, with new keybinds so this one game recognises the buttons i want to use, so i can play using the buttons i want for typical movements and actions, what a joke.

probably not a problem if your a controller user or someone who just uses the typical poorly mapped keybind for these kinds of lazy console made to PC ports, but yea, for over 10 years ive setup and used the same custom keybind setup, which i basically mirror everytime i get a new mouse/keyboard and follow the same map for every game so everything stays in muscle memory or logical to what i typically press on my mouse of keyboard, so it really ***** me of when a dev can so blatantly and shamelessly be bad at their job, how did they even manage to get employed? 

Again having experience myself seeing this level of work which is well below F grade by comparison to a free mod community, its no wonder so many AAA games launch like trash even when they pay people to do the job, they cant even compare to a modder with ZERO CODE EXPERIENCE who is just a novice, reading a mod tutorial onine only to covert game files to TXT, so they can edit them and convert the back = better then this dev at their job = what a joke, thats how bad the folks responsible for this were, even a novice who doesnt know how to code can do a better job... again HOLY COW!.

not sure if i can be be bothered to play this game after loading up yet another lazy port, only positive is i got it on sale, but already feel scammed before even leaving the menu screen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010769005', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4202, 'last_played': 1713986443}
review:
Despite loving FromSoft titles of years past, I find this game to be riddled with combat errors that make it a miserable and unfun experience to play through. The controls are extremely unresponsive and hitboxes are imprecise. If you don't tend to notice these things, then you might have a good time, but I simply cannot have fun when nearly every single fight I engage in is riddled with glaring mathematical errors. It makes dying feel unfair and winning feel unsatisfying. 

This game would be trivial if Sekiro actually parried when I pressed parry, dodged when I pressed dodge, and Mikiri countered when I pressed the button for it, but that simply does not happen. If that is not your experience, then congratulations--I sincerely wish I could play your copy of the game because mine is clearly faulty in some way. 

Even after killing every single boss, the fights feel just as random and frustrating as the first day I played the game. There have been no improvements even after 70 hrs of gameplay, Any other game that I play, including other FromSoft games, I can go back to the beginning of the game and feel like a master. That is not the case in this game.  This is how you know the game is fundamentally flawed to its core.

author: {'steamid': '76561199468677676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1716879494}
review: This game is incredibly hard. I initially got it for my 13 year old son and he ended up breaking his chair and controller over this game. I tried it out afterwards and I can agree that this game is very hard. Its effects on my son are visible as he no longer leaves his room and I frequently hear him screaming and crying through the walls while breaking things. I would not recommend this game for children

author: {'steamid': '76561197970728510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1714574769}
review:
This game is pretty terrible.

The dodge mechanic isn't supposed to be relied upon, but is present.

The bosses have too high of health and too many variations of attack to parry them consistently.

You either have to memorize their attack patterns and also accept despite remembering them you're still going to need luck to beat them.

Or, you cheat.

The environments are not very large, the difficulty of combat makes them seem bigger than they are due to the number of deaths you'll automatically be subject to because of difficulty of combat and number of enemies.

Also the camera lock feature will randomly disengage with default settings which can ruin boss fights.

The prosthetic feature and the enemies being disfigured are distractions to what could be an authentic Japanese setting / atmosphere.

Overall, a pretty terribly designed game with some memorable scenes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198161412125', 'num_games_owned': 61, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2688, 'last_played': 1710960456}

I didn't enjoy too much. It has its moments and every souls-like players should try for sure but for me wasn't it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054223319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3668, 'last_played': 1725222133}
review:
Sekiro is an awesome game. It's challenging, more challenging that any of the Dark Souls games in my opinion. The fact that you have to add parry/block actions to the gameplay really makes the game unique and rewarding after completion. 

Why negative review then? 

Well, for a game that costs 60$, especially from From Software, and ESPECIALLY in GOTY version, you would expect the things to be perfrct. One thing isn't perfect, in fact, it's not working at all - I'm speaking about the controller. Something in this game is preventing from "normal" use of a Xbox controller. "Normal" meaning - you just plug it, like in any other souls like game and you play, no questions asked. In Sekiro, I had to spend around 5 hours fixing my controller sh*t, searching on Reddit or other forums for a solution. We all know Sekiro has an issue with controller detection, setting THE controller which you are using to be your primary one. In all of those 5 hours I didn't find the solution, I've actually had to develop one for myself. Forum posts helped me find clues but in the end I HAD TO install EXTERNAL software, written by REGULAR people (not devs, like it should have been done). Only after that I was able to play, only after 5 hours of searching and testing.

To me it's unacceptable that a 60$ game of such prestige has this kind of basic problems, unsolved for 5 years so far. So if you are intrested how I'd fix it, check out my guides for a solution.

Other than that, like I said, game is a masterpiece itself. Fights are challenging, even the very basic ones. Maybe you are just a little bit tired with Xbox controller since you have to basically use parry (LT) all the time, and with your finger being a little bit up on your left stick (L) makes it uncomfortable after a few hours but w/e. 

I didn't like some of the boss fights, which basically required some of the Schinobi tools to use. You could do those fights without the tools but it was a pain. Also the fact that you had to tweak your consumables with your right hand on the D-pad made the fights frustrating sometimes.

All in all, very challenging game - to me the most difficult FromSoftware game so far. It was a great learning experience and awesome joy after each boss beaten.

author: {'steamid': '76561199152824589', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 117, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1736210293}
review:
Sekiro is a stealth game masquerading as an action/soulslike.  It is very much different from the games that it inspired.  In these open - yet - linear worlds, you face a barrage of enemies to make it to the end.  The game is fun if you know what to expect from it.

PROS:
1.  This is a challenging game, in a good way.  It is not unbearably hard, but it is much harder than games like it and the games that were inspired by it.
2.  There is a grappling hook, which is always good.
3.  If you're looking for a game with a little more emphasis on combat, this may be the game for you.

CONS:
1. The game forces you to play in a specific way - that is, in a stealthy way.  If you try to get around this, you will have a terribly difficult time.
2. The game can somewhat be played like a rhythm fighting game.
3.  Story and gameplay could be improved upon.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980901844', 'num_games_owned': 207, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1721799016}
review:
After 15 hours of gameplay, I can say I am starting to appreciate the game a lot more.

My main issue remain with controls and the camera. Essentially, some boss fights are too fast for the camera when locked onto an enemy.  Especially if you are fighting close, which is going to inevitable happen in tight spaces. You will eventually lose vision on the enemy and/or the camera will just detach, and you'll end up looking in all directions confused trying to reacquire the target lock. Extremely frustrating, as many enemies will deal a huge amount of damages per hit, and anticipating their moves is critical. It's frustrating, but only in some part of the game. It does work for the most part.

If you can overcome this aspect, you'll find a solid game. The combat mechanism is quite unique. Sekiro has interesting mechanics, beautiful graphics and a good story. It's as difficult as everyone claims; it makes Elden Ring look easy in comparison, as an example. That is because you cannot actually grind mobs to level up, or gear up for a specific boss fight. You can acquire prosthetic and combat arts which are not really game changers for the vast majority of the game boss fights. Because it has been stripped of most f RPG elements, you are actually required to master the art of combat and play the way the game is meant to be played. Boss fights usually can't be cheesed in any way. 

As with any Soulslike, you'll probably want  to spend some time reading wikis and watching youtube videos to make the learning curve a bit more manageable but realistically, the game is not as complex as other soulslike.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169732987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1720114119}

author: {'steamid': '76561199438801562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3828, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 3828, 'last_played': 1715018031}
review: Too Brutal of a game and not enough reward in my opinion. I'm a souls-likes fan, but the pure challenge of the game is not enough to motivate me. I need more incentive to keep playing especially in difficult games. I find motivation in rewards that give me a wider range to experience the game. I guess sekiro is some what of a swordplay simulator ( which is cool but it's too bare bones in my opinion). With the blandness on top of the extreme difficulty it doesn't feel like a "fun" game. I played to complete because that's what I like to do with my games, but about half way through I just wanted it to be over. If I ever muster up the courage to do a 2nd playthrough maybe I'll appreciate it more. As it stands right now I never want to play a sekiro-like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040316249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1715212159}
review:
The camera is completely poop, especially against multiple enemies. I suggest for their next game the developers take a look at Mordhau/Chivalry for how to implement proper 3rd person controls.

The combat seems to be pretty dull, you learn the enemy attack patterns and that's it. If you want a proper fighting game, play Mordhau/Chivalry instead. Playing against real people means that the skill ceiling is infinitely high. In these game every fight is different and not simply a preprogrammed choreography.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094513586', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1020, 'last_played': 1711989071}
review:
I expected more of a Dark Souls experience than a rhythm game experience. Don't get me wrong, DS has its rhythm moments, but that's all this game is. No clue why Fromsoftware decided to make a stealth game with half-baked stealth mechanics that get the job done, but only just. Like Dark Souls the world is decently sized, and non-linear in many cases, which I personally enjoy, but can see how that may be a deal breaker for some. There's also a story somewhere in the game, but it's hard to find sometimes, and not really all that engaging, so the only thing bringing you back consistently is gameplay - which again is more rhythm than anything.

TLDR; It's an unrelenting, half-baked-stealth rhythm game made by the same people who made Dark Souls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113492670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 608, 'last_played': 1733239112}
review:
Alternative title - Git Gud: The Game

Do not go in looking for your usual Souls-like experience. The game is very inflexible, dictating a very specific set of playstyles. No swapping between weapons or trying to go through with magic, no over-levelling, and definitely no dodging. The dodges don't even have i-frames (citation needed).

Instead, stand your ground, and keep attacking and deflecting until the enemy gets tired so you can kill 'em in one hit. It took me ages to adapt to Sekiro, but I've gotta say I love it and I hope you will too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043936163', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2965, 'last_played': 1731848152}
review:
Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice is something else. While it’s a game from the same minds that brought us Dark Souls, don’t go into it thinking it’s just another Soulslike — it’s not, and I think that’s what makes it so wild.

First off, forget stamina bars and RPG elements; they don’t exist here. There’s no leveling up your stats, no changing armor for different buffs, and you’re not going to find a sweet spot for magic builds or heavy weapon setups. This is pure, unfiltered skill-based combat, and if that sounds intimidating, well... it is. But it’s also what makes Sekiro such a standout.

I’ve gotta be honest: the combat is what’s going to make or break this game for most people. You’ve got one sword and a whole lot of grit, and that’s pretty much it. The core of the gameplay is all about attacking and parrying. It’s super focused, and that’s intentional. From Software knew exactly what they were doing by designing each fight to challenge your mastery of this single skill set. At first, I found it pretty brutal. There’s no fallback to a ranged build or summonings — it’s just you and your katana, one-on-one with whatever nightmare is staring you down. But once you get the hang of parrying, deflecting, and the glorious Mikiri Counter, the combat transforms from punishing to exhilarating.

The posture system is where Sekiro really sets itself apart. Unlike most games where you’re chipping away at a health bar, here you’re breaking down an enemy’s posture. Every parry, deflect, and attack fills up their posture gauge, and when it’s maxed out, you’re rewarded with a death blow that can end the fight or push them to the next phase. It’s so satisfying that I’d argue it’s one of the best mechanics From Software has ever come up with.  One thing to keep in mind: attacking is still important because a lower health bar means you’re going to deal more posture damage. So, finding that balance between pressing your attack and keeping up with deflections is key. It’s a dance, and when you nail it, it feels absolutely incredible.

Now, the game has its lows as well, the steep learning curve is real, and some fights had me on the edge of rage-quitting. But even at my most frustrated, I couldn’t shake the feeling that every death was my fault. The combat is precise, and it rewards practice and timing like nothing else. It’s the type of game where you can come back a week later, fight the same boss, and suddenly it clicks because you’ve gotten better.

TL;DR; If you’re into From Software games and want to test your skills with a fresh take on combat, Sekiro is a must-play. It’s a game that’ll have you cursing your reflexes one minute and feeling like an unstoppable sword master the next. And that’s the magic of it. Absolutely recommended. Just know what you’re getting into — this isn’t your typical Souls game, and that’s kind of the best part. 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198055525423', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 31573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31573, 'last_played': 1733128055}
review:
I don't normally write reviews on steam, and I especially don't write any in-depth reviews, but this game is an exception so here we go. Hopefully this review gives at least one person a better shot at what this experience is and I will be happy.

So let me start out by saying that I was very new to souls games when I started playing Sekiro. I had just beaten DS3, which I loved and was looking for more of that before Elden Ring came out. This game is NOT like Dark Souls, or Elden Ring, or any of the other souls game. This game is something entirely different than any game you have ever played... This was initially upsetting...

I quickly realized that this game wasn't really what I was looking for and refunded it. After playing many other souls games, I eventually returned to this game with a different mindset. I tried to have patience but quickly became frustrated. I couldn't dodge effectively, I couldn't parry consistently, the hit-boxes were BS, there were too many enemies, I couldn't just over-level... It felt like every part of this game was unforgiving and out to punish you on every level. I struggled my way through the first several bosses in hopes that I would improve, gritting my teeth the whole way. 

The final straw was a boss named Genichiro. This boss is the first true skill test you come across in this game. He tests you for almost every fundamental mechanic in the game to make sure you understand it. It was... impossible... He had soooo much health. His moves were so quick, he had THREE FULL PHASES!!! I thought there was no way I would ever be able to beat him, and maybe I didn't want to at this point.. I died to him countless times.

The really interesting thing about this game is the way everything comes together. There is a point in there where you die over, and over, and over, and over and you don't think you're getting better, but you actually are. The amazing thing about the human brain is that it picks up on things it doesn't even understand that it can pick up on. Slowly but surely, those "fast" moves start becoming readable. You start to know what moves transition into what. You start finding openings where you thought there were none. You start to dance with your foes rather than fight them... This stage might take you 10 times, it might take you 100, but I promise if you keep at it your hands WILL eventually learn what to do, even if your brain doesn't.

After enough attempts, something clicked in my brain. If you have ever seen the scene in The Matrix where Neo becomes awakened, its almost exactly like that. You start to anticipate every attack, every move. Its like you can see into the future... This is what the game is trying to bring you to. There is a motto in this game: "Hesitation is defeat." There is a reason this is the motto. To truly play this game, you must not SEE your enemy, you must FEEL them. In this moment, I truly felt like a samurai, a shinobi. Once you feel the moves in your bones, then you are ready to really experience what this game has to offer.

I  thought that this game had issues(which it does, just not the ones I thought it had). I thought that the hit-boxes or parrying systems were buggy or wrong sometimes. I failed many times and blamed the game. I eventually watched a video of someone beating the game with a dance pad, and with a blindfold(different videos). This showed me that the game is actually(almost) 100% consistent, it was ME that was the problem. Go watch a video of a boss fight in slow motion and it will show you that the hit-boxes and timings are practically flawless.

Once it clicked, the regular enemies transformed from something for me to avoid and be afraid of to something that becomes a challenge that I want to take on. I slowly learned that everything I thought about the game initially wasn't true. The reason dodging is so ineffective is because this game ISNT DS or ER. It is trying to teach you right off the bat that dodging is not how this game is meant to be played. Instead dodging is simply one of your many tools you have at your disposal.

This game has MANY tools. You might think that that by only having one weapon there is not much variety in this game, but you would be very wrong. All of those enemies that I struggled with had a trick, ALL OF THEM. Every. Single. Enemy. Every enemy in this game has an extremely effective counter, you just have to find it. Between the prosthetics, skills, weapon arts, and consumables there is a solution for any "BS" you can think of.

This game teaches you on so many different levels. The start teaches you to parry. The ogre teaches you that dodging is still a tool that is useful for some situations. Gyoubu teaches you that you can parry a lot more things than you thought you could. Lady butterfly teaches you to use consumables(snap seed), the Bull teaches you speed and aggression, the Monkeys teach you stealth, the Guardian Ape teaches you movement and placement, the Owl teaches you to not rely too much on instinct, and so on. I could go on all day about the lessons that this game is trying to teach you, but that is besides the point.

I love all of the souls games, but at the end of the day souls games are memorizing attack patterns and learning how to time rolls, and how to create builds. I feel like this game is much more than that. This game transforms YOU, not your character. New Game+ in the souls games is like a revenge tour of everyone who looked at you the wrong way your first go through. In DS NG+, your character is so much stronger, your weapons are so much better, and you even have a lot of the boss fight patterns sorta memorized so it is easier.

NG+ in Sekiro is an entirely different beast. Yes, your character is stronger. Yes, you have more tools. But the biggest difference in NG+ is you. You are stronger. You have faced all of the trials and tribulations. The bosses you come across will feel like a breeze. Not because you have better armor, but because you now know their moves inside and out. You have become a true shinobi. By the time I played the second time around, Genichiro was no longer a strong adversary, he was pathetic. A fool who was slow and predictable. I knew every move, I could practically do it with my eyes closed.

The Souls games are a test of adversity. They are difficult not to make you mad, but to show you enlightenment. A game is not rewarding if everything is handed to you. Anyone who has ever used cheats in a game has experienced this. It might be fun for a minute, but it is not a lasting joy. For you to truly feel like you accomplished something, you must first overcome adversity. Nothing feels as good as beating a boss that gave you sooo much trouble.

This game is the ultimate incarnation of overcoming adversity. In Dark Souls you can beat a boss, but there is a good chance you will have as much of an issue beating them a second time as the first. What makes Sekiro so special is that when you learn a boss, you learn a boss. They become a tango that you know by heart rather than a battle. Replaying bosses is one of the best things about this game since you will feel how far you came from having your ass handed to you. THIS is the ultimate joy. Mastery over bosses, and if you keep playing, mastery over every single thing in the game. The amount of satisfaction is unparalleled and will leave you wanting more and you just might end up beating the game 40+ times like me because there isn't another substitute out there(Sifu is good).

Suffice to say, I think this is one of the best games ever made and it easily has the best combat ever made. I could go on all day about it. If you like Dark Souls you will like this game, just in a way different way, and it will be harder to get to the place where it all clicks, but good god is it so worth it. So please, REALLY give this game a shot. You have to give it EVERYTHING you have for it to give you EVERYTHING it has...

author: {'steamid': '76561198047060747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4615, 'last_played': 1735015361}
review:
Sekiro is an absolute masterpiece. It is challenging and fun. It enforces an idea that you can do something difficult, if you bring together determination and perseverance, also retrospect your previous failed attempts and improvise on it.

The design of the bosses and game mechanics is something i have never experienced in any other games. None!
Game is not really perfect, (eg : there are some copy paste of few mini-bosses) but the positives surmounts the amount of negatives.

10/10 : Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561199186324106', 'num_games_owned': 61, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 3689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 98, 'playtime_at_review': 1545, 'last_played': 1736586135}
review:
Took a bit to get the feel for it but once everything started to click this became one of my favorite games. Highly recommend if you are down for a challenge.

....But for the love of god FS, PLEASE stop forcing me to sit through loading up the main menu when I am trying to quit your games. When I am relentlessly getting my ass kicked trying to learn a boss move-set and want to rage quit out of the game, and then I have to sit there white knuckled while I wait for your stupid names to flash across the screen, click the main screen, wait for my save file to be found, scroll down, and THEN finally quit to desktop, it really makes me want to punch a hole through my monitor. Next title please add a "save and quit to desktop" option. Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045695770', 'num_games_owned': 412, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 12973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12973, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 12973, 'last_played': 1716373416}
review:
My friend gifted me this game so I gave it a and I'm very glad I did. It's genuinely been a very tough on-going journey with this game.

Because of how fast the game is, no magic or summons, no grinding levels or equipment, no shortcuts compared to other souls games and punishing aggressive spamming gameplay while rewarding engaging in fights while calm I quickly found out I have an inferiority complex with BPD. I figured this out because of my mental breakdowns, Sekiro is the reason I figured more about myself.

The inferiority complex is rooted with my abandonment issues I believe, I feel worthless when I die and that I'm useless, this kicks off my BPD believing everyone will leave me and pushes me into a mental breakdown.

What Sekiro is doing is aiding me in fighting against my inferiority complex by altering my mentality. 

Instead of determining my self worth on dying, I get happy over the minor self improvement with each death. Especially when I learn a combo string. Set small goals each death to achieve instead of outright winning, it helps ^^

If a strategy fails, it's the fault of the strategy and doesn't mean you're worthless or flawed as an individual.

"I'm crap at this game, I'm stupid." upon death turns to "I figured out how to deflect 2 of the bosses attacks. I can work towards deflecting the third attack, I'm making good progress."

If I slip up and start melting down I journal the thoughts to reassure myself that I'm not worthless and that this is just my inferiority complex trying to force it's way into my brain.

Defeat will happen in this game, it teaches you to replace the hate from losing with love and admiration you got from self-improvement.

I also learned the brain applies everything you learn better upon resting, so taking breaks if it becomes too much will actually make you better!

This game actually feels like a form of therapy to me. It's structured similarly to therapy, if you struggle with similar issues please give this game a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198450032094', 'num_games_owned': 55, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 7506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7365, 'last_played': 1721211897}
review:
[u][b]What to expect going into this game:[/b][/u]
- Extremely fine-tuned and satisfying gameplay consisting of switching between being offensive and defensive on the fly. Knowing how to block/deflect properly and when to use your arsenal of prosthetic tools is key to conquering this game's combat, and becoming the best shinobi you can be.
- To get absolutely skill-checked on numerous occasions, especially in your starting hours. This game is hard, and contrary to what the name says, you will die more than twice. However, with enough practice, you'll find that enemies and/or bosses that you first thought to be impossible to defeat grow to become some of your favourite encounters in the game.
- A reinforced brick wall in the form of a certain red-eyed individual wreathed in chains. Trust me on this though, the game really opens up once you manage to break through and emerge victorious.
- Absolutely gorgeous environments to run around, explore and do battle in, as well as an amazing soundtrack to accompany them. The abundance of eye and ear candy in this game is phenomenal, and I will forever mourn the lack of an official Sekiro soundtrack on Spotify.
- A touching story interwoven throughout the game's progression, as well as a memorable cast of characters that you'll grow to care for to an emotional level. There are multiple endings and character side quests, but for the sake of keeping things spoiler-free, all I'll say is to be wary of some of the choices you make throughout your journey.
- New game plus! If you ever want to re-experience the game without resetting all your collectibles and stat buffs, or you want to try going for a different ending, just boot up a NG+ after completing the game. However, be warned that certain enemy stats, like their health and attack power, will be slightly buffed, and will continue to scale up until the seventh playthrough inclusive.
- Post-game boss rush modes and a menu to refight bosses you've encountered throughout your journey. A nice post-game challenge mode for players who are seeking for it, and a neat and accessible way of replaying some of the game's incredible boss fights without having to go through a new game to do so.


[u][b]Miscellaneous details to be aware of:[/b][/u]
- This game is naturally locked at 60fps. If you'd like to unlock the framerate, there's a really nifty mod available online that'll allow you to do so, as well as some other game-altering features should you wish to make use of them.
- The game is, at least from my experience, very well optimised. I don't recall running into any performance issues whatsoever in my 100+ hours of playing, despite running it at basically max settings on what is a relatively mid-tier PC. In any case, I still recommend checking for available benchmarks online to gauge your expected performance before purchasing.
- The game plays very well with keyboard and mouse. I unfortunately don't have any controller experience to share, but I can personally vouch for the fact that you can get good with a KB+M setup. Just make sure to tweak the keybinds to your preference if the default control scheme isn't working out for you.
- For all you completionists out there, most of this game's achievements outside of those for the separate endings are tied to either boss defeats or acquiring upgrades and skills. There are a few miscellaneous achievements that aren't necessarily tied to progression, but you're bound to run into them naturally unless you actively go out of your way to avoid getting them. All in all a simple game to 100%, though it will take multiple rounds of NG+ and a bit of grinding to get all the achievements.


[u][i]Overall thoughts:[/i][/u]
I didn't know what to expect when I first booted up the game, but I did not expect the levels of satisfaction and adrenaline I would experience playing this game. There were many moments where I deemed a challenge too hard and unfun to bash my head against, and considered throwing the towel in. But each time, I persevered, and looking back, I'm so glad that I did, because with each victory, I could feel pride at the fact that I learnt and got better with each attempt, no matter how long it took. 'Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice' truly forces you to get good, but when you do, you're rewarded immensely with opportunities to engage in combat that is basically akin to dopamine heaven. An easy 9/10 from me, and a must-play for anyone who's ever dreamed of becoming an acrobatic shinobi purging rats from the war-riddled lands of ancient Japan.

author: {'steamid': '76561199158532081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6727, 'last_played': 1733050790}
review: This Game has had me relentlessly charging into the same boss fight for 4 hours straight. Although this may sound tedious, I find it incredibly fulfilling to gradually learn how to counter a boss' attacks until you inevitably get to the stage of knowing the victory is just a couple attempts away. Difficult boss fights for me are most memorable and this game is full of them. This was the first FromSoftware game I've played and even though some consider it the hardest, I'd recommend it to any new player to the genre as it perfectly captures that feeling of triumph!

WHERE IS THE DLC FROMSOFTWARE ? WE NEED A DLC FOR THIS BRILLIANT GAME!!!

review: This is a game I wanted to refund at first because it was too hard for me, only to realise my playtime is  above the time limit. Left the game in the dust for months. Some time ago I had 2 weeks off work and decided to give it another try and oh dude... It turned out I was fucking wrong all along. This game has become one of my all time favourite once I progressed and managed to slap some bosses after it finally started to click with me. Most of all, this game is actually so much  fun and I have not been this engaged in a game in a very long time. The combat in this game is  some kind of masterpiece.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126930960', 'num_games_owned': 509, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 8206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8199, 'last_played': 1728329973}
review:
I was there on day one, at 4 am my time when Sekiro got released. I still remember vividly being awake because I was extra nervous for a job interview the same morning at 9 am. Could not sleep, picked up my phone and a friend told me it was available. The wait for the unpacking of the preload was torture!

I also remember losing my first 5h of playtime to my mother opening yet again the laundry machine and oven, on top of my PC, the fridges, etc.; a killer load for our electrical system. My UPS had recently died, my PC went off during a save and it corrupted. Don't get me wrong, my 5h were less than 1 when knowing where to go and what to do, but it still scorched me so bad I keep setting hourly backups of all the active games I play! 😂

For reasons I can't even understand, I'm five years late for this, but it's time I get around to reviewing Sekiro.
And what better time than now, right after playing through it again? Shoutout to Chad of Astora for the video about the intricacy of the maps in From Software's titles, as that reminded me how wonderful Sekiro is.

[h1]Ikuzo, SEKIRO![/h1]

The main character, Wolf, is a servant to Kuro, the Divine Heir, who is blessed with the ability to grant immortality to those who serve him. An ability that shapes the world of Ashina into obsession, considering it's so rare. Said blessing, is the lore explanation for why we as the main character can die and resurrect at least once during a fight, but also at the familiar idol checkpoints in the game when failing, but not without a cost.

Being a shinobi, Sekiro can't win a strength contest but excels in ability and agility. Sekiro's mobility is one of the best parts of the game. The grappling hook feels amazing, and the wall jump, plus grab ledge ability, really gives complete freedom of movement.
Gravity is not deadly anymore, and fall damage is a lot more lenient and can be canceled by anchoring where possible with the grapple, regardless of height.

The world's interconnectivity, heavily inspired by Dark Souls 1, is second only to the aforementioned, and Elden Ring. It's possible to explore and do so much before even completing the first objective after the prologue. 

The stealth mechanics and the ability to assassinate from behind walls, above, or behind enemies are so fun and well executed! The game is better at assassin's-creeding than any of the last games of the series.
Combined with all the shinobi tools you're given, unlockable skills, and shinobi arts, there is a good amount of customization and build-making available while keeping all the options viable.

Lastly, the collaboration with Activision has given us a great introduction and tutorial.

[h1]Stagnant Flaws[/h1]

Although set in feudal Japan, Sekiro is surprisingly varied when it comes to its environment and design, with plenty of cultural nuances. It's sad that for a foreigner many remain obscure because of a lack of cultural understanding.

Sekiro is extremely transparent with its story and is probably their most story-driven title to date with plenty of cutscenes and dialogues. It leaves little to speculate, and descriptions take the place of instructions for usage, more than pieces of a puzzle.

Compared to Western tropes, it seems to me some subjects are dearer to the Japanese narrative, and are often included in many mediums. For example, the cyclicity of a world/universe can be seen in Dark Souls, Final Fantasy 7 Remake, Dragon's Dogma, Jojo's Bizarre Adventure, and Evangelion which I can think of. Much like the Moonlight being present in almost all From Software titles in one way or the other, some subjects and mechanics are bound to be improved and reintroduced in new ways. 
The subject Sekiro focuses on is stagnancy, accompanied by a familiar mechanic that had not been seen since Demon Souls, abeit less punishing.
I mentioned all this because, for the longest time, the Dark Souls community was stuck in the misunderstanding - caused by a flawed translation - that the flow of time for those games was "convoluted" when the actual translation was "stagnant". 
Stagnancy in Sekiro is so excruciatingly explained that in the process, it gives a better idea of what that looks like in Dark Souls.

In Sekiro, my favorite example that sent me into a rabbit hole of research is the character "源” used for the name of an area. Although translated correctly, it also translates to Minamoto, the most powerful and important clan out of four great clans that dominated Japanese politics during the Heian, Kamakura, Muromachi, and Edo periods, who in the Genpei Wars crushed the Taira clan, which the Ashinas were related to.
It's a small history nuance, and not as major as the translation flaw in Dark Souls hindering the understanding of the world, but sad nonetheless as a history buff, when the main setting of the game is Japan, and we could have been exposed to more things like this.

[h1]Mastery is victory, hesitation is defeat.[/h1]

I consider myself a From Software veteran, but there is one boss, my favorite actually, I would say I know like the back of my hand. I can easily tell exactly what it'll do next, and take perfect spacing from its attacks.
I don't say this to boast myself, but to depict a picture of what killing any and all bosses in Sekiro is like. Mistakes are heavily punished, while ability is greatly rewarded.

Learning a fight and its pattern is, for lack of a better example, like learning a track on a rhythm game. It's not just about knowing the song, but knowing how to execute it to a level that will allow you to complete it.
When you learn how a boss moves, the objective shifts from using their windows to damage them, to using what they do against them.
Deflecting attacks will slowly chip away at their posture, giving you the opportunity, if well executed and with enough aggressivity to perform a death blow on a boss with almost all its vitality intact. At the same time, taking some of the vitality down will make their posture recover slower during breaks.
Not all attacks can be deflected, some must be avoided and others must be countered, and it's this intricate dance you do with each enemy that is the magic of Sekiro.

This rhythm, the bosses' ability to dodge or tank after consecutive hits, and the moveset of your attacks being a 4-hit combo with a long recovery on the last move, make the game a souls-lite, although it misses many key components of the genre.
The moveset combo idea worked well in Bloodborne, fast-paced and with low stamina usage, and made its way into Sekiro. The new posture system and rhythm of the boss attacks solve both the attack and roll spam Dark Souls 3 suffered from. All this then made its way into Elden Ring, making it the peak of their work yet.

I never lost a fight without understanding where my mistake was and learning from it, and I was never victorious without feeling like I could do it again.
Sekiro's punishing yet rewarding gameplay is what made me celebrate audibly for defeating a boss I had already defeated in the past, just because I didn't learn it so well at the time, but mastered it now.

[h1]Memories of Extraordinary [...][/h1]

After winning GOTY - might I remind everyone against Control, Death Stranding, and Resident Evil 2 Remake - almost a year after, a patch was released that added both a boss replay mechanic and three boss rush modes that award different outfits for Sekiro.
This is something I always felt was missing, and I'm glad made its way into it, although breaking a LOT of mod compatibility in the process. This also added some asynchronous online functionalities, like player ghosts and messages.

Although seemingly more restrictive at a glance, Sekiro offers some of the best visuals, gameplay, and movement in gaming.
It all builds up to the best reward for skill and ability of any of the From Software titles, and it makes me hope the true ending is nothing but a nudge to a sequel that would be more than welcome.

[b]10/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198083712192', 'num_games_owned': 1128, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 6910, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6910, 'last_played': 1702683769}
review:
In my opinion one of the hardest soulslike out there, this isn't a unpopular opinion or anything, a lot of people think the same way, but just pointing it out, what makes it so hard is probably a whole new combat system we've gotta get used to in a very fast-paced setting, it forces you to learn on the fly!

Other than that for me, easily an 10/10 game, if you're an die-hard fromsoftware fan like me you'd know the characters, worldbuilding and fights are just top-notch bar none.

There sure are some excruciatingly hard bosses, but it's what makes this game good, the satisfaction after finally understanding how to parry/counter a moveset of a boss eventually leading to victory, it's all worth it in the end.

As someone who also 100% this game, you do have to play through multiple playthroughs to get all the achievements so it's a bit tedious, but also seeing the different endings and the additional bosses you have to go through is just honestly so worth it. (would estimate 60-80hrs of playtime to 100%)

I love this game so much, and I hope you enjoy just as much as I do and show your support if you can, would love to see a sequel to this game someday.

author: {'steamid': '76561198175974851', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 8884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8884, 'last_played': 1713627193}
review:
One of the most satisfying experiences you can have is when a fight finally clicks and turns into that epic parry-rhythm battle. I returned after a long break to get the remaining endings and achievements and I fell in love with the combat, visuals and sound all over again.

If you are here after Elden Ring or other fromsoft games, don't go into it with the same mindset and expectations since Sekiro is its own. For example, while dodging has its place, parrying is king to win that posture battle. Good luck, ninja! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561199207326519', 'num_games_owned': 164, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1459, 'last_played': 1720372081}
review: Sekiro good game. You fight many enemies. Hard, but fun. Cool sword moves. Big bosses tough, need smart thinking. Pretty world, nice to look at. Must be sneaky sometimes. Story deep, but you need to pay attention. You die, learn, get better. Very satisfying. Sekiro make you feel strong. Sekiro 2 when? 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198040060656', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 9623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9611, 'last_played': 1716057860}
review:
After about 160 hours, I finally got all the achievements (not in record time, by any means), and the thought(s) that I am left with is simply just, wow. Sadly, a few years late to the "party", but playing Sekiro was one of the most memorable, enjoyable, painful, stressful, and sado-masochistic experiences I have ever experienced in my 20+ years of life. 

I will never forget it. I will never forget all the pain, the deaths, the grind for the XP, but I genuinely did miss actually playing a game - like back in the day when games were memorable and made a lasting impression - that imprinted itself into my own mind. 

I bought the game on sale too, so absolutely worth it. Looking back, I would even pay full price. 

A lot of people will tell you, "don't touch this, you will hate it" or "Sekiro is painful", which, is partly true, but learning the game and its mechanics, is the most rewarding feeling ever. It just requires that you remain persistent, keep grinding, and eventually it will click. Do get it, even if you haven't played other Souls games. This was my first, and I am glad that it was.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069477349', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2052, 'last_played': 1705290755}
review:
Great game. 

Great bosses all around, difficult but extremely fair outside of a few large mobs and arenas. Lots of ways to play the game to make it more easier/difficult depending on what you want. Can be frustrating at times but simply stopping and coming back really helps. Once the game clicks for you, it becomes exponentially more fun. 

The game also doesn't overstay its welcome and ends at a satisfying point along the play through. Highly recommend to anyone who wants to play a difficult game. 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198241078972', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 14269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14200, 'last_played': 1712500417}
review:
Not for the faint hearted.

It took me a long time to grasp the fundamentals and avoid getting my head stomped in during every single encounter. 
But once you engage with the mechanics and play how the game intends you to play, the combat is unlike anything you will ever experience in a video game. It's exhilarating, incredibly satisfying and will ruin your experience of playing every other Souls title.
The presentation is also sublime, the audio feedback is great, the story and setting is incredibly interesting and you will quickly find yourself absolutely immersed in the world FromSoft have created.
Greater character customisation would've been appreciated, but the very active modding community have ably stepped into the breach.

Phenomenal title. I hope beyond hope they will create a sequel one day. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077222198', 'num_games_owned': 306, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1248, 'last_played': 1722757025}
review:
I have tried this game a handful of times. I was getting farther each time but not really having any fun, and I didn't really feel like I was getting any better. I beat the lightning archer man and made it to where the game splits the path in several directions. None of the paths felt right and this already difficult (for me) game ramped up to something I couldn't handle. I never really got the hang of the combat system in the first place and the game asks pretty early in for mastery of the fundamentals (which is fine).

IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR ANOTHER SOULS-LIKE! THIS IS **NOT** IT!
It much of what makes souls, a souls game. It was not meant to be a souls-like. I dont hold that against the game AT ALL.

I recommend the game because there is a world where I do get the combat and absolutely love this game. It has some absolutely AMAZING mechanics and makes you feel like a shinobi. Sadly I was unable to git gud.

author: {'steamid': '76561199007028442', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 11379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11353, 'last_played': 1733918470}
review: Makes you feel like the boss when you master the combat, very cool looking and intense combat and great boss fights.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113687203', 'num_games_owned': 231, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 3400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3400, 'last_played': 1640979549}
review:
The quality of decision is like the well-timed swoop of a falcon which enables it to strike and crush its victim.

Hesitation is defeat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198825059582', 'num_games_owned': 133, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2311, 'last_played': 1734058151}
review:
Peak souls game after Bloodborne. If you are looking for fast paced and fluid CINEMA combat this is definitely the game. 
However bare in mind its gameplay mechanics match nothing of those of other souls game but they are very fun to play with and unique to this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064649551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2037, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2037, 'last_played': 1723862520}
review:
a pinnacle of gaming. a zenith of game design. a culmination of countless kalpas. a height which few games can fathom. a capstone for game development. a near perfect product. a story rich in history and culture. a championed cast of characters. an abundance of peak boss fights. an embarrassment of riches disguised as a video game. 

sekiro: shadows die twice is the quintessential game for gamers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044658419', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 17, 'playtime_at_review': 3914, 'last_played': 1736048102}
review:
"Get Good" 
The most appropriate phrase to use for this game.
It's tough and demanding, but I've never felt more satisfaction with gameplay and beating bosses after countless attempts.
This game has opened me up to Soulsborne games despite being the outlier of the bunch, its differences are what defines it and makes it more engaging allowing you to feel like your skills are actually improving!
This might not be a game you'll instantly be blown away by if you ever get to try it, but if you persevere and invest a little time there is a truly masterful game underneath that layer of initial difficulty resulting in some of the most satisfying gameplay you can experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198294721368', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3876, 'last_played': 1724049947}
review:
This is one of my favorite games I have ever played. It had that challenging feeling just like every soul-like game, especially the fight mechanics, which are very unique and hard to learn at first compared to every other game, but after I got the hang of how to play and the game mechanics, it suddenly got more fun and more satisfying, and I got addicted without even noticing. 
Also, the lore or story of this game is very easy to understand and every little detail in the game, once you figure out what it means gives you a very satisfying feeling for me I like [spoiler]the "Sculptor" true form it made me shock & emotional a lot[/spoiler]. Another thing that I like about this game is how balanced it is. Compared to other similar games, after you play for a while, you will notice how the game changes from easy to suddenly harder or hard to suddenly easier due to level differences, but this game has a unique mechanic that will change enemies stats to balance out to player stats so the challenging gameplay won't disappear and make the game unreplayable, so it can be called a "[u]Skill-Base[/u]" game without a doubt. 

Overall, [b] "Sekiro" [/b] is one of the greatest games I have ever played. Everything in this game makes me want to play it more, and it deserves to be "GOTY 2019" (game of the year). Except that it's a little expensive compared to how long the game is, but for me, it's definitely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066263543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 10001, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2408, 'playtime_at_review': 9440, 'last_played': 1736462291}
review:
Game is Goated. Hard as Nails, to be certain, but if you play along with what it's asking of you, you will be rewarded with an experience unlike any other. 

Hesitation is Defeat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067974550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2512, 'last_played': 1731900557}
review:
This game separates skillful gamers from casual gamers.
Boss fights require a lot of timing. I promise you'll die more than twice. I have real fun playing the game, dancing with my enemies and discovering this dark universe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198381755148', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 3524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3524, 'last_played': 1701783972}
review:
Absolutely exhilarating! Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice is a masterpiece in every sense. From its breathtaking visuals to its challenging yet rewarding gameplay, every moment spent in this world feels like a journey of self-discovery and mastery. The combat system is incredibly satisfying, offering a level of precision and depth rarely seen in gaming. The level design is intricately crafted, providing countless opportunities for exploration and discovery. And the story, oh, the story! It's a captivating tale of loyalty, revenge, and redemption that kept me glued to the screen until the very end. If you're looking for an unforgettable gaming experience that will push you to your limits and leave you craving for more, look no further than Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice. It's a true gem that deserves every bit of praise it receives. The best game ever someone need to try this epic battle. 

Recomended to play 5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198067250219', 'num_games_owned': 621, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 2956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1484, 'playtime_at_review': 2009, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1736813019}
review:
Compared to Elden Ring and Dark Souls Sekiro will force you to play in a very specific way. However this specific way is the best and coolest way to play this game.

You start off weak and almost get filtered by the bull, but near the end you'll become an almost unstoppable Shinobi. All the bosses (except for an optional boss near the end) are fun to figure out and fight against. I can't wait to try NG+ and get the other endings.

The game looks gorgeous (especially at ultrawide HDR which unfortunately does require a mod).

I don't like the dragonrot mechanic though which makes specific NPC quest lines unable to continue until you get far enough into the game to cure it (temporarily) with a limited resource. Luckily you don't have to use it that often.

author: {'steamid': '76561199115608128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3509, 'last_played': 1715563092}
review: If any of you met me in real life, you'd be dead immediately. I'm well versed in the ways of the blade. I train for 16 hours everyday except Sundays, when I meditate and watch anime where I learn all my combat techniques. I could dismember 7 of you in 2.7 seconds and yes thats a fact I have timed myself during training. I am in everyway a modern Samurai so come at me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198268749500', 'num_games_owned': 464, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 5049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5049, 'last_played': 1561265352}
review:
Fantastic game with combat, storytelling, and the environment designs. Bosses are very good as well in game too.

Unfortunately there are no cats in this game so I cannot consider this game as the best since it must include cats to be classified as best game :c

author: {'steamid': '76561198146551641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 3155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2493, 'last_played': 1710961987}
review:
The first time I played Sekiro I didn't understand it and therefore I didn't like it.
I abandoned it before reaching the first Boss.
God, how naive I was, I almost missed a unique and unforgettable experience!
Sekiro is a difficult and challenging game. The first time, my mistake was approaching it as if it were DS3 or Elden Ring.
Once I understood that being aggressive and deflecting at the pace of each enemy was the key, I became addicted to the combat the game offered.
Each enemy has its own rhythm, its most efficient way of being defeated and its unique mechanics that make the combat the best I have ever played.
he best for me were the bosses. Each boss was like a puzzle that I had to solve. And the challenge they presented was increasing. But never so frustrating that you don't want to keep trying.
At first I thought I wouldn't be able to finish the game, because Genichiro had me as his pet xD
But it was so satisfying to beat him and also find him again at the end of the game to destroy him in a matter of 3 or 4 tries. That's when I realized that the game encourages you to play better and better. And that's something I love.
El diseño de los mapas y lugares donde se lleva a cabo el juego es precioso!
Amo la cultura japonesa, por lo tanto ame recorrer cada sitio
La banda sonora no fue algo que destaco tanto como en otros juegos de FromSoft para mi. PEro igual no me quejo para nada al respecto.
The story is good and entertaining.

As for negative things, I think I can only say that repeating the headless monkey as a boss is quite poor and adds nothing to the game in my opinion, that battle is forgettable.
And that most of the items in my opinion are quite unnecessary. I think I once used a Damage Boost and very occasionally Pellets if I was on the verge of dying on a boss.

In short, an excellent game in my opinion, one of my favorites.
9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198114298083', 'num_games_owned': 75, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3015, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1215, 'last_played': 1724291531}
