author: {'steamid': '76561198061852147', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2, 'playtime_at_review': 4250, 'last_played': 1736721023}
review:
After beating all bosses in the game I have to leave a review for one of the best challenging games I've played.

[h1]I recommend it a lot.[/h1]

Sekiro is a soulslike/rhythm game that provides you with sword clanking ASMR and some of the most rewarding gameplay that makes you feel like you've mastered a fight once done it, so much that a boss fight that once takes multiple attempts to beat can be done first or second try on a second playthrough, and it still feels good.

So if you're a fan of the soulslike genre like I am..

[h2]Pros:[/h2]

- [b]It has the least bs in any 'hard' game I've played, ever. Meaning that deaths actually feel deserved.[/b] What this means, in other words: Hitboxes make sense, you don't die randomly in ways that feel like you had no control over, and the mechanic of being able to revive also means it's *absolutely* your fault if you die twice to the same thing, in the same way.

- [b]The feeling of beating a boss in this game is unparalleled.[/b] It very rarely feels like you got lucky or that you barely made it. Why? Because the game punishes you every time you get away from a fight to heal or even breathe, and encourages that your playstyle involves always standing right next to your enemy until you've perfected the kill. You either lose by using up all your healing items, or win by barely even using anything other than your sword.

- [b]It starts out as what seems to be the hardest souls game ever, but once you learn the basics, it can also feel like the easiest at times. You're adapting and getting good.[/b] This is a pro on its own that follows the previous one because you're constantly being reminded that you're improving by how a boss fight plays out by the time you win. You won't get this from your parents, so Sekiro can provide a good amount of this positive feeling for you.

- [b]ASMR.[/b] Ambience is good, sounds are good, and most importantly, fights often feel cinematic in the good, non irruptive way.

[h2]Cons:[/h2]

- [b]I lied, this is a pro too.[/b] What makes Sekiro a solid, amazing game overall is that it has the least cons in any soulslike. Most of them are the same, like the times the camera decides to give up and betray you, and the obligatory gimmicky/obnoxious fights. My point here being that Sekiro has the least annoying elements out of them all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198409366119', 'num_games_owned': 75, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1732996353}
review: Great game. If you want to try difficult games but are not fond of the slower-paced gameplay of Souls-like games, Sekiro is a good place to start. The combat is extremely tight and fast-paced, and very rewarding once you get used to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198420338095', 'num_games_owned': 1151, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 21794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20306, 'last_played': 1731952968}
review: The very best. A difficult game with an amazing intuitive combat system. Once mastered, highly addictive. Mods make this game even better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198957800061', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2194, 'last_played': 1712926716}
review:
Probably the most refined combat I've ever experienced, there's nothing like it. The gameplay is satisfying and punchy, it's easy to learn but extremely hard to master. By far the hardest FromSoft game I've played as you have no choice but to learn to play it and counter attacks as intended. 
It is also very pretty artistically and the narrative is pretty decent if you pay attention to it. Would definitely recommend to those looking for a challenge, but be ready to be stuck at some portions of the game

author: {'steamid': '76561198003825486', 'num_games_owned': 815, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 3618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3618, 'last_played': 1727256560}
review:
[strike] This is tactical espionage action... [/strike]
Combination of [b] good narrative[/b], [b] strong gameplay mechanics [/b] and [b] process of learning [/b] giving you the most immersive game of From Software studio. It's a linear anti-souls story one hundred percent with amazing sword combat you'll never seen before. It will be so satisfying for you when realization comes out. This game can be beaten without any guide because the world in this game is compact so it can be remembered for months when taking a break like i did myself. Simple and sharp. True masterpiece!

Few words about PC version:
- i'm not recommending any unnofficial easy mods because of respecting game designers
- highly recommending fps unlock mods (dll/background app) for this game because it's not breaking anything in game engine

author: {'steamid': '76561199543546744', 'num_games_owned': 34, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3125, 'last_played': 1733684513}
review:
Sekiro was my second souls game, and like most I died way more than twice unlike what the title of the game says lmfao

However, this was and continues to be one of my favourite games of all time. Sekiro has a completely different atmosphere to it compared to other souls games; its amazing scenery and visuals paired with its purely incredible combat system truly makes this game one of a kind. 

This game is also notoriously difficult, as is the theme with other FromSoftware titles. However, rest assured that once you begin to understand the combat system and it finally clicks, the game becomes much more enjoyable and defeating difficult bosses ends up feeling way more rewarding!

I would 100% recommend this game to anyone who’s up for the challenge, and always remember…

Hesitation is defeat.

author: {'steamid': '76561199477690688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7147, 'last_played': 1714827500}
review:
Peak combat design and game-play. The boss fights go hard. Although the learning curve will be high for many people, at some point the combat will click and you will start feeling like the boss. First FromSoftware game I played and now I am deep in the rabbit hole. 
10/10 - Must play for any gamer who wants a challenging yet rewarding experience

author: {'steamid': '76561198142761748', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4089, 'last_played': 1724485324}
review:
They said "git gud" and "hesitation is defeat"...so I did. I quit once, but I couldn't live with the fact that such a mechanically challenging game remains unfinished as if it's goading me to complete it. 

Before the final boss, I was quite sick. I tried to beat it a handful of times before almost up for the day. Then I said "alright, one last try for today." And that one last try was enough for me to finish it.

In most difficult bosses, I would feel a sigh of relief after defeating them. This time, I felt victorious and overwhelmed. 

9/10

The 1/10 withheld is because the game doesn't fully show the skill trees from the get go, meaning you cannot plan ahead with your build and become more masterful of the tool you have. This particularly applies to the prosthetics skill tree, which can make you more lethal if you apply them to your combos. 

P.S.

There's no shame in watching how other people defeat the bosses, but it's extremely important to not cheese the bosses. You will never learn how to deal with them, nor you'll improve as a player. 

P.P.S.

Shoutout to Jacob Geller's Sekiro video essay for partly motivating me to revisit the game after giving up once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064014293', 'num_games_owned': 715, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 4917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4917, 'last_played': 1726133481}
review: Absolutely fantastic game, really fun gameplay and an awesome story. The mechanics of the game take awhile to stick especially if you come straight from dark souls but its worth it, as you'll be rewarded with an amazing experience. Would highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561199185150634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5664, 'last_played': 1732655463}
review: The game is amazing, if you played too much of it you should check our the Resurrection mode, it made the experience feel new.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983732026', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3892, 'last_played': 1661359011}
review: Love this game! Although it doesn't have coop multiplayer, it has message system similiar to other Souls like games. Very rewarding when you get good at fighting enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078358587', 'num_games_owned': 301, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 11296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11296, 'last_played': 1703718439}
review:
There's not much to say about Sekiro. It has amazing combat with plenty of things to learn and skills to master. The game is merciless in it's teaching but if you listen to the game and what it tries to teach you, you will improve without a doubt and at a certain point the game will become easy and very fun. And there's no other way (mostly), you simply need to get good. 

The story is fine, it's much easier to follow than other Souls games'. It's not as obscure and there's plenty of lore you can find. The game takes inspiration heavily from Japanese folklore and some of the stuff (references) can fly above players' heads.

Game has multiple endings and they are very obscure. Other than that the game has plenty of content to keep you playing and doesn't overstay it's welcome like many others. My playtime includes more than multiple playthroughs, boss rushes and challenges. This is definitely the best game I had pleasure to play in my life. It's also my favourite.

author: {'steamid': '76561199088702605', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1138, 'playtime_at_review': 6155, 'last_played': 1736083296}
review:
Sekiro is one of the most satisfying games in terms of difficulty. All the bosses are incredibly hard, but each of them has a different strategy, and there is actually an easy way to defeat them. Once you realize this over time, the game can become easier. The mechanics of the game are so good that the combat feels like dancing. Especially when fighting Lady Butterfly, it felt as though we were dancing together. Moreover, the journey of the one-armed wolf, Sekiro, and the game's story are very impactful. The atmosphere of Japan’s Sengoku period and the details of Ashina Castle were beautiful.

"Death of a shadow"

author: {'steamid': '76561198124907258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 16587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16576, 'last_played': 1729194210}
review: The combat seems to be really hard, the game very difficult and frustrating, untill you try and try and try and learn the combat. The game becomes very easy after that. An absolut unique experience, a combat game masterpiece. An absolut gem which I recommend and one of my favourite games of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103071975', 'num_games_owned': 370, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4013, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3944, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 759, 'last_played': 1721547380}
review: Out of all the FromSoftware games, the combat in this is "[b]solid af[/b]". The bosses, minus one [i]bull[/i] one, get intricately more complex honing the player's skill as the game progresses, and depending on the ending, that skill is beautiful tested in what can be described as a crescendo of a final battle; the music, the pacing, and the intensity propel this game into a league of its own. No game has come close to the high that comes from mastering the combat system. No typical level system, no changing weapons, or equipping gear; just you, your sword, and the various skills you learn over time. NG is just the tutorial, NG+ is where the true game starts.

author: {'steamid': '76561199168374250', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 3543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1473, 'playtime_at_review': 3543, 'last_played': 1736743724}
review:
This game is very deep and eye watering perfection to 100%.
Makes you hear swords clashing in your head when trying to sleep.

Desperately grabbing the sheets*

author: {'steamid': '76561198307535168', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4059, 'last_played': 1733260520}
review: Favorite fromsoft game, probably the best combat system in any game ever. Can be very difficult to learn proper rhythm for the combat, but my advice is to play it somewhat as a rhythm game

author: {'steamid': '76561198084779333', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3595, 'last_played': 1722812824}
review: Good game design and decent story, but the best aspect is combat - it's challenging, but you feel like actually learning and knowing why you are losing until a great satisfaction comes from winning. Throughout the game you actually feel how you progress to becoming great shinobi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090736766', 'num_games_owned': 10418, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4260, 'last_played': 1715709423}
review:
I rage-uninstalled this game twice. But after i've finished Elden Ring and get used to souls-likes, i've started playing Sekiro again and proudly i can say i've finished the game.

This game requires a lot of patience. To all players who gave up the game like me, i highly recommend to give another chance and be patient. Because you will experience the most refined sword combat in a video game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198401588700', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 3553, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3553, 'last_played': 1719935763}
review:
Sekiro is well known for its high difficulty and having some of the most fun combat. After playing it, I have to agree with both. There is a brutal learning curve to overcome, and some bosses will test your patience to the limit. However, I wouldn't say it is far above the Dark Souls games in terms of difficulty, and if you go into this game with a good mindset, there is nothing impossibly difficult that will be able to stop you.

The combat system is the heart of the game, and it's probably my favorite one of any game, at least when it comes to one-on-one combat. Clashing your blade with another warrior just feels exhilarating. Every parry, counter, or dodge you time correctly feels great and makes for a very good flow of combat. There are no breaks during a fight, just constant action until you can finally run your blade into the enemy to end him, or fail to do so and perish yourself.

There are very few ways to customize your character, and there are not many different ways to approach fights. So you mostly have to play how the developer wants you to play, which means mastering the game mechanics and learning the enemys attack patterns.

To me, there is no big negative point to this game. There might be some specific enemies, attacks, or status effects that I found annoying, but really not something big worth mentioning. I just wish it was longer, with more areas to explore. There isn't much secret content to explore, and the main content isn't super long either. But I can not really say it's something negative that I would love to have more of Sekiro. But man why was there never a DLC for this amazing game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093608547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1246, 'last_played': 1731092928}
review: This game is beautiful, but I believe it is way over-hyped and the promises of difficulty are over-emphasized. Don't get me wrong, it is a very difficult game, but the only boss I struggled with for more than a day was the final boss (CURSE YOU GLOCK SAINT). My biggest complaint with the game is lack of one-on-one samurai duels. When I first saw Sekiro I assumed most of the game would be this way, but there are far more big beasts and ganks than I could have imagined. Bosses like Genichiro, Owl, and the glock saint are the peaks of the game's combat, but there simply isn't enough of these fights for me to do another playthrough. I highly recommend it to someone experienced in FromSoft's crushing difficulty. Although I enjoyed the ride, I feel like I merely checked this game off my list as a FromSoft fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065620208', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 15031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15031, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1732298453}
review: The game starts out slow but then something just clicks and you can feel the rhythm of the combat and it emboldens you. You stop reacting and start dictating the pace of the fight. It feels amazing to struggle and struggle against a boss, but then suddenly realize that you know everything they're going to do, you feel it. In Dark Souls I'd always get a boss to 30% and then after a few more attempts down to 20% and then a few more I could get him to 10% and then finally win after a few more. In Sekiro I'd hardly get a hit in on a boss for a dozen attempts and then suddenly finish him without hardly being touched.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116714007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4502, 'last_played': 1722366796}
review:
It's a fromsoft game but the combat isn't just waiting for your turn to attack. Once you're confident enough to smack the bosses in their face nonstop and parry them correctly it feels great.

The first playthrough is likely to be painful as you learn how the combat works. But I had a lot of fun doing some NG+ runs where I just blasted my way through all the bosses that destroyed me earlier.

author: {'steamid': '76561198355278539', 'num_games_owned': 139, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 529, 'playtime_at_review': 1220, 'last_played': 1736453599}
review: Infinitely better than Elden Ring. Combats tighter and more rewarding. There wasn't a single boss that didn't feel fair, some more difficult than others, but entirely doable with patience.

author: {'steamid': '76561199260846464', 'num_games_owned': 33, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 446, 'playtime_at_review': 3807, 'last_played': 1736196437}
review:
I've just completed my first run of the game. As a big Souls fan, when I heard people say Sekiro is better than Dark Souls 3, I was in disbelief. Well, now I believe they're right. 

One of the biggest examples I can give is Sekiro's exploration of areas made me realise how much of a slog DS 3's travel between bosses is. 

But you probably want to hear more about this game. The combat is very difficult, to a point where I felt quite at odds and had to take a break for a week or two. Plus, you can't summon anyone. It's just you vs. the boss. But then one day, the combat just clicks and you start to see the patterns and telegraphs for the bosses' moves. It's incredible because the improvement of the player ties into the improvement of our character Sekiro himself! 

I highly recommend this game because of its combination of stunning areas, addicting deflection mechanic, story and overall consistency in quality.

author: {'steamid': '76561198218443927', 'num_games_owned': 120, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 5907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4117, 'last_played': 1732752845}
review:
I have only played 3 of Fromsoftware's titles and while I don't think it's as good as Elden Ring, I do believe it's just as enjoyable as when I played Darksouls III. 

The posture + vitality system is the absolute best choice for a game like this. It's incredibly simple, yet has so much room for depth. Not a single boss felt like it was out of place. Even some bosses which do not wield weapons at certain times still felt like they were a part of the game. Were they all well designed? I don't really think so. The main story bosses that you face are obviously the ones that got the most attention in the game. You can tell because they are the bosses that make you feel as though you are learning them rather than slogging through another fight. The first boss I would make that label for is [spoiler] Genichiro [/spoiler]. He is the first brick wall I faced, but through the several hours of fighting him I could tell that I was slowly improving. The fact that a boss like that is in the game with any confetti boss is mind blowing to me. In the game there is an item you can receive called confetti, and in order to beat some of these bosses you need to use confetti on your sword to deal any damage. First of all, I don't understand how Miyazaki ever let that idea get through. The confetti is a rare drop, so I don't understand why so many bosses require it. Not only are these bosses locked behind a rare item drop, but they also suck from a combat design standpoint. So many of the hitboxes are bigger than they actually are, and for one particular boss named Headless that has a slow sword, the visuals on them are so off that I literally can't tell where the sword is half of the time. Sometimes it's underground, sometimes the sword is so shaky that I can't understand it's trajectory, or sometimes I can't tell whether the sword is about to hit me or not. Ontop of that, the boss also limits your movement which just felt annoying. I can't believe there are five versions of this guy. Thankfully those bosses are completely optional, but beating them does grant you some nice rewards.

I also want to talk about the movement of the game, because I think it is has some of the worst design choices I have seen among the three games from Miyazaki. First of all, Why would you ever add a seemingly 1 second delay to a run + jump? Half of the time when you intend to run and jump off of a ledge, the jump just cancels because you end up running off instead. It's not even like i'm jumping late either. At certain points the game will help you not run off of the ledge by keeping you on the floor, but those walls still seem to fail because the time between input and jump is so large. And to top it all off, the jump feature is a requirement for almost all bosses in order to not get hit by some of their moves. God forbid you recognize early that you have to jump to evade, only for your character to still be running into the guy you are trying to kick away from. And even when you do successfully run and jump into an enemy, often times you will end up passing them instead of kicking them. I think the grapple hook is a well placed feature in-game, but I think it needs some adjusting in terms of the camera work. Way too many times I look in an unintended direction while grappling. I really like the movement options in the game, but they need more fine tuning because they feel like they are getting in the way more than helping.

Onto combat, I felt like this is where the game really shines its brightest. The combat is absolutely phenomenal. Incredibly precise and satisfying for every battle. The sound design and animation for every battle is absolutely gorgeous. They both mix very well with the combat, giving you several unique options for how to counter each boss. The game progression is great, and even with some frustrations at the beginning of NG+, it still felt like the game was waiting patiently for me to improve. One small gripe I would give is that prosthetics eventually become useless once you hit lategame. If you don't have all prosthetics unlocked, then you are locked out of most upgrades that could potentially be of use for lategame enemies. I would relax on the upgrade barriers a bit so that you can still get max upgrades on some of them without needing all prosthetics. Combat arts also kind of suffer from a similar issue, but I think thats more of me not taking the time to learn them properly.

As always, the stories from Fromsoftware are great. I was really liking all of the characters that we saw, and one great thing was that I could actually understand the story, unlike the other souls games xD. Each area within the game is great, and makes the game very unique and interesting to follow, especially Ashina Castle. The final boss in the main route is incredible, definitely one of the best I have played. It's a culmination of everything you have learned up until then, and it's displayed masterfully. I wish that games would stop doing this thing where certain bosses are locked behind certain routes. I wish I could just play through all bosses without worrying about which route I'm taking. It would be good to add an option to create an additional save file so you could play both routes and their bosses. There are very few games where I feel like I want to replay the entire game over again once I already beat it.

This is a good game with some very strange flaws that don't make sense to me. Another great achievement by Fromsoftware and Miyazaki. Most of the issues I noticed were fixed in Elden Ring, so I'm glad to see that they saw them and fixed them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067516749', 'num_games_owned': 434, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 2796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1783, 'last_played': 1721100223}
review:
Sekiro is a great addition to FromSoftware's collection of legendary games.

Below I've put some thoughts on what makes this game great (and some comments about why it may not be a "perfect" game), but TLDR is that this game is a great choice for anyone who likes other FromSoftware games, and may be a good choice even for those who don't because of its differences from the traditional "formula": 

[h2] Pros: [/h2]

- The story. In comparison to some of FromSoftware's other games, I found Sekiro's story to be simple but much easier to follow than the other titles. The story progression feels natural, you get plenty of background on character motivations, and the game does a good job offering different endings to the game which have their own ways of wrapping up the story. This game doesn't have as many "NPC quests" as some of the other Dark Souls games, but I also appreciate how these are easier to follow than other Souls games.

- Combat. While parrying/deflecting is not a unique mechanic to Sekiro, this game puts it front and center and ensures that by the end of the game you'll feel like a true expert swordsman. On top of this, the game offers other weaponry besides your sword which can be a nice addition (but certainly not a replacement) to your blade. The game also offers a skill tree which rewards you in a similar way the souls games would for killing enemies, but instead of Sekiro having a level, you simply put your XP towards skills. 

- Swordsman fights / duels. The game is truly at its best when you're facing down a boss or miniboss in a 1v1 situation. Bosses wield a variety of weapons (and come in a variety of sizes) in this game, but some of the most adrenaline-pumping moments will come from fights against another swordsman where your reaction speed and thoughtful but quick decision making will be put to the test. Sekiro also ensures that bosses as you progress become more and more difficult, but in a way that you feel at least mildly prepared for (usually by placing enemies with similar techniques or gimmicks along the way to a boss). This is something FromSoftware generally excels at and it shows here. 

- Environment. Sekiro does not have as many environments as Elden Ring for example, but the game does a very nice job of "recycling" areas as the story progresses, and allowing you to return to areas to explore previously unavailable content (usually collectibles or secrets). The game also rewards you for exploring with Sekiro's movement abilities and taking the time to see what the map has to offer will save you lots of trouble with some of the stronger bosses later on.

- Average playthrough time. I appreciate Sekiro being a bit shorter because in today's world of gaming we're seeing a lot of AAA companies add "bloat" to games which simply waste the player's time. This game feels like every hour you spend in it is meaningful in some way and is bringing you closer to beating the game. It took me around 30 hours to finish my first playthrough and for some it may be as quick as 20 hours. This is a really nice amount of time for me, and for those who want more you can always do NG+ for the other endings and other secrets!

[h2] Cons: [/h2]

- Large / monster-sized boss fights. This is a sticking point for me in just about every FromSoftware title. I find that in general fights against larger enemies tend to be less about skill and more of a waiting game (or a gimmick fight). Sekiro does a better job than the traditional Dark Souls titles for the most part, but I still found myself less interested in these fights but not as frustrated as some oversized bosses are in Dark Souls. Some may not consider this a con since they encourage a different playstyle (less parrying, more dodging and poking generally).

- Lack of build variety. This is just a fact of the game and it's the trade-off that you make when playing a game where you are a particular person versus an "avatar" (player-driven character). In Sekiro you can only play as Sekiro, therefore you must use Sekiro's weaponry and skillset. There is variation in your other shinobi tools and the skill tree, but if you don't find his sword or prosthetic weaponry enjoyable then the game isn't really for you.

- Some things could be clearer. There are times where you can progress out to a certain area and be "locked" from progressing further until you do other significant story events. These aren't as obscure as other Souls titles but can still require a google search or a little more running around than you may want to do. 

- Small enemies protecting or blocking a mini-boss. There are at least 3-4 instances that I came across where a miniboss was surrounded by small enemies. Your options here are as follows: Charge in and try to fight all of them at once (this will almost always fail because of sheer numbers), sneak around and stealth kill each small enemy one by one (this will get the rest of them engaged usually which requires a dance of de-aggro, wait, stealth kill, rinse & repeat), or openly attack the small enemies as a group and ignore the boss until they're dead (works ok but you'll likely spend healing which you may need for the miniboss). This is a small gripe and not a huge deal, but worth noting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198164885048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8103, 'last_played': 1727662471}
review:
DO NOT GIVE UP

Learning the mechanics of the game is the only hurdle to being able to coom when fighting every boss. It's not a typical souls game where rolling/dodging is the main way to evade. Practice deflecting and the game turns into an experience better than sex. Once you get the hang of it you feel like a fucking god and im not normally that good at souls games but I learned this one and now I can do Mortal Journey whenever I feel like it. Strokes the ego from getting fucked on Shadow of The Erdtree.

Obviously biased opinion but best souls game out there. 100/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198329664504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1209, 'last_played': 1726974347}
review:
Sekiro's combat mechanics set it apart as the best FromSoftware game. The game emphasizes precision and timing with its unique posture system. Parrying and deflecting enemy attacks deplete their posture, leading to a satisfying deathblow. The use of the grappling hook adds verticality to fights, allowing for dynamic and strategic encounters.

The skill tree customization offers various combat arts and techniques, enhancing your fighting style. Stealth mechanics provide a tactical edge, letting you thin out enemies before engaging in intense one-on-one duels.

Each boss fight is a test of skill and patience, rewarding players for mastering the combat system. The difficulty is high, but the satisfaction of overcoming each challenge is unparalleled.

Sekiro’s combat mechanics make every fight a thrilling experience, solidifying it as the pinnacle of FromSoftware’s games.

review: One of the best-feeling games I have ever played! Seriously, it will be hard to go from this to almost anything else once I finish it. Plus just navigating the world with the fast run speed and grapple is a blast!

author: {'steamid': '76561198316333741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1720327371}
review: This game changed my view of what a video game could be.  While most games to me just feel like an amusement park ride this one is different somehow, it doesn't hold your hand and you can't level up by grinding you just have to get better at playing it and when you do finally get over the initial learning hump it feel extremely satisfying.  Every encounter matters and even minor mistakes will be quickly punished but somehow its never frustrating because its always fun to come back and try again.  The story is also on-point and doesn't rely on long boring cut scenes at all, the setting is a unique blend of realism and fantasy that I really enjoy as well.  This is probably one of, if not the best games I have ever played and while its not easy to get into I highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965485692', 'num_games_owned': 402, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2816, 'last_played': 1711726926}
review: Huge fan of Fromsofts Soulsbourne series and Sekiro might just be my favourite. It has a steep learning curve, even for veterans of other Soulsbourne games, but once you get into the rhythm, it is an incredibly enjoyable game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198997362871', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 424, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1721708433}
review:
Absolutely an intense ride from start to finish. The world is undoubtedly stunning—a mix of ancient Japan and fantasy—and exploring it feels like stepping into a masterpiece. The combat? Brutal but so rewarding. It’s all about timing and precision, and every boss fight feels like an epic duel.

I won’t lie—the difficulty is no joke, and I had plenty of moments where I wanted to throw my controller. But the sense of achievement when you finally conquer a tough enemy is unbeatable. The story is straightforward, which kept me hooked without overthinking the lore, and the grappling hook adds a fun twist to exploration.

If you’re up for a real challenge and love games that make you earn every victory, Sekiro is absolutely worth it. Just be ready to die a lot—and enjoy every minute of it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994708210', 'num_games_owned': 816, 'num_reviews': 328, 'playtime_forever': 4059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4059, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1651794672}
review:
FROM Software actually manages to tell a straight up story without relying on two-bit YouTubers' imaginations filling in your plotholes when some NPC says a single line like "Ahhh, Tregustus, here thou cavort with mine berriandere." 

Also, the woeful Bloodborne parry/dash gameplay was taken back to the drawing board and turned into something that actually works. 

Replayability takes a big hit, however. Still, hope they do more of this and less of Dark Souls 3.

author: {'steamid': '76561199216331943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 5246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 218, 'playtime_at_review': 3797, 'last_played': 1735771943}
review:
"Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice - GOTY Edition" is a masterclass in action-adventure gaming, delivering a unique and challenging experience that captivates players from start to finish. Developed by FromSoftware, this game stands as a shining example of meticulous world-building, precise combat mechanics, and an intricately woven narrative.

From the moment you step into the beautifully rendered world of feudal Japan, it becomes evident that every aspect of "Sekiro" has been meticulously crafted. The attention to detail in environmental design, character animations, and sound design is unparalleled. The atmospheric soundtrack further immerses players into the rich lore and heightened tension of the game's setting.

The combat system is where "Sekiro" truly shines. It demands patience, precision, and skill, challenging players to master the art of timing, parrying, and strategic positioning. Each encounter feels like a deadly dance, as you face a variety of formidable foes, each with their own unique combat style and weaknesses. The exhilaration of overcoming a particularly challenging boss or enemy is unparalleled, making victory all the more rewarding.

Moreover, the world of "Sekiro" is teeming with secrets, diverse landscapes, and hidden paths that beg to be explored. The interconnected level design encourages thorough exploration and rewards the curious player with valuable resources, lore, and shortcuts. The level of freedom and creativity in approaching encounters and navigating the environment adds a layer of depth and replayability to the game.

The storytelling in "Sekiro" is also a standout feature. The narrative unfolds through cryptic dialogue, environmental storytelling, and stunning cutscenes, painting a captivating and mysterious tale of loyalty, revenge, and sacrifice. The protagonist's journey is rife with moral choices and philosophical dilemmas, creating a thought-provoking and emotionally resonant experience.

The "GOTY Edition" of "Sekiro" further enhances the experience with additional content and updates, ensuring that players have access to the most refined and complete version of the game.

In conclusion, "Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice - GOTY Edition" is a tour de force of game design, seamlessly blending challenging gameplay, rich storytelling, and unparalleled craftsmanship. It stands as a must-play for enthusiasts of action-adventure games and a testament to FromSoftware's commitment to excellence.

author: {'steamid': '76561198260924442', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 494, 'last_played': 1735045057}
review: Best combat in any game I have ever played and probably will ever play

author: {'steamid': '76561197986697530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1834, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1672826707}
review:
As my first soulslike, I overall came away enjoying my time with Sekiro despite some disappointments. My expectation was that it would be insurmountable, and incredibly precise based on what I heard online but I'd say don't worry about it if you think the difficulty is unapproachable because it really is easy to abuse the mechanics to make it easy. I was a bit let down at this game's whole focus on the parry system because I feel like it wasn't fully thought out on how it affects the way a player approaches the meta or fine tuned. Once I came to the realization that health doesn't matter and that it is all about the posture gauge, it completely changed my approach to every fight in a way I felt was inelegant and cheesy. Boss fights went from being highly movement focused to instead being about planting my feet and timing my parries. Just not what I was hoping for in general when playing a game with such an agile Ninja character with a grappling hook. 

That said, it is a good introduction to FromSoft games at least to me purely because of the lack of RPG mechanics and not having to worry about making an awful build based on the game not communicating properly to the player like I've heard friends moan about with the Dark Souls games. The big setpiece boss moments were very memorable and it's a lot of fun to just explore these more focused, smaller environments, especially with how dense these areas are with secrets.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994936988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2771, 'last_played': 1720884123}
review:
I had to walk away from this game a couple times since I purchased it, due to my frustration. 
I have always preferred using a keyboard & mouse but decided to give a controller a chance. It made all the difference in the world for me. Timing & positioning in this game is key in battles & once you get in your groove, it becomes a very enjoyable experience. The world is beautiful & dynamic & the bosses are amazing & challenging & instill a real fear as each one seems unique in its approach with different strengths & very few vulnerabilities & weaknesses. What works against one, likely wont against the next one.
Completing this game definitely feels like a real accomplishment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006262713', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 28, 'playtime_at_review': 1724, 'last_played': 1735685680}
review: One of the best games ever made and probably the best possible melee combat in any game. Shame it never received a DLC but even at it's current state it will forever be in my top 5 games of all time.

review: my hot take, this is the best game so far in the fromsoft catalog. it's the best told story, with an absolutely gorgeous world and combat mechanics so fluid and responsive that it really feels exhilarating when you successfully fall into the rhythm of combat

author: {'steamid': '76561199089121617', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3407, 'last_played': 1728517101}
review:
Peak combat system. 
Peak soundtrack. 
Peak visuals.
Overall peak game.
Hesitation is defeat :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197983120155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 2355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2355, 'last_played': 1712127794}
review:
Good game. Came back to this five years after initially getting stuck on a bugged Corrupted Monk. It's got a lot of Souls DNA in it obviously but it feels a lot like old Ninja Gaiden and Tenchu games in the shinobi tools. While I think Bloodborne is a more difficult game, this might be the most difficult after. 

I think DS3 and Elden Ring have some harder bosses but as a whole Sekiro really pushes you to master parries and use of tools to interrupt attacks. You cannot brute force your way through by grinding levels and being a quality build, so that will turn others off. Solid 9/10 game though.

review: One of the best games I've ever played. My first playthrough was really hard, won't gonna lie. It took a lot of time to really seize the mechanics and understand the enemies attacks. It's like a dance, a beautiful one, and once you get the pace, everything flows. Amazing story, incredibly stressful but rewarding boss fights, beautiful landscapes, a lot of different mechanics to try to build your own play style. 100% recommend it. From Software doing another masterpiece.

author: {'steamid': '76561198307843134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 1843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1720304107}
review: I came to this game from Baldur's Gate 3 cause I wanted to try another game from Larian Studios. I didn't expect much since it's an older game, but, I've been pleasantly surprised. It's very immersive! There's so many items to find everywhere, the music is great, and I'm enjoying the voice acting. There's so much attention to detail and the tutorial really helps to ease players into the game. I'm 69 years old and have never played turn based games like BG3 or DoS2  but I"m happy to say you're never to old to learn something new and discover the joy of a new genre in gaming. I highly recommend this game to everyone who loves rpgs whether you're experienced with them of not. This one will take you on an adventure you'll remember for a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076697654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 963, 'last_played': 1734672665}
review:
The average DOS2 experience 

- Make character
- Get to Fort Joy
- Make character (again)
- Get to Fort Joy (again)
- Make another character (You definitely know what you're going for this time)
- Wow, this Fort Joy place is so in depth i keep discovering new things

16 hours later

- Make an UNDEAD character
- Get to Fort Joy

10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136280241', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3365, 'last_played': 1731125345}
review:
OMG GET IT!!
I came from bg3, and heard that this game was not as beginner friendly. Turns out, after playing 200+ hours of turn-based combat, dos2 is super intuitive. If you like the combat in bg3, you'll love it in dos2. The only downside is there's no jumping!
I also heard that the companions weren't as fleshed out. I disagree! I LOVE the companions in this game -- there's just no cut scenes. The dialogue is so so so good though and the humor is amazing. I also think that bg3 was a huge improvement for Larian's graphics, but after playing dos2 for so many hours, I genuinely think the game looks great and has a lot of graphical similarities to bg3. 

TL;DR if you loved bg3, you will love dos2! GET IT!

author: {'steamid': '76561198037567910', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 89031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73685, 'last_played': 1727828413}
review:
The difference between BG3 and D:OS2 can be explained pretty easily if you've ever looked at all the stuff that 5e has done to make D&D more simple and accessible-- all of that makes for a worse video game. D:OS2 is dense in systems, but it takes the time to teach them to you and by the time you get going, you really feel like a god of some sort. Combat is never about chipping away health, every turn has important decisions that can be made that affect how the combat rolls out, with enough dynamism to allow both you and the enemy to bounce back into contention from the brink of death at almost any point in the fight. Also, the music is better.

The quest writing and characters of BG3 are certainly more mature and more polished, but OS2 feels like I am sitting down with a bunch of friends back when I was a kid to make up a story on the spot. BG3 is the best version of 5e D&D as it actually exists, but OS2 is the game you thought you were playing when you first learned what Dungeons and Dragons was. Both are good, but damn I love OS2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117109790', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 58557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58064, 'last_played': 1727633708}
review:
What an incredible turn based RPG. I've spent just less than one thousand hours on this masterpiece which means its my most played Singleplayer game in my adult life (admittedly some hours were playing multiplayer with friends but still). Now there's no way that I'm going to be able to list all the good things about this game in one review, but I'll try my best and highlight some really good aspects to hopefully encourage anyone reading this to give it a go. 

Pros -
Firstly, the music in this game is AMAZING. It either sounds completely badass for fights or incomparably elegant for exploring the world. There were so many times during my many playthroughs that I had to make the decision of either humming along to the music or letting my ears fully embrace those beautiful instruments. 

Visually this game is stunning, the details in the world and the particle effects of abilities/spells look so well done and make it feel so satisfying when you cast them. I also really appreciate that this games movement is very freeing for a turn based RPG. I've always disliked those games where movement is restricted to like a chess board with squares. Having your characters quite literally being able to move anywhere feels so much better. 

Next up, the story. [b]EVERYTHING[/b] has lore in this game. If you love reading and want to read pages and pages of lore, character backgrounds and potentially hundreds of books scattered across the game, then you can most definitely do so. But its not forced onto you. Most books that you find throughout the game aren't necessary to progress, and a lot of the time there will be an option to resolve problems by fighting if you prefer a little more action. Its completely up to you how you want to play. 

Lastly, I want to talk about the character creation. The character creation in Divinity is phenomenal. Obviously you can change the look of your character to how you want but more importantly, there are 10 Skill categories that you can allocate points to. You can mix and match them together and pair them with *mostly* any type of weapon in the game. The combinations you can make are endless. For example:

Want to be a persuasive fire-wizard that uses daggers instead of the usual staff/wands?
Want to be a non-confrontational thief that escapes his enemies by turning the floor to ice causing them to slip?
Want to be an archer that fires love arrows to temporarily make his enemies fight for him?
Want to be a cleric wielding a giant axe who can explode corpses?

Well you can have all 4 in the same party! I could talk about this game for hours but at the time of writing this these are the aspects of the game that came to mind. Now I'll talk a little bit about some very minor cons that don't put the game in any bad light but I feel are good to know anyways.

Very Minor Cons - 

Gift Bags: [b]If you don't care about achievements then move onto the next con[/b] -- Gift bags are the developers way of giving their own made mods for divinity. They are free little game mechanics that you can choose whether to enable in your game or not. (I highly recommend that you [b]do not enable any of these for your first playthrough[/b] as some make the game considerably harder/easier). Some of these settings are incredibly useful but the issue is since these are acted like mods, achievements are disabled if you enable them, so you will need to replay the game without them in order to gain any. I wish the devs would have actually implemented some of these into the base game rather than adding them as mod-like settings after.

Inventory: Inventory management in this game could be a liiiiiiittle better. There's nothing necessarily wrong with the inventory system, but there are definitely a few QOL changes that they could have added. One example being the ability to name bags. Throughout the game you will pick up individual bags that you can place in your inventory and put any item inside. They are incredibly useful in tidying up your inventory and reducing clutter, but these bags cannot be named. So you will end up having to repeatedly look inside each bag to find out which bags have which items. Additionally, when crafting stuff, if an ingredient is inside one of these bags, the crafted item may appear in the bag of the ingredient instead of just appearing at the bottom of your inventory for you to sort out. Again, not exactly a game-breaking problem but definitely slightly frustrating when you have lots of items in a bag and now need to find a random crafted item amongst them all.

Other than whats listed above I just wish the game never ended honestly. I want more cool spells, more races, more talents, more fights, MORE OF EVERYTHING. Truly a really incredible game, please give it a go because the developers deserve it. 

Thanks for reading <3.

author: {'steamid': '76561198797521423', 'num_games_owned': 75, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 7224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7222, 'last_played': 1728405443}
review:
[h1]I'd say it was the best RPG experience I've ever had. 10/10[/h1]

[h3]To remember it for the future, I'll just list some memorable things from our journey[/h3]
- Friend didn't recommend undead... so I thought it'd be funny to be one and chose "undead".
- The only thing stopping me from unlocking every door in the game were puzzles.
- Eventually, I became a debuff overlord crippling any enemy I see.
- The first person we stole from was a crippled old lady struggling with several diseases. 
- Black pits.... Well, everything else was a breeze is all I can say about the matter.
- FIRE! FIRE! AHHHHH IT'S EVERYWHERE!!!! 
- One friend got pet pal, cause they like animals... but all the animals hated them :(
- That same friend was an elf. Things happened and they became to be hated by their entire race too.
- [i]Bard Friend pulls out lute[/i] "LISTEN, DO YOUR HEAR ME? LISTEN, DO YOU FEEL IT? LISTEN-"
- My red lizard companion who I also got to play as eventually became a one shot, one kill boss killer. 
- Made out with that same red lizard as an undead (somehow), but was later cuckolded... by his wife.

[h3] - Loading times were long, but I cannot forget the laughs we had while waiting. [/h3]

It was a several month journey with my friends.
I cannot thank them enough for enriching my experience of the game.
I highly recommend this game to everyone who wants to go on a journey with friends!

[h2]Thanks for inviting me to play! It was a blast![h2]

author: {'steamid': '76561198985218457', 'num_games_owned': 28, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5853, 'last_played': 1732297925}
review:
I am brand new to the Divinity series and I would like to come at this review from a 2024 perspective on behalf of other gamers new to the franchise. I got into DOS2 after playing BG3 because BG3 was probably the best RPG I ever played in my life. I wanted to see if DOS2 had that same magic. In short, yes it does. But I wanted list some pros and cons comparing to BG3 (obviously knowing BG3 came out 7 years after DOS2) for those in my shoes.

Pros

- I liked the story here better than BG3
- VA is just as good as BG3
- Combat system is better than BG3 simply by virtue that it is a home grown system and does not have the same restrictions given that BG3 is based off of D&D 4E. The AP, memory slot, and skill cooldown based on turns in DOS2 is MUCH better than the BG3 combat system built around Action, Bonus Action, spell slot, and especially the "once per long rest" restrictions that I loathed in BG3
- Combat relies more on crowd control than bursting down enemies for big damage. Feels more strategic
- The loot is more fun in DOS2 than in BG3 especially if you are a stat junkie. Seeing "big number go bigger" on your gear is fun. 
- The unique loot that has cool set bonuses and special effects are far more streamlined, and unlike BG3 you are far less likely to accidentally miss some crucial loot needed for endgame builds by doing something silly like Long Resting too much or accidentally talking to the wrong person with the wrong party member
- Respeccing your party is far easier, you can just add/remove points in specific skills rather than starting from scratch every time like you had to in BG3 

Cons

- While the story is better, the lore and characters are better in BG3. Not really a con but I thought I would mention it here. 
- Mild Spoiler: you have a total of 6 companions (in addition to an optional custom origin character) that you meet in Act 1, and you can switch them out whenever you please. However when you move to Act 2 whichever companions in you party ARE YOUR PERMANENT COMPANIONS and you will never be able to change them out again...and the game LITERALLY NEVER EXPLAINS THIS TO YOU. Such an odd and dumb choice by Larian here, I am glad BG3 changed this. 
- If you thought the auto pathing in BG3 was bad, DOS2 is far worse. Clearly Larian did some major improvements there
- Line of sight in this game is ridiculously janky. Characters apparently cannot tilt their heads up to look over waist high obstacles or down to look below knee high guard rails. This will kill a few fight for you almost guaranteed
- Casting AOE spells in CC is a pain because the cursor usually wants to auto lock on a target 
- Build crafting is far less reliant on loot than in BG3, but also has a lower ceiling since you are not using gear with broken extra abilities to combo with builds. If they ever make DOS3 I would love to see more of the unique loot that they had in BG3 while keeping the frequency, diversity, and power of generic loot in DOS2. 
- While certain quest and loot lockouts due to irregular game pathing are far less common in DOS2 than in BG3, it still happens. Be cautious.   

Overall, if you liked BG3 I can't recommend DOS2 enough. It truly scratches that same itch.

EDIT: after playing for tens more hours, I have some more cons

- no jumping means that for every single time the game want you to take a path with even the slightest  break in the ground, you have to jump through hoops pulling our your transpiration gloves or other spells to get your party to just FREAKING TRAVERSE THE GAME it's such a bone headed design oversight 

-without mods, the pack weight limit and inventory management is unreasonable. Get the mod that removes carry weight limits, it's the single best QOL thing you can do. The fact that the vanilla game, even in BG3, has this inventory limit nonsense is barbaric

author: {'steamid': '76561198201952338', 'num_games_owned': 53, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5864, 'last_played': 1734386062}
review: If you are here after playing Baldurs Gate 3, you are on the right track. Divinity offers more creativity than BG3 in fighting, in my opinion. I had more troubled time playing DOS2 than BG3. Nonetheless, it was a joyful ride, and I'm grateful to Larian Studios for producing masterpieces.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052770789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 13020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13014, 'last_played': 1733299950}
review: This may be an unpopular opinion, but BG3 was the best D&D video game ever to be made in the D&D world. However, I don't believe that BG3 was Larian's best game. In my opinion, DOS2 is the best game that Larian has ever produced, and the best game in this genre that exists. I believe Larians true potential with the D&D world was collared and restrained by Wizards of the Coast and the limitations of the lore and world and mechanics (which is fine, as thats what WOTC wanted). That being said- In my opinion, DOS2 (this game) is the crown jewel of the creativity and potential that Larian studios has crafted and I think it out ranks BG3 in many many ways. So if you liked BG3- Give this one a go, and dont be afraid to explore to your hearts content and loot everything in sight!

author: {'steamid': '76561199095346025', 'num_games_owned': 48, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 7183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6798, 'last_played': 1719956116}
review:
*destroys magic armour*
*cast dominate mind, mind maggot grenade, charm person, or madness*
- me every moderately difficult fight

I was told this was the best game to play after Baldur's Gate 3, and as I get to the end that was totally right. It fully feels like a stepping stone to get to BG3 and is also just fantastic to play. 

Pros:
- Honestly having so many levels feels very satisfying even compared to BG3 where you only got 12
-The fighting is just really fun. Took a second for me to get used to the small changes (like turn limits, source, and no resting needed for spells), but it was certainly well done and had so many possible moves/spells.
- Characters are great (Sebillle ily), and a fun plot that I enjoying playing out
- Voice acting is very good (Sebille VA ily)
- There's so many options for armour that all have different ways to boost you, so many different designs, ability combinations, sets to match etc. (not being able to level it up is a little unfortunate, but I think it makes sense for the game so I wouldn't say that's a con)
- Making your party specialize in different areas and have different abilities is so fun (which realtes heavily to the fighting, but in general it's just great)
- the support abilities are so much better here than BG3 - partially because I didn't need to worry about wasting a spell slot, and because some only took 1 slot which would be all i was left with, but also they were just legitimately better

Different than BG3 (not really pros or cons, just differences when comparing a relatively older game to a modern masterpiece):
- The characters (side characters and main ones) don't have nearly as much depth in this game even though what we get from them is great
- no cutscenes (again, these points aren't giving any negative points in my eyes, just stuff that could make it even better if it came out now)
- Levelling up doesn't come with as much customization and changes
- Aspects of the story (and side characters) are both a bit more convoluted and simple, as well as just harder to follow - still good
- There's no long resting, and short resting (using bedroll) is only for restoring health. Honestly besides missing the camp that aspect was actually more convenient
- Oh yeah there's no camp clothes, and costumization options due to no cutscenes, but there's also more armours and lacking informal clothes doesn't do anything
- there's no dice rolling which I missed even though it was kinda nice that I didn't have to worry about rolling a 1 lol
- Moving and actions are counted in the same 4 moves (the amount you can walk per move depends on character) which I can see being better or worse. I like both

Cons:
- The levelling system can be a little annoying and I ended up needing to look at level maps which I guess is elaborated on in my next point
- The game doesn't feel like it guides you enough or gives you quite enough freedom (to be clear this is a grievance, but isn't nearly as bad as that makes it sound, just something I encountered a couple times). There were times I would accidentally stumble into enemies who were too high levelled, but they were already aggravated (or I couldn't talk my way out) so I would have to load before I met them and just avoid them until I could reach the correct level. There was also one major time that I didn't know I had to trigger events in a specific order (or a couple times I thought something would trigger another event so I avoided it only for it to not matter - like going on that kids boat in act 1) and what I needed to do wasn't really said which led to me kinda fucking up a part of the main story... Also led to me not getting resolution on Peeper and reloading continuously to save him for half of Arx only to realize he had no relevance after the arc he got introduced in and I had just not casted Spirit vision where I was supposed to
- The persuasion (or I guess this applies to tags and just general interactions too) aspect can be annoying, maxing it for the main character is the move, but it can still be annoying just because occasionally your allies will be the ones to be spoken to, especially after battles if you aren't the closest one to the NPC. Then you have no persuasion and are lacking your tags which can lead to another issue. Also had to reload a couple times to bring my MC closest to the NPC before a fight ended or to intentionally trigger conversations that my allies accidentally did

Anyway I'm sure there's many more things I could add (and I probably should've waited until I actually finished, I'm sure the end is great) especially to the pros, but if you enjoyed BG3 and see this review, yes it's a fantastic game to play after BG3. It's got no major issues, and is just great, if you're craving another game like BG3 (or just craving any game to put some hours into) this is the one

author: {'steamid': '76561198025003557', 'num_games_owned': 2249, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11054, 'last_played': 1721436674}

author: {'steamid': '76561198086333243', 'num_games_owned': 403, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 26857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26857, 'last_played': 1677214117}
review:
The video game that was so good the devs were given the licensing rights to make a dungeons and dragons game.
Divinity Original Sin 2 is like playing a long, epic table top gaming campaign with a very talented, meticulous, and dedicated Game Master. DOSII features really excellent player expression with it's character customization, and you can make some very flexible builds without having to worry about ending up with weak, under powered party. (Necromancer/Fighter, hydromancy/pyromancy, ranger/geomancer are some examples, not to mention mods) Me personally, this system was so much fun, and I made so many cool character builds, that went Baldurs gate 3 came out, I was really missing Larian's classless system compared to the class based Fifth Edition DND rules.

Larian, give us Divinity Orginal Sin III! (please)

author: {'steamid': '76561198021449293', 'num_games_owned': 1431, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 7259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7259, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 5278, 'last_played': 1724299119}
review:
I was expecting a 40-60 hour adventure like the first Original Sin. 120 hours later, the credits roll and what a ride it's been. While a good deal more difficult and obtuse than Baldur's Gate 3, it's a steep improvement over Divinity Original Sin. The voice acting (narration included) was fantastic from start to finish, and the story, while largely your predictable high-fantasy fare, threw a couple of twists in that I didn't see coming. The characters are all very well written and interesting, especially once you start diving into their individual side quests. I loved the character development in each party member (especially The Red Prince's and Fane's), and while I typically don't revisit games once I've beaten them, I'm very much looking forward to taking another run through this excellent RPG down the road,

Edit: It's worth noting that I played through the majority of this game on my Steam Deck and it runs almost flawlessly out-of-the-box.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070682954', 'num_games_owned': 623, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 9317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9317, 'last_played': 1646496370}
review:
Important Spoiler-Free Info for new players  ;
1. Once you leave the starter island, there is no going back. Make sure you find and speak to ALL of the companions (The characters on the ship in the opening act) before leaving, as well as finish any quests.
2. After leaving the island, you will be on a ship again. When on the ship, it is important to choose your favorite companions to join you before leaving.
3. Very early on in the game, you want to find or buy a good shield with a Strength level of 5 or 6 and hold onto it. You will likely end up needing a low strength shield for a mage character later on, but will be unable to find one due to loot scaling based on your level.
