author: {'steamid': '76561198302333346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 20603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20603, 'last_played': 1729463884}
review:
Thanks to my friend for introducing me to Baldur's Gate 3 and Divinity. Now these are my favorite games that I completed to platinum. Music 10/10. The battles were a lot of fun, I especially enjoyed playing as the magicians.
It was perfect. Perfect. Everything. Down to the last minute details!

author: {'steamid': '76561198931188059', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 35031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1051, 'playtime_at_review': 30918, 'last_played': 1736279506}
review:
It's all a tiny part of this huge game. I could spend hours telling you about the huge amount of perk and spell combinations in this game. or the fact that depending on your race, skills, and decisions, many quests can be completed in any way you want. If you need to kill a man, but he is sitting in a tavern where there are a bunch of people, cook him a chowder, for which he will get diarrhea, and then just kill him in the back alley - This is a game that in the story you get the ability to see and talk to the dead, so you can dig up someone's grave - its owner Poe wishes you a good day. Or you can come to a sawmill and talk to the sign of an elf tree because it's been sawn and now it's dead. So it all makes sense. Divinity: Original Sin 2. Perfect Game. If you adore replayability and possibility, there's a simple test for a quality RPG. Ask yourself and your friends if you can Rp FOR the Big Gay Lizard in this game. If the answer is no, then don't waste your time on this game, because it's obvious that its creators have never played a real RPG. Can the game be called good? Yes. I would even say that the game is too good for the modern world. While other developers are just talking about freedom and possibilities, Larian Studios is just doing. And they're not going to stop. And as long as they are, Bouncer's dad will be satisfied. ;3
The little dog told me he loved me and gave me a task. And the dragon I freed from the witch and he said be my dragon queen. Larion Studios thank you 15/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012548415', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 47825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45524, 'last_played': 1734826622}
review:
This was my first Larian game and it raised the CRPG bar to a level that I don't think anyone except them has matched, never mind bettered.  The characters and story lines are engaging, the world, whilst still understandable fantasy isn't that generic, the voice acting is excellent and the freedom and creativity in combat is peerless.

Having played BG3 to death I have come back to this for a co-op run and whilst it's not quite at the level of BG3 as it's older and on a smaller budget, you don't really notice what it's missing because it fills the space very well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132108355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 20339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19748, 'last_played': 1728804924}
review: Solid RPG with almost too many choices for character building until you have played it enough and realize you want more. Great game, story, and level design. 10/10 wish I could experience it for the first time all over again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116999950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 10081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8542, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 8197, 'last_played': 1725147730}
review:
Divinity: Original Sin 2 is what I consider to be the single best game I have ever played. The combat, while initially challenging, turns into strategic fun. The dialogue and narration alone are good enough to justify the sale price. The world, the lore and the adventure you go on are not only incredibly exciting but highly re-playable too. 

I have subjected more than 5 of my friends to gift copies of this game. Play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199232893234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3958, 'last_played': 1732316781}
review: Been playing DOS for 3 years now, beaten the game 3 times on playstation. PC DOS is the way to go, much more streamlined and graphically appealing. If you are a fan of their most recent title Baldurs Gate 3, then you need to play this. It is hands down my favorite turn based combat system, and one of my all time favorite games period. Theres so much freedom with character building and how you can conquer each combat situation. Its more difficult in some ways than BG3 but much more rewarding. You don't have to camp after every combat encounter. Nuff said

author: {'steamid': '76561198003077343', 'num_games_owned': 950, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 7716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7716, 'last_played': 1729650251}
review:
Growing up I played a lot of games, shooters, platformers, adventure games, RPGs like Pokemon.  But somehow never played any old school classic ones like Fallout, KotOR, Baldurs Gate or any of like that.  So it seems all the more strange to say that I feel a weird sense of nostalgia from playing DOS2.  Maybe it's the lovingly crafted world, maybe its the variety of approaches to the gameplay, harkening back to a time when games were more immersive and less linear.  Or maybe it's something special about the way Larian makes their games.  Either way DOS2 has become one of my most enjoyable gaming experiences of my whole life and a game I would say may rank among the finest ever made.

Truth be told I bounced off of DOS2 maybe twice before I actually got it to finally click for me.  I tried it for maybe 10 hours 2 and a half years ago, got a bit into Fort Joy.  Gave up, quit for a year and decided Id try again.  Began a new save and got back into it pretty hard, fell in love with the first act, put 40 hours in exploring and loving the game.  Got to Act 2, felt overwhelmed and out of place and just desired to go back to Fort Joy and dropped the game again for an entire year.  Picked it back up on a whim and began right back where I left off.  Had a buddy help me respec my characters a bit and I was in love.  

Divinity Original Sin 2 is a classic RPG.  The main game play functions similarly to Dungeons and Dragons, where it is split up into segments where you explore with your characters, talk to NPCs, gain quests, and do whatever RPG stuff you want, steal, buy things, explore the games world and then obviously get into combat, the other chunk of the game.  DOS2 is played like a tactical turn based RPG somewhat similar to XCOM but not entirely.  The game has no rigid class system like Baldurs Gate or Diablo.  Characters can freely spec their attributes however and if they meet the requisite skill for a move, they can use it.    While my initial reaction towards the way the games armor system works was negative, it grew up me very well and I now see it as a way Divinity puts itself apart from other games in its style.  

The story itself is charming if not unremarkable.  It is full of wonderful characters however, hilarious moments and excellent side quests, whereas the overarching plot follows more in line with a typical chosen one RPG affair.  It serves its purpose very well without being so present it becomes boring.  

This is not a game Id expect to fall in love with, and yet I did.  It is almost without flaw and IMO a must try for any gamer.  An underappreciated and beautiful game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198279140910', 'num_games_owned': 510, 'num_reviews': 427, 'playtime_forever': 6180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6180, 'last_played': 1735182155}
review:
I initially bought divinity sin 2 for full price when it launched, it's the 3rd game that I ever bought on steam. Since I got it as a new gamer I had no clue what I'm getting into. I ended up dropping it multiple times during act 1 without making much of a progress.

I only just beat it recently, in co-op with 2 other people. I had a blast.

We played in a team made up of a warrior, assassin, archer and fire mage.

Some parts worked rly well in co-op, all the arena fights, item and character managment felt smoother when you only had to worry about yourself. You technically could go your way and progress alone but if a fight started with tons of enemies you would need the help of your allies.

It did take us almost a month of playing almost every evening, it is a lot of commitment to ask for. 

Alone I imagine the experiance would be a bit faster and smoother, since you would have control over everything when playing alone.

The game is fairly dialogue heavy, so might not be everyone's cup of tea. The quest system at times confused us and we werent sure how to progress and if we even can progress. We did what we could, but still felt like we missed plenty of things, this game is pretty big in terms of content, a lot of achievements to get too. A game for potentially tons and tons of hours.

I do plan to eventually revisit it, in order to focus more on the plot and make other choices, i would also want to play around different classes. In co-op I played mainly as the ranger , and experimented with skills in act 1.

The game is kind enough that it lets you pretty much change your gameplay/skills/stats anytime starting from act 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089598943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6324, 'last_played': 1734986335}
review:
Like many others, I bought this game to get some more turn-based-RPG action after completing Baldur's Gate 3. 

Compared to the latter, the game features a lighter atmosphere and a slightly different system for spells and actions, opting for turn-based "Action Points" (AP) costs - which regenerate each turn - rather than slots you regenerate by resting; I personally found this system more enjoyable.
The second main difference in the combat system is that it's based on two types of armor, physical and magical, which are both independent from one another.

The plot, divided in 4 acts spanning about 100 hours in total, is interesting but, in my personal opinion, hard to follow at times due to some narrative choices by Larian (this is evident - IMO again - especially in some quests in Act 4).

Featuring cartoon-style graphics, the game is pretty light on the system, making it really portable.
The soundtrack is also pretty nice, with some forgettable tracks as well as tunes you'll be thinking about in your daily life.

What really set this game apart from many others is that, not unlike BG3, it always offers creative ways to avoid combat and/or to beat powerful enemies and challenges, one just has to find them.

Last but not least, it's possible to not only host and join multiplayer campaigns but also to create your own campaigns if that's your thing.

Overall, I'd say the game is still worth its price seven years after its original release and a total no-brainer during sales (there is also a bundle offering Divinity OS 1&2 for a very convenient price)

author: {'steamid': '76561198035674401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 7526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7526, 'last_played': 1705536278}
review:
Just fantastic. Great story, great gameplay, great dialogs, well polished, details were carefully designed and implemented.

Only con I might say is that sometimes felt like the story could advance faster. I was often anxious to see what would happen next but took some time to happen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198334627925', 'num_games_owned': 57, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 755, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1736099694}
review:
PRO TIP:
If you want to save and free up space, you can delete the classic version of the game if you only play Definitive Edition. Navigate into the game folder (Manage > Browse Local Files), and delete the folders 'Classic' and 'Data'. this will free up about 30 gigs. (obviously you won't be able to play the classic version until you validate/repair game files).

Similarly, if you wish to delete Definitive Edition, delete the DefEd folder instead.

Folder \Classic\ (44mb): contains bins for Classic DOS 2, not needed to play Definitive Ed.
Folder \Data\ (31.9GB): contains assets for Classic DOS 2, also not needed to play Def. Ed.

\Bin (where launcher is) and \DefEd are the unique folders you need to play the Definitive Edition, so if you delete the others, you will save almost 32GB and the game will be just 21.8GB (even less than the Classic Edition)

author: {'steamid': '76561198076607941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10869, 'last_played': 1699867348}
review:
I finished my first BG3 playthrough and came back to play this again. Still plays great - visually beautiful, the areas and characters are fun. (Still hate the Red Prince, sorry buddy.) Holds up well in comparison to current games in a similar vein. 

What I appreciate is the ability to arrange my painting collection and item hoard, and not have the items vanish from where they're placed. Thank you for letting me admire all the shiny assets that your people worked hard on creating. It's one of my favourite random past times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134745300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 14190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13715, 'last_played': 1715405647}
review:
Perfection.
What. A. Ride. 
I am a bad player. Not really used much to CRPG - really, one of the first i played. 
I failed. Over and over again, restarting game completely, rolling new characters several times. Trying different cmbinations of classes.
Then, i finished my character main story quest at hour 200,and final game about 20 hours laters.
Full playthrough took me around 80-100 hours. 
Game is 'hard'. requires you to know what you are doing at many occasions. tutorial doesnt really prepare you on what you are about to face. there were times i was frustrated, when i was nearly throwing mouse across the room.
Story wise? It was perfect. Perfect. down to the last minute detail. 
I am writing this review minutes after finishing the game. What the ending 'did to me' is hard to put into words. I am moved. In world of "AAAA" games (which i think it stands for long scream into the abyss), with same developers creating 'same games' over and over again, dulled, empty and repetetive, I was given something authentic. Something with "soul".
Buy this game. give it a try. Even if, just as me, you wll need to go on vacation from it for about a year. it's worth every peny. No, it's actually worth more. as a 30 years old dude I was given my childhood back.
Dear Larian Studios. Thank you. Thank you for this absolute perfection of world. thank you for allowing me to once again feel joy between long days of overhours at my job. You raised the bar so high, that I fear I might not enjoy anything else in a long. long time. 
I cannot remember, when was the last time, I valued a game so high.
Perfection.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050824915', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 12135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11914, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1735475242}

Playing this after Baldurs Gate 3 i went in with lower expectations but this game is nothing short of impeccable.
The Story, Companions, Dialouge, Combat, Exploration are all superb.

Another big plus for the game is its replay value much thanks to different dialogue options and different playstyles and builds to play around with and if that isn’t enough there are also tons of mods to enhance the game even further.

10/10
Worth every penny

review: Brilliant RPG, one of my must-buy game recommendation. Trailblazer of the Baldur's Gate 3 huge success, in some ways it's even better: the original setting oozes personality and it shows that this series is truly a labour of love.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165141404', 'num_games_owned': 63, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 14266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11313, 'last_played': 1722089476}
review:
Before i even start talking about the game, here's a little tip that could save some players a headache. If you experience frequent crashes and have the Razer Synapse installed, unlink the game in the software parameters. It completely fixed the issue for me.

So, after playing to and loving BG3, i've become curious of Larian's previous works. I've heard people saying that BG3 should have been called DOS3 and i can perfectly understand their point, because they have A LOT in common. In both games, you start as a prisoner on a ship that crashes and are saved by a mysterious voice. There are a lot of little examples like this where the two stories are quite close. Some BG3 companions are directly inspired, or a mix from two DOS2 companions (i see Astarion as a mix between Sebille and the Red Prince).

But the resemblance doesn't stop there. Both games have no real huge travels between maps, they include 3 or 4 big zones absolutely packed with content, the last one being a city. So yeah, they're pretty alike (excepted BG3 has of course a lot more bells and whistles, like cinematic scenes for more or less every NPC encounter, there are none here). That hasn't been a problem for me as i found both games to be excellent, but at times i felt like they haven't been  very subtle in the way  they copied stuff from DOS2 to make BG3.

This being said, DOS2 might be inferior from a technical perspective but there are some aspects of the game that are better. DOS2 is tougher. I played both in tactician difficulty and i found DOS to be much more of a challenge. I'm now at the beginning of the final act and there have been times where i wondered if i would be able to go on  (you can't lower difficulty after picking tactician), because some fights are really tough and requires that you make the best use of the topography and of your skills. Not saying that BG3 is an easy game, but winning in DOS felt more rewarding to me.

There are also a ton of items. It seriously felt like i was playing a looter shooter at times. This is due to the fact that  there is a skill that gives you a chance from getting a magical item from basically any container in the game. Even better, a part of the loot is random. It adds an element of surprise and i prefer that to fixed loot tables. You can really finetune your gear to make exactly the character you want.

If you're looking for something to play after BG3, DOS2 can definitely scratch that itch, if a more modest technical presentation isn't an issue for you. If you can get it for 12 or 13 bucks during a sale like i did, it's a complete steal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107338908', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 10605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 14, 'playtime_at_review': 7737, 'last_played': 1736299716}
review:
If you haven't played BG3, I would recommend that over DOS2, but this is the obvious choice after BG3. 
What I like about Larrian is that they make crpg aproachable, voice acting, controller support, so even a casual like me can enjoy, the story telling, the tactical depth, and the character building process that makes this kind of games worthy of the time investment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198967888189', 'num_games_owned': 298, 'num_reviews': 215, 'playtime_forever': 5231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5231, 'last_played': 1729531351}
review:
The world of Rivellon, a thousand years after the events of the first game.
After the death of the spiritual leader, there is a merciless hunt for all users of the magical energy known as Source, to which you belong. Your adventure thus begins in a prison fortress rather sarcastically named Fort Joy, only to then plunge you through a stormy ocean, a wild coast, a tropical island, the shadows of a big city and the depths of your own soul.

And who are you? That is exactly the question. As in most RPGs, you can create your own character, including race, profession, and various stats. Or you choose, in my opinion, the significantly wiser option, and become one of the pre-made heroes who complete their own, carefully constructed, personal tasks, waiting for special adventures in the world.
And what heroes they are! The elf Sebille, like other members of her race, can eat human flesh and thus access the poor victim's memories. It can reveal pieces of the story, or perhaps learn a skill. The Red Prince is the ruler of all the lizards, although he is currently suffering from the slight inconvenience of exile. And the various reptiles he encounters in the world will either love him or hate him. Lohse is possessed by a demon. Fane is an undead skeleton that can only move between humans when it puts on someone's face instead of a mask.

Every moment of frustration and slight disappointment was richly redeemed by a trip to a fascinating and vibrant world, capable of dealing with a solitary adventurer, a dynamic duo and a foursome unleashing unimaginable chaos. [b] 40% [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198067142301', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 6651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6550, 'last_played': 1729132251}
review:
One of the greatest RPGs I've ever played, and probably the only turn-based game I've ever enjoyed other than Wildermyth.
Fantastic writing, characters, art, levels, and more than anything, incredibly satisfying combat. My favorite combat of any game, and it's for a genre I usually hate. So much synergy, so much adaptability, what a triumph of game design.
The only game where I don't make a custom character and actually go for a pre-made one. Just exceptional all around.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073863613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 8918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8918, 'last_played': 1672308963}
review: I killed them all, and not just my friends, but the companions, and the npcs to, They're like animals, and i slaughtered them like animals

author: {'steamid': '76561198010487138', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 4132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4132, 'last_played': 1710630662}
review:
This game has a decent story and features I like that are missing in other titles such as Baldur's Gate 3 or the Owlcat Pathfinder games. Specifically, I like that when playing co-op the player characters can talk to each other as if they were NPCs. Additionally, there are game design choices that feel better like dialogue checks being set numbers rather than RNG.

However, the character building and combat are garbage. Say you want to play a fire mage; the optimal build is to put as few points as possible into pyromancy in order to learn the spells you need, and to dump many points into the archery skill (huntsman) because its passive provides a better damage bonus. Larian spent far too much time putting barrels of oil and fire, and miscellaneous puddles all over every map and not enough making good combat. It's full of quirks that are sure to irritate you if you are expecting a typical CRPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019047931', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2154, 'last_played': 1727036983}
review: I've owned this game for a while but never gave it a good chance, then BG 3 came out and I was curious about it but I felt like I'd be doing DOS2 a disservice to not sit down and play it first before dropping $60. Needless to say I have enjoyed it. I havent beaten it yet but ive enjoyed my party members and and combat.. The writing is interesting and overall it's a quality game that has me all the more hype to see what larian has done with BG3 when I finally get the chance to play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963323627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 21962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 6742, 'playtime_at_review': 12893, 'last_played': 1736819623}
review:
Almost every line of dialogue is read aloud by a voice actor. This is a level of production-quality I've never seen, given the huge amount of dialogue. Outside of that, the combat system is like X-Com, but with swords and magic, and without all the crap like constantly missing at point-blank range, or losing your best guys to random crits.
It's a game I never suspected I'd be hooked on.

The controller support is fantastic too. If you'd asked me whether a game like this could be played on an X-Box pad, I'd have said "No way in a million years", but somehow they pulled it off beautifully. I don't take my hat off to UI people very often, but credit where it's due, they have pulled off some kind of miracle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038365836', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 7252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2177, 'last_played': 1726846040}
review:
I can't stop playing :(

While I very much enjoyed BG3 and that was an unbelievable introduction to Larian and their quality, I have found myself enjoying DoS2 more simply from getting away from DnD dice rolls for everything that BG3 had.

You can find items and skill where you will hit something 100%, when you are an Apex predator later in the game you aren't at the mercy of dice rolls missing, or hitting for some tiny damage when the range is large.

Here, when you make a build you can see your damage numbers rise and know that is actually what you are going to hit for.

Also enjoy the much higher leveling system.

Yes, I know they are very different systems but I'm just stating some of the differences I personally enjoyed, especially since I played BG3 first.

100% recommend if you got into the hype of BG3 when it released and are now checking out some other Larian games.  Personally I am much more drawn to the leveling and non-dice roll set up in this world

author: {'steamid': '76561198353343022', 'num_games_owned': 75, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 11834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11834, 'last_played': 1720841794}
review:
Simply one of the best RPGS of all time that feels every bit as polished in 2024 as it did in 2016. The combination of Larian's creativity and attention to detail in every aspect of the game is practically without equal in the industry.

Phenomenal music, a great and replayable story with many meaningful choices, high quality and fully voice-acted and a deep combat system with interactions that create almost infinite possibilities of how fights will play out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973218973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 697, 'playtime_at_review': 1660, 'last_played': 1735995751}
review:
Very very fun. I have not played a turn-based RPG for years. Do not let the seemingly simple graphics put you off because the game play, voice acting and story lines are terrifically well interwoven. There are many times you will feel stuck, only to find a route forward - the feeling of success in overcoming obstacles is amazing. The ability to re-spec if you make mistakes in builds is really forgiving. I made mistakes, but lived with them for fun. 

I am only 40 hours in and I can't wait to:
i) Progress further into the game
ii) Run the game again with different builds/characters

Tips:
i) Read/listen to dialogue and use your gut.
ii) Build a team covering as many different skills as you can.
iii) Be yourself - I don't like stealing, and every tip list said to pickpocket, but I did not because that is not me.
iv) If stuck simply look over quest details, talk to NPCs and explore more - there will be multiple avenues open to you that you have not yet realised.
v) The game is bigger than you think.
vi) Save very frequently.

Anyway, this is one of my first reviews in 20 years or so of Steam, but this game warranted it. I have to cut it short because I need to get on with some work as I want to get back to DOS2 ASAP!

Thanks for reading :)

I think I'll even make another run-through with a different set of companions once I've forgotten enough of the plot

author: {'steamid': '76561198098381419', 'num_games_owned': 183, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 4424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3482, 'last_played': 1734157657}
review:
Do you like having constant arguments with your friends over some loot, battle strategies or because someone went exploring alone and didn't wait the rest of your party?
If you do, this game is certainly for you!

Besides the incredible tactical rpg, perfect for a single player experience, the cooperative option adds a unique player/character competition between you and your "friends" that can make you hate each other even more!

author: {'steamid': '76561198136426671', 'num_games_owned': 86, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 40573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33274, 'last_played': 1730911673}
review: The amount of time I've spent playing this game probably says enough about how much I love it. Just as awesome as Baldur's Gate 3, only the combat here is less luck-based, which I prefer a bit more. Larian simply is the best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198804730022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2578, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 2578, 'last_played': 1723042316}
review: I love how you can basically do anything and still progress the quests in a bajillion different ways, this type of freedom isn't common in other similar games. At first I was pissed with how one of my companions had to murder an NPC for their quest which another companion needed to talk to for their own quest, but even that has workarounds too! The devs were able to make the game in a way where choices do matter while simultaneously ensuring that you don't screw up your playthrough, which again is very rare to see in other similar games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054970099', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 29341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29153, 'last_played': 1723130173}
review:
In my humble opinion, this is the best RPG game of all time, the progression feels solid, there's a lot of mechanics to sink your teeth into, abilities are varied, fun to use, and synergise with each-other in enough ways to give the game a fair bit of replay value, I could go on, but I don't want to info dump here, buy the game, play the game, explore what it has to offer for yourself.
What I will add to this however, is that the only reason I rate this slightly higher than Baldur's Gate 3, is because this game is significantly less janky than BG3, although it's still got a bit of jank.

author: {'steamid': '76561199409934841', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 15424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14881, 'last_played': 1735328093}
review:
As someone who's never touched an CRPG before nor do I have exposure to much DnD media, this definitely opened my eyes to how fun it could be. This game is immensely fun solo or with friends and multiple ways to do quests in the game, making it a very fun experience even on a replay. 

Though what makes this game stands out, is the spectacular voice acting and combat mechanics which gets you thinking how to maximize your turn, and trying out different strategies that just somehow works. Though there are certain character builds that outclass others and are easier to play while dishing out insane dps (I'm looking at you, ranger). 

Overall, a 9/10 game with my only problem is that not all of the companions in this game are written as equally well as others. I won't elaborate much due to spoilers, but I wish the next instalment to this series balances the companion writing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055389903', 'num_games_owned': 1225, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 14745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14745, 'last_played': 1707471661}
review:
I don't know what it is about the Divinity Original Sin series, but the hours played indicated are always grossly overexaggerated, mostly because I always end up having the game minimized while I do other stuff. That said, I definitely spent 100+ hours on the game (just not 240+ - that's insane), and admittedly toward the end in Arx the game definitely got a bit long in the tooth. But overall this is a big step up from the first game, which I still somewhat enjoyed but many elements hampered said enjoyment. For one, the story and characters here are a giant step up from the 1st game - I actually genuinely care about some of my companions now, and the game's build-up as we go from Fort Joy to Reaper's Coast etc is well-done narrative-wise. Equipment upgrade is also quite addictive - I love getting a divine item that is more powerful than what I am using. But there is a downside to said system also which I'll mention later. And gaining levels in this game makes a substantial and palpable difference to your combat abilities, unlike many other games where level increase is just a bunch of meaningless stat gains but with little in terms of feeling the power boost. Some of the fights are also really epic, like the one in the Blackpits fighting to save Gwydian - that was amazing to see all the flames bursting across the field. And the insanity of the Paradise Down area is another highlight. 

That said, the game often also misses the mark, which is a shame because I mostly enjoyed what is here, but these problems are just too big to ignore:
- the game weirdly gives next to no experience to solutions that do not involve combat, which means that peaceniks like me, when we come upon a combat situation, invariably become so level- and experience-deprived that it is basically impossible to continue. In fact, experience points are way too rare in the game, meaning that I was forced to reload back to Fort Joy to basically restart and to fight characters I would normally not choose to kill. But alas, the game really doesn't give me much choice due to it rewarding combat experience points over everything else, which is a major, major flaw. It really takes away from the role-playing aspect in a huge way, since I cannot fully play the way I want to.
- even when I already chose to do way more combat just to gain a bit more experience, the game is just way too hard in some areas, like when I first got to Arx. I was only level 18 but enemies were level 20, and it means there were swaths of areas I couldn't go to. And when I decided to pursue the sewers/dwarf quest, I realized later that this locked me from away from crucial experience points I needed from several fights with Nemesis enemies. So, once again, I had to reload all the way back to when I first got to Arx. Sigh - this is just tedious. And before you said I don't need to do that, well, yes I did, because I barely made it to level 21 toward the end game, and that final battle is *not* easy whatsoever. So every experience point counted, which is just not good design IMO.
- Inventory is also a real pain. Yes, I know that you can move multiple items if you use a controller, but I was using a keyboard and mouse, and boy moving a whole bunch of forks and spoons to sell is incredibly tedious. And swapping suits of amors also - there needs to be secondary sets you can pre-equip, because otherwise I need to keep tediously swap between individual pieces. My character has a set that maxes Lucky Charm during exploration, but he needs a different suit for combat, so every time I have to swap out each piece back and forth. Just a complete waste of time.
- Arx gets too bogged down on things that I felt didn't seem to matter anymore, like the Devourer suit. That suit would have been better accomplished on the Nameless Isle than in Arx, where already too many things were going on, and it was hard to keep track of things. It started to feel like busy work rather than me feeling invested. True, Fort Joy was also incredibly overwhelming at first, and that was also a negative, but Reaper's Coast I felt struck a near-perfect balance - it was so fun. 
- And speaking of Arx, that final dungeon and those weird puzzles and resurrecting bots with next to no explanations....seriously?? It was incredibly frustrating and anti-climactic. Really brought the whole experience down I feel. 

It is still a much better game than the first game, which I only gave a 6/10 to (that's still a thumbs-up from me), but I cannot ignore its myriad of issues to give a super strong score, so I'm going with a 7/10. I enjoyed it a lot, but admittedly the frustrations also really mounted while I played, especially having to restart due to my characters lacking experience points and levels due to the game's preference in rewarding combat. I still haven't played it yet, but I really hope Baldur's Gate III improves upon all this, because underneath this is a really fun and addictive game that needs some overhaul to really shine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198308672810', 'num_games_owned': 216, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 10151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8017, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 8011, 'last_played': 1728151158}

After 133 hours I can say that this is the best RPG I've ever played in my life and the best thing is that I still haven't beated the game yet since I just started ACT4 at the beginning I thought It will take as long as internet says aka 60hours but I guess I was wrong but anyway it's a really hard RPG where you'll get your ass kicked even on classic difficulty setting originally I was going to play this game alone on switch but then I thought why not invite my boyfriend to play with and it was a great idea especially on a steam deck, I can just lay down and play as I would on switch and it's overall a great experience whenever you play with a friend or a partner and I'm looking forward to beat the game and play something else with him

author: {'steamid': '76561198155946727', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 7378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7378, 'last_played': 1722683537}
review:
No doubts, the game is an excellent example of RPG game. 
First of all, I'd like to mention the music. It's astonishing, beautiful and fits for every moment of game.
The game world, Rivellon, is well designed. It has different locations, biomes, landscapes and every of them is beautiful in its own way.
Turn-based battle system is relaxing and helps the player have fun.
Also the main feature of battles in the game, elements interaction with themselves and the environment, is interesting and provides many opportunities for dealing with situations.
The game gives many variations for character's combat builds. With the help of variative dialog system, the first walkthrough can be different for all players. As a result the game have a big chances for multiple completing.
With all these factors in mind, it's no news that DOS2 can make you fall in love with it. And that applies to me too. Divinity is definitely my favorite RPG and one of my favorite games.
Thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198020954621', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 10543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10543, 'last_played': 1716765008}
review:
This is a huge game, with replay-ability. 
An Astonishingly beautiful soundtrack.
Great Aesthetics.
Stellar writing and stories, well... most of the time.  

It's far from perfect though:
The combat felt worse than DOSDE1 due to the armor. In the first game you immediately started with an elemental combo, now everything is blocked by armor, so my mage character felt far less useful after summoning its minions. And combat definitely feels tedious even on classic difficulty, so I think I'd only recommend playing it in Story mode. Difficulty increase doesn't make the game harder, just slower. Actually I ended up lowering to story more halfway and I still felt that its a bit slow.

Too many micro management stuff in the game:
- Like going back and forth to a source fountain to refill, 
- Too many lootable containters that are empty and are a waste of your time.
- Inventory management is a nightmare, and while the auto-sort in the character's inventory is nice, containers should have the same, and most importantly a 'store all crafring ingredients' button would be a welcome feature. 90% of my game-time is just dragging items in and out of the inventory. And I barely used most of them. But OCD be damned I can't help myself I had to check every container, because "What if it has something important in it?"

Too many simultaneous quests, I hate it when games dump over 20 quests at me at the same time. Pacing developers, pacing!

Lots of bugs: 
- Ryker first addresses you as if you attacked him even if you didn't.
- The entire Seed of Power questchain: Can't talk to Daeyena at the first encounter. Then at the second encounter if you have spores on you while she detonates the magister they will explode and she will get hit thus turning hostile. etc, etc.
- And many more I am not gonna list. Luckily most of them are not game-breaking and minor inconveniences.

Some A.I. Issues:
	Characters will avoid damaging surfaces, but will step on every single trap on the floor, even if they themselves spotted them. Even worse, Sir lora who's not in your control, and moves periodically(even in turn based mode, he just goes off repeatedly, teleports back, runs away again), had commited self-delete for me many times by running on and off of traps repeatedly.

Story (Spoilers)
[spoiler]Some quests are quite nonsense. For example I played Sebille, and Saheila doesn't make any sense to me. If you refuse to take the Mother tree's place because you don't wanna be a slave again, she attacks you. Then she asks you to kill the mother tree because the mother tree enslaves people. And then she thanks you for freeing them and says she hopes to see you again, even though she's freakin blind. 
	I think my biggest issue is that this game REALLY requires you to either be omniscient or to go to the wiki if you wanna have the best outcome for quests. For example, I encountered the Shadow prince before I went to the mother tree, and I ate his heart, only to realize that it was a quest item. Stuff like this happened a lot.
[/spoiler]

All-in-all, my complaints are minor and this game is a prime example of how an RPG should be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198357100919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 10651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10651, 'last_played': 1706585287}
review: With a more enjoyable RPG rule-set that makes for a really fun game, DOS2: DE is one of my favourite games. AP allows for more tactical choices alongside no strict classes, instead using magic and skill schools anyone can use; makes for an enjoyable combat experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198813287393', 'num_games_owned': 3554, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 11036, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11036, 'last_played': 1706443035}
review:
84/100 Short version: the combat is mostly fun, but it has done very little to address the issues with the original.

Long version:
-the first thing you should do is map Q and E to rotate camera left and right (the default is Del and End)
-expect *a lot* of pixel hunting, even when the game tells you you've spotted something.  The "highlight loot" key (alt) does not highlight containers such as chests, crates, baskets, tree stumps, trophies, etc.  Preparing to cast any AOE spell eg Bless highlights a bit more, but still not everything. 
-the engine is buggy.  Expect long battles where the enemy takes control of your characters (eg via Madness) to crash.  You'll sometimes find you can't attack a very close enemy with your Bone Widows.  The sound stops working quite a bit.  Items disappear (particularly if you equip loot directly from a body/chest rather than from inventory).  
-although the combat is mostly fun and the best part of the game, there are many battles which obviously weren't playtested for fun, ie those where enemies keep coming back to life or respawning, or take control of your characters via Madness or turning them into a cow etc.  In particular in the last Act, with the Lizard Embassy, Arx Arena Dream Portal, and Source Puppets in the lever puzzle room repeatedly taking away player agency.  
-inventory management is a nightmare, a good start would be the add search like in Pillars of Eternity. There is no multiple select/transfer option between PCs or NPCs.  There is no way to identify unread books.  There are no multiple loadouts for eg combat vs crafting/bartering/identifying modes.
-management of skills is also cumbersome.  Simply being able to display more than one taskbar at a time at the bottom would help (and being able to easily drag skills between task bars), as there are a massive number of skills, arrows, grenades, scrolls etc.  
-the quest log is a joke.  There is no sorting by location or type of quest (main, side etc).  The quest log is very poor at giving you guidance re what to do next, and you will be repeatedly having to use a walkthrough if you want to actually complete quests.  The issues go beyond things not being obvious, to being obtuse.  
-the crafting is deep but also cumbersome in terms of finding stuff in your inventory, and again you will need a walkthrough/guide
-the story and lore is long and confusing
-a number of mechanics are a waste of time: I never used the teleporter pyramids since I got Teleport, Tactical Retreat and Phoenix Dive.  Weapons and armour have durability but never take damage.  Lockpicking is never required if you have the skeleton Fane in your party.

Overall I would recommend it, but it is an 8/10 game, due to its many issues.  I certainly won't be playing it twice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198940416431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 7080, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7080, 'last_played': 1730377419}
review:
Rating: 9/10

Divinity: Original Sin 2 Definitive Edition is nothing short of a triumph in the realm of role-playing games. Building on the already stellar original, this edition enhances the experience with polished gameplay, refined mechanics, and an expansive narrative that truly immerses players in a rich fantasy world.

One of the standout features of Divinity: Original Sin 2 is its intricate storytelling. The game presents a world teeming with lore, filled with morally complex characters and choices that have meaningful consequences. Each decision you make can drastically alter the course of the narrative, making every playthrough feel unique. The game also offers a variety of origin characters, each with their own compelling backstories, allowing players to experience the world from diverse perspectives.

The tactical turn-based combat system is both challenging and rewarding. Each encounter requires strategic thinking, with environmental interactions and character abilities playing pivotal roles. The introduction of new skills and combos keeps battles fresh, while the ability to manipulate terrain—like igniting oil or creating surfaces that affect movement—adds layers of depth to combat strategy. The Definitive Edition also introduces improved AI, making enemies more challenging and engaging to fight.

Graphically, Divinity: Original Sin 2 is stunning. The hand-painted visuals bring the vibrant world of Rivellon to life, with detailed environments and beautifully animated character models. The sound design complements this with an atmospheric score and well-voiced characters, further enhancing the immersion.

The Definitive Edition includes various quality-of-life improvements, such as a revamped inventory system, better character customization, and refined user interfaces. These enhancements streamline the experience, making it more accessible to newcomers while still providing depth for seasoned players.

Divinity: Original Sin 2 Definitive Edition is a benchmark for modern RPGs. With its rich storytelling, strategic combat, and immersive world, it invites players to lose themselves in an epic adventure. Whether you’re a veteran of the genre or new to role-playing games, this title offers an unforgettable experience that is well worth the time investment. It’s a must-play for anyone looking to explore the depths of a beautifully crafted fantasy universe.

author: {'steamid': '76561199648124784', 'num_games_owned': 49, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2651, 'last_played': 1726616690}
review:
I think I am near the end of the game now, and man it has been an amazing journey and I only wish there was more and the last act wasn't rushed.

Divinity Original Sin 2 stands tall as one of the greatest RPGS ever made, this game deserves more recognition and credit. The world and setting(s) they have created in this game are truly fascinating and are incredibly diverse. The locations remind me of a fantasy game, however it has its own unique twist and flair to it.

The characters in this game, especially the companions are incredibly well written and very worth your time learning and understanding. Each companion has a different reaction to the actions you commit in this world and they all have their own usefulness and negatives in combat. It is not so simple as "a mage can heal but not do other mechanics". You have full control over how to spec your companions and character, I made a necromancer knight and it was incredibly viable throughout the whole game and never felt pressured by the game to doing something else. 

The story in D:OS2 might be my most least favourite aspect, it starts of very strong and engaging, and peaks at act 2 with branching story lines and engaging content and characters that make you keep playing late into the night wondering what is going to happen. However, during the later acts of the game, the story definitely starts to weaken a fair bit, the plot becomes confusing and wrongly paced and it becomes a point where you say to yourself "I just want to get this done with now". The constant puzzles and drawn out battles in act 3 just to drag out the playtime were not helped by the constant backtracking for certain items that game had not clear were necessary to progress the story. However, the combat and exploration is still incredibly rewarding and fun, so it evens out. If you are one to get burned out quickly, this game will not be for you at all.

Overrall, D:OS2 stands tall as a great game which has an incredible amount of quality content, paired with well-written characters and an interesting map. However, certain hindrances such as the fall off of the story, and the weirdly paced later acts and drawn out puzzles and battles must be noted.

9/10. Great game.

For me, a semi-perfectionist, this game makes me feel really torn.

I always want to make the best choice in the game, so when playing this game, I tried to load the previous game save file multiple times, which has resulted in me not completing the game yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025203813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 14894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14310, 'last_played': 1715755836}
review:
It's a solid RPG with strategic, turn-based combat and rich plot. 

Pros: Rich plot, rich characters (play as an origin character), dynamic combat that encourages using the enviornment tactically 

Cons: somewhat un-intuitive build system, lack of documentation of status and environmental effects, little auto saving (save manually after each encounter, trust me.)

review:
very fun turn based RPG game with decent voice acting , a complex story and a vibrant world which offer you a lot's of explorations.

Divinity Original Sin 2 doesn't require you to have played the first game and is also much easier to engage into , you have a large selection of recruitable characters which allow you to customize your party the way you want.

it's visually beautiful and offer a solid soundtrack that make it immersive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098171489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 6438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6438, 'last_played': 1731636099}
review:
A marvelous SRPG, with good multiplayer content.
The amount of content and customization this game has is humongous.

In this game we saw the evolution from Larian Studios after DOS1, and before their Baldur's Gate 3 consagration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198258917137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 2995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2995, 'last_played': 1729851491}
review:
8/10. Great story, slightly awkward and engaging gameplay, slow pacing.


As an RPG, you can feel that Larian blew this game out of the water.

For a small backstory: 
Larian wanted to make Baldur's gate three, but Wizards of the Coast(the owners of D&D) didn't have any real evidence that Larian could MAKE a good Baldur's gate game, so Larian made Divinity: Original sin 2.
Wizards saw the success of D:OS2, and went "yeah, you can make Baldur's gate 3".

This game feels good to play, just slightly awkward to get used to at first. A lot of the systems aren't very intuitive and there is a lot of menuing around to figure out what kinds of characters you can make.

I also have minor gripes about how leveling in this game works because it's too easy(if you like exploring, like me) to run into areas you aren't supposed to go to yet and die frequently to higher level enemies because you came unprepared for a fight... and underlevelled.

It's not that bad on a second playthrough, but if you are blindly playing DOS2 I strongly recommend having a friend who has played it, or a guide online to avoid falling into the many, many, many pitfalls that i fell into. 

Still, with all that being said, great game. 2nd and 3rd act are definitely weaker than the first but still enjoyable enough for me to replay this game again and again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049111447', 'num_games_owned': 481, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 8166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8166, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1735451366}
review:
This review comes from someone that played this AFTER beating Baulder's Gage 3 and has NOT played the first game in the Divinity series...

and let me tell you that i thoroughly enjoyed Divinity 2, it holds up VERY well to the standards of 2024.
The story is complex and there is definitely more content here than BG3.
I can see why people say divinity 2 is better than Baulder's Gate 3.

The graphics are 9.8/10. Only one spell casting animation is a bit weird but whatever.
The story is 9/10. There is a lot going on and it feels a bit overwhelming at times due to the sheer number of quests that stack up in the quest log. Its worth noting that the ending was satisfying.

My only complaints are that the inventory management and crafting can be bit tedious if your an OCD type. This is one of those things that got improved in BG3 thankfully.

Overall i give it a 9.5/10 - DO NOT buy the DLC unless you plan on playing it again.
I can see myself doing another play-through of this game in the future. 

If you're the kind of person that switches back and forth between games i would advise against it here. This would be a difficult one to pick back up and remember where you left off from a few weeks ago.

author: {'steamid': '76561199184876169', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 9436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9280, 'last_played': 1734084527}

author: {'steamid': '76561198092604503', 'num_games_owned': 257, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 39653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39505, 'last_played': 1735447527}
review:
[h1] The Story [/h1]
Act 1-2, solid 10/10 with good pacing , artfully weaving between fun and serious tones.
Act 3, is a 8/10 because progression grinds to a crawl with a couple of loose ends getting tied as you make your way into Act 4 which is a 7/10. The final act wraps up at what felt like a brisk power walk you'd use to cross the street when the pedestrian crossing sign started its countdown and you sure as hell aren't going to wait for the next light.

[h1] Combat [/h1]
Its a race to drop your opponents respective armor down so you can start stunning and Crowd Controlling (CC) them, whittling their health all the way to zero. Unfortunately, the AI is very much aware that if you have high physical armor that prevents physical stuns like knockdown, your magic armor will be vulnerable and you'll end up skipping your turn because you are frozen like a Popsicle or electrocuted. The heavy focus into CC rears its head at you more frequently at the higher difficulties and later acts when you, and the enemies you fight, have unlocked the final spells and skills.

[h1] Characters/Companions [/h1]
They are superior in every way compared to Baldurs Gate 3 companions, its not even close. Picture this, if Divinity Original Sin 2 companions are a pizza you'd order from any typical fast food joint, Baldurs Gate 3's ensemble is a piece of toasted bread with some ketchup and good ol' slice of everyones favorite plastic flavored american cheese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198249620796', 'num_games_owned': 167, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 10150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 67, 'playtime_at_review': 9583, 'last_played': 1735730658}
review:
This game has done so much for me, but thats personal bias.

Cyberpunk 2077 launched as a monument to everything wrong with game development, rushed, buggy, ugly, just mechanically broken. It was called every name in the book, cashgrab, garbage, etc.

However, these devs show so much love for this game, its incredible. The past 4 years have been spent making the game better day in and day out. Polishing and refining their original vision for the world of Night city. 

What we have today is a spectacular single player experience, an incredible story with heavy themes. With great gameplay to boot. Gunplay is satisfying, progression feels real and organic; at no point do you ever feel over or underpowered. The experience just feels balanced. This game is genuinely what i consider to be the best Single player game of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043768190', 'num_games_owned': 517, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 62372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 6328, 'playtime_at_review': 55637, 'last_played': 1736481608}
review:
Probably my favorite game ever, Cyberpunk is a game I'll always be coming back to. This game means a lot to me, and has seen me through some rough times. The world is comforting in a way, even though the oppressive atmosphere of the Corporation ran world is weighing down everything. Much like real life, you find comfort in the people you meet along the way. These characters are written so well that it's impossible not to resonate with at least a few, in their beliefs or struggles. How they view the world and how they wish the world were different. It can sometimes be very heavy stuff, this game holds no punches. 

Immersion is king. No game matches the feeling driving in Night CIty listening to the radio taking in the vibe. Night City is the most well crafted City in any game, period. The sense of scale is mind boggling, and whether you're walking among the skyscrapers or the skyline is just on the horizon the artistic design and scale is nothing short of a masterpiece in itself. Not one part of the map feels the same, and there will always be new things around the corner each playthrough. 

The gunplay is not often talked about enough, and I think that's a shame. I think Cyberpunk has some of the richest and most satisfying shooting in any first person shooter recently. Cyberpunk gives you the tools and the variety to become an unstoppable killing machine, but you have to put yourself together. The combinations in gun types and projectile types mixed with melee weapons, mixed with the plethora of absolutely ridiculous movement abilities on top of the dozens of overpowered cyberware that's been recently added to the game it's no wonder you're a legend in the city. Guns all have many different reload animations,  which I personally love when a FPS has this. Seeing the same reload animation an entire game kills my immersion. 

The soundtrack is one of my favorites, both the score and most of the radio. There are some really good songs that are guaranteed to raise your adrenaline given you've got the volume up, and you should. The sound design is superb, as an audiophile I can't NOT have this game's volume maxed out. Some of the music will no doubt ruin your accuracy from all the head bobbing, especially in the Phantom Liberty expansion. 

The amount of support this game has gotten post release is impressive, and I'm not including getting the game up to an acceptable point. The game shouldn't have released on past gen consoles, and there were a lot of issues I had with the game immersion wise that have been nearly fixed entirely. There's some bugs here and there but it's not going to ruin your experience anymore. This game is a feat. With how much is packed into this relatively small space, Night City, making it the most dense urban environment in games I understand that bugs will happen. 

This game is beautiful, not just visually but in what I've taken from it. This story and especially Phantom Liberty have hit me so hard it'll stick with me for forever. And with how varied the gameplay can be, with how many different endings there are and an almost unlimited modding platform Cyberpunk 2077 isn't leaving my PC anytime soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964267969', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 17923, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 308, 'playtime_at_review': 7823, 'last_played': 1736847028}
review:
Looks like skipping this game for the first 3 years paid off, since the Witcher games have taught me that it's always better to wait for an "enhanced edition". Maybe Cyberpunk 2077 had a shaky start, but as of this version and all the revisions, with the expansion, this game is an absolute masterpiece.

I've loved the Cyberpunk 2020 setting for three decades, Transmetropolitan is one of the best graphic novels ever and I've watched Fight Club more times than I can count. I didn't expect to see all of them reflected in the game. I still didn't expect I'd love Cyberpunk 2077 this much, but it totally got me.

These days, basing a massive game (with a major budget) on 30+ years of old RPG lore just doesn't happen. I was falsely under the impression that 2077 would be a soft reboot, since the attitude of "this much backstory could be a burden in attracting new players, so let's just scrap the old lore" is so common these days. (Fuck you, James Workshop.) I was pleasantly surprised when I realized that pretty much all of the stuff from Cyberpunk 2020 is still canon and even a major part of this game's main story.

If you want maximum appreciation of the setting, in the Steam version's bonus content you can find a complete scan of the Cyberpunk 2020 original rulebook. While most of this time capsule will make you appreciate the details of 2077 worldbuilding, I'd recommend at least reading the short story/adventure "Never Fade Away", originally published in 1988.

The last time I got this emotionally invested and immersed with a game's story and characters was probably back with Mass Effect 2. The Witcher 3 got close, but I like Cyberpunk 2077 even more. The saying "In Cyberpunk, there are no happy endings" is quite true. Half of the possible endings had me in bittersweet tears and the rest were so cripplingly depressing they should come with a medical warning. As it should be. Case never saw Molly again.

One other thing about this game that I don't think has been emphasized enough is the music. It's also something that nobody's dared to do. Instead of licensing famous old 80s/90s hits for nostalgic emotions (like pretty much any movie trailer these days), the music in this game is original. There's something closer to 15 hours of new music and radio stations in this game and it's performed by actual artists working under Cyberpunk pseudonyms, with the titles and lyrics in-universe. Hell, they've even recreated some of the bands and tracks referred to in the old RPG books. While this is already quite insane, the soundtrack just bangs with really diverse genres represented, from black metal to obnoxiously cute lazrpop. I don't think anyone has ever done musical justice to a fictional setting this well. 

This would be worth the price just so you can ride your motorcycle around the massive, detailed city (or ride the metro, I guess) while listening to the radio stations and soaking in the ambience of Night City.

This game is one massive love letter to one old cult RPG and it's so weird that it isn't actually made by greedy corpocunt suits who just want to chase profits. Work of art, really. Thank you, CD Projekt and Mike Pondsmith.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112583651', 'num_games_owned': 961, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 9607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8928, 'last_played': 1733014233}
review:
Never played the game during it's release. Started to get into it once a-lot of the issues were fixed. I can say the gameplay is definitely top-notch with the different amounts of variety included. The story is very well written and I enjoyed every conversation I had with Johnny. 

Side quest didn't feel boring, they had their own story within each-other so it didn't feel like your usual fetching quest to kill enemies and rinse and repeat. 

A-lot of characters felt fleshed out and felt genuine. Also, Having everything maxed out with path-tracing. This game looks unreal. ONE of the BEST looking games ever. 

I will say what I didn't really like was that we have "3" story lines but they didn't feel any different from each-other aside from special dialogue options during certain moments of the game. 

I'll give the game a 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993010115', 'num_games_owned': 360, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 33059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30100, 'last_played': 1733941547}
review:
This is, quite simply, one of the best games ever made. Full stop.

The combat is amazing. The story is top notch. The art direction is stunning. The VAs are all top notch, and the forced first person perspective means you LIVE as V. Whatever you have heard about the problems this game launched with, they have been fixed and oh so much more.

author: {'steamid': '76561199437680382', 'num_games_owned': 33, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 24779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 551, 'playtime_at_review': 22662, 'last_played': 1735781365}
review:
Rating: 9.5/10 (Masterpiece)

Cyberpunk 2077 has achieved one of the greatest redemption arcs in gaming history. It’s a stunning, immersive RPG that delivers on almost every level—but for me, it’s still missing that elusive something to make it a perfect 10.

What I Loved:

    Night City is Unmatched:
    Night City is the real star of the show. It’s vibrant, chaotic, and alive in a way few game worlds manage to achieve. From the neon-lit alleys of Japantown to the corporate opulence of City Center, every district is meticulously crafted. With improved AI, denser crowds, and enhanced environmental interactions since launch, the city finally feels like the bustling dystopia it was always meant to be.

    Deep, Immersive RPG Gameplay:
    Cyberpunk 2077 offers incredible freedom in how you approach the game. Whether you prefer hacking your way through systems, stealthily taking down enemies, or going in guns blazing, the gameplay accommodates multiple playstyles. The new updates and DLC bring even more depth to the combat and skill trees, making character builds more engaging than ever.

    Phantom Liberty DLC - A Game-Changer:
    The Phantom Liberty DLC is not just an expansion—it’s a revitalization. Set in Dogtown, a gritty new district of Night City, it introduces a tense spy-thriller storyline packed with twists, political intrigue, and moral dilemmas. Idris Elba’s performance as Solomon Reed is phenomenal, adding even more gravitas to the stellar voice acting. The DLC also brings significant improvements to the base game, like overhauled perk systems, vehicle combat, and more engaging side quests.

    Memorable Characters and Storytelling:
    Cyberpunk 2077’s story is rich and emotionally impactful. V and Johnny Silverhand (masterfully voiced by Keanu Reeves) have one of the most compelling dynamics I’ve seen in a game. The game masterfully weaves personal struggles with larger existential questions about identity and humanity. The Phantom Liberty storyline adds even more layers to this narrative brilliance.

    Technical Redemption:
    At launch, the game was plagued with bugs and performance issues, but it’s now in a state that lives up to its potential. CD Projekt Red has gone above and beyond to address the criticisms, making this one of the best post-launch redemption stories in gaming history.

What’s Still Missing:

    Lack of True Player Agency:
    As much as the game emphasizes choice, the main narrative often funnels you toward specific outcomes. While there are different endings, your decisions throughout the game don’t always feel as impactful as they could be.

    A Sense of Longevity:
    While the open world is packed with detail, it sometimes feels like a stage rather than a truly living world. Interactions with NPCs and side activities, though improved, still lack the depth to make Night City feel as reactive as it looks.

    Missing That "Perfect 10" Factor:
    For all its brilliance, the game still feels like it’s just short of perfection. Maybe it’s the lack of a revolutionary mechanic that changes the genre, or maybe it’s the way some gameplay elements (like crafting or economy systems) feel secondary. It’s hard to pinpoint, but there’s something intangible that stops it from being the definitive RPG experience.

Overall Thoughts:

Cyberpunk 2077 is no longer a cautionary tale—it’s a triumph. The Phantom Liberty DLC and continuous updates have elevated the game to masterpiece status, delivering one of the most immersive RPGs of this generation. The world-building, storytelling, and gameplay systems come together in a way that few games manage. However, as polished and engaging as it is, there’s still something missing—a spark or a layer of depth that could make it truly flawless.

Pros:

    Night City is a stunning, immersive open world.
    Deep, versatile gameplay with incredible build options.
    Masterful storytelling and memorable characters.
    Phantom Liberty adds an exceptional new storyline and gameplay features.
    A technical redemption that few games have pulled off.

Cons:

    Main narrative choices don’t always feel impactful.
    Some open-world interactions still feel surface-level.
    Missing an ineffable "wow" factor to make it a perfect 10.

Recommendation:
Cyberpunk 2077 is a must-play, especially in its current state. Whether you’re a fan of immersive worlds, gripping narratives, or deep RPG systems, it delivers on almost every front. The Phantom Liberty DLC is the cherry on top of an already incredible experience. It’s not just a game—it’s a world you’ll want to lose yourself in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012844356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 4219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2403, 'last_played': 1726942873}

author: {'steamid': '76561198007145445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 71625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69924, 'last_played': 1724550685}
review:
Cyberpunk 2077 stands as one of the most epic rides in gaming history, a journey through a world that is as breathtakingly beautiful as it is relentlessly brutal. While the game is not without its flaws and occasional technical hiccups, it more than compensates with its deep, complex narrative that plunges players into the darkest corners of human ambition and despair.

The story arcs are nothing short of mind-blowing, weaving together themes of identity, corruption, and the ceaseless march of technology with a finesse rarely seen in video games. With the expansion, players are treated to not just one, but two of the most intricate and emotionally charged narratives ever crafted, each one pushing the boundaries of what video game storytelling can achieve.

This game is a masterclass in world-building and character development, offering players a deeply immersive experience that lingers long after the credits roll. It's a game that challenges you, makes you question your choices, and pulls you deeper into its dystopian reality with every twist and turn.

For those seeking a story that is as complex as it is dark, as fulfilling as it is haunting, Cyberpunk 2077 is an unmissable experience. This game should not be skipped—it's a journey that demands to be taken.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047991514', 'num_games_owned': 922, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 6045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2186, 'playtime_at_review': 3654, 'last_played': 1736607079}
review:
Impressions after 50hours!
-(2.1 version/never playd on release or befor that)-

+ the world the feeling, the huge buildings or when you walk through the streets at night with all the illuminated signs, preferably with rain and ray trace/path trace really goose bumps in some places
+ the story is stronger than i've ever experienced in almost any other game, every side mission is a spectacle that you won't soon forget or that even makes you think(very emotional at some points which literally sucks you in). 
 But that was clear we have the witcher 3 developers here :)
+ the combat system is very complex when combined with mods for the body and weapon skill system and then using melee weapons and then melee skills on top of that.
+ various cars, some of which are very well detailed, and some cool weapons.


- little to do or few minigames outside of the *quests* i would like to see more in cyberpunk 2
- a few more bugs but none that I would say are really bad 

for me this game is now in this version clearly a buy recommendation, important game am grateful to have experienced it in my life :3

looking forward to play phantom liberty soon !

author: {'steamid': '76561198133770487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 5869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5758, 'last_played': 1720723422}
review:
[h1]For me this is the end of the Night City story.[/h1]

I completed all the tasks, unlocked all the endings and completed the DLC.
Honestly, I actually cried a lot in this game. haha. It was also fun, such a contrast in the game allowed us to move on, gave us hope for something good. But I can say that Cyberpunk 2077 will never end well. You have to make hard choices, but in the end you will still lose something.
I fell in love with this game and would like to forget everything that happened in it, so that I could plunge into Night City again like the first time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990185109', 'num_games_owned': 911, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 12760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12760, 'last_played': 1732547255}
review:
Cyberpunk 2077 is, without a doubt, the best single-player story game I have ever played. From the moment I stepped into Night City, I was completely immersed in its breathtaking atmosphere, compelling characters, and rich narrative. Every moment felt like it mattered, every choice had weight, and the sheer depth of the world kept me coming back for more.

The story is gripping and full of heart, touching on themes of identity, humanity, and freedom in a world dominated by greed and technology. I found myself laughing, crying, and even just sitting still in awe during certain moments. The performances, especially by Keanu Reeves as Johnny Silverhand, are unforgettable.

The gameplay itself is polished and diverse, offering so many ways to approach every situation, and the attention to detail in every corner of the city is stunning. The developers have clearly poured their hearts into this game, and the post-launch updates and the Phantom Liberty expansion have elevated it even further.

I genuinely cannot wait for future content and games set in this universe. CD Projekt Red has created something truly special with Cyberpunk 2077, and it feels like just the beginning of what this franchise can offer. If you're even remotely interested in storytelling, world-building, or RPGs, do yourself a favor and play this game. It’s a masterpiece.
