review: The game didn't click with me at launch what so ever. But, for some reason I decided to give it another chance and I'm loving it! No idea what changes were made or fixed, but it runs really well and it's a ton of fun! Bad ass game

author: {'steamid': '76561198067278707', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 4402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4246, 'last_played': 1729407677}
review:
I don't think i've ever had as much fun with an RPG as I ever have with 2077. This is the first game in a while where I got deep into the lore and found myself making a new character every time I return. It's crazy that its STILL getting updates and making the game ever better to the point where playing a build I used to is now entirely new and more fun. It's insane what an extra 4 years of development did for this game to where i'd say it's now in my top games of all time. 

Edgerunners made me give it a chance when I was on the fence, and every piece of awesome content that came after kept me around. I'm looking forward to more games with the Cyberpunk license in the future (and hopefully with actual development time)

author: {'steamid': '76561198122518670', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 2598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2454, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1721837713}
review:
Incredible experience overall - this game is finally where we all wanted it to be.

The combat system is astonishing, i personally preferred to play as an assassin, combining stealth with speed and the sheer amount of weapons and also "chrome-upgrades" is immense.

Character progression is paced fitting and satisfying - cars, bikes, weapons are piling up over time and are nice rewards for your efforts of keeping things under control while also trying to get cult status in Night City.

The story is pretty action-heavy (who would have guessed) and is well built but also a bit basic in my opinion.

In general Cyberpunk 2077 (also including the DLC) is an excellent adrenaline rushed experience with humorous elements bullying late-capitalism-ideologies mixed with an insane creative mix of futurism and the "real world". Combat mechanics are absolutely incredible and the game looks next gen indeed. A must play experience!

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197995822805', 'num_games_owned': 29, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6969, 'last_played': 1722089667}
review:
Great graphics, and atmosphere. Decent storytelling, combat system, music (some songs were great, especially in the DLC, some were awful), and attention to many little details is greatly appreciated. 

Wish there would be more romance and dialog options and some dialog options being more self-descriptive as to what outcome they would lead to. 
One of the biggest annoyances is when an enemy is alerted or notices you when he shouldn't. 
All in all, didn't encounter game-breaking bugs.

Hope Orion will answer many questions that were left unanswered here (some of the endings, rogue AIs, etc.)

author: {'steamid': '76561199387067084', 'num_games_owned': 47, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1024, 'playtime_at_review': 2991, 'last_played': 1736842565}
review:
Imagine you're working in a 9-5 corporate job, you're done with your work, you come back home, log onto Steam, see your games list for 5 seconds, buy a game on sale that you're never going to play and then switch off your PC and go to a bar. While having a drink, you think of the good times when games used to be fun and authentic. But then you tell yourself, the problem isn't the games, its you. "Its not that games aren't fun anymore, you have gotten older".

And then I play Witcher 3. And suddenly I can't wait to get myself home after work. Do you have any idea how precious that feeling is ? The feeling that you are actually immersed in the protagonist' shoes. I find myself in anticipation and excitement for the new adventures that are waiting for me, I think while driving back home...."Where is this story headed ? What new places and characters I will meet ?" And lets not talk about the characters. I thought myself as a guy who's dead on the inside and somehow these characters made me laugh, chuckle and empathise at the same time. I haven't felt these feelings for a game since 2008 when I played games such as Final Fantasy 12, Metal Gear Solid 3. Was I wrong to think that I was the problem and not the gaming industry that's shelling out mediocre AAA games with no memorable characters or storyline ?

And I got this game for 3$. 3$ !! And that includes the DLC ! I honestly feel I looted these amazing devs. And I paid twice for games that are not even worth playing. 23 hours in and I still haven't scratched the surface of the story. The side quests are actually fun. I find myself doing the side quests more because its feels like I am watching another episode of the "Witcher 3 TV show". I love this open world, I actually take my time wandering around and exploring every nook and cranny. I haven't done this since GTA San Andreas. I look at some distant island or mountain that I find interesting and I decide to just walk there just for the fun of it. That's how beautiful this Open World this. This is Open World game done right.

Thank you CD Projekt Red. You guys are a gem. I know its 5 years late and I don't know why it took me 5 years to play this, but better late than never.

author: {'steamid': '76561198449571208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 22690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22675, 'last_played': 1718732591}
review:
It's 2024, and The Witcher 3 remains the best game I've ever played. I wish I could go back and experience it for the first time.

Writing this after just finishing Ghost of Tsushima Director's Cut - the game is great: well-written story, enjoyable gameplay, and visually stunning, but it made me realize that in comparison, The Witcher 3 is still on another level—a masterpiece. I've played numerous RPGs, but few come close to The Witcher 3 in terms of the overall experience, including immersion, world-building, role-playing, player choices, blend of fantasy and realism, soundtrack, and replayability. The Next-Gen update has also made the game look absolutely stunning and not at all dated. The world, especially Toussaint, is incredibly beautiful.

The combat may be the weakest part of the game and can feel slightly dated, but it's definitely playable and not as bad as some people say. My favorite aspect is preparing for combat—knowing which potions or signs to use against specific types of enemies and situations.

One aspect that sets The Witcher 3 apart from other games is the developers' attention to detail, which makes the world extremely immersive and story-rich. The variety in the side quests is remarkable in terms of storytelling, often blending elements encountered elsewhere. Many of these quests are even more entertaining than the main storyline. This attention extends to random world encounters; in most other games, it's simply about killing bandits or rescuing someone, but in The Witcher 3, you can become invested in random characters you meet on the road, sympathize with their stories, investigate, and make tough decisions that leave you pondering whether you made the right choice.

I also appreciate that throughout the game—whether in main quests, side quests, or random encounters—you have the freedom to make choices, although sometimes the wording can be misleading in certain quests. Almost every choice has impactful, sometimes far-reaching, and unexpected consequences, which enhances the world's immersion, realism, and complexity. You can play as you like, shaping Geralt as you imagine or want him to be. This freedom is something I enjoy more than RPGs where players have limited decision-making and must follow a predetermined path.

If I were to rate some of the RPGs I've enjoyed (minimum 80 hours):

The Witcher 3: 10/10
Elden Ring: 10/10
Skyrim: 9.5/10
Kingdom Come: Deliverance: 9/10
Cyberpunk: 8.5/10
Ghost of Tsushima: 8/10
Hogwarts Legacy: 8/10
Assassin's Creed Origins: 7.5/10
Assassin's Creed Odyssey: 7/10

review: As someone coming from The Elder Scrolls franchise, this game is something else. Don't let the stupidly tedious introduction make an impression - or the odd combat controls. You get a hang of it in like 2 hours. At first I hated Geralt because my girlfriend loves him so much. But now I love him as well. Also there's boobs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198301924336', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6129, 'last_played': 1596231882}
review:
After so many hours, so many adventures, so many life lessons.. I wish I had words to describe this game, but I simply don't.
It is definately the best game I've ever played in my life, it's like a work of art that I'm glad I had the chance to experience.
Every place you go feels so alive, the characters are so well written that most of the time I would get completely immersed into the conversations with them.
When you look back at it after doing everything, every single quest, all the expansions, all the places.. You feel something like a good memory from the past, a feeling of nostalgia..
When people say this game is big, it's kinda hard to understand what it means, for some, it's the map, or the number of quests, or even the size of the campaign, but I believe this game is big on what it tried to achieve, on the greatness of the story that it told, the powerful effects of your choices, the felling you have when you discover a new monster and quickly have to adapt to overcome it, the experience you have when picking up a trail, or sailing through the cold oceans of skellige alone..

So many memories, that with words it's simply too hard to explain, memories that I will always hold dear to my heart.


Thanks CD PROJEKT, simply, thanks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970609778', 'num_games_owned': 234, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 14712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14712, 'last_played': 1639006719}
review:
Witcher 3 is perhaps my favourite RPG of all time. I'll admit it was a slow burn for the first few hours, and I wasn't exactly captivated initially. I had heard incredible things about this game and I began to wonder what all the hype was about. I'm glad I persisted because the payoff was immeasurable. After getting through the opening missions, the story picks up quickly and I was then sucked into the incredible world created by CD Projekt Red. And what a world it is. The map is absolutely massive, with various different environments to explore. The landscapes are beautiful and appear full of life, from random travellers to nefarious creatures roaming the wild. The sea, likewise, has much variety for those willing to explore the murky depths. The cities and villages feel alive, NPC's actually seem to have some purpose as they go about their tasks, there are shops and taverns everywhere with many accessible indoor areas. There are weather changes and a day/night cycles as well to add even more realism. 

The main story presents us with finding Ciri, and reaching her before the malevolent Wild Hunt. For those that haven't played the first two games, while they loosely continue certain events and character relationships, they aren't really necessary to enjoy the adventure here. I would argue though that while the main story does a good enough job of moving the game along, the shining stars are the side quests. Like most RPG's, side quests are a staple with this genre but in Witcher 3 some of these quests are actually much better overall. These quests are everywhere, even a small village has several be it help tracking down a missing person, hunting down a certain creature terrorising the land, or retrieving certain items for a reward. Geralt after all is a bounty hunter and makes his living through these jobs. Also, while some may disagree, I really enjoyed the Gwent mini-game and this could have easily made its own stand alone game (which it eventually did). 

The game provides a lot of options for character builds, with options to focus on alchemy, signs, combat or a mix of these. The character tree is deep enough but also not so deep as to need a university math degree to understand, which suits me more than fine. The combat system seems fluid and responsive, albeit simple. Sometimes the camera would frustrate me, especially with multiple enemies. 

Finally two expansions were released after the main game. They were offered for free and they may be even better than the base game. Specifically Blood and Wine holds a special place in my heart as the landscapes, characters and overall story is outstanding. I'm amazed that CD Projekt Red would just give these away, yet it displays a certain type of class that just isn't prevalent in the gaming industry anymore. 

Witcher 3 was a game I got sucked into during the heat of the Covid Pandemic, and it created some lasting memories into this brilliant world. I was so entranced with the experience (once I finally got hooked) and offered some much needed escapism during this difficult period (I work as an ER nurse). In fact I actually completed all the Steam achievements, collected all the Gwent cards and completed every side mission. And this was before I became a game completionist.   I doubt I'll ever be able to recreate the gaming experiences I had during this era. So give this game a go if you can, but give it a fair shot, because there's a good chance you'll be happy you did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198822240788', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 26108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26108, 'last_played': 1725130995}
review:
[list][*]ㅤA wonderful and immersive game, probably one of the best I've played in a long time. I had the chance to buy the complete edition of this game at a very low price, but that doesn't mean the game isn't worth every penny even at full price. There's a ton of content in it, from the main story to the two included DLCs, which justifies the price and makes the game worth it; over 400 hours of gameplay without any exaggeration. The game is literally HUGE. I finished the main story plus the first DLC when I already had around 370 hours played, and the second DLC which was also one of the best DLCs I've ever played was so large that I could say it felt like a completely different game in The Witcher series (a mini-sequel), finishing the whole game (including every contract, side quest, place to explore, etc.) in 430 hours without any NG+ or other replays.

[*]ㅤI started this game as a newbie, I would say, not having played the other two games in the series and having no knowledge of the story from the books or the movie. (For someone who has to choose a game from a series for the first time, they will always pick the most recent one for the graphics and other aspects, right?)
I'd say that someone who has no clue about what The Witcher is about won't understand much at the beginning of the game, as I didn't either, since the events in the game follow and are connected to the events in the previous two games (obviously). Everything starts quite abruptly, and some events are presented somewhat summarily in my opinion. I spent about a quarter of my gameplay time on various external websites, researching and getting an idea of what was going on, what events took place before The Witcher 3, who is fighting whom, who is who, etc., and I realized that the entire story is much broader than I had imagined, which made me adore this game along with the innovative mini-game of Gwent that was introduced in the base game; quite intuitive, easy to learn, and straightforward.

[*]ㅤI have to say honestly that I didn't like the first area at the beginning of the game at all, not in terms of design, but in how the actions unfolded and how the conversations between characters played out, giving me the impression of a gloomy, vague, and boring game that was to follow. Because of this, I was on the verge of giving the game a negative review, but I decided to give it another chance and time to see what it's capable of, as progressing in the game only to later realize that I could have made the biggest mistake of my life, despite everyone saying it is an extraordinary game filled with positive reviews.

[*]ㅤAt first, it was hard to understand and get used to the game's mechanics, but in the end, I managed to get the hang of it. The gameplay is great, but there were some aspects that I didn't really like; for instance the combat, which is kind of clunky and leaves a bit to be desired, but over time, you start to get good at it. Despite this, I should be glad, because I've heard from others that the combat is much worse in The Witcher 1 and 2, as well as the movement. Another aspect that's kind of ridiculous is the very low height from which you can fall and die. I mean, seriously, I fell from about 2m - 2.5m and died having full health; and another aspect that wasn't necessarily unpleasant was the bugs encountered throughout the game, one here, one there, but overall nothing very significant that would make the game unplayable.

[*]ㅤThe story is very complex and well-structured, very well designed areas, astonishing soundtracks that blend perfectly with the in-game atmosphere, there are a lot of characters, and the dialogue between them is very well written, the voice acting is excellent, and maybe that's why I shouldn't even have to say it anymore, as many have said it before me, but it's worth mentioning that [i]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt[/i] is a masterpiece, and it's truly one of the most acclaimed RPGs of all time. There's no doubt that I would fully recommend this game and I definitely intend to play the other two games in the series because this game got my full attention and gave me an excellent introduction to The Witcher universe, even if I started with the end.[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198079607713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 25198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23997, 'last_played': 1723133122}

author: {'steamid': '76561198942518402', 'num_games_owned': 80, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1717767730}
review:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is hands down one of the best RPGs I've ever played. I’ve played the whole game on my other account but now i’m gonna play it on this account also, Seriously, this game is a masterpiece in every sense of the word. From the moment you start playing, you're sucked into this incredibly detailed world filled with monsters, magic, and political intrigue.

The storyline is just...wow. It's so rich and immersive, with twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat. And the characters? They feel so real, with their own personalities, motivations, and flaws. You really get invested in their journeys, which makes every decision you make feel weighty and important.

And let's talk about the world itself. It's massive, but it never feels empty or boring. There's always something to do, whether it's hunting down monsters, exploring hidden caves, or just chilling in a tavern playing Gwent. And speaking of Gwent, don't even get me started on how addictive that card game is!

Combat is another highlight. It's challenging, but in a good way. You have to be strategic with your swordplay, magic, and potions to take down tougher enemies, and it feels incredibly satisfying when you pull off a tough fight.

Honestly, I could go on and on about how amazing this game is, but I'll just say this: if you haven't played The Witcher 3 yet, do yourself a favor and pick it up. You won't regret it.


I’m trying to get 10k steam points to customize my profile abit. Help a brotha out:D

author: {'steamid': '76561199111879897', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 16474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16474, 'last_played': 1727719726}
review:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt transcends mere escapism; it offers a profound retreat into a solitude that feels like rediscovering clarity. There’s a certain wisdom in Geralt’s solitary wandering—a tacit acknowledgment that sometimes, solitude isn’t loneliness but liberation. In Geralt’s journey, we glimpse Cioran’s musings on the absurdity of existence, where life’s weight becomes bearable because it’s accepted, not resisted. The game doesn’t resolve the chaos of the world, nor does it offer easy answers—it revels in moral ambiguity and existential bleakness, making the escape all the more meaningful. Like Cioran, who saw despair as life’s backdrop, The Witcher 3 crafts an escapism that doesn't seek to deny reality but to confront it with detachment. Here, the solitude of the path sharpens focus, and clarity arises not from solving life's riddles, but from accepting that they never had answers in the first place.

10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128385623', 'num_games_owned': 4705, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 12661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12661, 'last_played': 1577865448}
review:
This game is one of my favorites of all time. I’d say it’s easily in my top twenty games – no easy feat, since I usually find open-world games repugnant.

In fact, I tried playing it long before I settled in and played it start to finish. I was immediately inundated with a horde of characters who acted as if I should already know who they were. By the time I got to the part where I could freely explore the world, I was already overwhelmed. Letting me loose to explore the land as I pleased only made me feel more anxious. So, I stopped playing then and there.

Something about the experience must have captured my imagination, though. Since I was miffed that I learned little about the characters other than their names and a bit about their relationships with Geralt, I decided that I should be better prepared if I ever tried playing it again. That’s when I vowed that I would read the books before I went back to the game.

Then years went by. (I’ve got tons of practice at saying I’ll do something and then never doing it. It’s something I’m super good at.) I didn’t really think about it again until the first season of the Netflix series was announced. And suddenly, I was determined to read the books and play this game before the show debuted.

What ensued was a months-long quest to read everything from [i]The Last Wish[/i] to [i]Season of Storms[/i]. Between the first few books in the series, I read other, random books to keep from burning myself out. By the end of the series, though, I was reading the books back-to-back. Not because I was running out of time before the show came out… No, the books had me completely captivated.

This was a little strange to me. After reading [i]The Hobbit[/i] and [i]The Lord of the Rings[/i] series a couple of years prior and finding it to be a miserable experience (yes, I hate [i]The Lord of the Rings[/i] books – fight me, Tolkien nerds), I had avoided fantasy books and, more broadly, book series altogether. So, to find myself completely infatuated with this fantasy series I had only heard of through video game news articles and wanting more and more of it left me dumbstruck. From the first two books (that are filled with monsters and action and sex but were still able to contain some depth) to [i]The Lady of the Lake[/i] (whose narrative structure resembles a Russian nesting doll, with each layer showing another step in Ciri’s path to become the most powerful Witcher in history), I was in for the ride completely. I was thrilled, I laughed, and, though it’s been a few years and my memory is hazy, I probably bawled like a little baby in the end.

Anyway, as I mentioned before, after the final book in the series, I wanted more. Luckily, there was [i]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt[/i] waiting for me in my Steam library. And, this time, I was ready.

My god, this game. I can’t describe what it felt like to finally see these characters that I had spent months reading about brought to life to continue their adventures. To say I was moved would undersell the way I felt the first time I hopped onto Roach and galloped through the hills of Velen. This game was completely engrossing for hundreds of hours and it’s something that I’ll never forget.

However, there is something even more important that my experience with [i]The Witcher[/i] has done for me: I’ve discovered a love for fantasy, and I’ve been more open to reading book series. (Serieses? Seri? Whatever.) Since my time spent with Geralt and the rest of the crew, I’ve read both [i]The First Law[/i] series by Joe Abercrombie and [i]The Expanse[/i] by James S. A. Corey – two series I never would have even considered reading if it wasn’t for [i]The Witcher[/i]. Hell, I even got a tattoo of Geralt’s magic signs down my forearm a couple of weeks ago.

As you can probably tell, this game means a great deal to me. I can’t do anything besides recommend it. (And the book series, obviously.)

But I think the most important thing to take a way from this review is this: [i]The Lord of the Rings[/i] fucking sucks, guys. Guys: it’s boring as hell. It’s just [b]sooooo[/b] shitty, guys. [i]The Witcher[/i] makes [i]The Lord of the Rings[/i] its bitch. Do you know what I do when I can’t sleep? I turn on [i]The Lord of the Rings[/i] and I slip into a coma out of pure boredom. If I was trapped on a deserted island with only [i]The Lord of the Rings[/i], I’d let myself get eaten by sharks. [i]The Lord of the Rings[/i] is so dumb, it might as well be yo momma…

...

[i]Edit: I thought I should mention that this is my 100th review on Steam, so I wanted it to be something special. I hope you found it worthwhile. Don't worry - I'll be back to talking about boobs and farts again with the next one. Anyway, congrats to me! 🥳[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561199136139834', 'num_games_owned': 54, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 614114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 14104, 'playtime_at_review': 600010, 'last_played': 1736846858}
review: The Witcher 3 is a masterpiece, and in many respects simply the best and most exciting game in recent years. It captivates players with artistic vision, a huge world and an epic story. The developers were not looking for cheap applause - game design is uncompromising, consistent, thoughtful and nuanced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149209658', 'num_games_owned': 81, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 24327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24327, 'last_played': 1667768392}
review:
Should've written a review for this years ago, but I suppose better late than never. I've played this game, including the dlcs about six or seven times now and it really is my favorite game of all time. Every time I jump into a new play-through I lose a week of my life, because I'm fully immersed in the story and can't stop playing. Geralt is an amazing protagonist and all the areas feel so alive with the different characters and details that are put into them. Not only is the main story-line great, the side-quests are basically just as good and memorable. The dlcs feel like another game and have a freaking vampire story?? Only negative is that the combat can feel quite simple and boring at times, but trying to roleplay with potions and sword oils make it a bit more enjoyable. This game isn't really about the combat anyway, but the characters and just exploring the world. Also gwent. I also like that there are different endings and romance options, even though I will never choose the bad endings (Ciri is my child). 

10/10 my favorite game :3, please play it

author: {'steamid': '76561199071434615', 'num_games_owned': 45, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 8012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7704, 'last_played': 1709638109}
review:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is hands down one of the best RPGs I've ever played. Seriously, this game is a masterpiece in every sense of the word. From the moment you start playing, you're sucked into this incredibly detailed world filled with monsters, magic, and political intrigue.
After so many hours, so many adventures, so many life lessons.. I wish I had words to describe this game, but I simply don't.
It is the best game I've ever played in my life, it's like a work of art that I'm glad I had the chance to experience.
Every place you go feels so alive, the characters are so well written that most of the time I would get completely immersed in the conversations with them, Completed both the DLCs and man they were great. This is for sure a must-play.
10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197970788678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 11375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2428, 'playtime_at_review': 11375, 'last_played': 1736108197}
review:
[h1]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt[/h1]

How do you even review The Witcher 3 in 2025? 

Everyone knows what it is and what it's not. 

Regardless, I played the game fully (Main game + ALL DLCs) for the first time now. It was an excellent experience. It took me around 130 hours, all sidecontent included, on the Death March! difficulty.

I was expecting it to feel "old" in some ways, but I was gladly proven wrong quickly. The game looks amazing to this date, maybe due to the "next gen update" from 2022. The game looked and sounded great - maybe not as detailed as some newer games, but the art style carried and the design of the rather grim world of The Witcher still feels unmatched to this day. Novigrad especially I was surprised by - the city is vast, full of people and actually feels like a city rather than a level in a video game. 

Gameplay wise I had no real issues. Though the combat wasn't too deep, the variety in which you can build Geralt made up for it's simplicity. I went for a full Sign build (eg. magic) and had a blast weaving in devastating spells, while fending off enemies with parries of the sword and dodges. Death March! added some challenge and in some cases I used oils and bombs to further fight the various enemies and bosses. The best part about the combat was the variety of enemies. The Witcher 3 is full of very different creatures - man or monster - and a lot of different bosses (Witcher contracts mainly) that kept the game fresh throughout. Some recent games I've played had little in the variety department (Dragon Age: The Veilguard) which in those games made combat extremely repetetive. 

Looking past the combat, the game felt fresh due to it's amazing narrative. The story is gripping and every bit of the world feels alive and interesting. It's rare that a game's sidequests have as good or better storylines than the main objective, but the Witcher 3 has that in droves. [b]And this is what the Witcher 3 does best. [/b] The stories. The Wticher, while very action-heavy, is an RPG. There are multiple endings, choices to be made that aren't cut and dry and therefore offer interesting stories to tell. I can't help but compare that approach to the genre again to my recently played games. The Witcher 3 did it better 10 years ago. 

To keep it short and sweet: Banger of a game, 10/10, even in 2025. [b]Would highly recommend[/b] - [i]especially[/i] since you can buy the whole lot on sale quite often for less than 15 EUR/$.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006676144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 11556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8390, 'last_played': 1734890918}
review: The best RPG I have ever played, this game has a vast open world where whatever you can see you can go to, with environment design that makes it feel alive and vibrant. The writing is incredible! Your choices big and small matter and the game reacts to them throughout its' 135 hour story (and that's with me skipping a large chunk of the side content). Random adventures into the unknown unlock new quests and interesting stories that the game lets you discover on your own, no hand-holding involved.

review:
A rare game where you don’t want to skip the dialogues, and the side quests are on par with the main story, Stone Hearts is one of the most poignant and tragic narratives I’ve ever read or experienced in games. A Polish masterpiece of both literature and video games. Every couple of years, I replay The Witcher from the beginning, and the emotions are always the same. 

Bravo!

author: {'steamid': '76561199184522779', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1868, 'last_played': 1735140392}
review: I'm about 30 hours into it atm and loving it. Great writing with meaningful choices, beautiful open world with plenty of things to do, in depth combat and great setting and atmosphere.

author: {'steamid': '76561199214504160', 'num_games_owned': 546, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 11824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11739, 'last_played': 1724668390}
review:
Nearly a decade later this game still has no competition when it comes to delivering meaningful side content, with hundreds of quests all well written and voice acted. I didn't encounter a single fetch quest throughout my 200 hour playthrough. The combat can feel a bit clunky to begin with, but as you learn the mechanics and improve your chosen build, it becomes much more fun, even more so with the 2 expansions that add more depth. Thanks to the next gen update the visuals still look incredible, although using the default settings the game can be very demanding, this is because Screen Space Reflections are enabled, took me 160 hours to realise this so don't make the same mistake as me. 

Overall, I can't recommend this game enough. Even playing it for the first time 9 years late, I can still say that for me personally, no game released since then has been able to top The Witcher 3.

review:
The Witcher 3 is an absolute masterpiece that exceeds all expectations. author: {'steamid': '76561198022713973', 'num_games_owned': 161, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 18186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18186, 'last_played': 1723375138}
review:
Being the third and final installment of the Witcher series, this game is an epic conclusion to the adventures of the most popular witcher. As in the two first games, you play the witcher Geralt of Rivia, however, in Witcher 3 you have a great open world to explore in contrast to a closed area or linear map as in the predecessor games. The main story deals with the Wild Hunt and Geralt and associates searching for Ciri, who bears a crucially important power.

The sophisticated main story with its authentic main and side characters and diverse dialogue options is extremely well written and hooks you from the start. I have so thoroughly enjoyed it that I felt somewhat empty and even a bit sad when I finished it, as I knew there was most likely no other RPG being able to deliver something comparable to this marvelous adventure. Sometimes I wish I could forget the main story and play it all over again. Choices made during its course do not only determine the destiny of single characters, but also the future of whole empires. Next to the main quest, The Witcher 3 offers side quest plots that can be experienced before certain events during the main quest and that add a lot of immersion to the world. Most quests offer you different choices and give you the feeling that there is no absolute evil or good, but many shades of gray in an overall harsh world. In my opinion, the only subject that required more attention was the background story and motivation of the main antagonist.

The open world in which this RPG takes place is massive and filled with innumerable smaller side quests. Next to standard side quests, the witcher might also solve problems regarding monsters in special contracts to earn additional experience and funds. The developers have put in tons of effort to create and design as many diverse and interesting monsters as possible, which all have an entry in a bestiary and require a different strategy to be beaten by the witcher. For example, this means that you should brew certain potions to be able to effectively combat various monster types. Furthermore, you can enhance your witcher’s abilities by spending skill points on a diverse set of skills that can all improve your strength. These features increase the immersion of playing as a mutant human that the witcher actually is and thus increase the joy of playing as a true witcher. The very satisfactory feeling of character progression through the course of a playthrough is reinforced by finding and improving an armory set from a witcher school of your own choice. The cities and settlements and the people living in these feel quite vivid, however, you can sometimes notice that the open world and most of its inhabitants can often be more accurately described as a theatric scenery than a consistent and organic world that could also exist on its own. The open world felt quite bland and empty here and there, giving the impression that size mattered more than quality.

The two DLCs of the Witcher 3, Hearts of Stone (HoS) and Blood and Wine (BaW) are both absolutely worth it and actually handle my two main points of criticism quite well: the main antagonist and the open world. While HoS offers only little with regard to exploration of new areas, its story telling and main antagonist, who I would describe as the best written main antagonist up to this date, are the focus points of this expansion. BaW is an expansion that focuses on all strengths of this game and creates a more believable open world that is smaller, but more densely packed with quests and interesting characters. Basically, BaW is a better version of the main game just with smaller proportions. I highly recommend both DLCs to everyone who has played the main game.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is probably the best RPG of the 2010s and one of the best and most memorable RPGs of all time. Everyone who enjoys sophisticated story telling and an authentically written dark and ruthless world full of questionable human beings and dangerous monsters will wholeheartedly enjoy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078273913', 'num_games_owned': 649, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 9361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8428, 'last_played': 1724503405}
review:
[b] The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt [/b] tells the tale of [i] Geralt of Rivia [/i], a seasoned witcher still in his prime, despite his grumpy demeanor. His mission? To find his wayward apprentice and adopted daughter, Ciri, who has a knack for disappearing at the most inconvenient times. 
Along your journey, you'll meet a host of characters—some eager to help, others eager to use you for their own gain. The world is filled with fascinating personalities, both good and not-so-good, each with their own unique charm. Trust me, you'll want to learn everything about them.

The game is an absolute masterpiece of the RPG genre, boasting an open world so vast and full of life that it’s easy to get lost in it for hours on end. The story is shaped by your decisions, making each playthrough feel unique and deeply personal. You'll find yourself exploring the massive world, taking on monster contracts, solving dungeon puzzles, helping those in need, and, of course, engaging in some risky romances with powerful sorceresses (not the safest idea, but who can resist?) :D

The locations in the game are nothing short of stunning—whether you're roaming through vibrant, colorful landscapes or creeping through dark, terrifying dungeons, the visuals will leave you breathless. (I've taken about a million screenshots, and I regret nothing!) 
Combat is smooth and satisfying, with options to use swords, crossbows, bombs, potions, and signs to decimate your enemies. The mechanics are intuitive, making it a breeze to dive into the action.

[b] I highly recommend [/b] The Witcher 3 to fantasy lovers, open-world enthusiasts, or anyone who hasn’t yet experienced the epic story of Geralt of Rivia. It’s a game that’s sure to capture your heart and keep you hooked from start to finish. 
P.S I got the game on sale for just 3-4 dollars—practically pocket change! Don’t hesitate to grab it during a sale because this game is worth so much more. It's one of my favorites game for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977702388', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 15484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15484, 'last_played': 1716618033}
review:
[h3][u]The Big If[/u][/h3]
Insert '[i]what can I say that hasn't already been[/i]' cliche.  In 250+ hours, all achievements conquered, all maps cleansed of their quests and points of interest, and all dlc content thoroughly explored, I can confidently say I've experienced nearly everything this game has to offer.

This was the one: CDPR's golden child.  I know i'm rather late to the party, but I finally made time to try the game I had heard such an overwhelming amount about over the last decade.  Thankfully, I was not jumping in blind as I have completed both the Witcher 1 and 2 prior to tackling this beast, and would say I enjoyed those a moderate amount.  But this--the Witcher 3--this is the one that has gained a staggeringly strong reputation over the years for being such a strong entry in the fantasy RPG genre.  Needless to say, I went in with rather high expectations.

I'll keep it short and say that those expectations were absolutely met.  The absurd level of detail and effort put into creating a living, breathing world that ensures the player will [i]not[/i] feel like the center of the universe is incredibly respectable, leaving said player with an immensely satisfying and immersive experience.  One that I could not recommend more. . . . . . . .

[h2]IF[/h2]

a primarily story driven game is what resonates with the player.  

To go on a bit of a tangent, every time there's a [i]what's a popular game that you just couldn't get into?![/i] thread on popular gaming sites or reddit, there's always 2 very common answers: Zelda, Breath of the Wild (a discussion for another day..) and the Witcher 3.  That said, despite thoroughly enjoying my time, I have [i]absolutely[/i] come to understand why so many feel they just can't get into this game.

The Witcher 3's biggest strength is that the devs knew exactly what they wanted this game to be.  The engaging story and its themes, the lively cast of characters, the beautifully detailed and immersive world?  All great stuff!  The Witcher 3 as a general experience is undeniably fantastic...

The Witcher 3 as a [i]game[/i]?... Yeeeeah there's just nothing of interest here.   The problem with the devs focusing so hard on creating a believable world is that they doubled down on finely tuning this aspect of the game, leaving the rest of the experience to suffer as a result.  The player can go [i]hours[/i] without interacting with any of the game's core mechanics if they happen to engage in a chain of story-centered quests, which doesn't necessarily have to be viewed as a bad thing, but when they do finally happen upon gameplay, it can feel under cooked.

The open world contains many memorable and varied side quests, admittedly, but contains just as many points of interest that are considered busy work in other games of a similar format.  Combat is often cited as a particularly weak part of the gameplay as it boils down to a very a simplistic dodge-and-counter loop, a complaint I can't disagree with.  There are dozens of armor/weapon sets that all differ [i]only[/i] in numerical stats until the dlc, which by then is too little too late.  Signs, this game's version of magic, are rather one-dimensional and therefore pretty limited in spicing up combat.  There are [i]hundreds[/i] of lootable items, and while not all of them add to the limit, the devs decided on keeping the weight system that plagues so many rpg's.  This isn't a survival game, so no idea why this system exists here.  The list goes on, but I feel the point across.

I can wholeheartedly recommend this title [i]if[/i] and only if the player is aware of what they're getting into.  The Witcher 3 is an experience first and game second.  The devs knew this and if you don't mind that fact, you will be treated to one of the most memorable experiences in gaming.

author: {'steamid': '76561199031756745', 'num_games_owned': 91, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 8209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6291, 'last_played': 1719866864}
review:
[h1] [b]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt - A Journey from Frustration to Fascination[/b] [/h1]

[b]Having never played the previous installments of The Witcher series[/b], I found myself diving into The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt with a mix of excitement and trepidation. From the outset, the game felt like a [b]deprecation. The clunky combat mechanics and awkward movement system were immediate turn-offs.[/b] The game's complexity was overwhelming, inundating me with a barrage of new characters and rapidly evolving plot threads before I had even grasped the controls or memorized the key bindings. [b]Each attempt to immerse myself ended in boredom and frustration, as I felt humiliated by my inability to fight, navigate, or make crucial decisions effectively.[/b]

[b]However, as I reached the 50-hour mark, a revelation dawned on me.[/b] The game is designed to be challenging and intricate, and therein lies its allure. The initial struggle became a driving force, compelling me to persevere and master the game's systems. [b]The wooden simplicity of the controls and mechanics faded into the background as I grew accustomed to them, allowing me to focus on exploring the rich, immersive world.[/b]

Delving deeper into the game, [b]I began to truly embody the role of Geralt of Rivia I felt his rage at the world, his complex relationship with Yennefer, and the weight of his quest to find Ciri.[/b] The narrative became a living, breathing experience, with each cutscene evoking genuine emotions—laughter at the witty banter and sorrow at the loss of loved ones. [b]The way Geralt's actions impacted the game world was particularly satisfying, as favors granted to various characters came full circle in the end.[/b]

The soundtrack deserves special mention for its ability to heighten every moment, from the smallest skirmish to the most pivotal plot twist. The characters' loyalty and interconnectedness added depth to the story, making my choices feel significant. Despite the initial shortcomings, these aspects overshadowed the early frustrations.

[b]After spending over 100 hours in the game, completing the main storyline and most side quests[/b], I can confidently say that [b]The Witcher 3's slow-paced development is a double-edged sword[/b]. It may deter new players with its gradual build-up, but it ultimately leads to a crescendo of non-stop action and engagement towards the end, making it hard to step away from the screen—a feeling I never experienced earlier in the game.

In conclusion, [b]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a testament to the rewards of perseverance. Its initial hurdles are daunting, but they give way to a profoundly rich and engaging experience that is well worth the effort.[/b] For those willing to push through the early struggles, the game offers an unparalleled journey filled with emotion, depth, and satisfaction.

author: {'steamid': '76561199154833724', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1159, 'playtime_at_review': 4702, 'last_played': 1736372375}
review:
Firstly, I came to know about The Witcher 3 this year through a very close person to me since I generally tend to watch him stream from time to time whenever he played and let me tell you that we were both amazed by this game.❤ 

However...  it was not until I purchased and played it for myself that I truly got to understand the beauty of it. Honestly, its a whole new experience to play it first-hand even having known most of the plot. 

The story is definitely simple yet compelling as well as even the side quests (which you should not skip -and i don't think you will do such a thing !), allowing the player to get a feel of a satisfaction somewhat similar to putting together jigsaw puzzle pieces, along with the bigger picture; the end result which is based off many decisions made along the way. 

I also could definitely not forget to appreciate the beauty of the landscapes. The open world exploration is massive and truly immersive, being able to investigate into this dark fantasy world 🌄🐺🌌 of the Witcher.

Lastly, I should mention that I did take a 3 month break due to not being in the mood (this is before I realized all of the points stated above properly as well) but I've returned and to my surprise, now I can definitely say that it's my favorite 💞 so in conclusion, please don't hesitate to play this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198070443142', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 11819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 563, 'playtime_at_review': 9053, 'last_played': 1736795110}
review:
[h1]Gwent Playing With a Side of Monster S-Mash[/h1]

[h2]A Visual Feast That’s Better Than Your Last Vacation Photos[/h2]

From the moment you boot up The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, it’s clear you’re in for a visual treat. The character models aren’t just well-crafted; they’re so expressive you might start questioning if they’re more emotionally available than your ex. And the landscapes? Oh boy, forget your last vacation photos because this game’s scenery makes them look like they were taken with a potato. You’ll find yourself stopping to admire the view so often that Geralt might as well get a side gig as a travel blogger.

[h2]Engaging Systems and Storyline That Make Netflix Binge-Worthy[/h2]

This game isn’t just a pretty face; it’s got brains too. The systems, from alchemy to combat, are designed to keep you on your toes. The storyline balances the grand scale of world politics with personal conflicts so well, you might start thinking about running for office just to have something this interesting in your life. You’ll be torn between chasing after your adopted daughter, Ciri, and diving into political intrigues so juicy they make House of Cards look like a high school student council meeting.

[h2]Combat: Like Dancing with Swords (But Less Graceful)[/h2]

Combat in The Witcher 3 is a dance, a deadly, monster-slaying dance. Geralt’s swordplay is swift and fluid, and with signs and potions in the mix, you’ll feel like a magical martial artist. However, gauging range in combat can be a bit like trying to swat a fly with a broomstick – sometimes you hit the mark, and sometimes you’re just flailing around like you’re at a rave. But when you do connect, oh, the satisfaction is real.

[h2]Weather: Beautiful but Barely There[/h2]

The dynamic weather in The Witcher 3 adds an atmospheric touch that’s as gorgeous as it is irrelevant. Sure, it’s fun to watch a storm roll in, but it could’ve done so much more. Imagine tracking a monster through a blizzard, where the wind isn’t just blowing your hair but your chances of survival. Alas, the weather is more like background noise – pretty but not really making much of a difference. It’s like having a sports car and only using it to drive to the grocery store. I hope it's getting obvious I'm grasping at straws here, trying to find drawbacks.

[h2]An End That Leaves You Wanting More (And Sobbing Uncontrollably)[/h2]

All jokes aside, the biggest downside of The Witcher 3? It ends. After countless hours of engrossing gameplay, rich storytelling, and memorable adventures, you’ll be left staring at the credits, wondering what to do with your life. The realization that your epic journey has a conclusion might have you bargaining with the gaming gods for just one more quest. But like all good things, it’s the journey that matters, even if you’re left with a void that only another replay can fill.

[h2]Verdict[/h2]

[b]Graphics: 10/10[/b]
So stunning, they might make you reconsider reality. Your eyes will thank you.

[b]Sound: 9.5/10[/b]
From epic soundtracks to immersive soundscapes, your ears are in for a treat. Just don’t start singing LELELELELE along in public.

[b]Gameplay: 9/10[/b]
Engaging and fluid, with just a touch of awkward flailing. Like a first date that goes surprisingly well.

[b]Story: 10/10[/b]
An engrossing narrative that’s better than most TV shows. Get ready to binge.

[b][u]Overall: 9.6/10[/u][/b]

[h2]Closing Thoughts: A Journey Worth Every Step (And Every Monster Guts)[/h2]

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt isn’t just a game; it’s an experience that will have you hooked from the first monster hunt to the final farewell. With its stunning visuals, deep story, and fluid combat, it sets a new standard for RPGs. Whether you’re a veteran witcher or a newcomer, this is one journey you’ll cherish. Prepare to lose yourself in a world where every choice matters and every monster has a backstory more interesting than your co-worker’s vacation slides. Just remember, the path of a witcher is tough, but oh so worth it. Get ready to dive in – just don’t forget to come up for air. Or snacks. Snacks are important.

author: {'steamid': '76561199068160938', 'num_games_owned': 59, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2758, 'last_played': 1735574142}
review:
Rarely does a game come along that redefines the benchmark for excellence, but The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt achieves just that. It's a monumental experience that sets the gold standard for storytelling, immersion, and depth.
From the very first moments, the world of the Continent has breathtaking scope and detail. The windswept hills of Skellige, exploring the bustling streets of Novigrad, or wandering the hauntingly desolate swamps of Velen, the environments are alive with stories waiting to be discovered. Every corner feels lovingly crafted, every location brimming with atmosphere, history, and purpose. Seriously the lore and world building in this game is nuts especially after you read the books it really makes you feel like you are actually living in the world that Andrzej Sapkowski created.
The storytelling is nothing short of extraordinary. At its core is Geralt of Rivia, a protagonist of unmatched complexity, navigating a world as morally ambiguous as it is beautiful. The main quest—a gripping tale of love, loss, and destiny—is complemented by side quests that could easily stand alone as highlights in lesser games. These aren't mere fetch tasks but richly woven narratives that deepen your connection to the world and its inhabitants. Characters like Ciri, Yennefer, and Triss are so vividly realized that they feel like real people, their emotions, motivations, and conflicts resonating long after you've put down the controller.
Visually, The Witcher 3 is a marvel. Even years after its release, the attention to detail in its landscapes, weather effects, and character designs remains unrivaled. Taking photos of these visual marvels is a big part of what i enjoy so much about this game. The sunsets over Toussaint, the shadowy interiors of monster lairs, and the way the light dances through a forest canopy are all testament to CD Projekt Red's commitment to creating an immersive experience.
And then there are the DLCs, which elevate the game to even greater heights. Hearts of Stone introduces one of the most chilling and enigmatic villain, while Blood and Wine is practically a standalone game in its own right. With its vibrant, fairy tale-inspired setting and a deeply personal story, Blood and Wine provides a fitting swan song for Geralt's journey, offering closure while still leaving you longing for more. And with the Witcher 4 being annouced im eagerly waiting for more news on that and am very excited to play it. This playthrough on steam was my 8th one and ill probably still play more and more i just never get bored of this game :).
The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt is not just the best RPG ever made—it is arguably the greatest game of all time. Its fusion of narrative brilliance, world-building, character depth, and visual splendor is unparalleled. It’s a title that transcends its medium, reminding us of the power of video games to tell profound stories and transport us to extraordinary worlds. If you haven’t played it yet, do yourself a favor and step into the boots of the White Wolf. You won’t regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199223082612', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 31127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28191, 'last_played': 1709824140}
review:
Title: The Witcher 3: A Masterpiece of Epic Proportions

Introduction:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a testament to the heights video game storytelling can reach. From its breathtaking visuals to its immersive world and intricate storyline, every facet of this game exudes excellence. With all DLCs and expansions, The Witcher 3 delivers an unforgettable experience that will linger in the minds of players long after the final credits roll.

Main Game: The Wild Hunt
In The Witcher 3's main storyline, players step into the shoes of Geralt of Rivia, a seasoned monster hunter, as he embarks on a quest to find his adopted daughter, Ciri, pursued by the otherworldly Wild Hunt. The narrative unfolds in a vast open world, filled with political intrigue, moral ambiguity, and unforgettable characters. From the war-torn landscapes of Velen to the bustling streets of Novigrad and the majestic vistas of Skellige, every corner of the world is meticulously crafted and teeming with life.

The main storyline is a rollercoaster of emotions, blending personal stakes with grand political machinations. Players will find themselves drawn into a web of alliances, betrayals, and unexpected twists as they unravel the mystery of Ciri's heritage and the true nature of the Wild Hunt. Along the way, the game presents players with meaningful choices that shape the world and characters around them, making every decision feel weighty and impactful.

The visual fidelity of The Witcher 3 is nothing short of breathtaking. From the haunting beauty of the haunted swamps to the awe-inspiring architecture of ancient ruins, every environment is rendered with painstaking detail. Character models are equally impressive, with lifelike animations and expressive faces that bring the inhabitants of the world to life. Whether exploring the bustling streets of Novigrad or navigating treacherous forests, the game's visuals never fail to impress.

Expansions:
Hearts of Stone
Hearts of Stone takes players on a dark and twisted journey into the heart of Temeria, where they encounter Gaunter O'Dimm, a mysterious and enigmatic character with a penchant for making Faustian bargains. The expansion introduces a new cast of memorable characters, including the tragic figure of Olgierd von Everec, whose tale of love and loss serves as the emotional core of the storyline.

With its intricate plotlines and morally ambiguous choices, Hearts of Stone offers a refreshing change of pace from the main game. Players will find themselves drawn into a world of deceit and betrayal, where nothing is as it seems and even the most noble intentions can lead to unforeseen consequences.

Blood and Wine
Blood and Wine transports players to the sun-drenched kingdom of Toussaint, a land of chivalry and honor, where they become embroiled in a mystery involving a series of gruesome murders. As Geralt delves deeper into the investigation, he uncovers a dark secret lurking beneath the surface of this seemingly idyllic paradise.

With its vibrant colors and picturesque landscapes, Blood and Wine offers a stark contrast to the grim and war-torn world of the main game. But beneath its facade of beauty lies a story of corruption and decay, as players navigate the treacherous politics of Toussaint and uncover the true nature of the monsters that haunt its streets.

Conclusion:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, along with its DLCs and expansions, stands as a crowning achievement in the world of video game storytelling. With its richly detailed world, compelling characters, and intricate plotlines, it offers an experience that is as emotionally resonant as it is intellectually stimulating. Whether you're a fan of epic fantasy or simply appreciate a well-crafted narrative, The Witcher 3 is a must-play experience that will leave you breathless from start to finish.

author: {'steamid': '76561199046891845', 'num_games_owned': 377, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 9105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9105, 'last_played': 1722681836}
review:
Imagine you're working in a 9-5 corporate job, you're done with your work, you come back home, log onto Steam, see your games list for 5 seconds, buy a game on sale that you're never going to play and then switch off your PC and go to a bar. While having a drink, you think of the good times when games used to be fun and authentic. But then you tell yourself, the problem isn't the games, its you. "Its not that games aren't fun anymore, you have gotten older".

And then I play Witcher 3. And suddenly I can't wait to get myself home after work. Do you have any idea how precious that feeling is ? The feeling that you are actually immersed in the protagonist' shoes. I find myself in anticipation and excitement for the new adventures that are waiting for me, I think while driving back home...."Where is this story headed ? What new places and characters I will meet ?" And lets not talk about the characters. I thought myself as a guy who's dead on the inside and somehow these characters made me laugh, chuckle and empathise at the same time. I haven't felt these feelings for a game since 2008 when I played games such as Final Fantasy 12, Metal Gear Solid 3. Was I wrong to think that I was the problem and not the gaming industry that's shelling out mediocre AAA games with no memorable characters or storyline ?

And I got this game for 3$. 3$ !! And that includes the DLC ! I honestly feel I looted these amazing devs. And I paid twice for games that are not even worth playing. 23 hours in and I still haven't scratched the surface of the story. The side quests are actually fun. I find myself doing the side quests more because its feels like I am watching another episode of the "Witcher 3 TV show". I love this open world, I actually take my time wandering around and exploring every nook and cranny. I haven't done this since GTA San Andreas. I look at some distant island or mountain that I find interesting and I decide to just walk there just for the fun of it. That's how beautiful this Open World this. This is Open World game done right.

Thank you CD Projekt Red. You guys are a gem. I know its 5 years late and I don't know why it took me 5 years to play this, but better late than never.

author: {'steamid': '76561199147468715', 'num_games_owned': 33, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4076, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2255, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1736613405}
review:
The Witcher 3 is an RPG masterpiece and undoubtedly one of the best games in history. Its gripping story, countless meaningful choices in dialogues, and a beautifully crafted world make every moment unforgettable.

The scale and beauty of the world inspire exploration, while side quests rival the depth of the main storyline. Every detail is imbued with love for storytelling and atmosphere.

For me, this is more than just a game—it’s an unforgettable adventure. If you haven’t played it yet, don’t miss out—you’re in for a legendary experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034476300', 'num_games_owned': 336, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 11210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11210, 'last_played': 1706463264}
review:
This game is nothing short of a masterpiece! The world you step into is vast, highly detailed and simply breathtaking. Every little nook and cranny have their part to play to make this a truly immersive experience. The attention to detail in the games design, from bustling cities to the tranquil countryside, is a feast for the eyes. Almost every house is fleshed out and not some empty or locked up set piece. Character models are intricately designed, and the monsters you encounter are both terrifying and awe-inspiring. The graphics, even years after the games release, continue to stand the test of time.

The storytelling in The Witcher 3 and its DLC's are among the best narratives out there. Filled with complex characters, choices that makes you question morality and each dialogue or action have their consequences that shapes your tale. Every corner of the map is teeming with quests, mysteries, and hidden treasures. The side quests are not distractions but are tied to the main story, offering players a chance to explore the depths of the world and its lore. Whether you're hunting mythical creatures or solving mysteries, every quest feels meaningful and contributes to the overall story of the game.

The combat system is both challenging, fun and really satisfying. Movements and fighting feels so fluid with a big variety of combat styles to suit everyone, from sword fighting, spells, ranged and potions allowing players to really strategize. It's a perfect balance between accessibility for newcomers and complexity for seasoned players.

The sound design and music is something truly special and deserve a big praise! The music is especially haunting combined with the atmospheric sounds and have a huge emotional impact on every moment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018404096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 51192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51192, 'last_played': 1720929780}
review:
Simply one of the greatest CRPGs ever made, Witcher 3 is the game that made Geralt of Rivia famous. There's not much to say about this that hasn't already been said. It's perennially at or near the top of multiple reviewers' "best ever" lists (including mine). Only the gameplay doesn't quite hold up to modern standards; the actual combat is easy and the enemies predictable. Don't expect a soulslike here. It's not a chore to play, but the real draws are the characters and the story.

Highly recommended to any fan of role-playing games.

author: {'steamid': '76561199239068638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 458, 'playtime_at_review': 5625, 'last_played': 1735680227}
review:
I've played this game for about 90 hours in the last 2 weeks and let me tell you, this is hands down one of the best games I've had the privilege of playing. Mind you I'm still not close to the end of the story even after sinking 90 hours into it, just made it to Skellige in fact, that alone should tell you about how rich this game is in terms of content. 

The story is great, the characters are wonderful, combat can be a bit lacking but it's not that bad, but my favorite thing about this game, by far, is Gwent - the card minigame. Nothing beats Gwent, it's definitely the best minigame I've ever played and experienced.

I've had this on my backlog for a while, didn't think it'd be as good of an experience especially after playing through Elden Ring and Sekiro, but my God I was wrong. The Witcher 3 gets a solid 10/10 from me. I will update this review once more after I finish the game. But either way, I highly recommend this game to anyone looking to pick up an open world RPG, TW3 is a fine masterpiece that everyone should experience at least once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125856246', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 22726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18626, 'last_played': 1732332708}
review:
Having had five major playthroughs of The Witcher 3 over the years, I cannot recommend this game enough for fans of open-world, "fantasy-realism" RPGs. The writing, voice acting and story quality are excellent and full of humour, the combat is fluid and satisfying and there is a strong level of excitement created by unlocking new gear and visiting new locations. The graphics have also always been top tier, kept up to date with Patch 4.0 and the inclusion of ray tracing and HDR. 

The Blood and Wine DLC is definitely the best DLC pack I have played for any game, ever. It offers more of the best aspects of the base game, with its own bright atmosphere and locations which have been lovingly crafted with great ambition.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992468185', 'num_games_owned': 982, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 36227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15259, 'last_played': 1735395245}
review:
[h3]A Masterpiece of Storytelling and Adventure: The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt[/h3]

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is not just a game; it's an extraordinary journey that transcends the boundaries of conventional gaming, weaving a tale that is both deeply personal and epically grand. From the moment you step into the boots of Geralt of Rivia, you are enveloped in a world that is as breathtakingly beautiful as it is richly detailed.

[b]Narrative Excellence[/b]
The story of The Witcher 3 is a tour de force of storytelling. It masterfully blends intricate plotlines with deep character development, making you care deeply about the fate of each character you encounter. Geralt’s quest to find his adopted daughter, Ciri, against the backdrop of a world ravaged by war and political intrigue, is compelling and emotionally resonant. Every decision you make has weight and consequence, ensuring that your journey is uniquely yours.

[b]Stunning Visuals[/b]
Visually, The Witcher 3 is a work of art. The world of the Continent is brought to life with stunning detail and vibrant colors. From the dense, mysterious forests of Velen to the bustling streets of Novigrad, every location is meticulously crafted and filled with life. The dynamic weather system and day-night cycle further enhance the immersion, making the world feel alive and ever-changing.

[b]Immersive Gameplay[/b]
The gameplay mechanics are equally impressive. Combat is fluid and satisfying, combining strategic planning with fast-paced action. Geralt's Witcher abilities, combined with a wide array of weapons and magic, allow for diverse combat styles that keep the gameplay fresh and exciting. The variety of quests, from the main story to side missions and monster contracts, are all crafted with care and provide a deep and rewarding experience.

[b]A Living, Breathing World[/b]
One of the game’s greatest achievements is its open world. The Witcher 3’s world is teeming with life and detail, filled with unique characters, each with their own stories and secrets. The attention to detail is staggering, making exploration a joy. Whether you are uncovering hidden treasures, solving intricate puzzles, or simply taking in the stunning landscapes, there is always something new to discover.

[b]Unforgettable Characters[/b]
The characters in The Witcher 3 are unforgettable. Geralt himself is a complex and nuanced protagonist, and the supporting cast is equally memorable. Yennefer, Triss, Ciri, and a host of other characters are all well-developed, each with their own unique personalities and arcs. The voice acting and writing are top-notch, bringing these characters to life in a way that few games achieve.

[b]Heartfelt Music[/b]
The musical score is another highlight, perfectly complementing the game’s tone and atmosphere. The hauntingly beautiful melodies stay with you long after you’ve put down the controller, enhancing the emotional impact of the story.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a masterpiece that sets a new standard for open-world RPGs. Its combination of a deeply engaging story, stunning visuals, immersive gameplay, and rich character development makes it an unforgettable experience. Whether you’re a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer, this game is a must-play that will leave a lasting impression. CD Projekt Red has crafted a game that is not just to be played, but to be experienced, and it stands as one of the greatest achievements in gaming history.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085194903', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 7373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7333, 'last_played': 1734110433}
review:
[b]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt[/b] is like "Game of Thrones" in an open world, where you play as Geralt of Rivia, a rugged witcher with two swords and a pocketful of sarcasm. Imagine this: magical lands, dangerous monsters, intrigues, and Geralt racing on his trusty Roach. Ready for adventures and monster hunting? Let's go!

[h3]Pros:[/h3]
[list]
    [*][b]Huge Open World[/b]: Explore dense forests, snowy mountains, and grim swamps. Something is always happening, and every corner is filled with details and stories.
    [*][b]Deep Storyline[/b]: The main story and numerous side quests are as high-quality as the main plot. There are political intrigues, personal dramas, and the search for the lost daughter, Ciri.
    [*][b]Combat System[/b]: Swords, magic, and alchemy. Fights with monsters and humans never get boring thanks to the variety of tactics and skills.
    [*][b]Characters[/b]: Charismatic and memorable characters, from Yennefer herself to the merchant selling rattlesnakes.
    [*][b]Choices and Consequences[/b]: Your decisions affect the world around you. Sometimes this leads to unpredictable and dramatic outcomes.
[/list]
[h3]Cons:[/h3]
[list]
    [*][b]Abundance of Content[/b]: The huge number of quests and activities can be overwhelming, especially for newcomers.
    [*][b]Controls[/b]: Sometimes controlling Geralt and Roach can be a bit cumbersome and cause some frustration.
    [*][b]Bugs[/b]: Despite numerous patches, the game can still suffer from various bugs.
    [*][b]Demanding on PC[/b]: The game can be demanding on hardware, and not every computer can handle it on high settings.
    [*][b]Dark Atmosphere[/b]: Constant wars, monsters, and grim stories can be depressing for some players.
[/list]
[h3]Expansion [b]Blood and Wine[/b]:[/h3]
[list]
    [*][b]New Region[/b]: Toussaint is a colorful and picturesque region reminiscent of southern France, full of new quests and adventures.
    [*][b]Castle[/b]: Geralt gets his own castle, which can be upgraded and decorated.
    [*][b]New Monsters and Quests[/b]: Many new monsters, quests, and storylines enrich the main plot.
    [*][b]Humor and Atmosphere[/b]: A lighter and more humorous atmosphere compared to the main game, adding variety.
[/list]

[b]Overall[/b], The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt with the Blood and Wine expansion is an epic adventure that takes your breath away and provides a wealth of emotions. Despite some shortcomings, the game offers a unique experience, a deep storyline, and unforgettable characters. Ready your swords and potions, and head into the Witcher's world for new exploits!

author: {'steamid': '76561197998864375', 'num_games_owned': 754, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 15152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14672, 'last_played': 1735349092}
review: The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is an exceptional RPG that excels in storytelling, gameplay, and world-building. Following Geralt of Rivia on his quest to find Ciri, the game delivers a rich narrative filled with complex characters and impactful choices. Combat is dynamic, blending swordplay, magic, and alchemy, while the vast, beautifully detailed world offers countless exploration opportunities and rewarding side quests. Visually stunning and accompanied by a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, the game creates a deeply immersive experience. Despite minor technical issues, The Witcher 3 stands out as a masterclass in the genre, making it a must-play for any RPG enthusiast.

review:
One of rpg's of all time...
This game is a masterpiece of art, and i know the formula of success...
CDPR were inspired by GOTHIC 3, when they were working on this game... otherwise they wouldn't do such a huge world filled with memorable characters and interesting quests (even though GOTHIC 3 clearly has more land to explore and more interesting quests). 
The only bad thing is combat... unlike GOTHIC 3, THE WITCHER 3 has a really poor combat system... there is no intense in fights... just spamming mouse 1... Spells are also quite useless.
GOOD WORK CDPR, YOU ALMOST DID IT... YOU ALMOST MADE A DECENT ADVERSARY FOR GOTHIC 3... BUT THERE IS STILL TOO MUCH WORK TO DO
