author: {'steamid': '76561198065623985', 'num_games_owned': 803, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 11594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11594, 'last_played': 1710455639}
review:
After 8 years I finally mustered the courage and time to play and complete this game. I had the time to play and read every game/book since, so I was able to get the full experience.
It added an extra something, but fear not, it is far from a necessity to enjoy the game (even if I recommend at least taking a glance).

After a long adventure, the big question you wish an answer to then appears: Was it worth it?
Yes, it was, however it's not a perfect game and I'll break down several of its aspects to elaborate my point.

Starting with the narration and story, it had some high highs and a fair consistency in quality all around. Every dialogue had production value, but it also creates an issue where you will spend a lot of time watching a film or it pushes you to skipreading (skip the line when you read it to keep the pace, quite frequent while going through voice acted visual novel games or segments).
There was care put into having a lot of details to influence with choices, even if it lacked some of the more meaningful ones due to most being self contained bits, in terms of major choices I think the second game was more interesting with some really difficult positions to cut on and strong characters(Foltest, Letho, Iorveth, Roche, even Henselt and more).
Despite all that, it's still quite solid and entertaining to go along, with the exception of the final chapters falling off, likely due to the dev time coming short and needing to cut plans.

Gwent is a major part of the game even as an optional minigame, and while it is a bit goofy to play against some characters at awkward timings, you never say no to a round of gwent. Honestly it would have been funny to defeat Caranthir in Gwent instead.
I came from having played the multiplayer Gwent and the spinoff witcher game based on it, so I was a veteran to the rules and that meant it was overall very easy to me. This version was quite apparent as the prototype with more basic mechanics and terribly unbalanced exploits but that didn't prevent it from being addictive, really hoping to get a new gwent game one day.
Would've been nice to have a better way to track card locations and not have missable cards.

For the other kind of battles, compared to the previous entries, there was a clear technical improvement and better strategy to employ with the various bestiary. Balance was likely set on the easier scale for sure, considering even in Death March I was completely broken despite restricting signs to only Yrden (and the other ones didn't look weaker) and not using bombs too much.
The roll distance was a bit annoying at times, and likely because backstep dodge is what you should use for most situations, but my souls brain is hardwired sadly, it did make me realize its potential though. I liked the various weaknesses to exploit against enemies, even if not all was accurate and some enemies' biggest weaknesses weren't even marked (or worse, the opposite where it tells you Yrden is effective against the Ofieri Mage when he negates it, or Igni against Archespores when they just go away if on fire).
Target lock is quite abysmal, and I just didn't bother using it. I wished it would show when your items are damaged earlier and not wait to be half broken to tell you the stats are worsened.

Speaking of gear, the crafting is in a strange place with alchemy being the most essential and fairly easy to ignore the rest aside the witcher school gear. 
There are a lot of ingredients needed and to find, which should tingle my fancy usually, but here it was so abundant everywhere, combined with shops that had literally everything related, the fun of crafting was reduced to hunting for specific monsters for that one ingredient.
In the end it was another upgrade system, and you didn't even get to craft things for your home in B&W, spending materials somewhere. Not exploited enough.

Although something was really benefited was the looting, this game is dangerous for looting addicts, and if you're not, you become one. The first thing you will think of in a new room after a cutscene is to rob the place. I will partly blame the witcher senses for that, it's too hard to resist when it's available.
There are probably too many spread out loot containers as well, so it becomes a grinding task for little reward, and too much time relying on witcher senses, both a blessing and a curse.
As I mentioned before however, extreme abundance and supermarket shops mean most of the looting is pointless and only accumulating barrel scraps even if you can't stop it at the end of the game. It's a bit funny and awkward that you can anger the guards from stealing, but 90% of the time it's just free to take.
This is probably the main aspect I wished higher difficulty would impact, reducing the abundance, making important crafts much harder to make.

Of course I can't mention the looting without exploration, the backbone of open world. It was a joy to find all the different places and interesting locations, especially supported by the side quests. There were problems hard to avoid though, the main one being that every point of interest had a marker and all the markers' positions were shown at once if you checked boards.
This made it too similar to ubisoft style open world exploration, and stopped being about finding interesting places and only traveling from one marker to another. Skellige being the biggest offender with a ton of pointless loot caches in the seas, cut down more than half and you don't lose anything.
It would have felt better if markers only appeared on the map after being found, and the radar detection being a more hidden/complicated reward to show a handful of spots you haven't seen.
Imagine if Skyrim showed you every location marker for each hold when you enter it, how different it would be. It doesn't even count the smaller spots as worthy of a marker, but it felt like Witcher 3 was afraid of you missing a single one.

The DLC deserve their own section because they're honestly incredible, and even fix (partially) some of the problems mentioned above. Hearts of Stone has easily the best, condensed, rich story of the game with colorful side characters and dreadful main ones (in a good sense). The rest is more standard, but that's still good content, my only regret would be that it's a bit too easy to [spoiler]want to save Olgierd because the devil is too sadistic in making people miserable, despite the responsibility involved. It lacks creepy ambiguity to the character.[/spoiler]
Blood and Wine meanwhile goes the whole Solstheim route and provides a full isolated landmass with all the content going with it. It goes the extra mile by adding a whole new gwent faction (my second favorite), many more new things and even mechanics.
The story and side quests were also quite great even coming out of HoS, I went for [spoiler]full tragedy this time because I felt it was irredeemable, intentionally not revealing something and it was an emotional delight to have the option to split the flowers[/spoiler]. It also completely eradicated the looting issue by cramming a lot into one-pack containers and severely reducing their amount, increasing yield for lower menial steps.
What it failed however, was the ubisoft exploration by having a lot of misc spots that you had to find, and while they tried to make it worth it with a neat story page or book each time, one each time was probably too much and I kinda stopped reading at a point.
It's fine to have misc spots without a story, just like we don't have to find every small point of interest, and I felt it made the exploration suffer when the landscape looked such a delight to wander in.

In conclusion, this was an incredible experience, I couldn't stop. And while I went in details for things that could've been better, it's a pale figure compared to what I enjoyed.
I'm really interested to see what will come out of the editor update, maybe experience even more grand adventures from other people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016870475', 'num_games_owned': 192, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 11767, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11767, 'last_played': 1713705226}
review:
The Witcher 3 is a mastercrafted game. If you take the time to read the books or notes you loot, or simply explore and do some side quests, you will realize just how dark and depressing some of them are. The combat system is not the game's strong suit, however it can be very fun, depending on the armor/talents you choose.  
Some choices bear heavy consequences and some not. Yet the game manages to make even the unimportant choices exciting. With little influence I got "the good ending" on both the base game and both expansions. There's many more one can say about this game. But in the end, one has to play it to see just how good it is. Recommended 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974475595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6687, 'last_played': 1710203823}
review:
Even on a first full playthrough 9 years after release this is one of the best games I've ever played. Maybe even my all time favourite.

The combat might be bland and clunky, the investigation mechanics basic, and there's a pretty limited set of meaningful decisions to make over its chunky runtime, but when everything else is so perfect I doubt you'll care. The writing, performances and visuals are nearly impeccable, and it has the most fully realised game world I have ever experienced. And somehow it all feels so effortless and natural. It never feels like its trying to hard to impress or surprise, and yet it did from the first scene to the last. Being Geralt in W3 is easily the coolest role i've ever played in a game. I only wish there was more of it to experience.

10/10 would repeatedly remind folks I am A Witcher again

author: {'steamid': '76561198042690571', 'num_games_owned': 1346, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 14746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6953, 'last_played': 1732111517}
review:
[h1]One of the greatest RPGs of all time[/h1]

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is an action-adventure RPG based on the prose by Andrzej Sapkowski. It follows the story of legendary monster slayer Geralt of Rivia as he travels the Continent and beyond in search of his and Yennefer's adopted daughter, Ciri. Set in a beautiful open world and backed up by great storytelling, this is a compelling singleplayer experience that any fan of video games should experience at least once.

[h2]On the run from the Hunt[/h2]

The main story of the Witcher 3 takes us through the quiet landscape of White Orchard, along the battle-ridden and destroyed land of Velen all the way to the pyres of Novigrad located within Redania. The path is long and the open world can be explored at will. Any village, outpost or cave Geralt enters can have something unique, which will be useful in the battle against the Wild Hunt.

[b]Positives:[/b]
+ Compelling storyline that stays true to its source material but never tries to intersect with it. It is a fitting final chapter in Geralt's story that should leave both fans of the novels and newcomers satisfied.
+ Characters are interesting and complex. Whether it is Geralt's true love Yennefer or his dear friend Dandelion, everyone feels in place in the game's story without ever straying too far from their novel origins.
+ Fantastic and rich open world that can be explored at will. The world is your main source of income, whether you accept a lucrative contract or decide to search deep within a cave for lost witcher diagrams, curiosity will always reward you with something, even if it takes your life in the process.
+ A complex combat system that is easy to learn but difficult to master. Playing on lower difficulties will allow you to pass combat encounters with ease, but crank it up to "Death March" and you will soon find out that picking the right swords, signs and oils will be the only way to come out of that encounter alive.
+ Character development is in a league of its own. There are so many possibilities for different playstyles, a huge number of abilities one can master to suit their own preferences. I personally had a lot of fun making my sign build.
+ An enormous amount of quests, contracts and tasks for the witcher to do. You can stumble on a simple contract requiring you to free up a village from a nasty monster or end up in a chain of side quests that sometimes take a few hours to complete.
+ Graphics, especially with the next-gen update are great and not too demanding even for weaker PCs. There is always the option to run the old-gen version as well, in the unlikely scenario where you are totally not able to run this one.
+ Music and ambient sounds are a joy to listen to, especially when exploring the Continent.
+ Gwent is a fun pastime once you have understood the rules and know how to play properly. There are a number of side quests and achievements that heavily focus on it though, which did get repetitive for me.

[b]Negatives:[/b]
- There are many issues during cutscenes. Most of the time the game does not unload peds around a cutscene trigger. That means that when you start a cutscene you will often have random NPCs doing goofy or buggy animations while you are trying to listen to important story elements. This is especially common for cutscenes in dense areas such as taverns or streets in Novigrad.
- There are many reused faces, which you will notice quite quickly if you do side quests. This does not apply to any of the important/story/unique characters, they all have their own detailed faces. NPCs, merchants, random quest givers are the ones that suffer from this. It can ruin the immersion!
- Gwent card collection is a bit of a pain to do, if you care for achievements that is. You can easily lock yourself out of the achievement by progressing further into the story and there is no way to go back, unless you have made a manual save prior to the quest that locked you out.

[b]Overall:[/b]
The main Witcher 3 game is a fantastic story-driven experience that pushes the limits of what RPGs can be. All of this, by the way, comes from someone who is neither much into RPGs nor into fantasy in general. That alone should tell you how impressive and great this game is. It is a pinnacle in singleplayer experiences and I would wholeheartedly recommend it even if it costed $70. These days you can grab the Complete Edition for something as low as $10 or $15.

[h2]Hearts of Stone[/h2]

This is the first expansion pack (not DLC) for The Witcher 3. It is an adaptation of a Polish folktale regarding the devil and the consequences of one's wish. Geralt's contact with a cursed nobleman, Olgierd von Everec, take him on a trip around Oxenfurt where he slowly learns what it means to have a heart of stone.

[b]Positive and negative points listed beneath the expansions are things specific only to them. Most of the points mentioned in the main game section also apply to the expansions as they are still part of the same package.[/b]

[b]Positives:[/b]
+ Fanstastic story that is my personal favorite in the whole game. It's full of deep heartbreaking moments but also some fun and even goofy ones as well (whoever plays it will know exactly what I mean).
+ Further expanded combat and character abilities. The runewright has some of the best armor enchantments in the game, provided you have the initial coin to set him up.
+ Some of the music, especially in the Painted World, is a great companion piece to a great quest.

[b]Negatives:[/b]
Nothing specific that isn't part of the main game's issues.

[b]Overall:[/b]
The Hearts of Stone expansion is my favorite part of The Witcher 3, specifically because of its story. With the further refined combat and character progression it is an absolute must that you play this too alongside the base game. The Complete Edition is your friend as it includes both expansions along with the main game.

[h2]Blood and Wine[/h2]

The second and final expansion of the Witcher 3 is a fitting send off for our protagonist. Geralt is taken to the region of Toussaint, a land of wine and love, where he has to undertake one of the biggest contacts of his life. The scale of this expansion is so large, almost the size of a separate project.

[b]Positive and negative points listed beneath the expansions are things specific only to them. Most of the points mentioned in the main game section also apply to the expansions as they are still part of the same package.[/b]

[b]Positives:[/b]
+ Great finale to our hero's journey. While the Hearts of Stone story is my favorite, you can't go wrong with any narrative arc in The Witcher 3.
+ Massive overhaul of character progression and combat in this expansion. New Witcher mutations for Geralt to play around with, grandmaster quality Witcher gear and dyes to look the part while slaying monsters and bandits.
+ Proper vineyard where our hero can rest, harvest plants and tend to his armor and weapons (I don't want to give out too much as this is part of the story).
+ Another great soundtrack, especially ambient music when traversing the pretty landscapes of this southern paradise.

[b]Negatives:[/b]
- Yet more Gwent card collection related quests. Unlike the base game, however, you can collect all cards of the new Skellige deck at any point during your playthrough.

[b]Overall:[/b]
The closing chapter in Geralt's journey is a satisfying ending to the Witcher trilogy. With its massive scale and overhaul of gameplay, this is another must-play for everyone who thinks of picking up the game. If it wasn't clear yet, the Complete Edition is what you want to purchase. All of the content is absolutely worth it if you want the full experience. The game goes on sale very frequently so you have no excuse to not pick it up.

[b]Thanks for reading this lengthy review and thanks to my friend for gifting me the game![/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561199140556395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1714320134}

author: {'steamid': '76561198192708117', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 729, 'last_played': 1706974713}
review:
I've tried twice with this game now and perhaps it's just not for me.
The controls feel clunky. Turning a horse around feels like you're trying to rotate a cruise ship.
The combat is horrible. Rolling around to avoid hits that tank half your health.
Healing with food and water takes longer than a slow work week.
Upgrading is very slow. Often you are outmatched by enemies just navigating to your next mission.

Execution is okay. The story line seemed okay but I'll not be going any further to know.
It's a no from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120433510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1683870552}
review:
This game feels like it's really good, story rich with an interesting world that has been given a lot of love. It is detailed and complex, lots of interesting characters and areas and monsters.

There's something off though, I just can't get into this game...

I know that's a terrible reason, but that has been my experience. I want to like it, and it really seems like something I should love! Every time I play I just feel so... meh.

The only thing that really stands out to me is how clunky the combat felt. Almost like a console game lazily ported to the PC. I don't think that's why I dislike the game though, as I've enjoyed some really clunky stuff in the past.

Objectively I see that this game is amazing in scope, story, and diversity of content. I think they definitely deserve the love and money they have received. Objectively, I recommend the game.

Unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game personally... and I wish I had a more specific reason than "dunno... didn't like it" but... I don't.

Do with this information as you will.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114737798', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 14525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8488, 'last_played': 1733002443}
review:
Great game, but doesn't deserve a 95% rating
AND it still has some issues, even after the next-gen update.
First of all, as you may have heard, it's a great game. But not because of the combat, gamepaly or the RPG elements, but because of the world, the story and feeling. And probably mainly because of some of the side quests, since the main story doesn't go anywhere for quite a while and is quite redundant 

But anyway, how about a few things that really aren't that great. a negative review should list the negative things after all, right? 
Well, the levelling system is... bad, levelling isn't fun and doesn't feel rewarding, especially because you don't just have to unlock the skill, you have to equip it, and you're very limited by that amount. There's even a single skill that changes the interactions in conservation that you have to equip in order to use it. The way it works means that you have to focus on a few skills, which severely limits the potential for variety. Oh, and you get way too strong for combat pretty quickly. This is why people recommend the harder modes, as it can get boring otherwise. I mean, I was able to kill a boss monster twice my level in 3 igi casts. it could not even move. on the second hardest mode. And the crossbow is useless. you only use it under water and to get down airborn enemies.  
also, the controls are really not meant for the keyboard. after 150 hours i still don't know how to switch between jogging and walking except on accident, same goes for heavy and fast attacks. sometimes you control the direction Roach goes with the mouse and camera angle, sometimes just with the keyboard.  
oh and there are bugs, in numbers that are impossible to ignore even after the next gen update/patch. nothing bad or game breaking MOST of the time, like loot disappearing after loading, NPCs stuck in an animation you can't interact with, merchants not having a marker, things not being visible (weird in cutscenes), Roach sporning in under water. Your inventory will fill up with quest items that you can't get rid of, even though the quests are already completed, and some of the quest items are no longer marked as essential. Some items were never marked as essential (mostly treasure maps) or are marked as essential even though they’re not special at all. Okay fine and all, BUT
I even have a bug that prevents me from finishing a quest. The trigger isn’t there, and it seems like the bug has always been there.
To me, this just feels like sloppy work.
But now I can understand where all the issues that Cyberpunk had, and still has, are coming from.
For instance, this game doesn’t really have any AI or system around theft. At first, you run around looting everything, even if the owner is standing right next to you. They won’t even complain or say anything. But then a guard will attack you for it. And after that you either stop looting random things or just keep gambling if a guard wants to stop you from stealing. Sometimes some guards attack while others just watch, sometimes they all attack, and sometimes they don’t care at all. No system behind it. It seems like some chests are marked as ‘theft if looted,’ while others aren’t, and they just used random ones without paying attention to which was which. Even when you start a fight, the NPCs hardly react. Just like in Cyberpunk, they only run away screaming for a few meters, although at least the animations here are better.

All in all, it’s still a great game, you’ll feel it, and it’s on its way to becoming a GOAT. But in the end, Witcher 2 was the better game; it’s a shame it didn’t get the same attention.

Also, a sign of not-so-good gameplay: less than half the player base even finished the prologue. 
So, watch out, so you won´t become one of them!

author: {'steamid': '76561197964769784', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 10696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10411, 'last_played': 1728952942}

author: {'steamid': '76561198084071196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 4632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4632, 'last_played': 1624294502}
review:
"The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" made me question which game people were talking about when I heard the sung praises and amazement from everyone I knew who had mentioned the game's title. Alas, the game truly isn't that bad. It's got a decent enough main story, though most of the fun can be experienced through the side quests you can undertake, which really give a sense of life to the world. From funny little NPC quests to the DLC side stories, I found it all very enjoyable to experience, accompanied by some good music and Geralt's silky smooth, gruff voice.

Sadly, the most important part of this game came up lacking for me, as the combat felt bland, repetitive, and easy. Even adjusting the difficulty just didn’t do it for me. The best thing about the gameplay is probably Gwent when used as a short acronym for "Gwent to hang myself of boredom," because slogging through this 50+ hour mess sadly isn’t worth it. The game has a lot of cool attempted mechanics for fighting monsters, making you try to make concoctions and tinker with your setup to fight them. However, this just feels completely unnecessary and skippable, as the combat is easily done without it, and collecting the ingredients feels like a bore.

Overall, this game is good when it's on sale for chump change and you have 50+ hours to waste anyway, but if you can, I'd advise just going elsewhere.

review: Really cool world and story to explore but movement on foot and horse feels bad and laggy. Combat also feels bad. to be more specific after playing action games like horizon forbidden west by guerilla, god of war by sony, and souls games by fromsoft enemy moves especially small dogs and drowners at the beginning of the game have very snap fast attacks. There is very little time to react , parrying feels very awkward i don't know how to explain, but cyberpunk 2077 melee combat felt infinitely better, so maybe those comparisons help.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084308128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1590, 'last_played': 1707083161}
review:
After over 40 hours (for some reason my total time isn't recording on the game I'm playing) I quit and uninstalled. I did side quests, Witcher quests, gave that up after I got through all the ones in Temeria, focused on the story only, then quit after we had to put on a play.

The game is just... find this person. Find this person, then find this person, find this person and help them find a different person before they help you find the person you're looking for, find this person but you can't find them until you find a different person, but you can't find them until you find yet a different person, and then once you find all the persons you're looking for, you gotta find a different person. When I told Priscilla we needed to find Dudu, she said we had to put on a play to find him. And I had to find Irina, and then from Irina I had to find people to spread the word of the play and then find other people to ush. Ushers, they call 'em.

It basically felt like Fetch Quest: The Game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198215893488', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1720382118}

author: {'steamid': '76561198294273511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4233, 'last_played': 1639783837}
review:
I typically find new games to find by reading peoples' recommendations online. People are very passionate about this game. They say the story and the gameplay and the world is brilliant.

I disagree with these people. 

The story and lore are two separate things. The story consists of the events that unfold in the game. The lore is background information that contributes to worldbuilding and backstories that make the world feel more convincing and alive. I need the story to be good for me to care about the lore. How am i supposed to care about what happened to the main character in the past if you can't get me to care about whats happening to him now? 

The story does not entice me at all. I love games that have tight emotional scripts that feel like long movies. They should have an internal conflict and a philosophical conflict paired with the external conflict. This game really only had an external conflict I felt. 

The game asks you to care for the main character who shows no personality at all. He has a recurring joke that he hates portals. That's it. That's the joke. And he says it several times during the story in a monotone voice and it is supposed to be funny.  

Aside from the story, the combat felt fun at the beginning, but after a few hours, i realized that all you had to do to win most battles was use 1 spell and spam attacks. Maybe i should have played on a harder difficulty, but i don't know. The combat system itself is flawed.

Some games make you care about the characters, have fun gameplay, have enticing stories, and leave me with something to think about afterwards. This game was not one of them. (I like stories of games like Last of us, Uncharted 4, The beginner's guide)

author: {'steamid': '76561198371528127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4254, 'last_played': 1734413529}
review:
i played this game for 50 hours only to realize how burnt out I was with all the extra side content I'd been doing. on paper, the story is interesting, and don't get me wrong, the main story line is perfectly fine, but when you're doing another monster hunt for another troll for another 200 coin reward you start to get numbed by the gameplay and the "open-world" nature of the game. the skill tree is for the most part useless (as someone who played on the hardest difficulty offered) because the game is already way too easy if you just spam Quen and never take damage (you literally never get punished).
this game would've been better as a linear story based game tbh

review: I'd rather drag my ***** through broken glass then continue with this boring game. I don't understand the hype. The combat is junk and boring. All the quests are fetch quests and uninteresting. The crafting and merchant system is god awful. The best thing about this game is GWENT, and its free without this terrible junk attached to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087845627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 8606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8425, 'last_played': 1716839830}
review:
The game itself is great, beautiful, fun, engaging, yada yada yada. CDpr ruined it though, they are seemingly incapable of bugtesting. I've having to constantly manipulate my graphics settings to negotiate the games rampant instability. Crashing very predictably at the same point (at the end of the Yenefer portion of the first cutscene) if i have raytracing turned on for example. Didn't used to be so bad, the next gen update seems to have introduced a lot of the issues.

It's frankly impressive that even 2 years after launching the next gen update, the game is still entirely unplayable with it installed. Can't go 5 minutes without crashing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045079346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1734889809}
review:
God, this is infuriating! I would love to tell you whether or not this game is fun. Sadly, there seems to be a pretty widespread issue with CD Project Red's Launcher. I quite literally can't play the game as a result. 
Does anyone else remember when developers made games you could play? I'm pretty Goddamn sick of needing to devote hours of time troubleshooting and researching just to play a video game. It seems they're more interested in selling me on future products than providing a working product here in the present. 
If anyone wants to crush my head like a bug, I'm game. Thanks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041952670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1726522252}
review:
More playtime on gog.

Honestly don't know why I thought to buy this again. Couldn't gel with it the first time through, no difference this time around. Originally made it to some point past the bloody baron, I think? Can't really be bothered to remember, story up to that point was pretty forgettable, and gameplay was middling at best. Only thing that really stands out in my memory is the city and villages actually being populated. Technically impressive, sure, but not much substance.

Look past the hype, and all you get are nice graphics and a bland cast.

author: {'steamid': '76561199188563828', 'num_games_owned': 25, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1710609009}
review: does not run well at all with proton. Had tons of issues with just starting a new game, where the opening cutscene just kinda stopped (on dx12). Then when I got to the game, I had sub 10 FPS on default settings. I refuse to get a gaming setup for a 9 year old game. can not recommend. Also, why do so many games make me use their launcher (this one didn't show my mouse for some reason) when I already use steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198376049594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 12057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12057, 'last_played': 1712010391}
review:
I was very dissapointed with The Witcher 3 after having played the previous games in the series.
In terms of the storytelling and gameplay depth, with preparations and what is supposed to make you "feel like a witcher" - it's just lackluster and dumbed down.

I get that those mechanics like potion auto refill are supposed to make it so it's not a chore after 50 hours, but combined with other things being like this to fit the game being open world and "rpg-ified" with shitty skill trees and huge amount of unnecessary loot in the shape of totally not unique swords and armour (better by just a few damage point, so you change your swords every few hours or don't bother at all) I found it just ridiculous.

Although the open world level design combined with the graphics and environments is - I'm pretty sure - one of the best in games ever.
It just feels real, especially Toussaint - the differences in elevation there, with all the colors and vegetation makes it look great from every spot and every angle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062633485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 5633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4932, 'last_played': 1734062062}
review: Fun, but also slowly becoming abandon-ware. There is a known issue with crashing on newer GPUs that has yet to be addressed. You can find threads online from over two years ago talking about this as well. With that being said, the game still holds up visually even today on max settings—if you can get it to run longer than 20mins...

author: {'steamid': '76561198818644292', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1716083561}
review:
I am sure this is a good game but I can't really get into it at all. I have tried 3 times but i always end up in the same place. I play for a while and lose all interest in it. The story seems intriguing but the game play is pretty tedious. Maybe mods could make this a much more enjoyable experience. I was playing it on Death march but it was still pretty easy, Geralts movement is extremely clunky which is bad when majority of the game is to go from a to b, The combat is really bare bones and just revolves around spamming the same attack over and over again and the endless cutscenes really get grating.

I really like the story so I will just read the books.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128773674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 8024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6657, 'last_played': 1712096830}
review:
How in the world was this game voted Game of the Year is beyond me. The controls are unresponsive, extremely laggy, Signs (magic), even though you are spamming them like crazy and the animation plays, are not cast. This is especially true for the Yrden spell and before you even realize the spell wasn't cast, you are at less than 50% health. Healing? Yeah, good one. The consumables heal so little you either get killed trying to evade your opponents, or wait ages for the health bar to fill back up.

The game crashes every now and then even though I have everything set to low, running at 144 FPS and have no problems running other high-end games.

Would never have bought this game had I known this was just another one of those graphics lag fests.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025939191', 'num_games_owned': 499, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1727103849}

author: {'steamid': '76561198072849590', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1836, 'last_played': 1561267973}
review:
Graphics, sound, and voice acting are top notch. The mood for almost every area felt unreal.

Unfortunately combat, progression, and some of the open-world elements just didn't click with me. The world felt almost too big at times and while some of the side quests were great, other felt pretty mid. Also a lot of weird dialogue and story choices that just seemed....unusual. I wish I could give a neutral vote instead of a thumbs down, but ultimately I will have to give it a thumbs down. Maybe I'll come back in the future and give it another chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089617521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 665, 'last_played': 1727718769}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018354777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4759, 'last_played': 1568724136}
review: Shallow gameplay, a fake open world and hours and hours and hours and hours of rambling. Some quests are good, but there's no real exploration to it. It's more like being told to ramble through the Windows 95 maze screensaver for a bit until you find an actual point of interest or quest amongst all the fake ones where bandits and dogs give you items worth 2c and give you 1xp when you slay them. The people who play this and think of it as a good game are the same people who can stomach visual novels. It's not a good game. It's a pretty good movie, perhaps, but drinking ale that does nothing and wandering around the land to participate in some contrived bareknuckled boxing league about as engaging as the same activity from Skyrim is NOT fun. Hunting 'the interesting bits' across the land and running into so much placeholder content (the aforementioned dogs and bandits and dogs and bandits) is NOT fun. There's something here, but as a fantasy RPG enthusiast, I found myself bored to tears. I gave it just under 80 hours, and yes I dug into the backlore, not a bit of which I can remember because it's dull as dirt. Again, quests involving actual monsters are actually preddi gud, but so much of the game is just a frustrating walking simulator with empty minigames to break it up. Items you make via crafting are barely worth making, magic is barely worth using and the core combat is just 'press button to dodge press other button to hit'. Skyrim had better combat than this. Before anyone starts moaning that magic is necessary, yes, it is, but necessary =|= good. If your magic only exists to hard counter particular beasts, it's just a 'press button to continue fight' mechanic not much different from a bloody quick time event.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023136999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1734689325}
review:
This is really not that interesting of a game, maybe if I had played it when it came out it would have had a different affect on me. I always had a concept of Geralt's character through general internet references, but never imagined him to be this dorky and kind of desperate, where it doesn't fit the stoic demeanor or voice. Him and Vesimeer cleared a bar full of thugs and it didn't look right. 
It's funny that this game has read so far in it's 6 hours as just fanfic bait. He's Fabio for the redditor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160007024', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 1410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1410, 'last_played': 1712993581}
review:
Ok so I'll agree it is a good game but for me personally I have tried again and again and I just cant get into it. To start, there is waaaaaay too much overly descriptive dialog, its almost as if they just pulled paragraphs straight out of the books. That would be fine to a certain extent for things like for side quests but I just don't need to know in descriptive detail about everything when they could have just shown it to me. Other than that I think the pacing is too long and drown out, it just feels like there is more dialog than game here.
Overall I can see why people like this but for me, I need things to get to the point a little faster.
If I ever return to the Witcher 3 and or its franchise and it finally hooks me ill update this review but as of now i doubt anything about this series will ever captivate me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081151182', 'num_games_owned': 84, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1642636637}
review: I have tried to give this game a chance several times on multiple platforms. I always come to the same conclusion. It is simply the most overrated game of all time. Combat is uninspired. They just threw every mechanic possible into it for a game of this style and didnt polish a single one of them. This game is supposed to look amazing not only for 2015 but even now but its not AMAZING. Its simply was just pretty good for its time. Not saying its bad just not exceptional for the time like people say. Another thing that I have seen praise for are the facial animations. Once again im rating this as if it is 2015. They are just good nothing special they look like any other game at the time. The story pulled me in at the start but sadly did not refresh this feeling quick enough for me as it was the only thing keeping me on the game. What reason would I have to play a game where the combat is generic and not interesting and the story isn't captivating consistently enough? that's right none at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042773264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2955, 'last_played': 1625586222}
review:
I can't bring myself to like it. It's one of those massively overhyped games that have little substance and make you travel ungodly amounts of time for some wacky piece of dialogue that you'll never remember, but (and that's more likely) you're just opening the map to cruise from one point of interest to the next, because the game is telling you something is waiting for you there.

If you allow a personal comment: 
Welcome to Polish Ubisoft.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008728734', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 777, 'last_played': 1711065383}
review:
It's quite... tiresome adventure to play and one of those cases where I wish that games had a "neutral" grading on steam - because it deserves it instead of negative one.
On a surface level game is fine until one starts to look more closely into the nature of things.

First and foremost, I want to blast progression system. It's just bad to the point, where it's almost redundant to have. Since players cannot re-define what Witcher is, choices on shaping the playstyle are very limited and it comes to one of three designs - build based on attacks and combat mechanics, build based on the usage of cooldowns of the 5 spells you have or consumable-based build that relies on alchemy part of the game - and this assuming one won't hybrydize it at some point. So basically you always play the same.

Then it comes the aspect of exploration, that is mandatory and not at the same time. It's personal prefference if one likes 3000 map markers that lead them everywhere. Recipes, money and materials are things that might not be obligatory, but power-ups from Places of Power are - and if you're playing blind you have to waltz through most of the stuff to find them. I was getting tired of it after White Orchards, couldn't get assed to seek them later. This exploration doesn't spark any curiosity, it's just a map marker chase to get that 30/30 objectives done.

Economy is another issue I have with the game. Money is worth something, that's good. However, the plethora of money-sinks is just funny if one thinks about it. Gear breaking after few encounters, drop hundred coins to repair it. Want to craft something? Disasemble stuff, it costs. Then for crafting you pay something more. Wrong Blacksmith? Seek another one. Sometimes even number of quests don't pay the price of repair and ever-present nibbling on players pocket basically encourage to either not buy a thing, cheese money, grith teeth and play until it ceases to be the problem or run the side-objectives on the map.

Lastly, music and sound design. It's good, the score is good... until one has to listen to it in the game during few hours session. The morose melodies that game blasts at player are so goddamn draining that i just welcome ANY change to the track that game has to offer. The combat music is upbeat and cheerful in comparison to what exploration music offers - and horse race theme is like a choir of angels in the depresing world of the game. I mean, I've read all the books from the witcher series, back in 2008 and while world in it wasn't the most cheerful place - it didn't looked that bad. 

Probably I'll play it more after the review to finish it just to be done with it and never touch again - but I don't think it's gonna be any better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198274770993', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1732077193}
review: game lags super hard when going into inventory or looting corpses. 10-15 sec lag after dialog and sometimes game freezes. game was running fine about a year ago but after revisiting game, its now unplayable. sucks because i really enjoyed this game. probably wont be playing again till they fix the issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561199435575528', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2021, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1051, 'last_played': 1712736442}

This is after all the updates and patches so im probably not going to finish it, its too frustrating. Sometimes it crashes ingame other times it crashes on loading screen, but its at least twice an hour, m.2 harddrive, 17 13th gen cpu, 32 gig ram and a 4080 super graphics card, windows 11 and most recent NVIDIA drivers, When it works, it works, it just doesn't work for that long!

author: {'steamid': '76561199486105408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1785, 'last_played': 1728960361}
review: More fun to watch someone else play, Story and graphics are great, combat is a redundant and boring, saving is disabled in places it shouldn't be and the game forces you to watch a recap video every time you reload, save yourself the money and the trouble by watching someone else slog through it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156624177', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 77, 'playtime_at_review': 1760, 'last_played': 1736382600}
review: After six times of really trying to get into the game, I can finally say that I did not like this game. From the clunky controls to the amount freaking dialogues, it can get pretty tiring and boring. I hate ABSOLUTELY hate the music in this game. THERE IS CONSTANT MUSIC NO MATTER WHAT YOU ARE DOING. Exploring and enjoying the scenery? Music. Trying to find clues and piece together puzzles? Music. TALKING TO NPC's ABOUT SERIOUS MATTERS? MUSIC. Completely breaks the immersion. Other games would mute or pick an appropriate background music depending on the scenario. If it's an emotional moment, there shouldn't be music in the background. But this game just doesn't care what you're doing, there's always that annoying background music.

author: {'steamid': '76561199030501782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 8373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1716689156}
review:
Look. Bloodborne, Last of Us (first) and Witcher 3 are my TOP favorite games. No order, cannot be done with me. That being said, CD have done a world first for my library, completely broken a finished product. Crashes basically guaranteed every. single. play session. If you tab out for a second, crash. Load a game, crash. Eat too much food, crash. Also, enjoy the visual bugs, every play through, guaranteed. So many new bugs too. Camera zooming in and out on its own non-stop. Had to load the game to make it stop. Unreal people get paid more than me to do this to their own product. 

On everything, I am not even excited for whatever CD is cooking up. Next time they "NeXt-gEn" patch any game, beg them to leave it alone. This is insane. Search the internet, and by that I mean throw in DuckDuckGo / Google, "Witcher 3 next gen bugs / errors / crashes", to verify what I mean. It truly should be illegal to break a finished product and be allowed to walk away AFTER money is spent. This needs to change in the world. And for the record I HATE thumbs down, but it is too much. 

Good luck if you get it.

Update 
In the time played (50Hrs), I have sent probably 20/30 crash reports. I wonder if they'll be addressed? I also hear Toussaint still has a shadow flicker bug? I really hope that is not true. I replay to get to the DLCs... I like the main story, but I love the DLCs. Time will tell. 

Update
DLC intensifies crashes....

Update
In Toussaint now. Crashes are non existent, so far. I do see graphical errors here and there. Seems better.

review: Somehow it was less buggy 8 years ago. I played the base game in 2016/17 and loved it and have recently gotten back on the game to play the DLC's I never got to. Cross air on the screen when just playing normally, Crossbow not being equippable on a mission that requires a cross bow to shoot an apple on someones head,  and somehow getting a graphics bug something with the matrix transformations that stops me from moving  to be reloaded 30 minutes behind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198248830006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1720420045}
review:
I really went into this game with higher expectations. Someone else summed it up perfectly with another word: 'janky'. Combat mechanics are very imprecise and finicky. Perhaps I've been spoiled by RDR2, but horse riding in this game is genuinely unbearable. QOL in general is lacking with repetitive NPC dialogue as well (heard the same voice line 3 times, from 3 different NPCs in less than 15 seconds, not an exaggeration).

The default controls are not intuitive to say the least (coming from primarily FPS player, albeit), and the menu is not great. Not to mention that you will literally have to choose between no tutorials at all, and clicking through 10+ consecutive tutorial windows at a time.

author: {'steamid': '76561199074037886', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1708625661}
review:
I wish I could get my money back for this game. It is MASSIVELY overhyped. I've attempted it 3 times now, once on switch and twice on PC. Using a 4090 to crank the graphics settings, I'm still unimpressed with how this game looks - even in 4K. That aside, the world feels so sterile, its incredibly difficult to interact with anything. The game doesn't reward exploration and just sort of expects you to follow a pre-determined path. The mechanics and menus are cumbersome. Why do I have to open 3 menus just to heal my character? Combat is repetitive and just gives me no incentive to keep trying at a boss because I'm not having fun. Even basic traversal feels like a chore and riding your horse is even worse. I'm not even impressed with the voice acting, I'm actually sick of Geralt's little quips especially when talking to Roach. 

All around a sub-par experience, I don't understand why its still so highly regarded. Don't waste your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995807255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 24166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20518, 'last_played': 1714214539}
review: I've bought 2 copies of this game and played it for hundreds of hours. I have no problem with the quality of the game. It's a good game. The problem I have is with the company itself. They have gone full DEI in recent years. There is many years of evidence, videos and webpages of them pitching themselves as a DEI compliant company. I cannot condone giving them more money until this practice is abolished.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051197027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2482, 'last_played': 1721487955}
review: I cannot bring myself to play this game anymore. I tried to enjoy it(I really did) but just like TW2 the story is boring, the characters suck, the combat equates to button mashing, and it just feels like a giant waste of time. I loved the original Witcher game. It had a semblance of character/intrigue and while it certainly lacked in the combat department it was still light-years more engaging and fun than whatever the combat system is in TW2/TW3. At least in the original you had to aim to hit what you were wanting to attack. In the sequels when you press the attack button while facing away from an enemy you will do a backflip-aerial-gainer(Squirrel style) and while Geralt is flipping around like a gymnast he will pull out his sword, auto-target the nearest enemy, and slash them. No need to use the joystick to point in any meaningful direction. Just mash the attack button and you are good to go. Sure the Witcher series has some saucy scenes but this is not the type of game you should be able to play one handed. It makes me sad that so many revere this game as AMAZING, when it really kind of just sucks. Am I the crazy one? Maybe I have trash taste but regardless I cannot bring myself to finish this thing. If you enjoyed it good on you for your higher tolerance of wasting time than I. That is all.

author: {'steamid': '76561199216689312', 'num_games_owned': 37, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1735364116}
review: there are a lot of restrictions that kinda take the fun out of it, or mechanics that don't make sense. like if you go into this thinking its even remotely like skyrim you're gonna be very disappointed, looting is not fun since there isn't any consequences, guards don't get called and if you kill them after the most dragged out boring combat you're rewarded with nothing but a "thank god that's over" feeling. the weapons all look too similar, and play the same so 90% of the game feels repetitive, interrupted by cutscenes that rely on nudity to grab your attention. i feel like all this game has going for it is the scenery and some random side quests. more importantly this game serves as a nice annual reminder when i download it that other better games exist and i should play those instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198392770418', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 4296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4296, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 1124, 'last_played': 1735390170}
review: This game fucking sucks. First of all, the combat system is ass. The dodge has so fucking many iframes you can just mindlessly spam it wand no one will ever hit you. I was playing on hard difficulty and it still felt like a child's play, you can trivialize it EVEN more with queen. There's a whole potions and oils system to prevent taking some types of damage but why the hell would you need it if you can just trivialize the game from the beginning, the game literally gives those 2 mechanics from the start. Second thing, the skill tree doesn't matter at all. It's very linear and does not provide player with any visible difference in gameplay, at some point in the game I even stopped investing my points in it because it was just a waste of time. Third thing, whoever thinks that this excretion of a game is an RPG is far from the truth. For me an RPG is a game where you should be able to create your character or at least be able to change its story, you should also have many ways to play the game. But in the Witcher 3, you have an already existing character with a story you can not change and basically one play style. Yeah sure you can play naked without weapons and call it a different playstyle but it's not, it still is pressing 2 buttons. To sum it up, this "game" is not worth a single second in your life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198174992029', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 21497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21497, 'last_played': 1714757455}
review:
The CPU performance with RT is somehow worse than Cyberpunk with PT. Even after patches the performance is horrible.

CDPR [url=https://cdn-l-mkt.cdprojektred.com/image/TW3NG_requirements_table_16x9_EN_ilortqjlts4spa8e.png]officially recommends[/url] Ryzen 5 3700X for ultra(All RT feature enabled) settings, however 5700X which is superior to 3700X is unable to reach 60fps in CPU bound scenarios.


[h3] The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt Next Gen : RTX 3060 + RYZEN 7 5700X : 1080p / 1440p [/h3] 
https://youtu.be/AoC9YOZjMhM?t=688

If you have older PC I highly recommend you to play the older version(1.32) instead. Even at the same settings the next-gen version performs significantly worse.

[h3] The Witcher 3 Next Gen Update vs Patch 1.32 - Perfomance Test | 3060 Ti | i5-13600KF | 1080p [/h3] 
https://youtu.be/-RGq2e6xxl4?t=93

Also note that the shadow is broken in the next-gen version and Dx11 performs better than Dx12, so If you are not interested in RT features use Dx11.

[h3] The Witcher 3 Next-gen 4.04 and 4.03: Shadows are broken, downgraded [/h3]
https://youtu.be/UpFsP3ytT0I?t=166

[h3] The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt V4.04 Patch: FPS Test on RX 580 DX11 vs DX12 Comparison [/h3]

https://youtu.be/SSs4dI0G_N8?t=65

author: {'steamid': '76561199056858489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1038, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1038, 'last_played': 1733660834}
review:
I'm surprised that I don't like this game, but I just don't. It did not spark any joy or excitement in me. It has very repetitive & tedious elements that get in the way of gameplay & progression. What do I mean? 

1) The large number of unnecessary items that are collectible. Having to deal with sorting through the mostly useless junk & weapons you collect.

2) Every mission is go talk to this person then kill something/someone then talk to this other person and do it again & again, I never feel like I'm making progress. You're always being set on sopme wild goose chase to find someone or something, I find in most cases it is purely for the sake of lengthening quests, to appear like there is more content.

3) You'll always have to go back to blacksmith frequently to repair your swords which lose durability pretty quickly, particularly the monster killing silver sword, since it's hard to find others of its kind in the world compared to the regular steel sword. This does nothing but get in the way of progress & discourage engaging with combat, which should be a fun & exciting aspect of the game. This is especially true given that blacksmiths can only be found in certain towns, not all of them. These 3 points explain the game loop, which is going on quests, always having to frequently comeback to the same area in order to access the blacksmith & sell the plethora of junk you probably collected on your small adventure & do it again.

4) The controls are clunky, absolutely terrible. Combat, & just generally moving doesn't feel fun. I'm very sure that I wouldn't have been bothered by my 2nd point if atleast the combat & movement was fun, but it ain't.

What I would prefer for this game, would be a significantly better movement system, including animations & responsiveness. A reduction in the number of items that are collectible in the world, & needing to frequent the blacksmith & towns less, which just ruins the momentum of exploration. As great as the story is, if the gameplay sucks, it's still a lame experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977259007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 995, 'last_played': 1712883101}
review:
I bought into the hype. Well, for only $10. I'm glad I didn't spend more than that but I wish I would have been able to save my time as well. I'm sure its a fun game for many, the reviews seem to indicate as such. But for me, as other negative reviews do point out, it has too many issues or things that make it not fun for me. 

Positives: There is a good story in there with some good acting. The world is rich and beautiful and big.

Negatives: Combat sucks. I was playing on easy mode and still getting hammered and dying without having a chance to figure out what I was fighting and what I needed to do. Yeah, there's a skill issue, hence playing easy mode, but also I don't have time for trial and error gameplay because I'm an adult with limited time. That's beside the point though, since it was a pain in the arse to assign skills and stuff, blocking/parrying was about useless half the time, and movement was like wading through molasses in January. And so much dialogue. I don't know that I was actually playing much or just button pressing through dialogue. The pacing is off. Side quests didn't seem to well with the main quest, meaning you have to do a bunch of backtracking. And be careful about running into higher level mobs when exploring. Loot so far is well below expectations too. Nothing compelling. 

Gosh, there is just so much I don't like but I really wanted to like this game. There is good lore there. But I just can't slog through it. I played through Assassin's Creed Odyssey recently and really enjoyed that game. I wanted to like Valhalla and couldn't. And I didn't want to spend money on Mirage knowing things were kind of mixed. So, I was kind of hoping this game would scratch that itch. It's close, but still leaves me scratching. 

In the end, movement and combat overall could have been better. Story pacing and leveling could be improved.But mostly it was feeling like I was playing the story/dialogue parts more than the actually game parts. Like fetch quests that get old, this was a lot of going here to talk this person for 10 minutes then come back and doing again for another 5 minutes after you spent 2 minutes killing something.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022310747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 11922, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10911, 'last_played': 1715581954}
review:
If you're giving it a try because of the new show.

Be aware the game is almost 14 years old, don't expect it to "just work". PC gaming means you can go back and play older titles where the console players have to source down the disk/ backwards compatibility. This benefit also comes with its problems, such as older games not cooperating. 

Take the 30 minutes and read into 'Viva New Vegas', its easy and designed to be beginner friendly. It comes highly recommended
https://vivanewvegas.moddinglinked.com/

If that looks too complicated, you can try simpler guides such as this one 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2373580270

If you're still looking for something easier, then at the very minimum look into:
xNVSE, FNV 4GB Patcher, NVTF, Yukichigai Unofficial Patch

Fallout New Vegas is worth it

bonus:
Gopher has a video installing "Stable New Vegas" using Nexus collection feature
https://youtu.be/kZenIegk1-E?si=-SLFiS4ZQ4peatbL

author: {'steamid': '76561198072542853', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 245, 'playtime_forever': 8097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8097, 'last_played': 1735461077}
review:
This is one of the best RPGs of all time and probably the best game in the Fallout series.  After 14 years, playing the game today still gives a great experience, although encountered crashing a pack of times.  

The story is rich and explorable areas are huge.  After 100 hours into the game, I still have lots of areas haven't been to and many quests not experienced.  Most of the quests have multiple ways to handle and there are consequences.  Followers could take action without your instruction so beware.  

The combat system is quite unique.  You can play either as FPS / action game or strategic game.  Both are viable.  

Achievements are overall very doable.  GRA achievements and collection related achievements are probably the most difficult ones.  Hardcore mode is more tedious so better to do hardcore in the second run.

Overall this is a must play for single player who love story rich games.

author: {'steamid': '76561199165424186', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 39, 'playtime_at_review': 4858, 'last_played': 1735953275}
review:
Decide to replay the game with mods (including a weather mod)
Sandstorm starts
Decide to wait out the sandstorm in a nearby cave
The cave has a creepy vault entrance
I go into the vault and its completely empty with the exception of a couple enemy creatures
Decide to look deeper into the story of the vault
Find out a gruesome story about how every year the vault residents had to offer a sacrifice or else everyone would be killed
Decide to dig deeper
Find out that this vault was a social experiment and if there wasn't a sacrifice nothing would happen
Only 5 residents actually survived to find this out
Quickly run outside the vault after finding out this insanely gruesome story
Sandstorm is over

10/10 storytelling

author: {'steamid': '76561198282250333', 'num_games_owned': 372, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 15109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13683, 'last_played': 1724409262}
review:
Overall: 9/10

Okay, right off the bat, I believe Fallout: New Vegas is not just the best modern Fallout game, but also one of the best RPG's of all time. Graphically, New Vegas definitely appears to have aged like milk, but if you can remember, the graphics were pretty dated when the game initially launched. Despite this, the world, unique characters, lore rich narrative, several endings for main and side quests, focus on player agency, etc. all keep players both new and old playing, even 14 years later. New Vegas is one of the most prime examples of an RPG game done almost perfectly, at least in regard to narrative. The range of possible ways that you can solve all kinds of different quest is pretty insane sometimes, and you can literally see the end credits without killing a single person.
The biggest gripes I hear about New Vegas in 2024 is the graphics and general jank of the engine. While it doesn't excuse it, if you know anything about the development of New Vegas, then you should know that it at least partially explains why things are as they are. This would of course be a more significant problem if Fallout: New Vegas didn't have such amazing mod support. There are mods and mod packs that do everything from patching the most basic issues, all the way to completely overhauling the game, bringing the gameplay to the same quality of the astounding story. Regardless of whether you think you might have a preference for a vanilla or a 500+ mods New Vegas playthrough, the story and dense activity within this wasteland is simply one that must be experienced by EVERYONE!

TL;DR:

New Vegas is one of the greatest RPG's of all time, and despite being graphically unimpressive, the narrative and game world make up for it tenfold, with or without mods. Absolutely Recommend

author: {'steamid': '76561197998920808', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 17674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16062, 'last_played': 1730579304}

author: {'steamid': '76561198868209067', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 11860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11860, 'last_played': 1728518849}
review: After receiving years of taunts and humiliations from New Vegas fans whenever I brought up how much I enjoyed Fallout 4, I finally worked up the courage to give New Vegas a try. I don't even need to explain how good the game is when there are so many "good game is good and here's why" videos on New Vegas. However, the game is a bit old and requires some tinkering for a smooth experience. I recommend checking out Viva New Vegas modding guide if you are familiar with modding tools.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044602606', 'num_games_owned': 7837, 'num_reviews': 711, 'playtime_forever': 4338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4338, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 4289, 'last_played': 1714698777}
review:
Alright. [i]Fallout New Vegas[/i] is done and dusted. This is IDK...maybe the tenth time I've played through the base game and probably sixth or seventh time completing all the DLC as well. First time not on console though. This run took a bit over seventy hours with all major content completed and probably half of the side content.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3236525370

Stability is going to be a factor for most people playing this game, so I thought I'd talk about my experience having played this exclusively on the Steam Deck with no mods. FPS on maxed settings was consistently around 60. There were no instances of stuttering. On occasion, while in VATS, the game would freeze for a couple seconds, and during the endgame, it crashed twice during area transitions. The DLC crashed a bit more, but I detailed that in the reviews I previously wrote for each.

So all in all, performance was shockingly great. It was definitely a bug ridden mess on console, and I understand it hasn't responded well to newer PC rigs either, but New Vegas seems well suited to being played through Proton.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3231241948

As far as the actual game experience, it still held up perfectly well. It's a game that despite having aged significantly, still looks great, plays great, and sounds great. In many ways, this is still superior to plenty of modern era games.

Which isn't to say it is without issues. Depending on the order in which you complete quests, the dialogue might still assume you are in an earlier stage of the game, and with so many different things possible, the game does get confused by player actions at times. That's one of the more notable issues. Also, the open world traversal isn't always seamless. Sometimes for example, you can be on just the other side of a ridge from an area or objective, but you can't go over the ridge. Instead, you have to trek all the way around lol.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3237381639

Regardless of the above though, most of the systems in the game compliment each other and work well even today. I'd guess this game still has quite a number of years of life left in it. You might have to work to get it running, but once you do, it's a quality game that deserves to be experienced by everyone. It's a true and legendary piece of gaming history. Do yourself a favor and buy the Ultimate Edition though rather than buying the DLC separate, if you don't already own it. It's a huge step up from the base game version as far as content available.

[code]If you found this review helpful and would be interested in supporting my Curator group, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32549618/]Robilar's Reviews[/url], it would be appreciated. Cheers.[/code]

author: {'steamid': '76561198072690595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 11032, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 4, 'playtime_at_review': 7599, 'last_played': 1736116221}
review: do a full vanilla playthrough on very hard and your hairline will noticeably recede

author: {'steamid': '76561198041364613', 'num_games_owned': 265, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5074, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5074, 'last_played': 1693371607}
review:
One of the most engrossing games I've ever played, but... Weirdly enough, it really shouldn't be. There is so much jankiness embedded deep into the game itself. You may crash at any given moment (SAVE OFTEN), gunplay is better than 3 but still so weird to handle at times, the dialogue can get either corny as hell or edgy as hell, but it all just works. It comes together greatly as this hot mess that I cannot put down once I decide to play through again.

It is an absolute miracle that this game is as good as it is considering its development circumstances. It triumphs over releases that have had over 7 years in the oven (a certain Field of Stars). Give it a try. If the price tag of 10 buckaroos is too much, it usually goes on sale for at least 5, but I say spring for the Ultimate Edition, cause some of the DLC is actually pretty good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056322384', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11548, 'last_played': 1728490327}
review: I can’t believe I waited until 2024 to play this game! It’s one of the best open world RPGs I’ve ever played. I’ve played it started to finish multiple times (trying out the different endings) and I can see myself playing it again in the future! It takes you through many different emotions and you can play it as lax or serious as you want. I highly recommend downloading the Viva New Vegas mod for it as it updates parts of the game to run better and enhance it. But wow - what a game. Can only hope another game with this quality will be made one day!

author: {'steamid': '76561198869280801', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 16294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 233, 'playtime_at_review': 15658, 'deck_playtime_at_review': 1, 'last_played': 1735795029}
review:
[h1] The definitive Fallout experience: [/h1]
If you're looking to get into the franchise for the first time, or are already a fan of the franchise but haven't given New Vegas a go, I would highly recommend this game. For example if you've only ever played the classic games, this game acts as an almost direct sequel to fallout 2, taking some characters and plot threads from that game, and expanding upon them here as a sort of finale to the west coast chapter of this franchise. If you're a Fallout 3 fan, and want to experience West Coast fallout, but can't quite get into the isometric games, Fallout New Vegas has you covered since it runs on the same engine and has the same mechanics as Fallout 3. If you're a fan of Fallout 4, and want to experience [strike] a better game [/strike] the previous installments of the franchise, this is a perfect game to start with. If you've never played a fallout game before, that's OK, because if you don't know anything about the lore, this game will help you out to become more accustomed to the franchise. Fallout New Vegas also includes a wonderful story with social commentary like all of the Fallout titles, Excellent characters that feel more real than most games, a stellar cast, great and memorable factions, and an ending plus DLC that will leave you craving more. I would recommend a couple of stability mods as outlined in the Viva New Vegas guide, however you can enjoy the game without them, especially on platforms that don't support mods, like consoles.

author: {'steamid': '76561199129038107', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4073, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 152, 'playtime_at_review': 3794, 'last_played': 1736731799}
review: Best Fallout game to date but is unplayable on modern machines. Goggle Viva New Vegas and follow it step by step to able to have an enjoyable experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198161157355', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 15142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15142, 'last_played': 1705519178}
review:
I could write an entire essay on how much I love this game.

In my opinion, it’s the best first/third-person RPG ever made, and I’ve played my fair share of RPGs. This game doesn't just meet industry standards, it surpasses them in every possible way. The writing is sharp, the characters are unforgettable, and the main and side quests are woven with such depth that it feels like every choice truly matters. The music and atmosphere immerse you in a post-apocalyptic world like no other, and the dark humor brings a unique charm that never gets old.

Playing through New Vegas is always a wild and deeply rewarding journey, no matter how many times I return to it. Even now, 14 years after its release, no similar game has come close to topping it, and I genuinely don't think anything will in the foreseeable future.

There’s a reason this game is revered by the gaming community. It’s a masterpiece that has stood the test of time, and for good reason.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198066226226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 20280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12286, 'last_played': 1715702834}
