Trailer gives me hope but nowadays being optimistic or realistic is the way to go to not have your hopes crushed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046602411', 'num_games_owned': 403, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 11778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11778, 'last_played': 1718365659}
review:
This game is really fun if you focus specifically on the main quest and side quests. The fun lies within the sometimes humorously authentic portrayal of medieval bohemia. Even the things we see as weird or barbaric these days are portrayed. For example at the Monastery in the game they poop on the second floor toilets, and you can look through the toilet to see some trees below. Wouldn't want to be the gardener there. (You can even see some nasty stains along the walls below it outside.)

Focus only on the actual quests and levelling up skills and stats. Other than that the game isn't that great. Avoid wandering around looking for cool stuff in the open world. You won't find much ever. If you must look up where the treasure chests are...there aren't many to be found. However their rewards are actually quite good. Although the combat is jank and not all that fun if you have a powerful setup you can usually just pummel your way through things. Then you can get to the quests which are amusing and fun to do.

It's fun to kit yourself out with armor and medieval gear, then go out and help some peasants with their issues. I remember one quest where part of the quest was a lady putting up a stone cross as a penance for something bad she did in the past. It showed two dudes setting up the small cross as if it was the most impressive thing ever with triumphant music. It was just a basic stone cross. But to them it WAS impressive. This is the kind of amusingly authentic stuff in the game.

I particularly like the potion system as the potions aren't too hard to buy or make but have rather useful effects. Such as seeing better at night, allowing you to pick harder locks or get past difficult speech checks early...pretty much any application if you get the right potion it can help.

One thing I found really amusing was that when trying to get the "don't kill anyone in an entire playthrough" achievement, you can still kill people by running over them with a horse. In some cases, not killing a person makes a quest really really annoying to finish, such as the monastery quest. Instead, I choked the person out, carried their body to a road while they were unconscious, and ran over them with a horse a couple of times at a full gallop. This was a really funny concept to me, that "my horse killed him" rather than I did, so no one accused me of murder, and the achievement still unlocked at the end of the game. If I ever got to some point in the game where I got fed up and wanted someone out of the picture to speed things up...they got hauled to the old horse trampling road. 

Later on in the same "don't kill anyone" playthrough, soldiers witnessed the horror of I, a knight in shining armor jumping over the battlements of a castle and punching everyone up there to smithereens without a weapon. Soon everyone on the battlements was unconscious. Now that the knight's friends had arrived, they waited around 5 minutes standing there politely for the enemies to wake up from being unconscious only to immediately bonk them with a mace, killing them.

Gripes:
-The "Open world" is largely pointless. There is very little to discover by going out into the wilderness. A couple of treasure chests with useful gear, but 99% of the stuff in the wilderness is an "interesting site" with nothing of interest there. Just a long unused campfire usually. Or a literal pile of rocks. Or a broken wagon with a pair of pants in it. Or something stupid like that. Why even mark these on the map? There's literally nothing there. Oh - it's because open world games thrive on checklists and the facade that they have a lot to do in the game, whereas they actually just have a normal amount of content spread out massively in a bunch of empty nothingness. You know how much better this game would seem if it just focused on quests rather than pretending wandering empty forests was worthwhile?
-Enemies can fight like Maximus Decimus Meridius in a pitch black night with no torch whereas the player literally cannot see a single thing making it impossible to fight until you yourself take a torch out (which leaves you without a shield). For a game trying its damndest to be realistic this is super unrealistic that enemies can fight just as well with no light whatsoever. If you use a Nighthawk potion, things are easier. I realized that later.
-Game takes like 2 minutes to start up. Majorly slow in that regard. Even modding away the intro videos, it still takes a long time to start.
-Rattay, Uzhitz, and Talmberg run at like 30-50 fps on ultra with my 4070 ti. Wtf, how is this that unoptimized, this game has graphics straight out of like the early 2010s. Dunno how it is that demanding.
-Enemies constantly perform master strikes, making normal combat take forever. Somehow, standing right in front of the enemy in full armor and drawing your bow while taking hits to shoot an arrow point blank at their head is the fastest way of finishing fights. I feel this isn't well designed.
-The item list constantly changes sorting while you sell items for items with the same name, leading to you accidentally selling the wrong one. Very annoying.
-Although the soundtrack while exploring and playing is great, the tracks are a bit too short and there aren't enough of them. Some more variance and expansion to each track would be perfect.
-The game forces you to do Sir Hans Capon's Amorous Adventures DLC right at the end of the game to finish the game if you haven't yet. This DLC has very little to do with the story, so it seems like the devs just wanted to annoy players trying to finish the game on hardcore mode by adding *just one more thing* to do. I already did it, and so did everyone trying to finish the game repeatedly...stop with this nonsense.
-The game crashes somewhat often. I had it crash around 10 times in 200 hours of playing. I would heavily recommend playing with "save whenever" mod because having save restrictions on a game that can crash is a major aggravation.

author: {'steamid': '76561199700499218', 'num_games_owned': 123, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 86, 'playtime_at_review': 2173, 'last_played': 1736466143}
review: This is hands down one of the most immersive games I’ve ever played. The historical accuracy and the challenging, rewarding combat pulled me right into 1403 Bohemia. I found the story so captivating that I got super invested in the characters and their development. The landscapes are absolute visual masterpieces, and I often lost track of time just wandering around and soaking it all in. The save system can be a bit clunky, but it makes every decision feel significant. The learning curve is tough, but mastering it is seriously satisfying. This game is definitely on my top 10 favorite games list! What really sets it apart is how it forces me to think strategically with every encounter, delivering a level of realism that most RPGs just can’t match. I tried using cheats at first, but it totally took away the thrill, so I ended up replaying the whole game to earn my victories the right way. Trust me, skip the cheats. Playing it as intended is an emotional and immersive journey. Huge shoutout to Warhorse for crafting such a detailed and engaging world. It's clear they put their heart and soul into this project. I can't wait to see what Warhorse has in store for Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2, and I’ll be pre-ordering it soon!

author: {'steamid': '76561198103228178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 10322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5984, 'last_played': 1729462242}
review: Wonderful game, very authentic to the era and, though present here and there, is not riddled with modernisms and performative morality like most games of its type. Would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098171489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 15299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15299, 'last_played': 1712977219}
review:
A game like few others. I loved it.

First thing to notice is the difficulty, because you can be easily punished for doing things you "should" not do in reality, and the combat is a little hard to master, and even on late game I could get killed at any time.

But the beauty on this game for me is the setting: Medieval Europe game presented like few others. I learned a lot about the era and how it was to live in those times.
How the world was, with all the difficulties and beauty of the nature.

Besides, the RPG system is interesting, with a lot of things to do and level up. Combat, Archery, Alchemy, Thiefing, Horseriding, Stealth...
I wish there were more games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123889108', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1862, 'last_played': 1695479144}
review: One of the most immersive RPGs i have ever played. Best of all its all based on history with no magic involved! Going from peasant to hero is done really well in KCD and the progress of your character is well earned. KCD 2 is to be realesed at the end of this year so now is as good time as ever to try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087361953', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 8678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8678, 'last_played': 1602175298}
review:
Kingdom in fact did Come and Delivered... a bit of a mess.

Story wasn't anything special, liked the characters, liked the quests, loved sidequests the most, I enjoyed exploring the world and the setting was awesome, liked the feeling of the progression system from level 1 crook to level 100 boss. I do not like the endings that do not end anything except the game, but since the sequel is around the corner I think I can overlook that.

I'm a fan of making the games feel more realistic from the gameplay perspective to the point it almost feels like a simulator, e.g. blacksmith learning how to read, but I'm not a fan of the fighting system that takes the mind of quantum physicist to merely comprehend it and a skill of Lü Bu to simply use it. And don't even get me started on alchemy system in this game.

Performance is a problem at some places, especially in "big" cities, FPS drop like crazy.

Overall pretty decent game if you can handle the suffering of certain gameplay mechanics, the world really was worth it. Not sure if I would ever give it another go tho.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046369222', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4312, 'last_played': 1643173278}
review:
Jesus Christ be Praised!

Hands down one of, if not, the best game I have ever played. Blends the realism extremely well with game play. Making it a struggle to even just survive, but at the same time, incredibly fun to work on making Henry a viable person in society. Probably the only game I bought for both PS4 and PC, and played them both extensively. I am coming back here now, because KCD2 was just announced, and I cannot be happier. I am  a huge history buff, and this scratches that itch so well. What an astonishingly made game, with a wonderful, passionate and knowledgeable team behind it. 100% recommend this to everyone I meet. You will never have so much fun trying to read or being a monk, ever.

Pick up this game or the Cumans will come and burn your village.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102892441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 8941, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8941, 'last_played': 1709951685}
review:
Well, took my 149 hours over more than a year but I finally finished it and all the DLC. 

It's definitely one of the best games of recent times, but "best" is a very subjective term here. I spent the first dozen or so hours really struggling to enjoy it and just wanted to get it over with quickly. It's got a complicated combat system that feels great when your skills are high, you have good equipment, and you know how to use it. But that's not anywhere near where you are at the start of the game. Instead you're faced with a lot of text boxes and tutorials. 

BUT, by the end, it feels you've made friends with many of the characters. Many of them are so memorable. Henry feels like he has really grown as a person. I was so attached to my horse by the end, and had a really melancholy final ride off the map listening to the beautiful game music as I rode off the map. I really want to visit this area in Bohemia and see these places with my own eyes because I feel like I've lived there and known it for so long. And as someone who likes learning about the medieval world, it's so beautifully crafted. I spent way more time than is probably reasonable just looking at the buildings and the town layouts and feeling like I had been transported in time. 

Good game. Would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198840428132', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 9, 'playtime_at_review': 3429, 'last_played': 1735841768}
review:
This game is just incredible. It caught my eye because of recommendations from people highlighting it as a very historically accurate game, aiming to transport you to the Middle Ages like a time machine. This is exactly what I felt while playing it.

On the other hand, I must confess that the difficulty made me drop the game on my first try. Fortunately, after seeing the KCD2 trailers, I was inspired to try again. This time, I played with mods to make the game more casual and easier than it was originally designed. As a result, I really enjoyed the game, environment, and history, which, for me, are the main attractions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119194182', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7238, 'last_played': 1716875763}
review:
This game is undoubtedly one of the best RPGs out there, offering an amazing experience of medieval Bohemia and remaining incredibly immersive even after 100 hours of gameplay. 

A couple of notes about this game that I don't see often in other reviews:

-While the game is known for its well-written main plot and side quests, I believe more commendation should be given to the "stories" you can discover throughout the greater world just by exploring your surroundings. For example, I accidentally fell halfway down a giant cliff between two major settlements, breaking both of my legs and nearly dying, only to find the dead body of a man who wasn't as lucky nearby. Another time, I followed a subtle trail that ended up with finding a very... disturbing scene in a barn. The world is massive, full of detail, and is absolutely worth exploring.

-The soundtrack (which took ~5000 hours to create) is also very impressive- the composers used only instruments that would be heard in this time period, avoided elements that would be too modern, and even composed their own Gregorian chants based on period music. AND it's catchy- I've had KCD music stuck in my head for over a week now.

-I see a lot of complaints about the combat system, but people are missing the point. The combat in this game is a little more realistic than in other games. You need to train yourself to use weapons effectively, or you won't be any good in combat. In the same vein, when fighting solo, you can likely defeat one opponent, but taking on three or more will probably not end well for you, even if you're well-trained and they're farmers or low-level bandits. It's just how it is.

-The game is buggy at times, but the game is so good that it doesn't even matter.

It's clear a ton of love went into this game, and I wish I could play it for the first time again. Can't wait for KCD2!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049249961', 'num_games_owned': 428, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 9442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9442, 'last_played': 1666204345}
review:
[b]98/100[/b]

[b]The Good[/b]
One of the best single player games I've ever played. You get sucked in by the story, you grow affectionate of the characters, you feel motivated to get stronger, richer and wiser. It's historically accurate, the quests are very creative and engaging. No matter what kind of gamer you are, YOU SHOULD PLAY THIS GAME. The DLCs are good, by the way.

[b]The Bad[/b]
I wish the game was longer. Not because it is shorter than a game should be, but only so I could play this masterpiece a little bit more. 

[b]The Ugly[/b]
It ends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198387818152', 'num_games_owned': 83, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 693, 'last_played': 1713902591}
review:
A Masterpiece of Historical Immersion

"Kingdom Come: Deliverance" isn't just a game; it's a portal to another time, another world. From the moment you step into the shoes of Henry, a humble blacksmith's son thrust into the chaos of medieval Bohemia, you're transported to a meticulously crafted realm teeming with life, intrigue, and danger.

One of the most striking aspects of "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" is its unwavering commitment to historical accuracy. Every cobblestone, every blade of grass, every nuance of speech feels authentic, pulling you deeper into the heart of 15th-century Europe. The attention to detail is nothing short of breathtaking, from the architecture of bustling towns to the intricate designs of armor and weaponry.

But "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" isn't just a pretty facade; it's a rich and immersive RPG experience that puts player choice front and center. Whether you're engaging in heart-pounding sword fights, navigating delicate political alliances, or simply trying to survive in a harsh and unforgiving world, every decision you make has real consequences. Your actions shape not only the fate of Henry but also the destiny of the entire kingdom.

The depth of storytelling in "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" is truly remarkable. As Henry, you'll encounter a diverse cast of characters, each with their own motivations and agendas. Whether you're rubbing shoulders with nobles in grand castles or mingling with peasants in bustling marketplaces, every interaction feels meaningful and authentic, adding layers of depth to an already immersive world.

Of course, no medieval epic would be complete without epic battles, and "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" delivers in spades. Combat is visceral and intense, requiring skill and strategy to emerge victorious. Whether you're wielding a sword, a bow, or your wits alone, every encounter is a test of your mettle, pushing you to become the hero Bohemia desperately needs.

In the end, "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" isn't just a game; it's an experience. It's a chance to step back in time and explore a world unlike any other, to immerse yourself in the sights, sounds, and struggles of a bygone era. With its stunning visuals, gripping storytelling, and unparalleled attention to detail, "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" stands as a true masterpiece of historical gaming, a testament to the power of immersive storytelling in the digital age.

If you're a fan of RPGs, historical fiction, or simply great storytelling, do yourself a favor and experience "Kingdom Come: Deliverance." It's a journey you won't soon forget.

Rating: 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561199118438149', 'num_games_owned': 64, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1725217335}
review:
Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a breath of fresh air in the RPG genre, offering an incredibly immersive and authentic medieval experience unlike anything else. 
i make it pros and cons on this game

Pros:
-Super immersive medieval world with amazing attention to historical detail.
-Deep and engaging story with meaningful choices that impact the game.
-Realistic and challenging combat that feels rewarding once you get the hang of it.
-Beautiful open world with dynamic weather and a living, breathing environment.

Cons:
-Can be tough to learn at first; the combat and mechanics take some getting used to.
-Some bugs and glitches still exist, though they’ve improved over time.
-Pacing can feel slow for those used to more action-packed RPGs.

Overall, Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a must-play for anyone who loves a realistic, story-driven RPG experience. It's unique and totally worth the effort!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993298158', 'num_games_owned': 763, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 13256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13256, 'last_played': 1716652482}
review:
[h1]Ye Olde Gary Stu Simulatorre[/h1]
TL;DR: A slightly janky masterpiece. If you enjoy Elder Scrolls-like systems where you level skills by using them, and are interested by the idea of a medieval immersive sim where you can solve [b]most[/b] problems using different methods (i.e. brute strength, sneakiness, or charismatic speech), this game will probably delight you.[hr][/hr]
Somehow this game flew under the radar for me. I think I got it jumbled up with other medieval games that featured melee combat, or maybe the marketing just wasn't great. At any rate, I only became interested after watching Mortym's YouTube review. I got it and all the DLC for around $8, and wound up being so drawn in by it that I decided to 100% it, spending over 200 hours on it.
You play as Henry, a blacksmith's son who winds up being one of the few survivors of a military attack on his town. I don't want to spoil the plot, but the opening does a great job of putting you in the shoes of a hapless victim caught up in events far beyond the scope of his understanding. Over time this does get eroded a bit in order to let you feel like the protagonist in a story of escalating stakes, but it's effective all the same. While Henry starts off as a bit of an irresponsible kid, he matures over the course story, and grounding the experience with a likable POV character like this keeps the story more relatable than if you played a custom-made generic avatar. While I wouldn't argue that Henry's story is very realistic or typical to people of the time, it facilitates a game whose main goal is to let you explore and experience a somewhat realistic 1403 Bohemia.
Kingdom Come's gameplay is unique, but the closest experience I've had from a mechanical perspective is probably Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. It's a first-person RPG that focuses heavily on real-time melee combat, and you level skills (and their associated attributes) by using them. Personally I love games that rely on this kind of leveling system, having sunk hundreds of hours into the Quest for Glory series as a kid. Thankfully, KCD's similarity to Oblivion ends there; leveling up is intuitive, you simply choose perks as your skills and stats increase, and enemies aren't scaled arbitrarily. Combat feels visceral, large melees can be realistically chaotic, and even if you max out your stats you can still easily get killed by a mob of armed peasants. This can be a bit frustrating, but keeps you from ever feeling like an unstoppable killing machine. Other mechanics also work to keep things grounded in reality. Henry starts off illiterate, and books are scrambled messes until you learn to read. Alchemy has you physically flipping through recipes, manually grinding and boiling herbs depending on the directions. Archery does not feature a reticle of any kind, and you must rely on practice to learn how to line up your shots. Not every system feels great, but the whole is a satisfying experience that feels fresh, if not perfectly polished.
This being a Kickstarter-funded game and the inaugural title from a new studio, I am surprised by how well-made it is. That being said, there is a fair amount of jank left here even six years after its initial release. The opening story doesn't adequately tutorialize the skills you'll need to survive the next mission, and the game doesn't doesn't let you know how you could have done things better when you inevitably fail, which makes for a frustrating first impression that I'm sure will put a fair number of players off. While there are a lot of great sidequests that let you solve problems in different ways, some are frustratingly single-solution and can break to one degree or another if you try to get too creative. There are plenty of bugs, and while I didn't find any that were completely game-breaking, they were certainly immersion-breaking and often very frustrating. I wish that the devs had left a small team working on this gem to get rid of these rough edges after release.
To briefly discuss the DLC, I would absolutely recommend picking it all up as a package, especially if you catch the game on sale. The base game is fairly bursting with great content, and the DLC is integrated seamlessly into the experience. While not everything is among the best the game has to offer (I personally didn't care for Theresa's POV quest), most of it is top-notch and features rewards that are useful without being game breaking.
As I did decide to complete them, I'd like to give a quick overview of the achievements. For the most part they're fine, but I would've preferred if they'd avoided achievements that are most realistically obtained through save-scumming, which is something that the very mechanics of the game discourage. This means that there are a few that require you to see both exclusive outcomes of decisions, especially in the DLC. Sure, you [b]could[/b] do it differently on a subsequent playthrough, but realistically it's not worth running entire optional quest lines again when you can just save before making a decision then load it back up to see both options. Also, there is a no-kill achievement that is Just Not Fun™. It makes things a little more challenging in some ways, but it winds up locking you out of entire quest lines, and even the main story becomes a real drag, forcing you to rely on NPC allies to do your dirty work while you try to distract enemies. If the game were designed to let you find non-lethal solutions to every quest this would be a great roleplaying encouragement, but it simply isn't and the experience suffers for it.
In the end, I absolutely vibed with Kingdom Come. The open world is beautiful and fun to explore, without pointless collection-fests or excessive fetch quests. There's a massive amount of bespoke optional content to tackle at your own pace, leveling skills feels organic and rewarding, and there are a few points where you can make choices that help shape Henry as a character. I wouldn't recommend this game to everyone due to its rough edges and somewhat niche design choices, but if it sounds even a little intriguing to you, I absolutely recommend giving it a try. I had a blast, and now I'm eagerly looking forward to another sequel I didn't care about at all at the beginning of the year. I just hope this one works out better than Dragon's Dogma II.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097028353', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 5592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5592, 'last_played': 1716235234}
review: Great game with well written characters and story. The attention to detail really shows the developers passion and creativity. Overall really great experience with some lacking aspects. The game can be slow and tedious at times. The attention to realism can be a detriment to the players time.  The combat is just not there. It is okay for 1v1 engagements but awful for anything else.  I have high hopes for the sequel and definitely will be playing it but i hope they overhaul the combat and keep the games pacing engaging. Even with all the games shortcomings i really liked it.  With the issues of the first addressed the second will be something really special.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970368852', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5703, 'last_played': 1717378977}
review:
Pros:
- Cool grounded setting based on real history.
- None of the usual cliche fantasy rpg tropes. Great story and quest design.
- RPG elements. Start off as a unskilled peasant and progress from there.
- Improve at things by doing them. Not the typical experience and leveling mechanics.
- Fun combat system overall.
- Runs really well on older hardware.

Cons:
- In combat there are some ways to perform unblockable attacks which enemies can do to you as well. This makes it quite difficult to land the combos, especially the 4 hit combos, without being interrupted.
- The combat "lock on" to target game mechanic can really work against you when fighting groups of enemies. It is more suited to 1v1 fights.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089331504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 446, 'playtime_at_review': 5168, 'last_played': 1736697727}
review:
This game is an absolute joy for every medieval history lover.
I am mostly taken away by developer´s approach towards the game world, starting with a map, scenery, towns and villages and ending with every in-game item, inside of houses, clothing, etc.
All you can see in-game is based of historical reality of year 1403 in Bohemia (which is my homeland).
Of course this can not be applied on the potions and their effects, but otherwise it is perfect.

I appreciate the amount of work and details which bring the player into this exact time and place in the heart of Europe.
I got back to this game after few years, just with a better GPU than before and game currently works very well, only had one crash because of the ladder.

I can not wait for KCD II to release!
May the God be with you all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198826182120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 14990, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14990, 'last_played': 1701374994}
review:
Kingdom Come: Deliverance, developed by Warhorse Studios, is a medieval role-playing game that offers a unique and immersive experience. The game excels in historical accuracy, bringing the 15th-century Bohemian landscape to life with meticulous attention to detail. The realistic combat system, grounded storyline, and sprawling open-world contribute to the game's authenticity.

One of the game's notable strengths is its commitment to historical realism. From the architecture to the clothing, Kingdom Come: Deliverance captures the essence of medieval Europe, providing players with a captivating journey through a bygone era. The emphasis on realism extends to the gameplay, with a complex combat system that requires strategic thinking and skill development.

However, the game is not without its flaws. Some players have criticized the occasional bugs and technical issues that can detract from the overall experience. Additionally, the steep learning curve of the combat system may pose a challenge for newcomers to the genre.

Looking ahead, there's optimism for the potential of a sequel or future installments in the Kingdom Come series. With advancements in technology and the lessons learned from the first game, there's anticipation for even greater historical accuracy, improved gameplay mechanics, and a more polished overall experience. The foundation laid by Kingdom Come: Deliverance provides a solid base for the developers to build upon, and the potential for future installments to address and refine the current shortcomings is exciting.

In conclusion, Kingdom Come: Deliverance offers a unique and ambitious take on medieval role-playing, immersing players in a rich historical setting. While acknowledging its imperfections, the game sets the stage for a promising future, and fans can eagerly anticipate the evolution and refinement of the series in upcoming releases.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081790656', 'num_games_owned': 390, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 5493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5493, 'last_played': 1718877700}
review:
To start positively, it's one of the best games I have played. I do strongly recommend playing it. Consistent art direction, bold game mechanic choices, masterfully written story line (with some exceptions, of which I will write below), good dialogues and voicing over, all that and more is about Kingdom Come: Deliverance.

But, and that is a heavy but, there is approximately a 10-hour part of the game, right before the finale, when the pace slogs, the narrative is shattered with [spoiler]the long and boring siege preparation[/spoiler] quest, and even the writing and cut scene direction quality drops. And all for the content that's not only unnecessary but that actively breaks the flow of the story.

That said, it is still a charming game, very immersive and life-like, and I won't let my recency bias ruin the experience I had in the first 2/3rds.

P.S. A couple of words on the swordfighting gameplay: although many complain about it being clunky and messy, it's pretty reflective of what real swordfighting feels like. You don't know what to do and as a novice, you have zero chances against an experienced opponent. Then you start learning, step by step, how to swing that piece of metal effectively. And still, you won't stand a chance against multiple or experienced opponents for a long time. 10/10 for that fighting gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081133824', 'num_games_owned': 179, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 5429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5246, 'last_played': 1719750511}
review:
It's awesome, but proceed with some caution. The game tries to be extremely realistic, but... realism isn't always fun, hence why we play games. For example, at the start your character will be terrible with a sword so you need to practice. But to get it to an acceptable level you need to do this for like an hour or two after the prologue, while you'd probably much rather just continue with the story.

However, once you get past that initial beginner hurdle you are in for a nice treat. A decently sized world with a overarching story and plenty other things to discover. Fully voice acted with some nice moments, especially when Hans Capon is involved. Quests can often be completed in many different ways, so you can play the way you prefer. It might not be the most polished RPG around, but it certainly has its charm. Looking forward to the sequel they announced a while ago.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080536050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1725636065}
review: this game is good on so many lvls.....it isnt for everyone but for fans of RPGs like Oblivion, and Gothic 2, ect then your going to love this...its a very raw sort of fun with just a tad bit of janky....P.S it has the best potion making I have seen in any game to date...like that should have been how potion making felt in Hogwarts legacy

author: {'steamid': '76561198867124556', 'num_games_owned': 1349, 'num_reviews': 396, 'playtime_forever': 2388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2301, 'last_played': 1734484179}
review:
The best and the most realistc medieval RPG period. This game prioritise realism. Unlike other RPG, you cannot wipe out an entire gang of enemy alone cause trust me I tried lol And I am not going to sugarcoat this, the main problem of this game is the combat is janky af! I hope they'll fix this in the next game. Another thing that I disliked about this game is whenever you want to save the game (before doing something stupid/dangerous), you need a special potion to that. It's annoying me.

KCD is such a slowburn that I don't think it's for everyone. I almost gave up but I keep pushing myself believing it'll get good, and boy it did! It got me hooked and I am so glad I gave this game a chance. It is unlike any other medieval RPG that I had experience! Seriously one of the best in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211724327', 'num_games_owned': 266, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1718301115}
review:
>be me, son of a blacksmith
>saw parents and my girlfriend get murdered in front of my face
>run away and join a lord as a foot soldier
>get assigned to a murder investigation
>ride to this big ass village
>have to find out what happened to a dead suspect
>finds the priest who spoke to him last
>go on a mad drinking binge with said priest, being dragged into a bar fight with the town guards, ringing the bell in the bell tower at 2 am for no reason, and having an orgy with said priest
>wake up groggy and hungover
>have to help said priest deliver mass by improvising a sermon because he got too shitfaced

this game was worth every penny 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198067137066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 2980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2980, 'last_played': 1724383476}
review:
I haven't played any big RPGs in ages and always thought I couldn't really get into them anymore. This game proved me wrong, the combat at the start was brutal and I did not like it but now I am at a point where I search for conflicts on purpose so I can fight people, it's so much fun. You really grow with your character.
Played with some mods that allowed me to save at any time and some other small QoL stuff. I highly rec you do that, if something bothers you, there is prolly a fix for it.
Game is on sale for super cheap often, can't go wrong.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092561266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 6687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5146, 'last_played': 1735045779}
review:
This game is practically perfect.
The only flaws I can think of are to do with the physics of the game, which is minor, and fighting more than 2 or 3 people at once. Multiple opponents can lock you into a loop of constant clinching and it can be difficult to switch between targets in the middle of combat. Duels are challenging and a lot of fun though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993026869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1725139164}
review: The RPG element of the game is great and the story just playing a few hour in is very good and the environment is so beautiful to explore in, the combat is not for everyone but for me i like the slow pace of the strategic way of beating your foes once you understand how to do the chain attack combo your set. for under 5$ on sale it's a must have for RPG players.

author: {'steamid': '76561199365364289', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 17547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 10375, 'last_played': 1736672626}
review:
best rpg game i have played, its a game that breaks the norms, some people like it and some dont. its not just an rpg but a medieval simulator too which can be very unforgiving but if you manage to immerse yourself in this game then nothing can beat it.

cant wait for the sequel
